DOC.HEADLINE: FAMOUS KUNGFU NOVELIST TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Louis Cha, a famous contemporary Chinese adventure or kungfu novelist based in Hong Kong, will arrive in Taiwan Thursday for a visit and book signing.

Cha, better known by his pen name Jinyong, the author of many martial arts novels which have earned great popularity in Chinese-speaking world, will pay a visit to his thesis instructor David McMullen, who is now doing research on Tang dynasty history at Academia Sinica, the most prestigeous research institute in Taiwan.
During his stay in Taiwan, Jinyong will also autograph for fans at Yuan-Liou Publishing Co.'s booth at the ongoing 15th Taipei International Book Exhibition at 11 a.m. Feb. 2.

Jinyong was granted an honorary doctoral degree by the University of Cambridge in 2005, but remains a humble student. He has earned a M.A. degree at that university and aims to achieve a doctoral degree on his own academic merit.
The National Chengchi University is scheduled to confer an honorary doctoral degree on Jinyong in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOFTBALL OLYMPIC QUALIFYING SERIES OPENS IN TAINAN FEB. 1
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Jan. 31 (CNA) 02/01/07 10:40:02 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Asia-Oceania Women's Softball Olympic Qualifying Series will begin Thursday at a softball field in Tainan's Hoshunliao Sports Park and continue until Feb. 7.
Six national teams from North Korea, South Korea, Singapore, New Zealand, the Philippines and Taiwan will compete in 33 matches for the chance to realize their Olympic dreams in Beijing in 2008.

They will fight it out in a double round robin with the top two teams going on to contest a best of three finals series. Victory in the finals brings with it an opportunity to go to the 2008 Olympics.
A tough match is expected when Taiwan's team, known as "Chinese Taipei," confronts the White Sox team of New Zealand on the first day of the series.
The Chinese Taipei Amateur Softball Association played host at a dinner to welcome the teams from abroad Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP UNDECIDED OVER BLUE-FREE POLLING

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) leadership Wednesday reached a preliminary consensus on adopting strict measures to exclude the opinions of non-supporters from the process to nominate candidates for at-large legislators in the year-end election, party officials said.

The DPP Central Standing Committee Wednesday discussed the recently heatedblue- voter-exclusionissue. However, no resolution was reached that day and controversy still flies over whether the measure should be applied to primaries for constituency legislator and presidential elections, party officials said.

The DPP has a primary system which takes into account both opinion polls involving general citizens and voting by party members, with the former weighted 70 percent and the latter 30 percent. Concerned about the influence of opposition-leaning voters on the polls that will determine who represents the party in elections for presidential and legislative seats, the party last year adopted a measure to limit the number of effective samples in telephone polls.

According to the measure scheduled to be enacted in the legislative election at the end of the year, two questions are to be added to the questionnaire. The first asks which political camp the interviewee favors -- thepan-greencamp led by the DPP, or its opponentpan-bluealliance. Awrong answerto this question will result in the questionnaire being discarded if the person surveyed then answersNoto the following question: Would you, however, vote for a DPP candidate this time if you believe he or she is a good candidate?

Not satisfied by the previous policy designed to exclude only deep bluevoters - namely diehard supporters of the blue camp, DPP lawmakers Chai Trong-rong and Wang Shih-cheng recently initiated a proposal to exclude moreblue votersfrom being counted in the nomination polls.

The stricter version requires that the interviewees be asked whether they have voted for candidates of the Kuomintang, the People First Party, or the New Party in any of the pass three major elections: the 2004 presidential election, the legislative election that year, and the 2005 county-level commissioner elections or the 2006 Taipei and Kaohsiung City mayoral elections, depending on the respondent's constituency. A singleyeswould void the questionnaire.

Proponents of the stricter version argue that it would enhance members' loyalty to the party and strengthen solidarity within the party, while opponents say it would distract centrist voters and make the party more inward-looking and narrow-minded.

Chai Trong-rong said Wednesday that the current system is unfair in that DPP politicians who attack the party or President Chen Shui-bian enjoy higher popularity ratings than those who defend the party and Chen.

Those who are loyal to the party are unlikely to win support from blue voters in the polling, he said.Lawmakers in the party will be eager to attack President Chen if only to boost their polling numbers should the blue-exclusion clauses not be established.
Wang Shih-cheng had said he would withdraw from the party and run as an independent candidate in the year-end election if the party fails to adopt the strict blue-exclusion clauses.

Yang Chiu-Hsing, Kaohsiung County Commissioner and a member of the DPP's central standing committee, said the that an exclusion of deep blue voters is enough andlight blueas well as swing voters should be included.

As the year-end election will be the first under the single member constituency system, in which each constituency elects only one lawmaker, the DPP will need to attract more middle-of-the-road voters who has no strong party ties and tend to choose from among the candidates, not according to party linesYang said, responding to media queries before the committee meeting Wednesday.
Lin Cho-Shui, a DPP figure who quit his legislative seat in protest last November over the party's inaction on corruption scandals, called the strict blue-exclusion pollingridiculous.

He said the DPP should be confident in its current course as the trend in recent years has shown greater numbers of ballots cast for the party, adding that strict exclusion will only lead to a shrinking of the party's base.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CONSENSUS REACHED ON EXPANSION OF CHARTER FLIGHTS: MAC

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait have reached a consensus on expanding direct cross-strait charter flight services and allowing Chinese citizens to take such flights, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Wednesday.

The official made the remarks after a Beijing official in charge of Taiwan affairs said earlier in the day that "all technical barriers" have been removed to offering direct cross-strait passenger flights on a regular basis.

According to the MAC official, representatives from the two sides have indeed met recently to discuss both how to make cross-strait personnel and cargo transport more convenient and the feasibility of expanding charter flights. "Initial consensus has been achieved after extensive discussion," he acknowledged.

On pasenger flights, the two sides discussed how to expand the service target. At present, only Taiwanese citizens are eligible to take direct cross-strait charter flights on special festivals or for emergency or humanitarian purposes.
As Taiwan is determined to open its door to Chinese tourists, the official said, the government is not opposed to expanding the charter flight service targets to Chinese tourists.

As to the frequency of direct cross-strait character flights, the official said the two sides have also reached a preliminary consensus, but he didn't elaborate on the exact number of the flights to be allowed per week or the time intervals.

While the two sides have agreed on allowing Chinese tourists to take direct cross-strait charter flights, the official said they have not yet completed talks on details regarding entry of Chinese tourists.

Noting that charter flights and opening to Chinese tourists are being dealt with by different government departments, the official said the goal of allowing Chinese tourists to come to Taiwan via direct charter flights will become a reality when negotiations on both topics are completed.
According to the officials, personnel from both sides are expected to meet again before the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 18, in the hope of finalizing talks on certain contentious points.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 1, or the 14th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1650: Rene Descartes, French mathematician and philosopher known as the "father of French philosophy," dies at the age of 54. His philosophy is based on the rationalistic premise: "I think, therefore I am."
1893: Thomas Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, opens the first film studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
1901: Clark Gable, American film actor who became an international heart throb, is born. He played Rhett Butler in "Gone With the Wind."
1902: The Ching dynasty orders the lifting of a ban on marriages between the Manchus and the Chinese.
1913: The first Far Eastern Games are held in Manila, the Philippines, with athletes from the Republic of China, Japan and the host country attending.
1924: Britain recognizes the Communist government of the Soviet Union.
1948: The Bank of Taiwan issues a new edition of the 100-dollar bill.
1950: Deputies of the National Assembly respectfully invite Chiang Kai-shek to succeed acting President Lee Tsung-jen as the president of the Republic of China. Lee remained in the United States following the Nationalist government's retreat to Taiwan after being defeated by the Communists in China's civil war.
1951: The U.N. General Assembly condemns the Chinese Communists as aggressors in Korea.
1952: The U.N. General Assembly finds the Soviet Union guilty of violating the 1945 Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1958: The first U.S. satellite, the Vanguard-1, is successfully launched into orbit.
1963: Taiwan's `king of iron and steel' Tang Jung dies at the age of 83.
1967: President Chiang Kai-shek establishes the National Security Council. Vice Premier Huang Shao-ku is named secretary-general of the organization and Ku Shu- tung is named deputy secretary-general.
1973: One hundred and four members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan, 20 mayors and magistrates and the 73 members of the fifth Taiwan Provincial Assembly are sworn in.
1974: An economic mission headed by Economic Affairs Vice Minister Chang Kwang- shih leaves for Saudi Arabia for a five-day visit.
1978: The Central Daily News, the oldest newspaper in the country, marks its 50th anniversary.
1979: Iranian religious leader the Ayatollah Khomeini ends 16 years of exile, returning from Paris to a frenzied welcome at Tehran airport.
1980: Taiwan's North Link (Suao-Hualien) Railway is opened with ceremonies in Nanshenghu, near Ilan, and Hualien. The project cost the government NT$7.3 billion and took six years to complete.
1982: Alfred Britain III, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, opens the bank's branch office in Taipei.
1990: South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the legitimacy of the African National Congress and other political organizations. He also promises the unconditional release of jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela within two weeks.
1991: An earthquake rocks Pakistan and Afghanistan, killing more than 1,200 people.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin sign the Camp David declaration stating that their two countries no longer regard each other as adversaries.
1995: Communist Vietnam and the United States begin a new chapter in their relationship by opening liaison offices in each others' capitals.
1995: The World Trade Organization passes a resolution to accept the Republic of China as an observer country.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew presides over a ceremony to unveil the name plaque of the newly established Coast Guard Administration and swear in CGA Director- General Yao Kao-chiao.
2001: Nobel laureate Gao Xingjian, at the invitation of the Taipei City Government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, arrives in Taiwan from Hong Kong.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In my method of teaching, I always wait for my student to make an effort himself to find his way through a difficulty, before I show him the way myself. I also make him find his own illustrations before I give him one of my own. When I have pointed out the bearing of a subject in one direction and found that my student cannot himself see its bearings into other directions, I do not then repeat my lesson."

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON REAFFIRMS OBLIGATIONS TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 31 (CNA) 02/01/07 11:49:05 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department reiterated Wednesday that the Taiwan Relations Act remains one of the basic guidelines for U.S. policy on cross-Taiwan Strait ties and that the United States will fulfill its obligations towards Taiwan as defined in the law.

"It (the Taiwan Relations Act) still applies, and we still intend to live up to our obligations, " State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said during a daily press briefing, in response to a question on the issue.

Speaking of the U.S. policy on cross-strait relations during a Senate hearing Tuesday, John Negroponte, nominee for deputy secretary of state, said the United States supports a "one-China" policy and sticks to the three communiques with China but stopped short of mentioning the Taiwan Relations Act.
According to Negroponte, Taiwan's plan to enact a new constitution might conflict with the U.S. policy.

Asked if the State Department has tried to privately advise Taiwan to drop the plan, McCormack said: "We have made very clear what our policy is, and it's no different than what you have heard in public."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE CLARIFIES STANCE ON TAIWAN'S FUTURE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui has clarified his stance on Taiwan's development goal, saying Taiwan's urgent task lies in "normalization of its national identity " rather than independence.
Speaking in an interview with cable TV channel TVBS Wednesday, Lee claimed that he has never advocated de jure Taiwan independence because Taiwan is already an independent sovereign country.

"It's wrong to pursue independence now that Taiwan is already an independent country. But it is still not a normal country. Its constitution does not originate in Taiwan and is irrelevant to Taiwan's needs and situation," Lee explained.

He further said that what Taiwan needs most lies in making it a normal and complete country, with rectifying its name and writing a new constitution relevant to its unique circumstances and cultural and social context as its daunting challenges.
Lamenting that the country has become increasingly divided over the "independence versus unification" debate, Lee said it's unwise to waste time and energy on such a "false" issue.
"It will do no good and is in fact very detrimental to Taiwan, " Lee warned.

He further explained that since Taiwan is already democratized, with the people electing their own government and top leader, time need not be wasted on debating the issue of independence or unification.

Claiming that bickering over the issue in the past few years has impeded improvement of the people's livelihood, Lee said major domestic political parties should shift their focus from such senseless squabbles to more meaningful issues, such as economic development.

Lee also rebutted criticism that the discord over the country's future was fueled by his controversial definition of relations between Taiwan and China as a "special state-to-state" relationship near the end of his 12-year presidency.
The former president clarified that he has never characterized cross-Taiwan Strait relations as "one country on each side" of the strait nor has he advocated a so-called "two states" theory.
"What I have said is that cross-strait ties are a special state-to-state relationship. The word 'special' implies profound meaning," Lee said.

He argued that Taiwan differs from China in many ways. "For one thing, the two sides have different lifestyles. We in Taiwan can develop our own culture. We don't want ethnic rifts which would hinder social progress," he added.

In the interview, Lee also clarified his description of Taiwan's previous Kuomintang (KMT) government as an alien regime. "That was because the KMT government was not popularly elected. Under its authoritarian rule, people didn't enjoy freedom and political rights. But gone are those days. We now have freedom of speech, freedom of the press, freedom of assembly and freedom of expression as well as democracy, and we need not highlight the sins or injustices of that era anymore," he contended.
Lee further clarified a Next Magazine report which said that he intends to visit China. "The report is problematic and incorrect. I see no need for me to propose a visit to China," he said.

With China growing ever stronger economically and militarily, Lee said, Taiwan has much to do by using the platform provided by the World Trade Organization (WTO) which is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taiwan and China.

Noting that Taiwan's service industry has been hit hardest by the exodus of manufacturing companies and the flow of investment capital to China over the past decade, Lee said the government should craft a mechanism for capital to flow back to Taiwan from China.
"As far as the economy is concerned, nothing should be unilateral or a one-way track. Capital flow always needs a two-way track to facilitate balance," Lee said.
For this issue, Lee said, Taiwan must formulate a sound system and use the WTO as a conduit for constructive economic exchanges with China.

Asked about his views on Chinese President Hu Jintao, Lee refrained from making any comments. He instead said he sees differences between Hu and Hu's predecessor, Jiang Zemin, in their strategies toward Taiwan.

"When Taiwan held its first-ever direct presidential election in 1996 as a critical step toward democratization, Jiang ordered test-firing of missiles to intimidate Taiwanese voters and adopted other saber-rattling strategies against Taiwan. Such practices were not constructive, " he said, adding that cross- strait issues should be addressed with a moderate approach and that Taiwan itself should also think how to better deal with China with vision and foresight.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO HAVE 8 CONSTITUENCIES FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Taipei City will be divided into eight constituencies for the year-end legislative elections, according to the newly promulgated districting scheme.
After many twists and turns, the Central Election Commission (CEC) managed to secure 11th-hour compromises to complete electoral redistricting shortly before the legal deadline Wednesday.

Redistricting is necessary for the new Legislative Yuan elections because a new "single-member constituency, two vote" electoral system will be adopted and the number of legislative seats will be cut to 113 from 225 in line with a package of constitutional amendments passed in 2005.
According to the new districting blueprint, Taipei City's first constituency will cover the Peitou administrative district and 13 boroughs in the Shihlin district.

The second constituency will be comprised of Tatung district and 38 boroughs in the Shihlin district; the third constituency will include the Chungshan district and 20 boroughs in the Sungshan district.
The fourth constituency will encompass both the Neihu and Nankang administrative districts, while the fifth constituency will cover Wanhua district and 21 boroughs in the Chungcheng district.

The sixth constituency will cover the Taan administrative district, and the seventh constituency will contain the Hsinyi district and 13 boroughs in the Sungshan district, while the eighth constituency will incorporate the Wenshan district and 10 boroughs in the Chungcheng district.

Taipei was among the 10 cities and counties where electoral redistricting was not finalized until Wednesday. Six of them upheld the CEC-drafted redistricting plans, including Taipei City, while disputes over the remaining four were finally settled by way of lot drawing.
The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan approved the CEC-drafted redistricting designs for 15 cities and counties around the country before its winter session concluded Jan. 19.

As the next legislative elections could result in major changes in the domestic political landscape, major political parties are reluctant to surrender even the smallest advantage, making compromises difficult to reach.

After grueling negotiations between Premier Su Tseng-chang and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng in accordance with legal provisions, decisions were finally reached Wednesday evening that the CEC-drafted redistricting blueprints for six other cities and counties -- Taipei City, Taichung County, Taichung City, Tainan County, Changhua County and Miaoli County -- will also be upheld.

With Su and Wang's assent, redistricting designs for the remaining four -- Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Kaohsiung City and Pingtung County -- were determined by way of drawing lots based on versions presented by legislative caucuses of individual political parties or versions previously worked out by the legislature through consensus.

Among them, Kaohsiung City will take up the redistricting plan fleshed out through previous consensus; Taipei County will apply the blueprint initiated by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) ; Taoyuan County will embrace the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's proposal; and Pingtung County will adopt the version agreed upon by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) , the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) and the TSU.
The southern port city of Kaohsiung, which is the country's second largest city after Taipei, will be divided into five electoral constituencies, according to the new districting scheme.
Taipei County, the county's most populous administrative region, will be divided into 12 constituencies according to the TSU-drafted blueprint.

The northern county of Taoyuan will be subdivided into six constituencies according to the DPP-initiated plan, while the southernmost county of Pingtung will be divided into three constituencies based on the proposal agreed upon by the KMT, the PFP, the NPSU and the TSU.
Meanwhile, the central counties of Taichung and Changhua will be divided into five and four constituencies, respectively; and Tainan County and Taichung City will have three constituencies each.

Tainan City and the southern counties of Kaohsiung, Yunlin, Chiayi, Nantou and Miaoli will each have two constituencies, while the remaining seven counties -- Yilan, Hsinchu, Hualien, Taitung, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu -- and three cities, namely Hsinchu, Keelung and Chiayi, will each have one constituency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
FORMER PREMIER EXPRESSES CONFIDENCE IN POSSIBLE PRESIDENTIAL BID
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 31 (CNA) 02/01/07 14:08:48 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh expressed confidence Wednesday in his possible bid to run for the presidency in 2008.

Hsieh, who is in Washington D.C. to attend the National Prayer Breakfast on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, told Taiwan reporters that he is an outright optimist who has confidence in a lot of things, including his possible presidential bid.

However, Hsieh said he has no plan to discuss with the U.S. side his presidential visions during his current visit, because he has not officially become the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate.
Hsieh said he will meet with U.S. officials during the trip to discuss issues such as Taiwan's plan to reform its Constitution and the delayed arms procurement package from the United States.

Hsieh said it may be hard for foreigners to understand why Taiwan cannot place national security before partisan differences, but a lot of things are not under the government's control now that Taiwan is a democratic country.

Hsieh said the Cabinet has tried very hard but failed to have the legislature pass the budget for the arms procurement during the last legislative session and that he will try to explain the matter properly to the U.S. side.
During an interview with SET TV in Taipei Monday, Hsieh said he is seriously considering whether to run for the presidency in 2008 and when to announce his bid if he decides to do so.

Hsieh said he first needs to complete a tour of Taiwan's 23 counties and cities to assess his own ability to shoulder such a great responsibility and to evaluate his support among the people before making a decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSTALLED CAPACITY OF RENEWABLE ENERGY TO REACH 12% BY 2020: MOEA

TEXT.P: The government has made developing renewable energy an important policy and set a target of increasing the installed capacity of renewable energy in the country to 12 percent of total production by 2020, Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Thursday.

Chen said that although the development of renewable energy faces various challenges, such as high production costs and technological difficulties, the new policy will help Taiwan realize its goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and increasing the ratio of domestically-produced energy.
The policy could also revitalize unplanted farmland and boost the development of the biomass energy industry, Chen said.
Public buses in southern Kaohsiung City have started using biodiesel, and the government will select two more counties or cities in June to expand and promote the use of biodiesel, he said.
By 2008, all diesel sold on the market will be a blend containing 1 percent of biomass diesel, with the content of biomass diesel expected to increase to 3 percent by 2010, he said.

The minister made the remarks during a conference on the development of renewable energy held by National Central University's Research Center for Taiwan's Economic Development, the Grace T.H.W Group, and an economics association.

Sharing the experience of Brazil during the conference, Brazilian parliamentarian Luiss Piauhylino de Mello Monteiro said Brazil started to experiment with blending gasoline and ethanol in 1925, with the government offering incentives such as tax cuts and production loans.

According to Piauhylino, Brazil is now the world's largest producer and exporter of cane-based ethanol, the world's largest consumer of fuel ethanol and the world's third largest consumer of cane sugar.

Every year, Brazil produces 15 billion liters of ethanol, exports 19.6 million tons of cane sugar and 3.1 billion liters of ethanol, which generates 12 billion reais (US$5.66 billion) in annual revenue for the country, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 22 KILOS OF MARIJUANA IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: Police uncovered 22.8 kilos of compressed bricks of marijuana as well as several seeds and one kilo of ketamine in a search of the office of a freight company in Kinmen County Thursday, detaining a 34-year-old suspect identified as Chen Kuan-hau.

The police are still trying to track down the head of the drug ring, surnamed Chuang, who they said had smuggled marijuana bricks and ketamine from China into Kinmen several times, with the drugs later being transported to Kaohsiung. It has been reported that Chuang is now in China.
Chen, who has a criminal record for burglary and amphetamine use, is suspected of being responsible for transporting the smuggled drugs from Kinmen to Kaohsiung.

The police said they believe that the drug ring smuggled their goods via the ferry service between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou, adding that they are currently investigating how the smugglers passed through the security checks in those cities.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.26 percent, followed by cement shares at 0.54 percent, construction stocks at 0.43 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.39 percent, and machinery and electronic shares at 0.21 percent.

The new legislation is expected to give legal recognition of unmarried and gay couples.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIR QUALITY WORSENS AS COLD FRONT ARRIVES

TEXT.P: Air quality around Taiwan noticeably worsened Thursday owing to pollution carried to the island by a cold front, Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) officials said.
According to the EPA, most of the pollutants recently arriving in Taiwan with cold fronts are the result of industrial wastes produced by factories in China's coastal areas.

Monitoring conducted by the EPA Thursday morning showed that the hourly concentration of particulate matter, of up to 10 micrometers in size (PM10) , registered 150 micrograms per square meter per hour in Wanli, located in the northeastern tip of Taiwan, much higher than the background concentration of 80 micrograms.

The hourly concentration of particulate matter, of up to 2.5 micrometers (PM2.5) , soared from 40 micrograms to 105 micrograms, while the concentration of sulfur dioxide also quadrupled, rising from below 5 parts per billion (ppb) to 20 ppb, EPA data indicated.
In downtown Taipei city, the concentration of particulate matter registered more than 100 micrograms in Wanhua, Kuting, Chungshan and Shihlin districts.
Particulate concentration reached 171 micrograms in Tamsui, Taipei county and surpassed 200 micrograms in Taliao, Kaohsiung county, according EPA data.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune: Chirac muses on Iran, and then retreats.
The French president said that if Iran had one or two nuclear weapons, it would not pose much of a danger. A day later, he retracted many of his remarks which were vastly different from stated French policy and from what Chirac repeatedly has said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CLARIFIES DONATION TO PANAMA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that Taiwan's donation of US$5 million to Panama was part of the bilateral humanitarian cooperation program and not an example of checkbook diplomacy as claimed by some media.
Yeh Fei-bi, vice director general of MOFA's Department of Information and Cultural Affairs, said the donation to the Panamanian first lady's office was held in an open ceremony Jan. 17.

She was responding to reports by a local newspaper, the China Times, which quoted La Prensa, Panama's major newspaper, as saying that Taiwan Ambassador Hou Ping-fu donated the sum to the office of first lady Vivian Ferenandez de Torrijos via Panamanian First Vice President and Foreign Affairs Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro Jan. 17, one week after President Chen Shui-bian and Panamanian President Martin Torrijos Espino met at the inauguration ceremony of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega Jan. 10.
Following La Prensa's report, the Panamanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated Wednesday that the donation ceremony was held openly, but was unknown to others until reported in the press.
Yeh stressed that the donation is part of a humanitarian cooperation program between the two nations.

The donation was intended for a charity project presided over by the first lady's office, chiefly to help establish barrier-free facilities for the disabled and provide them with vocational training and counselling.
Yeh noted that the first lady's office has stated that the donation will not be managed by the office, but by a bureau for the nation's physically challenged under the Presidential Office.

She noted that Lewis, while accepting the donation in a ceremony Jan. 17, said that the money would be channeled into the nation's coffers in an efficient and transparent way. The management will be subject to the supervision of the auditing agency, and Taiwan has no need to worry that the funds would end up lining the pockets of certain individuals, according to Lewis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP TAIPEI HEALTH OFFICIAL RESIGNS

TEXT.P: Taipei City Commissioner of Health Mark Sung quit his post as Taipei's top health official Thursday, citing "disagreements with Mayor Hau Lung-bin over public health policies" as the reason.

In a rather surprising move, Sung, who took up the health commissioner post on Feb. 1, 2005, offered his resignation at a news conference called around noon Thursday, saying that he "feels saddened" over Hau's punishing intervention in the city's public health policies and "sees no turning point at which his ideals can be realized under Hau's leadership."

Sung, who holds a Ph.D. in immunology from Cornell University, New York, said Hau's "arbitrary" decisions not to retain Taipei City Hospital (TCH) Director Sun Jui-sheng and the firing of TCH Hoping Branch Superintendent Chu Da-cheng in the wake of a diagnosis dispute that occurred at the Hoping branch late last year, were completely unacceptable.

Hau's strongly-worded criticism of the Taipei Department of Health (TDH), at a city government meeting Wednesday for "negligence" over the allegedly illegal operation of an after-childbirth confinement and convalescence center in Taipei, and his demand for a "name list" of TDH officials in charge of related affairs, were moves tantamount to measures adopted during Taiwan's "white terror" era, Sung said.
Sung, who was a professor with National Yang Ming University's Institute of Anatomy and Cell Biology before joining the Taipei city government, asked Hau to "find somebody smarter" to replace him.
Later in the day, responding to Sung's surprising resignation, Hau said Sung's move has indeed taken him by surprise. Hau said he respects Sung's decision.

Hau, who assumed his mayorship just a month ago, added that maintaining quality medical services is one of the priorities of his city administration and there is still room for improvement in this area.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA STEPS UP EFFORTS TO PROMOTE BANANA EXPORTS TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: There is ample room for Taiwan to promote its bananas in Japan, an official of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Thursday.

TAITRA Deputy Secretary General Yeh Ming-shui made the remarks as he presided over a meeting in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, at which representatives from Taiwan and Japan took part. Japanese representatives had visited banana growing farms at Chishan and Meinung, Kaohsiung a day earlier.

Yeh noted that Taiwan exported US$3.29 billion worth of agriculture products in 2006, and Japan was one of its most important export markets, especially regarding fresh fruits. Bananas have been a mainstay of Taiwan's exports to Japan.

But Yeh noted that Philippine bananas have a market share of around 88.5 percent in Japan, which consumes around one million tons of bananas every year. The Philippines' market share is followed by that of Ecuator, Mexico and Taiwan.
Bananas from Taiwan enjoy a market share of only 1.4 percent in Japan, Yeh said, showing that there is room for further growth.
TAITRA has touted the unique flavor of locally produced bananas to the Japanese, Yeh said.
The council also hopes that local banana growers will pay attention to quality control to reassure Japanese buyers and encourage them to increase their purchases, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOGA, TAI-CHI GOOD FOR CANCER PATIENTS: MEDICAL EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Moderate exercise such as yoga, tai chi, and constitutionals, is good for the health of cancer patients, improving their immunity against minor diseases and reducing the side effects caused by chemotherapy, medical sources said Thursday.

Many patients and their families wrongly believed that the patient should stay still in bed after undergoing an operation or chemotherapy, said Hsieh Ruey- kuen, an oncologist at Mackey Memorial Hospital. However, supportive exercise is recommended as it can aid in the recovery process.

Citing recent research results from the U.S. National Cancer Institute, Hsieh said researchers have proven that yogic exercise can improve patients' immunity. The institute also recommended that patients practice yoga for 20 to 60 minutes per session, at least three times per week to boost their strength.

Hsieh noted that exercise like yoga, tai chi, and constitutionals is similar in essence, helping people to moderate their body's condition and improve health. Therefore, daily, supportive exercise could help cancer patients recover more quickly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PRESIDES OVER HANDOVER CEREMONY FOR DEPARTMENT CHIEFS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin presided over a hand over ceremony for several department chiefs Thursday, urging the new members of his working team to offer their best services to the citizens through interdepartment cooperation.

The Taipei city government will see five new department chiefs, including Department of Finance Director Lin Chien-yuan, Fire Department Commissioner Hsiung Kwang-hua, Feitsui Reservoir Administration Director-General Lee Kung- che, Research, Development and Evaluation Commission Chairman Sheng Chih-jen, and Department of Personnel Director Han Chun-ying.
Noting that these new section chiefs are all elite persons in their respective spheres of work, Hau said their arrivals will complete the Taipei city government working team.

Addressing the handover ceremony on behalf of other new section chiefs, Sheng said although individual performance is important, he would like to focus on team work in the future to help Hau implement his policies.

Hau re hired the outgoing Department of Personnel Director Chung Yu-nan as city government adviser for his extraordinary performance in streamlining personnel and planning English training programs for the city government employees.

According to Yen Chiu-lai, deputy minister of Cabinet-level Central Personnel Administration (CPA), who witnessed the handover ceremony, the CPA has rewarded Chung for his efforts in promoting the privatization of public buses and gender equality, employing aboriginal persons, and saving money for the Taipei city government.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT LEE NOT DROPPING TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE: TSU LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui's recent remarks about his hope to visit China and his denouncement of Taiwan independence were only a joke because Lee has never abandoned his desire to make Taiwan a normal country, members of the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Thursday.

The clarification of Lee's stance regarding Taiwan's future by TSU lawmakers at a news conference came one day after Next Magazine reported in its latest edition that Lee hopes to visit China, forswears Taiwan independence and calls for the government to open up to Chinese capital and tourists.

Brushing aside rampant speculation that Lee has again changed his attitude regarding Taiwan's future, TSU legislative caucus whip Tseng Tsahn-deng said that Lee was only stressing that there is no need to fuel Taiwan independence debate at the present stage because Taiwan is already an independent sovereignty.

According to Tseng, Lee still harbors the dream of turning Taiwan into a normal country through writing a new constitution for the country and changing its official designation, and calls for joint efforts from all pro-independence activists.

The former president was only kidding when saying that he hopes to visit China, and his call for an opening to Chinese capital was only part of his efforts to reverse trends that have resulted in a steady capital flow to China, Tseng explained, adding that Lee is deeply worried that continuous investment in China will eventually hurt this country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-DEVELOPED PIGS OFFER PROSPECT FOR XENOTRANSPLANTATION

TEXT.P: Pigs with genes resistant to rejection have been produced in Taiwan and offer the prospect of supplying organs for transplant into human bodies, a local researcher said Thursday.

Tu chin-fu, chief of the Division of Biotechnology at the Animal Technology Institute Taiwan, said his research team has developed pigs which carry transplanted genes resistant to acute and severe acute rejection which are common in organ transplants.

Noting that thousands of people around the world who need organ transplants die before suitable donors can be found every year, Tu said xenotransplantation may offer an option to solve the shortage of donated human organs.

Pigs, like baboon and chimpanzees, are close to human beings in physical construction, but unlike the baboon and chimpanzees, they are not protected animals, and therefore are promising suppliers of organs for human beings, Tu went on.
One of the major obstacles in transplanting organs between different species is rejection, which leads to the failure of the alien organs in the new host body.
However, Tu said, his team has succeeded in transplanting six genes which resist rejection into the genome of the pigs.

During a test designed to examine these genes' effective in human bodies, Tu said his team circulated human blood into kidneys and lungs removed from such pigs and found that the removed organs work quiet well.

The success of the experiment has placed his team at the forefront of this field in the world, Tu said. The next step for his team, Tu said, will be to develop pigs which carry all of the six rejection-resistant genes and produce them in en mass for widespread use.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO POLICE LUNAR NEW YEAR MARKET MANIPULATION

TEXT.P: The government will be guarding against market manipulation in the run-up to the Lunar New Year, so to keep prices stable for goods and services most popular during the period, a senior official said Thursday.

Concerted price raising, price fixing and hoarding of New Year necessities are prohibited, said Tang Jinn-chuan, newly appointed Fair Trade Commission Chairman, who just assumed office that day, adding that the commission is joining efforts with agricultural affairs and police agencies to address irregularities.

He made particular mention of barber shops and beauty parlors, which should keep in place their usual pricing, or adjust the prices in accordance with the market mechanism, saying that "they cannot reset prices in a concerted action.
The beauty industry has a tradition of doubling prices during the week or so prior to the Lunar New Year's Eve.

In order to ensure an adequate supply of goods and prevent manipulation during the New Year period, the commission is keeping in contact with several semi- government wholesale corporations so as to keep itself well-informed of market conditions, Tang said, adding that inspections have been carried out at major New Year commodity fairs.
New Year's Eve for the coming Year of the Pig is Feb. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MAY DESTROY WORLD'S CHIP SUPPLY CHAIN IF IT ATTACKS TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 1 (CNA) 02/01/07 19:49:12 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Chinese provocations against Taiwan could result in an extended disruption to the world's chip supply chain, particularly as Taiwan is set to become the world's leading manufacturer of DRAM chips in 2007, U.S.-Taiwan Business Council President Rupert Hammond-Chambers said Wednesday.

Hammond-Chambers said the recent destruction of a satellite by a Chinese ICBM renewed concerns over China's military intentions and its "peaceful" rise in Asia. "It also drew the world's attention to potential flash points, including Taiwan and the possibility that China would resort to using force to reunify with the island, " he said.

The missile test took place just prior to the release of the council's "Semiconductor Report - Annual Review 2006, " which anticipates that Taiwan will become the world's leading manufacturer of DRAM chips in 2007, Hammond-Chambers noted.
He quoted the report in highlighting Taiwan's strategic importance in the chip industry. Taiwan is home to the world's highest concentration of advanced 12-inch semiconductor fabrication plants.

He also quoted data from Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry that indicates that Taiwan is not only the leading producer of important semiconductor technologies like DRAM, but Taiwan companies are also responsible for a significant share of global technology production, including approximately 82 percent of notebook computers, 98 percent of motherboards, and 72 percent of LCD monitors.
U.S. companies sourced an estimated US$73.3 billion of technology products from Taiwan in 2006 alone, an 11 percent increase over 2005, he added.

Hammond-Chambers said the global economy is increasingly reliant on the supply chain synergies that run through Taiwan and its regional partners. "These partnerships produce many of the technological products on which we have become reliant, and which improve business productivity and empower consumers. Present trends point towards Taiwan strengthening its position in certain key sectors, particularly in semiconductors," he added.

Hammond-Chambers said the council is concerned about the potential costs to the United States if that critical supply chain is severed by "acts of god" such as an earthquake like that which struck in 1999, or if provocative actions undertaken by Beijing resulted in an extended supply chain disruption.

Semiconductors are critical not only to commercial businesses, but also to modern warfare, he said, adding that a reliable and robust supply base is a crucial component of any country's modern military. This is true in particular for the United States, as it relies on a single semiconductor manufacturer to provide it with all of the chips it requires for national security, and where additional supplies of chips must come from commercial sources, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Chirac Strays From Assailing a Nuclear Iran and KATRIN BENNHOLD PARIS
French President Jacques Chirac said this week that if Iran had one or two nuclear weapons, it would not pose a big danger, and that if Iran were to launch a nuclear weapon against a country like Israel, it would lead to the immediate destruction of Tehran. The remarks, made in an interview on Monday with The New York Times, The International Herald Tribune and Le Nouvel Observateur, a weekly magazine, were vastly different from stated French policy and what Chirac has often said. On Tuesday, Mr. Chirac summoned the same journalists back to Elysee Palace to retract many of his remarks.
Wall Street Journal: Wal-Mart Cuts Taxes By Paying Rent to Itself
As the world's biggest retailer, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. pays billions of dollars a year in rent for its stores. Luckily for Wal-Mart, in about 25 states it has been paying most of that rent to itself -- and then deducting that amount from its state taxes. The arrangement takes advantage of a tax loophole that the federal government plugged decades ago, but which many states have been slower to catch.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Muslim soldiers 'faced kidnap and beheading'
Muslims serving in the Armed Forces, Civil Service and the police are targets for British-based Islamists after detectives foiled an alleged plot to kidnap and behead a soldier home on leave from Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EXPLORE NEW DIMENSIONS OF DEEP OCEAN WATER USE: MOEA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is to establish a new facility in the eastern county of Taitung, utilizing deep ocean water to cultivate high-altitude vegetables, mushrooms and flower, MOEA officials said Thursday.

The project comes after the successful application of deep ocean water to bottled drinking water, cosmetics and aquaculture to further exploit the business opportunity of "blue gold" -- a nickname for deep ocean water, they said.

According to MOEA tallies, five local companies invested NT$3 billion (US$91 million) in research and manufacturing facilities along the eastern coast between 2004 and 2005, while three of them plan to put in an additional NT$11.2 billion in the coming two years.
The officials said the estimated production value of deep ocean water-related business will reach NT$1 billion in three years, while after six years, the total output value would top NT$18 billion.

The budget of the new facility for high-altitude produce is about NT$384 million and an MOEA review committee is working on a shortlist of site choices, with a final decision to be announced in one week.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA FLEXES MUSCLES TOWARD U.S., JAPAN BY DESTROYING SATELLITE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 1 (CNA) 02/01/07 20:52:14 (By Mandy Wong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: China's recent destruction of a satellite with an intercontinental ballistic missile was aimed at flexing its military muscles to the world and warning Japan and the United States against tampering in the Taiwan issue, Deputy Defense Minister Ko Cheng-en was quoted as saying Thursday.

Ko was quoted in an interview with the Chinese-language Yazhou Zhoukan as saying he considers China's development of anti-satellite weapons and its recent demonstration of J10 fighters were targeted on the situation after a planned meeting between the U.S. defense secretary and his Japanese counterpart and a meeting between the U.S. state department secretary and her Japanese counterpart -- the so-called "two plus two meeting."
Ko said China's latest military actions were partly aimed at warning the U.S. and Japan that should they intervene in a cross-Taiwan Strait conflict, they will suffer the consequences.
He noted that it was unusual for China's air force to conduct two large-scale exercises near Shanghai in December, with even the airports in Shanghai closed at certain points during the maneuvers.

Although having expressed concern over the destruction of the satellite by a Chinese ICBM, Washington was somewhat quieter than other major powers around the world over the matter, Ko said, adding that it was probably because the United States still needs Beijing's support over issues regarding the Iraq war, North Korea's nuclear program and the Iran issue.

Ko said China might intimidate Taiwan by firing anti-satellite missiles as a result of Taiwan's political situation, particularly President Chen Shui-bian's reiteration of his desire for a constitutional re-engineering plan, but added that intimidating Taiwan was not the sole purpose of the recent missile demonstration.

He said Beijing has used many means to intimidate Taiwan in the past, including conducting live-ammunition war games in the Taiwan Strait, moving its guided missile deployment and intensifying deployment of jet fighters in coastal areas.

Meanwhile, on a question of why the Republic of China military has not demonstrated its strength over the past decade, Ko said the military has restrained from flexing its muscles for fear of provoking Beijing or having its actions misunderstood as efforts to seek independence.
The military has also kept a low profile out of consideration for the stance of the United States, upon which Taiwan relies for its weapons procurement, Ko said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SULFUR DIOXIDE RESIDUE FOUND IN DRIED LILY BUDS SOLD IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: About 80 percent of the dried lily buds sold in Taoyuan County contain excessive amounts of sulfur dioxide residue, county health officials said Thursday.

The officials at the Taoyuan county government's Public Health Bureau said they had tested 15 samples of dried lily buds collected from stores in the county and found 12 of them to contain sulfur dioxide residue exceeding legal limits.
Dried lily buds -- the unopened buds of the lily flower -- are also called "golden needles" because of their color. They are a common ingredient in various Chinese dishes.
Some suppliers of the product use sulfur dioxide for bleaching and as a preservative.

The health officials indicated that the manufacturers of the problem goods were each fined between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000, while the stores selling such products were told to remove the goods from their shelves.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO INDIA'S WIFE HOSTS TAIWAN FOOD PARTY
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, India, Feb. 1 (CNA) 02/01/07 20:59:52 (By Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The wife of Andrew J. Kao, the Republic of China representative to India, hosted a Taiwanese food party at their residency Thursday for the wives of other representatives and ambassadors.

Nearly 30 guests, including members of international women's club in India and the wives of the ambassadors from Belgium, Hungary, Ireland, Singapore, Thailand, South Africa, Myanmar, North Korea and Rwanda, attended the party and expressed great interest in the dishes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO EARLY TO SAY WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM REDISTRICTING SCHEME: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Thursday that it is too early to say who will benefit most from the redistricting scheme for the year-end legislative elections.

Su made the remarks after media reports speculated that the redrawing of the 73 constituencies of the nation's 25 cities and countries could mean more polarization of Taiwan's political landscape, with southern Taiwan, which is a stronghold of the "pan-green camp" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), turning greener and northern Taiwan, which usually tilts toward the "pan-blue alliance" led by the Kuomintang (KMT), becoming more blue.
The premier said it is impossible to tell which camp will gain more from the new scheme, saying that it will rely on the strength and efforts of the various parties and candidates.

The redistricting was made necessary because of a 2005 constitutional amendment that changed the electoral system for the seventh legislature to a "single-seat constituency, two votes" from the present "multiple-seat constituency" and that will see the legislature cut by half to 113 members, including 73 regional seats from each constituency, six seats for aborigines and 34 for legislators-at-large.

"The redrawing of the constituencies is crucial to each party and candidate, " Su said, adding that this is why the redistricting work is so grueling and why eight contentious cities and counties had to resort to a last-minute drawing of lots.

Su said that since Jan. 24 he had met with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin- pyng five times for negotiations to try to thrash out the differences over the eight cities and counties, without success.
The matter finally had to rely on the drawing of lots to choose from resolutions floated by the Central Election Commission (CEC) , the Legislative Yuan and various parties.
Su expressed hope that all parties "if not satisfied with the result, can at least accept it and then make the best efforts for the year-end elections."

The redistricting scheme shows that 21 cities and counties, including Taipei and Taichung cities and Miaoli and Changhua counties, which were decided by lot drawing, have followed the redrawing scheme worked out by the CEC.

While Taipei County, which has the largest number of 12 seats due to its large population, follows a proposal by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, Taoyuan County adopts a version from the DPP and Kaohsiung City uses a version agreed upon by the Legislative Yuan. Pingtung County adopts a version proposed by the KMT, the People First Party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the Non- partisan Solidarity Union.

Meanwhile, faced with more competitive elections with greatly reduced seats, DPP Legislator Chen Chin-jun said the DPP has to work with the TSU, saying that if the TSU fields its own candidate in each constituency, it will impact the "pan- green camp."

KMT Legislator John Chiang estimated that the new scheme will be favorable to the major parties and that the KMT, which currently controls 90 seats in the 219-seat legislature, will garner two-thirds of the seats.

PFP Legislator Cheng Chin-ling said her party and the KMT will have to meet next week at the latest to talk about fielding candidates, as the two parties will be soliciting support from the same voters.
In related development, Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun said he regretted the result of the draw.

Chu said the initial redistricting scheme sent by the county to the CEC was based on Chungli and Taoyuan cities having the largest township-level cities in one constituency each, while the final version has cut more than 10 boroughs each from the two cities and has given them to other constituencies.

But Hsu Chung-wen, director of the DPP's Taoyuan branch, was elated, saying that the new scheme will finally break the KMT's traditional hold on the two cities and that the DPP will be able to win half of the six seats in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAST FOOD FRANCHISES URGED TO FORSAKE TRANS FATS

TEXT.P: Fast food franchises around Taiwan were urged by the Consumer's Foundation Thursday to stop using unhealthy trans fatty acids.

The foundation urged major fast food franchises, including McDonald's and Starbucks, to take the lead in stopping the use of trans fatty acids, commonly termed "trans fats, " in preparation of their food.
Trans fats are created during an industrial process to transform natural liquid plant oils into solids. The process is called partial hydrogenation.

Both foreign and domestic research documents show that trans fats are neither required nor beneficial for health and indicate that consuming trans fat increases the risk of cardiovascular disease due to its effect on cholesterol levels.
For these reasons, the governments of Denmark and the United States have restricted or banned all restaurants and food stands from using trans fats in preparing fried foods.
Foundation officials said McDonald's, Starbucks and Kentucky Fried Chicken outlets in the United States have announced that they have stopped using trans fats since November 2006.
The foundation suggested that the government should exert controls on trans fats by requiring foodstuff producers and processors to state the quantity of trans fatty acids on food packaging.
It also urged consumers to avoid trans fats and to pay extra attention to food labeling.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Senators Unite On Challenge to Bush's Troop Plan Revised Warner Language That Protects Funds Is Embraced for Bipartisan Appeal
Democratic and Republican opponents of President Bush's troop-buildup plan joined forces last night behind the nonbinding resolution with the broadest bipartisan backing: a Republican measure from Sen. John W. Warner of Virginia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO TO HOLD CHINESE PROFICIENCY ASSESSMENT TEST IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: The Cultural Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York will hold the 2007 Test of Proficiency-Huayu (TOP) assessment of Chinese proficiency, for beginner and basic levels in New York on April 15.
Ethan Kuo, director of TECO Cultural Division, said Wednesday that non-native Chinese speakers over 16 years-old are encouraged to take the beginner or basic level test.

The Test of Proficiency-Huayu is a standardized test developed by the Steering Committee for the Test of Proficiency-Huayu, affiliated with National Taiwan Normal University. Given that learning Chinese is becoming ever more popular, and that Chinese learners may appreciate the opportunity to assess their proficiency and receive credentials for the reference of educational authorities or employers, the Republic of China's Ministry of Education has promoted the assessment system overseas since December 2003.

The TOP test is designed for Chinese learners at the beginner, basic, intermediate, and advanced levels. As the test in New York will be the first of its kind in the United States, TECO will start by offering tests only at the beginner and basic levels.

In general, non-native Chinese speakers familiar with at least 800 Chinese characters, or having taken between 240 hours and 360 hours of Chinese language lessons can try the beginner's test and those familiar with at least 1,500 Chinese characters or having taken between 360 hours and 480 hours of Chinese language lessons can try the basic test.

The test is open to people aged 16 years or older. TECO Cultural Division expects 200 applicants each for the tests of beginner and basic levels. Application forms can be downloaded from the website, found at www.edutwny.org. All applications must be submitted by mail or in person to the Cultural Division, Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, 1 East 42nd Street, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10017 before March 15, 2007. In addition to the application form, three photos, a copy of a valid passport or ID, and payment of US$28 (for the basic level text only) should be included.

Encouraging Chinese learners to take the opportunity to measure their Chinese language proficiency, Kuo said that the Ministry of Education issued credentials for basic, intermediate as well as advanced levels, which can be used as job qualification references. For international students seeking Taiwanese scholarships or applying for academic programs at colleges or universities in Taiwan, the credentials are accepted by increasing numbers of educational establishments requiring Chinese proficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BCC OWNER TOLD TO EXPLAIN HIS PURCHASE CAPITAL

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) decided at its regular meeting Thursday to tell Jaw Shau-kong, former chairman of UFO Radio, to explain where he got the capital for his recent purchase of the Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC)
The NCC members made the decision after listening to a report by BCC executives on the transfer of the company's shares and the change of its superintendent.
According to Broadcasting and Television Law, any change of superintendents of broadcasting or television stations should be approved by the NCC

As Jaw's purchase of the BCC -- worth billions of Taiwan dollars -- through his four small companies, with capital of each totalling only NT$20 million, has drawn strong criticism from the public and many ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators, the NCC decided to demand an explanation from Jaw as to the source of his capital in the deal with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , the former owner of the BCC.
NCC Vice Chairman Shih Shih-hau said the commission has also asked the National Security Bureau and Financial Supervisory Commission for help by providing related information about Jaw's capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, TSU STILL ALLIES: DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Despite former President Lee Teng-hui's recent remarks about Taiwan independence, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) still views the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) as an ally, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.

Yu made the comments at a news conference after the Next Magazine claimed that Lee, the so-called "spiritual leader" of the TSU in the "pan-green camp" along with the DPP against the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), has said in an interview that he hopes to visit China, that he had abandoned the idea of Taiwan independence and that he wants Taiwan to open up to Chinese tourists and capital.
Saying that he respects Lee very much, Yu pointed out, however, that Lee' s performance must be judged by history and the Taiwan people.
Lee's political career can be divided into two stages -- one in Taiwan's democratic era and one in the preceding KMT era, according to Yu.

Lee in the democratic era shared the same aspirations as the DPP for Taiwan's formal independence, to be backed up by a new and tailor-made constitution and a change of the country's official designation, while Lee in the KMT's authoritarian era had nothing in common with the DPP, he said.

"To date, I still believe in Lee, who remains devoted to Taiwan's cause, " Yu said, claiming that the Taiwan people "will not accept a politician or a political party that forswears Taiwan's core values."
Meanwhile, the TSU headquarters telephone switchboard was jammed with callers wishing to voice their opinions of Lee's remarks, TSU Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia said.
The TSU will also keep collaborating with the DPP if the ruling party continues sticking to its principles regarding Taiwan's sovereignty, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED RESPONSE TO EX-PRESIDENT'S REMARKS DENOUNCING INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Political figures from the ruling and opposition parties were mixed Thursday in their reactions to the latest remarks made by former President Lee Teng-hui, who claimed that he never backed Taiwan independence.

Lee told Next Magazine, in its latest edition, that he hopes to visit China and forswears Taiwan independence. The former president and spiritual leader of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) also urged the government and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to open up to Chinese capital and tourists, according to the report.

Vice President Annette Lu expressed her "astonishment" when asked for her opinion regarding Lee's denouncement of Taiwan independence. She then argued that the public must judge a political figure's words and deeds over a long term.
In response to reporters' inquiries, Premier Su Tseng-chang insisted that Taiwan is already an independent sovereignty, though he claimed that he was not fully aware of Lee's remarks.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a stalwart in the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), however, said that Lee has always been consistent in his stance regarding Taiwan independence and that Lee was never active in the movement.

KMT Legislator John Chiang, who once served as KMT secretary-general when Lee was president and the party's chairman, doubted that the prime purpose of Lee's denouncement of the Taiwanese independence movement was aimed only at fortifying the TSU's position in domestic politics.

This was by no means the first time that Lee has changed his stance regarding major national issues, Chiang claimed, adding that Lee's statement highlights the fact that independence is no longer supported by the mainstream of Taiwanese society and that the cause will attract few voters.

Lee Hung-chun, spokesman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , accused Lee of seeking to score political points with the interview. The former president's changing attitudes only follow the various twists in his political line, Lee Hung-chun said.
Sheng Fu-hsiung, a former DPP legislator who is widely viewed as a moderate in Taiwan's polarized politics, praised what he called the former president's frank comments in the interview.

Speaking at a news conference, Sheng urged the public not to interpret Lee's remarks negatively. He claimed that Lee was only opposed to unworthy politicians scheming to manufacture an artificial confrontation by rehashing old issues.
Sheng hailed Lee's pragmatic attitude toward Taiwanese independence and pointed out that it does not mark a departure from the ruling DPP's resolution on Taiwan's future.

However, Sheng also called on Lee to provide the public with a clear explanation for his changing attitudes on the independence issue by discarding his personal concern for the TSU's future or the 2008 presidential election.
Doing so will help the former president better dispel public misconceptions about him and encourage social elites to join forces with him, Sheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BALLOTS IN KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL ELECTION TO BE RECOUNTED

TEXT.P: Ballots cast in last December's Kaohsiung mayoral election will be recounted beginning March 12, Kaohsiung District Court officials said Thursday.

The ruling received praise from Huang Chun-ying, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) mayoral candidate defeated by Chen Chu of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) by just 1,114 votes, or 0.14 percent of the total, and filed a lawsuit seeking to nullify both the election and Chen's victory.

"We trust the judiciary, " Huang said at a news conference, with his lawyer adding that a recount is expected to overturn the Dec. 9 election result. Chen said the same day that the court ruling was "unacceptable," claiming that Huang did not offer sufficient evidence to merit a recount.

Based on the 2004 presidential election recount, which found every polling station had at least five controversial ballots on average, debatable ballots across Kaohsiung City's 839 polling stations could be several times the narrow margin -- in an election that counted more than 6,000 invalid votes, according to the court ruling.
Tu Yu-to, a court spokesman, said the complainant had reported nearly 100 irregularities involving nearly 100 polling stations.

He said the court had started preparations for the recount and that 20 judges will each lead teams that will include election affairs officials to conduct the recount, which is estimated to take a week.

In his lawsuit, Huang contended that Chen's camp not only violated election law by continuing campaign activities after the 10 p.m. election-eve deadline, but also held a late-night press conference to spread a rumor to smear his name.

The KMT candidate added that on the day of the election, even President Chen Shui-bian made use of specific news media outlets to accuse him of vote buying and to claim that even if Huang was elected, his election results would be invalidated.
Huang insisted that the DPP's false accusation against him was in disregard of the electoral law and "apparently" influenced the results of the election and caused his defeat.
Huang has filed a separate lawsuit against Chen Chu's camp over the vote-buying allegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR OF PIG MEMORIAL COINS SELL LIKE HOT CAKES

TEXT.P: A batch of 120,000 sets of "Year of the Pig" commemorative coins issued by the Taipei-based Central Bank of China sold out in less than a day Thursday, the first day they were put on the market.

Each coin set, priced at NT$1,350, consists of three coins -- a one-ounce silver coin with a face value of NT$100 and two coins with face values of NT$50 and NT$20, respectively. They all feature the pig as their motif in celebration of the Feb. 18 arrival of the lunar calendar's Year of the Pig.
Most of the coin sets were sold at the Bank of Taiwan's 147 branches throughout Taiwan. A small number -- about 6,000 sets -- were sold at the 21 branches of the Central Trust of China.
Buyers formed long queues at the outlets, and by 3 p.m. Thursday, all 120,000 sets had been sold.
Although each person was allowed to buy only one set, some collectors who arrived early and bought a first set were seen sneaking back to the end of the queue and managing to get an extra set.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NAMES NEW CHIEF OF GENERAL STAFF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian approved a partial reshuffle of senior military posts Thursday, with Gen. Hou Shou-yeh, a Presidential Office strategy adviser, to be promoted to the position of chief of the General Staff, an official said Thursday.
Hou will succeed Gen. Lee Tien-yu, who will be transferred to serve as a presidential strategy adviser, the official said.

Meanwhile, Gen. Hu Chen-pu, the army commanding general, will be transferred to serve as a presidential strategy adviser and the position to be left vacant by Hu's transfer will be filled by Gen. Chao Shih-chang, who is at present a deputy chief of the General Staff.
The reshuffle also includes the promotion of Gen. Wu Ta-peng, director of the Political Warfare Department under the Ministry of National Defense, to the post of deputy chief of the General Staff.

Also receiving a promotion in the partial reshuffle was Gen. Chih Lin-lien, commanding general of the Logistics Command, who will serve as a presidential strategy adviser, while the post he vacates will be filled by Lt. Gen. Chin Nai- chief, who is presently an air force combat commander,

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO TO CHAMPION PUBLISHING INDUSTRY PROMOTION LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will champion the legislation of a law to facilitate reinvigoration of the publishing industry and music industry, GIO Minister Cheng Wen-tsan said Thursday.
Cheng said the bill would create mechanisms to encourage print, music and digital publishers to help promote Taiwan's publishing industry and cultural development.

The law's aim is to offer institutional protection and support to diversified and disadvantaged publishing business, including small or local newspapers, so that different voices might be heard by the public, according to Cheng.
Cheng said that in addition to advancing the promotion law, the GIO will also work on amendments to the Radio and Television Act and Motion Picture Act to enhance Taiwan's culture industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES EYE CHINESE MARKET

TEXT.P: Two state-run enterprises -- Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTL) and Taiyen Biotech Co. -- have announced their intention to explore overseas markets with China topping their list of desired locations, company spokesmen said Thursday.

TTL Chairman Martin Tsai said that the company's cigarettes are selling very well at five duty-free shops in China. He added that the company aims to further expand its business this year as it has won approval from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to set up offices in Beijing and Shanghai.

In addition, Tsai said that TTL has completed the first selection of agents for its Chinese operations and TTL will place its cigarette products for sale at an additional 152 duty-free shops at airports, harbors, and customs in China, he noted.
Meanwhile, TTL plans to begin selling its products through taxed sales channels in China, the chairman said.

Noting that the Chinese government has capped the total volume of tobacco and liquor imports, he estimated that TTL will have a quota of around 20,000 units that it may sell each year in Chinese shops.
Taiyen Chairman Lin Ching, for his part, announced that the salt firm has registered its cosmetics products in China, and that these are expected to go on sale soon.
Moreover, Lin said that his firm is now in discussions with several Chinese TV shopping channels to collaborate on selling the products.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO REVIEW CARLYLE GROUP'S ASE BUYOUT BID

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will start to review a Carlyle Group's proposed buyout of Advanced Semiconductor Engineering, Inc. (ASE) after completing consultations with relevant government agenices, an official said Thursday.

The official made the remarks after the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council called for the Taiwan government a day earlier to swiftly complete the application process for Carlyle Group's ASE acquisition bid.

The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, a non-profit association that groups companies involved in business between Taiwan and the United States, said in a news release that the potential deal highlights the ability of Taiwan companies to attract substantial foreign investments, greatly benefiting Taiwan's economy.

It also underscores the attractiveness of Taiwan's semiconductor market, which the council has predicted will become the world's largest market for chip equipment spending and for DRAM production in 2007, due largely to new partnerships and a number of new investments, the press statement said.
Responding to the U.S. council's comments, the MOEA official in charge of investment affairs said the buyout application is still in the opinion- soliciting stage.
Once the opinion-soliciting process is finalized, the official said the MOEA's Investment Commission will start to review the case and make a final decision.

The Carlyle Group, one of the world's largest private equity firms, offered in early January to purchase ASE, the world's largest chip packaging and testing company, for approximately US%5.5 billion and take it private.

According to the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, the Carlyle Group's intention to enter Taiwan's semiconductor market reflects the high caliber of Taiwan businesses and a desire to link the U.S. and Taiwan -- arguably the two most important semiconductor markets in the world.

"It is important to move away from the notion that only semiconductor companies can realize synergies through mergers and acquisitions in the semiconductor sector. Private equity firms are also well positioned to add value for shareholders, market sectors, and economies," the council said in its press statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISGRACED REBAR GROUP FOUNDER LEAVES U.S. FOR MYANMAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 1 (CNA) 02/01/07 23:54:32 (By Cheihyu Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Disgraced Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng left the United States Wednesday along with his wife for Myanmar, reliable sources said Thursday.
David Ta-wei Lee, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, confirmed the information, saying that U.S. authorities twice informed his office of the couple's departure Wednesday.
Quoting U.S. authorities, Lee said the Wangs departed Los Angeles 11 p.m. Wednesday.

The sources said the disgraced couple are heading for Myanmar. The sources, however, would not elaborate on whether the couple left the U.S. out of their own decision or under pressure from U.S. judicial authorities.
As to whether the Wangs were leaving under the escort of U.S. law enforcement officers, Lee said he is not in a position to comment or confirm any relevant details.

According to the informed sources, the U.S. authorities couldn't expel or repatriate the Wangs because Taiwan's judicial authorities had failed to present concrete criminal evidence involving the couple.

The Wangs fled to China late last year after two of the group's 120-odd member companies applied for insolvency restructuring. The fallout triggered a run on the Chinese Bank, another of the group's affiliates. Subsequent judicial investigations found that the couple and other family members and corporate executives were involved in many suspected irregularities, including fraud, embezzlement, breach of trust and insider trading.
