DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 2, or the 15th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1535: The Argentine city of Buenos Aires is founded by Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoz.
1556: An earthquake rocks the provinces of Shensi, Henan and Shansi in mainland China, killing an estimated 830,000 people.
1665: A British fleet captures New Amsterdam, the center of the Dutch colony in North America and the flourishing trading settlement on the island of Manhattan, renaming it New York in honor of the Duke of York.
1848: Mexico, according to a treaty signed after the U.S.-Mexico War, cedes Texas, New Mexico and California to the United States.
1878: Greece declares war on Turkey.
1913: The world's biggest railroad station, New York's Grand Central Station, is formally opened.
1915: Germany begins U-boat blockades of British waters, while the United States warns Germany against attacking American ships.
1926: Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French president from 1974 to 1981, is born.
1943: German troops surrender to the Soviet Union in Stalingrad.
1946: Taipei's Yuanshan Zoo is opened.
1953: The U.S. government announces it will no longer block Chinese Nationalist troops in their raids against mainland Chinese troops stationed along the mainland coastline during the period of the Nationalist-Communist struggle.
1967: Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle is elected president of Nicaragua.
1970: China Airlines launches ROC-U.S. flight services with its inaugural flight, by a Boeing 707, to San Francisco.
1970: British philosopher and Nobel Prize-winner Bertrand Russel dies at the age of 98.
1972: Protesters in Dublin burn down the British Embassy in an act of revenge for the "Bloody Sunday" shooting in Londonderry the previous weekend in which British troops killed 13 Catholic youths and wounded another 17.
1975: Gen. Gamad Shumaimari, chief of the general staff of the armed forces of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1979: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns from 14 years in exile in Paris to rule Iran. He succeeded the Shah of Iran who fled to Egypt 15 days prior to Khomeini's return after failing to resist mounting opposition masterminded by Khomeini.
1986: Oscar Arias Sanchez is elected president of Costa Rica.
1989: A coup in Paraguay topples President Alfredo Stroessner who ruled the South American country for 35 years.
1989: The last of the Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan, ending a nine- year occupation of the country by Communist forces.
1994: Rafael Caldera is sworn in as president of Venezuela.
1994: The Republic of China and Burkina Faso announce the restoration of diplomatic relations, which were suspended for 21 years.
1998: A Cebu Pacific Air DC-9 crashes into a mountainside 65 kilometers northeast of Cagayan de Oro airport in the Philippines, killing all 104 people on board.
2000: The U.S. House of Representatives passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, a bill aimed at strengthening military ties with Taiwan, despite warnings from Beijing and the White House.
2001: Exiled mainland Chinese-born Nobel laureate writer Gao Xingjiang meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
2003: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian offers condolences over the loss of space shuttle Columbia and the seven astronauts aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If there were a sure way of getting rich, even though one had to be a groom and keep horses, I would be willing to pursue it. But as there is really no sure way of getting rich, I prefer to follow the pursuits congenial to me."

DOC.HEADLINE: WANTED REBAR GROUP HEAD, WIFE ARRIVE IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng and his wife, who have been placed on Taiwan's most-wanted list, reportedly arrived at Singapore's Changi Airport Friday morning after leaving the United States the previous day.

Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs have been in close contact with the Singaporean authorities and have been kept abreast of all the latest developments surrounding the Wangs, who allegedly embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds before going on the lam.

The Wangs fled to China late last year after two of the group's 120-odd member companies applied for insolvency restructuring. The fallout triggered a run on the Chinese Bank, another of the group's affiliates. Subsequent judicial investigations found that the couple and other family members and corporate executives were involved in many suspected irregularities, including fraud, embezzlement, breach of trust and insider trading.
Foreign Minister James Huang has canceled all activities scheduled for Friday morning and early afternoon to be ready for a possible repatriation of the Wangs back to Taiwan during the day.

Meanwhile, a CNA reporter stationed in Singapore reported that Taiwan's judicial authorities and liaison officials posted in the city-state have been locked in intensive negotiations with the Singaporean immigration authorities over the Wangs' repatriation.

The Singaporean authorities reportedly said Friday morning that there are no reasons for them to take the Wangs into custody as the couple used authentic passports and normal travel papers for their entrance.

Besides, since Taiwan and Singapore maintain no judicial assistance accord, the Singaporean authorities may not respond to Taiwan's request for the Wangs to be repatriated, according to local law enforcement officials.
If the Wangs are not repatriated back to Taiwan, it is possible that the Singaporean authorities may send them back to the United States, according to the officials.

Meanwhile, David Ta-wei Lee, Taiwan's representative to the United States, confirmed Thursday that U.S. authorities had twice informed his office of the couple's departure from Los Angeles at 11 p.m. Wednesday.

The U.S. officials said the couple were heading for Myanmar. They, however, would not elaborate on whether the couple left the United States out of their own decision or under pressure from U.S. judicial authorities, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GOVERNMENTS URGED TO INCREASE MANPOWER TO PREVENT CHILD ABUSE

TEXT.P: City and county governments should fill job vacancies at their social work divisions in order to better protect children from abuse and provide them with useful services to enhance their well-being, a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Friday.

According to the official, the MOI implemented a special program last year to offer direct financial subsidies to local governments for employing more trained social workers to help children experiencing difficulties or at high risk of falling victim to violence or filicide-suicide.

Besides providing 40 percent of the funds needed for recruiting up to 320 social workers specializing in protecting children around the country from abuse, the central government has also lifted unnecessary restrictions and cut red tape to facilitate recruitment of trained social workers.
After eight months of intensive efforts, the official said, a total of 303 qualified caseworkers have been employed in various cities and counties.
However, the official said, 17 positions remain unfilled, with Hsinchu and Changhua counties each having four vacant posts.

Under the government's new "Mega Warmth" project, the MOI has also pledged full financial support for local governments to employ more professional social workers or caseworkers to help high-risk families, particularly those with abused or neglected children.

As of the end of January, the official said, 22 caseworker positions under the "Mega Warmth" project remained unfilled, adding that the southern city of Kaohsiung has six openings and that the northern county of Taipei has five vacancies,

"We hope local governments can speed up social work manpower recruitment so that their social affairs agencies will no longer be understaffed and overworked and can be better equipped to protect children from abuse and filicide-suicide, " the official said, adding that city mayors and county magistrates should pay more heed to child abuse problems in their districts and take active steps to address them.

According to tallies released by the Child Welfare League Foundation, 17 children died from abuse last year, and four more abused kids died last month alone. If this year's rate continues -- four deaths in a single month -- it would prove an even deadlier year for children, a foundation spokeswoman said.

The foundation has provided social services to 1,168 high-risk families since 2004. Amid an economic slowdown, the spokeswoman said, 71 percent of those families were in financial straits, with 52 percent of the parents lacking basic fiscal discipline and management skills. Worse still, 55 percent of parents were battling chronic diseases, and 72 percent suffered from depression.

The children growing up in those families were also not faring well. About 50 percent of the 2,000-plus children who the foundation cared for were malnourished, and one-third of them were in poor health, the spokeswoman said, adding that the foundation's caseworkers have been working hard in the hopes of making a difference.

TEXT.P: Singaporean immigration authorities conceded Friday to Taiwan's request for the extradition of Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng and his wife who arrived at the city-state's airport earlier the same day on their way from Los Angeles to Myanmar.

However, Wang and his wife refused to board the Singapore Airlines flight SQ876 which was designated by the immigration authorities and was slated to make a stopover in Taiwan's Taoyuan International Airport on its way to Los Angeles.
Instead, they demanded to return to the United States on a flight direct to Los Angeles, according to the immigration authorities.

Earlier in the day, immigration officials of Singapore, which does not maintain ajudicial assistance accord with Taiwan, hinted that when flight SQ876 arrives in Taoyuan, Taiwan authorities can take the Wangs into custody.

The Wangs, who allegedly embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds before going on the lam, arrived at Singapore's Changi International Airport Friday morning after leaving the United States the previous day.

The Wangs fled to China late last year after two of the Rebar group's 120-odd member companies applied for insolvency restructuring. The fallout triggered a run on the Chinese Bank, another of the group's affiliates. Subsequent judicial investigations found that the couple and other family members and corporate executives were involved in many suspected irregularities, including fraud, embezzlement, breach of trust and insider trading.
Taiwan's judicial authorities and liaison officials posted in the city-state engaged in intensive negotiations with the Singaporean immigration authorities over the Wangs' extradition Friday morning.

The Singaporean authorities said before the negotiations that there was no reason for them to take the Wangs into custody as the couple had used authentic passports and normal travel papers for their entrance.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURE TAIWAN PRESIDENT NEEDS TO STRENGTHEN U.S. TIES: EX-PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 1 (CNA) 02/02/07 14:27:44 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Mending and strengthening Taiwan's relations with the United States will be an important mission of the next president of Taiwan, Premier Frank Hsieh said here Thursday.
According to Hsieh, Taiwan must maintain its credibility while dealing with the international community, and this can be achieved through frequent communication.

Taking U.S. concern over Taiwan's plan to reform its Constitution as an example, Hsieh said the key point in this issue is whether Taiwan has communicated effectively with the United States and emphasized that "it is consistent with the interests of the United States and of the world for Taiwan to practice democracy."
Hsieh said that Taiwan's democracy is a soft power with strong appeal to the Chinese people and that Taiwan's success demonstrates that full democracy can be achieved in Chinese societies.
Hsieh, who is in Washington, D.C. to attend the National Prayer Breakfast, made the remarks in response to questions by Taiwan reporters after the event.
Hsieh said he is seriously considering whether to run for the presidency in 2008 and what he can do for the country if he is elected.

Pointing out that one of the purposes of his U.S. trip is to listen to the opinions of various sectors in the United States, Hsieh said the manners displayed by U.S. politicians of different partisan affiliations at the National Prayer Breakfast has demonstrated the idea of "reconciliation and coexistence" that he advocates.

Although the politicians might not agree with President George W. Bush, they all stood up and clapped to welcome the the president's arrival, which strikes a sharp contrast with the situation in Taiwan in which political rivals treat each other as the enemy, Hsieh said.

Asked to comment on former President Lee Teng-hui's recent remarks that "it's wrong for Taiwan to pursue independence because it is already an independent country, " which has drawn strong criticism from pro-independence supporters that Lee is giving up on his pursuit of independence for Taiwan, Hsieh said he thinks the main point that Lee was trying to convey is that "Taiwan has already achieved independence."
Hsieh said this point is consistent with his own belief and the stance of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
According to Hsieh, the status quo of Taiwan is that it is a sovereign, independent state, and the Constitution that was drafted under a "one China" framework is a problem that the country is facing.

Urging the public to pay more attention to the contribution made by Lee to Taiwan's democratic development, Hsieh stressed that Lee played a crucial role in turning Taiwan into a democratic nation with the least social costs.

As to whether he has any plans to visit China before the presidential election, Hsieh said he does not intend to do so in light of the distrustful atmosphere in Taiwan politics, in which every politician visiting China is stigmatized as a colluder with the Chinese communists.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA LAUNCHES JOB MARKET MATCHMAKING GROUP

TEXT.P: A job market matchmaking group under the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) was launched in Taichung, central Taiwan Friday.

Speaking at the launching ceremony, CLA Minister Lee Ying-yuan urged the members of the new group to act as a go-between for those looking for work and those who are short of workers to help ease the jobless problem at the grass-roots level.
Lee said that more than 4,000 people applied to serve as the job market matchmakers and that the CLA recruited 393 of them after a series of tests.

He expressed the hope that all members of the group will serve with patience and enthusiasm and that they will go around the island this year to visit long-term jobless people and find suitable jobs for them to continue to cut the nation's unemployment rate, which stood at 3.91 percent last year, marking a six-year low.
CLA officials said that the group will work closely with employment service centers around the country in the hopes of reaching 100,000 jobless and helping 30,000 of them land jobs this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up 70 points to close at 7,810, with 34,328 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March rose 70 points to finish at 7,815, with 1,270 contracts traded, while June futures increased 72 points to close at 7,815, with 30 contract transactions. September futures moved up 87 points to close at 7,655, with 54 contracts traded, while December futures gained 58 points to finish at 7,630, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,740 for February, 7,745 for March, 7,743 for June, 7,568 for September and 7,572 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

February TE futures gained 3.1 points to close at 331.25, with 3,121 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up 3.45 points to finish at 331.4, with 77 contract transactions. June TE futures rose 3.7 points to finish at 329.55, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

February TF futures gained 11.2 points to close at 1,054.2, with 2,351 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 9.8 points to finish at 1,057.8, with 28 contracts traded. June TF futures rose 14.6 points to finish at 1,056.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR KUNG FU NOVELIST SIGNS AUTOGRAPHS AT TAIPEI BOOK FAIR

TEXT.P: Popular kung fu novelist Jin Yong, whose knight-errant novels have been devoured by Chinese people around the world, appeared at the Taipei International Book Fair Friday to sign autographs for fans.
In his first appearance at a book fair in Taiwan, the 83-year-old Jin Yong was awaited by a long queue of fans aged from six to 70 seeking his autograph.
Shanghai-born Jin Yong -- Hong Kong's most eminent man of letters whose real name is Dr. Louis Cha -- signed some 400 copies of his novels over a one-hour period.

Jin Yong, who has written 15 best-selling martial arts novels, is in Taipei mainly to meet his mentor at Cambridge University -- Dr. David McMullen -- who is currently in Taiwan doing research at Academia Sinica.

He was also scheduled to dine with National Chengchi University (NCU) President Wu Si-hua, who will tell him the NCU is preparing to confer an honorary doctorate on him in recognition of his outstanding long-term contribution to Chinese-language writing and literature.

On Saturday, the last day of his visit, Jin Yong will accompany McMullen on a visit to the National Palace Museum, to see a Sung-dynasty ceramics exhibition and a special exhibition on loan from the British Museum.

Jin Yong last visited Taipei in September 2005, when he attended a ceremony marking the launch of the "Jin Yong credit card" issued by Taiwan's Yuan Liou Publishing Co., which publishes most of his kung fu novels in Taiwan.
Most of his martial arts novels have been adapted for film and television.

The soft-spoken, quintessentially Chinese man is renowned not only as the author of 15 kung fu novels but as a veteran reporter, publisher and political commentator. He founded the Ming Pao newspaper and its sister publications.

He is considered one of the best and most prolific Chinese novelists of the modern era. But his 15 novels, written between 1955 and 1972, are more than just kung fu stories. Their pages burst with fantastic knight-errant tales of heroic swordsmen and beautiful heroines, intermingling romance, tragedy and comedy with Chinese and religious values.

Universities around the Chinese-speaking world have formed Jin Yong fan clubs, sponsored seminars or opened classes on his classic novels, in which, Chinese readers can immerse themselves in their cultural heritage from the language, calligraphy, art, music, traditional costumes, cuisine and martial arts that they find in the novels. Traditional Chinese culture, fantasy and history form the colorful backdrops for his works.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME OF CHINESE PETROLEUM CORP. TO BE CHANGED

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve Ruey-long Chen said Friday that the ministry is planning to change the name of Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) by adding "Taiwan" at the front of the name.
Chen said the name-change will be in line with the government's "name- rectification" policy for state-owned enterprises to avoid people mistaking Taiwanese companies for Chinese ones.
It will also bring substantial benefits for the future operations of the state- owned enterprises, Chen claimed.

He noted that as the name Taiwan Petroleum Corp. has already been claimed and registered, the CPC will have to use another name. The CPC will become the first state-owned enterprise under the ministry to highlight Taiwan in its name, he added.
The MOEA is also scheduled to announce next week whether other state-owned enterprises under the ministry will also have their names changed.
President Chen Shui-bian first instructed in December 2004 that the names of all institutes that could be mistaken for Chinese institutes should be changed, starting with state-owned enterprises.

The Executive Yuan restarted the discussion on the matter recently and the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party also urged state-owned enterprises that have "Chinese" in their names to change their names as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.052 to close at NT$32.916.
A total of US$802 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.885 and fluctuated between NT$32.744 and NT$32.960.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 75.49 points to close at 7,777.03.
The bourse opened at 7,754.16 and fluctuated between 7,801.63 and 7,751.53 during trading. A total of 3.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$87.02 billion (US$2.64 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both at 1 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent, cement stocks and construction issues both at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.28 percent, and textile stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 820 to 372, with 202 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL VOTE RECOUNT NECESSARY: KMT LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) hailed Friday a Kaohsiung District Court ruling that a vote recount is necessary for the Dec. 9 mayoral election in southern Kaohsiung city.

KMT legislative caucus members at a Legislative Yuan news conference said that they are set to initiate a law revision at the legislature to legalize "an automatic vote recount mechanism" to deal with similar cases in the future, as is the case in most advanced countries.

The Kaohsiung District Court ruled that the recount should begin from March 12 following a month-long probe, after Huang Chun-ying, the defeated KMT candidate, filed a suit with the court demanding that it nullify the election and invalidate the victory of Chen Chu -- incumbent mayor of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Huang lost to Chen by a slim margin of 1,114 votes, or 0.14 percent of the total ballots. There were more than 6,000 invalid votes in the election.

KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said that the KMT legislative caucus will propose a law amendment to allow for an automatic vote recount if there is only a difference between 1 percent and 2 percent between election winners and losers.
KMT Legislator Alex Fei said that a vote recount is required to serve justice and safeguard democratic values, and he urged Chen to face the consequences.
The Huang camp accused Chen's camp of making public a suspicious but unconfirmed videotape on the eve of the election showing a man purported to be a Huang supporter buying votes aboard a bus.
Huang ascribed his election defeat to the release of the videotape and alleged that the Chen camp orchestrated the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 290,500 SQ. M. OF LAND TURNED INTO PARKS IN GREENING PROJECTS

TEXT.P: Some 290,500 square meters of land around factories and construction sites, or an area equal to some 700 basketball courts, has been turned into parkland around the country under a government-initiated project to green inner cities and suburban areas, the Environment Protection Administration (EPA) reported Friday.

Since the greening project was launched in August 2006, 561 factories and construction sites have signed up to take part in the project -- turning areas or environment in their vicinity into park or green land -- as of the end of December, EPA officials said.
Meanwhile, the 561 factories and construction sites have also sponsored the clean-up and maintenance of 1,724 km of roads around the country during the period, the officials said.
In related news, the Water Resources Agency said a river conservation army was established Friday to act as guardians of rivers.
A total of 229 people will be recruited to join the river conservation army, with over a half of the total expected to be indigenous people, Water Resources Agency Commissioner Chen Shen-hsien said.
The 229 "river guardians" will be assigned to 12 aboriginal rural townships to help protect upstream areas of rivers, Chen said.
While they will be working to protect the upstream areas from being polluted during anti-flood periods, they are also expected to be trained as tour guides, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUP CLAIMS NEED TO CONTINUE INDEPENDENCE PURSUIT

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Society released a statement Friday claiming the urgency and necessity for Taiwan to continue its pursuit of independence in order to make Taiwan a "true country."
The statement appeared intended to reject a recent claim by former President Lee Teng-hui that there is no need for Taiwan to pursue independence because "Taiwan is already an independent country."

According to Lee, seeking independence is not only a "regressive" and "dangerous" move that will downgrade Taiwan's status from a sovereign independent state to a country that has not achieved independence, but also a denial of Taiwan's democratic achievements.
Taiwan needs to change its name, enact a new constitution and "seek membership in the United Nations" to become a "normal country, "Lee argued.
However, the Taiwan Society said Taiwan is only a sovereign, independent "political entity" but "not a country."
"This is not a self-degrading statement, but a cruel reality, " the group said.
Recognizing this fact long ago, pro-independence forerunners in Taiwan ignited the flame of Taiwan independence when the country was still under authoritarian rule, the group pointed out.
Claiming that democratization is a "sufficient condition" but "not a necessary condition" to establish a new country, the group said democratization does not automatically make Taiwan a country.

"Democratization has only allowed the people of Taiwan to retrieve their autonomy from an alien regime. The people of Taiwan must exercise their autonomy correctly before they can turn Taiwan into a true country," the group said.

As Taiwan has so far been unable to abandon the national title of Republic of China or terminate the Constitution, Taiwan can only remain a "political entity" that is struggling for its survival in the international community, it said.

It said changing the name of Taiwan and enacting a new constitution are steps that will make Taiwan a true country and achieve the goal of independence for Taiwan, adding that Taiwan must first become a true sovereign, independent country before it can become a "normal country."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOD WITH FALSE LABELING TO BE DESTROYED: DOH

TEXT.P: Department of Health officials said Friday that food and agricultural products with false labeling will be destroyed and the producers fined.

Chen Chih-lang, an official from the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation, made the remarks at a press conference in which ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lee Chen-nan revealed that ten of so-called "organic" vegetable soup packs available in markets carried fake certification describing it as coming from Japan.
Several producers even claim their products can cure cancer, Lee added.
In accordance with the Food Sanitation Management Act, food labeling or advertising should not be false, exaggerated or misleading and medical benefits cannot be claimed, Chen said.
Local government health authorities can order companies withdraw illegal products or correct the labeling, Chen said, adding that the products will be destroyed if the companies fail to do so.
Food labeling claiming medical effects could be fined between NT$200,000 and NT$1 million, Chen went on.

Chen Chun-shih, an official from the Council of Agriculture's (COA's) Agriculture and Food Agency, reminded the public that currently there are only four certified organic product labels recognized by the COA -- MOA, TOPA, TOAF and FOA -- and said the agency will offer more information about these certified organic products on their Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BANK TO OPEN LIAISON OFFICE IN VIETNAM

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission approved Thursday an application by Taiwan Shin Kong Commercial Bank to set up a liaison office in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam the bank's first in a foreign country, commission officials said that same day.

Considering that 75 percent of Taiwanese businessmen investing in Vietnam are in Ho Chi Minh City and other cities nearby, the bank decided to set up a liaison office there to collect business information and provide them with advisory services, they said.
Currently, other Taiwanese banks have established seven branch offices, 10 liaison offices and one subsidiary bank in Vietnam, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30 METRIC TONS OF TAINTED PORK SEIZED IN YUNLIN COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin County, central Taiwan (CNA) 02/02/07 17:58:58 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Law enforcement agents in Yunlin County seized 30 metric tons of tainted pork believed to be from dead and diseased hogs during a late night raid on five illegal slaughterhouses Thursday.
The agents arrested a suspect at one of the locations in Yuanchang township and were still trying to catch the ringleader and his accomplices who fled before the agents arrived.
The Public Prosecutor's Office in Yunlin County ordered the raid after receiving tip-offs that the illegal ring was operating out of a shack in a village in Yuanchang township.

A spokesman for the prosecutor's office said that in addition to 1,000 kg of hog carcasses that were being butchered in the shack, law enforcement agents found 6,000 kg of frozen pork in a walk-in freezer.
At four other locations, the agents seized more than 23,000 kg of frozen pork -- believed to be from dead and sick hogs.

The spokesman said the pork was apparently meant for the Luna New Year holiday, when meat will be in big demand. The ring is believed to have obtained dead and sick pigs at cheap prices from hog farms, which should have destroyed the dead animals.
In accordance with the Waste Disposal Act, those who ignore health concerns and sell questionable meat from sick and dead hogs could be sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLORECTAL CANCER INCIDENCE GROWS NEARLY 50% IN 10 YEARS

TEXT.P: The incidence rate of colorectal cancer has increased 43.5 percent during the period between 1994-2003, according to a survey released Friday by the Bureau of Health Promotion (BOHP).

Every year there are more than 8,000 people diagnosed with colorectal cancer in Taiwan on average, according to the results of the survey, which also indicated that over 4,000 people around the country die every year from this form of cancer.

Hsiao Chu-chun, head of the BOHP team in charge of cancer control and prevention, said that despite the high mortality that makes colorectal cancer the third largest cancer killer in Taiwan, most Taiwan people having little awareness of the disease.

Citing data the BOHP collected from 29 hospitals around Taiwan in 2004, Hsiao said that over 53 percent of the total colorectal cancer patients reported that year were either in the second or third stage.

The number of colorectal cancer patients diagnosed at its early stage only accounted for 17 percent of the entire population of patients suffering from the disease, lagging behind the ratio of 29 percent recorded by the U.S. National Cancer Data Base in 2003, Hsiao said.

There were also relatively fewer colorectal cancer patients in Taiwan living through the first five years since they were diagnosed than in the United States, the BOHP official added, saying they found that most Taiwan people do not have regular health checks, which poses a threat to Taiwan's efforts in cancer control and prevention.

The BOHP began a free stool test service in 2004 for people aged 50-69, but only 460,000 people have taken the test so far, according to the bureau, which indicated that such a test, if done regularly, could reduce the mortality rate of colorectal cancer by 18 percent- 33 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Terror hitlist named 25 Muslim soldiers Defence chiefs have launched an urgent investigation into how a gang of suspected Islamic terrorists obtained a list of names and addresses for 25 serving British Muslim soldiers as part of an alleged plot to kidnap and behead a serviceman.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIPEI MAYOR CLAIMS HE IS CLEAN, TRUSTS IN JUDICIARY

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed Friday that his name is clean and said that he looks forward to a fair judgment by the judiciary in a case related to his alleged misuse of special municipal fees while serving as mayor of Taipei.

Ma made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after it was widely speculated that the KMT chairman, who ended his eight-year mayoral term last December, might be indicted by Feb. 9 on charges of embezzling the special municipal funds earmarked for his discretionary use.

Claiming that he is clean and that he only followed the Executive Yuan's regulations in claiming reimbursement from the special mayoral discretionary fund, Ma, however, said that he is unable to predict what will happen in the future and added that he has made full preparations for all kinds of possible scenarios.
Ma, who is widely assumed to be the "pan-blue alliance's" best bet for the 2008 presidential election, also thanked the public for their concern over the case.

Meanwhile, it was reported that KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, Ma's predecessor, is very likely to serve as the party's chairman again if Ma steps down from the party's top post over a possible indictment.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight, was reluctant to comment on the issue, while Lee Hung-chun, a spokesman for the People First Party (PFP) -- the KMT's ally in the opposition "pan-blue alliance" -- said that his party will rally behind Ma and the KMT and called for a fair handling of the case.
But Lee said that the PFP will respect the KMT as to who will take over the party's helm should Ma resign.

KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih cited a notification issued Aug. 5, 1981 by the Ministry of Justice that he said proves Ma is innocent, as according to the ministry, "half of the special funds allocated for government agency heads are for their discretionary use and not subject to scrutiny by the relevant authorities."
Ma did nothing wrong with the funds, Wu claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP WANTS CARE FOR ECOLOGY WHILE PURSUING TECHNOLOGICAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed hope Friday that local governments will do their utmost to preserve the ecology while seeking technological development in an effort to maintain a clean living environment for future generations.
Lu made the remarks during a meeting with Taoyuan county officials on an inspection visit to County Hall.

In her address, Lu proposed the idea of dividing Taiwan into "four provinces" -- Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Taitung -- and "two administrative districts" covering mountainous areas and outlying islands.
The idea could serve as an inspiration to the central government for plans to adjust administrative areas, she said.
In response to questions on her intention to take part in the 2008 presidential election, Lu claimed she has "never thought" of participating.
Lu served as Taoyuan magistrate before taking her present post.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT TO SPONSOR SEMINAR ON IPR PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) will sponsor a seminar on intellectual property rights (IPR) protection Feb. 5-6 in Taipei, an AIT spokesman said Friday.
According to the spokesman, the two-day seminar will focus on "Meeting the Challenges of IPR Protection in Taiwan."

National Chengchi University's Graduate Institute of Intellectual Property and Licensing Executives Society, as well as several other institutes, including the U.S. Department of Justice and Taiwan's Ministry of Justice are involved in organizing the seminar.

The spokesman said the organizers will invite experts and professionals from Taiwan, Thailand and the United States to share their experiences in IPR protection. Both AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen Young and Minister of Justice Shih Mao-ling will speak at the opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE ASSOCIATIONS TO CULTIVATE CHERRY TREES IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/07 18:59:00 (By Yang Ming-chu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Japanese association of cherry cultivation and a group of friends of former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui in Japan will visit Taiwan next week to promote cherry cultivation.
This will be the third consecutive year that the two associations have donated cherry saplings and cultivated the saplings in Taiwan.
According to the schedule, the associations will arrive in Taiwan Feb. 8 to donate 1,000 cherry saplings to the Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association in Taiwan.
They will visit Nantou County in central Taiwan Feb. 9 and proceed to Tainan County in southern Taiwan Feb. 10 to witness several cherry cultivation ceremonies.

Lee will be invited to a dinner organized by the two associations in Taipei Feb. 10, and the Japanese guests will then visit a park in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan Feb. 11 to view cherry blossoms they donated previously.
The two associations plan to cultivate 10,000 cherry trees around Taiwan with the cooperation of their Taiwanese friends.

Among the Japanese groups that will visit Taiwan will be prominent writer Hirano Kumiko, whose newest book depicts elderly Taiwanese people's feeling about their lives under the rule of the Kuomintang after the Japanese colonial rule of the island.
Kumiko said in Tokyo Friday that she appreciates the opportunity to make such a visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CLARIFIES HIS STANCE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui attempted to clarify Friday several contentious points in a recent interview with a local magazine, claiming that reports about his forsaking Taiwan independence are not true.

Lee's explanation came in the form of an advertisement in the Liberty Times paid for by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, which sees Lee as its "spiritual leader." The headline of the ad said: "Lee Teng-hui insists on rectifying the nation's name, crafting a new constitution and establishing a normal country."

The ad came in the wake of an interview carried by the Next magazine that quoted the former leader as saying that "I'm not a supporter of Taiwan independence, nor have I ever advocated Taiwan independence."

The interview dropped a bombshell on Taiwan's political scene, as Lee, who floated a "go slow, be patient" policy regarding investment in China and defined relations between Taiwan and China as "special state-to-state" during his 12 years of presidency that ended in 2000, has been nicknamed "the godfather of Taiwan independence."
Lee said there has been no about-face, as Taiwan is already a sovereign independent country and there is no need to advocate the pursuit of Taiwan independence.

He noted that Taiwan has come a long way since the lifting of martial law in 1987 and the ending of the period of mobilization for the suppression of communist rebellion in 1991, claiming that the popular presidential election in 1996 and the first transfer of power between two different parties in 2000 prove that Taiwan is a sovereign and independent country.
"Why should we engage in self-denial and backpedal for the pursuit of independence?" he asked in the Next magazine interview.
Lee said Taiwan has to think about amending the Constitution, changing its name and joining the United Nations for it to become a normal country, adding that "this has been my long-standing stance."

He also attempted to deny that he wants to visit China, saying that what he actually said was that some people want to invite him to visit China, but "the current situation is not suitable." Those who visit China, he claimed, have "power or position in mind" and he added that he "won't do such a thing."
On the economic front, in which he was asked about his remarks on introducing Chinese capital to Taiwan, Lee said he was only trying to raise investment in Taiwan and attract foreign capital.

He noted that Taiwan investment in China has continued to set new highs in recent years. Statistics compiled by the U.S. State Department show that foreign investment in China has reached US$560 billion and that Taiwan has accounted for half of it, or 5.6 times the general budget of the central government for 2007.
Even more alarming has been the one-sided situation, with Taiwan continuing to pump money into China over the past two decades, he said.

Taiwan's economic doldrums are due to capital flight and overreliance on China, resulting in the hollowing out of the industry, Lee claimed, adding that the government needs to encourage industrial development and domestic investment, as well as the introduction of foreign capital.
He said he is not as fickle as some detractors have claimed, adding that the society has changed a great deal and that he naturally changes his priorities when dealing with problems.
"Right now, we only have the problem of national identity. We should build our own Taiwan culture and not increase ethnic division, because we're all Taiwanese in a new era," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Ruling coalition defeated in Senate.
The ruling coalition suffered a setback in the Senate Thursday when a motion introduced by the opposition on a controversial U.S. military base expansion project was approved with a vote of 152 to 146. The government was left looking embarrassed although the motion changed nothing in practical terms. It merely approved the government's position on the expansion plan to which three extreme leftist parties in the ruling camp had expressed their opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE TOURIST MAPS OF TAIWAN BEING DISTRIBUTED

TEXT.P: One million copies of a tourist map illustrating Taiwan's scenic spots and the road systems leading to them are being distributed free at more than a 100 locations throughout Taiwan from Friday.
The map, in the form of a folding brochure, has been prepared by the Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communication.
In addition to showing the road systems linking Taiwan's most famous scenic spots, the map also provides information on the distance between locations and rest areas on freeways.

The maps can be obtained at major airports, railway stations, information centers at freeway rest areas, passenger service centers at Taipei's mass rapid transit rail system and information centers at 13 national scenic areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANTED REBAR FOUNDER LEAVES SINGAPORE FOR LOS ANGELES
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/07 19:48:12 (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Wanted Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng and his wife were allowed to leave Singapore and head directly back to Los Angeles Friday after they refused to fly via Taiwan, where they face arrest for corruption and embezzlement.

The couple arrived at Singapore's Changi International Airport earlier in the day on their way from Los Angeles to Myanmar and immediately fell under close scrutiny from the Singapore authorities, despite the absence of a judicial assistance accord between Taiwan and Singapore.

Through intensive negotiations between the two sides, the Singapore immigration authorities originally agreed to facilitate Wang's extradition by arranging for the couple to fly a Singapore-Los Angeles flight that would include a stopover in Taiwan so that they could be arrested by the Taiwan authorities.
However, the couple refused to cooperate and demanded to return to the United States on a direct flight to Los Angeles.

The officials said a Dominican Republic passport held by Wang had been canceled by the Dominican Republic government at the request of Taiwan and that he might have problems entering the United States unless he has other passports.

However, as Wang's wife Wang Chin Shyh-ying holds a U.S. passport and Wang reportedly has a U.S. green card, it is still possible that the U.S. government might allow Wang to enter the country based on "humanitarian reasons," the officials said.
They said Taiwan officials posted in Los Angeles will try to negotiate with the United States authorities for the couple's extradition to Taiwan.

The Taipei District Prosecutor's Office officially accused the couple Jan. 12 of violating the Securities Transaction Act and breach of trust over their role in a series of financial scandals within the Rebar group.
The couple, who fled to China immediately before the scandals broke and later flew to the United States, was put on a most wanted list Jan. 15.

The scandals came to light early last month after the Rebar group's China Rebar Co. and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co. applied for insolvency restructuring, triggering a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar affiliate.
The Wangs allegedly embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds before going on the lam.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC DENIES HIGH NUMBER OF CONTENTIOUS VOTES IN 2004 ELECTION

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission (CEC) officials denied Friday that as many as five contentious ballots were found in each polling station on average in a recount of the 2004 presidential election.
The officials said the Kaohsiung District Court's claim of the high number was far from the truth.
They noted that there were 13,749 polling stations nationwide in the 2004 presidential election and that there were 40,570 contentious ballots.
But in a recount ordered by the Supreme Court, those that were actually calculated wrongly totaled only 3,955 votes, averaging 0.288 votes per polling station.

The officials said the number of contentious votes was high mainly because of a change in the election rules that year that stated the stamp on a candidate had to be confined to a rectangle on the top of the candidate to be counted valid.

The actual number of incorrect ballots numbered only 3,955, with the remaining 36,615 the result of lawyers representing the two parties using their litigation skills to argue that they were controversial when in fact they were not.
They said the recount did not sway the election outcome, which saw President Chen Shui-bian win by a little more than 25,000 votes against his rival, Lien Chan of the main opposition Kuomintang.

The CEC made the statement after the Kaohsiung District Court granted a request for a recount by defeated Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chun-ying of the KMT in the Dec. 9 election, who lost to his rival Chen Chu by a mere 1,114 votes, or 0.14 percent of the total votes cast.

The court ruling said that based on the 2004 presidential election recount, which found that every polling station had at least five controversial ballots on average, debatable ballots across Kaohsiung City's 839 polling stations could be several times the narrow margin -- in an election that counted more than 6,000 invalid votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSPECTS ARMY TRAINING BASE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of the Chengkungling army training base in Taichung, central Taiwan Friday to boost the morale of soldiers stationed there ahead of the Lunar New Year, which falls on Feb. 18.

Accompanied by Minister of National Defense Lee Jye and Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai, Chen arrived at the military training base for conscripts to greet and dine with the military personnel stationed there, including 280 women.
Because the personnel will have to stay on duty during the Lunar New Year festival, Chen expressed gratitude to them for their contribution for the country.

A long-awaited National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq, presented to President Bush by the intelligence community yesterday, outlines an increasingly perilous situation in which the United States has little control and there is a strong possibility of further deterioration, according to sources familiar with the document.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PROMOTE DOMESTICALLY GROWN FRUITS AT HOME

TEXT.P: The government aims to have Taiwanese-grown fruit take 20 percent of the one- sixth domestic market share that imported fruit currently enjoys, within the next three years, said the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) Friday.
Su Jia-chyuan, the COA Minister, declared the goal at a news conference to the launch a campaign promoting homegrown fruits in the domestic market.

Annual fruit consumption in Taiwan creates a market worth around NT$70 billion, and it's a pity that imported fruit holds one-sixth of the market, he said, continuing that as Taiwanese fruit enjoys the advantages of high quality and a good reputation, it should therefore be able to recapture some of the market share now held by foreign products.

The COA is assisting local governments of 15 major fruit-yielding counties to set up a platform to promote the county's specialties and facilitate direct orders from around the country, including online orders, officials said.

They said the COA will also cooperate with farmers' associations and retail businesses to set up sections to specially feature homegrown fruits in some 40 supermarkets country-wide, saying the strategy is to highlight native products, attract consumers' attention, and significantly boost purchases in the run-up to the Lunar New Year, a period that traditionally brings a high demand for agricultural goods.

Su said Taiwanese fruits have faced fierce competition from abroad since the country joined the Word Trade Organization, and the COA is making significant efforts to persuade domestic consumers to buy local when shopping.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT FROM MAC ON EX-PRESIDENT'S REPORTED HOPE TO VISIT CHINA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) refused to comment Friday about a reported hope of former President Lee Teng-hui to visit China, saying that a ban on travel to China is restricted to high ranking government officials and agents involved in national security operations.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun made the remarks at a regular news briefing in response to reporters' questions about a recent report by the Next Magazine that Lee hopes to visit China and that he wants the government to open Taiwan to Chinese tourists and capital.

Lee, now the so-called "spiritual leader" of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , also told the magazine that he never supported Taiwan independence as Taiwan is already an independent sovereignty and there is no need for the country to pursue formal independence.
According to Liu, the MAC will not comment on the issue as every individual in a democratic society is free to air his or her views.

In response to speculation that Lee has once again changed his attitude toward Taiwan's future, TSU Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia said that Lee will clearly explain his stance on the issue in the local media, including print media and radio stations, in the coming days.
According to Lin, Lee will also take part in a TSU-sponsored concert in commemoration of the 228 Incident to make his stance on the issue well known to the party and the public.
Many supporters of the TSU and Lee have called the party and relevant organizations to protest over Lee's remarks in the Next Magazine.

In an effort to assuage the public anger provoked by Lee's latest statement about Taiwan's future, the TSU ran an advertisement in major print media Friday in which it said that "the former president still insists on writing a new constitution for Taiwan and on changing the country's official title to make it a normal nation."

To allow the public to gain a comprehensive understanding of the party's stance and ideals in this regard, TSU lawmakers will increase their presence through call-in programs and letters to newspapers, Lin said.
It was also reported that many backers of the Association of Lee Teng-hui's Friends at home and abroad were very disappointed with Lee's words and have suggested disbanding their units.

According to an official at the association's national headquarters, Lee is not against Taiwan independence and everyone has "misunderstood" his remarks. She said that many of Lee's backers have accepted her explanation and have agreed not to dissolve their local branches.

The world is already committed to centuries of warming, shifting weather patterns and rising seas from the atmospheric buildup of smokestack and tailpipe gases that trap heat, but warming can be substantially blunted with prompt action, according to experts of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change of the United Nations. In its fourth assessment since 1990 of the causes and consequences of climate change, the panel points out that carbon dioxide other heat-trapping greenhouse gases were the main drivers of warming since 1950.

Russia and Iran -- which hold nearly half the world's natural-gas reserves -- are talking about creating an OPEC-like organization for gas, a move that has the potential to unsettle energy markets and redraw geopolitical alignments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLISHING INDUSTRY REVIVAL LAW TO PROTECT TAIWAN'S DIVERSITY: GIO

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will protect the diversity of Taiwan's publications and the needs of disadvantaged publishers by drafting a law aimed at reinvigorating the local publishing industry, GIO Minister Cheng Wen-tsang said Thursday.
Cheng made the remarks while receiving delegates from publishers from South Korea and Thailand.
During his meeting with the Korean delegates, Cheng said Taiwan's publishing industry is unique in that the content of local publications is very diversified.
In addition, local publishers accept new things very fast, he added.
Cheng told the delegates that Taiwan should learn from them in passing on cultural values, and praised their achievements in children's books, animation and digital publication.

Speaking on the market for Chinese-language publications, Cheng claimed that Taiwan's use of traditional Chinese characters makes it easier for Taiwanese to be connected with classical Chinese culture.

Cheng used National Palace Museum art as an example, saying that Taiwan college students can understand the words in ancient Chinese books or paintings very easily, while claiming that their Chinese counterparts who use simplified characters cannot.
Later, during his meeting with the Thai delegates, Cheng thanked them for choosing to feature Taiwan at the Bangkok International Bookfair 2007, which will be held from March 28-April 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH MUSEUM ARTIFACTS TO BE EXHIBITED IN NATIONAL PALACE MUSEUM

TEXT.P: A total of 271 artifacts collected by the British Museum, valued at more than NT$5 billion, will be exhibited in the National Palace Museum (NPM) from Feb. 4 to May 27, the NPM announced in a press conference Friday.

The exhibition, "Treasures of the World's Cultures: The British Museum after 250 years", brings these historical relics from the U.K. to Taiwan for the first time and will be a part of celebrations marking the reopening of the NPM, which is entering its 80th year, NPM Director Lin Mun-lee said.

"We are expecting a very exciting week. Following the Grand View, this exhibition will be one of the most important events for the NPM this year," Lin said. Grand View is an exhibition of painting, calligraphy and Ju Ware of the Northern Sung Dynasty.

The NPM has designed three different visiting plans with time spans of 30, 60 and 120 minutes to cover the top 10, 20 and 42 recommended artifacts, which include items from different eras and regions of pre-history, Mesopotamia, ancient Egypt, ancient Greece, early Europe, Medieval Europe and the Renaissance. The display area, which is located in the Library Building, will be separated into 13 zones, according to the time period and place of origin.

Among the ten most notable items are The Unlucky Mummy wooden mummy-board, Queen Puabe's Lyre, Statuette of Hermes, Bust of the Emperor Hadrian, Bust of Antinous, and a cast gold pectoral of a chief or priest in South America.

The exhibition is important for the British Museum not only because it takes place in Taiwan for the first time, but also because the displayed items reflect humanity's achievements from both the past and present, said Andrew Burnett, Deputy Director of the British Museum.

Starting from Feb. 3, the NPM will also be holding its first NPM Outdoors arts festival. The festival has invited world-renowned performing groups, such as Japanese national treasure "Noh Theatre, " and Ming Hwa Yuan Taiwanese Opera Troupe, the Ju Percussion Group and the U-Theatre Group.
Noh Theatre master Umewaka Rokuro will share with the public a suspenseful performance of The Lion and widely-acclaimed Concubine Yang, produced by samisen master Yoshizumi Kosayo.
The performances will be held outdoors and are open to the public free of charge to allow visitors the opportunity to come face-to-face with these famous performing groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABRI SIGNS MEMORANDUM OF COOPERATION WITH U.S. ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: The Architecture and Building Research Institute (ABRI) under the Ministry of The Interior signed a memorandum of cooperation with the U.S. based APA-The Engineered Wood Association Friday to boost applications of eco-friendly wood- frame construction and materials in Taiwan.
ABRI Director Ho Ming-chin signed the "Memorandum of Cooperation on Wood-Framed Construction Technology" with APA's Executive Vice President Tom Williamson at the institute's Taipei headquarters.

According to Ho, wood-frame construction is the best choice of construction methods meeting the requirements of green building--a construction approach that responds to global environmental and sustainable development concerns. These requirements are measured against several indicators in EEWH (ecology, energy savings, waste reduction, health)--Taiwan's green building evaluation system.
The ABRI invited AIT Taipei Office Deputy Director Robert Wang, heads of various local architectural associations, and experts in wood-frame construction to attend the signing ceremony.

Ho said the institute, being at the forefront of Taiwan's green building technology developments, will actively promote the application of environmentally responsible wood-frame construction and materials in the country following the signing of the memorandum.

DOC.HEADLINE: SITUATION UNDER CONTROL REGARDING REBAR FOUNDER'S FLIGHT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The government remains in control of the situation surrounding wanted Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng and his wife, despite Singapore's move to repatriate the pair back to the United States, according to a statement released Friday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

MOFA Deputy Director General of Information and Cultural Affairs Yen Fei-pi read a three-point statement at a press conference held by the MOFA to explain the government's efforts to stop the suspects, who allegedly embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds before going on the lam, from fleeing to Myanmar.

The statement first stated that the government had held accurate information regarding the Wangs' movement before they boarded on a Singapore-bound flight in Los Angeles Thursday, and had therefore successfully frustrated the couple's attempt to flee to a third country.

Second, the government had conducted negotiations with Singaporean authorities concerning the Wangs' case and provided them with all the relevant information before those authorities decided to repatriate the couple back to the United States, a decision which Taiwan respects.
Third, the government is keeping the situation under control, and will continue to apply all of its power to manage the issue.

Asked whether the government has been at a loss as to what to do during the pursuit to nab the Wangs, Yeh answered that the Wangs would have been successful in fleeing to Myanmar if the government were at a loss.

The wanted couple arrived at Singapore's Changi International Airport Friday morning after leaving the U.S. the previous day. They fled to the U.S. from China late last year after two of the Rebar group's 120-odd member companies applied for insolvency restructuring.

The fallout triggered a run on the Chinese Bank, another of the group's affiliates. Subsequent judicial investigations found that the couple, other family members and corporate executives were involved in many suspected irregularities, including fraud, embezzlement, breach of trust and insider trading.
Earlier, Taiwan's judicial authorities and liaison officials posted in the city- state engaged in intensive negotiations with the Singaporean immigration authorities over the Wangs' extradition.

The Singaporean authorities said before the negotiations that there was no reason for them to take the Wangs into custody as the couple had used authentic passports and normal travel papers to enter the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS FIRST ROUND IN SOFTBALL OLYMPIC QUALIFYING SERIES
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/02/07 21:59:35 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has four victories in the first two days of the Asia-Oceania Women's Softball Olympic Qualifying Series, making it almost certain that its national team will compete in the final for the right to go to the 2008 Olympics in Beijing.

The qualifying series between six national teams -- North Korea, South Korea, Singapore, New Zealand, the Philippines and Taiwan -- is being played at the softball field in Tainan's Hoshunliao Sports Park. The seven-day event will continue until Feb. 7.
On Thursday, Taiwan's team, known as "Chinese Taipei," defeated New Zealand 10:3 in six innings and followed with another 12:2 victory over Singapore, ending the match after five innings.
In the second day of competition Friday, Chinese Taipei first trounced South Korea 7:0 to end the match after five innings, and then defeated North Korea 5:2.
Chinese Taipei's pitcher, Lai Sheng-jun allowed South Korea only two hits in the first four innings.

Although North Korea applied pressure on Chinese Taipei by scoring two runs in the first inning, the Taiwanese team managed to make four hits in a row in the fourth inning to score four runs and followed with another run in the sixth inning.
The six teams are fighting it out in a double round robin of 33 matches in total. The top two teams will go on to contest a best of three finals series.

Given the advantages accruing from its excellent scores in the first round, the Taiwanese team is almost certain to be in the final, even if it loses the next two matches in the second round to New Zealand and North Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT COMPLAINS TO SOLDIERS ABOUT OPPOSITION OBSTACLES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, during his inspection tour of military facilities on a front line islet, Friday criticized the opposition for blocking government budget bills in the legislature and delaying the delivery of new arms to the forces.
Chen made his visit to Wuchiu, a small group of islets near Kinmen island with a total area slightly over 1 square kilometer, to boost the morale of garrison soldiers.
Chen, in his address to the soldiers, stressed the importance of Wuchiu as holding a key position on Taiwan's front line with China.

He said the strategic value of Wuchiu is not just relevant to the place itself, but to Taiwan's overall national security. He told them thatthe assurance of Taiwan's national security and the safeguard of Taiwan's democratic system is a cornerstone for the safety and stability of the Asia-Pacific region.
He then pointed to the awkward situation encountered in dealing with arms purchases and other government budgetary measures.

Certain opposition party insisted on putting at the very top of the list the so- called 'Organic Act of the Central Election Commission', a highly politicized and party-centric bill, and therefore obstructed the whole legislative agenda,he said.

He said the opposition's movefroze out the central government general budget bill and another couple of dozen bills, including the major arms purchases, seriously hampering the forces' renewal of arms and again hampering military preparations, a result he called regrettable.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in last legislative session initiated a bill to restructure the Central Election Commission. According to the bill, the commission is to be made up by members recommended by political parties in proportion to the parties' legislative seats, with the limitation that no single party could control more than forty percent of the seats on the 17-member commission.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which currently enjoys exclusive power to name all members through the premier, opposes the new formula. Disputes over the bill resulted in a total lack of progress on the general budget and other bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTION REJECTS INDICTMENT REQUEST AGAINST KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office decided Friday not to indict Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu over allegations that she had made false vote-buying accusations against her rival Huang Chun-ying on the eve of last December's mayoral election.

Huang, the candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , asked prosecution authorities to place charges against Chen and three campaign aides, after losing the Dec. 9 mayoral election by a narrow margin, over what he called their violation of the Public Officials Election and Recall Law.

According to Huang, the Chen campaign's presentation of a video at a late night news conference ahead of the election allegedly showing vote-buying on a bus returning from a Huang rally had seriously tarnished his clean image and hobbled his chances of electoral victory.
Huang claimed that the allegations were a plot of the ruling Decmocratic Progressive Party (DPP) to win the election by smearing him.
After extensive investigations, the prosecutor's office said in a ruling that the vote-buying incident was not staged by the Chen Chu campaign.

A careful scrutiny of the videotape presented by the Chen campaign indeed showed that two men were giving cash to passengers aboard the bus and reminding them to vote for Huang, the prosecution authorities said, adding that some individuals aboard the bus were wearing the Huang campaign vests.
It was understandable that the videotape would lead the Chen campaign into believing that somebody in the Huang campaign was bribing voters with cash, the prosecution said in the ruling.

Against this backdrop, the ruling said none of the four accused should be prosecuted as they didn't purposely defamed Huang. "They were just telling facts while presenting the video, " the prosecution ruling concluded.
The three other accused were DPP Legislator Kuan Pi-ling, Chen Chu's chief campaign manager Chen Chi-mai and her spokesman Hsiao Yu-jen.
After learning of the prosecution's ruling, Hsiao said it is hoped that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Huang Chun-ying can make a public apology over their false accusation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 3, or the 16th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1468: Johann Gutenberg, a German goldsmith who developed the letterpress printing method and oil-based inks, dies in obscurity. His "Mazarin Bible" (1455) is believed to be the first book printed with such type.
1488: Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Diaz, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope, lands on Africa's eastern coast. He is the first European to land on African soil.
1830: Greece is declared independent under the protection of Britain, France, and Russia at a London conference.
1867: Prince Mutsuhito becomes Emperor Meiji at the age of 14. His reign in Japan lasted until 1912.
1913: The 16th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified, giving the government the power to impose and collect taxes on income.
1919: The League of Nations holds its first meeting in Paris with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson presiding.
1924: Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1919, dies at the age of 67.
1930: Ho Chi Minh establishes the Vietnamese Communist Party in Hong Kong.
1931: An earthquake jolts Hawks Bay in New Zealand, killing 256 people.
1943: British bombers pound the German city of Hamburg.
1945: U.S. troops recover Manila in the Philippines from Japanese forces during World War II.
1960: British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tells the astonished white politicians in the Cape Town parliament that they should accept racial equality.
1966: The unmanned Soviet spaceship Luna IX lands on the moon and sends signals back to Earth.
1969: Yasser Arafat is elected as the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1973: Fighting in Vietnam comes to a halt when a cease-fire goes into effect.
1974: Dr. Arthur A. Kimball, director of the International Training Section of the U.S. Agency for International Development, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The Indian Ocean satellite communications ground station in Taiwan begins operations, providing improved telephone service to Europe and Africa.
1974: The ROC's agricultural technical cooperation with Honduras is extended for two years.
1977: China Steel Corp.'s Kaohsiung mill begins operations.
1978: The European Economic Community and Communist China initial their first trade agreement.
1989: P.W. Botha resigns as chief of South Africa's ruling party.
1989: A military coup topples strongman Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay, ending his eight successive presidential terms and 35 years of rule.
1992: A fight breaks out in a camp for Vietnamese boat refugees in Hong Kong, resulting in 18 deaths.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces the lifting of the United States' trade embargo against Vietnam.
1996: An earthquake rocks Lijiang in southwestern China, killing more than 302 people.
2000: An A300-600R airbus of China Airlines, carrying 225 passengers, departs Taipei for Manila, formally resuming direct air links between Taiwan and the Philippines after they had been suspended for four months.
2001: One hundred and fifty practitioners and supporters of Zhong Gong, a form of Chinese kung fu which emphasizes the use of inner strength to toughen one's body, stage a parade around Guam to call for the release of founder Zhang Hongbao.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Living upon the poorest fare with cold water for drink and with my bent arms for a pillow, I could yet find pleasure in such a life, whereas riches and honors acquired through the sacrifice of what is right would be to me as unreal as a mirage."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTION REJECTS INDICTMENT REQUEST AGAINST KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office decided Friday not to indict Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu over allegations that she had made false vote-buying accusations against her rival Huang Chun-ying on the eve of last December's mayoral election.

A careful scrutiny of the videotape presented by the Chen campaign indeed showed that two men were giving cash to passengers aboard the bus and reminding them to vote for Huang, the prosecution authorities said, adding that some individuals aboard the bus were wearing the Huang campaign vests.
It was understandable that the videotape would lead the Chen campaign into believing that somebody in the Huang campaign was bribing voters with cash, the prosecution said in the ruling.
