DOC.HEADLINE: WANTED REBAR FOUNDER FLEES AGAIN TO U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/03/07 12:13:25 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Disgraced Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng and his wife, who face arrest in Taiwan for their roles in a series of financial scandals within the business group, returned to Los Angeles Friday after their attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore was thwarted by the Singapore authorities.

As both the Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports held by Wang have been canceled, Wang was held by U.S. immigration authorities upon his arrival at the Los Angeles International Airport.
However, Wang's wife Wang Chin She-ying, who holds a U.S. passport, is not expected to face any problems entering the United States.

Taiwan officials posted in the United States said they are still negotiating with the U.S. authorities in the hope that Wang can be returned to Taiwan. The two countries do not have an extradition treaty.

In Taipei, Minister of Foreign Affairs deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-pi said Taiwan is maintaining close communication with the United States to try to make the United States understand that Wang's case is not a simple immigration case.
However, it is up to the United States to decide how it will handle the case, and Taiwan will respect the decision made by the United States, Yeh said.
The Wangs, who have allegedly embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds, fled to China late last year just before the scandal broke, from where they flew to the United States.

The couple departed from Los Angeles Wednesday for Myanmar via Singapore and immediately fell under close scrutiny from the Singapore authorities upon their arrival at Singapore's Changi International Airport early Friday.

Through intensive negotiations with the Taiwan authorities, Singapore originally agreed to facilitate Wang's extradition by arranging for the couple to take a Singapore-Los Angeles flight that would include a stopover in Taiwan so that they could be arrested by the Taiwan authorities.
However, the couple refused to cooperate and demanded to return to the United States on a direct flight to Los Angeles.

The Rebar scandals came to light early last month after the Rebar group's China Rebar Co. and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co. applied for insolvency restructuring, triggering a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar affiliate.
The Taipei District Prosecutor's Office accused the couple Jan. 12 of violating the Securities Transaction Act and breach of trust and put them on Taiwan's most-wanted list Jan. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES TO HOLD EXPLANATORY SESSIONS ON PRESIDENT'S REQUEST

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) will meet Feb. 13-14 to review documents relating to President Chen Shui-bian's request for a constitutional interpretation aimed at blocking the continuing trial of the "state affairs fund" case in which his wife is a defendant, a Judicial Yuan spokesman said Saturday.

Constitutional law scholars and experts will also be invited to the two-day explanatory session to give opinions and views on the high-profile case involving the head of state's immunity and right to confidentiality, the spokesman said.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai filed the interpretation request with the CGJ Jan. 25 on behalf of Chen in hope of clarifying the constitutionality of the court proceedings of the "state affairs fund" case.

Cho also filed an injunction petition asking the Judicial Yuan to order the Taipei District Court to immediately stop the trial and repeal its previous ruling on opening supposedly "secret" files relating to the case.

"The grand justices feel the need to collect more information and about the issue, " the Judicial Yuan spokesman said, adding that the invitation of academics to present their views and insights is in compliance with the Enforcement Rules for the Law of the Interpretation Procedures for Grand Justices.
The spokesman further said the convening of the two-day explanatory session does not necessarily mean that the CGJ will come to a conclusion on the case soon.

First lady Wu Shu-jen, along with three former and incumbent senior aides at the Presidential Office, is facing trial at the Taipei District Court after she and Chen were named by a public prosecutor as "joint perpetrators" in an embezzlement case involving the alleged misuse of the president's discretionary "state affairs fund."

In a lengthy document submitted to the CGJ Jan. 25, the Presidential Office said the interpretation request is aimed at defending the constitutional status of the presidency, maintaining the democratic system and protecting the sanctity of the Constitution.

Since the president is protected by Article 52 of the Constitution, the statement argued that the court cannot ask the president to testify during the investigation process and court hearing or to surrender secret documents or to even hear the case. The president must also be entitled to litigation immunity and cannot be prosecuted until his term expires, the statement added.

It further said the Taipei District Court had infringed upon the president's executive privileges and risked leaking state secrets by opening the secret files relating to the "state affairs fund" case.

Chen has denied any wrongdoing with regard to the special "state affairs fund " and has claimed he has not lined his pockets with the fund. He has promised to resign if his wife is found guilty in the first trial and has said history will return justice to him and the judicial process will clear his name.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Budget open to accounting
The public can now demand full accounting of funds spent by government agencies, including pork funds allocated to legislators, under a special provision inserted in the R1.126-trillion General Appropriations Act for 2007, Sen. Franklin Drilon said yesterday.
The Philippine Daily InquirerG 49 inmates escape from Kidapawan jail
KIDAPAWAN CITY, Philippines -- Between 20 and 25 heavily armed men, believed to be members of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), raided the North Cotabato provincial jail and freed three suspected bombers and 46 other inmates early Friday, authorities said.
The Philippine StarG Govt cant go after Tan firms
The government has no basis in going after the assets of beer and tobacco magnate Lucio Tan, his lawyer told The STAR yesterday.
The Manila TimesG MILF springs 49 inmates from jail
Muslim insurgents using grenade launchers blasted their way into the Kidapawan jail in North Cotabato early Friday and freed 49 inmates, including two Jemaah Islamiah bombing suspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
1ST INTERNATIONAL CRUISE OF 2007 TO ARRIVE IN KEELUNG

TEXT.P: The Albatros, the first non-regular passenger liner carrying foreign visitors this year, is scheduled to arrive at Keelung Harbor Feb. 4, a spokesman for the Keelung Harbor Bureau (KHB) said Saturday.
The cruise, scheduled to start from Okinawa in Japan, will arrive in Keelung and head south to Kaohsiung later that same day, the spokesman said.

The 28,000 tonne Albatros, a Bahamas-registered ship, will be carrying 580 crew and nearly 600 tourists from Europe and America for sightseeing on a schedule arranged by the China Travel Service (Taiwan).
The sightseeing destinations include scenic spots in Taipei city and suburbs, Sun Moon Lake in central Nantou County and the Taroko National Park in eastern Hualien County.
The KHB has a target of processing 30,000 tourists from non-regular international cruises in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO HELP LOCAL MANUFACTURERS TAP EAST EUROPEAN MARKET

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will head a trade delegation of machinery manufacturers to Eastern Europe in May to help domestic manufacturers explore the market there, a TAITRA official said Saturday.

The official noted that as more and more East European countries have entered or are preparing to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) , trade information about these countries is becoming more transparent.

Judging from the statistics, there is a trend that more and more East European countries are shifting their purchase sources from Western Europe to more competitive Asian countries, the official added.
TAITRA is scheduled to hold three trade seminars in Poland, Ukraine and Russia, respectively, from May 15-27.

In addition to inviting buyers in these East European countries to trade consulting talks with the Taiwan delegates, TAITRA will also arrange several visits for domestic manufacturers to their East European counterparts or trade organizations there.
Domestic manufacturers in the electric or electronic machinery industries who are interested in joining the delegation can apply to TAITRA before Feb. 10, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANTED REBAR FOUNDER TAKEN INTO CUSTODY BY U.S. AUTHORITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/03/07 15:18:11 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Wanted Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng was taken into custody by U.S. authorities Friday soon after his return to Los Angeles following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore, Taiwan officials posted in the United States said later that day.

Wang, whose U.S. visa was canceled after both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports were revoked, was held and questioned for more than two hours by U.S. immigration officials upon his arrival at Los Angeles International Airport, the officials said.
Wang was later taken to a detention center and U.S. immigration authorities are expected to hold a hearing within seven days to decide how they will deal with him, they said.
Wang's wife Wang Chin She-ying, who returned to Los Angeles with Wang, was allowed to enter the country because she holds a valid U.S. passport, according to the officials.

In Taipei, Ministry of Foreign Affairs deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-pi said Taiwan respects the United States' handling of the case and will continue to negotiate with the U.S. authorities in the hope that Wang can be returned to Taiwan.
The Wangs, who have allegedly embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds, fled to China late last year just before the Rebar scandal broke, from where they flew to the United States.

The couples departed from Los Angeles Wednesday for Myanmar via Singapore and immediately fell under close scrutiny from the Singapore authorities upon their arrival at Singapore's Changi International Airport early Friday.

Through intensive negotiations with the Taiwan authorities, Singapore originally agreed to facilitate Wang's arrest by arranging for the couple to take a Singapore-Los Angeles flight that would include a stopover in Taiwan so that they could be grabbed by the Taiwan authorities.
However, the couple refused to cooperate and demanded to return to the United States on a direct flight to Los Angeles.

The Rebar scandals came to light early last month after the Rebar group's China Rebar Co. and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co. applied for insolvency restructuring, triggering a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar affiliate.
The Taipei District Prosecutor's Office accused the couple Jan. 12 of violating the Securities Transaction Act and breach of trust and put them on Taiwan's most-wanted list Jan. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: War at Stadium, one police officer killed.
Fightings between soccer fans during a Serie A Palermo-Catania match led to a large-scale violence Friday night in the Sicilian city of Catania. One policeman was killed while attempting to deal with fighting. Some 150 people were injured in the incident. The Italian soccer federation FIGC has called off all matches indefinitely.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED ABOUT CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS IN TAIWAN: FORMER PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/03/07 16:54:21 (By Chiehyu Lin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government appears concerned with constitutional reforms in Taiwan and has hopes Taiwan's government can always keep it informed of the latest developments in this regard, former Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Hsieh made the remarks in response to media inquiries during a visit to Tidal Basin, a scenic spot in Washington, D.C. Hsieh headed a delegation on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian that attended the National Prayer Breakfast held the previous day.
Asked in what way the U.S. is concerned about Taiwan's constitutional reform plan, Hsieh said the U.S. government is skeptical whether Taiwan would honor its previous promise on the issue.
Hsieh said he told U.S. officials that many things in Taiwan are not under the government's control and that a lot of situations cannot be anticipated now that Taiwan is a democratic country.
In his view, Hsieh said the two sides should increase communications so that they can more easily predict each other's actions or reactions.

He told reporters that it would not be proper for Taiwan to act differently from the information it gave to the U.S. in advance. To his best understanding, Hsieh said, the U.S. government was "surprised" by Taiwan's actions on several previous occasions.

The U.S. authorities do not want Taiwan to deceive them, Hsieh went on, adding that Taiwan should offer frank explanations to the U.S. side whenever it comes up with new policy initiations that may cause U.S. concern.

Although it is difficult to control the development of democracy, Taiwan's leaders should refrain from "talking too fast" and should keep their promises, Hsieh said, adding that when he returned to Taipei, he would inform the government of his opinion on Taiwan-U.S. relations, which is that "the two sides share same strategic interests but need to repair and strengthen bilateral ties."

Asked about U.S. concerns over Taiwan's delay in carrying out its plan to purchase arms from the United States, Hsieh claimed that consensus has been reached between the ruling and opposition parties on the issue and that the legislature will pass a long-delayed arms procurement bill by March or April.

DOC.HEADLINE: HON HAI GROUP RANKED AS `DREAM' MANUFACTURING FIRM TO WORK FOR: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of Taiwan's office workers selected the high-tech Hon Hai Group as their "dream" manufacturing company to work for, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

The survey, which was conducted by online manpower firm www.1111.com.tw from Jan. 19-Feb. 2 found that 61.75 percent of the respondents hope to work for Hon Hai, followed by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. Ltd. (TSMC) at 43.65 percent and ASUSTek Computer Inc. at 28.57 percent.
The survey, which received 1,260 valid samples from office workers around the country, had an error margin of 2.8 percentage points.
In the service sector, the state-run Taiwan Power Company was ranked as the most popular firm to work for due to its handsome bonus, followed by China Airlines and Acer Group.

In the financial and banking sector, Chunghwa Post Co. Ltd., which has seen a diversification in its operations in the last few years, was chosen as the most popular finance firm to work for, followed by the Bureau of National Health Insurance and Cathay Financial Holding Co.

Wu Ruey-ying, deputy director-general of the 1111 data bank, said more and more employees are choosing state-run firms as their dream companies to work for due to the stability and the high salaries these companies offer, especially after the recent financial crisis triggered by credit card debts and the run on the failing Chinese Bank.

By gender, 52.38 percent of the male respondents chose high-tech firms as their first selection for new jobs, followed by government officials at 21.9 percent, and medical doctors at 20.16 percent, while 26.35 percent of women respondents ranked secretary or special assistant as their dream job, followed by public relations workers at 23.97 percent, and entertainers or fashion models at 22.7 percent.
Asked about their reasons for choosing a particular job, 52.22 percent said personal interest was their top concern, followed by salary and welfare or added value attached to the jobs.
Wu suggested that office workers should be professional and progressive if they want a good position in the job market.

DOC.HEADLINE: WVT APPEALS FOR HELP FOR POOR KIDS

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan (WVT) , a Christian charity dedicated to humanitarian relief, called on the public Saturday to help some 40,000 children around the island whose parents are too poor to pay their school tuition fees.

A WVT official noted that thanks to the help of many individuals and enterprises last year, these children were able to attend school that year, and he said WVT hopes more people will help this year, particularly in the run up to the Lunar New Year festival.
According to the official, the children come mainly from families with unemployed parents or from single-parent families.
In cooperation with Far EasTone Telecommunications Co. this year, people who donate more than NT$2,500 to the program can receive a souvenir from Far EasTone, the official said.
Prospective donors can visit WVT's Web site at: www.worldvision.org.tw or call 02-2585-6300 for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ANNOUNCES HAKKA CULTURE PROMOTION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Saturday that the city government will promote Hakka culture as one of the city's marketing strengths.

Speaking at the assembly of the World Hakka Women's Association, Hau praised Hakka women for their "excellent abilities in the household and career fields," adding that he is impressed by his sister-in-law, who is "a diligent and competent Hakka woman."
Hau said the city government will focus its promotional efforts on Hakka people's family concept, patriotism and diligence.
Tzeng Li-ching, president of the association, said the association will organize a creative workshop on Hakka culture to work on projects related to cultural exchange and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA REWARDS 73 FOR REPORTING POLLUTION CASES IN 2006

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) rewarded 73 people for reporting pollution cases in 2006, an EPA spokesman said Saturday.

The 73 people each won between NT$1,000 and NT$160,000 for a total amount of NT$2 million (US$61,233) for reporting 38 water pollution, 22 illegal waste disposal, five air pollution, four noise pollution, one marine pollution and one drinking water pollution cases. Two polluters got jail sentences as a result.
People who report pollution cases that are verified by the EPA will be eligible to prizes of up to NT$200,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCOHOL ADDICTION TREATMENT PROGRAM FOR CHILD ABUSERS TO BE EXPANDED

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will expand its free alcohol addiction treatment program for perpetrators of alcohol-related child abuse to the entire country from April, officials said Saturday.
The program has been carried out on a trial basis in Hualien, Nantou, Pingtung, Taitung, Yilan and Kaohsiung counties since last year.

According to DOH tallies, 3,330 perpetrators of physical abuse were ordered by the court to receive compulsory treatment or counseling between June 1999 and November 2006, 34.29 percent of whom were required to undergo alcohol addiction treatment.
Meanwhile, perpetrators in 13 percent of child abuse cases reported around the country are alcoholics, the tallies show.

DOH officials said the treatment includes four to six outpatient visits and 15 psychological counseling sessions and cognitive education counseling, with the entire therapy expected to last four to five months.

While the government is footing the bill for the targeted alcoholics, civic organizations designated by the government will help monitor the treated abusers for one year after the therapy is completed, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: REBAR CASE SHOWS PROBLEMS IN FOREIGN JUDICIAL ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: The difficulties in getting a fugitive tycoon back to Taiwan to face justice for a series of scandals involving his business group have shown that there is still room for improvement in seeking mutual judicial assistance from other countries, judicial sources said Saturday.

The sources made the remarks after the latest unsuccessful diplomatic and judicial efforts to get Wang You-theng, founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, back to Taiwan from the United States. Wang was taken into custody by U.S. authorities Saturday after his Taiwan and Dominican Republic passports were invalidated through Taiwan's efforts.

Wang first fled to China late last December shortly after the Rebar scandal broke out, from where he later fled to the United States. Taiwan put him on its most-wanted list in mid-January. He tried to fly to Myanmar via Singapore Wednesday but was sent back to the U.S. Friday by the Singapore authorities for lacking proper travel papers.
The sources pointed out that Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations and that it has to rely on taking part in international organizations to get judicial assistance from other nations.
Other channels include Taiwan's investigation agencies that cooperate with other countries and Taiwan's judicial officials who cooperate with their foreign counterparts through private exchanges.

In terms of taking part in international organizations, they noted that Taiwan, represented by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), has taken part in such organizations combating money-laundering as the Asia/Pacific Group on Money Laundering and the Egmont Group.
On forging international cooperative relations, they noted that Taiwan inked a mutual judicial assistance agreement with the United States in March 2002.
They said the MOJ Investigation Bureau and the Criminal Investigation Administration Bureau have in recent years forged informal cooperation ties with their counterparts from other countries.

Taiwan has established channels of communications with 70 law enforcement agencies in nearly 50 countries, they said, achieving substantive results in the areas of information exchange and receiving alerts when Taiwanese criminals are expelled from other countries.
Taiwan has also sent prosecutors to take part in meetings of the International Association of Prosecutors since 2001. It is hoped that this will pave the way for mutual judicial assistance someday.
They said Taiwan currently has cooperative relations with prosecutors from the United States, Japan, Singapore, Switzerland and Macau, but added that the scope needs to be expanded.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOAN RATIO OF GRASSROOTS FINANCIAL INSTITUTES DOWN TO 8.13%

TEXT.P: The credit departments of the country's farmers' and fishermen's associations had an average 8.13 percent overdue loan ratio at the end of December 2006, down 0.39 percentage points from the previous month, according to tallies released Saturday by the Bureau of Agricultural Finance under the Council of Agriculture.
The total amount of the non-performing loans was NT$53.8 billion (US$1.64 billion) at the end of December, or NT$2.2 billion less than the previous month, the tallies show.
The assets of the credit departments of the farmers' and fishermen's associations stood at NT$1.58 trillion (US$48.17 billion) as of the end of December, up NT$7.4 billion from the previous month.

The net worth of the credit departments totaled NT$84.1 billion as of the end of December, down NT$3.4 billion from the previous month, while the outstanding deposits totaled NT$1.37 trillion, up NT$9.9 billion from the previous month, and the outstanding loans totaled NT$661.9 billion, up NT$5.1 billion.
The bad loans were as high as 21.53 percent in June 2002 before the government took action to cut the amount of non-performing loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY PLANS TO MAKE WORLD'S LONGEST FIRECRACKER STRING

TEXT.P: The Tainan county government has invited experts from its Yenshui township to make firecrackers that will go toward an attempt to challenge the Guinness record for the longest string of firecrackers in the world, county officials said Saturday.

The southern county plans to use the record-breaking string in a firecracker display titled "legend of the fire dragon" in the annual Lantern Festival, which will fall on March 4, in Yenshui, a small town that traditionally celebrates the festival with a parade that involves setting off thousands of "beehive firecrackers, " the officials said.
The official 2007 Taiwan Lantern Festival will take place in neighboring Chiayi County March 4-11.
The theme lantern of the Chiayi event will feature a Taiwan boar and the concept of "peace and prosperity" for the upcoming "year of the Pig, " according to the organizers.
Other Lantern Festival celebrations include the sky lanterns at Pinghsi township in northern Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP OPPOSE NAME-CHANGE FOR STATE-OWNED ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) legislators voiced opposition Saturday to an announcement that the names of state-owned enterprises will be changed to reflect the fact that they are Taiwanese rather than Chinese.
The legislators expressed their opposition after Economic Affairs Minister Steve Chen Ruey-long announced the previous day that two state-owned enterprises will have their names changed.

Chen said the name of the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will be changed to CPC, Taiwan, while the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) will adopt the name CSBC, Taiwan. The changes are in line with the government's name "rectification" policy aimed at avoiding confusion with Chinese businesses, according to Chen, who claimed that it will also benefit the future operations of the companies.
KMT Legislator Hsu Shao-ping said the name-change is part of the government's efforts to cater to the supporters of Taiwan independence.
"It has no substantial significance except squandering taxpayers' money," she said, claiming that it does not come at an appropriate time "when the nation is in economic doldrums."

She said the KMT legislative caucus is mulling whether to boycott the general budget of the central government for 2007, which failed to pass the previous legislative session that ended January, the first time the legislature has failed to pass the budget before the new fiscal year begins Jan. 1.

She expressed discontent that the government, before the budget is even passed, is thinking of spending unnecessary money, estimated at NT$70 million (US$2.13 million) for the CPC and NT$20 million for the CSBC according to estimates by the two enterprises.
Legislator Cheng Chin-ling, a PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said the economic minister's claims that the name-changes will not cost a lot are aimed at blurring the focus of the issue.

Claiming that the nation's economy is "getting worse every day, " she asked why the ministry does not put more efforts into boosting the economy instead of on trivial issues that she claimed are irrelevant.
Cheng said the PFP agrees with the KMT in terms of reviewing the screening of the government's budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY CHIEF VISITS U.S. WEST COAST
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/03/07 19:01:24 (By Wu Jih-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih arrived in San Francisco Friday for a four-day visit to the U.S. West Coast.

Su, heading a county government delegation, began the visit at the University of California at Berkeley, where he attended an international wildlife preservation activity focusing on efforts to preserve the endangered black-faced spoonbill.

The mouth of the Tsengwen river in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, is the wintering ground of the migratory bird, with statistics showing that at least two-thirds of the world's entire population of black-faced spoonbills spend the winter there every year, according to Su, who said the rivermouth is protected by the central government.
As the trip is also aimed at attracting investors to Tainan, the delegation is also scheduled to visit Silicon Valley and Sacramento.

Su said that the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County generated NT$450 billion (US$13.67 billion) in revenues last year. Mentioning that a special zone for the fabrication of thin-film transistor liquid crystal displays has been established in the park, Su said the county hopes more high-tech enterprises will set up production facilities there.
The delegation visited Seattle in neighboring Washington State before traveling to San Francisco, where it toured environmentally friendly architecture and the University of Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOWNSHIP SUCCEEDS IN EXPORTING ONCIDIUM TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Kukeng, a rural township in southern Yulin County, has succeeded in exporting oncidium to Japan, Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen said Saturday.

An oncidium production cooperative in Kukeng signed a contract with a Japanese company a day earlier to supply it with 1.6 million oncidium stems this year, Su said, adding that the deal will help bring the cooperative's annual production value to more than NT$15 million (US$455,705.43).
The flowers are produced by the cooperative's oncidium production division that was set up in 2005, according to Su.
The division, which has 17 hectares under cultivation, is expected to produce 1.7 million stems this year, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES WARM WELCOME AT AUTOGRAPH SESSION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu received a warm welcome at an autograph session Saturday at the 15th Taipei International Book Exhibition being held at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Lu visited the exhibition for the second time to autograph two books. One, titled "Daughter of the World" is a novel authored by a South Korean writer based on Lu's life and Lu noted at the session that her other book, titled "The Global Taiwan, " is aimed at "correcting" the distorted record of Taiwan's history.
Crowds lined up for the vice president's autograph and she was also warmly welcomed when she visited various other booths at the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG New fears on climate raise heat on leaders
Britain is to spearhead a new drive against climate change by bypassing President Bush and urging US states to join directly with Europes own carbon trading scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC WARNED NOT TO BRING IN ILLEGAL ANIMALS OR PLANTS FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) officials warned the public Saturday not to use the "mini three links" routes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to bring in from China live animals, plants or farm produce that are not allowed to enter Taiwan.
The officials issued the warning in the runup to the Lunar New Year festival, during which "mini three links" traffic usually reaches its annual peak.

The "mini three links, " implemented in 2001, originally referred to direct postal, transport and trade links between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, and Xiamen and Fuzhou harbors in China's Fujian Province.
As transport via the links has increased significantly, a new route from Kinmen to the port city of Quanzhou, also in Fujian Province, was opened last year.

Quarantine officials on Kinmen said that as China still has many infectious plant and animal diseases, the majority of its fresh agricultural products and live animals are not allowed to enter Taiwan.

The officials said they had recently confiscated a lot of cured meat, ham and fresh fruit, which are popular gifts at Lunar New Year, and they warned travelers that violators will have their contraband goods confiscated and destroyed, with serious violators facing fines of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000, in addition to jail terms of up to three years.
The officials said quarantine inspections will not be relaxed during the Lunar New Year festival period.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 60% HEALTH CLUBS FAIL SAFETY INSPECTION: COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of health clubs in 12 randomly chosen cities and counties around the country have failed building safety management inspection, a spokesman for the Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) under the Executive Yuan said Saturday.

A total of 61 health clubs, gyms & spas, or fitness centers in 12 administrative regions, including Taipei City, Taipei County, Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City, Miaoli County, Hualien County, Taichung City, Chiayi City, Yilan County and Keelung City, were examined, the spokesman said.
The review covered building safety management, fire safety management and use of standardized contract documents, the spokesman said.
According to the spokesman, 36 health clubs, or 59 percent of the total, failed building safety management inspection, while 25 percent, or 15 health clubs, failed fire safety examination.

Of those failing the building safety management inspection, 25 percent illegally expanded their operation spaces; 15 percent failed to properly install emergency exits; and 23 percent failed to apply for regular building safety inspection with proper government agencies.

Among those failing fire safety inspection, 11 percent were found to have defective fire alarm equipment; and 13 percent failed to meet the requirements in emergency lighting, emergency exit signage or evacuation facilities.

Meanwhile, 15 health clubs, or 25 percent of the total, were found to have not used standardized documents in their contracts with clients. Among the 46 health clubs that use standardized contracts, 33 failed to meet the stipulation set forth by the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports with regard to contract narrative terms. As a result, the number of gyms that failed to use officially sanctioned contract forms reached 48 or 79 percent of the total.

Officials from the CPC under the Executive Yuan joined consumer protection staff at city and county governments as well as construction administrators, fire fighting and physical education departments officials in conducting the extensive safety inspection last month, the CPC spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Science Panel Calls Global Warming 'Unequivocal'
In a grim and powerful assessment of the future of the planet, the leading international network of climate scientists has concluded for the first time that global warming is "unequivocal" and that human activity is the main driver, "very likely" causing most of the rise in temperatures since 1950. They said the world was in for centuries of climbing temperatures, rising seas and shifting weather patterns X unavoidable results of the buildup of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFICATION NOT KMT'S PRESENT POLICY GOAL: PARTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that promoting unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is not the party's policy goal at the present stage.
Even the Chinese mainland doesn't make cross-strait unification its present goal, Ma claimed in an interview broadcast on CNN International channel's "Talk Asia" program.
As to whether the two sides will unify in the future, Ma said nobody knows whether there will be conditions or circumstances conducive to such a development.
Noting that Taiwan's future must be determined by its 23 million people out of their own free will, Ma said that at the moment, the majority of Taiwanese citizens opt for maintaining the status quo.

Asked about his views on cross-strait relations, Ma said that economically, China is an opportunity for Taiwan, but politically, it is a threat to Taiwan. What Taiwan should do is to maximize the opportunity presented by China while working to minimize its threat, Ma suggested.

The Harvard-trained politician acknowledged that China is a security threat to Taiwan as it has deployed 800 ballistic missiles aimed at the island. Nevertheless, he said the Chinese mainland offers business opportunities for Taiwan.
Quoting official tallies, Ma said cross-strait trade exceeded US$100 billion last year, with China and Hong Kong accumulatively taking up 40 percent of Taiwan's overall exports.

In the interview, Ma also expounded on the KMT's stance toward cross-strait relations. While the KMT, which originated in China and ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until May 2000, accepts the "one China" principle, Ma said the party insists on "separate definition" of China by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

For the KMT, Ma said, "one China" refers to the Republic of China -- Taiwan's official title. The Chinese mainland may not accept the KMT's "one China" definition and likewise, the KMT could not agree to Beijing's defining "one China" as the People's Republic of China -- the Chinese mainland's official title.

Ma said he believes the KMT-coined "one China, separate interpretation" discourse is the best strategy for this extremely contentious and sensitive issue. In his view, Ma said Taiwan need not challenge China's definition in this regard and should instead simply shelve it for the moment.
Ma, who ended his eight-year stint as Taipei mayor last December, is widely seen as the KMT's best bet for the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 4 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Feb. 4:
09:30, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend the inauguration of the Tunghsiao- Yuanli section of the Western Coastal Expressway in Miaoli County.
10:15, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a tree-planting promotion activity to be held at an agricultural biotechnology park in southern Pingtung County.
19:30, Vice President Annette Lu will inspect Taipei's Shihlin night market at the intersection of Tatung Road and Wenlin Road.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 4, or the 17th day of the last month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: George Washington is elected as the first president of the United States.
1793: France abolishes slavery in all its te0ritories.
1810: Tsar Alexander I of Russia refuses to grant Napoleon I his sister Anna's hand in marriage. The Russian tsar's plans to liberalize the government were forestalled by wars with Napoleon I.
1899: Fighting breaks out in the newest U.S. protectorate, the Philippines, which declared itself a republic the previous month.
1902: Charles Lindbergh, the American aviator who made the first solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out.
1906: The New York Police Department adopts fingerprint lifting methods to collect evidence in criminal cases.
1922: China signs an agreement with Japan in Washington, D.C. to settle the Shantung dispute.
1938: Joachim von Ribbentrop becomes foreign minister of Germany while Hitler assumes the office of war minister.
1945: Leaders of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union meet in Yalta, USSR and reach the so-called "Yalta secret agreement." According to the pact, Soviet troops enter the war against Japan on the condition that its former land rights in China, taken by Japan in 1904, are to be restored later.
1948: Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) gains independence from Britain.
1949: Taiwan Provincial Governor Chen Cheng publicizes the practice of the Farm Rental Reduction Program, which was put into force on April 12 of the same year.
1966: An All Nippon Airway plane crashes at Tokyo's Haneda airport, killing all 133 people aboard.
1969: Liao Ho-shu, Communist China's charge d'affaires in the Netherlands, arrives in the United States and requests political asylum.
1973: The Asian Relations Association opens its Japan office in Tokyo.
1976: Dr. Raymond Jallow, senior vice president of the United California Bank, Los Angeles, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale jolts Guatemala, claiming more than 22,000 lives.
1976: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs H.K. Yang decorates Dr. Tare Takemi, president of the Japan Medical Association, with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Cordon.
1978: Junius Jayawardene becomes the first president of Sri Lanka.
1978: Fan Yuan-yen, the defecting Communist Chinese pilot who flew a MiG-19 to Taiwan the previous July, writes an open letter to the United Nations condemning human rights violations by the Beijing regime.
1980: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr becomes the first elected president of Iran. He is expected to follow the line of the country's de facto ruler, religious leader Ayatollah Khomeini.
1986: Twelve political dissidents jailed in Taiwan for the Formosa magazine incident are released on parole. The incident occurred in 1979 when political dissidents clashed with police while celebrating the anniversary of the publication of the magazine.
1988: The Executive Yuan passes a bill allowing high school graduates to study abroad.
1992: The Republic of China's Fair Trade Law goes into effect.
1997: Two military helicopters collide in mid-air in a storm in northern Israel, killing 73 Israeli soldiers.
1998: A strong earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale hits northern Afghanistan, killing 4,000 and leaving more than 15,000 homeless.
2000: Three Indonesian workers at the sixth naphtha cracking plant owned by Taiwan Plastic Corp. are killed in an accident while cleaning gas pipelines.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I am not the one born with understanding. I am only the one who has given himself to the study of antiquity and is diligent in seeking for understanding in such studies."

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFICATION NOT KMT'S PRESENT POLICY GOAL: PARTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that promoting unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is not the party's policy goal at the present stage.
Even the Chinese mainland doesn't make cross-strait unification its present goal, Ma claimed in an interview broadcast on CNN International channel's "Talk Asia" program.
As to whether the two sides will unify in the future, Ma said nobody knows whether there will be conditions or circumstances conducive to such a development.
Noting that Taiwan's future must be determined by its 23 million people out of their own free will, Ma said that at the moment, the majority of Taiwanese citizens opt for maintaining the status quo.

Asked about his views on cross-strait relations, Ma said that economically, China is an opportunity for Taiwan, but politically, it is a threat to Taiwan. What Taiwan should do is to maximize the opportunity presented by China while working to minimize its threat, Ma suggested.

The Harvard-trained politician acknowledged that China is a security threat to Taiwan as it has deployed 800 ballistic missiles aimed at the island. Nevertheless, he said the Chinese mainland offers business opportunities for Taiwan.
Quoting official tallies, Ma said cross-strait trade exceeded US$100 billion last year, with China and Hong Kong accumulatively taking up 40 percent of Taiwan's overall exports.

In the interview, Ma also expounded on the KMT's stance toward cross-strait relations. While the KMT, which originated in China and ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until May 2000, accepts the "one China" principle, Ma said the party insists on "separate definition" of China by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

For the KMT, Ma said, "one China" refers to the Republic of China -- Taiwan's official title. The Chinese mainland may not accept the KMT's "one China" definition and likewise, the KMT could not agree to Beijing's defining "one China" as the People's Republic of China -- the Chinese mainland's official title.

Ma said he believes the KMT-coined "one China, separate interpretation" discourse is the best strategy for this extremely contentious and sensitive issue. In his view, Ma said Taiwan need not challenge China's definition in this regard and should instead simply shelve it for the moment.
Ma, who ended his eight-year stint as Taipei mayor last December, is widely seen as the KMT's best bet for the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 60% HEALTH CLUBS FAIL SAFETY INSPECTION: COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of health clubs in 12 randomly chosen cities and counties around the country have failed building safety management inspection, a spokesman for the Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) under the Executive Yuan said Saturday.

A total of 61 health clubs, gyms & spas, or fitness centers in 12 administrative regions, including Taipei City, Taipei County, Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City, Miaoli County, Hualien County, Taichung City, Chiayi City, Yilan County and Keelung City, were examined, the spokesman said.
The review covered building safety management, fire safety management and use of standardized contract documents, the spokesman said.
According to the spokesman, 36 health clubs, or 59 percent of the total, failed building safety management inspection, while 25 percent, or 15 health clubs, failed fire safety examination.

Of those failing the building safety management inspection, 25 percent illegally expanded their operation spaces; 15 percent failed to properly install emergency exits; and 23 percent failed to apply for regular building safety inspection with proper government agencies.

Among those failing fire safety inspection, 11 percent were found to have defective fire alarm equipment; and 13 percent failed to meet the requirements in emergency lighting, emergency exit signage or evacuation facilities.

Meanwhile, 15 health clubs, or 25 percent of the total, were found to have not used standardized documents in their contracts with clients. Among the 46 health clubs that use standardized contracts, 33 failed to meet the stipulation set forth by the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports with regard to contract narrative terms. As a result, the number of gyms that failed to use officially sanctioned contract forms reached 48 or 79 percent of the total.

Officials from the CPC under the Executive Yuan joined consumer protection staff at city and county governments as well as construction administrators, fire fighting and physical education departments officials in conducting the extensive safety inspection last month, the CPC spokesman said.

The Washington Post: At Least 125 Killed in Blast at Baghdad Market
Toll in Deadliest Single Bombing in Capital Is Expected to Rise After Victims Are Pulled From Rubble
Baghdad, Feb. 3 -- A suicide bomber detonated more than a ton of explosives in a market in central Baghdad late Saturday afternoon, killing at least 125 people and wounding 300 in the deadliest single bombing in the capital since the war started.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVEL AGENTS WARNED AGAINST DEALING IN CHINESE CURRENCY

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official warned Taiwan's local travel agency operators and tour guides Sunday from dealing in yuan, the Chinese currency.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said it is illegal under the nation's currency law to buy or sell Chinese yuan privately, and called for travel agency operators and tour guides to avoid such practices, especially now that the Chinese New Year holiday is approaching and transactions in the Chinese currency is anticipated to increase sharply.

Liu said the MAC will collaborate with the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to jointly control illegal transactions in Chinese yuan in order to prevent possible currency irregularities from occurring.
Currently, only banking institutions, airports and seaports in the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu are allowed to engage in exchanges of Chinese yuan, Liu said.

He added that between the time that exchanges in Chinese yuan were first permitted on Kinmen and Matsu early last year and December 2006, about 228.11 million worth of Chinese yuan has been exchanged. Of that total, over 99.5 percent was bought or sold by Taiwan residents.

Liu attributed most of the large volume of transactions in yuan on Kinmen and Matsu by Taiwan residents to speculation that the value of the Chinese yuan might further appreciate, and to an increasing number of Taiwanese residents traveling back and forth between Taiwan and China via Kinmen and Matsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ALLEGEDLY SEEKING TIES WITH DPP

TEXT.P: A local Chinese-language daily reported Sunday that Beijing has stepped up contacts with Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , particularly in the wake of the mayoral elections held in Taipei and Kaohsiung late last year.

The United Daily News quoted Lin Chong-pin, a professor with Tamkang University's Institute of International Studies, as saying recently that Beijing's Taiwan policy and strategy have changed drastically since Taiwan's ruling DPP won the important mayoral election in Kaohsiung.

Lin said he sees that the Chinese authorities have begun to seek improved relations with the DPP in all aspects and will no longer stake their approach to cross-strait relations solely on Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang, according to the daily's report.

Lin added that the visit to Beijing by Chung Chia-pin, a former DPP deputy secretary-general, in 2005 at the invitation of Beijing Union University was just one of the examples underlining Beijing's attempts to improve relations with the DPP.

Responding to that report, DPP Deputy Secretary-General Tsai Huang-liang said Sunday that the ruling DPP will not exclude the possibility of making contact with Beijing or exchanging views with Chinese authorities on the premise that they recognize Taiwan's sovereignty.

Tsai's response echoed remarks made by DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, who said recently that the ruling DPP will not shun contact, exchanges or dialogue with Beijing so long as Taiwan's national interests, cross-strait peace and the principle of equality are respected.

The truth is, however, that exchanges between the ruling parties from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have yet to begin because Beijing continues to reject government-to-government dialogue or negotiation with Taiwan, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FOREIGN STUDENTS STUDYING IN TAIWAN SOARS 23 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The number of foreign students seeking education in Taiwan soared by 23 percent to 14,479 in 2006, mainly as a result of a global new fad for learning Mandarin, the Ministry of Education reported Sunday.

Of the 2006 foreign students, a total of 9,135 were in Taiwan to study Mandarin at various language centers around the island, marking an increase of 953 over the year-earlier level, ministry officials said.

Japanese dominated the ranks of Mandarin-learning foreign students, with a total of 1,807 students, followed by Indonesians with 1,279, Americans with 1,252, Koreans with 1,039 and Vietnamese with 402, the officials said.
Meanwhile, another 3,935 foreign students were in Taiwan last year studying for academic accreditation, an increase of 1,082 students over the level of a year- earlier, the officials said.
About 70 percent of these students were from Asian countries and most of these sought higher education in fields of science, engineering, medical and agriculture, they added.

Besides Mandarin-learning students and students studying for academic accreditation, there were 1,409 other foreign students in Taiwan last year receiving education as "exchange students, " they noted.
Of this group, 245 students went to Taipei's Ming Chuan University, the top- drawing institution among the 50 Taiwanese colleges and universities hosting foreign exchange students.
Japanese students were again tops in this category, with 265 students on exchange, following by Americans, 204, and Koreans, 186, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL DONATE FUNDS TO HELEN KELLER INTERNATIONAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/04/07 16:38:38 (By Lillian Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate funds for two health promotion projects in Burkina Faso, one of its diplomatic allies in Africa, a spokesman for the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York said Saturday.

The two projects -- a trachoma prevention plan and a cooking oil plan -- are jointly organized by the New York-based Helen Keller International (HKI), the United Nations Children's Fund and the World Health Organization, the spokesman said, adding that the HKI will implement the two programs using funds donated by Taiwan.

Andrew L. Y. Hsia, head of the TECO, will provide the funds to HKI President Kathy Spahn on behalf of Taiwan's government during a reception to be held at the TECO office in Manhattan next Wednesday, the spokesman said.
The funds will include US$103,940 for the trachoma prevention project, the spokesman said, adding that this donation represents the final installment in a three-year project that began in late 2004.

Taiwan has donated more than US$375,000 to the project aimed at combating trachoma in Burkina Faso's Komandjari area by planting vegetables and fruits to boost local residents' vitamin A intake, improving medical facilities and promoting hygiene and good sanitary habits among school children.
Trachoma is a highly infectious disease of eyes that is caused by bacteria and is the second largest cause of blindness in Africa and Asia.

Encouraged by the success of the trachoma prevention project, the spokesman said, Taiwan has decided to sponsor a cooking oil project in Burkina Faso from 2007. The project, which focuses on adding vitamin A to cooking oil to reduce the risks of mothers and young children dying from malnutrition, will also be implemented over three years at an estimated cost of US$300,000. Taiwan will foot the bill, with the first-year donation set at US$128,952.
The Helen Keller International (HKI) combats the causes and consequences of blindness and malnutrition by establishing programs based on research on vision, health and nutrition.
Founded in 1915 by Helen Adams Keller and George Kessler, the organization's mission is to save the sight and lives of the most vulnerable and disadvantaged.

Keller was a deaf-blind American author, activist and lecturer. The woman, from the small farm town of Tuscumbia, Alabama taught the world to respect people who are blind and deaf with her outstanding career achievements and dedicated services to the disadvantaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL CROSS-STRAIT CONTACTS IN PROFESSIONAL FIELDS INCREASE: MAC

TEXT.P: Official contacts across the Taiwan Strait in professional fields have increased over the past year, although these contacts could not be characterized as "close, " a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Sunday.

The MAC official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that over the past year Chinese officials have become more willing to contact their Taiwanese counterparts on issues in various specialized or professional fields, instead of insisting on cross-strait contacts only in strictly private sectors.

This improvement, he said, is leading developments of cross-strait relations in a healthier direction and is worthy applause and encouragement since the effect of exchanges would be, and have been, limited were cross-strait affairs tackled only via private channels.

The official, however, declined to comment on local daily reports that Beijing's Taiwan policy and strategy have changed drastically since Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won the important mayoral election in Kaohsiung late last year, or that Chinese authorities have begun to seek improved relations with the DPP in all aspects and will no longer stake their approach to cross-strait relations solely on Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang.

Meanwhile, at a seminar held Saturday, MAC Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan called for Beijing to grasp "golden opportunities" in the first half of this year to resume cross-strait negotiations on seven important issues -- ranging from Taiwan's agricultural exports to China, the establishment of a cross-strait financial liquidation mechanism, the establishment of a cross-strait financial supervisory mechanism, to intellectual property rights protection, mutual judicial assistance, cross-strait crime-fighting and the signing of an investment guarantee pact aimed at protecting Taiwanese citizens maintaining business operations in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italian soccer championship behind closed doors.
The Italian soccer federation FIGC is considering to resume national chiampionship matches behind closed doors before new security measures be worked out and taken into effect in order to avoid soccer violence. One policeman was killed and more than 100 people were injured during clashes between fans in a Serie A Palermo-Catania match held Friday night in the Sicilian city of Catania. The incident prompted the FIGC to call off all matches indefinitely.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT WRITER PUSHES FOR WOODLAND RESTORATION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Welsh writer who has been a long time resident of Japan visited the Taipei International Book Fair Sunday, where he expressed his hope that woodland restoration can be achieved as successfully in Taiwan as in Japan.

Clive Williams Nicol, 66, a writer, actor and Japanese citizen who has published many books about wildlife and the environment in both English and Japanese, is bringing new inspiration to Taiwan with regards to restoring woodlands by putting his books on display at the book fair.
On display at the fair are a number of his latest books -- all in Japanese but translated into Chinese -- including "I Bought a Forest," "The Whisky Cat," and "Tree."
In addition to promoting his new books and delivering speeches at the Taipei book fair, Nicol will also help Taiwan's NGOs in their efforts to restore Taiwan's woodlands.

Nicol, who used to be a hunter but is now a wildlife conservationist and gourmet, said at the book fair that he was very much impressed with the Taiwanese readers, whom, he described as totally different from those he found in China.
The Taiwan readers are friendly and enthusiastic, quite unlike the Chinese people, who do not smile at strangers and who seem to have never seen birds or butterflies.

Noting that it takes time for a people to nurture the concept of environmental protection and implement it, Nicol said he hopes that his books will help extend the woodlands of Taiwan little by little, and that more Chinese-reading people will contribute to efforts related to wildlife conservation and environmental protection.

Nicol was born in Neath, Wales, and from a young age expressed an interest in wildlife and the environment. In 1958 he visited the Arctic circle to research the Elder duck for McGill University. He also spent two years in Ethiopia working as a game warden in one of Ethiopia's national parks. By the early 1960s he was studying karate in Japan, and soon thereafter began to study Japanese at Nihon University. He has lived in Japan since that time.

Since taking up residence in Japan he has written many books and other literary works. In 1980 he won the Japan Broadcasting Writer's Award for a television drama written in Japanese. He also soon became an environmentalist activist, and to this day travels both within and outside of Japan giving talks and lectures on the environment, addressing issues such as deforestation and the preservation of natural environments. He is particularly interested in restoring Japan's vast woodlands, and due to these and other endeavors is quite famous in Japan.
In the book, "Why I became Japanese, " Nicol wrote about how he obtained Japanese citizenship. He now resides in a plot of forest land he owns in Japan with his wife and two daughters.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE TENG-HUI MEETS WITH AND CALMS SUPPORTERS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui has reassured worried supporters he met with Sunday morning to clarify recent controversial remarks he made concerning Taiwan's national goals, said the head of a group supportive of Lee after the meeting.

The 'Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association' will not disband and will continue to throw strong support behind Lee, Hwang Kun-hu, President of the association told the press after Lee addressed cadres of the group and its pro-independence allies in the Taiwan Solidarity Union and Taiwan Society.
Hwang said Lee's insistence on Taiwan's sovereignty in his talk with the participants in the breakfast meeting, held at a Kaohsiung City hotel, has relieved them of their doubts and anxieties.

Only cadres from eight out of the association's 21 local branches attended the meeting amid rumors that several branches were to disband due to disappointment with Lee, long dubbedthe godfather of Taiwan independence, who was quoted in Next Magazine in late January as saying that he has never advocated Taiwan independence.

Lee thereafter clarified his stance through a TV interview and a newspaper advertisement, saying that Taiwan already has de facto independence and therefore no longer needs to pursue it. He also reiterated that Taiwan needs to rectify its name, craft a new constitution, seek membership in the United Nations and become a normal country.

However, his remarks still angered and disaffected some of his most enthusiastic allies and supporters. Lee Shiao-feng, a historian prominent for advocating Taiwan's national identity, said Saturday he decided to vacate his committee seat with the Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association. He said while Lee's explanation about Taiwan independence may be acceptable, he cannot stand thecomplete confusion of valuesapparent as Lee accuses President Chen Shui-bian as corrupt while praising the Kuomintang Chairman Ma Jing-jeou as clean.

Political commentator Chin Heng-wei also said the same day he would resign from the board of Taiwan Advocates, a think tank funded by Lee Teng-hui, while Chet Yang, secretary-general of the Taiwan Society said many members of the society required sleeping pills or anti-hypertensive drugs to calm down following Lee's comments.
Hwang, however, said Sunday that while there are various opinions being expressed across the political spectrum these days, the 'Lee's Friends' Association' will remain firmly in place.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRST OLYMPIC MEDALIST BURIED IN CALIFORNIA
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/04/07 19:04:40 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first Olympic medalist, Yang Chuan-kwang, who died Jan. 28 in his Ventura County, California home at the age of 73, was buried at Ivy Lawns Memorial Park in that county Saturday after a brief funeral.

The funeral was held at a local funeral home at 11 a.m, where his family members were joined by officials from Taiwan's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles, the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, and the Democratic Progressive Party's Western America Chapter.
They sang the Republic of China's (ROC's) national anthem at the funeral in memory of the athlete who won a silver in the decathlon at the Rome Olympics in 1960 for the Republic of China.

Chen Chuan-show, former chief of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, and an official from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles, covered his coffin with a ROC national flag to mark the great glory Yang brought to his country.

Notable among the attendants was Rafer Johnson, an American athlete who undertook training together with Yang at the University of California Los Angeles in the later 1950s and defeated Yang to win the gold in the decathlon in Rome in 1960. He recalled at the funeral his five-decade friendship with Yang, which has become a legend among athletes.
Yang died of brain hemorrhage. He is survived by his wife, Daisy Chou and two sons, Cedric Yang and C.K. Yang Jr.
Daisy Chou and C.K. Yang Jr. will attend a memorial service for Yang Chuan- kwuang on Feb. 9, in Taipei, during which the silver medal the Taiwanese decathlete won will be put on display.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN'S SOFTBALL TEAM ONE STEP CLOSER TO OLYMPICS

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei women's softball team secured a place in the finals of the Asia-Oceania Women's Softball Olympic Qualifying Series after beating both the North and South Korean teams Sunday in back-to-back action in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
In the game against North Korea Sunday morning, Taipei was tied with Pyongyang 3 - 3 at the end of the seventh inning.
However, Taipei edged out North Korea by scoring one run in overtime innings.
Riding high on its victory against Pyongyang, Taipei defeated South Korea Sunday afternoon 4 - 1.

These, the seventh and eight victories respectively for Taipei in the preliminary rounds, secured the team a place in the finals where it will fight with the winner of Monday's game between North Korea and New Zealand for a slot in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT LAMENTS PARTISAN STRUGGLES

TEXT.P: Amid recent controversy over his remarks on Taiwan's national goals, Former President Lee Teng-hui said Sunday theTaiwan Independencedebate is a false one used by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to wrap their power struggle.

Addressing a graduation ceremony of Lee Teng-hui Academy's southern Taiwan branches, in Kaohsiung, he said extremist sects with the design to cut the country's history off were formed within political parties after the transfer of power in 2000.

The anti-democracy force in the KMT betrays Taiwan's history of democratization and aims to take back the power and rebuild a party-state system,he said, while the extremist force in the DPP, just like their KMT counterparts, denies Taiwan's achievement in democratization and says Taiwan is not yet an independent country and is still in need of seeking independence.

He said one of the two forces defines itself as seeking independence while the other is engaged in counter-independence efforts with the Chinese communist regime.Both attempt to utilize the false issue of Taiwan independence to provoke a 'unification versus independence' conflict and to grab power out of it,he said.
He said Taiwanese people have become the masters of their own country in the 1996 presidential election, when 75 percent of the votes went to him and the DPP candidate, under Chinese missile threats.

Lee saidthe old parties, old politicians and old parliament have turned a blind eye to the real needs of the people.They are only causing problems instead of solving them; they are dragging the country downward.

If the two extremist forces are left unchecked and continue to split the people, Lee said, it's very possible that one political force may collaborate with outside force and help fulfill the Communist empire's ambition to annex the democratic Taiwan, scraping the freedom Taiwanese people had fought hard to gain.

He said he is very worried over what policies China will adopt toward Taiwan after its hosting of the 2008 Olympic Games and the 2010 World's Fair.Important things are happening outside and affecting Taiwan but Taiwan is only keen on internal struggles, he said,just thinking about this can make one shed tears.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INT'L BOOK EXHIBITION WINDS UP, DRAWING 400,000 VISITORS

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Book Exhibition 2007 lowered the curtain Sunday after drawing more than 400,000 visitors in six days, its leading organizer said Sunday.

Rex How, chief of the Taipei Book Fair Foundation which organized the annual gala, dismissed the decline in the number of visitors this year as insignificant, attributing it to the fact that this year's exhibition took place in the leadup to the Chinese New Year Day when local people are busy with ushering in the new year and it concurred with the national academic performance examinations for senior high school graduates.

However, How claimed the exhibition has developed into an regional event which distinguishes it from book fairs in Beijing which cater mainly to publishers and book fairs in Hong Kong which aim at promoting sells of books.

In addition to publishing companies in Japan and South Korea that debuted in the exhibition last year, How said, publishing firms in Southeast Asia were invited to display their books in the exhibition this year, a move aimed to reflect the country's increasing immigrants from that region.

How whose term as chief of the Taipei Book Fair Foundation ended with the close of the 2007 exhibition said he was glad the book fair has put the island on the map of international publishing business.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC: FLU LIKELY TO PEAK IN NEXT TWO WEEKS

TEXT.P: The period from now to the Lunar New Year holidays is likely to see an influenza peak, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) warned Sunday.

Past experiences show that the first two weeks of February pose a peak for flu, said Shih Wen-yi, CDC deputy director, adding that busy transportations and frequent contacts during the New Year time all help spread the disease.

According to CDC statistics, type B influenza has claimed four lives across the country this winter. The center's monitoring system, meanwhile, suggested a slight increase in the influenza-like illness (ILI) rate in the past week - 5.7 to 5.8 cases out of every hundred patients who consulted sentinel physicians.
Good news is that, Shih said, winter vacation for schools have silenced cluster infections for two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY AGREES TO REMOVE LATE PRESIDENT'S STATUES: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has agreed to remove all statues of late President Chiang Kai-shek from its barracks before Feb. 28, which will be the 60th anniversary of the so-called 228 incident, three lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday.

Citing a report issued last year by the 228 Memorial Foundation, DPP lawmakers Chai Trong-rong, Sandy Yen and Hsueh Ling said in a statement the Chiang Kai- shek is the leading culprit of the 228 incident in 1947 when the troops of the national government crushed a revolt in Taiwan, killing thousands of people.

In memory of the incident, the lawmakers said they had requested the Ministry of National Defense to clear barracks of Chiang's statues before Feb. 28 and the ministry had agreed orally to their request. The statement also called for the rename the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei as Taiwan democracy memorial hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: New York Times: In Washington, Contractors Take on Biggest Role Ever Without a public debate or formal policy decision, contractors have become a virtual fourth branch of U.S. government. On the rise for decades, spending on federal contracts has soared during the Bush administration, to about US$400 billion last year from US$207 billion in 2000, fueled by the war in Iraq, domestic security and Hurricane Katrina, but also by a philosophy that encourages outsourcing almost everything government does. Contractors still build ships and satellites, but they also collect income taxes and work up agency budgets, fly pilotless spy aircraft and take the minutes at policy meetings on the war. They sit next to federal employees at nearly every agency; far more people work under contracts than are directly employed by the government. enditem

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 5, or the 18th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Japanese Shogun Hideyoshi Toyotomi puts 26 Catholic converts to death in Nagasaki after he banned Christianity earlier in the year.
1792: Tippo of Mysore, India is defeated and cedes half of Mysore to the British.
1788: Sir Robert Peel, British prime minister and founder of the Metropolitan Police, is born.
1900: Adlai Stevenson, American statesman and ambassador whose liberal views caused him trouble during the McCarthy witch hunts, is born.
1914: Andreas Papandreou, Greek prime minister, is born.
1917: Mexico becomes a federated republic of 28 states.
1922: The first issue of the U.S. magazine Reader's Digest rolls off the presses.
1924: French automaker Renault launches an epoch-marking car safari in the Sahara.
1929: The Nationalist government changes the name of Fengtien province to Liaoning province.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur and U.S. troops enter Manila. On Oct. 20, 1944, MacArthur and his forces landed on the Philippine island of Leyte, fulfilling his pledge to return to the Philippines.
1955: U.S. President Dwight Einsenhower instructs the Seventh Fleet to assist Nationalist troops in withdrawing from the island of Tachen, opposite mainland China's Chechiang province.
1959: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan adopts a resolution to open Hualien port in eastern Taiwan as an international port.
1959: The Ilan branch of Taiwan's East-West Highway is formally opened to traffic.
1962: A total solar eclipse occurs in the morning.
1962: President Charles de Gaulle of France calls for independence for Algeria.
1971: U.S. Apollo 14 astronauts land on the moon.
1974: Thirteen-year-old Mats Wermelin of Sweden scores all 272 points in a basketball game.
1976: A major earthquake rocks Guatemala, killing nearly 23,000 people.
1977: Brazilian soccer star Pele arrives in Taiwan for a three-day visit.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev indicates that the Communist Party must abandon its monopoly on power.
1990: Rafael Calderon Fournier wins the presidential election in Costa Rica.
1996: Rene Preval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a peaceful transfer of power in Haiti.
1997: Switzerland's three banking giants announce the creation of a 100 million Swiss franc Holocaust memorial fund.
1999: Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua and his wife Hiromi Kabua arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou awards a plaque to popular movie star Andy Lau in honor of his appointment as "Taipei Rapid Transit Ambassador," which includes the right to travel on the Taipei MRT for free for the rest of his life.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When three men meet together, one of them who is anxious to learn can always learn something from the other two. He can profit by the good example of the one and avoid the bad example of the other."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 9,200 CHARGED WITH GRAFT OVER 7 YEARS: MOJ

TEXT.P: A total of 9,251 people were indicted in 3,636 graft cases between June 2000 and December 2006 under the Ministry of Justice's (MOJ) anti-corruption operations, according to tallies released Sunday by the ministry.
Illicit gains seized in these cases amounted to more than NT$29.55 billion (US$898.18 million), MOJ officials said.

Of the 9,251 people indicted, 503 were senior-level civil servants, 579 were people's representatives, 1,680 were intermediate-level civil servants, 2,820 were junior-level civil servants, and 3,669 were regular citizens, the officials said.
