DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INT'L BOOK EXHIBITION WINDS UP, DRAWING 400,000 VISITORS

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Book Exhibition 2007 lowered the curtain Sunday after drawing more than 400,000 visitors in six days, the event's leading organizer said Sunday.

Rex How, chief of the Taipei Book Fair Foundation, which organized the annual event, dismissed the decline in the number of visitors this year as insignificant, attributing it to the fact that this year's exhibition took place in the leadup to Chinese New Year when local people are busy preparing for the holiday and during the national academic performance examinations for senior high school graduates.

However, How claimed, the exhibition has developed into a regional event which distinguishes it from book fairs in Beijing, which cater mainly to publishers, and book fairs in Hong Kong, which aim to sell books.

In addition to publishing companies in Japan and South Korea that debuted at the exhibition last year, How said, publishing firms from Southeast Asia were also invited to display their books at the exhibition this year, a move aimed at reflecting the country's increasing number of immigrants from that region.

How, whose term as chief of the Taipei Book Fair Foundation ended with the close of the 2007 exhibition, said he is glad the book fair has put the island on the map of the international publishing business.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY AGREES TO REMOVE STATUES OF LATE PRESIDENT: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has agreed to remove all statues of the late President Chiang Kai-shek from barracks around the country before Feb. 28, which will be the 60th anniversary of the so-called 228 Incident, three lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday.

Citing a report issued last year by the 228 Memorial Foundation, DPP lawmakers Chai Trong-rong, Sandy Yen and Hsueh Ling said in a statement the Chiang Kai- shek was the main culprit behind the 228 Incident in 1947 when troops of the Chinese Nationalist government crushed a revolt in Taiwan, killing thousands of people.
In memory of the incident, the lawmakers said that they asked the Ministry of National Defense to remove the statues before Feb. 28 and that the ministry agreed to their request.
The statement also called for the renaming of the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei as the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
INT'L SYMPOSIUM ON SUNG DYNASTY CULTURE, ARTS OPENS

TEXT.P: An international symposium on Sung Dynasty culture and artifacts opened at the National Palace Museum Monday with more than 40 scholars and art researchers from home and abroad participating.

The four-day international symposium is part of the ongoing high-profile exhibition "Grand View: Painting, Calligraphy, Ju Ware and Rare Books from the Northern Sung Dynasty" which the National Palace Museum has organized to mark its official reopening on Feb. 8 after almost two years of remodeling.

Addressing the opening of the symposium, National Palace Museum Director Lin Mun-lee said that arts, culture and the cultural development models from the Sung Dynasty (960-1279) have tremendously influenced the world's cultural development and that the collections of Sung Dynasty artifacts happen to be among the most pivotal collections of the National Palace Museum, which is considered the world's leading Chinese artifact museum.

The scholars and experts from the United Kingdom, Germany, the United States, Japan, South Korea, China and Taiwan are expected to exchange views during the symposium on Sung Dynasty artifacts and the trends of cultural development during that period, Lin said.

The three-month Grand View exhibition, which is scheduled to end March 25, showcases a total of 42 paintings and 29 pieces of calligraphy dating from the Northern Sung period (960-1127), as well as five Northern Sung paintings and calligraphy works on loan from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City.

Also on display are Ju ceramic wares of the Northern Sung period, fired in the early 12th century, which are renowned for the classical beauty of their warm and glossy sky-blue glaze. Surviving pieces of Ju ware are extremely rare, with less than 70 found in collections around the world today. The National Palace Museum is fortunate to have 21, the most of any collection.

Renowned for its impressive collection of art works of the Sung Dynasty, the museum is putting its collection of Sung Dynasty artifacts in its entirety on display for the first and possibly the last time due to the fragility of the art works. The museum is known for its unique collection of some 654,500 imperial art treasures brought to Taiwan at the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949 to keep them out of the hands of the communists.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO IMPORT WORKERS FROM NAURU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday Taiwan will sign a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in labor affairs with Nauru to pave the way for the import of Nauruan workers to Taiwan.
Speaking on the issue while receiving Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty, Chen said one of the purposes of Scotty's current visit to Taiwan is to sign the document with the Council of Labor Affairs.
Chen said he was very happy to have the opportunity to join Scotty in participating in the first leadership summit between Taiwan and its Pacific allies held last year in Palau.
Nauru is now preparing for the establishment of an embassy in Taiwan, which was one of the conclusions reached in bilateral talks held during the summit, Chen pointed out.
According to Chen, exchange activities and cooperation projects between Taiwan and Nauru have been proceeding very smoothly.

While the government has also supported the infrastructure and development projects in Nauru, Taiwan's technical corps have made a great contribution to the agricultural and fishing cooperation between the two countries to improve the well-being of the Nauruan people, Chen said.

Meanwhile, Chen expressed his gratitude to Scotty and the Nauruan people and government for their firm support for Taiwan, especially on the issue of Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DEFENSE MINISTRY TO HOLD REGIONAL SECURITY FORUM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will host a regional security forum Feb. 6-7, with Lee Jye, head of the ministry, to preside over the talks focusing on perspectives on regional security in East Asia, MND officials said Monday.

Many foreign and domestic scholars in the field have been invited to attend the forum, including Randy Schriver, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs; Dan Blumenthal, vice chairman of the U.S.-China Security and Economic Review Commission and former senior director for China, Taiwan and Mongolia in the U.S. Office of the Secretary of Defense; as well as Bernard Cole, a professor of international history at the National War College in Washington, D.C.

Discussions in the forum will center on four major topics, namely ways to improve the military transparency in Asia-Pacific countries, ways to reinforce mutual trust among countries in the region, as well as humanitarian relief operations, anti-terrorism affairs, and international crisis management and conflict prevention, according to the MND.

Participants will also talk about issues concerning China's military threat against Taiwan, the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, China's military modernization, and exchanges and cooperation among Japan, Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAURUAN PRESIDENT ON PRIVATE VISIT IN TAIWAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty's current visit in Taiwan is mostly private in nature, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.
Releasing a news statement concerning Scotty's visit the same day that he met with President Chen Shui-bian, the MOFA said Scotty arrived in Taiwan Saturday for a five-day visit.

Although Scotty's trip is mainly for private purposes, his itinerary includes meeting with President Chen, signing a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in labor affairs with Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lee Ying- yuan, and inspecting the preparation work for the establishment of a Nauruan embassy in Taiwan, the MOFA said.

Nauru, which switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in July 2002, re- established formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan on May 14, 2005 after Scotty was elected president of the South Pacific nation.

Scotty made an official visit to Taiwan in March 2006 and made a private stopover visit in Taiwan between late August and early September the same year on his way to Palau for the first leadership summit between Taiwan and its Pacific allies.
The stopover visit, which was not disclosed until Scotty had left, sparked rumors that he engaged in some kind of "diplomatic extortion" of Taiwan during the visit.

According to MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh, the ministry usually does not release information concerning transit stops or private visits by heads of state or government officials of its diplomatic allies.
However, to avoid unnecessary speculation by the media this time, the ministry is releasing some information about Scotty's private visit after obtaining his permission, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 6.09 points to close at 7,783.12.
The bourse opened at 7,786.77 and fluctuated between 7,823.94 and 7,772.05 during trading. A total of 2.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$75.39 billion (US$2.64 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down 0.4 percent and machinery and electronics shares decreasing 0.1 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 615 to 588, with 194 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARSENIC CONTENT IN GUANDU PLAIN RICE NEGLIGIBLE: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: The arsenic content in rice harvested on Taipei's Guandu Plain is negligible, and the rice poses no threat to human health, an academic at National Taiwan University (NTU) claimed Monday.

Chang Tsun-kuo, a professor in NTU's Department of Bioenvironmental Systems Engineering, said the average amount of arsenic in Guandu Plain rice has been discovered to be just 0.2 ppm, even lower than the German standard of 1 ppm for allowable arsenic content for grains.

Under a contract with the Taipei City Environmental Protection Bureau, Chang has led an NTU research team to conduct field research on the Guandu Plain, where the team has discovered that of the 800 hectares of farmland, 123 hectares were detected to contain arsenic levels above the national standard of 60 ppm for farmland.
Chang attributed the high arsenic content in the soil on the Guandu Plain to the fact that the farmland is irrigated by water from a hotspring valley located in the plain's northern Beitou suburb.
Arsenic content in earth or rocks found in the Beitou hotspring valley has been discovered to be as high as 10,000 ppm, although the arsenic content in the water is only 0.5 ppm, Chang said.
Chang said the arsenic "pollution" on the Guandu Plain is a natural phenomenon resulting from geothermal activity in the hotspring area.

Noting that farmers in the Guandu Plain area have been using hotspring water from Beitou to irrigate their farmlands for more than 200 years, Chang said that no cases of black-foot disease resulting from arsenic-polluted water have been reported in the Guandu Plain area in that time and that rice grown in the area is not harmful to human health.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MACHINE TOOL EXPORTS CONTINUE TO GROW

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported NT$53.5 billion (US$1.62 billion)-worth of machine tools between January and July last year, up 9 percent from the same period of the previous year, the Precision Machinery Development Association of Taiwan reported Monday.

Association President Yang Teh-hua said machine tools have great development potential and estimated that the annual production value of machine tools, parts and components could break NT$400 billion by 2010.
Taiwan is the fourth-largest exporter of machine tools in the world, behind only Japan, Germany and Italy.

The production value of Taiwan's machine tools was registered at NT$109 billion in 2005, of which 78 percent, or NT$85.4 billion, was destined for export. China was the largest export destination, accounting for 34 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST BATHROOM CLEANERS CONTAIN STRONG ACIDS, ALKALIS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The Consumer's Foundation urged the government Monday to require manufacturers of bathroom and toilet cleaners to label the pH value of their products and to issue related warnings for consumers in the wake of survey results showing that 75 percent of these products are either strong acids or alkalis.

The survey was conducted among 20 bathroom and toilet cleaners purchased by the foundation from various department stores, supermarkets, hypermarkets and household item stores in Taipei between Dec. 15, 2006 and Jan. 5, 2007.
Of the 20 products, 13 were strong acids and two were strong alkalis, foundation officials said.
While only seven of the 20 products had the pH value listed, three were wrongly labeled and only four advised consumers to wear gloves while using the cleaners, the officials said.
They called on consumers to select bathroom and toilet cleaners with complete labeling to ensure their own safety.
While using the cleaners, consumers should avoid direct skin contact with the cleaners and should only use them in well-ventilated areas, they said.
If their skin comes in contact with the toxic substances, they should rinse the affected area with plenty of water and seek medical treatment, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HELPS TRAIN DOCTORS FOR MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: Eleven doctors from Mongolia received certificates Monday marking the completion of a six-month training course they undertook in Taiwan.

The 11 doctors received training in emergency rooms and departments of internal medicine, surgery, rehabilitation, ophthalmology, pharmaceuticals and traditional Chinese medicine of Taipei Hospital under the Department of Health, located in Hsinchuang, Taipei County.

Addressing a commencement ceremony, Huang Kun-chang, superintendent of the Taipei Hospital, said Taiwan has helped train a total of 22 Mongolian doctors since Taiwan's International Medical Training Center was established at the hospital in late 2002.
The center provided training for one Mongolian doctor in 2003, following by four in 2004, six in 2005 and 11 in 2006, Huang said.

Of the 11 Mongolian doctors who received training in Taiwan prior to 2005, one has been promoted to be a deputy superintendent of Mongolia's major Central Hospital, Huang said, adding that two others have also been promoted as department chiefs of state-level hospitals in Mongolia.

The training program has not only helped raise the professional standards of Mongolia's doctors but has also led Mongolia, which maintains no formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, into supporting Taiwan in the country's bid to enter the World Health Assembly, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization, as an observer, Huang claimed.
G. Enkhtsetseg, one of the doctors who received their graduate certificates Monday, said she feels blessed and privileged to have had an opportunity to receive training in Taiwan.

Having learned about neurological diagnosis and treatment, Enkhtsetseg said that although much of the equipment she saw and used in Taipei Hospital are still not available in Mongolia's hospitals, the training she has received will benefit her career.

According to Huang, Taipei Hospital has helped train 50 medical professionals from six countries since the inception of the International Medical Training Center. The center has also conducted exchange programs with medical organizations from 31 countries over the past four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD TO REVEAL 2008 PRESIDENTIAL BID `AT RIGHT TIME'

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that he will explicitly announce his 2008 presidential bid "at the right time."

Ma made the remarks during a visit to the outlying county of Penghu as part of his ongoing nationwide tour in his capacity as KMT chairman to gain an understanding of public opinion since he stepped down in last December as Taipei mayor following eight years in office.

Ma has been troubled by the possibility that he will be indicted on embezzlement charges over his alleged misuse of special municipal fees earmarked for his discretionary use while serving as mayor of Taipei. It was widely reported that the prosecution is expected to end its probe into the case and that Ma is likely to be indicted by Feb. 9.

Although Ma has been widely assumed to be the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" best bet for the 2008 presidential election, KMT regulations require that a party candidate must withdraw from elections if prosecuted.

In response to a greeting from local KMT members who urged him not to abandon his desire to take part in the next presidential election despite the possible indictment, Ma thanked them for their support and said that he will announce his presidential bid "at the proper time."
Ma also met Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa and County Council Deputy Speaker Lan Chun-i to exchange opinions on local party affairs.

Ma promised that the KMT and its allies in the "pan-blue alliance" -- the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party -- will jointly field the most qualified candidates in December's legislative elections and the 2008 presidential race.
According to Ma, the KMT primaries for the coming legislative and presidential polls are slated to kick off in early April. "Unity and reform are the party's unchanged top priorities," he said.

The "pan-blue alliance" cannot afford to have another split if it wants to outgun the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union in the coming elections, he said.

PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun called on the KMT and the PFP to collaborate to tackle future elections and meet high public expectations based on their cooperation framework, now that the two parties inked an agreement last month to form a formal alliance.
Should the two parties fail to exercise greater combat ability through the establishment of the new alliance, it will definitely disappoint their many supporters, Lee said.
PFP legislative caucus whip Cheng Chin-ling said that she favors the idea of fielding the two parties' common hopefuls in the December legislative elections under the name of the alliance.
The two parties must do their utmost to secure "pan-blue" victory in future elections and no options should be ruled out, she said.

Lee's and Cheng's comments came while answering reporters' questions after it was reported that KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih and his PFP counterpart Chin Ching-sheng will begin this week discussing cooperative issues for the year-end legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO WORK ON PLAN TO GET FUGITIVE TYCOON BACK: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Monday that the government will continue to work on a contingency plan to get a fugitive tycoon back to Taiwan to face justice for a series of scandals surrounding his business group.

Huang was referring to Wang You-theng, founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, who was taken into custody by the U.S. authorities upon his arrival in Los Angeles Saturday because his Taiwan and Dominican Republic passports were invalid as a result of efforts by the Taiwan authorities.

Noting that a U.S. court hearing is expected to be held on Wang's case within a week, Huang said it is inappropriate for the Taiwan government to comment on the issue now that the case has entered the U.S. judicial process.
"Taiwan will respect the handling of the case by the U.S. judicial authorities and will continue to keep tabs on developments and try to work out contingency plans," Huang said.

Wang first fled to China late last December shortly before the Rebar scandal broke, from where he later fled to the United States. Taiwan put him on its most-wanted list in mid-January. He tried to fly to Myanmar via Singapore last Wednesday but was sent back to the U.S. last Friday by the Singapore authorities as he lacked the proper travel documents.

On reports that the government has spent lavishly on hiring top-notch lawyers to fight the elite lawyer team expected to be hired by Wang, Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said the government has hired professional legal advisers and is seeking their views.
Wang Chieh-yeh said that whether Wang will be able to enter the United States is an issue for the United States to decide and that the Taiwan government has no need to hire lawyers over that issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPECTS PARTNERSHIP WITH TAIWAN ON IPR ISSUES

TEXT.P: The U.S. government expects a productive partnership with Taiwan on issues concerning intellectual property rights (IPR) protection, the director of the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT's) Taipei office said Monday.

Stephen M. Young made the remarks in an address to the opening of an IPR protection workshop, a two-day event organized by National Chengchi University's Graduate Institute of Intellectual Property, the Licensing Executive Society.

In addition to Young, several U.S. Department of Justice officials and judges from Thailand, as well as Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin and professionals from Taiwan's judicial sector also took part in the workshop titled "Meeting the Challenges of IPR Protection in Taiwan and Beyond."

Young praised Taiwan for its efforts to establish a new IP court and expressed hope that judges and prosecutors in the district courts will have the resources and training they need to deal with IPR-related cases.

He also said the U.S. welcomes Taiwan's efforts that see the Legislative Yuan in the process of reviewing legislation to regulate peer-to-peer file sharing, and a plan to put forth legislation on Internet Service Provider (ISP) liability.

Young said Taiwan's economic future depends on IPR, explaining that as Taiwan's economy continues to evolve into "one of the most technologically advanced in the world, " strong IPR protection and enforcement means more choices for consumers, more opportunities for Taiwan businesses, and more jobs for Taiwan's workforce.

The workshop is supported by the U.S. Department of Justice/U.S. Overseas Prosecutorial Development, Assistance and Training, as well as Taiwan's Judicial Yuan, the Ministry of Justice and the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, according to an AIT press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER SUGGESTS EARLY REGISTRATION FOR PRIMARIES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/05/07 17:56:30 (By L.S. Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh, who has expressed confidence in his possible bid to run for the presidency in 2008, suggested Sunday that the registration of candidates for the Democratic Progressive Party presidential primaries be moved ahead of schedule.

Hsieh, in Los Angeles after attending the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C. on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, said at a news conference that he would voice no opinions about whether the DPP primaries should be held earlier than originally arranged in May this year, but he suggested that the primary registration be moved ahead of schedule. Registration was slated for April.
He said early registration will help sort out sooner who exactly is running in the presidential primaries and give more time for inner party negotiation before a DPP ticket is finalized.
After the news conference, Hsieh delivered a speech titled "Taiwan Identity, Reconciliation and Co-existence" at a dinner party hosted by the DPP's U.S. West Coast Chapter in his honor.

Hsieh, who said during a recent interview with a Taiwan-based TV channel that he is seriously considering running for the presidency in 2008 and when he should formally announce his bid if he decides to do so, said he first needs to complete a tour of Taiwan's counties and cities to assess his ability to shoulder such a great responsibility and to evaluate his support base before making a decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES STAND AT US$265.97 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves amounted to US$265.97 billion as of the end of January, down US$176 million from the month-earlier level, according to statistics released Monday by Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC).

CBC officials attributed the slight decrease mainly due to domestic investors increasing their foreign currency investments. Taiwan remained the country with the world's third-largest foreign exchange reserves after China and Japan, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY CPI UP 0.4% YEAR-ON-YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) for January increased 0.4 percent from the level of the same month last year, according to tallies released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
DGBAS officials attributed the rise to hikes in cigarette, vegetable, fish, fuel and clothing prices this year.

By category, prices of miscellaneous items jumped 3.91 percent year-on-year in January; transportation prices climbed 1.5 percent; food prices rose 0.58 percent; and clothing prices increased 2.5 percent, the officials said.

The wholesale price index for January soared 7.02 percent compared with the same month of last year, owing to hikes in the prices of basic metals, electrical and mechanical equipment and chemical materials, they said.
While the prices of products for domestic sales rose 8.18 percent year-on-year in January, the prices of imports jumped 7.64 percent, and the prices of exports climbed 5.36 percent, they said.

Meanwhile, the officials said Taiwan's inflation rate for 2006 registered a three-year low at 0.6 percent, compared with the United States' 3.2 percent, Japan's 0.3 percent, Singapore's 1 percent, China's 1.5 percent, Hong Kong's 2 percent and South Korea's 2.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOG-RESCUE GROUP TAKES STRAY DOG OFF FREEWAY

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Concerns Stray Animal Association (KCSAA) rescued a stray dog that had been living on a freeway for more than two years, an association spokesman said Monday.
The association sent a crew of more than 10 Sunday to a section of the Sun Yat- Sen Freeway in the central county of Changhwa to capture the dog, the spokesman noted.
The animal, which lived on scraps thrown to it by drivers, was tranquillized by KCSAA staff following hours of chasing, the spokesman said.
An initial checkup showed that the dog was in good shape, the spokesman added.
The rescue, however, drew criticism from other rescue groups who said the action was dangerous for both the catchers and the dog, as well as violating traffic laws.

In response, traffic police said that considering the association was helping "remove a road obstacle, " they would be lenient on this occasion with the KCSAA but stressed that their action was not encouraged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINES CALL FOR MORE ATTENTION TO LATE TAIWAN ATHLETE

TEXT.P: Members of the indigenous community called Sunday for more attention to be paid to the memory of Yang Chuan-kwang, Taiwan's legendary decathlete, also known as the "Iron man of Asia," who died of a stroke in California recently.

The remark came after Yang's funeral in the United States, where his wife and children insisted that he be buried. A memorial service was also held simultaneously at his hometown in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, which few people attended.

Aboriginal Legislator Liao Kuo-tung of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), who assisted Yang's family in organizing Sunday's memorial service in Taitung, said he hoped the government and the media will attach greater importance to the "Iron man of Asia."
He lamented that since Yang's death, the media has focused a great deal of attention on Hsu Wei-lun, a 28-year-old actress who died on the same day as Yang following a serious car crash.

Liao said the government will hold another memorial service for Taiwan's first Olympic silver medal winner in Taipei Feb. 9 and added that the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and the Council of Indigenous Peoples will also organize yet another one in the county.

Lin Ching-long, a student of Yang's and a member of Taiwan's national pole vaulting team, said Yang made an irreplaceable contribution toward raising Taiwan's international profile but did not receive much attention from the media.
Yang, a member of the Ami tribe born in 1933, won a gold medal in the decathalon at the 1954 Asian Games in Manila and in 1960, took silver at the Rome Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE EQUIVALENT OF TOEFL TO MAKE OFFICIAL DEBUT

TEXT.P: A Chinese equivalent of the TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language) will be officially launched in March overseas, the Ministry of Education (MOE) announced Monday.

MOE officials said the Test of Proficiency-Hanyu (TOP), devised by National Taiwan Normal University and a Chinese language test promotion committee at the commission of the ministry, began tests for basic-level Chinese in Thailand, South Korea, Japan, Britain and the United States on a trial basis last year.

Chang Chin-sheng, director of the ministry's Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations, said the first test of all-level Chinese language will be launched in Japan, South Korea, Vietnam, Thailand, New York and Los Angeles. The basic-level test will be held in Britain and France, tentatively set for March or April.
Chang said that as it will be on a trial basis in Britain and France, there will be no registration fees charged, although registration fees will be needed in other areas.

Those who pass the tests -- available in either traditional or simplified characters -- will be issued a score sheet and conferred a language proficiency certificate, and will be given priority should they seek scholarships in Taiwan.
TOP performance will also be used as a reference by colleges and universities when screening foreign students' enrollment applications, he said.
The government will also encourage Taiwan businessmen to give hiring priority to those who have passed the TOP.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUESTIONS RAISED ABOUT SEXUAL HARASSMENT PREVENTION ACT

TEXT.P: A lawmaker raised questions about the effects of the Sexual Harassment Prevention Act one year after it went into effect Monday.

Citing government statistics, Huang Sue-ying of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said there had been only 168 complaints filed under the law, with Taipei City, Taipei County and Kaohsiung City accounting for 50 percent of them, and nine counties reporting none at all, which the lawmaker claimed is evidence that both the central and local governments have failed to raise public awareness about the offense.

The lawmaker also raised the question of the ability of employers to handle the complaints, as only 37 percent of the complaints dealt by them were determined as harassment, while 75 percent of complaints logged with police were determined to be offenses.

As the offenses prohibited under the act are often offenses also covered by the Criminal Code, the Social Order Act or the Gender Equity Education Act, Huang claimed it stirred up confusion among the victims of sexual harassment about which law their case should be pursued under.

In response to the last point of lawmaker's criticism, an official from Sexual Assault Prevention Commission under the Ministry of the Interior said victims can pursue their complaints via whatever law they like, although the Social Order Act might provide them with recourse more quickly than the other laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU FIRM ON INDEPENDENCE, CLARIFIES EX-PRESIDENT'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) stands firm on its dream of pursuing Taiwan independence and of making Taiwan a normal country through writing a new constitution and changing its official title, TSU lawmakers said Monday.

According to TSU lawmaker Ho Ming-hao, the party has never deviated from its pro-independence stance through a change of the nation's name and creating a new constitution, although it calls for greater government attention to the people's livelihoods.

Ho's clarification of the TSU's standing came after former President Lee Teng- hui, the party's so-called "spiritual leader, " said recently in two separate interviews that there is no need for Taiwan to pursue formal independence because it is already an independent sovereignty. Lee also claimed that he has never backed Taiwan independence.
Lee's remarks aroused strong criticism from supporters of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the TSU, with many of Lee's supporters' clubs planning to disband.

In a bid to dispel public anger over his comments, Lee invited pro-independence backers to have breakfast with him Sunday in southern Kaohsiung city to clarify his stance regarding Taiwan's future. He also said later the same day that he will keep insisting on Taiwan's sovereignty and pursuing formal independence and new constitution.

Claiming that many grass-roots supporters have accepted Lee's explanation and no longer doubt his position, Ho urged the DPP and pro-independence activists not to attack the TSU or Lee over his statement, as the two parties need to continue cooperating.
TSU lawmaker Lo Chih-ming said that the party is determined to adopt a left- leaning moderate path by sticking to the goals of stepping up Taiwan's democratization and upgrading its economy.
The DPP should also adopt a middle-of-the-road policy if it is afraid that the TSU's policy change could sway its supporters to the TSU's fold, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELOCATING CKS MEMORIAL HALL NEEDS NO LAW REVISION: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Monday that a relocation of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall at the heart of Taipei City would require no revision of the law.
DPP Legislator Gao Jyh-peng noted that the organic law of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall administration does not stipulate the exact location of the hall.

As such, the Executive Yuan need only reach a formal resolution on the relocation at its floor meeting. The memorial hall could then be relocated to Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan, the location of the temporary mausoleums of Chiang Kai-shek, who died in 1975, and his son Chiang Ching-kuo, who died in 1988, Gao said.
The current site of the CKS Memorial Hall could then be renamed the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, he added.

He said the DPP Central Standing Committee invited Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng to report at its weekly meeting last Wednesday, in which Tu suggested the change and Premier Su Cheng-chang said the matter could be studied.
"The Executive Yuan should pass a relocation of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall as soon as possible," Gao urged.

He said that with the coming of 60th anniversary of the 2-28 Incident of 1947, when troops of the Chinese Nationalist government crushed a revolt in Taiwan, killing thousands of people, the government should form an investigation committee to get to the bottom of the tragedy that continues to split society today.
If Chiang Kai-shek is confirmed to have been the perpetrator of the suppression, there is no way the next generation should be educated to pay respects to the killer, he said.
The call for memorial hall relocation came after reports that the Ministry of National Defense had agreed to remove all statues of the late president from barracks around the country before Feb. 28.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs also announced last week a plan to change the name of the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to "CPC, Taiwan," and that of the Chinese Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) to "CSBC, Taiwan" as part of the government's efforts to avoid confusing the state-run companies with Chinese ones.
The opposition parties have accused the DPP of "ruling the nation with ideology" in a bid to blot out the last vestiges of China's influence from the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG CUSTOMS SEIZES PEAR TREE STEMS SMUGGLED FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: Customs authorities have recently cracked down on smuggling in central Taichung county, and seized over 60,000 pear tree stems smuggled from China, which carried buds and flowers to be used as grafts, customs officials said Monday.

Acting on tips, customs inspectors raided an illegal exchange of some of the smuggled pear tree branches at the Tungshih town fruit and vegetable market, and then discovered the rest of the smuggled plants at a warehouse run by a local farmers' association.

The inspectors found that all of the smuggled buds and flowers, weighted 600 kg in total, are from premium strains, and provide sufficient material for local farmers to raise grafted pears on about 50 hectares of orchards, the customs officials said.

However, when examined by the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, the smuggled pear tree stems were found to be hosting some virus- carrying foreign insects, the officials said, noting that if the stems had been grafted onto local trees, they would have badly affected the island's ecology.
During the raid, a 40-year-old man suspected of illegal trading was arrested on suspicion of involvement in the illegal trading of the smuggled stems. An investigation into the case is underway.

Grafted pears are one of major fruits grown in Taiwan, with farmers grafting buds and flowers from pear trees grown in temperate areas like Lishan (Mountain Li) in central Taiwan, or Japan, onto their plants to produce juicy and sweet "temperate pears."
So far, it is permitted to import only pear buds and flowers from certificated districts of Japan into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT APPOINTS TEMPORARY MANAGERS FOR CHINA REBAR

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court Monday appointed three temporary managers for the financially troubled China Rebar Co. while it continues to review the company's insolvency reorganization petition, filed last December.
The court appointed a deputy manager of the Mega International Commercial Bank, which is a major creditor of Rebar, a lawyer from the KPMG accounting firm and an accountant as temporary managers.

The court selected the three after consulting with the Ministry of Economic Affairs and decided that they are professional and skilled in company organizational affairs, a court spokesman said Monday.

A self-help association formed by suppliers to the Idee Fashion Stores, a sister company to the China Rebar, had proposed that Wang Lin-mei, general manager of both Idee and China Rebar, be appointed as China Rebar's temporary manager on the basis that she best knows what is needed, and is most able to stabilize the company's operations.
But the court rejected the association's proposal as Wang herself is suspected of diverting Rebar's funds and is free only due to a NT$8-million bail release, the spokesman said.

The Company Act stipulates that when a company's board of directors is unable to function and such a situation is likely to cause damage to the company, the court can appoint temporary managers at the petition of interested parties, or the prosecution, to exercise the functions of the chairman and the board.
The court's ruling came as a response to a petition by the district prosecutor's office, the spokesman said.

China Rebar and the Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co., both subsidiaries of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, applied for insolvency protection Dec. 29. The disclosure of the conglomerate's financial troubles kicked off intensive investigations into a series of economic crimes affecting many of the group's several dozen affiliates.

The primary fugitive Wang You-theng, founder of the Rebar Group, is now being held by the U.S. immigration in Los Angeles. His attempt to fly to Myanmar from the United States failed last Saturday when the authorities of Singapore, his planned transit stop, sent him back to the U.S. and Taiwan authorities then invalidated his travel documents.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqis Fault Pace of U.S. Plan in Attack
A growing number of Iraqis blamed the United States on Sunday for creating conditions that led to the worst single suicide bombing in the war, which devastated a Shiite market in Baghdad the day before. They argued that the Americans had been slow in completing the vaunted new American security plan, making Shiite neighborhoods much more vulnerable to such horrific attacks. @@The critics said the new plan, which the Americans have started to execute, had emasculated the Mahdi Army, the Shiite militia that is considered responsible for many attacks on Sunnis, but that many Shiites say had been the only effective deterrent against sectarian reprisal attacks in Baghdad's Shiite neighborhoods.
Wall Street Journal: Tired of Laughter, Beijing Gets Rid Of Bad Translations
For years, foreigners in China have delighted in the loopy English translations that appear on the nation's signs. They range from the offensive ("Deformed Man," outside toilets for the handicapped) to the sublime (on park lawns, "Show Mercy to the Slender Grass").
Last week, Beijing city officials unveiled a plan to stop the laughter. With hordes of foreign visitors expected in town for the 2008 Summer Olympics, Beijing wants to cleanse its signs of translation nonsense. For the next eight months, 10 teams of linguistic monitors will patrol the city's parks, museums, subway stations and other public places searching for gaffes to fix.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE RESHUFFLES POSTS

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office Monday announced an interchange of posts between Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen.

Other changes include the appointment of National Security Bureau Director Hsueh Shih-min as Strategy Adviser to the President, and the succession of Deputy Director Shi Hwei-yow to Hsueh's post, according to a Presidential Office news release.
The new posts will become effective Wednesday, the news release stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO SIGN LABOR COOPERATION PACT WITH NAURU THURSDAY

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Lee Ying-yuan will sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with visiting Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty Thursday on bilateral cooperation in labor affairs, a CLA official said Monday.

The official in charge of vocational training made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian said during a meeting with Scotty earlier in the day that one of the purposes of Scotty's current visit is to sign a labor cooperation agreement with the CLA to pave the way for importing laborers from Nauru.

Noting that both Taiwan and Nauru are interested in cooperation in labor affairs, the CLA official said the two sides have decided to sign an MOU expressing their intention to forge cooperative ties in the field.

Nevertheless, he said, the two sides have not yet discussed any details regarding the introduction of Nauruan workers into Taiwan. The CLA has not yet studied the feasibility of importing Nauruan laborers and the concrete measures necessary for implementing such a policy, the official said, adding that future developments in this regard will depend on whether both countries share similar ends.
Scotty arrived in Taipei Saturday for a five-day visit.

Nauru, which switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in July 2002, re- established formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan in May 2005 after Scotty was elected president of the South Pacific nation.

According to President Chen, Nauru is now preparing for the establishment of an embassy in Taiwan, which was one of the conclusions reached in bilateral talks held during a leadership summit between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies, including Nauru.

Chen said exchange activities and cooperation projects between Taiwan and Nauru have been proceeding very smoothly. Taiwan's technical mission in Nauru has contributed much to agricultural and fishing cooperation between the two countries and improvement of the well-being of the Nauruan people, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA REMINDS MANILA TO RESPECT TAIWAN'S LABOR ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government agrees in principle some of the Philippines- proposed new measures to protect its workers in Taiwan, but suggests it refrain from interfering with Taiwan's internal administration or encroaching upon Taiwan's administrative sovereignty, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) officials said Monday.

The officials were responding to media reports that the Philippine government will implement a package of new measures from March, which include demanding that Taiwanese employers provide their Philippine household servants with a separate room for sleeping, and demanding that Philippine workers intending to change employers should apply for approval with the Philippine representative office in Taiwan.
In the process, the media reports said, the Philippine government will also require Taiwanese employers to explain why the Philippine workers would change employers.

Noting that the ROC government has spared no efforts to protect the rights and interests of foreign people working in Taiwan, the CLA officials said the council respects the planned measures that will ask employers to provide a single sleeping room to their Philippine household maids or family helpers.

However, the officials said the CLA could not agree to the proposed measures of requiring local employers to answer to the Philippine representative office's questioning and Filipino workers applying for its representative office approval before changing employers.

Such measures, if implemented, would infringe upon Taiwan's administrative sovereignty, the officials said, adding that it is a general international norm and custom that labor importing country's legal provisions should be respected in handling labor disputes.

Stressing that the CLA as well as city and county governments around Taiwan have had proper mechansims in place to handle labor disputes, including change of employers, the officials said, the Philippine government should not try to unilaterally interfere with Taiwan's labor administration or exercise of its administrative sovereignty.

Since labor rights protection is a universal value and one of Taiwan's top policy guideline, the officials said the CLA will ask Taiwan's representative office in Manila to gain a better understanding of details of the Philippine- proposed new measures and to negotiate with relevant Philippine agencies over the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGEST YET HAUL OF CONTRABAND DRUG SEIZED ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: Agents of the Bureau of Investigation seized, last month, 32,000 tablets of Nimetazepam on the outlying island of Kinmen, the largest haul yet intercepted in the mail from Taiwan proper, a bureau spokesman said Monday.

A 48 year-old man, identified as Lu Hsing-huan, who is alleged to have tried smuggling the contraband third-grade drug to Xiamen, in China's Fujian province, through direct trade and shipping links between the two sides. Lu was arrested Jan. 22 by investigating agents upon his arrival from Xiamen at the Taoyuan International Airport near Taipei, the spokesman said.

It was the first time that a drug courier sought to export contraband narcotics from Taiwan to China using the mini three links, the spokesman said, adding that the illegal drugs have a street value of up to NT$6 million.

Nimetazepam has reportedly become increasingly popular among Chinese youth -- in addition to marijuana and ketamine -- prompting Taiwan drug dealers to seek to smuggle the drugs into China to tap the strong demand there.

According to the spokesman, Kinmen's prosecutor was tipped off some six months ago that Lu was planning to smuggle a large haul of Nimetazepam from Kinmen to Xiaman by the Feb. 18 Chinese New Year, using direct transport links between the two sides. Citing investigators stationed on Kinmen, the spokesman said that Lu mailed the 32,000 tablets of Nimetazepam in three parcels from Taiwan to Kinmen Jan. 3, from where he attempted to have the illicit drug smuggled into Xiamen through the mini three links.

Investigation shows that Lu flew from Taiwan to Kinmen the same day to arrange smuggling channels to take the contraband substance to Xiamen. He flew back to Taiwan later the same day and immediately transferred to Macau en route to Xiamen, where he planned to take delivery of the three parcels himself.

However, Lu was forced to fly back to Taiwan and was detained by agents Jan. 22 upon his arrival at the Taoyuan airport, after having waited in vain in Xiamen for the arrival of the three parcels of Nimetazepam, which had been intercepted by relevant authorities on Kinmen Island.

Although Lu argued that he had no any idea that an unlawful drug was concealed in the three parcels, the spokesman said, he was nonetheless sent to the Kinmen Prosecutor's Office for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 370 CHINESE ILLEGAL MIGRANTS SENT HOME OVER 11 DAYS

TEXT.P: Taiwan repatriated Monday 152 illegal Chinese migrants, bringing the numbers of those still in Taiwanese custody to a historic low, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) said.

The action followed the largest ever operation, which sent home 218 illegal Chinese immigrants on Jan. 26. The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said the repatriation of as many as 370 illegal Chinese immigrants in only 11 days is encouraging.

China has now become receptive to bringing home illegal immigrants,Liu Te-shun, MAC vice chairman said Monday.This is not only good news for those Chinese who want to go home for the Lunar New Year, but also a sign that China is finally willing to face up to the problem and to take care of its citizens.

China's past reluctance to accept the return of its illegal migrants to Taiwan long disturbed Taiwan authorities. Delays in repatriation operations often caused the number of migrants held in Taiwanese facilities to soar, with 1993 seeing a record of 5944 inmates in three asylums in northern Hsinchu, eastern Ilan and outlying Matsu Island, according to NIA tallies.

Now there are only 128 Chinese illegal immigrants in the asylums after Monday's operation, the NIA officials said, adding that all of them had been implicated in criminal cases, and therefore there are no inmates pending repatriation, and this too is a record, officials said.
The repatriation of Chinese illegal immigrants has been conducted through the Red Cross Societies of the two sides, in accordance to a 1990 Kinmen Agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SECURITY BUREAU TO GET 1ST CIVILIAN DIRECTOR

TEXT.P: Shi Hwei-yow, deputy director of the National Security Bureau (NSB) , will soon become the bureau's first civilian head.

The Presidential Office announced Monday that NSB Director Hsueh Shih-min will be transferred to serve as a strategy adviser to the president and that the post to be vacated following his job transfer will be filled by Shi. The personnel reshuffle will take effect Wednesday.
Up until now, the NSB, the country's top intelligence agency, has been headed by senior officials with military backgrounds.
Shi, a judge-turned-politician, will be the first non-military NSB chief when he assumes office Wednesday.

Shi, who has a Ph.D. in law from National Chengchi University, had been a Tainan and Taipei district court judge before joining the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) in the early 1990s. During his stints as SEF's deputy secretary-general and later SEF secretary-general and vice chairman, Shi took part in many important rounds of negotiations with Chinese officials to lay down a framework for institutionalized engagements across the Taiwan Strait.

Shi later served as vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council which charts Taiwan's policy toward China. When the Coast Guard Administration was established in 2004, Shi became its inaugural chief, a post that provided him with further opportunities to deal with the military and intelligence units.
In February 2006, Shi was "demoted" to serve as NSB deputy chief. The unexpected job transfer caused wide attention at that time. Shi has consistently kept a low profile since then.

Sources close to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Shi's "demotion" a year ago was actually an arrangement to prepare him for taking up a heavier duty in the country's intelligence system.

Many DPP lawmakers have expressed high expectations of Shi's new assignment, expecting him to streamline the country's intelligence operations. They said they are hopeful that Shi's promotion will mark a major step forward toward the goal of having a civilian to lead the country's military.

In contrast, opposition Kuomintang legislators, including Ting Shou-chung, were skeptical about Shi's qualification and competence, saying they doubt Shi's ability to head the county's mammoth intelligence and security system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 6, or the 19th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1643: Abel Janszoon Tasman, Dutch mariner and explorer who was the first European to discover Tasmania and New Zealand in 1642, discovers the Fiji Islands in the Pacific.
1665: Queen Anne, last Stuart ruler of Britain, is born.
1778: Britain declares war on France.
1788: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state in the Union of American States.
1804: Joseph Priestley, British chemist moted for work on the isolation of gases and his discovery of oxygen (1774), dies at the age of 71.
1819: The East India Company, represented by Stamford Raffles, sets up its settlement at Singapore.
1840: Britain annexes New Zealand.
1895: Babe Ruth (George Herman), American baseball player with a tremendous batting record, is born.
1899: The Treaty of Paris is ratified, whereby Spain cedes Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States for US$20 million.
1911: Ronald Reagan, an actor turned politician and the 40th president of the United States, is born.
1917: British women over 30 get the vote.
1922: The Washington Conference ends with the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan agreeing on restricting the use of poison gas and submarine warfare.
1932: Japanese troops capture Harbin in northeastern China.
1932: The ROC National Military Council is established.
1938: The ROC National Military Council sets up a Political Department, with Chen Cheng serves as director and Chou En-lai (Zhou Enlai) and Huang Chi-hsiang as deputy directors.
1941: Erwin Rommel, a German general known as "the Desert Fox" who committed suicide after his implication in the July Plot to assassinate Hitler in 1944, becomes the supreme commander of German forces in Africa.
1945: American General Douglas MacArthur announces the retaining of Manila and the rescuing of more than 5,000 prisoners of war.
1952: King George VI of Britain dies peacefully at Sandringham. He was succeeded by his eldest daughter Princess Elizabeth.
1957: Taiwan's textile industry enters the age of chemical fibers, as a man-made fiber company's plant in Toufen begins production.
1958: The Manchester soccer team of Britain, one of the best teams in Europe, is virtually wiped out in an air crash in Munich.
1983: Klaus Barbie, known as "the Butcher of Lyon" during World War II, is charged in Lyon, France, with crimes against humanity.
1983: Lee Mei-hsu, noted Taiwanese painter, dies at the age of 82.
1999: The Taipei District Court sentences Hong Kong business tycoon Lin Por-yen to three years and two months in prison for his role in a bribery scandal.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski says that despite pressure from mainland China, his government will not change its decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
2000: Tarja Halonen becomes first woman president of Finland.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Holy, sainted men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with wise and good men I would be satisfied."

Manila Bulletin: Elected officials need not resign

The Philippine Daily InquirerG Palace parties fighting

DOC.HEADLINE: NAURU TO SET UP EMBASSY IN MARCH: MOFA

TEXT.P: Nauru is set to establish an embassy in Taiwan next month, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Lee Chuan-tung, director-general of the MOFA's Department of East Asian & Pacific Affairs, also said that Nauruan Ambassador to the Republic of China Ludwig D. Keke, who arrived in Taiwan recently, will present his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian soon.
Lee noted that since the two countries re-established diplomatic relations in 2005, exchange activities and cooperation projects between the two countries have been proceeding smoothly.
After Nauru sets up the embassy in March, relations between the two countries will be further boosted, he added.

Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty, who is currently on a five-day visit in Taiwan, met with President Chen Monday. His itinerary also includes signing a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in labor affairs with Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lee Ying-yuan and inspecting the preparation work for the establishment of the embassy.

Nauru, which switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in July 2002, re- established formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan on May 14, 2005 after Scotty was elected president of the South Pacific nation.

Scotty made an official visit to Taiwan in March 2006 and made a private stopover visit in Taiwan between late August and early September the same year on his way to Palau for the first leadership summit between Taiwan and its Pacific allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER SUPPORTS CIVILIAN CONTROL OF MILITARY

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye expressed support Tuesday for the idea of civilian control of the military, saying he hopes the goal can be achieved as soon as possible.
Lee said that he has been discussing the issue with President Chen Shui-bian and that he "can leave any time" if the president has found a suitable person to replace him.

Lee was commenting on recent remarks by President Chen that he hopes the principle of civilian control of the military, which has not been realized in the past seven years, can be implemented in the final year of his term.

On the Ministry of National Defense's recent decision to remove the statues of late President Chiang Kai-shek from military bases around the country, Lee urged the opposition parties not to make a big deal out of what he called a "simple question."
Lee explained that the ministry is not going to destroy the statues but is only relocating the statues to appropriate places, such as a museum.

Noting that different opinions always abound in a democratic society, Lee said there is no need for members of the opposition to squabble over the issue because they can reinstall the statues when they come to power in the future if they are unhappy with the decision.

According to Lee, removing the statues has not undermined the military's respect for Chiang, as the military still educates soldiers about Chiang's contributions to Taiwan and follows Chiang's defense policy and his principles in dealing with China.

Calling Chiang the key perpetrator responsible for the 228 Incident of 1947 in which thousands of people were massacred by Kuomintang (KMT) troops in the suppression of a rebellion against KMT rule in Taiwan, legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have requested that the statues of the late KMT leader be removed by Feb. 28 this year in memory of the 60th anniversary of the incident.
Legislators from the opposition KMT and People First Party have criticized Lee for approving the DPP's request, saying Lee was currying favor with the DPP to secure his position as defense minister.
The opposition legislators claim the move is intended by the DPP to gain the support of pro-independence voters in elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ HAS PROVIDED EVIDENCE AGAINST FUGITIVE TYCOON TO U.S.: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has provided criminal evidence against a fugitive tycoon to U.S. judicial authorities for reference, Vice Minister of Justice Lee Chin-yung said Tuesday.

However, Lee said that he "could not confirm" media reports that prosecutors recently went to the United States to communicate directly with U.S. officials on the case of Wang You-theng, founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, who is wanted in Taiwan for his suspected involvement in a series of fraud and embezzlement scandals surrounding his business group.
To get Wang back to Taiwan to face justice, the prosecutors also communicated with the U.S. officials on possible ways of cooperation, the reports said.

Taiwan put Wang on its most-wanted list in mid-January. He tried to fly to Myanmar via Singapore last Wednesday but was sent back to the United States last Friday by Singaporean authorities as he lacked the proper travel documents.

Wang arrived in Los Angeles Saturday and was taken into custody by U.S. immigration officials because his Taiwan and Dominican Republic passports were invalid as a result of efforts by the Taiwan authorities. A U.S. court hearing on whether Wang can stay in the United States will be held in one week.

Lee said that to get Wang back to face justice will live up to the public's expectations and that to enhance the U.S. understanding of Wang's involvement in a series of scandals surrounding his business group is crucial to negotiations with the U.S. authorities in getting him back to facilitate the probe.

Lee noted that the ministry is playing a dual role in Wang's case. First, the ministry, based on the judicial assistance agreement signed between Taiwan and the United States in March 2002, is communicating directly with the U.S. judicial authorities, requesting assistance from the U.S. Justice Department.
However, Lee said that the ministry has yet to receive notification from the United States on sending officials to the country to deal with Wang's case.

Secondly, many agencies under the Executive Yuan are dealing with Wang's case, particularly the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is in charge of negotiations with the United States, and the MOJ is serving as the legal adviser to the Executive Yuan, providing views on legal counselling.
Asked whether prosecutors have been sent to the United States or whether prosecutors have traveled to the United States with foreign affairs officials, Lee said he couldn't "confirm the matter."

China Rebar and the Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co., both subsidiaries of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, applied for insolvency protection Dec. 29. The disclosure of the two companies' financial troubles triggered a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar affiliate, Jan. 5, as well as intensive investigations into a series of economic crimes affecting many of the group's several dozen affiliates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY RUNS TWO SHELTERS FOR HOMELESS

TEXT.P: Taipei City social affairs authorities have been managing two halfway houses for the city's homeless, with the shelters being equipped with a total of 104 beds to help those living on the streets survive the bitter winter, city officials said.

Statistics compiled by the municipal government's Bureau of Social Affairs show that there are some 500 people living on the streets in the city, with 220 gathering in the Chungcheng district and around 80 staying on a street in the old Wanhua district.

Bureau officials said that currently, the city's policy on dealing with the homeless issue focuses on efforts to guide street people to return home and to assist those capable of working to find jobs.

There are two different shelter programs for the homeless, with the first offering accommodations for a 1-3 month short-term stay, and the second providing accommodations for up to a year, according to the bureau.
Last year, the bureau helped 381 homeless people find jobs, with 128 of these people keeping their jobs for at least three months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF HOMESTAY PROVIDERS IN TAIWAN TOPS 2,000

TEXT.P: The number of homestay providers around Taiwan had increased to 2,001 as of the end of 2006, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Of the 2,001 homestay providers, 1,704 are licensed, up 42.7 percent from the year-earlier level, DGBAS officials said.
These licensed homestay providers offer a total of 6,836 rooms, the officials said.
By region, Hualien, Nantou and Yilan counties are home to the largest number of homestay providers, they said.

While Hualien County saw the number of its homestay providers soar 73.5 percent from the previous year to 439 in 2006, the number in Nantou and Yilan counties rose more than 20 percent to 347 and 240, respectively, they said.

Owing to the competition from homestay providers, the average hotel occupancy rate in the country declined to 69.2 percent in 2006, down 2.8 percentage points over the previous year, the officials said, adding that the average occupancy rate of international-class hotels registered a drop of 2.9 percentage points.
In 2006, there were 60 international-class hotels and 29 ordinary hotels in Taiwan, they said.

The rates for international-class hotel rooms averaged NT$3,272 (US$99.45) per night in 2006, up 5.1 percent from the year-earlier level, and those for ordinary hotel rooms averaged NT$2,222 per night, up 5percent, the officials said.

Much of Jakarta was crippled yesterday as the worst deluge in five years cut road, rail and telecommunications links to the Indonesian capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 92.63 points to close at 7,875.75.
The bourse opened at 7,816.3 and fluctuated between 7,875.75 and 7,802.94 during trading. A total of 3.49 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$97.81 billion (US$2.97 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by cement stocks and textile stocks both at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, construction issues at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 789 to 400, with 202 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC AGREES TO QUICK OPENING TO CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will permit Chinese tourists and cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights on weekends and holidays soon after wrapping up bilateral negotiations, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said Tuesday.

Liu made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan seminar sponsored by the legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , members of which suggested that the government permit the opening as soon as possible after the coming Chinese New Year -- which falls on Feb. 18 -- to help bolster Taiwan's economy.

Officials from relevant government agencies, including the MAC, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Ministry of the Interior and the Central Bank of China (CBC) , as well as KMT lawmakers such as Tseng Yung-chuan, Lai Shyh-bao, Alex Fei and Hung Hsiu-chu were present.

According to Liu, bilateral talks on Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists, cross-strait weekend and holiday charter flights, and the exchange of Chinese yuan in Taiwan have made concrete progress and the MAC will allow the opening soon after the two sides conclude negotiations.
CBC Deputy Governor Hsu I-hsiung voiced the bank's support for allowing renminbi-new Taiwan dollar exchanges in Taiwan as part of the government's efforts to wipe out black market deals.
Meanwhile, local real-estate and property developers forecast that opening up to Chinese tourists will galvanize market demand for department stores, hotels, shopping malls and office buildings.

As Taiwan's property prices still lag far behind those in other developed countries, coming Chinese tourists with strong purchasing power are very likely to target the local real-estate market, industry sources said.
According to a survey carried out by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, Chinese tourists spent an average of US$987 at each retailer -- the world's highest level.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST HAIR DYES CONTAIN IRRITATING CHEMICAL: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Sixty-seven percent of hair dye products sold on the Taiwanese market contain p-phenylenediamine (PPD) , an irritating chemical that can lead to allergies and even cancer, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Consumers' Foundation.
The survey found that six of the products contained PPD, and four of these did not issue any warnings for consumers, the officials said.

Hsu Wan-sheng, a member of the foundation's medical disputes committee, noted that PPD can trigger allergic reactions such as swelling, itching and rashes in many people and result in a greater roughness and darkening of the scalp.

Hsu advised people experiencing an allergic reaction to wash their hair every day, warning that the problem can cause cell death of the hair follicle if it is not dealt with properly over a long period of time.
PPD can also damage blood cells in human bodies and hamper metabolism, which can lead to anemia, breast cancer and bladder cancer, Hsu said.

Yu Kai-hsiung, secretary-general of the foundation, pointed out that Germany, France and Switzerland have banned the use of PPD as an ingredient for hair dyes, while Taiwan has set the concentration limit of PPD at 4.5 percent.
Yu urged the government to require hair dye manufacturers to include relevant warnings on the labels of their products and to stop using the chemical if there are safer substitutes available.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MILITARY EXPERT REMINDS TAIWAN OF CHINA'S THREAT

TEXT.P: Professor Bernard Cole of the National War College in Washington D.C. reminded Taiwan Tuesday that it faces a great military threat from China, advising that the island should never neglect this factor in its military strategic analyses.

The U.S. expert in war affairs sounded the warning at a forum on regional security and national defense, organized by the Ministry of National Defense, to explain his previous remarks which cast doubt on the combat capability and will of Taiwan's military force.

Last month Cole expressed concerns in his speech at the Brookings Institute in Washington D.C. that Taiwan's air force could lose its air superiority in the Taiwan Strait as it has not moved forward while Beijing's air force has been improving by leaps and bounds.
Cole said he voiced his concerns to remind Taiwan of the existence of China's military threat.

During the Taipei forum, Cole also spoke of his opinions on Taiwan's plans to engage in organization adjustment and to expand the recruitment of voluntary military personnel. "It is a long way to go, " he said, noting that Taiwan needs to first make efforts to resolve its financial and military investment problems.

Also participating in the two-day forum opened Tuesday are Randy Schriver, former U.S. deputy assistance secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, and Dan Blumenthal, vice chairman of the U.S.-China Security and Economic Review Commission and former senior director for China, Taiwan and Mongolia in the U.S. Office of the Secretary of Defense, as well as many retired military officers from Japan, U.S. and India.
Cole visited Taiwan during the Cold War era in his capacity as a U.S. Navy officer.
