TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.051 to close at NT$32.968.
A total of US$990 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.917 and fluctuated between NT$32.840 and NT$32.968.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up 110 points to close at 7,889, with 35,426 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March increased 111 points to finish at 7,893, with 1,374 contracts traded, while June futures gained 101 points to end at 7,892, with 88 contract transactions. September futures moved up 103 points to close at 7,721, with 31 contracts traded, while December futures increased 102 points to finish at 7,730, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 7,779 for February, 7,782 for March, 7,791 for June, 7,618 for September and 7,628 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

February TE futures increased 5.2 points to close at 334.9, with 3,084 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 5.1 points to finish at 334.8, with 199 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 1.85 points to end at 333, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

February TF futures moved up eight points to close at 1,055, with 2,925 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures increased 7.6 points to close at 1,057.6, with 109 contracts traded. June TF futures increased nine points to end at 1,054.8, with three contract transactions, while September TF futures decreased 0.2 points to close at 1,046.8, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI-WU YING CULTURAL CENTER TO BE COMPLETED IN 2012: CCA

TEXT.P: The construction of the Wei-Wu Ying Arts and Cultural Center, located on the border of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County, will be completed in 2012, an official of the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) under the Executive Yuan said Tuesday.

Lin Chau Hau, Provisional Office Director of Wei-Wu Ying Arts and Cultural Center announced the completion date at a meeting of the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan.

The Executive Yuan approved the construction project for the cultural center in November 2005, with the intention of rebuilding the former military barracks into a multi-functional cultural center of international standards.

The construction project was originally scheduled for completion in 2009, with three theaters and one concert hall and related facilities. The project, which comes with an expected price tag of NT$ 8.36 billion (US$ 254 million), has been earmarked as special budgetary item intended to enrich southern Taiwan's performing arts.

Already the project has been delayed for multiple reasons, but the first stage of international architecture design competition has been completed and the final winner will be chosen from among the six candidates in March. The future design will incorporate the Metropolitan Park between Kaohsiung City and County.

Lin said the CCA has budgeted NT$ 760 million for nurturing professional art performers, planning programs and other related affairs in an effort to bring the Wei-Wu Camp Cultural Center up to the standards of an international institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO ASK CABINET TO REMOVE GUARDS AT LATE PRESIDENT'S MAUSOLEUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is expected to put forth a proposal Wednesday recommending that Cabinet remove the military guards posted at the mausoleum of late President Chiang Kai-shek, party officials said Tuesday.

Claiming that the Cabinet has no reason to continue to protect the mausoleum of the "dictator", officials said the job of maintaining the mausoleum should be taken care of by the offspring of the Chiangs, not the government.

They said DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun will officially raise the proposal during the party's Central Standing Committee meeting, when Academia Historica Curator Chang Yen-hsien will brief the committee on an investigative report on who bore responsibility for the 228 Incident.

The report, which was completed two years ago, pinpoints Chiang Kai-shek as the key perpetrator for the incident that occurred in 1947, in which thousands of people were massacred by KMT troops in suppression of a rebellion against KMT rule in Taiwan.

The proposal to remove military guards from the Chiang's mausoleum will be yet another move by the DPP to try to eliminate symbols of authoritarianism associated with the Chiang from the country, and follows the removal of Chiang Kai-shek's statues from military bases and a proposal to rename the Chiang Kai- shek Memorial Hall as "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BRIEFS PREMIER ON RESHUFFLING KEY POSTS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian has explained to him his reasons for reshuffling several key Presidential Office posts.

Su made the remarks one day after an announcement by the Presidential Office regarding a swap of posts between Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen.
Other changes include the appointment of National Security Bureau Director Hsueh Shih-min as a strategy adviser to the president and the promotion of Deputy Director Shi Hwei-yow to Hsueh's post.
Su said that "we have kept abreast of the personnel change. I expressed appreciation to the president for telling me about his intentions in detail."
But the premier added, "it is inappropriate for me to disclose the president's intentions."

Asked if the personnel change is aimed at preparing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for the March 2008 presidential election, Su only said that both Chiou and Tan Sun Chen have solid political backgrounds and that they are capable of "shouldering great responsibilities."

Chiou served in the posts of secretary-general to the Executive Yuan, the Presidential Office and the National Security Council between 2000 and now, while Tan Sun Chen served as legislator, Tainan county magistrate and foreign affairs minister between 1992 and 2006.

Meanwhile, DPP legislators said the new lineup, which will take effect Wednesday, means that the DPP has taken up combat positions for the year-end legislative elections and the March 2008 presidential election.

Ker Chien-ming, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, noted that President Chen has relied on Chiou's resourcefulness in many ways, and that Chiou served as the chief strategist in Chen's two presidential elections.
Chiou's return to the post of secretary-general to the president, in which he first served between January 2003 and May 2004, will assist the president in dealing with many thorny issues, Ker said.

He also said that Tan Sun Chen, who holds a Ph. D. in geophysics from Purdue University, spent more than 20 years in the United States and has developed an international perspective. He is also well versed in local and central government affairs given that he served as both a magistrate and foreign minister.

DPP Legislator Wang Hsin-nan also said that the president has made appropriate adjustments, noting that Tan Sun Chen excels in administrative ability, while Chiou, an adept who usually maintains a low profile, will be capable of coordinating various factions before the upcoming primaries for the legislative and presidential elections.
Opposition legislators generally agreed that the president took the latest move "out of concern with winning the elections."

The main opposition Kuomintang said Chiou's new appointment means that the president wants Chiou to serve as his chief strategist in the two major elections ahead, and that the president's announcement last year that he would loosen his grip on power and "delegate his executive power" was nothing but "a joke."

They were referring to the president's announcement last May that he would give full power to Premier Su to control the Executive Yuan and refrain from meddling with the affairs of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) amid rising calls in both the DPP and the opposition for the president to take responsibility for a series of scandals embroiling his family members and close aides.

KMT Legislators Hsu Shao-ping, Fai Hrong-tai and Lin Teh-fu speculated that Chiou would resort to anything just to win the election, and his return to the main strategic post for upcoming elections may mean that the president fears that he will face persecution if the DPP loses in the 2008 presidential elections in 2008.

First lady, Wu Shu-jen, is currently one of the defendants in the "state affairs fund" trial. The president was named along with his wife as a "joint perpetrator" in the embezzlement of funds available for his discretionary use, but is protected by constitutional immunity until he steps down in May 2008. The president has consistently maintained his innocence in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR U.S.

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu left for the United States for a three-day visit, the nation's top China-policy charting agency said Tuesday.
During his stay in the United States, Wu is scheduled to call on U.S. congressmen and scholars.
Wu is set to deliver a speech on current cross-strait relations and their outlook at the non-profit Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington D.C. Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST ANOTHER RING SELLING TAINTED PORK

TEXT.P: The Pingtung District Prosecutor's Office on Tuesday released 11 suspects on bail after law enforcement officers detained them a day earlier on charges of selling tainted pork from sick and dead hogs.

Environmental police busted the ring the previous day in Pingtung County's Changchih township and in the city of Pingtung, seizing 5,500 kg of tainted pork. The ring's members included seven people with a license to transport sick and dead hogs for safe disposal, as well as several hired hands.
The law enforcement agents found that the licensees had actually been butchering the sick and dead hogs and selling the tainted meat to consumers.

Police officers removed 5,500 kg of frozen pork, sausage and preserved pork from a large walk-in freezer. Because the freezer was built 10 years ago, they estimated that the illegal operation might have gone on for a decade and were working to find out the ring's distribution network.

The latest crackdown in Pingtung County came after law enforcement agents in Yunlin County, central Taiwan, raided five illegal slaughterhouses Feb. 1, arresting one suspect and seizing 30 metric tons of tainted pork believed to have been stashed to meet the increased demand for meat during the Lunar New Year holiday.

In accordance with the Waste Disposal Act, those who ignore health concerns and sell questionable meat from sick and dead hogs can be sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison, plus a fine of up to NT$3 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEATS NEW ZEALAND FOR OLYMPIC SOFTBALL PLACE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's women's softball team has secured a place in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games after it defeated New Zealand 9-7 Tuesday at the finals of the Asia- Oceania Women's Softball Olympic Qualifying Series.
The win marks Taiwan's 12th consecutive victory in the series, which was held in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
The team is also the first sports team in Taiwan to qualify for the Beijing Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CRACK DOWN ON LARGEST DRUG SMUGGLING SHIPMENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Investigation (BOI) announced Tuesday that police had seized more than 100 kg of high-quality amphetamines and ketamine in the northern port city Keelung, marking the largest volume of drugs that law-enforcing authorities have ever uncovered in a single smuggling case.

Earlier police arrested the main suspect, a man surnamed Chuang, at the Taiwan Taoyuan airport on charges of smuggling and violating regulations on drug hazard prevention and control, frustrating his attempt to flee to China, according to a task force formed by the BOI to investigate the case.

The task force indicated that the drugs, seized in two separate operations with the first launched last July at a wharf warehouse along the coast of Keelung and the other conducted Monday at a Keelung Customs cargo container center, included 36 kg of amphetamines and 106.4 kg of ketamine.
The street value of the drugs exceeds NT$100 million, and were the drugs smuggled onto the island, they would be sufficient for use by 15 million people, the task force said.

The drugs were cleverly hidden in an "in-between" layer at the bottom of a cargo container shipped from Guangtong Province, in southeastern China, the police said, noting that since last July they have been watching a criminal ring discovered to have schemed to smuggle goods, including foreign cigarettes, into Taiwan by using cargo containers.
A further investigation into the criminal ring has been launched, according to the BIO.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CENTRAL NOT IN FAVOR OF TAILOR-MADE CHANGE IN CLAUSE: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang's (KMT) central does not favor any regulation or clause changes to serve one particular individual, main opposition KMT spokesman Su Chun-pin said Tuesday.

Su made the remarks at a news conference in response to reporters' questions about speculation that the KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) will modify a clause in a bid to enable KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to run in the 2008 presidential election even if he is indicted on a graft charge.

It was widely reported that the prosecution will indict Ma on embezzlement charges by Feb. 9 over his alleged mishandling of special municipal fees earmarked for his discretionary use while serving as mayor of Taipei from 1998 to 2006.

As the KMT regulations require a candidate to pull out of any election if he or she is indicted, it has been rumored that the powerful CSC is trying to revise the measure to allow Ma, the party's most likely hopeful, to take part in the 2008 presidential race.
Meanwhile, the KMT's CSC members were reportedly preparing to put forward a motion at its weekly meeting the following day calling for approval of the revised clause.

Claiming that the party central does not encourage such a customized change, Su, however, said that it is not in a position to meddle in any decision made by the top decision-making CSC and that it was unaware of any such CSC plan.

KMT lawmaker and CSC member Lai Shyh-bao, who is widely viewed as pro-Ma and who maintains close links with the KMT chairman, acknowledged that amending the clause to bail out Ma would be controversial.

But he claimed that it is necessary for the CSC to deal with it to avoid similar politically charged cases in the future because the issue also involves many other high ranking officials who receive special discretionary funds from the government, Lai said, adding that he has no idea whether some CSC members have endorsed the motion.

According to local media reports, some CSC members are in favor of changing the party's clause to make "conviction" instead of "indictment" the bottom line for any hopefuls seeking the party's nomination to run in future elections.

Some CSC members were quoted by the reports as claiming that the KMT's clause excluding indicted members from taking part in an election is invalid because it goes against one of its platforms saying that "convicted party members are not permitted to run in any election."

Upon hearing this, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight, questioned how the party could fairly make amends to other party members already banned from taking part in an election in the past due to the special clause.
If the party approves the proposed modification to the clause, it has to weigh how it could make it up to other affected members, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE COMPANY TO SEEK TAIWANESE OUTSOURCING PARTNERS

TEXT.P: Representatives of the Japanese company NEC will come to Taiwan to look for software outsourcing companies from Feb. 12-14, an official of the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic affairs said Tuesday.

The IDB has helped Taiwanese software companies find software outsourcing markets in Asian countries since last year. Minister without Portfolio Lin Feng- ching led a team of IDB officials and businessmen in the information service industry on visits to six Japanese information companies, including NEC, at the end of last year.

More than 10 Taiwanese companies, including MiTAC, Syscom and Acer, will give brief reports at a business cooperation seminar held by the IDB Feb. 13 in the hop of winning outsourcing orders from Japanese companies.

The IDB has set a goal for the information service industry to achieve NT$300 billion(US$9.11 billion) in output value and NT$60 billion in export value, and an NEC order placement would be a great step forward in achieving this goal, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST DEPARTMENT STORE BRAND DOLL TO MAKE DEBUT

TEXT.P: Taipei 101 Mall will become Taiwan's first department store to launch its own line of doll products as part of the mall's effort to develop its brand, a department store spokesman said Tuesday.

Scott Chen, vice president of Taipei Financial Center Corp. (TFCC), which owns the world's tallest skyscraper, Taipei 101, said that "Damper dolls" and related products will make their debut Feb. 8. In addition, Taipei 101 will develop a series of Damper products promoting the beauty of Taiwan, adding that these will be launched by March.

The TFCC's assistant vice president Michael Liu said that Taipei 101 has authorized a Japanese company to design and manufacture "Damper dolls, " which are expected to generate profits though he declined to provide an estimate as to how much.
The mall views brand management as its top priority, Chen stressed, and therefore will not open a chain of stores as do other local department stores.

Noting that the mall recently spent nearly NT$20 million on the promotion of its image by placing advertisements in international media, Liu complained that the central and local governments have not created an environment attractive to overseas tourists; as a result, Taipei 101's marketing efforts have produced limited benefits.
Nonetheless, according to Liu, Taipei 101's observation deck brings in an annual profit of between NT$300 million and NT$400 million.
Liu noted that 40 percent of its customers are Japanese, while 50 percent are Taiwanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE, JAPANESE MEDICAL UNIVERSITIES INAUGURATE RESEARCH CENTER

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese medical university and its Japanese counterpart inaugurated a co- founded research center Monday, which aims to enhance bilateral academic exchanges and research standards, a school spokesman said Tuesday.

The inauguration came after China Medical University, based in Taichung, central Taiwan, signed an academic cooperation agreement with Nikon Pharmaceutical University in 2005, according to the spokesman.
In the wake of the agreement, the Japanese university donated $100 million yen (NT$27 million) to fund the construction of the center to research Chinese medicine, the spokesman said.

Nikon Pharmaceutical University is one of the 44 schools -- including kindergartens, elementary schools, junior and senior high schools, as well as universities -- established by the Tsuzuki group across Japan, which has a total number of students exceeding 50,000.
The university is located in a suburban area of Tokyo and offers six-year programs in Chinese medicine, medical pharmacy, and health pharmacy, the spokesman added.

Nikon Pharmaceutical University's Chinese medicine program focuses on teaching clinical application, the spokesman said, pointing out that this aspect is also to be highlighted in the bilateral project.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR MEETS BRISBANE COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu hosted a group of officials and representatives of the commercial and industrial sectors of the Australian city of Brisbane headed by Brisbane Mayor Campbell Newman at City Hall Tuesday.

Chen extended a warm welcome to the 15-member delegation, which is on a four-day visit to the southern Taiwan harbor city as part of celebrations for the 10th anniversary of the formation of sisterhood relations between the two cities.

In the meeting, Chen recalled a visit she made to Australia three years ago to learn how the country manages unemployment and provides assistance to job- seekers. She praised the country for its employment system and its services for the unemployed.
Chen expressed hope for more exchanges and cooperation between Kaohsiung and Brisbane in the fields of trade and investment and that the two cities will make efforts to further boost bilateral ties.
In return, Newman extended an invitation for Chen to visit Brisbane for the sixth Asia-Pacific Cities Summit in September.
During its stay in Kaohsiung, the delegation will hold a presentation to introduce to local businesses the investment environment in Brisbane, the Queensland state capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST MAINTAIN ADEQUATE DEFENSE CAPABILITY: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Tuesday that maintaining a military equilibrium in the Taiwan Strait is the best way to prevent a Chinese invasion of Taiwan and ensure peace and stability in East Asia.

Speaking at a national defense forum on East Asia's regional security held by the National Defense Fu Hsing Kang College, Lee said Taiwan must maintain adequate defense capability to prevent a war from occurring in the Taiwan Strait.
He claimed that Taiwan can satisfy its defense needs by procuring submarines, P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot PAC-III missiles from the United States.
Lee said China's military threat to Taiwan is evident in the fact that it has deployed 988 missiles on its southeast coast, with Taiwan the target.

He also said that other factors that might affect regional security are potential tension between China and its neighbors, including Japan, South Korea, India and Southeast Asian countries, such as territorial disputes and competing interests in securing oil resources.
According to Lee, peace in the Taiwan Strait is not an issue only between Taiwan and China, because any military conflict between them is bound to affect stability in the whole region.

He gave credit to the United States government for taking measures in recent years to engage China through strategic dialogue, mutual visits of defense ministers, confidence-building mechanisms and joint military exercises.

Italian authorities revealed a package of measures against soccer hooliganism after a meeting of government and sports leaders Monday. The measures, including a ban on known soccer hooligans, are subject to approval by an extraordinary Cabinet meeting.

With its gleaming towers and explosive growth, this city has helped inspire dreams of a China century. Governed for four years by a British-educated architect named Chen Liangyu, hanghai exuded a can-do attitude that welcomed foreign investment and showcased China's emergence on the world stage.
But underneath the boom and glitter, Communist Party leaders in Beijing say, lay a secret: massive corruption. @@Communist Party leaders in Beijing say massive corruption is behind Shanghai's recent building boom. But more than the ouster of one official, it amounts to an indictment of the business model known as Shanghai Inc.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE HEAVYWEIGHT CLARIFIES EX-PRESIDENT'S STANCE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui has not changed his pro-Taiwan independence stance and will take part in a special activity in commemoration of the 228 Incident, a pro-independence heavyweight said Tuesday.

Ng Chiau-tong, head of the Hand-in-Hand to Safeguard Taiwan Alliance, made the remarks at a news conference in which he said Lee remains firm on promoting Taiwan independence and supports the idea of writing a new constitution and changing the country's official title in order to make Taiwan a normal country.

Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen and Chin Mei-ling, a Japan-based pro- independence backer who once served as a national policy advisor to the president, were also at the news conference to endorse Lee's stance.

According to Ng, who met Lee for over an hour earlier in the day to discuss controversy arising from Lee's remarks about Taiwan independence in recent days, the former president has also promised to participate in the commemorative activities slated to be held Feb. 28 to which President Chen Shui-bian will also be invited.
Ng claimed that Lee has never deviated from his pro-Taiwan independence stance and called for the public's "continued support" for the cause.

Lee told Next Magazine and the TVBS cable station the previous week that he had never backed Taiwan independence and claimed that there is no need for the government to pursue formal independence since Taiwan is already an independent sovereignty.
Lee's comments stirred up strong criticism from pro-independence groups and "friends of Lee Teng-hui" groups, prompting some of them to consider disbanding.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT, BRITISH PUBLISHER TO PRINT TAIWAN ECONOMIC ALMANAC

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) and the London-based Oxford Business Group (OBG) will collaborate to make the Taiwan Economic Almanac available around the world from June with the aim of helping European companies become more acquainted with Taiwan's investment environment.
ECCT Chief Executive Officer Guy Wittich and OBG Taiwan Director Karolien Holsters signed an agreement Monday in Taipei City to seal the deal on their cooperative venture.

The almanac will be compiled by the OBG, which presently has 105,000 subscribers and publishes economic yearbooks for emerging countries in Eastern Europe, Africa and the Middle East, according to Holsters.
She said Taiwan is the 25th country to be included on its almanac publishing list, adding that South Africa, Jordan, Egypt and Malaysia are also on the list.

Holsters said the group will station researchers in Taiwan for six to eight months who will highlight the characteristics of Taiwan and make comprehensive, in-depth reports on the economy. She estimated that a total of 65,000 copies will be issued.

She said that in the eyes of investors, Taiwan is a market with great potential, adding that Taiwan's commercial advantage lies in sharing a common language and culture with China, doing business with companies from the United States and European countries, and yet remaining small enough for investors to deal with easily.
Wittich said foreign investors find a lot of business opportunities in Taiwan, although he added that there is much room for improvement in its cross- Taiwan Strait relations and politics.

He noted that European enterprises fare quite well in the retail, traffic and transport, and pharmaceutical industries in Taiwan, while Taiwan also has the advantage of a better living environment than that of China.
He expressed hope that the yearbook can help foreign investors explore more business opportunities in Taiwan, including non-traditional areas such as tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY PEOPLE LIVING ALONE TO RECEIVE FREE EYE CARE

TEXT.P: The Ophthalmological Society of Taiwan is calling on eye doctors to join a nationwide campaign to provide free eye care to elderly people who live by themselves.

Pan Chih-chin, chairman of the society, quoted a study by the Cabinet-level Department of Health saying that 38 percent of old people troubled by eye disease are inclined to develop symptoms of depression -- about three times that of healthy old people.
He added that eye ailments are not just physical problems but also psychological problems, and that the problems are even more serious among old people who live alone.

Pan said the Ophthalmological Society of Taiwan is inviting more eye doctors to become "ambassadors" in the campaign to locate elderly people living alone with eye disease and offer them free treatment.

The campaign is being supported by the pharmaceutical company Alcon. Some 300 old people living alone in one Taipei community received free eye care Tuesday and heard lectures on how to keep their eyes healthy.
Statistics show that the society has provided free eye care to more than 2,000 people since 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEEPENING DEMOCRACY TAIWAN'S BEST DEFENSE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that strengthening Taiwan's democratic system is its best defense against China's missile threat.
Nevertheless, the president also acknowledged the need for Taiwan to upgrade its military strength in the face of China's attempt to alter the Taiwan Strait status quo.

"China's military strength is growing exponentially, making it imperative for Taiwan to upgrade its weaponry to maintain the military balance," Chen said while meeting with a visiting delegation from Britain's Royal United Services Institute for Defense Studies.

Chen told his British guests that China has outlined a three-stage plan in preparation for action against Taiwan. According to Chen, China will have the readiness to respond to an emergency military conflict this year. By 2010, it will be prepared to fight a large-scale war, and before 2015, it will achieve the decisive capability to win a war. The development deserves grave concern, he added.

Chen further said China had already installed almost 1,000 missiles on its southeastern coast targeting Taiwan. Since he took office in May 2000, Chen said China had increased its total number of missiles targeting Taiwan from 200 to 988 by the end of 2006.
In the face of China's military expansion and attempts to change the Taiwan Strait status quo, Chen said Taiwan must strive to upgrade its combat prowess and military arsenal.
Moreover, Chen said Taiwan is committed to deepening its democratic system as the best means against China's military threat.

Noting that China has not improved its human rights records, Chen also asked British scholars and experts present at the meeting to help push European Union countries not to lift their arms embargo against China.
The British delegation is in Taipei to attend a seminar on regional security and peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 7, or the 20th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1478: Sir Thomas More, English Lord Chancellor who was executed by Henry VIII for refusing to deny the Pope's authority, is born.
1685: King Charles II, king of England, Scotland, and Ireland known as the "merry monarch" who reigned during the Restoration, dies at the age of 55.
1792: Austria and Prussia sign a military pact against France.
1812: Charles Dickens, the great English novelist who wrote a number of well- loved classics like "Oliver Twist" and "David Copperfield," is born.
1816: Italian missionary Giovanni Lantrua of Triora is executed by the Chinese.
1870: Alfred Adler, Austrian psychoanalyst who introduced the concept of the inferiority complex, is born.
1885: Sinclair Lewis, U.S. novelist and Nobel Prize winner who wrote "Main Street," is born.
1886: George Walker, an English carpenter, strikes gold in the Transvaal in South Africa while building a cottage for a prospector.
1948: Liaoning Province falls into the hands of Communist Chinese troops.
1950: Vietnam splits in two, with the Soviet Union recognizing the provisional government of Ho Chi Minh and the United States and Britain endorsing the French-backed government of Emperor Bao Dai.
1955: Republic of China government troops begin to evacuate the Tachen Islands.
1960: Israeli archaeologists unearth a number of Dead Sea Scrolls.
1968: The ROC's Ministry of Education agrees to the establishment of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
1971: Switzerland grants women the right to vote.
1973: Former Kaohsiung City Mayor Yang Chin-hu and his wife are arrested for suspected involvement in a bribery case during his term in office.
1974: Grenada gains independence, with Eric Gairy as its first prime minister.
1976: Emanuel O. Gardiner, Liberian deputy minister of planning and economic affairs, and Lafayette Kwie Johnson Jr., assistant minister of the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and Transportation, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1982: Luis Alberto Monge becomes president of Costa Rica.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the project to make Yushan into a National Park.
1986 Self-styled "President for Life" Jean Claude "Baby-Doc" Duvalier flees Haiti with his loot, bound for exile in France in the face of a national uprising.
1986: Both Ferdinand E. Marcos and his chief election opponent, Corazon Aquino, claim victory in the Philippine presidential election. The National Assembly would later rule that Marcos won the election.
1990: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party votes for a package of reforms that will end its monopoly on power.
1991: In its most daring daylight raid to date, the Irish Republican Army fires three mortar bombs at British Prime Minister John Major's residence at No. 10 Downing Street.
1992: Ministers of Europe formally sign the Maastricht Treaty of the European Union.
1996: A Boeing 757 passenger jetliner on its way from the Dominican Republic to Frankfurt crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 189 aboard.
1999: Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the king of Jordan following King Hussein's death from cancer.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Perfectly honest men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with scrupulous men I would be satisfied. But in a state of society in which men must pretend to possess what they really do not possess; pretend to have plenty, when they have really nothing; and pretend to be in affluence when they are in actual want -- in such a state of society, it is difficult to be even a scrupulous man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SALARY INCREASES TO BE WORLD'S 14TH HIGHEST IN 2007: SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/07 12:26:15 (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to post the 14th highest real salary increases in 2007 among the world's 45 major economies, according to the results of an annual survey released Tuesday by an international human resources organization.

The survey, conducted by ECA International, forecast an average of 3.6 percent in real salary increase -- a worker's actual salary increase after inflation is taken into account -- for the Asian region in 2007, up approximately 50 percent from 2006 and well above the global average.

Among the 45 economies surveyed, the five highest real wage increases for 2007 are all expected to occur in Asia, with India topping the list with projected real salary increases of 7 percent, according to the survey.

Rounding out the top-five list are Indonesia and China, with projected real salary increases of approximately 6 percent each, as well as the Philippines and Thailand, with projected increases of 4 percent each.
Real salary increases in Japan, Taiwan, South Korea and Malaysia are expected to range between 2 percent and 3.5 percent, and those in Hong Kong are forecast to be 1.5 percent.
Slovakia and Russia are the two economies outside Asia that are expected to see the highest real wage increases in 2007, according to the survey.

Meanwhile, real wage increases in Argentina, Hungary, Germany, New Zealand and Spain are expected to register below 1 percent, the lowest among the 45 economies surveyed, while real wage increases in the United States are forecast to be 1.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES 10-YEAR PLAN FOR CRAFTING LONG-TERM CARE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The government will spend more than NT$76.8 billion (US$2.31 billion) developing a long-term care system over the next decade to deal with the challenges created by the greying of the local population, Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Wan-yi said Wednesday.

The plan has been incorporated into the "Mega Warmth" social welfare project with an aim of offering long-term care aid to elderly people who require assistance with daily activities, physically and mentally challenged people over 50 years of age, indigenous people aged over 55, and disabled elderly people who live alone, Lin explained.

It will be the largest social welfare program after the national pension system, Lin said, adding that low-income families will receive full subsidies if needed under the long-term care program, while middle-low-income families will receive a 90 percent subsidy and regular families will be entitled to a 60 percent subsidy.

Noting that long-term care includes a variety of both medical and non-medical services for the elderly and people with disabilities or chronic illnesses, Lin said the ambitious program is expected to create some 60,000 new jobs.

Quoting official tallies, Lin said that the local population is steadily greying, with seniors accounting for 10 percent of the country's total population this year. "This means more than 2.26 million people over 65 years of age, with more than 200,000 of them needing different levels of long-term care or assistance," he added..

By 2016, Lin said, seniors will make up over 13 percent of the total population. "By that point, the ratio of people aged under 14 will begin to decline, while the elderly population will continue to increase, " he added.

Changing demographics will make the need for crafting a long-term care system even more critical than ever, Lin said, adding that what the elderly need most is medical care, social care and economic security.

At the moment, Lin said, Germany, Japan and the Netherlands have introduced long-term care insurance systems to pay for long-term care services for the elderly. Most other countries are using tax money to finance elderly welfare services.
Lin said the government will refer to Japan's 1994 "New Golden Plan" in forging a comprehensive long-term care system for the elderly over the next decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMAINS 12TH LARGEST MARKET FOR SWISS WATCHES IN 2006
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/07/07 14:07:09 (By Neil Lu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan imported 256.5 million Swiss francs (US$206.85 million) worth of watches from Switzerland in 2006, making the country the 12th largest overseas market for Swiss watches, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry.

The figure marked an increase of only 1.8 percent from the year-earlier level, which was much lower than the growth rates of 22 percent recorded in 2005 and 12.2 percent recorded in 2004, the tallies show.
The value of Swiss watch exports hit a new high of 1.37 billion Swiss francs in 2006, with luxury products remaining the main driving force of the industry.
The export value of Swiss watches costing more than 3,000 Swiss francs jumped 27 percent in 2006, with their export quantity soaring 34.7 percent.
Products costing below 3,000 Swiss francs saw their export value for 2006 remain at a similar level as that for the previous year, while export quantity increased marginally by 1 percent.
The United States remained the largest overseas market for Swiss watches in 2006, importing 2.29 billion Swiss francs worth of watches from Switzerland during the year.

Hong Kong, which imported 1.95 billion Swiss francs worth of Swiss watches in 2006, was the products' second largest overseas market, followed by Japan, which imported 1.27 billion Swiss francs worth of Swiss watches in the same year.

China was the 10th largest overseas market for Swiss watches in 2006, importing 404 million Swiss francs worth of the watches during the year, up 14.9 percent from 2005. The growth rate compares with 25.7 percent registered in 2005 and 41.7 percent registered in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 1.2 MILLION PEOPLE CONSIDERED SUICIDE IN 2006: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A total of 1.42 million people around Taiwan thought about ending their own life in 2006, with more than 410,000 actually attempting suicide, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
The survey on the mental health of the Taiwan people was conducted by the Mental Health Foundation in November on 1,122 adults from cities and counties around Taiwan.

In the survey, the Taiwan people received a score of 82.63 points on their general mental health, with 100 points indicating perfect mental health. The score marked an improvement over the figure of 80.2 points in a similar survey by the foundation a year earlier.

The scores for the four major indicators used to calculate the overall mental health of the people -- namely "mental and physical health, " "individual value, " "life control" and "family health" -- also increased over the figures recorded in the year-earlier survey, according to the private foundation.

However, the results on the two survey questions on whether the respondent has thought about committing suicide and whether the respondent has actually attempted suicide have triggered concerns among experts at the foundation.

Yang Tsung-tsai, head of the mental health center of Taipei-based Cardinal Tien Hospital and convener of the foundation's team in charge of health indicator affairs, said that based on the survey results, about 130,000 people around the nation attempted suicide at least twice in 2006.
"These people need care, " Yang said, noting that the survey results also revealed that care shown by family and friends are crucial in maintaining one's mental health.

Yang explained that work-related and financial pressures as well as trouble in intimate relationships are some of the main reasons leading people to consider suicide, adding that people with the healthiest minds tend to be those that share their thoughts with others.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SUGAR CHIP' CAN DETECT CANCER IN ONE SECOND

TEXT.P: Powerful "sugar chips" developed by incumbent Academia Sinica President Wong Chi-huey and his U.S. research team for tracking protein glycosylation have been confirmed to be capable of detecting cancer within one second.

Powerful sugar probes and sugar chips that were developed by Wong and researchers from the Scripps Research Institute four years ago were confirmed recently to be capable of detecting not only cancer within one second with a 100 percent accuracy but also the HIV virus and avian flu virus, the Academia Sinica ENews reported Tuesday.

The details of the innovative "sugar chips" -- which have great potential for industrial use as high-throughput diagnostic tools for the analysis of post- translational protein glycosylation in disease states -- were published online in the internationally-renowned journal Nature Protocols Jan. 31. They are also scheduled to appear in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America Feb. 5.

According to Wong, who is the most-cited chemist worldwide working in the area of enzymes and who assumed the post of Academia Sinica president last October, more than 80 percent of human proteins have sugars called glycoproteins attached to them, and the process of protein glycosylation is known to play a central role in mediating protein function in living organisms.

Noting that altered glycosylation is often associated with inflammation and cancer metastasis, Wong said the detailed correlation between glycosylation and biological or pathological status may provide information for diagnosis and treatment of diseases, particularly cancers.
He added that by spreading a drop of human blood on the "sugar chip, " the researchers can almost instantly determine what kind of cancer the patient is suffering from.

Wong, who has been a professor of chemistry with the Scripps Research Institute, has pioneered work on the development of effective enzymes and the design of novel substrates and processes for large-scale organic synthesis.

The methods and strategies that Wong has developed have made possible synthetic transformations that are otherwise impossible or impractical, especially in areas vitally important in biology and medicine, and have pointed the way toward new green methodologies for use in large-scale chemistry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY CIVILIAN CANDIDATES QUALIFIED AS DEFENSE MINISTER: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Touting his idea of civilian control of the military, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday there are numerous civilian candidates available who are qualified to be minister of national defense.
Chen claimed that although he is reluctant to talk about his contribution to the country, he has nurtured a lot of talent for the country over the past several years.

For example, there are "more than half a dozen" aspirants in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party who are interested in running for the presidency in 2008, while there are "a truckload of" civilian candidates who are qualified to be defense minister, Chen said.

The president made the remarks while presiding over a changover ceremony in which Chiou I-jen was sworn in as the new secretary-general of the Presidential Office, replacing Tan Sun Chen, who took over Chiou's previous post of National Security Council secretary-general on the same occasion.

Chen has recently appointed Shi Hwei-yow, deputy director of the National Security Bureau, as the intelligence agency's first civilian head and expressed the hope that the principle of civilian control of the military can be realized in the final year of his term as president.

Commenting on the issue Tuesday, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said that he hopes the goal can be achieved as soon as possible and that he "can leave any time" if the president has found a suitable person to replace him.

The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.968 and fluctuated between NT$32.800 and NT$33.010.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF DIGITAL CONTENT INDUSTRY RECORDS 17% INCREASE

TEXT.P: The production value of the digital content industry totaled NT$341.2 billion (US$10.37 billion) in 2006, up 17 percent from the previous year, according to Industrial Development Bureau Director-General Chen Chao-yih.
Chen made the remarks when he presided over an award-presentation ceremony Tuesday for the winners of a digital content competition that took place last year.
He said the purpose of the competition was to induce creativity and turn that creativity into products and upgraded production values.

He expressed hope that the competition, now in its fifth year, will serve as a platform between digital content businesses and schools so as to introduce school talent to the digital content industry.

Minister without Portfolio Lin Feng-ching said the government had originally set the production value of Taiwan's digital content at a projected NT$600 billion by 2010, but he added that given the performance of the digital content industry last year, the future development of the industry could be even more stunning.

He noted that the main difference between the digital content industry and the manufacturing industry lies in creativity, saying that future development will center on animation and games, in the hope of making inroads into the international market through TV and film animation.

The government has in recent years put a great deal of effort into the digital content industry as part of its "two-trillion, twin-star" program. "Two trillion" refers to the production values of the semiconductor and imaging display panel sectors reaching NT$1 trillion each while 'twin star" refers to digital content and biotechnology industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION CALLS FOR CERTIFICATION SYSTEM FOR PORK

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation called for the government Wednesday to help build a certification system for pork products amid reports that tainted pork from sick and dead hogs has once again appeared in markets around Taiwan.

Consumers' Foundation Chairman Cheng Jen-hung said relevant government agencies' efficiency is open to doubt, with illicit selling of sick and dead hogs to consumers occurring every year since 2001 even though the matter has been one of the top 10 consumer news items every year.

Cheng said building a pork certification system is the only effective way of curbing tainted pork sales, as the business is too lucrative to be ignored and the penalties meted out by the government are too lenient.

Since violators of regulations banning the sale of pork from sick and dead hogs are usually released on bail of just NT$50,000, Cheng suggested that the government impose heavier penalties on violators.

Meanwhile, Luo Chiu-ying, a member of the Consumer's Foundation, said that to counteract the marketing of tainted pork, consumers should avoid buying pork from unknown sources or pork at prices much cheaper than street value.
Buying pork products carrying the CAS label at supermarkets or hypermarkets is also safer, Luo added.

Luo said the foundation has found that only a small number of meat dealers have been involved in the crime -- Taiwan people consume about 9 million head of hogs each year, with about 30,000 head slaughtered every month -- and the latest news report about the busting of a ring in the southern county of Pingtung indicates that only about 20 to 50 sick and dead hogs have been sold to meat markets per day recently.
The Pingtung District Prosecutor's Office a day earlier released 11 suspects on bail after law enforcement officers detained them Monday on charges of selling pork from sick and dead hogs.

A total of 5,500 kg of tainted pork was reportedly seized in a raid along with the Pingtung ring, which included seven people licensed to transport sick and dead hogs for safe disposal, as well as several hired hands.

The latest crackdown in Pingtung County came after law enforcement agents in Yunlin County, central Taiwan, raided five illegal slaughterhouses Feb. 1, arresting one suspect and seizing 30 metric tons of tainted pork believed to have been stashed to meet the increased demand for meat during the Lunar New Year holiday.

Meanwhile, officials from the Council of Agriculture's Animal Industry Department said they will accelerate the installation of global positioning systems (GPS) on vehicles contracted to transport sick and dead hogs for safe disposal so that they can be monitored.
The officials said they will also step up raids on unlicensed slaughterhouses and push for the implementation of a pork certification system, beginning with supermarkets and hypermarkets.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARSENIC LEVELS IN TAICHUNG AIR SOAR AFTER OPENING OF SCIENCE PARK

TEXT.P: The concentration of arsenic in the atmosphere in central Taichung City has skyrocketed since the inauguration of the Central Taiwan Science Park, with a reading of as high as 37 nanograms per cubic meter detected in certain spots in the city, according to data released Wednesday by the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU).
The data included the results of monitoring conducted by the city's Environmental Protection Bureau and another laboratory report obtained independently by the union.

The data shows that the arsenic concentration in the air surrounding the science park soared from just 2.5 nanograms in 2005, when the park was still under construction, to 31 nanograms in 2006, when some plants in the park had started mass production.
While researchers detected arsenic concentrations of up to 37.4 nanograms at Tunghai University, another test conducted by the Environmental Protection Bureau returned a reading of 27 nanograms.

Meanwhile, the arsenic concentration in the air in the city's Hsitun district registered 30 nanograms, much higher than the concentration recorded in even severely polluted mining zones around the world.
TEPU Chairwoman Hsu Kuang-jung noted that arsenic is a toxic substance that can cause cancer and kill.
The carcinogenic risk registers 0.001 percent when the arsenic concentration in the air stands at 2 nanograms, increasing to 0.01 percent when the concentration reaches 20 nanograms, Hsu said.

The TEPU demanded that National Science Council Chairman Chen Chien-jen and Taichung City Environmental Protection Bureau Director Lee Li-teh step down to take responsibility for the failure to prevent the pollution.
The council should also present a resolution for the problem in 30 days and punish manufacturers responsible for the arsenic emissions, TEPU officials said.
