DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 25.69 points to close at 7,850.06.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,894.77 and closed at the day's low of 7,850.06. A total of 3.21 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$91.96 billion (US$2.79 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks and construction issues both moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
The three other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.5 percent, and cement stocks at 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 835 to 358, with 202 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS WELCOME TO FILE COMPLAINTS IF MALTREATED: CLA

TEXT.P: Foreign workers are welcome to lodge petitions with relevant labor agencies whenever they are improperly treated, a Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Wednesday.

Tsai Meng-liang, a division chief at the CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training, was responding to Philippine media reports that Filipina housemaids and caregivers have complained about their Taiwanese employers' reluctance to offer them days off.
As many of the Filipinas are afraid of losing their jobs, the reports said, they dare not argue with their employers to take a day off per week.

In the past, Tsai said, employers might "viciously" fire foreign workers, but the situation has improved since last October when a new set of protective measures for foreign laborers were put into force.

Under the new system, local governments are required to verify every case involving firing, advanced termination of contract and repatriation of foreign laborers and should assist in handling disputes between local employers and foreign employees.

Moreover, Tsai said, special counters have been opened at major airports for disgruntled foreign laborers, particularly those who feel their legitimate rights have been denied, to file their grievances and seek legal remedies before their departure or repatriation.

Noting that employment and management of foreign workers must comply with existing law and working contracts, Tsai said local employers will be fined and even deprived of their qualification to hire foreign workers if they are found to have committed any infractions.
Given all these extensive protective measures, Tsai said maltreated foreign workers need not hesitate to voice complaints through legal channels.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN DIGNITARIES INVITED TO NATIONAL PALACE MUSEUM REOPENING

TEXT.P: Prominent foreign dignitaries and curators, including former French Primie Minister Michel Rocard, have been invited to attend a ceremony marking the reopening of the National Palace Museum slated for Thursday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs reported Wednesday.

Inviting some two dozens of foreign officials and museum experts to Taiwan to witness the reopening of the National Palace Museum after the museum's nearly- three-year remodeling is part of the Foreign Ministry's efforts to expand Taiwan's influence in the international community via the cultural front, ministry officials said.

The invited guests -- also including Gambian Tourism and Cultural Minister Angela Colley; Stephane Martin, curator of Museum Quai Branly of France; and Emily J. Sano, director of the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco -- are also expected to pay a visit to the high-profile exhibition "Grand View: Painting, Calligraphy, Ju Ware and Rare Books from the Northern Sung Dynasty" which the National Palace Museum has organized to mark its official reopening Feb. 8.

Culture and the cultural development models from the Sung Dynasty (960-1279) have tremendously influenced the world's cultural development and the collections of Sung Dynasty artifacts happen to be among the most pivotal collections of the National Palace Museum, which is considered the world's leading Chinese art treasures.

The three-month Grand View exhibition, which is scheduled to end March 25, showcases a total of 42 paintings and 29 pieces of calligraphy dating from the Northern Sung period (960-1127), as well as five Northern Sung paintings and calligraphy works on loan from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City.

Also on display are Ju ceramic wares of the Northern Sung period, fired in the early 12th century, which are renowned for the classical beauty of their warm and glossy sky-blue glaze. Surviving pieces of Ju ware are extremely rare, with less than 70 found in collections around the world today. The National Palace Museum is fortunate to have 21, the most of any collection.

Renowned for its impressive collection of art works of the Sung Dynasty, the museum is putting its collection of Sung Dynasty artifacts in its entirety on display for the first and possibly the last time due to the fragility of the art works. The museum is known for its unique collection of some 654,500 imperial art treasures brought to Taiwan at the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949 to keep them out of the hands of the communists and Mao Zedong's Red Guard.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL DIGITAL MANDARIN LEARNING WORTH US$60 BILLION: CEPD

TEXT.P: The global market for digital mandarin Chinese learning will be worth some US$60 billion in five years, officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) predicted Wednesday.
CEPD officials urged Taiwan businessmen and companies to grasp the opportunity of a rising Chinese-learning fad worldwide to make money out of the trend.

The officials quoted a survey conducted by the Summer Institute of Linguistics (SIL) International as indicating that among the world's 6,809 languages in use, mandarin is currently the language with the greatest number of speakers.

About 14.8 percent of the world's population, or roughly 885 million people, speak mandarin as their mother tongue or second language, compared to 400 million people who speak English as their mother tongue or second language, officials said.

It was assessed that about 1 million mandarin teachers will be needed worldwide to meet the demand arising from the Chinese-learning fad. Currently, nevertheless, there are only about 100,000 mandarin teachers working.
The evident shortages has resulted in a huge need for digital mandarin teaching materials, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HON HAI TOP IN PATENT APPLICATION, APPROVAL

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. was top in terms of patent application and approval for the fourth consecutive year in 2006, the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) said Wednesday.

IPO officials noted that in terms of patent applications in 2006, the top three were the same as 2005, with Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. top with 1,830 applications, followed by the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) with 873 and Inventec with 819.
In terms of applications approved, Hon Hai had 898, ITRI had 583 and Inventec had 493.
IPO officials said that since 2003, Hon Hai has maintained top place in terms of patent application and approval, showing the company's strength and its efforts in research and development.

Royal Philips Electronics was top among foreign institutional organizations in terms of patent applications with 850, followed by Samsung Electronics with 747 and Sony with 493, while Sony was top with 401 patent applications granted, followed by Intel with 364 and Epson with 355.

Academic institutes have in recent years been more active in applying for patents, the officials said, adding that 13 academic institutes each were on the lost of the top 100 companies or institutes that applied for patents and received approval in 2006, three more than in 2005.
The IPO handled 80,989 applications for patents in 2006, up 1,547 from 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO NEW 'SUGAR PROBES' FOR CANCER SPREAD DEVELOPED

TEXT.P: Researchers at Academia Sinica's Genomics Research Center have developed two new "sugar probes" that can target abnormal proteins in cancer cells to facilitate studies on cancer metastasis, academic sources said Wednesday.
The research team led by Academia Sinica President Wong Chi-huey, includes postdoctoral research fellow Hsu Tsui-ling and staff at the Scripps Research Institute in the United States.

Scientists have long known that proteins transmit genetic information from cell to cell. If the protein responsible for relaying information related to cancer metastasis can be spotted, then researchers might be able to stop the metastasis by blocking the protein. However, there are tens of thousands of proteins in the human body, making tracking a specific one like looking for a needle in a haystack.

However, Wong explained, the team has found that metastasis- related proteins tend to combine with certain types of carbohydrates, so they made two probes out of trehalose and sialic acid analog to "trap" the proteins.
The team has also deployed agide compounds to mark those proteins combined with the probes, facilitating the examination process.
In the process, they discovered the protein, Wong said. However, further analysis and research is needed to better understand its characteristics and the therapy to stop the metastasis.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSPECTION OF 1,148 PORK SUPPLIERS SHOW NO SIGNS OF TAINTED MEAT

TEXT.P: An investigation by the Department of Health (DOH) of 1,148 meat suppliers and vendors around the country has turned up no signs of pork from sick and dead hogs, a DOH official said Wednesday.

The DOH mobilized every city and county health bureau from Feb. 1 to investigate the meat suppliers and vendors, including 240 pork-processing factories, 402 restaurants and 506 traditional market vendors.

Bureau of Food Sanitation Director Cheng Huei-wen pointed out that it takes time to find illegally butchered pork because the illegal slaughterhouses discovered so far have produced only around 5,000 kg of pork, while around 2.8 million kg is consumed daily.
Restaurants near universities were the investigation's key point, but no evidence of tainted meat was found.
Cheng reminded consumers to check for the CAS logo on the skin of good quality pork and to be aware of pork selling for extremely low prices or without skin.
Those caught selling pork from sick or dead pigs face fines of between NT$30,000 (US$909) and NT$150,000, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMMUNICATING WITH U.S. ON FUGITIVE TYCOON: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/07/07 19:03:04 (By Lin Chiehyu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been communicating every day with the United States on the case of Wang You-theng, fugitive founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, Republic of China Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Tuesday.
Lee made the remarks while attending a party to mark the fifth anniversary of the inauguration of the U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus, a pro-Taiwan group in the House of Representatives.
Lee said Taiwan and the United States are cooperated closely on the case and that both sides "have communicated daily on the case to exchange views."

Asked when a U.S. court hearing on Wang's case will be set and how Taiwan prosecutors traveling to the United States will cooperate with U.S. judicial officials, Lee said only that the case "has entered judicial process, and that it is not appropriate for me to comment on the case."
Wang, wanted in Taiwan for his suspected involvement in a series of fraud, accounting and embezzlement scandals surrounding his business group, is in the custody of U.S. immigration officials.

Taiwan put Wang on its most-wanted list in mid-January. He tried to fly to Myanmar via Singapore last Wednesday but was sent back to the United States last Friday by Singaporean authorities as he lacked the proper travel documents.
Wang arrived in Los Angeles Saturday and was taken into custody because his Taiwan and Dominican Republic passports were invalid as a result of efforts by the Taiwan authorities.
In related development in Taiwan, prosecutors continued their probe into the case, summoning nine defendants in detention for more questioning Tuesday.

Fifty-one people related to the Rebar scandal have been listed as defendants so far, 13 of whom have been detained. The number of people related to the case barred from leaving the country has increased to 91.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK SHOWS STUNNING GROWTH

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Science Park recorded stunning growth last year with its annual revenues reaching NT$178.5 billion (US$5.42 billion), nearly three times the NT$60.09 billion recorded in 2005, park officials said Wednesday.

Officials attributed the rapid increase to manufacturers newly stationed in the park that began operations over last year; such operations helped boost year-end revenues by more than NT$50 billion over the original estimate of NT$120 billion.
The officials estimated that the revenues of the park could continue to climb to the NT$240 billion mark this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD DEFENDS NAME CHANGE DRIVE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun defended Wednesday his proposed "desinicization moves" amid rampant speculation on why he raised the proposals at this particular time.

In response to the speculation on why he proposed a name change for some state- run companies and a withdrawal of military guards posted at the mausoleums of the late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo now, Yu, displaying an official document, argued that he asked in January 2005, while serving as premier, that task forces be set up in relevant government agencies to promote a name change of public enterprises that carry "China" in their titles.
But Yu was reserved when asked by reporters whether it was his successor, former Premier Frank Hsieh, who failed to continue carrying out the mission.

Yu also ascribed the 228 Incident in 1947 to Chiang Kai-shek, whom pro- independence activists say is the main culprit behind the tragedy, in which thousands of Taiwan's elite were murdered by Kuomintang (KMT) troops in the initial stage of the KMT's authoritarian rule of Taiwan.

Yu was also reportedly planning to propose at the DPP's Central Standing Committee meeting later that same day that the government remove all Chiang statues from military barracks around the country and pull all military guards stationed at the two late presidents' temporary mausoleums in northern Taoyuan county.
Yu will also ask KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to make a vow Feb. 28 that he will stop paying his respects to the two late presidents at their mausoleums.

Yu's series of proposals provoked criticism from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" and stirred up allegations within the DPP, in particular from pro- Hsieh lawmakers, as to whether his moves were aimed at outgunning other DPP aspirants vying for the party's nomination to run in the 2008 presidential election, including Hsieh, Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Su Tseng-chang.
DPP lawmaker Wang Hsing-nan, however, voiced his support for Yu's proposal to relocate statues of Chiang and his son, pointing out that many Taiwan people have no respect for the two late dictators.

Wang hailed Yu's statue relocation idea and argued that it is not the government's obligation to finance the maintenance of the two Chiangs' tombs and that providing finance in fact lacks any legal basis according to the law.
DPP lawmaker Cheng Yun-peng, a Hsieh protege, claimed that Yu should first quit the chairmanship if he wants to start electioneering for the 2008 presidency.

Cheng said that he agrees with the statue relocation idea but contended that the DPP head should have discussed the issue with the Legislative Yuan and should have allowed the Executive Yuan to make the announcement instead of the party central.
Meanwhile, KMT legislative caucus members accused Yu of seeking to cement "deep green" voter support by airing the comments.
KMT legislative whip Hsu Shao-ping argued that both the military and honor guards at the mausoleums must not be removed because they are one of Taiwan's major tourist attractions.

KMT lawmaker Alex Fei urged Yu to "stop rubbing salt into wounds" by rehashing these historic issues, and said that the DPP chairman did this to jockey for a position in the DPP aimed at the next presidential election.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan news conference, Lee Hung-chun, spokesman for the opposition People First Party (PFP) in the "pan-blue alliance, " accused the DPP of attempting to launch a "cultural revolution" in Taiwan in a covert move to "conceal its fear of declaring formal Taiwan independence."

Lee also blasted Minister of National Defense Lee Jye for "having no guts" in yielding to DPP pressure and for having agreed to remove a total of 228 statues of the two former presidents from military barracks on Feb. 28.
PFP legislative caucus whip Cheng Chin-ling and PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung demanded that Lee Jye immediately step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: 340 TONS OF PONKAN MANDARIN ORANGES EXPORTED TO SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Fruit growers of Taichung County in central Taiwan have supplied more than 340 metric tons of ponkan mandarin oranges to Singapore and other Southeast Asian countries since mid-January, the Tungshih Farmers Association indicated Wednesday.

A spokesman for the association noted that with the Lunar New Year holiday drawing near, ponkan mandarin oranges produced in Taichung County, especially Tungshih township, are in great demand, with Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia being major importers of the fruit.
He said such exports would not only bring increased revenues to fruit farmers, but also help stabilize the price of the autumnal fruit on the domestic market.

The ponkan mandarin orange is a favorite fruit for people in Taiwan and other southeast Asian countries not only because it is available in autumn and winter, but also because of its bright color, sweet fragrance and taste, and ease in peeling.
Orchards in Tungshih township are best known for this fruit, and produce more than 1,000 metric tons a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 WORLD ROBOT OLYMPIAD TO BE HELD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The 2007 World Robot Olympiad will be held at the National Taiwan University's sports center from Nov. 16 to 18, the head of the World Robot Olympiad Committee announced in Taipei Wednesday.
Nearly 1000 players from approximately 200 teams, representing 25 countries, will participate in this year's WRO, the largest in its history.

WRO Committee Chairman Norikane Kanai, who came to Taiwan to look into related affairs, attended a press conference at the National Taiwan Science Education Center where he announced the competition's date and place.
Topics for this year's competition categories were assigned by Taiwan, and a new college group was added to the original primary, junior high, and high school groups.

Players in regular competition will design robots that simulate the Ali Mountain train's z-line switchback movement; in doing so they will come to know specific construction features of Taiwan's mountain railways. Teams in the open category competition are to create a "family robot" that increases the convenience of family life.
Related activities will be held in succession, including seminars, selection competitions in schools and regions, and a final national contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRAM SCHOOLS TO BE BANNED FROM ENROLLING CHILDREN UNDER 6

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved an amendment to the Supplementary and Continuing Education Law Wednesday that will prohibit cram schools from enrolling children under the age of six.

According to Cabinet officials, education of preschool children should focus on health and ethical education and should be closely linked with family education, and the amendment is designed at laying a sound base for the mental and physical development of children.
However, cram schools that offer children under six classes related to rhythm and artistic training will not be included on the list of prohibited schools, the officials added.

Taiwanese parents tend to push their children from a very early age into various cram schools to receive supplementary courses outside the formal education system in a wide variety of subjects to prepare them for their entry into the fierce job market.
The tendency has resulted in a country swarming with cram schools and enviable incomes for teachers in these schools -- plus a group of unhappy children.

The amendment will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for approval, the officials said, adding that once approved, violators will receive a warning to follow the new regulations or face fines of between NT$50,000 and NT$200,000, with serious violators getting their licenses revoked.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER INKS AGREEMENT WITH S. KOREAN THINK TANK
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/07 20:18:20 (TIER) and South Korea's Samsung Economic Research Institute (SERI) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research signed a cooperation agreement Wednesday to jointly study the impact that investment by Taiwan and South Korea in China will have on their economies.

The signing ceremony was presided over by TIER President David S. Hong and SERI CEO Kim Kyeong-Won in Taipei, with both sides promising to cooperate in the study of Taiwanese and South Korean investment in China and its impact on their respective economies.
The two think tanks agreed to release reports in this regard in June both in Taipei and Seoul.
After the signing of the agreement, Kim delivered a brief report about SERI's point of view regarding the changes in investment patterns of Asian countries during the last several decades.
According to SERI's report, Asian countries have shifted their focus from Japan during the last several decades to China currently.

With China's rise, it is necessary for Asian countries to make a thorough study of how they deploy their investment in this market, especially for Taiwan and South Korea, which have experienced a mass exodus of their high-tech companies to China in recent years, Kim said.
Against this background, it is a necessity for both Taiwan and South Korea to jointly study how their investment in China will influence their respective economies, according to Kim.
Hong noted that TIER's cooperation with the SERI marks a milestone in the institute's march toward internationalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS MINISTRY TO ADDRESS NEW YEARS' HOLIDAY TRAFFIC

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang ordered the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Wednesday to plan in advance for traffic congestion that may arise during the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday.
At a regular cabinet meeting, Su said as this year's Lunar New Year holiday will last nine days, and the weather is forecast to be fairer at that time, so it is expected that traffic will be heavy.

In addition to reminding MOTC officials to make plans for traffic beforehand, Su also expressed his gratitude to those government officials who will remain on duty during the Lunar New Year holiday, the most important annual family reunion for ethnic Chinese people.

Meanwhile, Su expressed appreciation to Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin for his decision to continue the services at customs offices around the country during Lunar New Year holiday to facilitate Taiwan's exports to foreign countries.
In addition, Su also ordered related government agencies to thoroughly plan for the provision of medical services, garbage disposal, and law enforcement during the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., TAIWAN OFFICIALS SHARE OPINIONS ON TIFA ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: U.S. and Taiwan officials recognize that the U.S.-Taiwan Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) is "the best platform" for efforts to promote cooperation between the two sides in the fields of trade and investment, although they share differing opinions on the issue of a free trade accord (FTA).

A workshop on the proposed U.S.-Taiwan FTA was held Monday at the Brookings Institute in Washington, D.C., with Richard Bush, director of the Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies of the think tank and a former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan presiding over the talks.

The event drew the participation of Eric Altbach, the deputy assistant U.S. trade representative, and U.S.-Taiwan Business Council Chairman Rupert Hammond- Chambers, as well as Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang, Taiwan's Deputy Representative to the U.S. John C.C. Deng and Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih.
During the talks, Shih voiced Taiwan's desire to forge an FTA, saying that Taiwan needs to reinforce its cooperative relationship with the U.S.

Chen said that while Taiwan faces political suppression by China in the international society, economically the nation has also been seen to have an increasing reliance on the Chinese market. The imbalance in both politics and economics will damage the common strategic interests of the U.S. and Taiwan, the economist warned, adding that an FTA would get rid of the imbalance.
Chen urged Washington to realize the urgency of the issue.

Echoing Chen's remarks, Deng said that the two countries need to take steps to integrate resources in the U.S.-Taiwan cooperation mechanism and that with Taiwan's great efforts to seek economic upgrading, it would be beneficial for the U.S. to sign an FTA with Taiwan. In response to the call, most of the American participants pointed out that Taiwan is not listed among the countries in the process of FTA talks with the U.S. trade and investment departments.

While the United States has always believed Taiwan is motivated by political need rather than economic interest in its bid for an FTA, the U.S. enterprise sector has expressed hope that Taiwan first lift limitations against trade between the two sides across the Taiwan Strait and push for direct cross-strait transport links, the U.S. experts said, with Altbach suggesting that the two nations concentrate their energies on talks under the TIFA.

Altbach said there has been great progress in previous rounds of U.S.-Taiwan TIFA talks in past years on many issues, including those concerning intellectual property rights protection, agricultural trade opening, modernization of the financial industry and pharmaceutical trading controls.

The TIFA was signed between the American Institute in Taiwan and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States in 1994 to resolve bilateral trade issues and enhance economic cooperation in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSO TO BEGIN PERFORMANCE TOUR OF SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: The National Symphony Orchestra (NSO) will perform in Singapore and Malaysia from Feb. 23- 28, an NSO spokeswoman said Wednesday.

The NSO's executive director, Joyce Chiou said the NSO will join the "5th Huayi- Chinese Festival of Arts" at the invitation of Singapore's Esplanade-Theaters on the Bay. Chiou pointed out that this performance is the first step to bringing the NSO back onto the international stage.

The NSO will follow the theme of "Philharmonic Taiwan" by presenting three music works composed by Taiwanese musicians: the "Capriccio of Kuan-du for Piano and Orchestra" by Ma Shuei-lung, the "Festive Celebration" by Chung Yiu-kwong, the "Heterophony Concerto for Orchestra" by Pan Huan-lung.

Chiou said this performance tour will reintroduce the NSO to international audiences after its 1997's performance in the Europe. The NSO is also planning performance tours in Japan, Hong Kong, France in later this year or next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO ATTEND MEMORIAL FOR FORMER DECATHLETE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will be present Friday at a memorial ceremony for Yang Chuan-kwang, Taiwan's legendary decathlete who died of a stroke in California at the age of 74, and will award a presidential citation to honor Yang's contribution to the nation, an organizer of the event said Wednesday.

The ceremony will be held at Chi-nan Presbyterian Church, near the Legislative Yuan, said Tsai Szu-chung, Vice Chairman of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee and chief organizer of the ceremony, adding that the Christian form of a memorial service was chosen in accordance with the wishes of the Yangs, a Christian family.

President of the National College of Physical Education and Sports, Chou Hung- Shih, will serve as presider, and Chi-Cheng, a former athlete who won bronze in the women's 80-meter low hurdles at the 1968 Mexico City Summer Olympics, will deliver a eulogy, Tsai said.

Yang, born in 1933, won gold in the decathlon at the 1954 Asian Games in Manila. Dubbed theIron man of Asia, he won gold again at the 1958 Tokyo Asian Games and took silver at the 1960 Rome Olympics after a duel with his UCLA schoolmate Rafer Johnson of the United States. It was the first Olympic medal Taiwan had ever won.

Yang's family held his cremation near Los Angeles Feb. 3, after his last wish that his body be buried in the National Sports Training Center in Kaohsiung was denied by Taiwanese authorities on the grounds that it would not be legal. The government sent delegates to attend the funeral and covered Yang's coffin with both the national flag and Taiwan's Olympic flag.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPORTS LOTTERY MIGHT BE LAUNCHED NEXT MARCH: NCPFS

TEXT.P: Taiwan might launch a sports lottery next March, a National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) official said Wednesday after Premier Su Tseng-chang vowed a day earlier to eradicate domestic baseball-related scandals.

Council Vice Chairman Chen Yu-hsin said that last year, the NCPFS submitted a plan for the sports lottery to the Ministry of Finance, which he said is likely to announce public bidding following the Chinese New Year holiday that starts Feb. 17.
Nevertheless, the official launch of the lottery might take another year, he added.

Chen's remarks came after Su made the vow during a meeting with Chao Shou-po, chairman of the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , and representatives of Taiwan's six professional baseball teams.

At the meeting, the premier instructed Finance Minister Ho Chih-chin to step up the launch of the sports lottery, which is expected to help stem illegal gambling on local professional baseball games and generate money to finance domestic sports.
Meanwhile, the premier ordered the National Police Agency and the Bureau of Investigation to take measures to prevent gangsters from interfering with local professional baseball games again.

There have been three baseball scandals involving organized crime in 1996, 2005, and 2006, respectively, which have caused the number of people attending games to drop from 1.05 million to 670,000 within the past five years, according to Su.

In addition, Su requested that Ho grant tax breaks to six business groups that have long sponsored local baseball, while ordering the Ministry of Economic Affairs to ask state-run enterprises to form a baseball team.

In related news, Joseph Tsai, director-general of the Finance Ministry's National Treasury Agency, remarked that despite the NCPFS's plan, the ministry needs to further discuss with the Executive Yuan the establishment of supplementary measures and a monitoring mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Military Wants More Civilians to Help in Iraq
Senior military officers, including members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have told President Bush and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the new Iraq strategy could fail unless more civilian agencies step forward quickly to carry out plans for reconstruction and political development.
The complaints reflect fresh tensions between the Pentagon and the State Department over personnel demands that have fallen most heavily on the military. But they also draw on a deeper reservoir of concerns among officers who have warned that a military buildup alone cannot solve Iraqs problems, and who now fear that the military will bear a disproportionate burden if Mr. Bushs strategy falls short.
Wall Street Journal: How One Man Riled The Emerald Trade
Walking through this city's historic emerald district last summer, Arthur Groom was approached by a man who sidled up and flashed a fistful of white folded papers containing cut stones.
Arthur Groom is stirring up a sometimes shady nook of the gem world by becoming the first person to try selling branded, natural emeralds, just as De Beers did with diamonds.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Weathermen predict heavy snowfall and travel trouble
Some of the heaviest snowfalls for years are forecast for this week, bringing the prospect of delays and cancellations for rail and air passengers and hazardous conditions on the roads.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR SUPPORTS BLOOD DONATION DRIVE

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and his city government employees answered a call by the Taichung Blood Center Wednesday for donors to help relieve its current blood shortage.
The Taichung city government and the Taichung Blood Center jointly held a blood donation drive in front of the city government after the mayor learned of the shortage being experienced by the center.
Hu was the first to roll up his sleeve to donate, leading fellow employees waiting for their turn in a long queue.

Hu told the donors that he was grateful that his wife's life was saved by an emergency surgery that required a transfusion of 20,000 c.c. of blood after she was seriously injured in a car accident in November last year.
He said that he will be a "happy frequent blood donor" for the rest of his life.

The Taiwan Blood Services Foundation has pointed out that the Lunar New Year holiday beginning on Feb. 17 is a period when blood centers throughout Taiwan are dogged by blood shortages, which threaten the ability of hospitals to perform surgeries and respond to emergencies.
To cope with the crisis, the foundation and its blood centers have launched a month-long blood donation campaign from Jan. 16 to Feb. 16.
Experts at the foundation estimate that if everyone who is eligible to donate blood did so twice a year, shortages at Taiwan's blood centers would become a thing of the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME RECTIFICATION LONG-TERM POLICY GOAL: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Despite controversy arising from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyu-kun's drive to change the names of state-run companies, the government is poised to promote the long-term goal of making Taiwan a normal country, Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said Wednesday.
According to Cheng, the "rectifying the country's name" campaign is a key task that the government will definitely do its utmost to implement in pursuit of the nation's overall interests.

Meanwhile, Yu was slated to put forward his proposal on changing the names of the state-owned enterprises that carry the term "China" at the party's Central Standing Committee meeting later the same day.

In addition to the name change drive, the DPP chairman was also reportedly planning to suggest that the Executive Yuan immediately withdraw both military and honor guards posted at the temporary mausoleums of late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching-kuo during the party's weekly meeting.
Premier Su Tseng-chang said a day earlier that the government will undoubtedly undertake any task beneficial to the nation after thoroughly considering such matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN GROUP TO TRAIN TAIPEI CLOWNS

TEXT.P: The German clown group Cirque Artikuss will present their skills Feb. 14 at a clown workshop for children to be held in Taipei, a spokesman for the event organizers said Wednesday.

Sponsored by various Taiwanese enterprises, the German Cultural Center in Taipei decided to organize the workshop and invite the group with the aim of provoking children's imagination and giving them a happy winter break, the spokesman said.

The workshop will begin with a clown show that will be the group's first performance in Taiwan, followed by a practice session headed by Olav Keith and Andreas Landersheim, both of whom are graduates of a comedy school in Hanover, according to the spokesman.
The children will be shown some basic clowning skills, including warm-up activities, circus performances, juggling and stunt techniques.

DOC.HEADLINE: KANGSHAN TOWNSHIP COUNCIL MEMBER CHARGED FOR ORGANIZED CRIME

TEXT.P: A member of the Kangshan Township Council in Kaohsiung County was arrested Wednesday on charges of running a brothel and forcing Vietnamese women into prostitution.

Chang Mao-yung and seven accomplices were taken into custody when police from the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) raided seven locations in Kangshan township, Yenchao township and Sanmin District in Kaohsiung city.

The crime ring has been under police surveillance since Kaohsiung County police separately detained several Vietnamese women working as prostitutes in the townships of Kangshan and Fengshan on Jan. 25 and Jan. 28.
CIB agents rescued six Vietnamese women who have been forced by the crime ring to work as sex slaves.

According to a spokesman for the CIB's local detachment, Chang and the "snakehead" of his ring went to Vietnam to recruit women to work in Taiwan, promising them good employment opportunities. They brought the Vietnamese women into Taiwan under the guise of what turned out to be false marriages, and then coaxed or forced the women into prostitution.
The spokesman said Chang and his accomplices will be referred to the Kaohsiung District Public Prosecutors' Office for prosecution for violating the Organized Crime Prevention Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO BOOST GIS INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: The government is to spend NT$21.1 billion (US$641 million) over ten years to build Taiwan's national geographical information system (GIS) , in order to spur on private sector applications of this technology, a senior economic official announced Wednesday.

Speaking at a news conference, Ho Mei-yueh, Chairwoman of the cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said the integration of various geographical data bases held separately by different governmental agencies is needed.
These data won't contribute to industries if they are not utilized, Ho said.The state has to establish an information system, standardize it, and make it available to the private sector for its use.
GIS is an important part of a knowledge-based economy, she added.

The CEPD hopes that governmental efforts on this project will help create new businesses. For example, Ho said, people could consult a GIS company to know whether the residence they are considering buying is located on a fault.

She said the CEPD will serve as an integrator, reviewing materials from separate governmental agencies to avoid repetition, ensuring compatibility and increasing the efficacy of the geographical information.

Ho said other measures the government is considering to foster GIS industries include establishing a national space library, training people to apply GIS knowledge as a secondary skill, offering low-interest loans, subsidizing projects, setting up venture capital, developing authentication mechanisms and so forth.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLLAND URGED TO GRANT VISA-FREE PRIVILEGE TO TAIWAN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the Netherlands Wednesday to grant visa-free privileges to Taiwanese tourists to further boost bilateral civilian exchanges.
Chen made the call while meeting with Hans van Baalen, chairman of the Dutch parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee, who arrived in Taipei earlier this week for a visit.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Chen said, substantive relations between Taiwan and the Netherlands have been close and cordial. Two-way trade reached US$6.6 billion last year, making Holland Taiwan's second largest European trading partner after Germany.

"There should much more room for bilateral trade to grow further in the years to come," Chen said, adding that the Netherlands is also Taiwan's biggest investor from Europe, with accumulated Dutch investment in Taiwan reaching US$8.88 billion at the end of last year.
Chen lauded Baalen for his ardent efforts in the past years to help promote friendly relations between Taiwan and the Netherlands.

Among others, Baalen initiated a resolution in the Dutch parliament in December 2003 on opposing the European Union to lift its arms embargo against China. Through his strenuous effort, the resolution cleared the Dutch parliamentary floor. In the following year, the Netherlands took up the E.U. presidency and used its diplomatic leverage to prevent the bloc from removing its arms ban against China.

In October 2005, Baalen again used its political clout to have the Dutch parliament pass a resolution throwing support behind Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's governing body -- as an observer.
"Neither of these achievements came easily. We are grateful for your kind- hearted assistance with our national cause, " Chen told Baalen during their meeting at the Presidential Office.

Noting that there is still ample room for Taiwan-Dutch ties to grow, Chen galvanized Baalen to continue assisting in promoting substantive relations. Tasks in this regard include pushing the Dutch executive branch to take concrete actions to substantiate support for Taiwan's WHO bid, offer visa-free entry for Taiwanese tourists and advocate the formation of a pro-Taiwan subgroup in the Dutch parliament.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Feb. 8

10:20, President Chen Shui-bian will preside over a groundbreaking ceremony on construction of a Hakka culture research institute at National Chiaotung University.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 8, or the 21st day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Spanish explorer Capt. Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba sets sail from Cuba and later "discovers" Mexico.
1587: Mary, Queen of Scots, who had been found guilty of plotting to assassinate England's Queen Elizabeth I, is beheaded.
1725: Peter the Great of Russia dies. He would be succeeded by his wife Catherine.
1902: The eruption of a volcano on the French island of Martinique in the Lesser Antilles kills more than 26,000 people.
1904: Japanese warships launch a surprise night attack against Lushun (Port Arthur) in northern China, destroying three Russian warships and causing the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1906: A strong typhoon hits Tahiti in the South Pacific, killing about 10,000 people.
1910: The Boy Scouts of America organization, a cousin to the movement founded by Sir Robert Baden-Powell in Britain two years earlier, is inaugurated.
1924: The gas chamber as a method of execution is used for the first time in Carson City, Nevada, when Gee Jon, a Chinese gang member, is put to death.
1926: American archaeologists discover relics from the Mayan civilization in the jungles of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula near the Caribbean coast.
1931: More than 3,000 miners are killed in an accident at the Fushun mine run by a Japanese company of the Southern Manchuria Railway in Liaoning province, northeastern China.
1931: James Dean, the U.S. film actor and cult hero who died at the age of 24 in a road accident while driving his Spider convertible, is born.
1946: A provisional people's council is set up in Soviet-occupied North Korea, with Kim Il Sung serving as chairman.
1949: The National Central Library moves to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.
1954: More than 14,000 Communist Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland begin to undergo job training in Tahu, Siahu, and Yangmei in Taiwan.
1955: Nikolai Bulganin becomes premier of the Soviet Union, replacing Georgi Malenkov.
1962: The U.S. military council is set up in South Vietnam.
1963: President Abdel-Karim Kassem of Iraq is overthrown and killed in a military coup.
1964: Princess Irene of Holland renounces her right to the throne in order to marry Spanish Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma.
1965: British Health Minister Kenneth Robinson announces that cigarette ads will be banned from television.
1966: The Republic of Vietnam and the United States issue the Declaration of Honolulu, outlining their aims for Vietnam.
1974: Dr. George L.B. Pratt, director of the Office of Education and Manpower, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Chinese investors in Taiwan and Gulf Oil Corporation officials agree on the establishment of a joint company to produce low-density polyethylene.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan decorates Dr. Harry Bodan Shields, visiting vice minister of foreign affairs of the Republic of Nicaragua, with the Grand Cordon of the Order of Brilliant Star.
1976: Guatemalan Ambassador Agustin Donis Kesler calls on Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan to thank the government for helping earthquake victims.
1980: Louis Vorster, new ambassador of the Republic of South Africa, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1984: Athletes from the Republic of China re-enter the Olympic Games, taking part in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1995: The U.S. liaison office in Vietnam begins business operations, marking the first step in the return to normal relations between the two countries.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui says the ROC and the Vatican should join hands to strive for freedom and democracy for the enslaved people in mainland China and other parts of the world.
2001: Chen Li-fu, a member of the presidium of the opposition Kuomintang Central Advisory Committee, dies at the age of 103.
2001: Two reporters from mainland China's Xinhua News Agency who have been granted permission to be stationed in Taiwan arrive in Taipei, marking a new milestone for news exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are, perhaps, men who propound theories they themselves do not understand. That is a thing I never do. I read and learn everything and, choosing that which is excellent, I adopt it; I see everything and take note of what I see: that is, perhaps, next to having a great understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECORDS FIFTH FLU-RELATED FATALITY THIS WINTER

TEXT.P: A three-year-old girl died early this month of serious complications caused by type B influenza, becoming the fifth flu-related fatality recorded in the country this winter, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) reported Wednesday.
The victim, a Hsinchu City resident, was hospitalized Jan. 22 for fever, sore throat, diarrhea, vomiting and decreased level of consciousness, CDC officials said.
Despite receiving intensive medical care, the girl developed complications, including cardiopulmonary failure, shock and cerebral edema, and died Feb. 1, the officials said.
According to CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi, tests confirmed that the girl was infected with type B influenza. She had not received flu vaccination this winter or last winter.
CDC tallies show that 24 cases of severe influenza have been confirmed this winter, with all five fatalities caused by the type B influenza virus.

Shih said the good news is that the number of flu cases reported around the country is decreasing, with the ratio of patients making medical visits for flu having dropped to 4.99 percent last week from 5.55 percent the previous week.

Despite the slight decline in the number of new flu cases, Shih reminded the public that the country still remains in the peak period of flu season and that there might be a small outbreak during the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR ACTIVE STEPS TO STAMP OUT CHILD ABUSE

TEXT.P: Relevant government agencies should pull out all the stops to stamp out child abuse and enhance children's well-being, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Thursday.
Su made the remarks amid an increasing number of reports of child abuse cases, including some shocking and horrifying child abuse and neglect fatalities, in recent weeks.
"It's sad and disheartening to hear one after another child neglect or abuse case, " Su said, adding that the government cannot stand idly by while many young children face the threat of abuse.

According to government statistics, up to 83 percent of child abuse fatalities were committed by the children's own parents or their natural parents' live-in lovers, and 73 percent of the victims were under 6 years of age.

Over the past year, Su said, the government has devoted a huge amount of funds and manpower to addressing the child abuse issue. "But the continuing rise in the number of reported child abuse cases indicate that our efforts are still not sufficient, " Su said, adding that in the face of rapid social changes, relevant government agencies should work even harder to protect children from falling victim to violence or filicide-suicide.

According to a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) report, 90 percent of child abuse cases happened within families, and more than 50,000 children have been listed for special attention as they live in families at high risk of violence or suicide.
An MOI official said the ministry will push for amendments to the existing child welfare law to require grass-roots community coordinators to report child abuse cases or high-risk families.

The official said the ministry is also studying the feasibility of using funds from the public-interest lottery to set up regional family welfare service centers for disadvantaged children or high-risk families.

"We are also considering stopping recruiting grass-roots community coordinators and using the budget to recruit trained social workers or caseworkers to strengthen services for disadvantaged children from high-risk families," the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TAIWAN CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT JUDICIAL COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/08/07 15:26:00 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu urged China Wednesday to respond positively to Taiwan's call for cross-Taiwan Strait judicial cooperation so as to clear itself of the reputation of being a "paradise for Taiwanese criminals."

Wu noted that under the Kinmen Agreement signed by the Red Cross societies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1990, Taiwan has repatriated a large number of illegal Chinese immigrants and criminals.

Although China has also repatriated more than 100 Taiwanese criminals over the years, approximately 400 Taiwanese criminals are still hiding in China, and Chinese authorities have no intention of helping Taiwan arrest them and send them back, Wu pointed out.

According to Wu, owing to the lack of any standards or system in dealing with matters as such, Beijing usually bases its decision on whether to repatriate the Taiwanese criminals on whether they have committed any crime in China.

Citing the case of Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng as an example, Wu said that Taiwan asked Chinese authorities to help track down and repatriate Wang soon after he fled to China but that Beijing ignored the request and even allowed Wang to leave China freely for the United States.

As Beijing has no obligation to help Taiwan arrest criminals hiding in China under the present situation, Taiwan has repeatedly called for the establishment of a cross-strait accord on crime-fighting cooperation, Wu said.
Wu, who is on a visit in the U.S. capital, made the remarks in response to questions from Taiwan reporters.

On China's effort to improve its international image ahead of the 2008 Olympic Games to be held in Beijing, Wu said it is a positive development that China has recently relaxed its news coverage restrictions for foreign media and allowed the content of a book on democracy to be published in newspapers in the country.
However, China has on the other hand stepped up its suppression of civil rights activists and shown no improvement in human rights protection, Wu said.

On the issue of allowing Chinese media outlets to post correspondents in Taiwan, Wu said the MAC suspended permits for China's state-controlled Xinhua News Agency and People's Daily to post correspondents in Taiwan two years ago because they had repeatedly produced misleading reports about Taiwan.
While making the decision at that time, the MAC also asked Beijing to allow the Chinese people to enjoy broader access to news reports by Taiwanese media, Wu noted.

Praising China for having made some progress in this regard recently, Wu pointed out that news Web sites run by Taiwan's China Times and United Daily News, which were blocked by Chinese authorities in the past, are now accessible in some areas of China.

Wu said the MAC will restore the permits for the two Chinese media outlets and even allow more Chinese media to post correspondents in Taiwan if Beijing removes its "blockade" against Taiwan media completely.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped Thursday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 7.84 points to close at 7,842.22.
The bourse opened at 7,875.52 and fluctuated between 7,884.79 and 7,790.63 during trading. A total of 2.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.59 billion (US$2.51 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground with plastic and chemical shares moving up the most at 0.4 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.3 percent, and banking and financial issues at 0.1 percent.
Three other stock categories lost ground with construction issues moving down the most at 0.4 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares as well as foodstuff issues both at 0.3 percent.
Cement and paper and pulp stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 755 to 394, while 242 stocks remaining unchanged.

Senate Republicans who earlier this week helped block deliberations on a resolution opposing President Bush's new troop deployments in Iraq changed course yesterday and vowed to use every tactic at their disposal to ensure a full and open debate.

Los Angeles TimesG Israel Sounds alarm on Iran's nuclear efforts.

But the specter of a nuclear-armed Iran has rattled Israel's self-confidence. ]By Lu- sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: 320,000 WEIGHT-LOSS TABLETS CONTAINING ILLICIT DRUG SEIZED

TEXT.P: Police seized about 320,000 weight-loss tablets containing amphetamine in a search of a biotechnology plant in northern Taoyuan County Thursday, detaining a 45-year-old woman identified as Chang Wen-hsin.
Police said Chang has sold some 17 million such tablets through various department stores in Taiwan over the last five years and has earned more than NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) from the sales.
Chang, who sold cosmetics, is very familiar with marketing products through department stores, according to the police.
The police were tipped off about the possible presence of illicit substances in the tablets by the mother of flight attendant who became addicted to the tablets and committed suicide recently.

Chang told police that she found the medication in Shanghai several years ago and began using it herself. After discovering the effectiveness of the tablets, she began smuggling them into Taiwan via various channels.

Although claiming that the tablets only contain traditional Chinese herbal medicine, Chang revealed that she also suffered from bouts of depression after starting to take the tablets, which police said they believe is one of the side- effects of the substances contained in the tablets.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up two points to close at 7,870, with 42,625 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March gained seven points to finish at 7,878, with 3,252 contracts traded, while June futures dropped three points to close at 7,859, with 12 contract transactions. September futures moved up 27 points to close at 7,700, with 47 contracts traded, while December futures dropped 33 points to finish at 7,672, with four contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,868 for February, 7,871 for March, 7,862 for June, 7,673 for September and 7,705 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

February TE futures dropped 0.15 points to close at 334.45, with 3,723 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up 0.3 points to finish at 334.6, with 170 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 2.85 points to close at 331.05, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

February TF futures gained 0.8 points to close at 1,050.8, with 2,411 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up three points to close at 1,054, with 426 contracts traded. September TF futures increased 4.4 points to finish at 1,047, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO ASSESS FEASIBILITY OF PROPOSALS ON TRANSITIONAL JUSTICE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will evaluate the feasibility of proposals put forth by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) regarding the pursuit of transitional justice in the country, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said Thursday.

Cheng said he agrees that Taiwan, having achieved democracy through a peaceful transition of power, needs to further deepen its democracy and address issues of transitional justice by providing redress for those victimized during the period of authoritarian rule and correcting historical truths that were distorted in the past.

However, as the proposals raised by the DPP involve not only the jurisdiction of the central government but also of local governments and even the cooperation of the people, the Cabinet will conduct a comprehensive review of the proposals before deciding whether to adopt them, Cheng said.
Marking the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident this year, the DPP has recommended that the government step up its effort in the pursuit of transitional justice.

The DPP has proposed that the country enact a law on transitional justice, release a report on the truth behind the 228 Incident, eliminate the remnants of authoritarian rule, and hold various commemorative events to mark the 228 Incident.

Among the measures to eliminate the remnants of authoritarian rule, the party has asked the Cabinet to remove military guards posted at the mausoleum of late President Chiang Kai-shek, rename the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall" and rename all roads named after Chiang -- who is considered the key perpetrator of the 228 Incident of 1947 during which thousands of people were massacred by Kuomintang (KMT) troops suppressing a rebellion against KMT rule in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUSEUM SCHOLAR REMINISCES ON TAIWAN EXPERIENCE, TALKS CHINESE CULTURE

TEXT.P: As an eyewitness and a longtime observer of Taiwan's development over the past 30 years, British Museum scholar Jan Stuart told the CNA on the sidelines of an international academic conference that she has been constantly amazed that it's possible for Taiwanese identity and Chinese identity to coexist.

Currently in Taiwan for the promotion of a British Museum artifacts exhibition and an international conference on the art and culture of China's Northern Sung Dynasty (xxx-xxxx) , the Asia Department keeper of the British Museum has also been busy meeting acquaintances during his visit. And she hasn't needed a guide.

Stuart, a U.S. citizen, speaks excellent Mandarin and is very familiar with Taipei City because she lived in Taiwan for a total of one-and-a-half years on two separate occasions in the 1970s and the 1980s.

She visited Taiwan for the first time in 1976 "to see if studying Chinese in Taiwan could be an option" and ended up staying for six months, living with a well-educated couple in the Wanhua district of Taipei City.

"We lived in an old community and a house with no hot water. It was the first time I realized that people with the same education level enjoy different living standards, " Stuart said, describing the experience as "culture shock."

With her interest in Chinese culture growing, Stuart came back to Taiwan in 1982 and enrolled in a National Taiwan University Chinese-language program, living this time on Roosevelt Road for nine months. "I've been surprised to see how fast Taiwan has changed as a country since that time," she told the CNA.
Based on her experience and observations, Stuart presents a unique perspective on Taiwanese culture and Chinese culture.

There are many regions in China, such as Tibet and Xinjiang, that have distinct cultures, Stuart said, adding that this is the reason why she thinks the Taiwanese identity can coexist with the Chinese identity.

"From the viewpoint of an outsider, "it's possible to be Taiwanese and Chinese at the same time, " she said, adding, however, that she realizes it is not easy to separate politics from culture, especially in Taiwan's case.

Stuart said that she first fell in love with Chinese culture after seeing Chinese paintings as a high school student and that her experience in Taiwan facilitated her decision to pursue Chinese culture research as a career.
Stuart obtained both her bachelor's degree and master's degree at Yale University and worked in the field of Chinese culture studies thereafter.

Specializing in art and culture from China's Sung Dynasty (960-1279) to the Qing Dynasty (1644-1912) , Stuart worked in the Smithsonian Institute before joining the British Museum three months ago. She is now based in London.

In addition to scholastic research, Stuart enjoys "visual arts of every country and form" as well as folk practices. During her time in Taiwan, she spent numerous hours watching outdoor puppetry performances.
"I enjoy observing how people live, " she said.

A total of 271 artifacts collected by the British Museum valued at more than NT$50 billion are being exhibited at the National Palace Museum in Taipei City from Feb. 4 to May 27. This marks the first collaboration between the two museums.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD CALLS FOR STRONGER JAPAN-US-TAIWAN ALLIANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/08/07 17:18:33 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu on Wednesday called for stronger alliance between the United States, Japan and Taiwan to bolster regional security amid worries over China's recent flexing of its military muscles.

During a speech delivered at the Center for Strategic and International Studies think tank, Wu said China's Jan. 11 destruction of an old Chinese weather satellite by a warhead launched from an intercontinental ballistic missile "demonstrated that China has every intention of expanding its military power, and even of trying to militarize space."
The anti-satellite test "sent a signal that is very clear to any countries concerned about a possible future conflict between Taiwan and China," Wu said.
China's destruction of the satellite also posed a threat to U.S. efforts to protect security in Taiwan and around the Asia-Pacific region, he asserted.

Wu said this move proved the hypocrisy of a white paper issued by the People's Liberation Army (PLA) last year which claimed that all of the military actions of the PLA were aimed at spurring "peace."

Besides the United States and Taiwan, China also had Japan in mind when it chose Jan. 11 as the date for the test, Wu said during his speech. He said the test coincided with a trip to Europe by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who cautioned Europe's leaders that lifting an arms embargo against China could threaten security in Asia.

Wu noted that it came as Abe's conservative government upgraded the Japanese Defense Agency to a full ministry, which raised worries about the state of postwar pacifism in China's traditional rival, Japan.

"We need to consider a possible stronger alliance between the United States and Japan, and stronger and closer cooperation in security matters between Taiwan and the United States in order to deal with a multipronged security threat in East Asia," he said.

Meanwhile, Wu also stressed that Beijing has continued to strangle Taiwan's activities in the international community over the past year -- in seven incidents last year, Beijing tried to press Taiwan to change its formal designations used in NGO organizations.

Taiwan would not be that active in pushing for the use of "Taiwan" as the formal name of the country in the international community should Beijing relent in pressing Taiwan over the issue, Wu asserted.
