DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY FOG CAUSES ANOTHER CLOSURE OF TAOYUAN INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Heavy fog caused another closure of Taoyuan International Airport from 2 a.m. - 10 a.m. Thursday after a previous closure stretching from Tuesday night until Wednesday evening, a spokesman of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday.

Low visibility caused by heavy fog started at 2 a.m. Thursday, affecting more than 30 flights and nearly 6,000 passengers. About 30 flights were delayed and six were redirected to Kaohsiung International Airport. Most of the passengers affected were from tour groups to Southeast Asia.
Runways were not reopened until visibility increased from 100 to 2,200 meters around 10 a.m the same day, said the CAA spokesman.

The previous closure of the Taoyuan International Airport affected 150 passenger and cargo flights between Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. Some of the affected flights were redirected to other international airports or delayed, while others were canceled.

Taoyuan International Airport usually redirects flights to other international airports in reaction to closures caused by bad weather. Some local carriers may be redirected to Songshan Airport in Taipei under special conditions; if so, their passengers must then go through the formalities of customs or transfer procedures at Taoyuan International Airport.
The spokesman reminded passengers to confirm their flight schedules with the airlines to avoid delays and inconvenience.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOICES SUPPORT FOR NAME CHANGE DRIVE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian voiced his support Thursday for a national name rectification campaign, saying that the move will help highlight Taiwan's identity and galvanize the people's confidence.
Writing in an online newspaper published by the Presidential Office, in response to a reader's inquiries, Chen said that the government is poised to carry out the task in a piecemeal fashion.

In the future, overseas outposts and state-run enterprises, such as the Chinese Petroleum Corp., China Shipbuilding Corp., as well as various official documents will no longer carry the term "China" or "Chinese" in their official titles to distinguish from their Chinese counterparts, Chen said.

The national name rectification campaign is a long-term policy goal of the government, the first move towards which was changing the name of Chiang Kei- shek International Airport to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, a move that received a warm response from the public, Chen said, adding that most of the Taiwanese people want to correct the name used to represent the country's public companies.

Although the president acknowledged that changing names for Taiwan's state-run enterprises will entail some effort and costs, he argued that it is worthwhile to do so because it will be helpful in building world-class brands such as Nokia, Microsoft and Toyota among Taiwan's businesses.

Chen's endorsement for the national name rectification campaign came one day after ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun proposed at the party's Central Standing Committee that a name change drive be launched nationwide, starting with the names of public-run companies.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chien-yeh echoed Chen's call and said that the ministry will continue working to have the word "Taiwan" added to the nation's embassies and representative offices.

Brushing aside rampant allegations that the name change drive is a politically charged move, Wang urged the outside world to refrain from speculating the issue and called it a necessary measure to avoid international confusion.

DOC.HEADLINE: RP, TAIWAN SIGN MOU ON INDIGENOUS AFFAIRS COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Officials representing Taiwan and the Philippines signed a memorandum of understanding Thursday aimed at bolstering bilateral exchanges and cooperation on indigenous peoples' affairs.

Antonio Basilio, resident representative and managing director of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office in Taiwan, joined Wu Hsin-hsing, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines, at a ceremony held to ink the MOU, which calls for closer cultural and economic exchanges and cooperation of indigenous people between the two countries.

Walis Pelin, chairman of the Council of Indigenous Peoples, and his Philippine counterpart, Jannette Cansing Serrano-Reisland, witnessed the MOU signing at the ceremony, which was followed by performances of indigenous songs and dances, all flavored with champagne.

Speaking at the ceremony, Walis Pelin told a beautiful story about interactions between indigenous peoples from Taiwan and the Philippines. Filipinos are believed to be descendants of the various Austronesian-speaking migrants who arrived in successive waves over some thousand years ago from Taiwan, and are genetically most closely related to the Tao (formerly known as Yami) people now living on Green Island located off Taiwan's southeast coast, he said.

Twenty years ago, he said, a young Tao man ferried to Batan, in the Philippines' northernmost island group to marry to a Batan girl, thereby reliving the close relations that the two countries' ancestors had maintained a thousand years ago.

Walis Pelin also disclosed that the Council of Indigenous Peoples had been planning to sponsor some 20 Taiwan indigenous people to ferry to Batan in the near future to again follow the path that Taiwanese ancestors followed when they ferried to the Philippines a millennium or more ago.
Thursday's MOU marked the fourth of its kind that Taiwan has signed with foreign countries. Taiwan has signed similar pacts with indigenous groups from Canada, New Zealand and Belize.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCTU TO DEVELOP SECOND GENERATION ELECTRONIC EYES

TEXT.P: National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) is aiming to develop the second generation of electronic eyes, equipped with higher resolution and wireless power supplies, sources at the Hsinchu-based university said Thursday.

NCTU President Wu Chung-yu said that professor Liu Wen-tai at the University of California, Santa Cruz, invented the first generation of electronic eyes. However, their applicability remains limited, so Liu and NCTU have agreed to an arrangement to expand their capacity.
Wu said the new research team would bring together experts from both biomedical science and electronic engineering.

As for the current version, the device uses 16-pixel chips as artificial light receptors. When implanted into the eyes, the chips serve as light receptors on retina, enabling the visually impaired to regain partial vision.
Seven patients that took part in the experiment at University of California can now read alphabetical eye-charts and the outline of objects after undergoing the procedures.
However, the field of vision is confined and the chips are reliant on wired power supplies, both of which limit its range of application, Wu noted.

Wu said the goal of the new team is to improve the device with 256-pixel chips to offer greater vision and employ wireless or solar batteries as a power source, thereby reducing the inconveniences of a hard-wired power supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCALLY DEVELOPED ENGLISH TEST UNVEILED

TEXT.P: An English test touted to be the first developed in compliance with regulations laid down by the Ministry of Education and the Common European Framework was unveiled here by a private educational institution, the National Development Institute (NDI) Thursday.

In a news conference called to promote the examination system, Huang Chun-teng, an associate professor in the Department of English, National Changhua University of Education, and head of a panel of scholars responsible for the development of the test, said the Global English Test (GET) is learner-centered and action-oriented, and is thus designed to measure the exam-taker's ability to communicate.
Noting that many English tests available on the market concentrate on gramar, Huang said GET stresses the students' ability to use English in daily life.

In the course of its development, Huang said, more than 16,000 students from 50 junior and senior high schools and universities took the exam between September and December last year to help its developers to finetune the system.

Citing the examination results of GET A2 level, which is the equivalent to the English level of junior high school sophomores, Huang said freshmen from gifted classes at junior high schools perform better not only than their counterparts in regular classes, but also better than students from universities.

Although the results may not reflect the whole picture of the country, Huang said, it suggests that the English language has been taught as a study subject rather than an applied skill, and as a result many local university graduates cannot communicate in English while studying abroad.

Stressing the importance of motivation in learning a foreign language, Huang said young students -- except for those who are applying to schools overseas -- are not encouraged to take the examination because there is no point for them to invest their time in it.

The test, which ranks learners from beginner to superior, in six grades from A1 to C2, consists of a listening and reading section, and speaking and writing section. The test for each section carries a fee of NT$550 (US$15.12).

DOC.HEADLINE: LOVERS NABBED FOR SMUGGLING HEROIN INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 29-year-old man and his girlfriend were arrested for smuggling heroin from Cambodia into Taiwan in the guise of chocolate, police reported Thursday.
Police seized more than 2,800 grams of high-purity heroin, with a street value of NT$70 million (US$2.13 million).

The man, surnamed Shih, and his 23-year-old girl friend, surnamed Huang, were hoping to get through the inspection when air traffic at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport was thrown into chaos Wednesday night due to heavy fog.

Police noted that they were carrying out monitoring operations over a fraud case when they inadvertently discovered a drug smuggling ring that solicits those who have no prior criminal record to work as couriers, or "mules."
The couriers were asked to travel to such countries as Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia, and bring back the controlled substance.

To evade detection, the heroin was coated with heavy layers of chocolate and wrapped up in tinfoil paper, making it difficult to detect using X-rays or sniffer dogs. But police were tipped off in advance and therefore were able to catch the couple despite their ingenuity.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DRINK MARKET SLUMPS IN 2006

TEXT.P: The health drink market showed a surprising slump in sales of nearly 9 percent in 2006, failing for the first time to realize the same steady growth as in previous years, a representative of the industry said Thursday.

The health drink market used to be a battlefield for businessmen due to the lifting of restrictions and rapid changes in biotechnology. New drinks appeared on the market one after another, but while businessmen have continued to introduce new products, sales performance declined in 2006.
The industry representative suggested that the market ceased to grow because new products on the market did not perform as well as in the past while many established brands dropped out entirely.
Taiwan's health drink market grew steadily from NT$25 billion in 2003 to over NT$35 billion (US$ 1.06 billion) in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMMUNICATING CLOSELY WITH U.S. ON FUGITIVE TYCOON: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been communicating closely with the United States on the case of Wang You-theng, fugitive founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh made the remarks after the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service announced that a court hearing will be set for 8 a.m. Tuesday at Wang's detention center in Los Angeles (or midnight Wednesday Taipei time).

Wang said that Taiwan's representative office in Washington D.C. and its office in Los Angeles have worked closely with the U.S. on the case and the ministry has kept abreast of the latest developments.
Taiwan also hopes to convey evidence against Wang to the United States, hoping that the U.S. court will hand down a ruling favorable to Taiwan.
Taiwan will also work closely with related U.S. agencies through the judicial assistance agreement signed between Taiwan and the United States in March 2002, Wang added.

Wang said that Taiwan will respect the judicial process of the United States, but will by no means sit by idly, stating that Taiwan will do everything possible to facilitate the repatriation of Wang to face justice in Taiwan.
Wang is wanted in Taiwan for his suspected involvement in a series of accounting frauds and embezzlement scandals surrounding his business group.

Taiwan put Wang on its most-wanted list in mid-January. He tried to fly to Myanmar via Singapore Jan. 31 but was sent back to the United States Feb. 2 by Singaporean authorities because he lacked the proper travel documents.
Wang arrived in Los Angeles Feb. 3 and was taken into custody because his Taiwan and Dominican Republic passports were invalidated as a result of efforts by the Taiwan authorities.

Wang fled to the United States shortly after China Rebar Co. and Chia Hsin Food & Synthetic Fiber Co., two subsidiaries under the Rebar group, filed for insolvency protection late last December. The revelations of the two financially-distressed companies triggered a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar affiliate, and a probe into the other subsidiaries of the group, which turned up ever more irregularities in a snowballing scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GOVERNMENT URGED TO EXTRADITE REBAR FOUNDER TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A dozen people gathered outside the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Thursday, requesting that the U.S. government extradite fugitive Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng.

Accompanied by ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislator Wang Tu-fa, several members of Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) displayed slogans in both Chinese and English in front of the AIT office, appealing to officials within to convey to the U.S. government the desire of Taiwan's people to see Wangs brought home to face justice.

Wang, who was taken into custody by U.S. immigration officials for traveling on invalid Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports, has been put on Taiwan's list of most wanted fugitives after beginning his fugitive tour with his wife in early January.

The tycoon is wanted by Taiwanese judicial authorities for his suspected involvement in a series of crimes, including forgery, fraud, insider trading, and embezzlement of corporate fund of his gigantic group.
TAUP Chairman Tsai Ting-kuei expressed hope that the U.S. government will extradite the Wangs based on the principles of democracy and the rule by law.

Stressing that the United States is supposed to be in the vanguard of democracy and the rule by law, and not a paradise for criminals on the lam, Wang Tu-fa urged the U.S. government to help repatriate the Wangs to Taiwan.
The TAUP members had one small conflict with police, however, the protest ended peacefully after AIT officials accepted the petition from the professors.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGE ON SHIPYARD GOLIATH CRANE PAINSTAKING: CSBC

TEXT.P: It would be a "painstaking task" for the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) to erase the company's Chinese name and repaint a new one on the huge Goliath crane at the CSBC shipyard, which is the largest of its kind in Southeast Asia, a CSBC official claimed Thursday.

In addition to having to use a "super-high" crane with a man-carrying cage for the name-change job, it would cost at least NT$10 million to have the CSBC's new Chinese name painted on the Goliath bridge crane, CSBC Vice President Wang Ko- hsun claimed.

Despite his complaints, Wang said the name-change idea -- from CSBC to "Taiwan International Shipbuilding Corp." in Chinese -- is generally supported by company management since it is a set government policy and will help avoid confusing the state-run company with a Chinese one.

There will be little change in the company's new English name -- from CSBC to CSBC Taiwan -- out of consideration for the company's convenience in operations in international shipbuilding markets, Wang noted.

Wang said the name-change plan is expected to be passed smoothly at a meeting of CSBC board directors to be held in Taipei Friday. The plan will then be referred to a meeting of CSBC general investors slated for March 1 for final approval.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs also announced last month a plan to change the name of the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to "CPC, Taiwan."
The opposition parties have accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party of "ruling the nation with ideology" in a bid to blot out the last vestiges of China's influence from the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT, IMPORT VALUES IN JANUARY GROW BY DOUBLE DIGITS: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export and import values reported double-digit increases in January -- up 17.9 percent and 23.8 percent respectively, from the same period last year -- to record levels of US$19.85 billion (NT$655.6 billion), and US$17.96 billion, an official from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Thursday.
This gave Taiwan a trade surplus of US$1.89 billion, Lee Li-shu, chief statistician at the MOF, noted.
However, both exports and imports are likely to see negative growth in February, owing to the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday, Lee pointed out.
January's export value was the second highest single-month value after last September's US$20.1 billion, while the import value was the third highest, Lee said.

In addition, the import of consumer products hit a new high for a single month at US$1.52 billion, marking a strong contrast with the negative 2.3 percent growth rate for the entire 2006, Lee pointed out.

Kung Ming-hsin, vice president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) , attributed the strong performance of imports and exports in January to the favorable international economic climate.

Kung explained that the United States reported higher economic growth in the fourth quarter than was widely expected, and oil prices have not been skyrocketing, which have contributed to Taiwan's economic growth.

According to MOF officials, January saw a high rise in the number of passenger cars imported. At the same time, the import of vehicles with engines between 1500cc and 2500cc grew by 139.1 percent, while those 3000cc and above was up 66 percent, they added.
Meanwhile, there was also a noticeable growth in the import of medicine, tobacco and liquor, as well as cosmetics, the officials noted.
Officials explained that the lowering of import duties and commodity taxes might have prompted more people to buy cars this year.
On the other hand, Kung said it is likely that many export companies earned profits last year, and therefore rewarded their young employees more year-end bonuses.
As a result, they have begun to purchase cars, and might choose foreign cars over domestically manufactured ones as the price gap between them is narrowing, Kung added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA DRAFTS AMENDMENT TO COMPANY ACT

TEXT.P: According to a government draft amendment to the Company Act, key officials of a company should be discharged if they are convicted of economic crimes in the first instance, economic officials said Wednesday.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) geared up its efforts to amend the Company Act in pursuit of better corporate governance in the wake of the Rebar Group scandal and the ministry held a meeting with academic and businessmen Thursday to exchange views.

According to the MOEA draft, board directors, supervisors and managers of a company are subject to discharge if they are found guilty of economic crimes in the first instance -- a clause harsher than the current stipulation, which mostly requires finalization of a conviction for such crimes to lead to a compulsory discharge.

The draft also proposes that the government review applications to establish companies more strictly in order to prevent the practice of setting up several companies with the same capital and conducting false transactions, officials said.

The officials also said that for the sake of the board directors' autonomy, the law will no longer allow representatives of legal person shareholdings to serve as both director and supervisor of a company at the same time.
Companies that involve "public interest" or whose shareholders or capitalization reach a certain amount will be required to go public under the amended law, officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DREAMS OF DPP FAILURE TO BE DISAPPOINTED: MAC HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/08/07 20:48:38 (By Flor Wang) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Beijing would certainly be disappointed if it expects Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to fail in the 2008 presidential election, Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said here Wednesday.
Wu, who is currently visiting the United States, made the comments at the Twin-Oaks Garden during a meeting with Chinese-language media.

Quoting some U.S. think tank members who recently visited China, Wu said that ranking Beijing officials displayed obvious reluctance to see the DPP once again win in Taiwan's upcoming presidential election.
However, Wu pointed out that Beijing seems to have become more mature in handling its relations with Taiwan's democratization.

For instance, he said, Beijing did not halt its negotiations with Taiwan on opening special cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights last year when the opposition "pan-blue alliance" mobilized to launch a recall vote against President Chen Shui-bian nor when the mayoral elections were held in Taipei and Kaohsiung last December.

"I prefer to assume that Beijing would observe Taiwan's future elections, including December's legislative elections and the March 2008 presidential election, with a more mature attitude, " the MAC chief said, adding that "otherwise, it will be upset again, just as it was in 2000 and 2004."

In a keynote speech delivered during a visit earlier the same day to the Center for Strategic and International Studies, Wu said that Beijing seems to have eased its policies toward Taiwan in some fields, such as agreeing to launch cross-strait charter flights on major festivals and for humanitarian purposes and allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, while flexing its muscle in other areas, including further squeezing Taiwan's international space and continuing its military buildup aimed at Taiwan.
Wu expressed concern that negative developments in cross-strait relations will eliminate positive elements in bilateral interactions.
He also forecast that two-way exchanges could slow down due to major political events that are set to evolve in the second half of this year, both in Taiwan and China. ENDITEM/jnc

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Copter Crashes Suggest Shift in Iraqi Tactics
With two more helicopter crashes near Baghdad, including a Marine transport crash on Wednesday that killed seven people, the number of helicopters that have gone down in Iraq over the past three weeks rose to six. American officials say the streak strongly suggests that insurgents have adapted their tactics and are now putting more effort into shooting down the aircraft.
Wall Street Journal: Political Hazard: Candidates Bilked By Their Treasurers
Florida Republican Nancy Detert had two days to register her candidacy for Congress last April when she got a disturbing email from her secretary : Ms. Detert's campaign treasurer was missing.
Nancy Detert's treasurer went missing with most of her campaign funds during her Florida congressional race. What happened isn't uncommon because candidates trust friends to handle their money and don't look too carefully at their work.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU MAYOR INTRODUCES GLASS MUSEUM TO EUROPEAN TV REPORTER

TEXT.P: Hsinchu Mayor Lin Jung-tse introduced the Hsinchu Municipal Glass Museum in the northern city Thursday to a reporter from a European cable TV channel visiting to do a segment on Taiwan.
EuroNews journalist Margitta Kirstaedter was also scheduled to cover the National Palace Museum, the official noted.

Lin received the journalist with the city's Bureau of Cultural Affairs Deputy Director-General Lin Rong-chou, Glassman Society Chairwoman Huang Bao-shue, and Hsinchu Wind City Glass Artist Association Chairman Hsu Yuan-rong.
Lin Jung-tse explained that in earlier times, the glass craft in the city was limited to industrial glass production.
Nowadays, however, the craft has transformed into an artform, he said.

EuroNews is a European cable television network broadcasting to 189 million households in 121 countries every day in seven languages -- French, English, German, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese and Russian.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SIGNS MOU WITH NAURU ON LABOR COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lee Ying-yuan and visiting Nauru President Ludwig Scotty signed a memorandum of understanding(MOU) in Taipei Thursday on cooperation in labor affairs to pave the way for future imports of Nauruan workers to Taiwan, a CLA official said later that same day.

Chen Yi-min, chief of the CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training, said both sides will comply with the memorandum to work out technical details for future labor cooperation, including labor import processing units, medical places and recruitment procedures. Taiwan will start recruiting Nauruan workers after related measures and policies are settled.

Nauru will be the seventh country to provide foreign laborers to Taiwan after Thailand, Vietnam, the Philippines, Indonesia, Mongolia and Malaysia. President Scotty arrived Taiwan for a five-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSUEHSHAN TUNNEL TO BE OPENED TO LARGE PASSENGER VEHICLES

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei said Thursday the ministry plans to open the Hsuehshan tunnel linking Taipei and Yilan counties to large passenger vehicles in June to mark the anniversary of the tunnel's formal opening June 16, 2006.

During an inspection tour in Yilan County, Tsai said his ministry will honor its promise to open the tunnel to large passenger vehicles on the first anniversary of its opening to cars, since the traffic situation has been smooth.

The Hsuehshan tunnel, the most difficult part in the construction of the 54.3-km Peiyi Freeway, is the longest highway tunnel in East Asia and the fifth-longest in the world. It was opened to traffic June 16 last year after 15 years of construction.
As the tunnel is only open to small cars, Yilan residents have been urging the government to open it soon to large passenger vehicles to further boost tourism in Yilan.
According to Tsai, the ministry is planning supplementary rescue measures to cope with possible accidents in the tunnel in preparation for the opening.
Meanwhile, Yilan County Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua instructed related agencies to adopt countermeasures in advance of the possible swarm of tourists from around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRITERIA FOR H.K., MACAU STUDENTS STUDYING IN TAIWAN RELAXED

TEXT.P: Criteria for students from Hong Kong and Macau applying to study in Taiwan have been further relaxed in a bid to allow more young people from these two areas to receive education in Taiwan, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Thursday.

The relaxed regulations -- which went into effect this month -- allow Hong Kong or Macau citizens who have lived there for six consecutive years to apply to study in Taiwan. Previously, the criterion was eight years, said Lin Shu-chen, executive secretary of the MOE's Mainland Affairs Task Force.

Lin, however, pointed out that the eight-year-residence criterion is still required under the new regulations for Hong Kong or Macau applicants wishing to study medicine, dentistry and traditional Chinese medicine in Taiwan's colleges and universities.

The new regulations also allow Hong Kong or Macau youths who have finished junior high school education in Taiwan to attend Taiwan vocational senior high schools or five-year junior colleges without having to pass entrance exams.
According to Lin, Taiwan's colleges and universities reserve up to 10 percent of their enrollments for overseas Chinese or Taiwanese descendants and students from Hong Kong or Macau.
Taiwan received 154 freshmen students from Hong Kong and 513 from Macau in the 2005 academic year, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COORDINATION AMONG DPP HOPEFULS WILL BE SMOOTH IF TIMING RIPE

TEXT.P: Coordination among the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential hopefuls will only be smooth if the timing is ripe, President Chen Shui-bian's top aide said Thursday.

Chiou I-jen, secretary-general to the president, made the remarks amid reports that four DPP heavyweights -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- are jockeying for party nomination in the runup to the party primaries in May.
Noting that some DPP officials are hoping that Chen will intervene to smooth out difficulties in nominating a presidential candidate, Chiou said nothing should be done in haste.
"We can't rush the matter. When the timing is ripe, the coordination will go smoothly," he said.

He also claimed that if coordination is needed, it means that the party's primary mechanism in which public opinion polls will account for 70 percent and party member vote will account for the remaining 30 percent will not work.
It also means that the result of the coordination must be "accepted willingly by every aspirant," he claimed.

DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said party members at the grassroots level have generally expressed the hope that Su and Hsieh will form a ticket and the party has not ruled out the possibility of suggesting that Chen tout coordination this Saturday at a spring gathering to which elected DPP officials and the party's Central Standing Committee have been invited.

Yeh made the remarks after DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun proposed removing the guards stationed at late President Chiang Kai-shek's temporary mausoleum in northern Taiwan Taoyuan, which was widely seen as a move by Yu to cater to the wishes of hard-core supporters of the "pan-green camp" led by the DPP to facilitate his bid for DPP Presidential candidacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAWMAKER TO RESIGN OVER CORRUPTION CHARGES

TEXT.P: Legislator Huang Cheng-che of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is to resign following his indictment over his suspected role in a highway construction scandal, a TSU official said Thursday.
Chuang Po-lin, a member of the TSU Central Advisory Committee, made the remarks after hour-long talks with Huang earlier in the day.
According to Chuang, Huang agreed to resign from his at-large legislative post before the new legislative session formally opens later this month.

Huang was indicted last November on charges of corruption, breach of trust and fraud in a scandal involving construction of roads linking the Taiwan high-speed railway's Shalun station in southern Tainan County to neighboring townships and cities.
Chuang said the legislative seat to be vacated by Huang's resignation will be filled by Lin Chih-chia, the TSU's incumbent secretary-general. The party controls 12 seats in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN WILL TENDER RESIGNATION IF INDICTED: PARTY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will definitely tender his resignation to the party's Central Standing Committee if indicted on embezzlement charges related to his alleged misuse of special municipal funds during his tenure as Taipei mayor, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said Thursday.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan news conference, Wu said Ma will offer to resign if he is indicted. "The party's Central Standing Committee will respond to such a drastic development in line with its existing mechanisms, " he said, adding that "the party is not considering a bailout plan for such a scenario."

Wu's comments came after the People First Party (PFP), an ally of the KMT in the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " proposed earlier in the day that the two parties should jointly nominate a presidential candidate for the 2008 election based upon their new but closer KMT-PFP alliance.

Wu thanked the PFP for its concern and suggestion but insisted that the KMT has not worked out any package to deal with the situation in the event of Ma's indictment. The former mayor is widely viewed as the most eligible "pan-blue" candidate in the 2008 president poll.

Meanwhile, it was reported that the prosecution had concluded its probe into the case of Ma's alleged embezzlement and is set to indict the former Taipei mayor in the coming days. The KMT has reportedly been planning to revise its clauses to secure Ma's right to participate in the next presidential race or allow him to run as an independent even if he is indicted.
According to PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung, the two proposals are bad ideas that would doom Ma's chances in the race, as both alternatives will significantly taint Ma's moral reputation as "Mr. Clean."

Liu said the best chance of victory in the 2008 presidential election is for the two "pan-blue" parties to jointly field a candidate who stands the best chance of success. By so doing, Liu said, Ma would not necessarily be nominated, as other hopefuls could also join the race for nomination. But given Ma's popularity with grassroots pan-blue supporters, Liu said, Ma stands a good chance of winning the primary through this process while avoiding damaging unity within the "pan-blue" alliance.

"As long as Ma enjoys widespread grassroots support, the best way to bail out Ma is through the joint nomination mechanism of the new KMT-PFP alliance, " Liu argued, adding that he believes PFP Chairman James Soong will also fully back Ma in the 2008 presidential race if Ma is truely nominated by the alliance.
He urged the KMT to quickly come out with countermeasures to settle the issue as Ma enjoys very strong support among "pan-blue" voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: WARM-UP ACTIVITIES FOR KAOHSIUNG PUPPET THEATER FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: A warm-up took place in southern Kaohsiung County's Fengshan City Thursday for the upcoming "2007 Global Puppet Theater Festival and Doll's World" slated to start Feb. 10 at the Wei-Wu-Ying Cultural Center, according to a county government official.
Representatives of the participating groups paraded through the city before arriving at the cultural center.

Kaohsiung Magistrate Young Chiou-hsing said the puppet festival provides a platform for puppet show troupes from different countries to have dialogue and cultural exchanges and he invited people from northern Taiwan to attend the festival by taking the high speed railway.

The festival includes 10 theme parks and brings together puppet theater troupes and dolls from many countries including France, Ireland, Italy, America, Brazil, Indonesia, and India, in addition to Taiwanese traditional puppet shows, shadow plays and marionette shows for a total of 42 performances.

The festival is scheduled to run Feb. 10-March 4, except for Feb. 17, which is Chinese New Year's Eve. Kaohsiung County residents get discounts on ticket prices, while the disabled and elderly get free entry. The first 2,007 people to attend on the first day with their own dolls, art toys or puppets will also get free entry, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO ASSOCIATE `NAME-CHANGE' DRIVE WITH CHANGING NATION'S NAME

TEXT.P: There is "no need" to associate the current name-change drive with the changing of the nation's official name, President Chen Shui-bian's top aide said Thursday.

Chiou I-jen, secretary-general to the president, made the remarks after Chen expressed his stance of supporting the drive to change the names of state-owned companies and suggested that the name of Chunghwa Post Co. be changed to Taiwan Post in his online newsletter published earlier that day.

Chiou pointed out that "the assessment of the name-changes has been going on for quite a long time, although the ball only started rolling recently, so that the public might think the government only thought about promoting the matter recently."
Chen first floated the name-change drive in 2004 to avoid Taiwan enterprises being mistaken for Chinese companies.
But he also said the scope of the changes will be left to the discretion of the state-owned enterprises.
Chiou claimed there is no need to associate the name-changes with the changing of the nation's official name, which the president promised not to do in his inaugural addresses in 2000 and 2004.
He said the "plight of Taiwan lies in the fact that it can't change its official name but also can't have its official name recognized by the international community."
"Under the circumstances, the current name-change move is the only resort we have if we want our enterprises to enter the international community," he said.

He noted that there is a China Steel Corp. based in Taiwan and a Chinese company bearing similar name, which could be confusing if both were to be members of the International Iron and Steel Institute, adding that China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) have the same problem, although the Ministry of Economic Affairs said recently it plans to change these to "CSBC, Taiwan" and "CPC, Taiwan" to underscore that they are Taiwan businesses.
Asked whether Taiwan's central bank -- the Central Bank of China (CBC) -- should also change its name, Chiou said this would be best.
But as the CBC takes part in a great many international financial organizations, the CBC and the Executive Yuan will have to assess the scope of any change, he added.

Asked if the president supports "the stance of ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun's drive to obliterate the last vestiges of the authoritarian rule of the late President Chiang Kai-shek," Chiou said that "there is nothing to oppose."

"The blotting out of Chiang's last vestiges in Taiwan is a substantial move under a big concept," he said, adding that emerging democratic countries have shown the same tendencies in cutting all lingering influences of the past authoritarian rule.

Yu has accused Chiang of being the culprit responsible for the 2-28 incident of 1947, in which Chiang's Nationalist government sent troops to crush a revolt in Taiwan, resulting in the deaths of thousands, and proposed that the guards stationed at Chiang's temporary mausoleum in northern Taiwan be removed.

DOC.HEADLINE: POST OFFICE TO CHANGE NAME

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Post Co., the state-owned postal service, will change its name Friday to show its Taiwan identity in a wave of name changes among state enterprises.

The word "Chunghwa" means China. A new Chinese name translated as "Taiwan Post Co." will be applied after a board meeting Friday passes the proposal, although an official English name has yet to be decided, company officials said Thursday.

Chunghwa released Thursday a position paper and said the change of its title is actually a restoration with historical significance, because Taiwan's postal service was first named Taiwan Post Administration when founded in 1888 by Liu Ming-chuan, the first Governor of Taiwan appointed by China's Ching Dynasty.

The position paper denies claims that a change of name can only be legal if the legislature amends the law governing the service's establishment, pointing out that as a company it can change its name upon a resolution by its board of directors.
Not everyone in the company was happy with the change and union Chairman Tsai Liang-chuan said he will lead colleagues in a protest at the board meeting Friday.
We don't see any good the name change can bring to the company's business, he said, adding that "it's regrettable for the name-changing of state enterprises to be used for political purposes."
Lai Ching-chi, chairman of Chunghwa Post, said a new signboard will be in place as soon as Monday.
He said the cost of the change won't be as much as some have claimed, estimating it to be around NT$67 million. "Old signboards are scheduled to be replaced anyway," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALACE MUSEUM EMBODIES TAIWAN'S COMMITMENT TO DIVERSITY OF CULTURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the National Palace Museum symbolizes Taiwan's commitment to promoting cultural diversity.
Chen made the remarks while presiding over the inauguration of the museum's newly renovated main exhibition hall.

Saying that the overhaul project manifests the government's determination to build a modern museum based around its ancient Chinese art collection, Chen said the inauguration of the Palace Museum main hall will give history a new twist.

The National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei houses the world's most famous collection of ancient Chinese artworks. It is often compared to leading Western museums like the Louvre in Paris and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
The three-year renovation project has given the old museum a brand new face and new spirit, Chen said, adding that the museum will from now on handle art collection in a broader vision.

According to Chen, the museum's future art collection will reflect "love for Taiwan and vision on globalization." Noting that the museum's Chinese art treasures are invaluable world cultural heritage, Chen said the government will continue sparing no effort to preserve and glorify them.

Nevertheless, Chen said, the museum should also endeavor to expand the scope of its art collection to realize its ambitious goal of becoming the world's top- notch cultural institution with diversified artworks in its possession.

Chen also mentioned his administration's plan to build a new museum in Taipao in southern Chiayi County to be the Palace Museum's branch facility which will focus on displaying Asian artworks and cultural heritages. The southern branch will demonstrate Taiwan people's vision and passion for arts, cultures and lifestyles in neighboring Asian countries, he added.

Over the past three years, almost two-thirds of the National Palace Museum building was closed for the renovation project. Following the overhaul, heroic statutes of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and of Sun Yat-sen, the founding father of the Republic of China have been removed, while new lighting, air- conditioning, climate-controlled storage vaults and other features of the renovated institution rival the newest museums in the West.

Many dignitaries, including Premier Su Tseng-chang, museum curators from home and abroad, members of the Taipei Diplomatic Corps, scholars, experts and business executives, attended the reopening reception.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEBRUARY 9 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Feb. 9
09:00, High-ranking central government officials will take part in a training program for implementation of the much-touted "Mega Investment, Mega Warmth" projects.
10:30, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a memorial service commemorating "Asian Iron Man" Yang Chuang-kuang.
11:00, President Chen will receive foreign delegates who have come to Taipei to attend the reopening ceremony of the National Palace Museum's newly renovated main building.
15:00, President Chen will receive family members of vistims of the 228 Incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 9, or the 22nd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1775: Hostilities between Britain and the American colony of Massachusetts become imminent as the British Parliament announces the state is in rebellion and approves new laws to control the situation.
1799: The U.S. Navy draws first blood in a war with France.
1801: France signs the Peace of Luneville with Austria, dissolving the Holy Roman Empire.
1825: John Quincy Adams, an American politician who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine and who advocated antislavery measures, is elected the sixth president of the United States, defeating Andrew Jackson.
1830: Explorer Charles Stuart discovers the source of Australia's longest river, the Murray.
1881: Feodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski, Russian writer who wrote such great novels as "Crime and Punishment," "The Idiot," "The Possessed," and "The Brother Karamazov," dies at the age of 60.
1899: The Boxer Uprising breaks out in China. Sparked by popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by unequal treaties, the boxers lay siege to the foreign legion in Peking, where a combined force of Japanese, French, British, Russians, and American troops held out for over a month.
1921: The Living Buddha of Outer Mongolia proclaims "independence" after Mongolian and Russian communists gain control of Outer Mongolia. They established the Mongolian People's Republic in 1924, after the Living Buddha died.
1942: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek visits India after assuming office as supreme commander of the China Theater of War on Jan. 2, 1942.
1945: Mia Farrow, the American actress who first made her name in the television series Peyton Place and went on to make many films, notably comedies with Wooden Allen, is born.
1955: The U.S. Senate approves the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty by a vote 64-6.
1957: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China advocates independence for the Ryukyus. China and Japan both claimed the Ryukyus until 1874, when the Ching court signed a treaty recognizing Japanese rule. After Japan's defeat in World War II, the U.S. took over the Ryukyus. In 1953, the U.S. returned the islands north of Okinawa to Japan. Okinawa and the southern Ryukyus were returned in 1972.
1962: The Taiwan Stocks Exchange formally begins operations.
1964: Beatlemania hits the United States as 73 million Americans watch four lads from Liverpool appear on the Ed Sullivan Show.
1973: H.E. Hisham Muhiuddin Nazer, state minister of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Six winners of the Second Cathay Children's Music Contest leave Taipei for Hong Kong to attend the Arts Festival.
1981: General Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's defense minister, becomes prime minister and chief of the Polish Communist Party.
1993: President Francois Mitterrand visits Vietnam, ending Vietnam's isolation in the international community. He was the first Western head of state to visit the communist country since 1966.
1994: President Lee Teng-hui leaves for the Philippines, Indonesia, and Thailand on an eight-day visit.
1999: A 352-page collection of news photographs depicting historic moments in ROC diplomacy over the past six decades is published by the Central News Agency, which was founded in 1924.
1999: The Republic of the Marshall Islands opens an embassy in the Republic of China, heralding a new era in relations between the two countries.
2000: The Taiwan Stock Exchange performs well on the first trading session after the Chinese New Year holiday, with the market's weighted price index breaking the 10,000 point level at the close.
2001: Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Deputy Director-General Francis K.H. Liang, leaves Taipei for Beijing to attend a senior officials meeting of the Asia- Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Why should one be too severe? When a man reforms and comes to me for advice, I accept his present reformation without inquiring what his past life has been. I am satisfied if I find that, for the present, he has really reformed, without being able to guarantee that he will not relapse again. But why should one be too severe?"

DOC.HEADLINE: 52 IDLE PUBLIC FACILITIES REVITALIZED: PCC CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Public Construction Commission (PCC) has successfully assisted local governments in reviving 52 idle public facilities around the country over the past couple of years, a senior official said Friday.
All of these revitalized public facilities were originally built for a total cost of NT$13.78 billion (US$417.58 million) , PCC Chairman Wu Tze-cheng said.
According to Wu, 96 idle or underused public facilities are still listed for revitalization, redevelopment or demolition.

To show the government's determination to resolve the issue and save public funds, Wu said, Premier Su Tseng-chang has instructed the PCC to further review all the listed facilities to determine whether they should be redeveloped. "The premier is not opposed to the demolition of those facilities for which redevelopment is not warranted," he added.

Claiming that many idle or underused public facilities were by-products of election politics, Wu said the facilities were mostly built for the sake of winning voter support in elections without making any "down-to-earth" evaluation of practical market demand.

Citing the example of the construction of parking lots in each township or village, Wu said many of the parking facilities have been left idle or underused as local governments have never seriously cracked down on parking violations.

"Local governments' inefficient management of public facilities has not only resulted in a waste of public resources but has also affected local people's confidence and trust in the central government," Wu said.

Noting that the Executive Yuan has formed a special task force to review the feasibility of redeveloping or transforming idle public facilities, Wu said that if possible, private operators will be introduced to manage idle parking lots, swimming pools, exhibition halls and other public facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA CHIEF INDICTED OVER AIRPORT NOISE INSULATION SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Chang Kuo-cheng, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) , has been indicted on corruption charges for his suspected role in a Taoyuan International Airport noise insulation subsidies scandal.

The Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office indicted Chang and 28 other CAA and airport officials as well as borough and village chiefs in northern Taoyuan County Thursday after more than two years of investigations into the case.
Prosecutors are seeking a seven-year prison sentence for Chang, who was released on NT$1 million bail after being questioned regarding the case last year.

The scandal involving noise insulation subsidies for residents in the vicinity of the Taoyuan International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, broke in May 2004 after prosecution authorities received tip-offs that many subsidy recipients did not use the money to install air-conditioners as soundproofing.

Subsequent prosecutorial investigations showed that some households managed to claim soundproofing subsidies even after they had relocated to other areas, while many other households used fake pictures to mislead transportation ministry officials into believing that their homes had been equipped with air- conditioners to qualify for soundproofing subsidies even though they had not.

As residents could apply for subsidies by just producing pictures showing their homes were equipped with air-conditioners, the indictment said some air- conditioner suppliers assisted residents in faking pictures through introductions by borough or village chiefs who were given NT$2,000 to NT$4,000 in commission for each such deal.

The indictment said that although the then-Taoyuan Airport Administration's environmental section chief had informed his superiors of possible irregularities or profiteering practices in the process, Chang shut his eyes to the warning and continued the practice of requiring residents to just produce pictures to receive soundproofing subsidies.
According to the indictment, the scandal caused a huge waste of taxpayer's money.
Chang's deputy Wang Teh-ho and CAA Chief Secretary Wei Sheng-chih were also indicted on corruption charges, with prosecutors recommending a six-year prison sentence for each of them.
Seven Taoyuan Airport Administration officials, including Deputy Director Liu Chuang-sheng, were also indicted on similar charges. Prosecutors are seeking a 12-year prison sentence for Liu.
Prosecutors also indicted a number of former and incumbent village and borough chiefs and are seeking eight-year prison sentences for each of them.
As to residents who had claimed noise insulation subsidies without actually installing soundproofing equipment, prosecutors said they will be indicted later on charges of fraud.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TAIWAN RELIES ON JUDICIAL CO-OP PACTS FOR APPREHENDING FUGITIVES
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 8 (CNA) 02/09/07 13:06:51 (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Since Taiwan is not a member of the International Criminal Police Organization (Interpol) , the largest worldwide body established to assist international criminal police cooperation, Taiwan can only rely on bilateral judicial cooperation pacts for apprehending criminals who have fled the country.

An Interpol spokesman said during a telephone interview with the CNA that the fact that Taiwan cannot seek Interpol assistance to extradite fugitive Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder Wang You-theng from overseas epitomizes the difficulties that Taiwan has faced in trying to apprehend criminals on the lam.

Interpol is the world's third largest international organization, after the United Nations and FIFA, with 186 member countries and an annual contributions of about US$41.7 million from its member countries. The Lyon, France- headquartered organization's work focuses primarily on public safety, terrorism, organized crime, war crimes, illicit drug production, drug trafficking, weapons smuggling, trafficking in human beings, money laundering, child pornography, white-collar crime, high-tech crime and corruption.

Wang, who was taken into custody by U.S. immigration authorities at the beginning of February for traveling without valid travel documents, was put on Taiwan's list of most wanted fugitives after fleeing the country with his wife in early January.
The tycoon is wanted by Taiwanese authorities for his suspected involvement in a series of crimes, including forgery, fraud, insider trading, and embezzlement of corporate funds from his group.
The U.S. government has been asked by Taiwan law enforcement authorities to help extradite the Wangs as the two countries maintain a judicial cooperation pact.

Fifty-one people related to the Rebar scandal have been probed as suspects, 13 of whom have been detained. The number of people related to the case barred from leaving the country has increased to 91.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND AWAITS INSTRUCTIONS ON HANDLING OF LATE PRESIDENTS' MAUSOLEUMS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has not received any instructions from the Cabinet with regard to disbanding an office in charge of maintaining the mausoleums of the late Presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo, a ministry official said Friday.

Huang Yi-ping, deputy chief of the general staff for personnel, said that basically, the office will only be disbanded after the Chiang family has agreed to and completed the removal of the late presidents' remains from the mausoleums for permanent burial.
However, if any instructions are received from the Cabinet on the disbandment of the office, the ministry will assess the feasibility of doing so, Huang said.
Huang made the remarks during a public hearing on the issue held by several opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators led by John Chiang, son of Chiang Ching- kuo.

On Tuesday, a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators requested that the Cabinet make an announcement by Feb. 28 to disband the mausoleum maintenance office under the MND and scrap the budget for the maintenance of the mausoleums located in Taoyuan County's Tzuhu and Touliao, respectively, where the two late presidents' remains are temporarily interred.

Pointing out that the government has prepared new tombs for the two late presidents at Taipei County's Wuchihshan Military Cemetery, the legislators said the Chiang family should make a decision by Feb. 28 on whether to remove the remains of the two late presidents.

They argued that it lacks any legal basis and is a waste of taxpayers' money for the government to earmark a budget of more than NT$70 million per year to maintain the mausoleums, including the personnel expenses for 35 staff, 70 military police and 24 honor guards posted at the facilities.

The proposal to disband the mausoleum maintenance office is among a series of measures put forth by the DPP recently to "eliminate the remnants of authoritarian rule" associated with Chiang Kai-shek -- whom the DPP claims was the key perpetrator behind the 228 Incident of 1947 in which thousands of people were massacred by KMT troops in suppression of a rebellion against KMT rule in Taiwan.
Also Friday, John Chiang said he will take legal action against DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun if he does not apologize within one week for the claim.
He alleged that although the DPP claims it is against authoritarianism, the party is turning itself into a "Nazist" party under Yu's leadership.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA POST LABOR UNION RESISTS COMPANY NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: Members of the labor union of Chunghwa Post Co. resisted Friday a plan to have the state-owned postal service's name changed and blockaded the office of Chunghwa Post chairman to bar him from attending a board meeting aimed at endorsing the name change plan.
Unable to attend the meeting, Chunghwa Post Chairman Lai Chin-chi called Chunghwa Post President Wu Min-you to convene the meeting at another location.
Labor union members burst into the meeting room and disrupted the meeting, causing Wu to call the police in to maintain order.
Meanwhile, Lai managed to escape from his office and attended the meeting as the standoff came to an end and the police pulled back from the scene.

At the meeting, Lai stressed that the change of the company's name is actually a restoration with historical significance because Taiwan's postal service was first named Taiwan Post Administration when founded in 1888 by Liu Ming-chuan, the first Governor of Taiwan appointed by the Ching Court

Union leader Tsai Liang-chuan argued that the union sees nothing good about changing the name of the company in terms of increasing its business, adding that it's regrettable that the issue of changing the names of state enterprises is being used for political purposes.
Tsai claimed that the name change will probably make Chunghwa Post a fully privatized company overnight without the workers' interests being protected.
Tsai also lambasted Chunghwa Post Chairman Lai for initiating the name change drive and implementing the plan without consulting anybody or notifying any of the company's workers in advance.
Chunghwa Post Co. said it was planning to change its name Friday to show its Taiwan identity in a wave of name changes among state enterprises.

The word "Chunghwa" means China. A new Chinese name translated as "Taiwan Post Co." will be applied after Friday's board meeting passes the proposal, although an official English name has yet to be decided upon, company officials said Thursday.
Lai said a new signboard with the new name will be in place as soon as Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CONFUSING' ROC NAME SHOULD BE CHANGED: EXAMINATION YUAN HEAD

TEXT.P: The country's designation -- the Republic of China -- should be changed, as it is confused with China's formal name and "fails to reflect Taiwan's historic truth," Examination Yuan President Yao China-wen claimed Friday.

Speaking at a colloquium on Taiwan's historic status and future diplomatic strategy, Yao, a well-known Taiwan independence advocate, said the country of Taiwan -- whose official name is the Republic of China -- is not the same country that uses the same designation whose capital had been in Peking, Nanking and Chungching prior to 1949, nor the regime currently ruling China, whose formal name is the People's Republic of China.

Claiming that the Republic of China is "too easy to be confused" in the international community with the People's Republic of China, Yao said a national name change as President Chen Shui-bian has championed recently is "a must" for the country.

According to Yao, the Taiwan people have been given too many "distorted facts and untrue concepts" by the former Kuomintang government, leading some of the country's people to have the wrong perceptions about Taiwan's history and its status in the international community.
The colloquium was sponsored by the Taiwan International Studies Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-WEEK NATIONAL CLEAN-UP CAMPAIGN TO KICK OFF SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will launch a one-week national "clean-up" campaign Saturday ahead of Chinese New Year, one of the most important annual festivals in Taiwan.

The clean-up campaign, slated for Feb. 10-16, is designed around the traditional notion of sweeping the old away to make way for the new, EPA officials said Friday. It is a custom in Chinese society to clean up the home in preparation for the Lunar New Year, which falls on Feb. 18 this year.

During the clean-up campaign, people can dispose of any large waste items, such as old furniture, at designated sites at specific times regulated by local governments for recycling, according to the EPA.

While cleaning up indoors, people should check for any possible breeding spots for disease-carrying mosquitoes in or around their homes, the EPA officials suggested. They also reminding people to clean up the public area within four meters around their homes, including road surfaces and gullies, as stipulated by the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 17.31 points to close at 7,859.53.
The bourse opened at 7,847.18 and fluctuated between 7,884.55 and 7,822.53 during trading. A total of 3.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$97.2 billion (US$2.95 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and paper and pulp issues both at 1.6 percent, textile stocks at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 622 to 547, with 221 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS F-16 FIGHTERS TO COUNTER CHINA'S MILITARY THREAT: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 8 (CNA) 02/09/07 16:32:39 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official urged the United States Thursday to approve the sale of new F-16 fighter aircraft to Taiwan, saying Taiwan needs to acquire the aircraft to beef up its ability to defend itself against China's military threat.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks during an interview with U.S. cable television station C-span, in the wake of a Defense News report that the Bush administration has refused to sell 66 F-16 C/D fighter aircraft requested by Taiwan because Washington is unhappy with Taiwan's delay in its procurement of diesel-electric submarines, P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries from the United States.
Wu noted that the production of J-10A fighter aircraft by China has significantly upgraded China's air force and directly threatens the security of Taiwan.

With China continuing to expand its military deployments targeting Taiwan, the number of short-range ballistic missiles deployed by China along its coast opposite Taiwan has increased from several hundred to more than 1,000, Wu said.
In addition, Wu said the number of submarines owned by China is far larger than its actual demand, which he said is evidence of China's intention to launch a naval blockade of Taiwan.

Wu said that not only Taiwan but also other countries in East Asia and even the whole world have also felt China's military ambitions, citing the successful anti-satellite weapons test by China as an example.
Wu admitted that the Bush administration's refusal to sell the F-16 C/D fighter aircraft to Taiwan is related to the delay of the previous arms procurement package.
He said the Legislative Yuan is expected to pass part of the budget for the procurement package in the new legislative session.
Also during the interview, Wu called Washington's attention to the rapid expansion of China's influence in Africa.
In particular, it is a development deserving international concern that China is engaging with countries with poor human rights records such as Sudan and Zimbabwe, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI REP OFFICE PROTESTS OVER BERLIN FILM FESTIVAL NAME GAFFE
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb. 8 (CNA) 02/09/07 16:33:20 (By Lin Yu-li and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Germany protested against the organizer of the 57th Berlin International Film Festival Thursday for continuing to label Taiwan's films in competition as Chinese film products.

In a press release handed to the Berlin film festival organizer, officials of Taiwan's representative office in Germany said the country is proud of being invited to participate in the festival. However, the organizer's labeling of Taiwanese films as "Taiwan, China" has seriously insulted Taiwan's democracy, as the island is a democratic and sovereign country in its own right, while China has never exercised sovereignty over Taiwan.

The officials noted that the festival organizer' move contrasted with those of the organizer of the Cannes Film Festival and the Venice International Film Festival, which introduced Taiwanese films simply as Taiwanese.
The protest letter has obtained the attention of major European media, including Germany's Der Spiegel weekly magazine, which published the whole letter in its online edition.
The weekly magazine noted that the German government adopts a "one China" policy, which means Taiwan can only promote its diplomacy through a representative office rather than an embassy.

A spokesman for the Berlin film festival explained to Der Spiegel that they adopted the German Foreign Ministry's policy of maintaining close relations with Taiwan without recognizing it diplomatically.

Switzerland's Neue Zurcher Zeitung said in its international edition that the fact that the cultural achievements of the most democratic country in Asia has been included in the products of autocratical China reflect the political ignorance of the film festival organizer, and said Taiwan's anger is understandable.
Officials of Taiwan's representative office in Germany said it was not the first time that the organizer of Berlin film festival had labeled Taiwan as "Taiwan, China."
Last year, Taiwanese officials also protested against the label, which resulted later in a correction by the film festival organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up 14 points to close at 7,884, with 32,858 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March gained 17 points to finish at 7,895, with 3,570 contracts traded, while June futures increased 25 points to close at 7,884, with 27 contract transactions. September futures remained unchanged to close at 7,700, with 42 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 16 points to finish at 7,714, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,870 for February, 7,878 for March, 7,859 for June, 7,700 for September and 7,698 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

February TE futures dropped 0.05 points to close at 334.4, with 2,792 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved down 0.3 points to finish at 334.3, with 192 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 0.95 points to close at 332.45, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

February TF futures gained 2.2 points to close at 1,053, with 1,777 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 3.2 points to close at 1,057.2, with 240 contracts traded. June TF futures increased 3.2 points to finish at 1,057, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOG BREEDERS SIGN SELF-DISCIPLINE CONVENTION

TEXT.P: Hog breeders around Taiwan signed a self-discipline convention Friday as a pledge to provide consumers with pork from healthy hogs amid the public's shunning of pork and processed pork products out of food safety concerns in the wake of reports of meat from sick and dead hogs being sold in local markets.
Pork sales have been affected countrywide since police cracked down on illicit trading of diseased and dead hogs in central and southern Taiwan in early February.

News reports have said the illicit sales of substandard pork from sick and dead hogs have been going on for many years, with buyers including vendors at traditional markets, restaurant operators and food processing businesses around Taiwan.

The signing took place at the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture (COA), and was witnessed by COA officials. During the ceremony, representatives of the convention endorsers vowed to deal with the bodies of hogs hit by sudden death through a certified process from delivery to cremation or burying.

The signatories also urged local hog breeders to support the practice of applying for life insurance for their livestock as part of efforts to stem illicit trading of sick and dead hogs, while suggesting that judicial authorities impose more severe punishment on illegal slaughterhouse operators and meat transporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP, PREMIER CALL FOR SUPPORT FOR NAME CHANGE CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called Friday for public support for the government's current campaign to change state-owned enterprises' name to avoid confusion with their Chinese counterparts, saying that it is essential to correct "mistakes left by history."
Lu made the comments while answering questions from reporters before attending a seminar on Taiwan's historical standing and its foreign policy.

Quoting President Chen Shui-bian's stated resolve to make Taiwan a complete, normal and great nation, Lu said that the public should back the government's efforts to "correct the historical mistake in a piecemeal fashion" by taking out the words "China" or "Chinese" from the names of state-run companies in the initial stage.

Despite Chen promised in his 2000 and 2004 inaugural speeches that Taiwan's official title will not be changed during his tenure, Lu said that Taiwan's people should back the government's ongoing name change campaign, which has begun with some state-run companies, such as Chinese Petroleum Corp., China Shipbuilding Corp. and Chunghwa Post.

In response to accusations by opponents that the name change drive will cost the government a fortune to carry out, Lu contended that it is worthwhile to do so and it will help Taiwan gain a solid ground in the international arena over the long term.
The name change campaign is "not an ideological conflict," rather it is an issue that affects national dignity and which requires nationwide efforts to achieve and safeguard, Lu claimed.

The campaign is backed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) but opposed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " with DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun displaying full support for the drive at the party's weekly Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday.
Meanwhile, Premier Su Tseng-chang claimed that the campaign is unlikely to cost the government a fortune and will not affect workers' rights and interests at the state-run companies.
Su appealed for widespread public support for the drive and claimed that the move will help sharpen Taiwan companies' competitiveness by avoiding unnecessary confusion in the world market.
Claiming that the name change campaign should have been carried out long ago, Su promised to implement the mission through due legal process.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH, COA PROMOTE '5 A DAY' DIET

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) and the Council of Agriculture (COA) have been working on the popular "Five a Day" plan to promote a lifestyle of eating at least five servings of vegetables and fruit per day, a DOH official said Friday.

Cheng Huei-wen, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said the DOH and the COA are promoting the plan by releasing convenience packs containing three vegetables and two fruits in stores such as Carrefours and agricultural product marketing centers, in an effort to make vegetables and fruit easier for consumers to buy.

An investigation by the DOH shows that 96 percent of Taiwanese realize the importance of balanced nutrition, but 80 percent do not eat enough fruit and vegetables, especially those who eat out. The investigation also revealed that convenient buying channels would increase consumption.

Cheng pointed out that insufficient intake of dietary fiber causes constipation and increase the risk of colorectal cancer, chronic and cardiovascular diseases. Consuming at least three servings (about 300 grams) of vegetables and two servings (about 200 grams) of fruit contributes to good health.
The DOH will also call on government authorities, companies and food suppliers to join this plan and encourage the consumption of more vegetables and fruit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUHUA HIGHWAY AT RISK OF `BECOMING DANGEROUS': OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Suhua highway linking Suao and Hualien in eastern Taiwan has become a "dangerous" highway that requires costly maintenance, an Executive Yuan official in charge of public construction works said Friday.

Wu Tze-cheng, chairman of the Public Construction Commission under the Executive Yuan, said the road, which was built alongside steep cliffs, has been eroded by the sea and that it experiences subsidence and rockfalls whenever there is heavy rain.
The highway is dangerous, requires constant maintenance and could "even disappear someday," Wu claimed.

Premier Su Tseng-chang claimed in Hualien early this year that "Hualien residents harbor high expectations" that a Suhua freeway will be built and said that as soon as the project has an environmental difference analysis report ready that will reinforce an earlier environmental impact assessment, construction can start.

An environmental impact assessment on the proposed freeway did pass several years ago, but construction failed to start in the stipulated time because of continued controversy surrounding its construction.
Wu said that after the Chinese New Year holiday it will become clear whether the freeway will be built.
In any case, out of safety considerations as well as the establishment of an islandwide traffic network, another highway linking Suao and Hualien should be built, he said.

Faced with the pros and cons of its construction, Wu said the government should provide more information in a transparent way for the public to make its judgment, including the safety of the present highway, annual maintenance costs, as well as the impact on the environment after its completion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS THREATEN TO GIVE CHUNGHWA POST HARD TIME OVER NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) lawmakers threatened Friday to give Chunghwa Post a hard time should the state-owned postal service insist on changing the company's name without the consent of its staff and the legislature.

PFP Legislator Lee Hung-chun, who doubles as the party's spokesman, said that although Chunghwa Post has changed to corporate operations, it is still a state- owned company subject to Legislative Yuan screening and approval for its annual budget.
Lee warned Chunghwa Post not be so confident over the company name change issue, claiming that the issue's fate is still up to the legislature.

Lee said he agreed with remarks made by Chunghwa Post labor union leader Tsai Liang-chuan earlier in the day in which Tsai argued that the union sees nothing good about changing the name of the company in terms of increasing its business, adding that it is regrettable that the issue of changing the names of state enterprises is being used for political purposes.
Tsai claimed that the name change will probably make Chunghwa Post a fully privatized company overnight without the workers' interests being protected.
He also lambasted Chunghwa Post Chairman Lai Chin-chi for supporting the name change drive and implementing the plan without consulting anybody or notifying any of the company's workers in advance.

Lee said that when the new legislative session begins later this month, the PFP will be instrumental in boycotting Chunghwa Post's budget for the coming year, as a tit-for-tat measure over the name change issue.

Chunghwa Post Co. was planning to change its name Friday to show its Taiwan identity, part of a wave of name changes among state enterprises under a name change campaign advocated by President Chen Shui-bian.

The word "Chunghwa" means China. A new Chinese name translated as "Taiwan Post Co." was planned to be applied after Chunghwa Post's board meeting passed the proposal Friday, although an official English name had yet to be decided upon.

Lee likened the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's name change campaign to the Chinese Cultural Revolution launched by Mao Zedong, claiming that the name change drive is a Taiwan version of a cultural revolution against political foes camouflaged by the advocacy of Taiwan independence.
PFP Legislator Lin Hui-kuan called for Chunghwa Post and the ruling DPP not to play the "magic of names" any longer and instead do something useful to benefit the people.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs also announced last month a plan to change the name of the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to "CPC, Taiwan," and China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) to "CSBC, Taiwan."
The opposition Kuomintang has accused the DPP of "ruling the nation with ideology" in a bid to blot out the last vestiges of China's influence from the country.
