DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD URGES CHINA TO DEVELOP DEMOCRACY TO ATTRACT TAIWAN PEOPLE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 8 (CNA) 02/09/07 18:21:47 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Beijing should speed up its democratization to appeal to the people of Taiwan if it expects Taiwan to unify with China, a Taiwan official said in the U.S. capital Thursday.
According to Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, the government of Taiwan respects its people's choice on whether the country should unify with China or declare independence.
However, the undemocratic practices adopted by China are making unification an increasingly undesirable choice for the Taiwanese people, Wu said.

For example, he said, the Chinese people under Beijing's totalitarian rule enjoy no press, religious or political freedom, and democracy in Hong Kong has regressed after its handover to China from the British colonial government.
In addition, China's relentless suppression of Taiwan in the international community is also abominable to the people of Taiwan, Wu said.

As a consequence, results of various opinion polls indicate that the vast majority of people in Taiwan are opposed to Chinese rule, with more and more people supporting independence for Taiwan, he said.
Wu made the remarks in response to a question on the issue of Taiwan independence after an interview with U.S. cable television station C-SPAN.

Asked about the necessity of Taiwan spending big money on arms procurements, Wu said the purpose of Taiwan's arms procurement is to defend itself from a Chinese invasion, not to attack China, because Taiwan needs to equipped with strong self-defense ability to protect its economic prosperity.
Wu pointed out that China has been building up its military power over recent years, with the number of missiles targeting Taiwan increasing year after year.
While Beijing has continued to upgrade its fighter aircraft, China's submarines have appeared more and more frequently in waters close to Taiwan, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPORTS AUTHORITIES PROMOTE SAILING IN SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei Sailing Association (CTSA) purchased 50 Optimist dinghies Friday with money provided by the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) in an effort to promote the sport of sailing in schools.

The dinghies will be presented to 24 junior high schools and elementary schools in 10 cities and counties around the country, CTSA Chairman Wang Chin-chung said at a press conference marking the purchase.
The association hopes the move will trigger a trend of sailing on campuses and draw the attention of local governments to the promotion of maritime sports, Wang said.
NCPFS officials also attended the press conference.

Optimist dinghy is one of Asian Games' official competition events for athletes aged under 15, and a basic type of small sailing boat, Wang said, indicating that most medal-winning skippers in Asian Games and Olympics were former Optimist sailors.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO STEP IN IF NCC ALLOWS KMT TO SELL RADIO STATION

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will step in if the National Communications Commission (NCC) allows the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to sell its Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) , a spokesman for the Executive Yuan warned Friday.

Cheng Wen-tsang, minister of the Government Information Office (GIO) , said the Executive Yuan has ordered the NCC to instruct the BCC to fulfill its promise to hand back the two radio frequencies it uses and not to sell its property before a lawsuit brought by the Executive Yuan against it is settled.

Although the NCC agreed to relieve the BCC of its obligation to carry out the promises in a settlement in the Taipei High Administrative Court late last year, the Executive Yuan is mulling whether to cancel the settlement after a three-member panel led by Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung determined that the agreement between the NCC and BCC was illegal.
Cheng said Premier Su Tseng-chang has repeatedly instructed the NCC to take back BCC's radio frequencies, thereby foiling the KMT's scheme to sell off its ill- gotten assets.

The BCC, which made the promises in 2004 to the GIO in return for the GIO's renewal of its operating license, asked the court to annul the promises after the KMT sold the company to a private radio operator last year, claiming that the GIO abused its power by coercing it into making the promises.

The NCC, which was founded in 2006 to take over the GIO's business of supervising the country's broadcasting companies, agreed in court to cancel the GIO's requests in return for BCC's withdrawal of a lawsuit asking for government compensation for damages.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ACTING MAYOR LANDS PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE POST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced several major appointments Friday, including that of Chen Chi-mai, a former legislator and former Kaohsiung acting mayor, who will serve as deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.
Chen Chi-mai will fill the vacancy left by Liu Shih-feng, who will take the new post of deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council.
In addition, National Security Council Deputy Secretary-general Wang Hsi-tien will serve as deputy director of the National Security Bureau.

Chen Chi-mai served as acting Kaohsiung mayor in 2005 before resigning to take responsibility for a riot in late August that year by Thai laborers working for Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system to protest against poor treatment and inhumane management.
The appointments will take effect Feb. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUSEUM TO EXCHANGE EXHIBITIONS WITH AUSTRIAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he supports exchanges between Taiwan museums and internationally well-known museums.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Michael Spindelegger, the second president of Austria's parliament, who was in Taipei to attend a ceremony marking the completion of a reconstruction project for the National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei.

Chen said he was glad to see that Austria's art history museum (Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien) will hold an exhibition at the National Palace Museum in October, while several Taiwanese museums, including NPM, will exhibit in Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien next February.

According to Chen, the Quai Branly Museum in Paris, which was established last year under the promotion of France's President Jacques Chirac, also has a collection of treasures of some of Taiwan's aboriginal tribes.
Noting that the NPM is planning to construct a branch in southern Taiwan, Chen expressed gratitude to France's Ecole Francaise d'Extreme-Orient for its help in the planning.
He also expressed hope that France's Guimet Museum, which focuses on collections of art from East Asian countries, will help the NPM in the construction and exhibition affairs of its southern branch.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGES AIMED AT SEPARATION FROM CHINA: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Friday that promoting a name change campaign in the international community is aimed at "proper partition" from China.

Huang said the campaign is a bid to avoid the international community or the nation's allies from mistaking Taiwan for China or vice versa, claiming that it is not out of "ideological concerns, " but "out of pragmatic considerations."
Asked whether the United States has expressed concern over the campaign, Huang said the U.S. had not expressed any views.
He also said that it was not appropriate for him to comment on the matter as it is an internal issue.

He said the "name rectification" issue plagues Taiwan as well as China, citing the examples that when Chinese President Hu Jintao visited the United States last year, the master of the welcoming ceremony announced to play the national anthem of "the Republic of China," instead of "the People's Republic of China."

Also, when Hu recently visited Grenade, an island nation in the southeastern Caribbean Sea, the band played the national anthem of "the Republic of China" instead of the "People's Republic of China," Huang said.
He noted that the campaign is not a new development, saying that it has been in the making over the past two years.
He said Taiwan has communicated with its allies and that currently, Taiwan's embassies have "Taiwan" in parenthesis as part of their names.
Taiwan has continued to coordinate with nations with which it does not maintain diplomatic relations and has made substantial progress, he said without elaborating.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VISITS PREDECESSOR

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou met his predecesor, KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, Friday, stirring up speculation about the meeting at a time when the prosecution authorities are reportedly soon to indict him over embezzlement charges.

Both Ma and Lien were reluctant to answer questions from reporters after their tete-a-tete -- the latest move by Ma after an interview with a newspaper Thursday and a visit to the anti-corruption task force at the Taiwan High Court Prosecutor's Office a day prior to that. The prosecutors have concluded a probe into the case related to Ma's alleged misuse of special municipal fees allocated for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

According to KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih, Ma remained unchanged on his decision to resign from the party chairmanship if he is indicted, but Wu was reserved about the question of whether Ma will take part in future elections for public office if he is indicted.

Although Ma's public approval ratings have recently dropped due to the embezzlement allegations, Wu pointed out that Ma still enjoys a high level of public backing that far exceeds that enjoyed by the various possible presidential aspirants of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
More than half the respondents to several public opinion polls conducted in recent months have expressed support for Ma for president in the 2008 elections, Wu claimed.

According to KMT spokesman Su Chun-pin, Ma and Lien reached an agreement during the meeting that the KMT must be fully united if it wants to secure victory in the next presidential race in the face of the challenge of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Bernard Matthews faces illegal imports inquiry
Bernard Matthews is under investigation by the Government amid concerns that the company has imported poultry from inside an avian flu exclusion zone in Hungary, it emerged last night.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HOLD TALKS ON DRAFT BILL CONCERNING INDUSTRIAL UPGRADING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will hold talks Feb. 13 with representatives of leading commercial and industrial groups on a package of draft bills stipulating measures to promote industrial upgrades, MOEA officials said Friday.

The talks, to be hosted by Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, will be part of the government's efforts to work out a new policy on Taiwan's industrial development given the upcoming 2009 expiration of the existing Statute for Upgrading Industries, officials said.

According to the MOEA, the draft bills, designed to cover every possible legal field concerning industrial upgrades, will include a basic law regulating industrial development, regulations concerning investment incentives and supplements, as well as a statute on the establishment and management of industrial parks.

The planned basic law will provide guidelines around which the government is to form policies and regulations on industrial development, focusing on issues such as the knowledge-based economy, the import and training of talented personnel, technology transfer and proliferation, development of sustainable industry, international cooperation, and cooperation between the academic and industrial sectors, according to the MOEA Industrial Development Bureau in charge of drafting the bills.

The bureau is expected to complete the drafts by the end of June, and is scheduled to submit them to the Executive Yuan by July or August for review before they are delivered to the Legislative Yuan in 2008 for approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTERPRISES URGED TO DEVELOP LAND NEAR HIGH-SPEED RAIL STATIONS

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei urged domestic entrepreneurs Thursday to develop land near high-speed rail stations, as the development efforts are sure to be profitable.

Tsai made the call as he delivered a speech on the prospects of Taiwan's transportation development, at the invitation of the National Association of Industry and Commerce. Also present was association President Theodore Huang.

Entrepreneurs could help develop land near stations on the country's first high- speed railway that was inaugurated Jan. 5, under the build, operate, transfer model that would allow them to make huge profits, according to Tsai.
Huang echoed Tsai's remarks, saying that entrepreneurs could follow America's and Japan's successful examples by building hotels and department stores in the stations for tourists and shoppers.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA CREDIT TRAIL SHOWS TAIWANESE PREFER TRAVEL IN ASIA-PACIFIC

TEXT.P: Taiwanese prefer traveling in the Asia-Pacific area, for 60 percent of a total NT$52 billion (US$1.57 billion) in Taiwanese spending in 2006 transactions was spent outside the country in this area, a Visa International spokesman said Friday.

Visa Taiwan Managing Director Marco Ma pointed out that of the top five destinations for Taiwanese travelers, four are in the Asia-Pacific: America, China, Hong Kong and Japan; only fifth- place England is outside the region.

Some 44 percent of transactions went to purchases of retail products, after which came housing, transportation, professional services, sports, and food and drinks. The average single transaction amounted to NT$5,700.

Ma said that highest-value single transactions were made in Italy (NT$113,600) , Macau (NT$10,780) , and France (NT$10,730) . Most transactions in Italy and France are conducted in retailing boutiques, while most transactions in Macau focused on sports and recreation.

Visa International has designed special traveling programs for the growing high- consumption group of Visa Infinite and Platinum Card holders, a group whose transactions accounted for 66 percent of the overall total of NT$ 52 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES REACT ALONG PARTY LINE ON LATEST PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Politicians reacted along party lines Friday upon learning that former Kaohsiung acting mayor Chen Chi-mai has been appointed deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) responding positively and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) criticizing the appointment.
President Chen Shui-bian announced several major appointments, including that of Chen Chi-mai, earlier Friday.

This was the president's second wave of key post appointments this week. He announced a swapping of posts between Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the National Security Council and Tan Sun Chen, secretary general of the Presidential Office, earlier this week.
The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Chen Chi-mai's new post is "very appropriate."

Ker Chien-ming, DPP legislator and caucus whip, said that Chen Chi-mai served three terms as a legislator and had administrative experience given the fact that he once served as a minister without portfolio and spokesman of the Executive Yuan.
For his part, Chen Chi-mai vowed to serve with humility, saying that he would do his utmost to assist President Chen in cross-Strait and diplomatic affairs.

Chen Chi-mai stepped down as the Kaohsiung acting mayor to take responsibility for a riot in August 2005 by Thai laborers working on Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system to protest their harsh treatment and inhumane management. Subsequent investigations into the riot uncovered a series of irregularities in the MRT project involving Chen Che-nan, former deputy secretary-general to the president and Chen Chi-mai's father.

Chen Chi-mai reportedly has been biding his time since then, and was said to be keen on running in the year-end legislative elections, which will adopt a new "single-member constituency, two votes" electoral system, and halve the 225-member legislature to 113 seats.
As DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling also made known her intention to run in the same constituency as Chen Chi-mai's, his new appointment has certainly helped relieve internal pressures for the DPP.

But the KMT and its ally the People First Party (PFP) criticized the intentions of the president in appointing Chen Chi-mai, a protege of the president and a rising star until the Thai riot brought an abrupt stop to his otherwise smooth political career.
Hsu Shao-ping, KMT legislator and caucus whip, said that Chen Che-nan was indicted for influence peddling and as a result the public has a poor impression of the Chens.
"The president has total disregard for public sentiment, and is only thinking of his own protege," she lamented.

Her colleague, legislator Alex Fai, said that the president's latest wave of personnel appointments could signal that the president is afraid of becoming a "lamb duck" before his second term expires in May 2008, so to demonstrate that he is still in command he has invited his protege to help him with the preparations for two major elections ahead -- the year-end legislative elections and the March 2008 presidential election.

PFP Legislator Lee Hung-chun said that the truth of the Kaohsiung MRT probe has yet to come to light, and the president is appointing Chen Chi-mai to his new post in return for assisting Chen Chu in last December's Kaohsiung mayoral election.

Chen Chi-mai served as the campaign manager for Chen Chu in the fiercely contested election, helping Chen Chu to win by a razor-thin margin against her KMT rival Huang Chun-ying when the DPP was mired in its lowest approval rating due to a spate of scandals involving President Chen's family members and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGE COSTS LOW, WON'T AFFECT STAFF'S RIGHTS: CABINET

TEXT.P: The funds needed to change the names of three state-run enterprises are limited and the move will not affect their employees' legitimate rights and interests in any way, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Friday.
Cheng made the remarks after the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) , China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) and Chunghwa Post Co. approved their name changes in board meetings earlier in the day.

Noting that changing corporate titles to remove references to China and prevent confusion with Chinese counterparts is the government's long-term policy goal, Cheng said each of the three companies has been assessing the feasibility of name changes for quite a long time.

According to Cheng, all three companies fleshed out comprehensive technical details regarding name changes before presenting them to the Executive Yuan for approval. "We have avoided premature exposure to prevent controversies, " he said, adding that Premier Su Tseng-chang has kept President Chen Shui-bian informed of the developments in the issue.
The name changes follow calls from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to remove references to China in state organizations.

The Chinese Petroleum Corp. said its new name is CPC Corp., Taiwan, while China Shipbuilding said it will be called CSBS Corp., Taiwan. The oil company's name change took effect immediately, while the CSBC's name change is still pending a formal endorsement by its shareholders at a March 1 meeting.

Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said the name changes will contribute to upgrading the images of the two companies' brand awareness and international competitiveness, while requiring only a limited outlay of financial resources and will have no adverse impact on the rights and interests of corporate staff.
Moreover, he added, the name changes will have a positive impact on the two companies' sustainable development.
Chunghwa Post -- Chunghwa means "Chinese" -- changed its name to Taiwan Post Co., Ltd, but only after the meeting of its board was disrupted by opponents from the company's labor union.

Dozens of protesters kicked down the door of the meeting room and forced board members to move to another location. The union claimed that the name change would cost too much and come at the expense of the company's employees.

However, Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei said the name change will hardly impact the postal company's business growth nor undermine the rights and interests of its staff and clients.
As to the cost, Tsai said the name change will cost the postal company less than NT$70 million.
Tsai said the postal company has been preparing for the name change since the Executive Yuan ordered a study of the feasibility in 2004.
Both CPC Corp., Taiwan and Taiwan Post Co. will begin to use new signboards Monday. Plaque unveiling ceremonies will be held at both firms' Taipei head offices at 2 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% OF PERMS POORLY LABELED: CPC

TEXT.P: Some 70 percent of perms on the market in Taipei do not meet labeling requirements when spot-checked by the Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) under the Executive Yuan and the Department of Health (DOH), a CPC spokesman said Friday.

At the CPC's request, the DOH asked the Taipei City and Taipei County health bureaus to examine samples at salons and stores selling hairdressing materials. The DOH found that while the labels for 14 out of 20 samples did not meet regulatory requirements, samples taken gave no reason for quality-related concerns.

The spokesman said that pharmaceutical perms should follow regulations and be labeled correctly to provide important information regarding ingredients, expiration dates and notices relevant to the health and safety of consumers.

The spokesman reminded consumers to check the DOH's Website to verify the authenticity of product licenses, purchase only properly labeled perm products, and cease using any product that causes problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Accord Is Signed by Palestinians to Stop Feuding
The main rival Palestinian factions agreed late Thursday to form a government of national unity aimed at ending a wave of violence between them and an international boycott.
The agreement, signed here in Islams holiest city under Saudi auspices, appeared likely to end, at least for now, weeks of fighting that had ravaged the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Still, it seemed to stop short of meeting the demands of the international community for resuming relations and support for the Palestinian Authority.
Wall Street Journal:Off the Runway,A Makeup Artist Gets Her Big Break
Like many young people who move to New York, Leslie Peck arrived here in 2005 with a dream: to become a famous makeup artist. As a first step, she took a job behind a cosmetics counter at Bloomingdale's. While she applied makeup to customers and sold them foundation, lipstick and eye shadow, she dreamed about getting her big break.
On Sunday night, the 30-year-old Ms. Peck got her chance: a call to sit at the side of top makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury at British designer Matthew Williamson's show. For three hours, Ms. Peck worked backstage at the New York fashion week headquarters in Bryant Park and helped apply dark-green eye shadow with gold highlights to the faces of 22 top models.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOT POT INGREDIENTS CONTAIN HIGH SODIUM LEVELS: CONSUMER GROUP

TEXT.P: The non-profit Consumer's Foundation checked 51 hot pot ingredient samples, mostly fish balls and Japanese-style surimi products, bought from supermarkets, shopping malls and traditional markets around the greater Taipei area from November through January, it said.
Around 80 percent of the samples contained 400 mg to 800 mg of sodium per 100 g, the foundation said, while a government regulation on packaged food recommends a daily sodium intake of 2,400 mg.

One surimi product surveyed contained 1,100 mg of sodium per 100 g, the foundation said, adding that eating only a little over a dozen of the products can mean ingesting about 2,400 mg of sodium, without even counting the salt contained in seasonings.
The checks also found use of preservatives in around 40 percent of the samples, with two products exceeding legal standards, the foundation said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGE OF CPC TO TAKE EFFECT IMMEDIATELY: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Two state-owned enterprises -- Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) -- are set to change their names in line with the nation's "name rectification" campaign, Minister of the Economic Affairs Steve Ruey-long Chen said Friday.
Chen said that the name of the CPC, which will be changed to Taiwanese Petroleum in Chinese and "CPC Corporation, Taiwan"(or CPC in short) in English, will take effect immediately.

A ceremony marking the new name of the CPC will be held Feb. 12, Chen said, while the name of the CSBC, which will be changed to CSBC Corporation, Taiwan (or CSBC in short), will only take effect after the decision -- approved by its board of directors earlier Friday -- is endorsed at an upcoming shareholders' meeting March 1.
Chen noted that the name-change of the state-owned enterprises aims at avoiding confusion with similarly named businesses in China.

He stressed that the name-change will positively impact the image, brand and market identification of the companies, providing an upgrade in their international competitive edge, and will by no means affect the rights of the employees in the two companies.
On the cost of "name-rectification,' Chen said the ministry has clearly instructed the two companies to change their names in the most "simple, efficient and cost-saving" way.

For example, the sign boards of the CPC petrol stations will not have to be changed completely, and the ID passes of the employees will only require stickers, which he said will incur only a "very limited cost."

President Chen Shui-bian first proposed the "name-change" campaign in December 2004, saying that state-owned enterprises that bear the names of "China" or "Chinese" should change their names to highlight that they are Taiwanese companies.
The Executive Yuan has recently announced that it would promote the name changes in a "reasonable and pragmatic" way.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEBRUARY 10 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Feb. 10
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a "new challenge, new prospect" activity at a spa and recreational facility in Snahsia, Taipei County.
13:30, Six youth groups will hold a joint news conference to promote Taiwan's U.N. bid.
20:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend a concert featuring new Taiwanese Lunar New Year songs to be held at the Tainan City Culture Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 10, or the 23rd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1763: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending seven years of war and heralding Britain's emergence as the leading world power. Britain gained both Canada and Florida and established dominance in the East.
1840: Queen Victoria of Britain and Ireland and empress of India, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, marries her first cousin, Prince Albert.
1846: British forces defeat Sikhs at Sobranhan, India.
1890: Boris Pasternak, the Russian author famed for his prize-winning novel "Doctor Zhivago," is born.
1894: Harold Macmillan, British statesman and Conservative prime minister, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out after Japan formally declares war on Russia.
1923: William Rontgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays and developed X-ray photography, thereby revolutionizing medical diagnosis, dies in Munich at the age of 77.
1939: Haikuo falls after Japanese troops land on Hainan Island in southern China.
1946: In the first Jakarta (Batavia) meeting between the two sides, the Netherlands government bows to the inevitable and agrees to let Indonesia become independent, on the condition that Indonesia forms a confederation of states.
1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black people from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in their wake.
1955: All 14,483 residents of the Republic of China-held Tachen Islands near mainland China's Chekiang Province are evacuated to Taiwan.
1962: In an historic exchange, captured U.S. spy-plane pilot Gary Powers starts walking to freedom from the communist side of a Berlin bridge, while the highest-ranking Russian spy ever caught, KGB Colonel Rudolf Abel, sets off from the American side.
1964: The government of the ROC recalls its envoy from France and announces the severance of diplomatic relations with the European country.
1964: More than 80 people die as HMAS Voyager, a destroyer of the Royal Australian Navy, sinks after a collision with HMAS Melbourne.
1974: An all-star women's basketball team leaves Taipei for a tour of the United States.
1976: Work begins on an elevated road across the North Gate area of Taipei, in a move designed to relieve traffic congestion.
1980: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with Colombia.
1981: King Juan Carlos names Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo as prime minister of Spain.
1981: The 32 new ROC Control Yuan members are sworn in.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a congratulatory message to President- elect Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Finance orders the 10th Credit Cooperative of Taipei to stop transactions for three days for violating operating regulations.
1996: On the Japanese island of Hokkaido, a landslide crushes a highway tunnel, killing 20 people.
1998: Former French Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann dies. He is considered a founding father of the European Union.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to further expanding bilateral cooperation.
2001: Fan Liqing and Zhen Binhua, the first two mainland Chinese reporters allowed to be stationed in Taiwan, cover their first story, with themselves being the center of attention among the local press.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Is moral life something remote or difficult? If a man only wishes to live a moral life -- there and then his life becomes moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOES NOT SUPPORT TAIWAN'S NAME-CHANGE DRIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/10/07 13:36:23 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States does not support steps that would appear to change Taiwan's status unilaterally, including changes in terminology for entities administered by Taiwan authorities, a U.S. State Department official said Friday.
Sean McCormack, spokesman of the department, reiterated that the maintenance of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait remains the primary interest of the United States.
"The United States does not support Taiwan independence and opposes any unilateral steps by either side that would change the status quo," McCormack said during a daily press briefing.

"President Chen's fulfillment of his commitments will be a test of leadership, dependability and statesmanship, as well as the ability to protect Taiwan's interests, its relations with others, and to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait," he added.
McCormack made the statement in response to questions concerning President Chen Shui-bian's recent indication of plans to change the names of Taiwan's overseas outposts.

In the latest issue of his online newsletter published Thursday, Chen said that besides the government's current efforts to change the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China, the names of the country's overseas embassies and representative offices will also be changed in the future to highlight Taiwan's identity.

In their respective board meetings held Friday, the Chinese Petroleum Corp. decided to change its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " China Shipbuilding Corp. decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan" and Chunghwa Post Co. decided to change its name to "Taiwan Post Co."

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party has been promoting the name rectification campaign to avoid confusion resulting from Taiwan-based organizations carrying similar names to organizations in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: UPU HAS NO COMMENT ON TAIWAN'S POSTAL NAME CHANGE ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/10/07 13:50:36 (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Berne-based Universal Postal Union (UPU) said Friday it is not in a position to comment on Taiwan's decision to rename its state-owned postal company to make it more recognizable in the international community.

Noting that the UPU focuses on upgrading global postal services, setting relevant operation standards and coordinating the worldwide postal system, the organization said it never interferes with individual country's internal postal policies and practices, such as postal charges and the issuing of stamps.

Moreover, a UPU spokesman said, Taiwan is not a UPU member. The UPU, a U.N. affiliate, has recognized the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate Chinese representative since April 1972. The UPU now has 191 member countries.

The spokesman made the remarks amid reports that the labor union of Taiwan's state-owned Chunghwa Post Co. -- Chunghwa means "China" -- is protesting the company's decision to change its name to Taiwan Post Co. and has warned its management that redesignation might draw a backlash from China and lead to a suspension of postal links across the Taiwan Strait and even with other countries.

Although Taiwan is not a UPU member, it has consistently followed international norms and postal regulations and exercised self-rule. The UPU spokesman said it could not make any comments on the Taiwan postal company's name change issue. "As to other countries' possible responses to such a move, it's up to Taiwan to address them, " he added.

In Taipei, the board of directors of Chunghwa Post Co. approved the corporate name change Friday, despite protests from dozens of labor union members on the grounds that the name rectification would cost a lot of money and come at the expense of the company's employees. The name change will take effect Monday when a nameplate bearing the company's new name "Taiwan Post" will also be unveiled.

Also on Friday, the boards of directors of two other state-owned enterprises -- Chinese Petroleum Corp. and China Shipbuilding Corp. -- approved similar redesignation proposals, removing references to China and including "Taiwan" in their titles.

Opposition parties have criticized the name change policy as a politically motivated move that will stir up ethnic disharmony or confrontation, but government authorities argue that the policy has been adopted based on the practical need to maintain "proper partition" from China and save Taiwan's state-owned enterprises from being confused with similarly named Chinese companies.

Confusing titles between Taiwan and China are truly a problem for foreign people. Just recently, the band of the Caribbean nation Grenada played the national anthem of the "Republic of China" (Taiwan's official title) instead of that of the "People's Republic of China" at a ceremony welcoming visiting Chinese President Hu Jintao.

The Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia, elaborates on the special phenomenon with regard to Taiwan's postal service and advises readers to write "Taiwan" rather than "Republic of China" or "ROC" on mail addressed to Taiwan to ensure the quickest delivery.

The Wikipedia's UPU entry includes a paragraph that reads: "The Republic of China joined the UPU on March 1, 1914. After the People's Republic of China was founded, the Republic of China continued to represent China in the UPU, until the UPU decided on April 13, 1972 to recognize the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate Chinese representative. This makes the International Reply Coupons not available to Taiwan. Mail addressed to Taiwan will still be delivered there, albeit routed through a third country. However, writing 'Taiwan' rather than 'Republic of China' or 'ROC' ensures the quickest delivery. Writing 'Taiwan, Province of China' may send the mail through mainland China and cause delays."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO LAUNCH HOLIDAY CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS FEB. 13

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) , will launch the 2007 Lunar New Year direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services Feb. 13 with a Taipei-Shanghai round-trip flight, a CAL spokesman said Saturday.
CAL and Mandarin Airlines will provide a total of 16 charter flights between Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Beijing/ Shanghai/Guangzhou/ in China during the Lunar New Year period from Feb. 13-25.

Following the Mandarin Airlines' charter flight Feb. 13, CAL will launch its first flight, also a Taipei-Shanghai round-trip flight, the following day, and its first Kaoshiung-Shanghai round-trip flight Feb. 16.

The spokesman reminded people who want to travel to China by taking one of the holiday charter flights to reserve seats as early as possible, noting that most of the flights from China to Taiwan are already fully booked.

In addition to presenting Chinese New Year's gifts to passengers flying with CAL during the festive season, the spokesman said, the airline will also serve special meals and snacks, including "Taiwanese Buddha Skipping Wall" for first- class passengers, XO sauce fried rice cakes for business class passengers, and peanut muffins for economy class passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK CHANGES ENGLISH DESIGNATION ON WEB SITE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank announced Saturday it has changed its English designation as shown on its official Web site.
The monetary authority, which was originally referred to as "Central Bank of China, Republic of China (Taiwan)," has been changed to "Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan)."

The bank said in a news statement that the change is aimed at avoiding confusion and is consistent with international practices in which the official name of a country is used when referring to the central bank of that particular country.
The move comes amid the government's current efforts to change the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China.

In their respective board meetings held Friday, the Chinese Petroleum Corp. decided to change its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " China Shipbuilding Corp. decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan" and Chunghwa Post Co. decided to change its name to "Taiwan Post Co."
The Cabinet claims the name rectification campaign will help avoid confusion resulting from Taiwan-based organizations carrying similar names to organizations in China.
President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that similar changes will also be made to the names of the country's overseas embassies and representative offices in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS NAME CHANGES FOR STATE-OWNED ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang defended Saturday the government's move to rectify the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China, saying the changes will help boost the competitiveness of the enterprises.
Su said that after the changes, the Taiwan-based enterprises will no longer be confused with those in China and promised that the changes will not affect the rights and interests of their workers.

In their respective board meetings held Friday, the Chinese Petroleum Corp. decided to change its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " China Shipbuilding Corp. decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan" and Chunghwa Post Co. decided to change its name to "Taiwan Post Co."

Commenting on the issue Friday, U.S. State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said the United States does not support steps that would appear to change Taiwan's status unilaterally, including changes in terminology for entities administered by Taiwan authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF CRITICIZES NAME-CHANGE CAMPAIGN AS 'CHILDISH'

TEXT.P: The chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) criticized Saturday a campaign initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to change the names of state-run enterprises, calling the move "childish."

Ma Ying-jeou made the criticism in a press release following a statement by the U.S. government earlier the same day that it "does not support changes in terminology for entities administered by Taiwan authorities."

Ma rebuked the DPP for attempting to "gloss over its incompetence in running a country and the fact that the country's economy has been in a state of stagnancy" by pursuing the name change campaign, which he called "political manipulation."

"No matter what changes the DPP makes, it cannot change the fact that the Republic of China exists, " Ma said, describing the move to "eliminate the ROC's existence in state-run enterprises" as "childish."

Ma said the "childishness" and "political manipulation" have harmed the people of the country. He claimed that Chunghwa Post Co.'s decision to change its name will not only make the employees suffer by having to engage in the time- consuming task of changing the company designation on countless documents, it will also cause problems for people around the country who will have to spend a lot of time having documents issued by the postal company, which also provides insurance and banking services, changed.

"The losses caused by the name-change campaign will be too large to imagine," Ma claimed, advising President Chen Shui-bian, who gave instructions to initiate the campaign, to "refrain from playing the game of terminology and to stop playing with the issue of Taiwan independence at the expense of the Taiwan people's interests and Taiwan's relations with the United States.

In their respective board meetings held Friday, the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) decided to change its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) decided to change its name to CSBC Corp., Taiwan, " and Chunghwa Post Co. decided to change its name to "Taiwan Post Co."
Chunghwa Post's decision triggered protests by the company's worker's union.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE NAME-CHANGE DRIVE: SENIOR OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Senior officials said Saturday the government will continue to push forward with its "name rectification" campaign, calling it an "internal matter."

They were responding to remarks by a U.S. State Department official Friday that the United States does not support steps that would appear to change Taiwan's status unilaterally, including changes in terminology for entities administered by Taiwan authorities.

Several Taiwan state-owned enterprises, including the Chinese Petroleum Corp., the China Shipbuilding Corp., the China Post Co., have decided in their respective board meetings to remove any reference to "China" and include "Taiwan" in their titles.

President Chen Shui-bian also said Thursday that the name-change campaign will not be restricted to state-owned enterprises and will include Taiwan's overseas embassies and representative offices in the future.
Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general of the National Security Council, said that name rectification campaign is a national policy, and the campaign will continue.
"The matter will not affect Taiwan-U.S. relations," he added.
Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, echoed Tan Sun Chen's views.
"This is an internal matter, and foreign countries should not interfere," Yu said.
Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that "this is the government's policy, and we have a right to carry on the matter."

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday that the current name-change drive is not intended to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and that it is aimed at avoiding confusion arising from the fact that many Taiwan organizations have names that are similar to their counterparts in China.
"The government's name-change drive has nothing to do with the unification versus independence debate or with changing the official name of the country," MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh stressed.
Wang also said the ministry's efforts to have overseas embassies have the word "Taiwan" added to their names in parenthesis have been proceeding smoothly.

However, in countries with which Taiwan does not maintain diplomatic relations, changing the name of representative offices will require the consent of the host countries, Wang said, adding that the matter will have to be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.
Currently, Taiwan representative offices in Jordan, Bahrain, Papua New Guinea, Nigeria and Bolivia have the word "Taiwan" included in parenthesis in their names, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGES PRESIDENT CHEN TO HONOR 'FOUR NOES' PLEDGES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/10/07 16:43:12 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States called on President Chen Shui-bian Friday to fulfill his "four noes" commitments, including not to change Taiwan's national title, while expressing concern over Taiwan's ongoing move to rectify the names of its state- owned enterprises.

"President Chen Shui-bian repeatedly has said he would not allow either domestic or foreign pressure to alter the guarantees in his 2000 inaugural address, in which he pledged not to declare independence, not to change the national title, not to push for inclusion of sovereignty themes in the Constitution, and not to promote a referendum to change the status quo regarding independence or unification, " the U.S. State Department said in a written statement.

"President Chen's fulfillment of his commitments will be a test of leadership, dependability and statesmanship, as well as ability to protect Taiwan's interests, its relations with others, and to maintain peace and stability in the strait," it added.

The statement was issued in response to a question raised during the department's daily press briefing, in which spokesman Sean McCormack was asked to comment on Taiwan's ongoing efforts to rename state-owned enterprises that contain references to China and plans to change the names of the country's overseas embassies and representative offices in the future.

Stressing that the primary interest of the United States remains maintenance of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, the State Department reiterated that the United States does not support Taiwan independence and opposes any unilateral steps by either side that would change the status quo.

"We do not support administrative steps by the Taiwan authorities that would appear to change Taiwan's status unilaterally or move toward independence. The United States does not, for instance, support changes in terminology for entities administered by the Taiwan authorities," it said.

In their respective board meetings held Friday, Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. decided to change its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " China Shipbuilding Corp. decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan" and Chunghwa Post Co. decided to change its name to "Taiwan Post Co."
The Cabinet claims the name rectification campaign will help avoid confusion resulting from Taiwan-based organizations carrying similar names to organizations in China.
President Chen said Thursday that similar changes will also be made to the names of the country's overseas embassies and representative offices in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG BLOOD CENTER CALLS FOR BLOOD DONATIONS AHEAD OF HOLIDAYS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Blood Center has called for people to donate blood ahead of the Lunar New Year to help deal with an expected blood shortage during the holiday period, the center's spokesman said Saturday.

The center provides about 1,200 250 c.c. bags of blood to medical institutes in Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County, Pingtung City and Pingtung County everyday, the spokesman said, adding that the center currently only has a four-day back-up supply of blood, short of its minimum safety supply of seven days.

With several cold fronts forecast to hit Taiwan during the holiday period, an increase in the number of cardiovascular disease patients is expected, putting a strain on the blood supply, the spokesman said.

The spokesman said that all four blood types --- O, A, B and AB -- are in short supply and that blood donations are appreciated in order to ensure a sufficient supply of blood during the holiday period.
People who donate blood at the Kaohsiung Blood Center or at activities held by the center at other sites from Feb. 10-16 will receive oyster essence presented by Paolyta Co., the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S ELECTION CHANCES TO IMPROVE IF NATION BECOMES MORE NORMAL: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that if the nation becomes "more normal" and its people's lives improve, then the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will have a better chance in elections.

The president made the remarks at a spring gathering at a recreational facility in Sanhsia, Taipei County. Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, other ranking officials, DPP mayors and magistrates, legislators, and DPP Central Standing Committee members were invited to attend the gathering in a show of the party's solidarity.
The president noted that a great number of people have expressed concern about the year-end legislative elections and the March 2008 presidential election.

"There are a host of challenges ahead, and we should have confidence, " the president said, citing a Taiwanese saying that "as long as a tree is in solid ground, then the top end of the tree has no need to worry about the coming typhoon."
"Whether they are legislative or presidential elections, they are just like a coming typhoon," the president said.

"Taiwan is the root. If Taiwan is better, more normal and the people have a better life, then the DPP will have the support and identification of the people, and it will have a better chance in the elections," he stressed.
The president urged all participants to join hands to face the new challenges in the coming year. Noting that the gathering was
proposed by Vice President Lu, he also presented each of the participants a copy of Lu's new book, "The Global Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLINE BANKING USERS URGED TO BE ON GUARD AGAINST 'PHISHERS'

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) reminded users of online banking services Saturday to check their bank's Web site address before engaging in any transactions or information exchanges in order to protect themselves from being "phished" by cyber-criminals.

The FSC issued the warning after the technology crimes prevention and control center of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) revealed that it has recently discovered that some computer hackers from China have been acquiring online banking users' personal information, such as bank account numbers and passwords, through false bank Web sites.

Explaining the scheme called "phishing, " anti-technology crime police officers said that "phishers" copy Web site pages of legitimate banks to trick users into disclosing sensitive personal information.
People who do not have the habit of checking the official Website address of their banks can easily be cheated as the false bank Web sites look almost identical to the real ones, the police said.

According to the CIB center, in addition to personal information of bank clients, the phishers have also been discovered to have been stealing money from bank accounts online by cooperating with criminal rings in Taiwan.
The FSC therefore called for the public to be on alert against this new type of online fraud and to avoid communicating by e-mail with any banks or other businesses with which they are not familiar.

People should always check information on exchanges through their online bank accounts and contact their bank at once if they suspect that their bank accounts and passwords have been used without their authorization, the FSC suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TAKES PART IN CLEAN-UP ACTIVITY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin took part in a clean-up activity held by the municipal government's Department of Environmental Protection Saturday to promote the idea of keeping the city clean, a department spokesman said.

Speaking at the activity held in the city's Wenshan District on the first day of a week-long national clean-up campaign launched by the Environmental Protection Administration under the Executive Yuan ahead of the Lunar New Year, Hau urged the city's residents to take time out once a week to clean up the area in around their residences to keep the city clean.

According to the spokesman, Hau said the clean-up activity is meant to promote the concept of turning Taiwan into a "beautiful Formosa" and noted that Singapore keeps its environment clean by mobilizing half a million people in clean-up activities every year and educating citizens on how to keep a clean environment.

The spokesman also reminded people that the city's garbage collection times will change slightly during the Lunar New Year period, with no garbage collection services from Feb. 18-20, except at 57 specified collection locations at scheduled times.

The department will begin collecting general garbage and kitchen waste from Feb. 21, and garbage collection operations will return to normal from Feb. 23, the spokesman added. The Lunar New Year's Day falls on Feb. 18 this year. endtiem/Li

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER ASSESSING WHETHER TO ENTER KMT PRIMARY FOR PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday that he is cautiously assessing his future options amid reports that he is actively preparing for the Kuomintang (KMT) primary for the 2008 presidential election.

Wang was responding to reports by the United Daily News, a major local newspaper, that he will make a formal announcement to throw his hat in the KMT primary at an "appropriate time" after the Chinese New Year holidays to try to win the party's nomination.

Instead of confirming the news, Wang said he has to "seriously consider the questions of what he can do for the country and what the country should do for the people to live up to their expectations."
"I will also engage in self-reflection to see if I'm capable of serving the country," Wang continued.
"There are many options ahead, and I'll cautiously assess my future direction, " he said, adding that "I'll not rule out any possibilities, and staying on in the legislature will also be an option."
Asked about the possibility of running against KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, the most likely bet of the party for the presidential election, in the primary, Wang said that he will respect Ma's decision.

The politically-savvy Wang resigned from his concurrent post as the KMT vice chairman after losing to Ma, then also a KMT vice chairman, in the party's chairmanship election in 2005. He has until now been tightlipped about his intentions concerning the 2008 presidential election.
Meanwhile, there were mixed reactions from KMT lawmakers to the reports.

KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said that the primary system will provide all aspirants with the opportunity to engage in a "gentlemen's battle, " which he said is better than the fighting under the table between the four heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , referring to Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh, and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun.

While KMT Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung said that he will not speculate on unconfirmed reports, his colleague Wu Chih-yang stressed that "it is a good thing for aspirants to make known their intentions."

Legislator Daniel Hwang, executive director in charge of policy of the People First Party (PFP) , an ally of the KMT, said that the party respects "Wang's running for the KMT's nomination in the primary."
Hwang said that he is sure that the two parties will throw their support behind a presidential candidate endorsed by the KMT-PFP alliance.

Meanwhile, Legislator Lo Chih-ming of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) noted that Wang has remained on friendly terms with former President Lee Teng-hui, the spiritual leader of the TSU.
"If Wang can identify with the Taiwan-centric consciousness as well as the center-left direction espoused by the TSU, then the chances of bilateral cooperation will increase," Lo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE MATTER TO BECOME CLEARER IN APRIL: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The matter of who will be the Kuomintang's (KMT's) presidential candidate will become clearer in April, Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the main opposition party, said Saturday.

Ma, widely seen as the most likely bet to be the KMT's candidate in the 2008 presidential election, made the remarks while meeting supporters in Taipei County as part of his islandwide tour to listen to the voice of the grass roots.
Ma noted that the party will coordinate a ticket for the March 2008 presidential election in April.
The KMT will "recover the happiness, stability and harmony that have long been missing during the rule of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party," Ma said.

Ma has recently been facing questions regarding reports of his alleged misuse of the "executive's special allowance" during his tenure as the Taipei mayor which ended last December. He has maintained his innocence and said that it was gratifying that a lot of people expressed faith in his integrity during his meetings with them.
Ma has also repeatedly said that he would resign from the party chairmanship in accordance with the KMT charter if he were to be indicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZAMBIAN OPPOSITION PARTY CONSIDERING OPENING OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Patriotic Front, Zambia's major opposition party, may open a representative office in Taiwan to learn from the country's experiences in technological and democratic development, the party's leader said in Taipei earlier this week.

Speaking in an interview with the Central News Agency prior to his departure Friday for home after a five-day Taiwan visit, Michael Chilufya Sata said he has been impressed by Taiwan's booming economy and technological advancement as well as its liberal democracy during his stay in Taiwan.

"This is my first trip to Taiwan, and it won't be my last. I'm impressed by Taiwan's prosperity and development in various fields. After I return to my country, I'll discuss with my party colleagues the possibility of operating a liaison office in Taiwan, " Sata said, adding that given its proximity to Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea and the Philippines, Taiwan is an appropriate location to be home to his party's Asia base.

Praising Taiwan as having come a long way in transforming itself from an agricultural backwater into an industrial powerhouse, Sata said he believes that African countries, including Zambia, should have much to learn from Taiwan's developmental experiences.

"It is regrettable that few Africans know about Taiwan's achievements in technological and democratic development, and I believe that such ignorance is the major reason behind the sad fact that only five African countries recognize Taiwan," Sata said.

Sata, 70, is a prominent Zambian politician known for his activism. He used to be a provincial head and held Cabinet posts in labor, health and social welfare fields. He made headlines last September when he drew the ire of China by calling Taiwan a sovereign state on the campaign trail ahead of the Zambian presidential election.

Sata led by a large margin in the Zambian capital, major copper mining towns and urban areas in the first two days of the vote count, but the situation took a dramatic turn on the third day, with incumbent President Levy Mwanawasa coming from behind to score an upset victory. Sata ended up losing the election, garnering only 30 percent of the vote to Mwanawasa's 43 percent.

Sata's supporters staged a two-day rally to protest the result but were dispersed by police with tear gas and warning shots. Sata later conceded defeat (with) but maintained that the ruling party had rigged the vote.

When Chinese President Hu Jintao visited Zambia early this month, the Patriotic Front issued a statement expressing Zambian people's anti-China sentiments. Hu was forced to cancel his plan to visit a Chinese-run copper mine north of Zambian capital after learning that Patriotic Front supporters were planning to stage a protest against Hu's visit. Due to his anti-China stance, Sata was excluded from all welcoming activities during Hu's visit.

Noting that his party holds a strong clout in Zambia's capital and copper mining areas, Sata said he believes that Hu should have gotten the message of Zambian people's discontent with China's exports of laborers to work at Zambian's mining areas.
"China's labor exports to Zambia and other African countries have caused resentment among Africans because Africa itself has abundant labor supplies but lacks job opportunities," Sata said.

Asked why he is so critical of China at a time when most African countries are vying for China's aid in their economic development, Sata said their expectations are based on wrong perception and ignorance of the many meaningful aid projects Taiwan has launched for his five African allies -- Malawi, Burkina Faso, Swaziland, The Gambia and Sao Tome & Principe.

Sata further said he believes that China's relentless efforts to block Taiwan's international presence and constant military threat against Taiwan mainly result from "its jealousy of Taiwan's successful economic development and its fear of the spread of Taiwan's democratic notions and lifestyle across the Taiwan Strait to influence its people."

Asked why he recognizes Taiwan as a sovereign state, Sata said Taiwan is a bona fide sovereign state because "it has its own government, lifestyle and has been independent for more than 50 years." He further said Taiwan's future will mainly be decided by its own people, not anybody else. Sata said if had won Zambia's last presidential election, he would have switched his country's diplomatic recognition from Beijing to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH SCHOLAR PRAISES CONTRIBUTION OF BUDDHIST NUNS IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, India, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/10/07 22:00:02 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Richard Gombrich, a professor of Buddhist studies at Oxford University, praised the contributions of Buddhist nuns in Taiwan to the promotion of Buddhist doctrines, saying the influence of Buddhism has significantly increased on the island while followers of the religion have suffered from repression in many other countries.

Gombrich made the remarks in an interview with the CNA Saturday, after presiding over an international conference on Buddhism held in Bodh Gaya in Bihar Province, northeast India Feb. 4-6 to mark the 2,550th anniversary of the passing of Buddha.

During the three-day conference, Master Chue Men of the Fo Guang Shan Monastery in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan gave a briefing on Buddhist nun's contributions in the 21st century. In his report, Chue Men said 75 percent of the around 30,000 Dharma masters in Taiwan are female, nuns, the highest ratio of any country in the world.
There are eight universities and colleges, three hospitals and 28 libraries around Taiwan founded by Buddhist organizations, and the country is home to over 5.4 million Buddhists.

Chue Men indicated that most nuns in Taiwan are highly educated, with many of them holding degrees from domestic or foreign universities. He noted that in Taiwan, nuns enjoy a high social status, a fact which has drawn the attention of Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama who announced on a visit to Taiwan in 1997 his plan to study the system of training female Dharma masters in Taiwan and expressed the intention of establishing a similar system for Tibetan Buddhism.

Chue Men stated that in Taiwan, nuns are widely respected because of their diligence in studying the doctrines of Buddhism as well as their active participation in charity operations. Citing the Fo Guang Shan organization, he pointed out that nuns serve as administrators of 95 percent of the Fo Guang Shan branches in Taiwan and overseas.

The Bodh Gaya conference, titled "The 21st Century and Buddhism, "drew around 1,000 leaders and representatives of Buddhism from countries around the world, including the United States, Britain, Germany, Estonia, Brazil, Hungary, Malaysia, Taiwan, Japan, Sri Lanka and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENAMING STATE-OWNED FIRMS DOESN'T VIOLATE 'FOUR NOES': OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Changing the name of Taiwan's state-owned companies to make them more identifiable with their country of origin doesn't conflict with President Chen Shui-bian's "four noes" pledge, Chen's chief of staff said Saturday.

Chiou I-jen, secretary-general to the president, was responding to a U.S. State Department statement that the United States does not support Taiwn's ongoing move to rectifying the names of its state-owned companies.

"The U.S. statement reflects more of its concern about whether Taiwan would move a step further toward embracing the 'four noes' rather than the current move to change the names of our state-owned companies," Chiou said.

Speaking on the sideline of a spring gathering of senior govenrment and ruling Democratic Progressive Party officials in Sanhsia, Taipei County hosted by President Chen, Chiou said the government will continue communication with U.S. authorities to let them understand that changing the name of Taiwan's state- owned companies is not in conflict with the "four noes" commitments.
"We'll reassure U.S. authorities that our government will continue upholding the 'four noes' commitment," Chiou said.

The "flour noes" refer to commitments made by Chen in his 2000 inaugural address, in which he pledged not to declare independence, not to change the national title, not to push for inclusion of sovereignty themes in the Constitution, and not to promote a referendum to change the status quo regarding independence or unification.
Noting that redesignation of state-owned companies is an internal affairs, Chiou said the government will continue implementing this policy without any pause.
Quoting President Chen's previous statement, Chiou said the state-own enterprises' name rectification need not be associated with change of Taiwan's national title.

In their respective board meetings held Friday, Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. decided to change its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " China Shipbuilding Corp. decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan" and Chunghwa Post Co. decided to change its name to "Taiwan Post Co."
The Executive Yuan said the name rectification is mainly aimed at avoiding confusion resulting from Taiwan-based organizations carrying similar names to organizations in China.

Expressign concern about the three Taiwan state-owned enterprises' name- change decisions, the U.S. State Department issued a statement Friday reminding President Chen of the importance of fulfilling his "four noes" commitments, saying that the "fulfillment will be a test of leadership, dependability and statesmanship, as well as ability to protect Taiwan's interests, its relations with others, and to maintain peace and stability in the strait."

The statement also said that the United States does not support administrative steps by the Taiwan authorities that would appear to change Taiwan's status unilaterally or move toward independence. "The United States does not, for instance, support changes in terminology for entities administered by the Taiwan authorities," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 11, or the 24th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: French Emperor Napoleon I, a brilliant military strategist whose military and political might gripped Continental Europe, marries Marie-Louise, daughter of the first emperor of Austria, Francis I.
1847: Thomas Alva Edison, the American who invented the incandescent light bulb and patented more than a thousand other inventions, is born. He patented his motion picture projector on his birthday in 1909.
1889: A constitution is granted in Japan with a two-chamber Diet, with the Emperor retaining extensive powers.
1920: The League of Nations convenes its first council meeting in London.
1922: A treaty for securing China's independence and maintaining an "open door" is signed in Washington by nine powers.
1929: Pope Pius XI and the Italian government of Benito Mussolini sign the Lateran Treaty, which gives Vatican City the status of an independent sovereign state.
1944: American war planes strike heavy blows against Japanese positions in the Marshall Islands.
1945: The Yalta Conference ends with an agreement for the establishment of the United Nations as well as plans for the defeat of Germany.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes makes public the Yalta Secret Agreement. With victory in the war with Germany virtually assured, the three allied leaders, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, and Joseph Stalin, met on Feb. 4, 1945 at a secret meeting in the Black Sea resort of Yalta to map out Europe's future.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with France.
1967: Military rule is imposed in Beijing.
1968: Communist troops execute 300 civilians in South Vietnam during fighting for the city of Hue.
1970: Japan successfully launches its first satellite into orbit.
1970: The Taiwan Provincial Bureau of Mines is established with Tien Wei-wu serving as the first director-general.
1971: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty in Washington banning underwater nuclear testing.
1973: Lic. Raimundo Guerrero, president of the Mexican Chapter of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1974: Archbishop Domenico Enrici, roving ambassador of the Holy See, arrives in Taipei on an inspection tour. He had served in the Apostolic Internunciature in Taipei 20 years earlier.
1974: Nineteen top Chinese golfers, including Melbourne World Cup Champions Lu Liang-huan and M.N. Hsieh, leave for Manila for the Asian circuit.
1974: U.S. Army Assistant Secretary Eugene E. Berg and a party of 2 arrive in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: For the first time in its 300 year history, Britain's Conservative Party names a woman as its leader when Margaret Thatcher defeats four rivals to succeed Edward Heath.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives the visiting Dr. N. B. Sommer, the first vice president of U.S. Cyanamid Corporation, and W. A. Liffers, the Pacific area general manager.
1979: Islamic revolutionaries take control of Iran's government after the shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, fled Iran the previous month after strikes, riots, and mass demonstrations against his rule.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela is freed after being imprisoned for 27 years for his anti-apartheid activities.
1991: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sends a letter to government leaders of the Warsaw Pact nations proposing that the military structure be disbanded by April 1.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and U.S. President Bill Clinton fail to reach a critical trade deal.
2000: Liu Shao-tang, publisher of the Chinese-language monthly Biographical Literature, dies at the age of 80 after a long illness.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the knowledge of letters and arts, I may perhaps compare myself with other men. But as for the character of a good and wise man who carries out in his personal conduct what he professes -- that is something which I have not yet attained."

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH SCHOLAR PRAISES CONTRIBUTION OF BUDDHIST NUNS IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, India, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/11/07 10:45:08 (By Paul Kuo and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Richard Gombrich, a professor of Buddhist studies at Oxford University, praised the contributions of Buddhist nuns in Taiwan to the promotion of Buddhist doctrines, saying the influence of Buddhism has significantly increased on the island while followers of the religion have suffered from repression in many other countries.

Gombrich made the remarks in an interview with the CNA Saturday, after presiding over an international conference on Buddhism held in Bodh Gaya in Bihar Province, northeast India Feb. 4-6 to mark the 2,550th anniversary of the passing of Buddha.

During the three-day conference, Master Chue Men of the Fo Guang Shan Monastery in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan gave a briefing on Buddhist nun's contributions in the 21st century. In his report, Chue Men said 75 percent of the around 30,000 Dharma masters in Taiwan are female, nuns, the highest ratio of any country in the world.
There are eight universities and colleges, three hospitals and 28 libraries around Taiwan founded by Buddhist organizations, and the country is home to over 5.4 million Buddhists.

Chue Men indicated that most nuns in Taiwan are highly educated, with many of them holding degrees from domestic or foreign universities. He noted that in Taiwan, nuns enjoy a high social status, a fact which has drawn the attention of Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama who announced on a visit to Taiwan in 1997 his plan to study the system of training female Dharma masters in Taiwan and expressed the intention of establishing a similar system for Tibetan Buddhism.

Chue Men stated that in Taiwan, nuns are widely respected because of their diligence in studying the doctrines of Buddhism as well as their active participation in charity operations. Citing the Fo Guang Shan organization, he pointed out that nuns serve as administrators of 95 percent of the Fo Guang Shan branches in Taiwan and overseas.

The Bodh Gaya conference, titled "The 21st Century and Buddhism, "drew around 1,000 leaders and representatives of Buddhism from countries around the world, including the United States, Britain, Germany, Estonia, Brazil, Hungary, Malaysia, Taiwan, Japan, Sri Lanka and Thailand.
