DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILLING TO HELP WITH DPP CANDIDACY COORDINATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has promised to help with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate selection for the 2008 presidential contest through building a consensus among all of the hopefuls, party sources said Sunday.

Ker Chien-ming, top whip of the DPP legislative caucus, quoted Chen as saying at a spring gathering of senior administrators and DPP officials at a recreational park in Sanhsia, Taipei County Saturday that he feels "bound in honor" to assist in coordinating the selection of the DPP's 2008 presidential ticket.

"If necessary, I'll not evade the duty of helping with presidential candidate selection through coordination, " Chen was quoted as having said at the spring gathering he hosted in honor of government and party officials as well as DPP lawmakers.
According to Ker, the selection of the party's candidate for the next presidential election was the hottest topic discussed during the "hiking and talking" event.

With the party's four heavyweights -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun -- overtly or covertly vying for the party's mandate for the presidential race, Ker said many DPP members are worrying over how to build a consensus among the four aspirants to avoid damaging party unity.
"Many participants to the spring gathering requested that the president help with this tough and arduous job, " Ker said.

Former Premier Hsieh was quoted as having said on the occasion that party unity is most important in ensuring electoral victory. Therefore, he said, the party should act early to pick its presidential ticket through consensus building instead of holding a primary, which he said could undermine harmony and unity within the party.

If the 2008 presidential election and the year-end legislative election are, in fact, held simultaneously, Hsieh said, the voting day should be advanced to Jan. 26, 2008. Should that be the case, he said, less than a year is left for preparations. "This is why I have been advocating that our party should start presidential hopeful registration as soon as possible," Hsieh added.

Some lawmakers present at the meeting called for an extensive debate among all aspirants on the party's future policy lines and various reform initiatives. Hsieh reportedly threw his support behind such a proposal.
Premier Su said he believes that the Cabinet's demonstrated administrative success would be the best guarantee of the ruling party's success in the two upcoming critical elections.

"Against this backdrop, I'll work diligently and cooperatively with all party members in carrying out all of our policy initiatives and reform projects. I also wholeheartedly support the proposal of having the president assist in deciding on our party's presidential ticket as early as possible," Su said during the meeting.

For his part, DPP Chairman Yu said the party central committee has worked out a schedule in reference to past practices for selecting the party's presidential candidate. According to the schedule, candidacy registration will start in April, a primary vote by party members will take place in May and public opinion polls will be held in June. According to DPP regulations, the primary voting result will account for 30 percent and the opinion poll results will make up 70 percent in selecting the party's presidential nominee.
If necessary, Yu said he himself would not oppose advancing the whole work schedule or have President Chen help coordinate the candidate selection.

Another major topic discussed in Saturday's gathering was the DPP administration's ongoing campaign to rename state-owned companies to get rid of Chinese reference and include "Taiwan" in their titles to make them more identifiable with their country of origin and avoid confusion with similarly named Chinese organizations.

President Chen was quoted as having acknowledged that it would be very difficult to satisfy all social quarters with regard to the "name rectification" campaign. Consequently, he said, the government and the DPP would be better off if they keep a low profile and refrain from "talking too much" about the issue.
DPP Chairman Yu said the "name rectification" drive is both aimed at realizing the party's policy goal and a move to deliver on its commitment to making Taiwan a "normal, complete and great" country.

"There might be practical limitations and obstacles to accomplishing our ultimate goal, but we should never back away from hard work or our party's ideals, " Yu said, adding that his current push for name rectification and desinicization is in line with the party's policy line.

He further said that even though writing a new constitution for the country is a tall order, the DPP should still present a draft bill in this regard to deliver on its promise to its hard-core supporters.

Both Premier Su and his predecessor, Hsieh, were reportedly more reserved about touting the party's ideals that may be hard to be fully implement given the present international environment. Both said they prefer to see a delicate balance achieved between advocating the party's ambitious goals and their pragmatic implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUPPET SHOW MASTER PASSES AWAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's legendary hand puppet show master Huang Hai-tai passed away at his home in Yunlin, central Taiwan early Sunday. He was 107 years old.

Huang checked into the Yunlin branch of National Taiwan University Hospital last month due to the accumulation of fluid on his lungs as a result of influenza. He had been placed under intensive care for about 10 days, hospital authorities said.

Huang celebrated his 107th birthday in his hometown Jan. 2. Celebrities attending his birthday party included Premier Su Tseng-chang. On that day, the Yunlin County Council passed a resolution designating the date the "Yunlin Hand Puppet Show Day" in recognition of Huang's contribution to hand puppet show development and related traditional folk arts in Taiwan.

Hand puppetry is not just a choice of entertainment, it helps preserve traditional theater, sculpture and embroidery. Since Yunlin started organizing biennial international hand puppet festivals in 1999, the county has helped revitalize the traditional art form.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSING SHORTAGE IN TAIPEI, EXCESS IN TAICHUNG.

TEXT.P: Housing is available in excess of demand throughout Taiwan, especially in Taichung City, but not in Taipei city where there is a shortage, an executive with a local real estate brokerage firm said Sunday.

Citing statistics compiled by the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior, Liao Peng-sheng, a manager of the Yungching Realty Company, said there were 7.4 million homes in the whole Taiwan by the end of 2006, thanks to an abundance of new units built by local real estate developers over the last three years, but there are only 7.36 million households, which translates into a surplus of 39,000 homes.
That excess represents an expansion of 46.76 percent compared with the 26,000 surplus units at the end of 2005, and the excess in supply is expected to keep growing, Liao said.
The oversupply is most obvious in Taichung City where there were 415,000 homes and 353,000 households which translates into a surplus of 62,000 homes.

Liao attributed that city's housing surplus to broad-based speculation that Taichung will become more prosperous following the inauguration of high speed rail service earlier this year and the full operation this year of the Central Taiwan Science Park near Taichung, not to mention the anticipation for direct shipping links between Taichung Harbor and mainland China.
However, the glut of homes in Taichung is sure to put a damper on home prices there in the short term, Liao predicted.
At the other end of the spectrum, Liao said there is a shortage of nearly 90,000 homes in Taipei city, which boasts 9.41 million households but has only 8.51 million homes available.

Three other counties -- Yunlin, Kaohsiung and Tainan -- also have experienced a shortage of housing but the deficit, varying from 13,000 to 15,000 units, is not great enough to raise the prices of homes there too steeply, Liao went on.
Taipei and Taoyuan counties are two counties other than Taichung with an oversupply of homes, showing a surplus of 59,000 homes and 56,000 homes respectively, Liao went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CALLS FOR KMT-PFP SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) called Sunday for an urgent summit between the PFP and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to present a united front against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) push for renaming the state-run enterprises and to iron out ways for cooperation in the 2008 presidential race.
Opposition PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun issued the call at a Legislative Yuan news conference.

According to Lee, the ongoing name change campaign for the state-run enterprises, one in a series of the DPP's pro-independence moves, will eventually lead Taiwan to an economic and national security disaster.

The DPP administration's recent decision to change the name of several state- owned companies, such as Chunghwa Post, Chinese Petroleum Corp., China Shipbuilding Corp. and Central Bank of China, will have a far-reaching and negative impact on Taiwan's economy, Lee warned.

Lee criticized President Chen Shui-bian for only seeking to grasp greater power and of ignoring a U. S. backlash on the name change issue, and he opined that a summit should be held as soon as possible between PFP Chairman James Soong and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to discuss countermeasures to cope with possible implications arising from the DPP's name change drive.

PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung echoed Lee's comments and opined that budget for relevant agencies should be slashed and that a referendum should be called to allow the public to have a say on the name change issue so as to stop the DPP from further fueling the matter.

The PFP and the KMT, which recently established a new alliance between them, also have to put forward their blueprints for national development and cross- Taiwan Strait exchanges, despite the fact that Ma has been dogged by the possibility of indictment on embezzlement charges related to alleged mishandling of special municipal funds for his discretionary use while serving as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006, Liu argued.
Although Soong is currently in the United States, Liu said, the PFP chairman will definitely offer to contribute through the mechanisms based upon the new KMT-PFP alliance.

Challenging former U.S. first lady Hillary Clinton, Democratic Senator Barack Obama has launched his presidential bid with call for an end to Iraq war and pledging to build a more hopeful America.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VISITS KINMEN

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou paid a visit to the Chen's Family Clan Association on Kinmen Sunday as part of his tour of grass-root communities on the outlying island.

Ma received a warm welcome from Chen family members when he visited an 100-year- old ancestral hall of the largest family organization on Kinmen island, with the family unfurling a red banner and opening the main gate to welcome him.
Chen Shui-Tzai, president of the Chen Clan Association said opening the main gate is not common, with openings occurring only three times during the previous Lunar New Year holidays.

Chen added local residents understand that Ma was troubled by the embezzlement charges related to his alleged misuse of special municipal funds when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006, and that they believe in his moral soundness and integrity.

He also expressed his belief that 90 percent of people on the island would support Ma's run in the 2008 presidential election, and gave voice to his hope that Ma's resolution and aspirations to serve the country, government and people will not undermined by political manipulation.

Meanwhile Ma insisted on his innocence, saying that he expects prosecution authorities will look into the case based on justice, that he will appeal to reason to prove his innocence, and he will fulfill the responsibilities entrusted to him by the 23 million people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHERRY SAPLINGS FROM JAPAN PLANTED IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK

TEXT.P: The Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration held a ceremony in the park in Tainan Saturday to plant 250 cherry saplings donated by a Japanese cherry cultivation association and unveil a commemorate tablet marking friendship between Taiwan and Japan.

The Chimei Group Founder Shi Wen-long, Huang Kun-hu, a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, and scores of Japanese businessmen were present at the ceremony, according to a spokesman for the agency.

During the ceremony, the Japanese businessmen performed Japanese folk songs, accompanied by Shi on mandolin, with the aim of creating the atmosphere of cherry blossoms appreciation event in Japan, the spokesman said.

Tai Chien, deputy minister of the National Science Council, said on the occasion that a total of 15 Japanese firms were stationed in the park which has established the closest relationship with Japan among all of the science parks in Taiwan.

He added, following a recommendation from Huang, that the cherry cultivation association agreed to donate 250 cherry saplings to the park, he said in the near future, not only local residents but also the Japanese firms' employees will have the chance to observe Japanese cherry blossoms in the park.

Huang expressed the hope that the cherry planting drive will enhance exchanges between the two countries, adding that if the Hsinchu Science Park and the Central Taiwan Science Park are interested in initiating similar projects, he will be glad to lend them his support.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER SAID TO TAKE PART IN KMT PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARIES

TEXT.P: A close aide of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng confirmed Sunday that Wang does not exclude the possibility of his running the 2008 presidential race "to live up to the people's expectations."

Although running in the presidential race, continuing to be the legislative speaker and retiring to become a farmer are all options for Wang in the coming two years, the aide said that since there are so many voices from the grass- roots calling on him to run, Wang will probably throw his hat in the opposition Kuomintang primary after Chinese New Year to try to win the party's nomination.

The aide said once Wang wins in the KMT primaries, he will then appoint a vice presidential candidate as his running-mate, hinting that Wang will not be running with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on the 2008 KMT presidential ticket, as many have speculated.
Ma, widely viewed as the KMT's best bet in the 2008 presidential race, has until Sunday said no word about his presidential bid, although he has intensified grass-roots visits since late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 POSTAL SAVINGS DEPOSITS EXCEED NT$4 TRILLION, HITTING NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: In 2006 total postal savings deposits surpassed NT$4 trillion (US$123 billion) , marking a record high, according to the latest tallies released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

Tallies of Chunghwa postal businesses showed the 2006 total postal savings deposits in Taiwan amounted to NT$4 trillion, an increase of NT$363.8 billion, or 9.9 percent, compared to the previous year.

The postal savings system accounted for 15.4% of total deposits among all financial institutions in Taiwan in 2006, representing a 0.6 percent year-on- year increase, while the total value of postal simple life insurance was NT$830 billion, a decrease of NT$ 23.3 billion, or 2.7 percent, compared with the previous year.
The value of money orders transferred by postal services reached NT$1491.1 billion, posting an increase of NT 85.8 billion, or 6.1 percent, year-on-year.

Meanwhile, a total of 17.9 million postal parcels were delivered in 2006, or 49,000 parcels on average per day. This represents a 13.5 percent growth over last year, marking the fourth consecutive yearly rise of its kind, according to the tallies.

The number of letters posted reached 2.66 billion in 2006, an average of 7.3 million per day, a drop of 5.2 percent from the previous year. The decline was mainly due to the competition from the private sector and the impact and increasing prevalence of online and electronic payment options.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN HAS NOT YET THOUGHT ON RUNNING MATE ISSUE

TEXT.P: The top priority for the Kuomintang (KMT) now is to unite and field the most qualified ticket to take back power in the 2008 presidential election, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.

Brushing aside a media report that he had discussed the issue of forming a presidential ticket with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng during a Friday meeting with KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, Ma clarified that he has not thought of the question and added that he only mentioned to Lien that there must be only one ticket to represent the KMT in the next presidential poll.
Ma said that he has yet to officially announce his presidential bid and that he has never thought about with whom he should form a ticket to run in the race for the KMT.
Ma made the remarks at a seminar with KMT Taipei city committee members who urged him to quickly make public his presidential bid for the sake of the nation's overall interests.

According to Ma's aides, the KMT's presidential candidate must be produced in line with the party's mechanisms. Once the party's presidential hopeful is decided, whether through negotiations within the party or through its primaries, he or she is entitled to choose a running mate, they said, adding that it is pointless to discuss the question of who and who should form a presidential ticket.
Earlier the same day, Wang also claimed that he had not considered forming a ticket with Ma to run in the next president poll. "I need more time to carefully assess the issue," he said.

Wang also denied a media report that he might team up with a running mate from the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, arguing that he never discussed such an option or revealed such an intent.

Meanwhile, KMT lawmakers voiced their worry that there have been no signs of cooperation between Ma and Wang, despite high public expectations that the two men should team up to run in the 2008 presidential election.

According to KMT lawmaker Hsu Shu-po, grass-roots supporters keenly wish to see Ma and Wang form a ticket to represent the KMT in the next presidential election. But he said that there have been no signs that the two KMT key men will collaborate in this regard, a development he called "worrisome."

"Aides surrounding Ma must realize that it will be very difficult for the KMT to take back power if Ma doesn't team up with Wang in the 2008 presidential race, " Hsu said, urging both Ma and Wang to unite and face up to reality, and warning that DPP heavyweights have started to coordinate on producing a combative candidate for the next presidential race.
Stating that support for a Ma-Wang presidential ticket remains strong among the rank and file, KMT lawmaker Lai Shyh-bao encouraged the two men to "have a talk and settle the issue."

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGE DRIVE HELPS BOOST TAIWAN IDENTITY: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The government's ongoing name change campaign for state-run companies is very helpful in galvanizing the people's identification with Taiwan, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Sunday.
Yu made the remarks while giving a speech at a ceremony in central Changhua county during which more than 100 new party workers took an oath to serve the DPP.

Defending the name change campaign that he launched earlier this month, Yu contended that the drive will certainly boost the identification of the people of Taiwan with the country. "The more the issue is being talked about, the more the people will feel akin to Taiwan," he argued.

He further pointed out that the United States has no right to meddle in Taiwan's internal matters, like the ongoing name change campaign for state-run enterprises, and called for a customized constitution and joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan" making Taiwan a normal country.
Meanwhile, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou voiced his opposition to the ruling DPP's name change drive at a seminar with the party's Taipei city committee members.

Reminding the DPP government that such a meaningless move will only waste the taxpayers' money and create concerns in other countries, like the United States, Ma questioned whether the name change drive is the DPP's first step towards a formal declaration of Taiwan's independence.
Arguing that the DPP's "bossing around" will gain no public support, Ma said that he was reserved about a proposal that the KMT should dramatically respond to the DPP's name change drive.
The KMT must refrain from dancing to the tune of the DPP, which has been seeking to divert public attention away from its corruption and incompetence, said Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT GIVES COLD SHOULDER TO PFP'S CALL FOR SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers gave the cold shoulder to their political allies in the People First Party (PFP) Sunday over the PFP's call for a summit between the two parties to field jointly a pair of candidates in the 2008 presidential election.

In response to PFP lawmaker Lee Hung-chun's call earlier that day for a meeting of leaders of the two parties, KMT lawmaker Wu Chih-yang said that as no PFP politician has thus far expressed any interest in running in the presidential election only KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and KMT Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng are likely to enter the race.

Noting that the KMT has its own process to choose candidates, Wu said the competition between Ma and Wang for the chance to stand for the presidency on the KMT ticket should be dealt with via this process, or through discussions between the two contestants themselves, rather than a summit involving current and former leaders of the KMT and PFP.
Wu's statement referred to Lee's suggestion that the summit include former KMT Chairman Lien Chan, PFP Chairman James Soong in addition to the two hopefuls of Ma and Wang.

KMT lawmaker Hsu Shu-po claimed the summit should be held only after the KMT chooses its presidential candidate according to its own rules, adding that a decision reached at a KMT-PFP summit may not be acceptable to the New Party and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union -- two tiny political groups also included in the "Pan-blue alliance" -- unless they too are invited to the summit.

Another KMT lawmaker, Lai Shih-bao was also not in favor of the summit, arguing that as the existing alliance between the two parties has provided both sides with channels of communications, "there is no point of bypassing these to hold a summit."

In addition to the 2008 presidential election, Lee Hung-chun urged the two parties take advantage of the summit to discuss putting forth a united front on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's push to purge the words "China" and "Chinese" from the names of all state-own companies, but his call drew a blank from his KMT counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTBOOKS OMIT JAPAN'S INVASION OF CHINA TO AVOID REPEAT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government-approved history textbooks for local senior high schools omit Japanese aggression against China to avoid a repeat of the depiction of the war, an education official said Sunday.

Chen Yi-hsing, head of the Secondary Education Department under the Ministry of Education, said the Sino-Japanese War between 1937 and 1945 had been mentioned in the textbooks of eighth grade at junior high school, and a repeat of it in the history textbooks of the junior high school will unnecessarily increase the students' study burden.

In order to support his claims, Chen cited a guideline issued by the education ministry for publishing companies on compiling history textbooks which said the textbooks of the senior high school should not give too much description of the Sino-Japanese War as it has already been mentioned in the history textbooks of the junior high school.

He made the remarks in response to a criticism from the United Evening News which broke the news on Sunday about the disappearance of Japan's aggression against China from the new textbooks published by many private companies, saying it has caused an uproar among local history teachers. It is especially ironical, the paper claimed, as the Rape of Nanking, in which Imperial Japanese Army killed 300,000 Chinese civilians after seizing that city of China's than-capital in 1937, will reach its 70th anniversary at Dec. 12 this year.

The newspaper also quoted some teachers as criticising the administration of the Democratic Progressive Party, which is campaigning to purge the island's of any Chinese influence, for trying to cover up Japanese brutality toward Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 12, or the 25th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Abraham Lincoln, the U.S. president who was assassinated a few days after the end of the American Civil War, is born.
1851: Fortune hunters rush to the town of Bathurst in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, Australia, in search of gold.
1895: Japan scores an impressive victory at Weihaiwei in northern China when Japanese forces quickly breach Chinese defenses and sink most of its northern navy in the war between the Ching court and Japan which broke out in 1894.
1899: Germany purchases the Marianas Islands, the Caroline Islands, and Palau from Spain.
1908: The first global Grand Prix is inaugurated at Times Square in New York.
1912: Henry Pu Yi abdicates as emperor of China, ending the rule of the Manchu dynasty.
1941: A group of researchers led by Howard Florey of Australia and Ernst Chain of Germany develop a method of extracting and purifying small amounts of penicillin, which was first used by physicians to treat a human a day later when the drug was given to a British policeman suffering from blood poisoning.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan announces that the total membership of the Republic of China National Assembly, under the period of national emergency, shall be 1,576.
1964: Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida arrives in the ROC to confer with President Chiang Kai-shek.
1970: Express trains collide north of Hsinchu, in northern Taiwan, killing 10 and injuring 47.
1974: Chang Kwang-shih, ROC vice minister of economic affairs, returns from Saudi Arabia, where he signed a memorandum of economic coorperation.
1974: Soviet Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn is arrested in Moscow and exiled the following day.
1974: Raimundo Guerrero, chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1975: The people of South Korea vote to adopt a new constitution that gives the president almost unlimited power and permits him to serve an unlimited number of terms.
1976: Six hundred members of the ROC's National Federation of Industries Association, National Federation of Businesses Association, and the Industrial and Business Association meet and pledge to support government economic policy.
1976: The first Sino-Japanese exhibition of modern painting opens, with more than 52 works by contemporary Japanese artists on display.
1980: Hong Kong's subway is formally inaugurated.
1987: The U.S. Air Force successfully launches "Titan 3B" missiles into orbit above the North and South Poles.
1992: Mongolia's new non-communist constitution takes effect.
1996: Yasser Arafat becomes the first president of Palestine.
1996: Faced with threatening military maneuvers undertaken by Beijing, the ROC Executive Yuan sets up a temporary policymaking task force to closely follow developments and coordinate the actions of various agencies to respond to the situation.
1997: Hwang Jang Yop, a confidant of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, defects in Beijing and seeks asylum in South Korea.
1999: The U.S. Senate votes against removing President Bill Clinton from office in the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
2000: Taiwan doctor Chen Chiu-huang wins the 2000 award of the Foundation de Enterprise Montblanc de la Culture of Britain.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Extravagance leads to excess; thrift to meanness; but it is better to be mean than to be guilty of excess."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
MOFA MUM ON REPORTED REPLACEMENT OF REP TO SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman declined to comment Monday on a newspaper report that just-retired Armed Forces Chief-of-Staff Lee Tien-yu will be assigned to serve as Taiwan's representative to Singapore, replacing Hu Wei- chen.
MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said neither he nor the foreign ministry have any idea about the report, carried in Monday's United Daily News.

The daily said that Gen. Lee, who retired from the military chief of staff post just last month, will be appointed by President Chen Shui-bian soon as Taiwan's new representative in Singapore, replacing Hu, who has served in the post for more than two years.
According to the daily, Lee's appointment will be part of a "major reshuffle" of military personnel that President Chen has pushed to carry out since January.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR COUNCIL TO REVIEW MINIMUM WAGE

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is set to convene a meeting after the Chinese New Year holidays to discuss adjusting the country's minimum wage, which has remained unchanged at NT$15,840 (US$481) per month for the last nine years, CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said Monday.

Lee said that whether to adjust the minimum wage and by how much is a matter for a CLA basic wage screening committee to decide, although he added that he personally feels the minimum wage should be raised to better reflect current realities.

Lee said he sees an upward adjustment of the NT$15,840 minimum wage as necessary given the fact that over 90 percent of Taiwan's laborers earn over NT$20,000 a month, that the country's unemployment rate fell to a new six-year low of 3.91 percent in 2006, and that many local companies have reported a shortage of labor.

The top labor affairs official also noted that some firms have suggested that the minimum wage for foreign laborers be de-linked from that for Taiwan citizens so that they can continue to employ foreign laborers at low costs. Lee said that he does not think this is something that the CLA will do anytime soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST SET OF 'TAIWAN STAMPS' TO BE ISSUED FEB. 28

TEXT.P: Taiwan Post Co. is expected to issue the first set of "Taiwan stamps" Feb. 28 featuring the Taipei 228 Memorial Museum as the theme of their design, officials said Monday.
The issuance will be the first carrying the mark "Taiwan stamp" after the company changed its name from "Chunghwa Post Co." to "Taiwan Post Co."

However, other stamps issued by the company in the first quarter of this year will still be printed with the mark "Republic of China stamp, " as the issuance of stamps requires preparation in advance, the officials said.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications ordered the company to prepare for the issuance of the set of "Taiwan stamps" last year, long before the company was renamed, to make it in time for its issuance on Feb. 28, they said, adding that the issuance of "Republic of China stamps" will stop completely in April at the earliest.

The board of Chunghwa Post Co. approved a proposal to rename the company Taiwan Post Co. Friday amid the government's efforts to change the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China. "Chunghwa" means "Chinese" or "China" in the Chinese language.
Also Friday, Chinese Petroleum Corp. decided to change its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " while China Shipbuilding Corp. decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan."
The Cabinet claims the name rectification campaign will help avoid confusion resulting from Taiwan-based organizations carrying similar names to organizations in China.
President Chen Shui-bian said last week that similar changes will also be made to the names of the country's overseas embassies and representative offices in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN HELPERS ENTITLED TO REASONABLE TIME OFF, PERSONAL SPACE

TEXT.P: Foreign domestic helpers are entitled to a reasonable amount of time off and personal space, and employers who violate this right will be subject to fines, Taipei City's top official in charge of labor affairs said Monday.

Su Ying-kuei, director of the Taipei City Department of Labor, said that beginning from March 1, all of the 914 Taipei families who employ foreign helpers will be required to provide a single room exclusively for the domestic helper's use and to allow the helper to sleep for at least eight consecutive hours, as demanded by the Philippine authorities in charge of overseas employment.
Violators will be fined between NT$60,000 (US$1,817) to NT$300,000 (US$9,085) and repeat violators could have their permits to hire foreign helpers revoked, Su noted.

Although the personal space and minimum eight-hour sleeping time requirements were requested by the Philippine government, the requirements will also be applicable to Taipei families who employ domestic helpers from other foreign countries, Su added.
Su made the announcement at a news conference to which officials from the representative offices of the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam and Indonesia were also invited to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO SETS UP BOOTH AT BERLIN FILM FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/07 15:04:28 (By Lin Yu-li & Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Government Information Office (GIO) has for the first time set up a booth at the Berlin International Film Festival as part of its efforts to help local filmmakers expand into overseas markets.
At the film festival, being held Feb. 8-18, the GIO is promoting seven Taiwan- produced films, including director Leste Chen's "Eternal Summer", Zero Chou's "Spider Lilies" and Arvin Chen's "Mei".

Simon Hsieh, an offical in the GIO's Motion Pictures Department said that the GIO has in the past assisted local filmmakers in taking part in major international film festivals in Cannes, Pusan and the United States.

To help Taiwan filmmakers break into international markets, Hsieh said, the GIO is also interested in working with the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), adding that the two organizations have been engaged in consultations over the matter.

Hsieh said that the GIO hopes to use the TAITRA's marketing experience and strong overseas presence to help in efforts to have Taiwan filmmakers participate in even more international film festivals, including those in Hong Kong, Beijing and Singapore.

Also during the 57th Berlin Film Festival, the GIO will hold a "Taiwan Night" cocktail party at Berlin's Hotel Marriott on Feb. 12, with Taiwan's representative to Germany, Shieh Jhy-wey, to host the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PREMIER URGES FOLLOWING PRIMARY SYSTEM TO SELECT DPP CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: One of the 2008 presidential election hopefuls of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) expressed the hope Monday that the process of selecting the party's candidate for the election will follow the current primary system as much as possible.
Former Premier Frank Hsieh made the remarks when he met with grass-roots DPP members in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.
Hsieh said the DPP should have "teamwork in mind" and choose a candidate who has the best chance of winning the election, while the others help with the election campaign.
"None of the hopefuls should have a 'zero-sum' mindset," he said, adding that not having this mindset would make the hopefuls more relaxed in taking part in the party's primary.
Hsieh also said that primary regulations should not be changed unless agreement on the matter is reached among all the hopefuls.
"To change the rules of the game after it starts will not work in democratic politics," he added.

Hsieh is one of the four DPP heavyweights said to be keen on representing the party to run in the 2008 presidential election. The other three are Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST CONDOMS SOLD AT EROTIC PRODUCT STORES NOT LICENSED: SURVEY

TEXT.P: As much as 88 percent of condoms sold in erotic product stores have not passed inspections by the health authorities, according to the results of a survey released Monday by the Consumer's Foundation.
The survey was conducted among 25 condom products sampled by the foundation from 11 erotic product stores in the city and county of Taipei from Feb. 3-4.

While all condoms sold on the market are required to be registered with the Department of Health (DOH) as a medical product and to receive a license code after passing inspection by health authorities, the survey found that 18 of the surveyed products did not carry a license code and four others had codes that did not belong to them.

The survey shows that only two products were labeled with complete information as required by the Pharmaceutical Affairs Law, including the name and address of the manufacturer, name of the product and its license code, the manufacture date or shipment identification number, as well as the expiration date.

Six of the products carried inconsistent labels in their inner and outer packagings in terms of their manufacture and expiration dates, and four others had passed their expiration dates, according to the survey.
Meanwhile, among 18 condom products with special fragrances, 12, or 67 percent, either did not indicate their ingredients at all or failed to label their ingredients clearly, the survey shows.

Responding to the results of the survey, foundation chairman Cheng Jen-hung urged the DOH to step up its inspection of condoms sold on the Taiwan market and fine manufacturers failing to comply with the regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUNIOR HIGH STUDENTS LEARN HOW TO PREPARE 'ANTI-CANCER' DISHES

TEXT.P: A total of 40 junior high students had the privilege Monday to learn from chefs from a five-star restaurant how to prepare dishes for Chinese New Year feasts that are also nourishing and supposedly prevent cancer.

The students, selected from families with cancer sufferers around Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu, attended a cooking session at the Formosa Regent Taipei, where top-notch chef Chen Chao-teng led a team of five cooks who demonstrated the preparation of six Chinese New Year dishes that are nutritious and particularly good for cancer sufferers.

The six dishes were a healthy hors d'oeuvre, a Buddha-Leaps-Over-the- Wall pot, steamed baby abalone with garlic, rainbow fresh scallops, a garden vegetable assortment and mashed taro with dried nuts.

Dietician Chiang Hsiao-min, who also attended the session, said almost all the materials and ingredients used in the six dishes are good for the health and that the vegetables, with their antioxidant elements, are especially good for cancer sufferers.

Fifteen-year-old Wu Po-tseng said his mother has been cancer-afflicted since his childhood and that he had no idea how to help with his mom. He said cooking the garden vegetable assortment was difficult, but he learned how to do it nevertheless and will prepare the dish for his mother during the Chinese New Year holidays.

Thirteen-year-old Chang Ting-yao from Taoyuan -- who came under the spotlight a week ago when his story of taking care of his colorectal cancer-afflicted father alone since he was an elementary school student -- also attended the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,826.46 and closed at the day's low of 7,767.41. A total of 2.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$77.48 billion (US$2.35 billion).

Losers outnumbered gainers 905 to 283, with 200 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DECLARES DIFFERENT STANCE TO THAT OF DPP

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui, who used to be reputed as the "godfather of Taiwan independence, " has recently said he shares no common views with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and has declared that his future efforts will focus on the "reconstruction of democratic Taiwan."
Lee made the remarks during an interview with the Sankei Shimbun, a mass- circulation Japanese economic daily. The interview was published in the paper's Monday edition.
Lee reiterated that Taiwan is an independent and sovereign country that is faced with the problem of how to become a "normal" country, rather than how to seek independence.
Taiwan should endeavor to make up the "deficiencies" that impede its sovereignty as a democratic independent country, Lee said.

Talking about the future development of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which regards Lee as its "spiritual leader, " Lee said the party is undergoing a complete reconstruction under the leadership of Huang Kun-huei, who took over the chairmanship last month.

While the party is working on amendments to its platform and a name change, Lee said it will cut its political ties with the DPP, concentrating on work aimed at putting together a Taiwan-centric consciousness.

In reply to questions about his controversial remarks published by Next Magazine in early February in which the magazine claimed he was "giving up independence, open to investment from China and looking forward to visiting China, " Lee claimed that Taiwan's economic growth is stagnated while the number of unemployed is growing and the gap between the rich and poor is expanding.
For all that, Lee claimed that the ruling party is still reluctant to make efforts to resolve the problems but is concentrating on a power struggle with the opposition Kuomintang.
The DPP's economic policy is a "failure, " according to Lee, who suggested that the ruling party try to correct its wrongs while making efforts to end interparty conflicts.
He also claimed that he has never considered visiting China under communist rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE IN U.S., CANADA SOUGHT AS VOLUNTEER ENGLISH TEACHERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/12/07 18:17:53 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is inviting ethnic Chinese youths residing in the United States or Canada to take part in a volunteer English teaching program this summer, Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) officials posted in the U.S. capital said Monday.

The program, which is organized by the OCAC and the Ministry of Education, aims to recruit 250 participants who will serve as volunteer English teachers in schools in remote areas of Taiwan this summer vacation, the officials said.

Registration is being accepted until Feb. 21 at OCAC service offices around the United States or through the OCAC Web site at www.ocac.gov.tw, with ethnic Chinese aged between 16 and 27 who speak English as their mother tongue welcome to take part, the officials said.

The program, scheduled to run from July 16-Aug. 13, will include an English teaching training course in the first week, teaching at designated schools in the second and third weeks, and a round-the-island tour in the fourth week, the officials said.

While the participants will have to pay for their own travel expenses to and from Taiwan, their meals, accommodation and transportation in Taiwan will be covered by the organizers, they said, adding that the participants will be issued a service certificate at the conclusion of the month-long program.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR TO WELCOME WIFE'S HOMECOMING WITH '100 ROSES'

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Monday that he will have 100 roses ready to welcome his wife Shirley Shaw's first return home since being admitted to hospital following a serious traffic accident in late November.

With Shaw's steady recuperation over the last three months and with the recent removal of the steel brace on her partially amputated left arm, Hu said he asked doctors to grant his wife "a three-day leave" from hospital to spend the Chinese New Year holiday at home with him.

Doctors at the China Medical University Hospital agreed to his request but also urged that Shaw spend most of her time in bed while at home as "her bones are still as fragile as sugar cane, " according to Hu.

The traffic accident occurred on the evening of Nov. 18 when Hu and his wife were heading home to Taichung from a campaign rally in Kaohsiung along the north-bound section of the Formosa Freeway. Their car rolled over after it was hit by a vehicle that was trying to pass a truck. Shaw sustained serious injuries in the accident and was unconscious when she arrived at Chimei Hospital in Tainan. Hu also sustained minor injuries in the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO RESPOND TO TRANSITIONAL JUSTICE AT 2 28 ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The government will respond to the issue of transitional justice around Feb. 28, the 60th anniversary of the tragic 2 28 Incident, Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Monday.

Cheng made the remarks amid reports that Wu Nai-teh, a researcher at Academia Sinica, the nation's highest research institute, was preparing to form a private sector truth and reconciliation commission.

Wu expressed hope that the historical facts about the 2 28 Incident of 1947 and the ensuing "white terror" imposed by the former Kuomintang administration will come to light in full to serve as part of democracy education and avoid any repetition of the tragedy, according to the reports.
Cheng said it would be more suitable for the government to conduct some of the probes but added that some could be done by the private sector and that the government would support such efforts.
He noted that transitional justice is an issue for all emerging democratic countries seeking to resolve the legacy of authoritarian rule.

"Through reflection on transitional justice, Taiwan will be able to deepen and cement its democratic system, " Cheng said, adding that the methods used by other countries, including probes into truth and accounting for responsibility, can provide a good reference.
Noting that 2007 is the 60th anniversary of the 2 28 Incident, when Kuomintang forces crushed a revolt in Taiwan, Cheng said that "it is an appropriate time to discuss transitional justice."

He added that the transitional justice issue will not only cover the 2 28 Incident but will also include the ensuing white terror and all other controversial incidents that took place during the previous authoritarian era.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW TO RESIGN FROM NTUH

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) confirmed Monday it has approved the resignation of President Chen Shui-bian's disgraced son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming.
Chao's resignation will take effect Feb. 14, according to NTUH spokesman Lin Ho- hsiung.
There have been reports that Chao has been hired by Sin Lau Hospital in southern Tainan City, but the hospital declined to confirm the reports.
Chao, who was an orthopedic surgeon at NTUH, was suspended from duty immediately after he was indicted in July 2006 on charges of insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stocks.
NTUH voted down Chao's request to return to his job in October on the grounds that he "seriously violated medical ethics."

The Taipei District Court sentenced Chao to six years in prison and fined him NT$30 million (US$909,090) in December after determining that he took advantage of his influence to obtain important information regarding TDC share prices, based upon which he traded TDC shares for huge profits.

According to the court, Chao got more than NT$54 million in actual gains from the trading together with his father, although pro forma earnings calculated in accordance with the Securities Transaction Act amounted to only NT$4.27 million.
Chao has appealed his case to the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Meat from bird-flu farm was sent abroad
An investigation was under way last night after claims that poultry meat was exported from the Suffolk farm at the centre of the bird flu outbreak after the disease was identified.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU SOLICITING NEW NAME FOR THE PARTY

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will run an ad Tuesday to solicit a new name for the party, TSU officials said Monday.
The ad will describe the TSU as a political party that insists on a Taiwan- centric path and that speaks for the middle-class and the underprivileged, the officials said.
"To demonstrate the new direction of the TSU, the party will need a new name," the ad will say.

TSU officials urged the public to look at the TSU's Web site at www.tsu.org.tw and enter their proposed names in a competition for the chance to win NT$100,000 (US$3,050) in cash for the winning name.
New TSU Chairman Huang Kung-huei said upon assuming the post last month that he will engage in party overhaul in an effort to win public trust.
Huang said at the time that he is also considering whether to change the name of the party to project a clear set of values to "rekindle the passion of the people."
The TSU was founded by former Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen in July 2001 with former President Lee serving as its "spiritual leader."

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO TALK WITH CHINA ON GRAVEL EXPORT BAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government has commissioned the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TETRA) to make initial contact with related agencies in China on its ban on gravel exports slated to take effect March 1, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.
MAC Chief Secretary Jan Jyh-horng said gravel imported from China accounts for one-fifth of Taiwan's total demand, showing that gravel from China is very important to Taiwan.
Jan said he hopes cross-strait consultations will have good results and that the measure will not be detrimental to Taiwan.

Asked about the government's contingency plans in the event of a Chinese ban, Jan said only that the Ministry of Economic Affairs has made efforts to help expand its resources, including increasing the amount of domestic dredging and imports from other countries.
But he also said the measures will require a period of adjustment and expressed hope that China's gravel exports will not undergo dramatic changes in the short term.
China originally announced that its gravel export ban would start May 1 last year but later put it on hold. It announced last month that the ban would start March 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECTIFYING NATIONAL TITLE TOPS ALL NAME-CHANGE ISSUES: TSU

TEXT.P: A spokeswoman for opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) told the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government Monday that rectifying Taiwan's national title tops all other name-change efforts.

Commenting the ongoing campaign aimed at changing the names of state-owned enterprises to avoid people mistaking Taiwan companies for Chinese ones, Chiang Yueh-chin said the TSU lauds the government's determination to fortify Taiwan's national identity by pushing for the changes, but considers the efforts made by the government "hasty, not delicate enough and lacking sufficient communication."

Chiang said the TSU considers rectifying Taiwan's national title is the most important. As the DPP administration-initiated constitutional amendments have raised the threshold for revising the Constitution to allow for a change of the national title, Chiang said she remains skeptical of the DPP government's sincerity to reach that goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRISBANE MAYOR PRAISES KAOHSIUNG'S CONSTRUCTION ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: Brisbane Mayor Campbell Newman expressed upon his return from Taiwan Sunday his admiration for the achievements of the southern port city of Kaohsiung in terms of city construction.

Newman visited Taiwan Feb. 5-10 to attend celebrations for the 10th anniversary of the formation of sisterhood ties between Brisbane and Kaohsiung. During the visit, he also visited Taipei City and called at the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

Speaking about his trip, Newman praised Kaohsiung for its waterfront construction and the scenic landscaping of the Love river that runs through the port city. "The beautiful waterfront establishments amazed me, " he said, expressing his confidence in Kaohsiung's future development.
"In a few years, Kaohsiung will be much more beautiful, " Newman said.

James C.K. Tien, Taiwan's representative to Brisbane who helped organize Newman's visit, said that the mayor has attached importance to Brisbane- Kaohsiung exchanges in various fields since assuming office three years ago.
As a result of Newman's attention, he said, bilateral relations between the two cities have also been promoted in the diplomatic field.
During their stay in Kaohsiung, Newman and his delegation visited city officials and business representatives and organized a presentation to introduce Brisbane's investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR COUNCIL PUSHES FOR PENSION REFORM

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) aims to put in place a monthly pension system for labor insurance by 2009, CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said Monday.
The trends toward longer life expectancy and fewer kids have made a pension system more necessary, Lee said at a news conference held to outline the council's objectives in 2007.

Currently the old-age benefit in labor insurance is paid in a lump sum. The Conference on Sustaining Taiwan's Economic Development held July agreed to change the system, considered to be outdated, into a monthly pension system.
Lee said he hopes that an amendment to the Labor Insurance Act will be passed by the end of this year, so as to allow implementation of the pension system in 2009.

According to the CLA's calculations under its pension program, a worker with an insured wage of NT$43,900 will monthly pay NT$483 in labor insurance premiums and, over 22 years from retirement until death, will be repaid more than 19 times over for the total premiums paid over 40 years of work.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HONORARY CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR UNITY TO WIN PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan reiterated Monday a call for party unity if it wants to regain power in the 2008 presidential election, but he did not volunteer to coordinate a presidential candidate within the party, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said later that same day.

According to Wang, Lien invited him to the meeting and the KMT honorary chairman issued the call during their hour-long closed-door discussion. But Wang added that Lien did not say he would help coordinate the KMT's presidential candidacy between KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Wang himself. Wang is also a KMT stalwart.

The Lien-Wang meeting came at a sensitive time as Ma, the former mayor of Taipei who ended his tenure in December last year and who is the KMT's most likely candidate in the 2008 presidential race, is being investigated for his alleged misuse of special municipal funds earmarked for his discretionary use during his mayoral term.

Speaking with a group of reporters earlier that same day at the Legislative Yuan, Wang said that the party's unity must be built upon sincerity and consensus through discussion and coordination and that the KMT must not deceive itself if it hopes to achieve that aim.

Wang's remarks came after Ma said during a meeting with a group of farmers at the KMT's Taitung County chapter in eastern Taiwan that it is better to conduct intra-party negotiations when the party's aspirants in the 2008 presidential election have all publicly announced their bids.

"Winning back power for the KMT was one of my promises made to KMT members when I took part in the party's chairmanship election in 2005," Ma emphasized. He made it clear that "the KMT cannot afford to have another split" and that "the party must field only one ticket to run in the 2008 presidential race."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COULD BECOME NORMAL COUNTRY IN 10 YEARS: DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan could become a normal country in 10 years if backed by a tailor-made constitution and a Legislative Yuan dominated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Monday.

The DPP could make Taiwan a normal and competitive country in a decade if the party is fully committed to the goal and backed by full support from the rank and file, Yu said, adding that Taiwan still dreams of joining the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" and of acquiring sufficient defensive weapons to safeguard the nation's security.

In response to criticism from main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying- jeou that the name change campaign for the state-run enterprises, being promoted by the DPP administration, is "unaccountable, " Yu clarified that he began broaching the idea to underscore Taiwan identity as early as in January 2005 while serving as premier.

The current name change drive was by no means a hasty move or campaign ploy aimed solely at solidifying grass-roots support for the DPP ahead of the December legislative elections, he argued, adding that the redesignation of state-owned companies is part of the DPP administration's goal of making Taiwan a normal and complete country.

Since Yu rekindled the name change campaign earlier this month during a DPP's Central Standing Committee meeting, several state-owned enterprises have been renamed, including the nation's shipbuilding and postal companies, as well as the petroleum provider.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Nuclear Talks on North Korea Hit Roadblock
Negotiations on a step-by-step deal that the Bush administration hopes will lead North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons program appeared near collapse on Sunday over North Koreas demands for huge shipments of fuel oil and electricity before agreeing to a schedule for turning over its nuclear weapons and fuel.
The chief American envoy, Christopher R. Hill, said he and North Koreas envoy, Kim Kye-gwan, held a lengthy and very frank meeting on Sunday. But Mr. Hill seemed much less optimistic that a deal could be struck. Negotiators are planning to end the talks on Monday, and other envoys were pessimistic that any breakthrough would emerge on the final day.
Wall Street Journal:London Parents Scramble for Edge In Preschool Wars
London, like Manhattan, is one of the most extreme examples for preschool admissions mania. At nearly all private schools here, parents must apply as soon as children are born.
Some schools grant spots on the basis of those applications. At others, applying at birth might merely win a chance for a child to interview and test for admission when he or she is ready for elementary school at four. Parents who don't apply early or who move to London with a small child are often out of luck.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA UNVEILS 'HAPPINESS' PROGRAM FOR WAGE EARNERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has come up with a NT$10 billion (US$303 million) program to provide new welfare services for the country's 8 million wage earners, CLA officials said Monday.

According to the new "Happiness" plan, the CLA will earmark NT$3.7 billion for employment boosting programs; NT$2.7 billion for projects to subsidize childbirth, child care and education, including increasing childbirth subsidy from one month's salary to three months'; NT$2 billion for a plan to provide subsidies for workers to purchase residential units; and NT$1 billion for projects aimed at helping laborers improve their professional skills.
In addition, the CLA also plans to improve labor insurance benefits, including relaxing restrictions on payments to laborers who fall ill or are wounded on the job, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENAMED STATE ENTERPRISES TO KEEP TRADEMARKS

TEXT.P: Renamed state-owned petroleum and shipbuilding companies will retain the rights to their current trademarks, the two companies said Monday.

The company formerly known as the Chinese Petroleum Corp. became "CPC Corporation, Taiwan" after the company's board meeting Friday, and the China Shipbuilding Corp. is set to change its name to "CSBS Corporation, Taiwan" in March, with their respective abbreviations CPC and CSBS remaining unchanged.
The CPC also said that it will retain its well-established trademark torch, which is displayed high above every CPC gas station.

It also filed a pre-registration enquiry with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) seeking the right to use its original name; the move allows it to set up a new company under that name within six months, MOEA officials said.

Even if the CPC or the CSBS stops using its original name or trademark after the changes takes effect, the government will not --over the next few years -- register identical or similar marks proposed by other parties because the CPC and CSBS marks are well-known and receive special protection under the Trademark Act, the Intellectual Property Office said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSTAL CO. REDESIGNATION REFLECTS MAINSTREAM OPINION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that renaming the state-owned postal company to include "Taiwan" in its title complies with prevailing mainstream public opinion, which favors promotion of Taiwan's distinct national identity.

Chen made the remarks while giving a speech at a plaque-unveiling ceremony to mark the redesignation of Chunghwa Post Co. -- Chunghwa means China -- to Taiwan Post Co. as part of the government's ongoing name rectification campaign to prevent Taiwan's state-owned enterprises from being confused with similarly named Chinese counterparts.

Acknowledging that the name change campaign has inevitably met criticism, misunderstanding, opposition and obstruction, Chen said the government should nonetheless be adamant, determined and responsible in doing what it thinks is right for the nation.

If the government pulls out all the stops to fulfill "mission impossible", Chen said he believes the campaign will eventually win public support and recognition. He called for widespread public backing in future endeavors, including pushing to have the country join international organizations -- including the United Nations -- under the name "Taiwan".

According to the president, the postal company name change is completely justified and responsible. He also said the change also conveys "high praise for the country's high-quality mail system" that has served well the Taiwan people over the past 120 years.

Chen said the previous authoritarian government assumed a negative attitude toward all things Taiwanese, including the dialect, culture and artistry due to its own rigidly "Chinese supremacy" mindset and consciousness. This animosity led the past government to prohibiting private groups from using "Taiwan" in their titles.

Gone are those dark days, Chen said, adding that Taiwan has democratized and all local people should be freed from such unreasonable restrictions and courageously embrace the beautiful name of their homeland. "We should no longer hesitate to call our country Taiwan," he added.

Chen said Taiwan Post Co. will issue the first set of "Taiwan stamps" Feb. 28 featuring the Taipei 228 Memorial Museum in their design. The issuance will be the first carrying the mark "Taiwan stamp" following the company's name change from "Chunghwa Post Co." to "Taiwan Post Co." This set will be a tribute to Taiwan's century of struggle for freedom, democracy, human rights and peace, Chen said.

Speaking at the same event, Premier Su Tseng-chang described the government's name change campaign as a "justifiable move" to "recover the historical truth" and he gave his assurance that postal workers' and customers' rights and interests will not be affected by the change.

DOC.HEADLINE: REDESIGNATION NOT AIMED AT DENYING HISTORY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that renaming the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. as CPC Corp., Taiwan is not aimed at completely denying history but rather at having a company worthy of its name.

Chen made the remarks while presiding over a plaque-unveiling ceremony to mark the redesignation of Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) as CPC Corp. Taiwan as part of the government's efforts to prevent state-owned enterprises from being confused with similarly named Chinese ones.

"As the petroleum company was inaugurated in Shanghai in 1946 and moved its headquarters to Taipei along with the previous Kuomintang government in 1949, the government has decided to preserve 'chung' -- which means China -- in its Chinese title to retain its historical roots," Chen explained, adding that he believes that the inclusion of "Taiwan" in the company's new English title will bring even more business opportunity to "CPC Corp. Taiwan."

In their respective board meetings held last Friday, the Chinese Petroleum Corp. decided to change its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " China Shipbuilding Corp. decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan" and Chunghwa Post Co. decided to change its name to "Taiwan Post Co."

Chen said the postal company was first inaugurated in Taiwan in 1888 and the shipbuilding firms was established in Taiwan in the 1970s. "Both of them originated in Taiwan, so their new titles do not carry any Chinese references," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEBRUARY 13 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Feb. 13
05:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will inspect the Huangnan fruit and vegetable market in Taipei.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive a British House of Lords delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 13, or the 26th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1542: Catherine Howard, wife of English King Henry VIII, is beheaded for treason.
1668: Spain recognizes the independence of Portugal under the Treaty of Lisbon.
1692: Under English orders, Robert Campbell of Glen Lyon and his 128 men carry out the Glencoe massacre in Scotland against the MacDonald clan.
1793: Austria, Britain, Holland, Prussia, Spain, and Sardinia form an alliance against France.
1858: Captain John Speke and Sir Richard Burton become the first Europeans to discover Lake Tanganyika in East Africa.
1912: Dr. Sun Yat-sen tenders his resignation to the provisional Senate which was established in Nanking on Jan. 28, 1912. He also agrees to relinquish the provisional presidency of the Republic of China to Yuan Shih-kai, who promises to establish a republican government.
1920: Switzerland is admitted to the League of Nations.
1935: A judge sentences Bruno Hauptmann to die in the electric chair after a New Jersey jury found him guilty of kidnapping and murdering flying ace Charles Lindbergh's infant son three years earlier.
1941: The wonder drug penicillin is used for the first time on a human, a policeman from Oxford, England.
1945: U.S. warplanes bomb Dresden, Germany, killing over 35,000 civilians, while allied forces capture Budapest, Hungary.
1954: Chou Lu, a veteran revolutionary leader of the Kuomintang, dies in Taipei at the age of 70.
1957: The British Defense Ministry announces the production of its first H-bomb.
1958: Taipei area records its lowest temperature (2.6 degrees Celsius) in half a century.
1960: The French test their first atomic bomb in the Sahara Desert in Africa.
1966: The list of winners of the first 10 outstanding ROC female youth awards is announced.
1971: Spiro Agnew, vice president of the United States under President Richard Nixon, hits three spectators with his golf ball during the Bob Hope Desert Classic tournament.
1971: Aided by U.S. aircraft and artillery, South Vietnamese troops enter Laos.
1973: Minister of Economic Affairs Y. S. Sun of the ROC leaves for Bangkok to attend a meeting of the board of trustees of the Asian Institute of Technology and meet with Thai government officials.
1975: The ROC Cabinet decides to ban activities of the Christian Unification Church on the grounds that it has been violating the customs of the Chinese people.
1975: The Sino-Guatemalan and the Sino-Dominican technical cooperation agreements are approved by the ROC Cabinet.
1984: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party elects Constantin Ustinovich Chernenko as its secretary-general.
1989: Soviet troops leave Kabul, capital of Afghanistan.
1990: Boxer James Douglas is recognized as the new world heavyweight champion after knocking out Mike Tyson in Tokyo two nights earlier.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Task Force permits performing artists from Taiwan to stage commercial performances in mainland China and to participate in activities sponsored by the Chinese communists.
1991: A U.S. missile hits an air-raid shelter crowded with civilians in Baghdad, killing more than 300 people.
1994: A ferry taking illegal Burmese workers home capsizes off Thailand. More than 150 of them are feared dead.
1998: A special convention votes to make Australia a republic and promises a referendum on replacing the queen as head of state in 1999.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is composed and happy; a fool is always worried and full of distress."
