Los Angeles TimesG U.S. Makes Case That Iran Arms Flow Into Iraq.
U.S. defense and intelligence officials sought Sunday to bolster the charge that Iran was providing arms to Shiite Muslim militants in Iraq, displaying munitions and weapons fragments that they said constituted evidence that Tehran was contributing to Iraq's violence. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME RECTIFICATION 'A MATTER OF COURSE': MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday that Taiwan's ongoing name rectification campaign to remove any references to China from the names of its state-owned enterprises is a matter of course following the country's democratization.

Speaking in a meeting with a German Bundestag delegation, the country's top China policy planner pointed out that many of Taiwan's stated-owned companies and institutions have kept the words "China" or "Chinese" in their names, which he said has often caused confusion in the international community.

Noting that the practice dates back to the period of authoritarian rule by the Kuomintang (KMT) , Wu said the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration is obligated to tackle the legacies of that era, such as renaming state-owned companies by including the word "Taiwan" to make them more identifiable with their country of origin.

Acknowledging that the name change campaign has met criticism and sparked heated debate in local society and even drawn a "no support" comment from Washington, Wu said the campaign is a matter of course now that Taiwan has become a democracy and must address issues remaining from the period of authoritarian rule.

Wu further said many of Taiwan's national symbols are legacies of the previous one-party state era. For instance, Taiwan's national emblem is the KMT's party emblem, and its national anthem is the KMT's party anthem, he noted.
Since Taiwan is a democratic country and the KMT is no longer its ruling party, Wu said, the people of Taiwan are entitled to freely discuss whether its national symbols should be changed.

Wu also pointed to the national titles of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, saying that the close resemblance between the two has caused problems for both sides. Wu recalled a faux pas made by the master of a welcoming ceremony for Chinese President Hu Jintao during his visit to the United States last year when he announced the playing of the national anthem of "the Republic of China" -- Taiwan's national title -- instead of "the People's Republic of China" -- China's official name.

A similar gaffe happened recently in Grenada, with the Caribbean nation's marching band playing the national anthem of "the Republic of China" instead of that of the "People's Republic of China" during the inaugural ceremony of a China-funded stadium in the country.

To help the international community better understand that the "Republic of China" refers to democratic Taiwan, not authoritarian China, Wu said, the government has arranged for Taiwan's embassies to have the word "Taiwan" added in parenthesis to their names. He said progress has also been made in negotiations with countries with which Taiwan does not maintain diplomatic relations for similar arrangements for Taiwan's representative offices in those countries.

No matter how these issues are discussed or addressed, Wu said, the government's policy is crystal clear, namely that "so long as China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, Taiwan will not change its official title nor its anthem."
"This has been our commitment to the international community since 2000, " Wu said, adding that the government's current name rectification campaign will by no means touch on Taiwan's official title.

Nevertheless, Wu took the opportunity to voice his protest over China's customary addressing of Taiwan as "China, Taipei, " "China, Taiwan, " or "Taiwan Province of the People's Republic of China" on international occasions.

While China repeatedly threatens war if Taiwan takes steps to formalize its de facto independence, including changing its official title, it arbitrarily changes Taiwan's national title all the time, Wu said.
Equally disheartening and unfair to democratic Taiwan is that the international community has consistently kept mum over China's arbitrary change of Taiwan's official designation, he lamented.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENAMING STATE-OWNED ENTERPRISES DOES NOT CHANGE STATUS QUO: MOFA

TEXT.P: The government's recent move to rename state-owned enterprises is an internal matter which does not involve changes to the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

Asserting that any country has the right to change the names of its state-owned enterprises, MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said during a regular press briefing that the scenario that the United States is worried about has not occurred.

Since the U.S. State Department released a written statement to express its concern over the issue last week, Taiwan has not received any further messages from the United States either through formal or informal channels, Wang said, adding that communication between Taiwan and the United States remains smooth.

In the statement issued last Friday, the State Department said the United States does not support administrative steps by Taiwan that would appear to change Taiwan's status unilaterally or move toward independence, including changes in terminology for entities administered by the Taiwan authorities.

Also, the State Department called on President Chen Shui-bian to fulfill his "four noes" commitments, namely not to declare independence, not to change Taiwan's national title, not to push for inclusion of sovereignty themes in the Constitution, and not to promote a referendum to change the status quo regarding independence or unification.
The statement was issued in response to Taiwan's recent moves to rectify the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China.

While Chinese Petroleum Corp. has changed its name to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " Chunghwa Post Co. has changed its name to "Taiwan Post Co," and China Shipbuilding Corp. has decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan."
The Cabinet claims the name rectification campaign will help avoid confusion resulting from Taiwan-based organizations carrying similar names to organizations in China.
President Chen said last week that similar changes will also be made to the names of the country's overseas embassies and representative offices in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST CASE OF GERMAN MEASLES FOR THE YEAR REPORTED

TEXT.P: A 34-year-old man was diagnosed as having rubella, or German measles, in mid- January after developing high fever and rashes, the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said that the man has become the first rubella case in Taiwan this year. Staff at the center were worried that he might pass the disease on to pregnant women, but fortunately, this has not taken place.
Shih said the man has never received vaccination against rubella, measles or the mumps.
Rubella has yet to be rooted out in Taiwan, Shih said, adding that the man probably was infected through breathing in the flying particles of the saliva or the phlegm of a sick person.

He said that rubella is an illness caused by a virus. Adult men will be immune from the disease for the rest of their lives after being infected, but they are likely to pass the disease on to women, he continued.
If pregnant women are infected, this might result in a poor birth outcome, such as stillbirth, premature delivery, or birth defects.
Shih said that there were three indigenous and three imported German measles cases in Taiwan last year.

The center received 23 confirmed cases of German measles over the past five years, with most of the patients being middle-aged or old people, Shih said. The youngest female was only two years old, while the youngest male was 16. The children were infected mainly because they did not receive their shots before traveling with their parents abroad, he added.

The government has inoculated children under 15 months old against measles, rubella and the mumps since 1992. It also gave shots to primary school students and female junior high school students between 1992 and 1994, Shih said.

This means that everyone under the age of 28 has received vaccinations against measles and the mumps, he said, adding that women over the age of 28 should get shots against measles and rubella at least one month before a planned pregnancy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN NIGHT' HELD AT BERLIN FILM FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/07 14:43:51 (By Lin Yu-li and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Government Information Office held a "Taiwan Night" cocktail reception here Monday evening as part of the ongoing 57th Berlin Film Festival, with nearly 200 foreign media and movie industry representatives attending the event.

Also on hand at the cocktail party, held at the Hotel Marriot in the German capital, were the directors of the locally-produced films "Mei" and "Spider Lilies, " as well as several actors and actresses starring in the films.

Speaking at the cocktail reception, Taiwan's representative to Germany, Shieh Jhy-wey, who hosted the event, introduced the Taiwan guests and expressed the hope that everyone could encourage and support the new generation of Taiwan directors and actors by checking out their movies.

After the cocktail party, portions of director Arvin Chen's "Mei", which has been selected to participate for Best Short Film in the Short Film Competition of the festival, and Zero Chou's "Spider Lilies, " which has been included in the Panorama section of the festival, were screened for the guests and received their enthusiastic applause.
During the cocktail party, the Taiwan filmmakers engaged in friendly exchanges with their foreign counterparts as well as organizers of several major international film festivals.

This marked the first time that the GIO has held a "Taiwan Night" cocktail reception at the Berlin Film Festival. The move was part of the GIO's efforts to help local filmmakers expand into overseas markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved down 49 points to close at 7,743, with 35,858 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March decreased 47 points to finish at 7,750, with 11,250 contracts traded, while June futures lost 55 points to close at 7,734, with 39 contract transactions. September futures moved down 102 points to finish at 7,583, with 77 contracts traded. December futures decreased 38 points to close at 7,600, with 14 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 7,792 for February, 7,797 for March, 7,789 for June, 7,685 for September and 7,638 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

February TE futures decreased 3.95 points to close at 325.3, with 4,631 contracts traded, while March TE futures lost 4.35 points to finish at 324.85, with 3,303 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 4.7 points to close at 324.55, with three contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 0.15 points to finish at 322.7, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

February TF futures lost 3.8 points to close at 1,042, with 2,730 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures decreased 2.4 points to finish at 1,045, with 1,770 contracts traded. June TF futures moved down 6.6 points to close at 1,045, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF INDICTED FOR CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was formally indicted on corruption charges Tuesday.
Ma was charged with lining his pockets during his term as Taipei City's mayor with NT$11 million (US$332,684) from a special allowance fund set aside for the mayor's discretionary use.

One of Ma's aides, Yu Wen, who allegedly used others' invoices to help Ma to claim reimbursements from the special allowance fund, was also indicted for embezzling NT$760,000 from the special allowance fund.
Five other city government officials who had allegedly provided Yu with their invoices were handed deferred indictments on forgery charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT READIES ITSELF FOR CHAIRMAN'S INDICTMENT

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has readied itself to cope with all sorts of possible scenarios in case Chairman Ma Ying-jeou is indicted over embezzlement charges related to his special municipal fund during his term as mayor of Taipei, KMT spokesman Su Chun-pin said Tuesday.
Whether or not Ma is indicted, the KMT will deal with the situation according to an established set of mechanisms, Su said.

Although Ma has been viewed as the KMT's most likely candidate to run in the 2008 presidential election, Su made it clear that Ma will offer to resign from the party's top post if he is indicted over his alleged misuse of special municipal funds allocated for his discretionary use while serving as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006.

Su gave assurances that Ma, as a responsible politician, will "definitely" live up to his promise by stepping down from KMT chairmanship if indicted, consistent with his efforts to help raise Taiwan's moral standards.
According to Su, the KMT needs to be fully united in the face of the unprecedented situation and called for calm among supporters.
Sources close to the KMT said that the party's powerful Central Standing Committee will call an emergency meeting later in the day to discuss measures to deal with the latest development.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Govt to pay market rate for land acquired.
In a significant departure from a decades-old practice, the Government intends to pay the prevailing market rate when it acquires land.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Government's inter- ministerial panel will help disabilities in two ways.
Singapore government will set up an inter- ministerial panel to help disabilities in early education and employment abilities increasement.
Under the proposal, the national office will be supported by two governing panels - the Early Intervention and Education Panel, and the Employment Panel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BEGIN EXPORTING MANGOES, LYCHEES TO CHILE, AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Tai wan has obtained permission from the governments of Chile and Australia to export Taiwan-grown mangoes and lychees to the two countries this year, officials of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday.

The bureau signed with Chilean authorities a working plan last year on quarantine measures regarding Taiwan's mango shipments to Chile as well as an agreement on Taiwan mango exports to the South American country. Since the importing country has ratified the working plan and agreement, COA officials said, Taiwan can start shipping the fruit to the country this year.
In Australia, relevant authorities have also recently ratified similar agreements, allowing Taiwan to begin exporting mangoes to the country this year, the officials said.
Under the quarantine regulations, mangoes have to undergo heat-steaming before they are transported to the two countries, the officials noted.

Before the first batch of mangoes are shipped, the COA will invite Chilean and Australian officials in charge of quarantine affairs to visit the island to inspect the steaming and relevant operations, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow TimesGPutin Courts Mideast Rulers While sampling Oriental candies and walking on rose petals, President Vladimir Putin courted Saudi businessmen with talk of lucrative oil, banking and satellite deals during a visit to Riyadh that ended Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The authorities announced Monday crackdown of a Red Brigate-style terrorist group who were prepared to carry out attacks. The police has arrested 15 suspects with charges of subversive activities, association with terrorist organizations, illega possesion and smuggling arms.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABUNDANT FRUIT, VEGETABLE SUPPLIES BEFORE LUNAR NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: There will be greater supplies of fruits, vegetables and flowers available in domestic markets during the five-day period in the lead up to the Chinese New Year holiday, officials of the Agriculture and Food Agency (AFA) said Tuesday.

Compared with average levels, an increase of 46 percent will be seen in vegetable supplies during this period, while there will be a 53 percent greater supply of fruits, and 137 percent more flowers, the officials assessed, noting that the AFA has asked farmers to increase supplies to meet an expected increase in demand before the week-long Chinese New Year holiday that will begin on New Year's Eve Feb. 17.

Chinese New Year's Day, which falls on Feb. 18 this year, is one of the most important festivals in Taiwan, with many families preparing traditional feasts for the festival. Owing to the fact that wholesale markets for agricultural products will be closed during the holiday, most people are expected to engage in a shopping spree in preparation for the holiday break.
As a result, the demand for agricultural products is expected to peak during the approach of the Chinese New Year festival, AFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS TAKE OFF

TEXT.P: An airplane from the Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines took off early Tuesday from Taoyuan International Airport, bound for Shanghai, marking the first lunar New Year charter flight across the Taiwan Strait.

The Boeing 747-400 airplane, carrying more than 200 passengers -- mostly tourists and family members of Taiwan businessmen operating in China -- left the airport at 7: 00 a.m. en route for Shanghai's Putung airport.

The special direct cross-strait lunar New Year charter flight service is expected to enter its peak period Wednesday and will last through the end of the holidays in early March, business sources said. This year's Chinese New Year's Day falls on Feb. 18.
The Mandarin Airline's plane is slated to return to Taiwan later the same day, fully loaded with 397 passengers on board.

Six carriers from either side will provide passengers with 192 special charter flights between Taiwan and China during the Chinese New Year holidays, up by 48 flights from the previous year's level. The two sides are yet to set up regular direct air and shipping links due to a political feud that has lasted for more than 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE WORKS TO IMPROVE EDUCATION FOR CHILDREN WITH FOREIGN-BORN PARENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has adopted various measures aimed at enhancing the learning efficiency and adaptability of school children with a foreign-born parent, whose numbers are rising in the country owing to the increase in the number of mixed marriages, a ministry official said Tuesday.

These measures include priority enrollment in public kindergartens for these children and providing them with after-school care and guidance, according to Yang Chang-yu, deputy director-general of the ministry's Department of Elementary Education.
While a total of 6,363 children with a foreign-born parent are enrolled in public kindergartens for the 2006-2007 academic year, 19,943 have joined the after-school programs, Yang said.

Yang said the results of a study show that although the performance of children with a foreign-born parent is not as good as that of other children when they first enter school because of their weaker Chinese language ability and their lower socio-economic status, these children gradually catch up as they advance to higher grades.

In addition to taking steps to help the children improve their academic performance, the ministry is also encouraging schools to hold activities, such as a cultural week and an international week, to allow children from families with two Taiwan parents to learn about different cultures, Yang said.

Stressing that children from mixed marriages deserve just as much respect as other children, he said the cultural activities will allow students to appreciate cultural diversity and enhance cultural exchanges and assimilation.
A report released by the ministry last month said that as the fertility rate among foreign spouses has been increasing, an average of one in every eight newborns in Taiwan has a foreign-born parent.

The number of elementary and junior high school students with a foreign-born parent has also jumped 1.8-fold over the past four years, from 30,040 in the 2003-2004 academic year to more than 80,000 in the 2006-2007 academic year, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES HOLD SESSION ON PRESIDENT'S REQUEST

TEXT.P: Grand justices began a two-day exploratory session Tuesday on President Chen Shui-bian's request for a constitutional interpretation aimed at suspending trial currently dealing with the high-profile "state affairs fund" case in which the first lady is one of the defendants.

Five professors -- Lee Hui-tsung, Hsu Cheng-jung, Chang Tai-lin, Chen Tsung-wen and Yang Yun-hua -- who specialize in German and French law, were invited to participate, Fan Kuang-chun, secretary general of the Judicial Yuan said.

Fan said the grand justices have taken into consideration the academic specialties, personal willingness to contribute, and availability of scholars as they collect more information on the relevant issues.
"The exploratory session does not mean that the grand justices have reached any decisions. There is no cause for speculation, " he stressed.
Two items on the agenda of the exploratory session were the criminal immunity of the president and the state secret privilege enjoyed by the president.

On the president's immunity, the discussion focused on the nature and content of the immunity as stipulated in the Article 52 of the Constitution, and compared this with related articles in the constitutions or other relevant laws of the United States, France and Germany.

On the president's state secret privilege, the discussion centered on which similar privileges in the United States, France and Germany might be used by the grand justices in deciding whether or not to accept the request for a constitutional interpretation.

The first day session began at 9 a.m. and closed at 12:30 p.m. It was presided over by Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng. Each of the five scholars was given 20 minutes to express his views, then the grand justices and the scholars engaged in a question-and-answer session.

The five scholars wouldn't share much information following the closed-door session. Professional Hsu said only that they did not discuss the injunction, and mainly provided opinions on foreign laws with which they are familiar.

In the second day session Wednesday, scholars specializing in American constitution will be present. The Judicial Yuan also presented written briefs on the definition of state secret privilege in Japan, Austria and Australia.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai filed the interpretation request with the Council of Grand Justices (CGI) Jan. 25 on behalf of President Chen in the hope of clarifying the constitutionality of the court proceedings on the "state affairs fund" case.

Cho also filed an injunction petition asking the Judicial Yuan to order the Taipei District Court to immediately stop the trial and repeal its previous ruling on opening supposedly "secret" files relating to the case.

First lady Wu Shu-jen, along with three former and incumbent senior aides at the Presidential Office, is being tried at the Taipei District Court after she and President Chen were named by a public prosecutor as "joint perpetrators" in an embezzlement case involving the alleged misuse of the president's discretionary "state affairs fund."

In a lengthy document submitted to the CGJ Jan. 25, the Presidential Office said the interpretation request is aimed at defending the constitutional status of the presidency, maintaining the democratic system and protecting the sanctity of the constitution.

Since the president is protected by Article 52 of the Constitution, it has been argued that the court cannot ask the president to testify during the investigation process and court hearing; nor, it is argued, can the court order him to surrender secret documents or even hear the case as, according to Article 52, the president enjoys immunity to litigation other than treason and sedition and cannot be prosecuted until his term expires, the statement added.

The petition further states that the Taipei District Court infringed on the president's executive privilege and risked leaking state secrets by opening secret files relating to the "state affairs fund" case.

Chen has denied any wrongdoing with regards to the special "state affairs fund" and claims that he has not lined his pockets with monies from the fund. He has promised to resign if his wife is found guilty in the first trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: REBAR FOUNDER'S CASE TO BE HEARD TUESDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/13/07 17:36:16 (BY Chu Lu-sheng & and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: An immigration official confirmed Monday that a preliminary hearing will be held in San Pedro, California Tuesday morning to review the case of whether Taiwan fugitive tycoon Wang You-theng will have to leave the country.

Wang, founder of the Rebar Group, was placed on Taiwan's most wanted list on Jan. 15 for suspected embezzlement of large amounts of capital from the group before fleeing with his wife to China and then on to the United States at the turn of this year.
Wang's hearing will be held at the immigration holding center in San Pedro, where he has been detained since Feb. 2 for entering the country without valid travel documents.
Taiwan authorities have actively been seeking to have Wang and his wife repatriated back to Taiwan to face the charges against them.

As Tuesday morning's hearing is preliminary to any possible immigration procedure regarding Wang's case, its result is not likely to present any final resolution on whether the fugitive tycoon will be sent back to Taiwan.
Wang has hired several top immigration lawyers to represent him in the case.
According to an anonymous Los-Angeles based immigration lawyer, Wang will probably ask to be released on bail during the hearing, a request which is likely to be turned down.
"Unless there is some unexpected twist in events, Wang is destined to spend the Chinese New Year Day at the immigration holding cell," the lawyer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA ANNOUNCES ESTABLISHMENT OF FIRST 'INDUSTRIAL SAFETY AWARDS'

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Tuesday the establishment of the first national-level "industrial safety awards" as an incentive for businesses and individuals to promote safety and hygiene in the workplace.
Starting this year, the awards will be presented annually to 10 businesses and individuals that perform best in this regard, CLA officials said.

The awards will be divided into several categories, including state-owned enterprises, private enterprises, small- and medium-sized businesses, individuals and public construction, the officials said.
CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said promoting industrial safety is a matter that can allow for no delay because only if the lives of workers are protected will their families remain intact.
Therefore, the government should grant the highest honor to those who are committed to enhancing safety and hygiene in the workplace, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMALE UNDERGRADS PREFER RINGS, NECKLACES AS VALENTINE'S GIFTS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Rings and necklaces are the gifts Taiwanese female undergraduates in Taiwan most wish to receive on Valentine's Day, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
Coming in second on the wish list are clothing (lingerie included) and shoes, followed by a romantic candle-lit dinner, chocolates and flowers, the survey shows.
The survey, conducted recently by a domestic lingerie manufacturer, Easy Shop, contacted 590 female undergraduates around Taiwan.
The pollsters said flowers do not enjoy a high ranking on the list because most of the respondents feel that flowers represent a momentary vanity that is quick to wither.
Some respondents asserted that men only give flowers when they cannot think of a gift for their lovers, the survey found.
While 20 percent of the respondents have never thought of receiving lingerie as a Valentine's Day gift, more than 50 percent said they would feel very happy if they received such a gift.

However, 80 percent of the respondents think it would be more appropriate for men to present lingerie as a gift for their lovers after they have been dating for more than six months, according to the survey.
On the favored designs, the survey found that black lingerie decorated with sexy lace, cute lingerie in pink, and purple lingerie decorated with romantic ribbons are the most popular choices.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.057 to close at NT$33.081.
A total of US$1.01 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.024 and fluctuated between NT$32.982 and NT$33.086.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 39.53 points to close at 7,736.83.
The bourse opened at 7,782.07 and fluctuated between 7,800.87 and 7,725.81 during trading. A total of 2.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$81.05 billion (US$2.46 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 615 to 554, with 218 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AUTHORITIES TO DISCUSS FEASIBILITY OF RAISING MINIMUM WAGE

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is planning to organize a commission following the Chinese New Year holiday to discuss the feasibility of raising the minimum wage, which has remained constant since 1998, CLA officials said Tuesday.
The current minimum wage, which came into effect Oct. 16, 1997, is NT$15,840 (US$478.55) per month, NT$528 per day, or NT$66 per hour.

The CLA decision to convene meetings of the "basic wage fixing commission" by the end of May follows demands from laborer groups who have not seen an adjustment in the minimum wage in over nine years, the officials explained.
A proposal concerning basic wage adjustment must be endorsed by the commission, which would then submit the proposal to the Executive Yuan for ratification, according to the CLA.

The CLA must be very cautious in considering such an adjustment to the basic wage because the basic salary is associated with various social benefits including labor insurance, national health insurance, and the wages of foreign workers and social relief. Such an adjustment might also affect local enterprises and the general economic development of the country, the CLA said, noting that so far it has not yet come up with a likely range for such an adjustment.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK CHAIRMAN OPPOSES MINIMUM WAGE CHANGE

TEXT.P: A proposal by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to review the minimum wage ran into opposition from the chairman of a major think tank Tuesday on the grounds that such policy would do more to harm disadvantaged workers.

The government's move would raise the minimum wage above the value of some workers' labor, thus discouraging employers from hiring and push some factories to leave, Chen Po-chih, an economist and Chairman of Taiwan Thinktank, said in a telephone interview with the CNA. The think tank is seen to be close to the Democratic Progressive Party government.
In the end, it is the disadvantaged workers that will be hurt, Chen said.

CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said a day earlier that the council is to convene a meeting after the Lunar New Year holidays to discuss adjusting the country's minimum wage, which has remained unchanged at NT$15,840 (US$481) per month for the last nine years. Lee said he is personally in favor of raising the minimum wage, but the decisions on whether to adjust it and by how much will be made by a CLA committee.
Chen Po-chih said that the CLA's position is understandable, but his point is made from a global economic perspective and is aimed at protecting poor and unemployed laborers.

He called the move to adjust the minimum wageirresponsibleand said that he will only consider challenges to his view from laborers now paid with current minimum wage -- provided that they are willing to accept responsibility for their own future unemployment should their position on an increase be accepted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD CONTINUE BOOSTING CROSS-STRAIT TIES: HONORARY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, the honorary chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Tuesday that the KMT should continue to work towards reconciliation with the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) as their previous efforts have contributed significantly to the improvement of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Lien made the remarks at a meeting organized by the KMT's think tank on KMT-CCP affairs.

According to Lien, the two parties have made intensive efforts to strengthen bilateral ties during the last year, including the organization of two economic forums and a meeting on the interests of Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China.

In those meetings, the two parties have reached a consensus on many issues and are implementing some of the agreements, Lien said, adding that these measures have won the support of many Taiwanese people and businessmen with operations in China.

However, Lien expressed regret that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has been trying to mislead the public by offering misinformation regarding China's good-will gestures, including a decision to offer tariff- free treatment to some of Taiwan's fruit exports.

Noting that although Taiwan's agricultural produce has entered China and proven popular on that market, Lien said Taiwan's fruit exporters still can not expand their market share in China due to the high cost of transportation between the two sides.
Lien suggested that KMT continue making efforts to resolve the problems of Taiwan people and seek the maximum benefits for people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF RESIGNS, ANNOUNCES BID FOR PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou announced his bid for the presidency in 2008 and his resignation from his party post Tuesday, hours after a prosecutor indicted him for stealing NT$11 million (US$332,684) from a special allowance fund during his term as Taipei city mayor.
Claiming innocence, Ma said he used the special allowance at issue according to the law and that he refused to accept the corruption charges.

The stern-faced KMT chief said he would step down from his post as KMT chief as he had promised and would fight to clear his name through the judicial system, which he described as a struggle not only for him but also for thousands of active and former senior government officials who also spend their special allowances in the same way as him and therefore may face the same charges.
Claiming that the ruling party is going out of its way to bash him, Ma vowed not to be knocked down.
Rather, he said, he will appeal to the people to clear his image by entering the 2008 presidential race and vindicating his integrity "via voter support" in the election.

In anticipation of Ma's indictment and ensuing stepdown, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih had said a day earlier that the party's first vice chairman, Wu Poh- hsung, will take over as acting KMT chairman and will call for the election of a new chairman within three months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTIBIOTICS FOUND EFFECTIVE IN SOME HIGH-GRADE MALTOMA CASES

TEXT.P: High-grade gastric mucosa associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma (MALToma) can be cured with antibiotic therapy before it spreads, according to a recent study by the National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) and National Health Research Institute.
The results were released to local press Monday, after The Journal of Pathology published the findings in its January issue.

Spokesman for the team, Cheng Ann-lii who is also the deputy director of NTUH's Department of Oncology said that up till now, patients with helicobacter pylori- related low-grade gastric MALToma were treated with antibiotics, while high- grade MALToma patients, whether the tumor had spread or not, have had no other choice but undergoing generalized chemotherapy for at least six months.

However, Cheng said, following the study, which extended over a two-year period, they concluded that 50 to 70 percent of patients with high-grade MALToma could be cured by a simpler, less-painful antibiotic therapy before signs of spreading appeared.

Cheng called the beginning of the research a "pure coincidence." He related that a 49-year-old female Taiwanese scholar was diagnosed with high-grade MALToma in the United States about a decade ago. Refusing the course of chemotherapy recommended by the U.S. physician, she turned to NTUH to find alternative treatments.

Afterward, the scholar was given a period of antibiotic therapy. Her gastric ulcer and tumor were gone after six weeks and her stomach returned to normal after 16 months. She has had no relapse since, Cheng said.

The case inspired the NTHU team to undertake further study, he said. The team then conducted a clinical experiment with 34 patients with low-grade cases and 24 patients with high-grade cases, and the results showed that 97 percent of low-grade patients, and 92 percent of high-grade patients were cured. Moreover, only one-eighth of the low-grade patients experienced a relapsed, whereas none of those with high-grade afflictions did.

Nevertheless, Cheng said, follow-up experiments produced less satisfying results, which prompted them to investigate further into the crux of the problem and improve the effectiveness of the therapy. Currently, the cure rate has stabilized at between 50 and 70 percent.

In a recent project, the team has found two biomarkers -- BCL10 and NF-kB -- that can spot the pathogen of MALTome -- TNF-alpha. If the inflammation caused by TNF-alpha can be stopped, the cure rate is be even higher, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA NEEDS TO FURTHER STUDY MINIMUM WAGE INCREASE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday that the ministry is not opposed to a review of the minimum wage, but will have to study the matter further.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said that the ministry is not opposed to a review, pointing out that it has already convened an internal meeting to exchange opinions.
Other complementary measures must also be studied, he added.

He said that the ministry has collected information for reference from Japan, South Korea and Singapore. The ministry is expected to reach a conclusion in a month, and will publish the ministry's stance at that time.

Shih made the remarks after reports that the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is scheduled to convene a minimum wage review commission after Chinese New Year holiday, although the level of increase that might be proposed is not yet certain.
Taiwan's current monthly minimum wage of NT$15,840 (US$489) was first instituted in October 1997. It has remained unchanged since 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI COUNTY'S TANGERINES POPULAR IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Chiayi county's "Taiwan Tangerines" (citrus-ponkans) are proving to be very popular in Singapore, with more than 300 tonnes exported to Singapore in the past month alone, a county government official said Tuesday.

The county's Agriculture Bureau Chief Hsu Ling-sung said that export of tangerines helped to correct for an over-abundance of produce in the domestic market and that the "Great Luck" tangerine sets, packaged with a miniature spring couplet on each tangerine, have become hot-selling gifts in Singapore in the run-up to the Chinese New Year holiday.

With the Tropic of Cancer running through it, Chiayi county is an ideal place to grow a variety of fruits including tropical pineapples, bananas, papayas, guavas, mangos, as well as temperate tangerines, oranges, and pears, Hsu said, adding that tangerine orchards in the county cover more than 2,300 hectares and produce over 33,000 tonnes of fruit.

County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen encouraged the bureau two years ago to export tropical fruits to temperate countries like Japan, China, Canada and South Korea, and temperate fruits to tropical countries like Singapore, Hong Kong, and Southeast Asian countries. Hsu said the marketing strategy has proved to be successful.

County government's marketing strategy has helped to create export channels for the county's high quality tangerines, Hsu said, pointing out that with Singapore importing more than 300 tonnes of Taiwan's tangerines in only one month, on average, every group of 20 people in Singapore has collectively consumed one creatively packaged set of "Great Luck" tangerines.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIPEI MAYOR INDICTED ON CHARGES OF EMBEZZLEMENT

TEXT.P: The chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) was indicted Tuesday on charges of embezzling from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use while he served as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

The anti-corruption center under the Taiwan High Court Prosecutor's Office formally indicted Ma Ying-jeou on charges that he embezzled NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from the mayoral special allowance during his two mayoral terms.
Prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen said in the indictment that Ma received NT$10.23 million in special allowances during his first term from December 1998 to December 2003.

However, the expenditure records of Ma's bank accounts show that he spent only NT$3.49 million of that amount but did not return the unspent portion -- NT$6.74 million -- to the national coffers, Hou continued.
From January 2004 to July 2006, Ma used NT$630,000 of the NT$5.06 million fund and kept the remaining NT$4.43 million in his account.
Hou contended that the unspent money during his two terms, totaling NT$11.7 million, should be considered "gain from embezzlement."
Hou rejected an interpretation by the Ministry of Justice last November that special allowance funds for executives of government departments are actually meant as salary subsidies.

"The view raised by the Ministry of Justice alone is not shared by others and contradicts the rules and regulations set by the Cabinet and the Ministry of Finance governing the use of special allowance funds," Hou said.

He pointed out further that Ma had acknowledged when he was first summoned for questioning last year that the special allowance fund was not part of his salary and should have been spent completely on office-related affairs.

Although taking note of the fact that Ma and his wife donated tens of millions of dollars to charitable organizations during his mayoral terms, Hou argued that those donations came mostly from Ma's unspent election campaign funds rather from his special allowance funds.

All executives holding public office are given a special allowance fund every month. Although the money is left up to the administrative chief's discretion, half of the fund can be spent without any proof of spending, while use of the other half must be substantiated with receipts.
Hou began his investigation into Ma's alleged misuse of fund in August last year after Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni complained that Ma had channeled money from the fund into his private bank accounts.

Ma contended on a TV show a week earlier that he had no intention of breaking the law because he considered the fund set aside for his discretionary use as "private money," as it is regarded by every other recipient of similar funds in Taiwan.

He argued that if he is found guilty, then the same fate will befall almost all government executives, including political heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and everyone who has ever served as a mayor or county magistrate.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Diplomatic row over raw meat shipped from Matthews plant to Continent
David Miliband met the Hungarian Ambassador over discoveries about shipments across Europe as poultry farmers feared a collapse in consumer confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDICTMENT DOES NOT MEAN GUILT: PFP SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The indictment against opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman and former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou does not mean he is guilty, a spokesman for the opposition People First Party (PFP) pointed out Tuesday.

Lee Hung-chun made the remarks after the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office indicted Ma on embezzlement charges. He also expressed hope that the court will deal with the case swiftly and that the case will not affect the year-end legislative election or the 2008 presidential election.
If the KMT asks for the PFP's cooperation regarding the two major elections, the PFP -- the KMT's political ally -- will give a hand under the newly formed KMT- PFP alliance, Lee said.

Ma, who used to be regarded as a political "Mr. Clean, " was charged with lining his pockets during his eight-year mayoral term that ended at the end of 2006 with NT$11 million (US$332,684) from a special fund set aside for the mayor's discretionary use.
One of Ma's aides, Yu Wen, who allegedly used others' invoices to help Ma claim reimbursements from the fund, was also indicted for embezzling NT$760,000 from the fund.
Lee urged the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP to stick together through the challenge.

Mentioning the alleged involvement of President Chen Shui-bian, his wife Wu Chu- jen and several of his aides, in a state affairs fund embezzlement scandal, Lee claimed they are more suspicious than Ma of involvement.

Lee also urged the judicial authorities to launch investigations into Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh, all of who also had special funds during their services as administrators of local governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CHIAO TUNG UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT VISITING SILICON VALLEY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/13/07 20:00:51 (By Wu Jih-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting National Chiao Tung University President Wu Chung-yu met with Robert Birgeneau, Chanciller of UC Berkeley, to discuss possible cooperation between the University System of Taiwan (UST) and UC Berkeley Monday during a visit to Silicon Valley.
The UST represents National Chiao Tung University, National Tsinghua University, National Central University and National Yang Ming University.
Wu noted that there are 120 foreign students at National Chiao Tung University, and the number is expected to increase to 400; the number of exchange students is expected to increase to 300 per year.

During his visit to UC Berkeley, Wu expressed his hope that there will be greater bilateral cooperation and academic exchanges between the schools, particularly in the areas of electric engineering, information engineering and biomedics.
He also visited biomedic research projects of UC Berkeley and UC San Francisco.

Wu's visit to Silicon Valley is also aimed at meeting with alumni of the Chiao Tung University in the region and soliciting opportunities for Chiao Tung University students to intern at high-tech firms in Silicon Valley.
Wu pointed out that Chiao Tung University is currently ranked just behind National Taiwan University, National Cheng Kung University and National Tsinghua University in Taiwan.
Although Chiao Tung University excels in nurturing semiconductor talents for Taiwan, its ranking cannot improve as the school has no departments of biology or medicine.
He said that the school is planning to cooperate with other schools in research related to biomedicine to improve the overall academic rating of the school.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD COMMUNITY URGED NOT TO IGNORE TAIWAN'S QUARANTINE RIGHTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that it will be regrettable for the whole world if Taiwan becomes a global quarantine loophole should it continue to be excluded from the World Health Organization (WHO).

Chen made the remarks at a meeting with Lord Howell of Guildford, deputy leader of Britain's Conservative Party in the House of Lords, in which the president also expressed gratitude to Howell for his long-term support for Taiwan.

In addition to Howell's support, the British House of Commons released a pro- Taiwan report in August last year suggesting that the government help Taiwan join the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the decision-making body of the WHO -- as an observer and increase its political interaction with Taiwan, Chen went on.
On the global anti-avian flu efforts, Chen said Taiwan has been making great efforts in this regard, including the organization of three high-level anti-bird flu meetings during the last two years.
Taiwan is one of the few countries that put anti-bird flu work on the level of national security. It is still free from bird flu, Chen noted.

Noting that Taiwan and Britain share the values of democracy, human rights and peace and have close exchanges in trade, education, tourism and culture, Chen expressed hope that the two countries can establish closer cooperation ties in sanitation, quarantine and health care.

Chen noted that some of the treasures of the British Museum are being exhibited at the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei and that Britain is Taiwan's third-largest trade partner in Europe, while Taiwan is Britain's ninth-largest export market in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CRIMINAL EVIDENCE AGAINST KMT CHAIRMAN'S WIFE

TEXT.P: No criminal evidence has been found against the wife of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou in the case of his embezzlement charges, a spokesman for the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office said Tuesday.
Chang Wen-cheng made the remarks after Ma was formally indicted on corruption charges during his term as Taipei mayor that ended December 2006.
He was charged with lining his pockets with NT$11 million (US$332,684) from a special allowance fund set aside for the mayor's discretionary use.
Asked about the role of Chou Mei-ching, Ma's wife, in the case, Chang said Chou was called as a witness by prosecutors during the investigation but that no evidence had been found of her involvement.
Meanwhile, a KMT clean politics commission called a news conference 30 minutes after a public prosecutor indicted Ma.

The commission said that its own investigation found that the special allowance fund deposited into Ma's bank account had been used up without arrears "in stark contrast" with the prosecutor's findings and that the commission could not rule that Ma had committed any embezzlement.
The commission noted that Ma donated more than NT$68.09 million to charity during his eight-year mayorship, which was far greater than the NT$15.47 million special allowance fund he claimed.
Even if Ma's campaign subsidy of NT$45 million donated to two foundations was deducted, the gap remained at NT$23 million, prompting the commission to rule that he had used all his special allowance.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7-11 WORKS WITH CTJOB TO OFFER 24-HOUR JOB HUNTING SERVICE

TEXT.P: Internet manpower company CTjob will collaborate with 7-11 to offer a 24-hour job hunting platform for unemployed persons who can't get online, an executive of CTjob announced at a press conference Tuesday.

The executive said the service is for people who need jobs but lack computer skills. Job hunters can grab forms at neighborhood 7-11 stores, send their resumes to CTjob, and await interviews from companies that CTjob regularly matches with job seekers through internet.

CTjob invited artist Ma Chau-chun to be its "Marketing Advocate for Saving the Unemployed." Ma had held no job for over one year because his studio was destroyed in the 921 earthquake. He later returned to the entertainment business with the help of friends and now wishes to give back to those in need.

Taipei Deputy Mayor Wu Hsiou-kuang, CTjob's Chief Executive Li Laing-yiou and Ma read the declaration, "Saving the Unemployed", at the press conference Tuesday to kick start the 24-hour job hunting service.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK GETS ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR ACCESS ROAD

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang promised Tuesday that the Cabinet will appropriate an additional NT$1.8 billion (US$54.38 million) to help the Central Taiwan Science Park complete an access road at an early date to link the industrial complex with the public road system.

Su gave the assurance during an inspection tour of the park that the funds will be channeled to match the progress in the construction of the access road, so that industrial companies setting up shop in the park can enjoy convenient transportation.

At a briefing for the premier, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said construction of the access road has lagged behind schedule because the original budget from the central and local governments was insufficient to meet the extra costs arising from the widening of the road from an originally designed width of 30 meters to 60 meters.

He said the 3-km road linking the science park with the No. 1 Freeway and the Taichung-Changhua Expressway carries a price tag of NT$4.67 billion, of which NT$2.2 billion came from Taichung City and NT$400 million from Taichung County.

Although the Cabinet has earmarked NT$100 million for the project, there is still a shortfall of NT$1.8 billion, Hu said, adding that insufficient funding could delay the completion of the road from the end of 2008 to 2013 and have an adverse impact on the operations of the science park as well as the development of central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS WELCOME KMT CHAIRMAN'S INDICTMENT

TEXT.P: Legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) welcomed Tuesday the indictment of Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou over his alleged embezzlement of a special allowance fund during his two Taipei mayoral terms.
"Ma owes the people of Taiwan an apology," DPP legislature caucus leader Ker Chien-ming said at a news conference.

"He kept patching up lies with other lies during the criminal investigation, causing turmoil in society; he provoked partisan conflict in the legislature during his chairmanship, failing all the bills crucial to people's lives," Ker claimed.

Hsieh Hsin-ni, the DPP legislator who originally made the corruption allegations against Ma, claimed the indictment has "proved" that the accusations against Ma and evidence unfavorable to him in the case were not political manipulations, as the KMT claimed.

You Ching, a DPP at-large legislator, complained that the indictment should have been made earlier, claiming that it had been made pretty clear that Ma treated the special fund as personal property rather than spending it on official business.
Yeh Yi-jin, a DPP legislator from Tainan County, said the principle that public funds should only be used for public business should not be violated.

Kao Chien-chih, a DPP legislator from Taipei City, described the indictment as a "celebration of democracy and rule of law" and called on the KMT not treat Ma's case and President Chen Shui-bian's special state affairs fund cases differently.

The prosecutors said Ma, during his two consecutive terms as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006, received a total of NT$15.29 million (US$461,934) in a mayoral special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use and failed to return the unspent portion - some NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) -- to the national coffers but instead kept the money in his own account.

Ma has contended that he had no intention of breaking the law, pointing out that his treatment of the fund is in line with the way such funds are treated by every high-ranking public official across party lines.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO SUPPORT LEGAL AID FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Wednesday to provide support for the Legal Aid Foundation as he lauded the group for protecting the legal rights of disadvantaged people.
Chen made the remarks while receiving members of the foundation at the Presidential Office.

Noting that the legal aid system does not simply help people handle lawsuits, Chen said it is also important that the system serves as a reminder for the public and the government to reflect upon the problems faced by people when dealing with the judicial system.
Since its establishment two-and-a-half years ago, the foundation has set up 20 branches around Taiwan and has handled a total of nearly 25,000 cases.
However, the president pointed out that the foundation is not large enough to provide help for more people in need and he promised to provide more resources and funds.
He also expressed hope that the foundation can further improve the public's understanding of the law in addition to providing lawyers to represent them.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO ELIMINATE HIGH ENERGY CONSUMING LIGHT BULBS BY 2010

TEXT.P: The government will adopt a stricter standard for electricity-conserving light bulbs starting by 2010, with the aim of using the more energy-efficient light bulbs, officials from the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.
The new plan is part of the government's efforts to deal with global warming and to conserve energy, according to the officials.

The new standard is higher than those set in the United States, South Korea and China, the officials noted, adding that a total of 43 million kWh of electricity could be saved each year, which amounts to a reduction of 29,900 metric tons of carbon dioxide emissions.
Taiwan's electricity consumption for lighting is rising, and already accounts for more than 10 percent of total electricity consumption, bureau officials pointed out.
As a result, it is important that the government to follow other countries' footsteps in regulating the energy efficiency of lighting products, the officials stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD DEVELOP HIGH-TECH AND RECREATIONAL AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Vice Minister Tai Chen-yao said Tuesday that Taiwan should develop high-tech and recreational agriculture to enhance its competitiveness.

Tai made the remarks at a seminar organized in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan, by the Wu San-Lian Historical Foundation on Taiwan's history and industries, in which the participants expressed concern over the future of the country's agriculture.

Noting that many countries attach great importance to agricultural reform and development, Tai said industrially advanced countries like Germany, Britain, the United States and Japan have injected a great deal of funds and personnel into agriculture to maintain sustainable agricultural development.
Taiwan should focus its efforts on developing agricultural products with local uniqueness through high technology, and dedicate energy to developing recreational agriculture, he said.
However, Tai expressed regret that some Taiwan businessmen have taken the country's agricultural high technology to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:In Shift ,Accord on North Korea Seems to Be Set
The United States and four other nations reached a tentative agreement to provide North Korea with roughly $400 million in fuel oil and aid, in return for the Norths starting to disable its nuclear facilities and allowing nuclear inspectors back into the country, according to American officials who have reviewed the proposed text.
While the accord sets a 60-day deadline for North Korea to accomplish those first steps toward disarmament, it leaves until an undefined moment in the future X and to another negotiation X the actual removal of North Koreas nuclear weapons and the fuel that it has manufactured to produce them.
Wall Street Journal:In Race to Take Tourists Into Orbit,Partners Split, Spar
When the suborbital craft SpaceShipOne first lifted off from the Mojave desert in June of 2004, it ignited lofty dreams of space travel for tourists. Now, it's fueling a feud between its two creators.
Partners Burt Rutan, a famous aerospace designer, and Jim Benson, an entrepreneur, envisioned that passengers would pay $200,000 for the ultimate joy ride -- a roughly two-hourlong flight reaching 3,000 miles per hour and more than 60 miles above the earth.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO MAKE TAIWAN GLOBAL RFID STRONGHOLD

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has drafted plans to make Taiwan world-class in the Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) industry, a government spokesman said Tuesday.

The spokesman said the technology industry describes the rapidly developing RFID technology as "the second IT revolution." Hardware and software factories have invested heavily in RFID technology research and development and advanced countries regard it as a new power in industrial development.

RFID can be used in the fields of mobile business, global logistics, national security, transportation, operations management, and medical care. Deployment of RFID in wholesale, convenience, and department stores can also reduce inventory inaccuracies.

In addition, RFID helps to control product distribution chains from loading and transportation, to the retail level. The Kaohsiung Customs Office and Port of Kaohsiung replaced manual escorts on products in logistics with RFID, a move that has reduced escort waiting time by 6,200 hours.

The spokesman pointed out that according to ABI Research statistics, RFID's market scale will reach US$22.3 billion by 2011, while the Asia-Pacific market's rapid growth will surpass the American market in 2010 to account for half of the global output.

The CEPD has completed a blueprint for RFID applications from 2006-2013 and is now promoting the deployment of RFID in the country's free trade port zones for better operation efficiency, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG COUNTY REPORTS GOOD SALES IN PRODUCE EXPORT

TEXT.P: Taichung county government officials reported Tuesday that the central county enjoyed good sales in agricultural product exports last year, with more than 710,000 kg exported for revenue of NT$34.8 million.
Sales were better than expected, official of the county's Agriculture Bureau said, adding that the figures will continue to increase.
In recent years, the county government has been working hard to explore overseas markets for produce such as mandarin oranges, grapes, pears, lychees and golden mushrooms, the officials noted.
Currently, the government has exported them to Brunei, Malaysia, Japan and Singapore, according to the officials.
Mandarin oranges accounted for the largest portion of the total exports at over 567,600 kg, followed by grapes at more than 69,400 kg, the officials pointed out.
County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng congratulated local farmers and the bureau, while encouraging them to maintain good quality in their products, the officials said.
The county also plans to make inroads into Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia, which has an overseas Chinese population of more than 4 million, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 TAIPEI GAMES SHOW ATTRACTS 330,000 VISITORS

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei Games Show closed at the Taipei World Trade Center Monday, with 330,000 people having visited the five-day event, a spokesman for the Taipei Computer Association said Tuesday.

During the event, with scores of players mobbing company booths to try out new games, business transactions for each company grew by 10-20 percent over last year's levels, the spokesman said, adding that more newly developed games will hit the market following the Feb. 17-25 Chinese New Year holiday.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said during the event's opening ceremony that the city government intends to make available in public places -- including department stores and shopping malls -- games that encourage intellectual development.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS FIRM ON CHAIRMAN RUNNING IN PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers voiced their keen support Tuesday for KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's participation in the 2008 presidential election, saying that Ma must not pull out of the race despite his indictment on embezzlement charges earlier in the day.

Ma, a former mayor of Taipei who ended his eight-year mayoral term last December, was indicted on embezzlement charges over his alleged mishandling of special municipal funds earmarked for his discretionary use.

Ma was charged with lining his pockets with NT$11 million (US$332,684) from a special allowance fund for the mayor's discretionary use that required no invoices or receipts upon which to claim reimbursement, while Yu Wen, a municipal government clerk, was also indicted for graft and document forgery for allegedly using others' invoices to claim reimbursements from the special municipal fund.

Describing Ma's indictment as a "politically charged move, " KMT lawmaker Lai Shyh-bao said that Ma must take part in the next presidential election regardless of the indictment, claiming that the public strongly believes in his "clean name."

Lai questioned why investigations into similar charges against heavyweights in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , such as Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh and former Premier and incumbent DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, as well as Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng and National Security Council Chairman Tan Sun Chen, have not even started.
"The prosecution's singling out Ma is just a politically motivated move," he claimed.
KMT lawmaker Hung Hsiu-chu asked the prosecution to come out with a timetable for beginning probes into the DPP figures and called for calm and unity within the KMT at this very critical time.

KMT lawmaker Kuo Su-chun ascribed Ma's indictment to a long-existing flawed government system that can be used as a pretext to set someone up and claimed that it is "extremely unfair" to solely indict Ma.
KMT lawmaker Shuai Hua-ming insisted that Ma has to stay in the race for the sake of the overall national interest.

Meanwhile, Lee Hung-chun, spokesman for the opposition People First Party (PFP) , a KMT ally, told the KMT that December's legislative elections and the 2008 presidential elections must not be hobbled due to Ma's indictment.

Lee called for speedy follow-up trials and a conclusion of Ma's case as quickly as possible. He offered to collaborate with the KMT through their cooperation mechanisms in order to secure victory in the coming elections.

"Ma's indictment does not mean he is guilty, " Lee pointed out, calling for judicial justice through due legal process and warning that the opposition "pan- blue alliance" cannot afford to have another split.
Meanwhile, DPP lawmakers demanded that Ma weigh his next move, apologize to the public and conduct self-reflection now that he has been indicted.

Speaking at a news conference in the Legislative Yuan, DPP Legislator Lin Shu- fen insisted that Ma must judge himself by the same standard with which he judged President Chen Shui-bian's wife and son-in-law, who were indicted on charges of embezzlement and insider trading, respectively, last year.
Investigation results show that Ma lied Nov. 15 last year when he claimed he did not embezzle from the special municipal allowance, according to Lin.

Meanwhile, Ma immediately offered to resign from the KMT chairmanship following his indictment -- a promise he made before his indictment. The party's Central Standing Committee is slated to call an emergency meeting to deal with the drastic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER HAS CONFIDENCE IN FORMER MAYOR'S INTEGRITY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday he believes in opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's integrity, despite Ma's indictment on charges of embezzling from a special allowance fund while serving as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.
"I also have confidence in the nation's judicial system," Wang said when asked to comment on Ma's indictment.

Wang, who is a seen as a presidential hopeful and major rival to Ma in the KMT's primary for the 2008 presidential election, also said that he respects Ma's resignation from his post as KMT chairman, as well as his decision to join the presidential race.
Wang indicated last weekend that he would not rule out the possibility of taking part in the KMT presidential primary.

The anti-corruption center under the Taiwan High Court Prosecutor's Office formally indicted Ma on charges that he embezzled NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from the mayoral special allowance during his two mayoral terms.
Shortly afterwards, Ma professed his innocence at a press conference and claimed that he had used the special allowance fund according to the law.

Ma announced his resignation from the KMT chairmanship but vowed that he will appeal to the people to clear his image by entering the 2008 presidential race and vindicating his integrity "via voter support" in the election.

Meanwhile, Wang Hsin-nan, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), urged DPP heavyweights seriously considering their presidential bids to examine whether they used their special allowance funds in the same way as Ma while serving in their executive posts.

Wang said those DPP bigwigs who want to run in the 2008 presidential race should make sure they have no such problems before declaring their candidacy, so that efforts by the party to help them in their election campaigns will not be in vain.

DOC.HEADLINE: "INSTITUTIONAL TRAPS" PROBLEM SHOULD BE ADDRESSED: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday, upon hearing about the indictment of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman and former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, that the problem of possible "institutional traps" should be addressed.
Lu was responding to queries from the press during a visit to a Taipei community. She claimed to be "surprised" to hear about the indictment.
"Some have fiercely attacked President Chen-Shui-bian over his state affairs fund case, " Lu said, adding that "now it's time for more contemplation on whether there are some 'institutional traps'".
She said there should not be joy over Ma's indictment, for its impact can be profound.

According to the indictment, during his two consecutive terms as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006 Ma received a total of NT$15.29 million (US$461,934) in special allowance funds designated for the mayor's discretionary use and failed to return the unspent NT$11.17 million kept in his account.
Ma has pointed out that his treatment of the fund is in line with the way such funds are treated by every high-ranking public official across party lines.

Sympathizers of Chen have also described the special state affairs fund case, in which the first lady is on trial on corruption charges, as an incident caused by the lack of laws that clearly define the way such money should be dealt with.
Lu refused to comment further on Ma's case, saying she had not read the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS TO PROBE OTHER SPECIAL ALLOWANCE FUNDS CASES SOON

TEXT.P: Investigations into suspected special allowance fund misuse involving many government executives will get underway soon, a spokesman for the anti- corruption center under the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office said Tuesday.

The spokesman made the remarks after main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was indicted earlier in the day on charges of embezzling from a special mayoral fund designated for his discretionary use while he served as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

According to the spokesman, prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen began his investigation into Ma's alleged misuse of fund last August after Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni complained that Ma had channeled money from the fund into his private bank accounts.

Under the existing budgetary system, all executives holding public office are given a special allowance fund every month. Although the money is left up to the administrative chief's discretion, half of the fund can be spent without any proof of spending, while use of the other half must be substantiated with receipts.

The anti-corruption center has also received similar accusations against Vice President Annette Lu, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, Premier Su Tseng- chang, and other heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The High Prosecutor's Office spokesman said the anti-corruption center will begin to investigate those cases in the near future now that probes into Ma's case has been concluded.

Ma was charged with embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from the mayoral special allowance fund during his two mayoral terms. Ma claimed innocence and argued that if he is found guilty, then the same fate will befall almost all government executives, including almost all prominent DPP heavyweights.

The indictment dealt a blow to Harvard-educated Ma, but he denied the charges and announced he would run for president next year. "I want to face the people and prove my innocence, " he said in a televised speech. "Ma Ying-jeou won't be knocked down."
However, Ma announced that he would step down as KMT chairman in line with a promise he has made repeatedly over the past several weeks.
The KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee rejected his resignation. It remains uncertain when Ma's resignation will take effect.

Meanwhile, the KMT committee passed a resolution at an extraordinary meeting Tuesday evening to revoke a party regulation that requires suspension of membership rights of any KMT member who is indicted on criminal charges. The removal of the regulation is part of the committee's efforts to retain Ma as party chairman.
Responding to Ma's indictment, Vice President Lu reminded her DPP colleagues to refrain from harboring the feelings of schadenfreude over Ma's predicament or the KMT's misfortune.

"All DPP politicians should instead reflect upon themselves and brace themselves up for new challenges ahead, " Lu said, adding she believes that Ma's indictment would have significant ramifications on domestic poltiical development.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEBRUARY 14 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, Feb. 14
09:30, Vice President Annette Lu will donate blood.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Malawi Finance Minister Goodall Edward Gondwe.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 14, or the 27th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1766: Thomas R. Malthus, the British economist who wrote "An Essay on the Principle of Population," is born. His 1798 work argues that populations tend to increase faster than food supplies unless the increase is checked by moral restraints or by war, famine, or disease.
1779: Captain James Cook, the British navigator and explorer who commanded three major voyages of "discovery," charting and "naming" many islands in the Pacific Ocean, is killed by a native's spear in Hawaii.
1797: British naval forces under Admiral John Jervis and Captain Horatio Nelson defeat the Spanish fleet off Portugal's Cape St. Vincent.
1859: Oregon becomes the 33rd state of the United States.
1893: Hawaii is annexed to the United States by a treaty.
