DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER HAS CONFIDENCE IN FORMER MAYOR'S INTEGRITY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday he believes in opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's integrity, despite Ma's indictment on charges of embezzling from a special allowance fund while serving as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.
"I also have confidence in the nation's judicial system," Wang said when asked to comment on Ma's indictment.

Wang, who is a seen as a presidential hopeful and major rival to Ma in the KMT's primary for the 2008 presidential election, also said that he respects Ma's resignation from his post as KMT chairman, as well as his decision to join the presidential race.
Wang indicated last weekend that he would not rule out the possibility of taking part in the KMT presidential primary.

The anti-corruption center under the Taiwan High Court Prosecutor's Office formally indicted Ma on charges that he embezzled NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from the mayoral special allowance during his two mayoral terms.
Shortly afterwards, Ma professed his innocence at a press conference and claimed that he had used the special allowance fund according to the law.

Ma announced his resignation from the KMT chairmanship but vowed that he will appeal to the people to clear his image by entering the 2008 presidential race and vindicating his integrity "via voter support" in the election.

Meanwhile, Wang Hsin-nan, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), urged DPP heavyweights seriously considering their presidential bids to examine whether they used their special allowance funds in the same way as Ma while serving in their executive posts.

Wang said those DPP bigwigs who want to run in the 2008 presidential race should make sure they have no such problems before declaring their candidacy, so that efforts by the party to help them in their election campaigns will not be in vain.

DOC.HEADLINE: "INSTITUTIONAL TRAPS" PROBLEM SHOULD BE ADDRESSED: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday, upon hearing about the indictment of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman and former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, that the problem of possible "institutional traps" should be addressed.
Lu was responding to queries from the press during a visit to a Taipei community. She claimed to be "surprised" to hear about the indictment.
"Some have fiercely attacked President Chen-Shui-bian over his state affairs fund case, " Lu said, adding that "now it's time for more contemplation on whether there are some 'institutional traps'".
She said there should not be joy over Ma's indictment, for its impact can be profound.

According to the indictment, during his two consecutive terms as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006 Ma received a total of NT$15.29 million (US$461,934) in special allowance funds designated for the mayor's discretionary use and failed to return the unspent NT$11.17 million kept in his account.
Ma has pointed out that his treatment of the fund is in line with the way such funds are treated by every high-ranking public official across party lines.

Sympathizers of Chen have also described the special state affairs fund case, in which the first lady is on trial on corruption charges, as an incident caused by the lack of laws that clearly define the way such money should be dealt with.
Lu refused to comment further on Ma's case, saying she had not read the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS TO PROBE OTHER SPECIAL ALLOWANCE FUNDS CASES SOON

TEXT.P: Investigations into suspected special allowance fund misuse involving many government executives will get underway soon, a spokesman for the anti- corruption center under the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office said Tuesday.

The spokesman made the remarks after main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was indicted earlier in the day on charges of embezzling from a special mayoral fund designated for his discretionary use while he served as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

According to the spokesman, prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen began his investigation into Ma's alleged misuse of fund last August after Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni complained that Ma had channeled money from the fund into his private bank accounts.

Under the existing budgetary system, all executives holding public office are given a special allowance fund every month. Although the money is left up to the administrative chief's discretion, half of the fund can be spent without any proof of spending, while use of the other half must be substantiated with receipts.

The anti-corruption center has also received similar accusations against Vice President Annette Lu, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, Premier Su Tseng- chang, and other heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The High Prosecutor's Office spokesman said the anti-corruption center will begin to investigate those cases in the near future now that probes into Ma's case has been concluded.

Ma was charged with embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from the mayoral special allowance fund during his two mayoral terms. Ma claimed innocence and argued that if he is found guilty, then the same fate will befall almost all government executives, including almost all prominent DPP heavyweights.

The indictment dealt a blow to Harvard-educated Ma, but he denied the charges and announced he would run for president next year. "I want to face the people and prove my innocence, " he said in a televised speech. "Ma Ying-jeou won't be knocked down."
However, Ma announced that he would step down as KMT chairman in line with a promise he has made repeatedly over the past several weeks.
The KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee rejected his resignation. It remains uncertain when Ma's resignation will take effect.

Meanwhile, the KMT committee passed a resolution at an extraordinary meeting Tuesday evening to revoke a party regulation that requires suspension of membership rights of any KMT member who is indicted on criminal charges. The removal of the regulation is part of the committee's efforts to retain Ma as party chairman.
Responding to Ma's indictment, Vice President Lu reminded her DPP colleagues to refrain from harboring the feelings of schadenfreude over Ma's predicament or the KMT's misfortune.

"All DPP politicians should instead reflect upon themselves and brace themselves up for new challenges ahead, " Lu said, adding she believes that Ma's indictment would have significant ramifications on domestic poltiical development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
NAME CHANGE NOT TO AFFECT VALIDITY OF STAMPS: TAIWAN POST CO.

TEXT.P: The change of the name on stamps issued by Taiwan Post Co. will not affect the stamps' validity, a spokesman for the state-owned company said Wednesday.

The spokesman made the remarks after a postal expert with the Berne-based Universal Postal Union (UPU) said a day earlier that individual UPU member countries can ask to invalidate new stamps to be issued by the newly renamed Taiwan Post Co.

The state-owned postal company formally changed its name from Chunghwa Post Co. -- "Chunghwa" means China-- to Taiwan Post Co. Monday, and it plans to issue the first set of stamps marked "Taiwan" Feb. 28, featuring the Taipei 228 Memorial Museum as the theme in commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident.
The stamps will be the first to carry the Chinese characters for "Taiwan stamp" instead of the words "Republic of China stamp."
According to the UPU expert, UPU member countries are entitled to void the new "Taiwan stamp" in line with Article 8 of the UPU Convention regarding the name on stamps.

If any individual UPU member state informs the UPU Secretariat of its decision to invalidate the new "Taiwan stamp, " the expert said, the UPU Secretariat is obliged to deliver the message to all other member states. It's up to individual UPU member states to decide whether to follow suit, the expert said.

Commenting on the UPU expert's remarks, the Taiwan Post spokesman said such a scenario is not expected to happen given the company's longstanding good cooperative ties with various UPU member countries.

Although Taiwan has not been a UPU member since 1972, it has consistently followed international norms and UPU regulations, the spokesman said, adding that the bilateral postal cooperation agreements the company has signed with various UPU member states are valid for good.

"Following our company's redesignation, we need just to exchange notes with various UPU member countries and our bilateral postal cooperative contracts will continue to be valid and binding, " the spokesman explained.

According to the spokesman, stamps prepared with the words "Republic of China" will continue to be printed in the first quarter of this year, with "Republic of China" stamps to stop being issued in April at the earliest.

Unveiling the "Taiwan Post Co." plaque at the postal company headquarters Monday, President Chen Shui-bian said the name change is "a belated move to serve Taiwanese justice by dumping the outdated 'Great China' ideology."

"Although we have practiced democracy for 20 years, " Chen said, "many people still have martial law in their hearts, and they refuse to use the beautiful name of Taiwan to address ourselves and our country."

Noting that the history of the postal company dates back to 1888 when the Qing Dynasty established a Taiwan Post Bureau, Chen said the redesignation also marks the restoration of the name and history of the postal service.
"Since Taiwan is already a democratic country, we Taiwanese should recognize ourselves and value our culture as well as our name," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEARING ON REBAR FOUNDER'S CASE NOT OPEN TO PUBLIC
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/14/07 13:09:26 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A preliminary hearing on Taiwan fugitive tycoon Wang You-theng's illegal entry into the United States was held as a closed-door session in San Pedro, California Tuesday.

The judge ruled that the hearing, which began at 8 a.m. at an immigration court in the immigration holding center in San Pedro, was not open to the public at the request of Wang's attorneys, shutting out a large group of Taiwan media members waiting there to cover the event.
The hearing ended two-and-a-half hours later, but Wang's attorneys declined to make any comment regarding the case despite inquiries by the media.
The next hearing on the case reportedly is scheduled for March 6 or 7, but U.S. justice officials would not confirm the information.

Wang, founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, has been detained by U.S. immigration authorities since Feb. 2, when he tried to return to Los Angeles with both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports canceled, following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore.

According to Yang Ling, a former U.S. immigration official who is now working as an immigration lawyer in Los Angeles, Wang could have petitioned for political asylum through his lawyers, which was the reason why the hearing on his case was allowed to be held as a closed-door session.
However, Yang said that such a petition by Wang would have slim chance of success as Taiwan is not defined by the United States as a country where citizens suffer political persecution.

Even if Wang makes up a story to try to justify his petition for political asylum, U.S. immigration authorities will judge whether Wang was actually being persecuted or just making an excuse to evade facing trial in Taiwan for allegedly breaking the law, Yang said.

Wang is suspected of having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the group before fleeing with his wife, Wang Chin She-ying, to China late last year and then to the United States early this year.
Taiwan authorities placed the couple on the country's most-wanted list Jan. 15 and are actively seeking U.S. assistance to have them repatriated back to Taiwan.

Yang said that Wang might be trying to use the political asylum petition to extend his stay in the United States to facilitate his application for family- based immigration, given the fact that his wife is a U.S. citizen.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLAR DESCRIBES INDICTED KMT HEAD AS 'CLEVER STRATEGIST'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/14/07 13:34:20 (By Chiehyu Lin, Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A U.S. scholar on Tuesday described Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) who was indicted on corruption charges the day before and subsequently resigned from the position, as "a very clever strategist" for announcing his bid to run for the presidency in 2008 almost immediately after the indictment.

June Teufel Dreyer, a China hand and a professor of political science at the University of Miami at Coral Gables, said during an interview with the CNA that "sadly, people in Taiwan are not shocked to hear that politicians are corrupt, and in any case, the proceedings will probably drag on for so long that the general public will lose interest."

Describing Ma as a "very clever strategist, " Dreyer said that there is no doubt Ma will be able to portray himself as a victim in this indictment and that he has tried to maintain his innocence and vowed to clear his name by announcing his bid for the presidency in 2008.
She stressed that it is uncertain whether Ma's crisis has been solved by making the announcement, noting that "one of the reasons is that Taiwan politics is so unpredictable."
"I wonder, however, if Ma's indictment will change many voters' minds," she added.

In related news, renowned U.S. China hand Alan D. Romberg said that a key to Ma's political future is not so much his formal status in the KMT party as what the public reaction is both to the indictment and to Ma's response.

Romberg, a senior associate and director of East Asian studies at the Henry L. Stimson Center, said that if the public takes the indictment -- without a conviction -- as tarnishing Ma's image and therefore turn away from him, the whole political situation in Taiwan will open up, both within the KMT and in the "pan-blue, pan-green" competition.

If, on the other hand, the public continues to view Ma as a man of integrity -- a standing that he obviously considers extremely important -- and continues to support him, and, of course, if he is not found guilty, then he will continue to have a good chance of winning the KMT nomination and perhaps the presidential election, Romberg continued.

Romberg said that in the wake of his indictment, Ma has taken two steps to try to consolidate his political position. First, Ma followed through on his promise to resign as KMT chairman, thus showing himself to be a man of his word. And second, Ma has made clear that he will run for president, thus forestalling a political vacuum within the KMT or an opportunity for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to dominate the political field while the "pan-blue" camp struggles to find its moorings.
He said the race for the presidency was always destined to be closer than current public opinion polls indicate, and Ma's indictment adds even greater uncertainty.

If Ma is able to quickly clear himself -- and he undoubtedly will seek an early trial to do just that -- then this uncertainty may also quickly pass. If, on the other hand, it takes some time to bring the case to resolution, this will undoubtedly handicap Ma in his quest for Taiwan's presidency and create new ferment in Taiwan's political situation, Romberg commented.

Romberg also predicted that if Ma were to be "fatally hurt" by the indictment and related developments, this would seem to enhance the chances of a DPP victory in 2008. While this does not mean that the cross-strait situation could not improve -- clearly Beijing wants improvement and thinks some progress would be possible with either Su Tseng-chang or Frank Hsieh as president -- nonetheless it would alter Beijing's perception about the likely pace and extent of that improvement, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT CHAIRMAN'S MENTOR 'STUNNED' BY INDICTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/14/07 14:35:13 (By Jaw-pyng Hwang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's mentor at Harvard Law School, Jerome A. Cohen, described the indictment of Ma on charges of embezzlement the day before as "stunning" and "surprising."

On Ma's announcement of his bid for 2008 presidency, the U.S. authority on law said if Ma feels he was wronged, he should try to prove his innocence. And if he is clear of the charges, Cohen said there is no doubt that the opposition Kuomintang chairman can run for the presidency.

During an interview with the CNA, Cohen, who is currently a law professor at New York University, described Ma as a person of honesty and uprightness. He said he feels sympathetic and sad just as what he felt after the imprisonment of his another Taiwanese student -- current Vice President Annette Lu -- in the 80s.

Both Ma and Lu were Cohen's students at Harvard Law School. Returning home from the United States in 1978, Lu joined in the pro-democracy movement in Taiwan. However, because of a 20-minute public speech at a rally held to commemorate Human Rights Day Dec. 10, 1979, she was subsequently sentenced to 12 years in prison for sedition.
Lu ended up spending five years and four months in jail before being given a medical parole due to thyroid cancer.

Asked about the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office's move to indict Ma for allegedly embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from a special allowance fund during his two mayoral terms, Cohen said he is not familiar with the case and expressed that he does not want his remarks on the issue to be "misinterpreted" as support for either the ruling "pan-green camp" or the opposition "pan-blue alliance" in Taiwan.

"People should give Taiwan's judicial system a chance, " suggested the scholar, who has been paying attention for a long time to Taiwan's democratic development as well as human rights and judicial practices in China. He also noted that Ma's indictment is a whole new judicial case and that the judicial system has been facing greater pressure given the increasing level of inter-party confrontation.
The case could be an "interesting" challenge for Taiwan in its efforts to develop democratic politics, Cohen said.

Ma, who has portrayed himself as a political "Mr. Clean, " tendered his resignation as KMT chairman and announced his bid to run for the presidency in 2008 just hours after he was indicted. He argued that if he is found guilty, then the same fate will befall almost all government executives and everyone who has ever served as a mayor or county magistrate.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY MAKES BREAKTHROUGH IN UAV TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taoyuan County-based Yuan Ze University has recently achieved a breakthrough in the development of technologies for building unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for commercial use, the director of a UAV development project at the university said Tuesday.

Wu Chang-huei, an associate professor at Yuan Ze University's department of mechanical engineering, indicated that through the UAV computer system his team has developed, an unamanned vehicle can be made to automatically carry out various surveillance missions simply by punching in the coordinates of the appointed targets.

Wu noted that unmanned aircraft have been widely used to carry out military missions for many years, but it has only been in recent years that such vehicles have started to be developed for civilian uses.
In 2006, the Environmental Protection Administration contracted Yuan Ze to develop a commercial UAV system capable of performing automatic flight by following satellite navigation signals, he said.

With cameras, a UAV can also transfer images from the sky back to the control headquarters on the ground, Wu said, adding that the machine is useful for all kinds surveillance missions, including monitoring pollution at sea and the traffic situation on roads and highways. In addition, UAVs can be used for rescue missions in difficult to reach locations, such as mountainous regions or on the open seas.

Citing an unoffical estimate, Wu said military-use UAV production is expected to reach US$3 billion annually over the next five years, while civilian UAV production is forecast to reach US$600 million per year in the same period.
"The space for Taiwan to develop UAVs and relevant technologies is unlimited," the expert said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BULLET TRAIN DELAYED 13 MINUTES

TEXT.P: A south-bound bullet train was delayed by 13 minutes Wednesday due to a switch machine problem, Taiwan High Speed Rail (THSR) officials reported.

The train, which departed from Banciao, in northern Taipei County for Zuoying, in southern Kaohsiung City, came to a temporary halt at around 10: 30 a.m. after passing Yunlin Station due to a failure in a switch machine, the THSR officials said, adding that the train resumed its journey after switching to another rail. It arrived at Zuoying Station 13 minutes late.
The THSR railway operators denied that they had backed the train up to make a correction in the wake of the switch machine failure.
Taiwan's first high-speed railway has been operating normally over the past several weeks after a spate of glitches during the first few days of operations in January.
The 345-km railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung has reduced rail travel time between Taiwan's two largest cities to 90 minutes from the previous four- and-a-half hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 72.62 points to close at 7,809.45.
The bourse opened at 7,800.98 and fluctuated between 7,812.18 and 7,764.31 during trading. A total of 3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.4 billion (US$2.68 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 1.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, cement stocks and textile stocks both at 0.4 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF TAIWAN OFFICE WORKERS SUFFER FROM LONELINESS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Valentine's Day may not have been the most romantic time for most of Taiwan's offices workers this year, with a recent survey showing that a vast majority of these workers suffer from a sense of loneliness.

The "loneliness index" survey, conducted by the Chinese-language monthly job- tracking magazine Career between Jan. 17-26, found that 88.9 percent of office workers in Taiwan suffer from a sense of loneliness.

As to the reasons for their feelings of loneliness, "unchanging routine in life" was mentioned most often, by 44.5 percent of respondents, followed by "not having a boyfriend/girlfriend" by 38.3 percent of respondents, and "a lack of sense of achievement at work" by 37.4 percent.

A total of 49 percent of the office workers surveyed said they are still single, with 61.4 percent of these respondents noting that Valentine's Day makes them feel especially lonely, and 78.6 percent mentioning that they want to give up the single's life.

As to the kind of relationship they aspire to have, 58 percent of the single respondents said they want a "loving relationship in which each partner has their own personal space, " perhaps indicating that many young workers in Taiwan have become accustomed to a carefree lifestyle.

On ways to get rid of feelings of loneliness, "watching TV or seeing a movie" was mentioned most often, by 59.3 percent of the respondents, followed by "visiting an online chatroom" by 50.3 percent of the respondents, "listening to music" by 46.1 percent, "reading a book" by 39.1 percent, and "going shopping" by 32.6 percent.
The survey was conducted online, with a total of 1,734 valid samples being collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-OWNED ENTERPRISES RENAMED 'TO BE HONEST TO HISTORY': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that the government's recent move of changing the names of three state-owned enterprises shows that it is facing history and the country honestly.

Revealing that preparatory work for the name changes had been going on for six months before being finalized Feb. 9, Su expressed satisfaction that the information was not leaked beforehand, which he said helped avoid "unnecessary troubles" that could have hampered the process.

Su made the remarks during a weekly Cabinet meeting, when the Cabinet approved draft amendments to the Postal Service Act and to a statute on the establishment of the Chunghwa Post Co. The amendments became necessary after the company was renamed "Taiwan Post Co."

According to Su, the name "Taiwan Post" appeared as early as 1888 when postal service was inaugurated in Taiwan during the Ching Dynasty, and changing the name of Chunghwa Post Co. to "Taiwan Post Co." is only "a return to truth so that the familiar name -- Taiwan -- can be spoken."
As to Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), Su pointed out that company was established in 1946 in Shanghai and moved to Taiwan three years later.
"With CPC having lived together with the people of Taiwan for the last 50 years, renaming the company 'CPC Corp., Taiwan' has more clearly reflected its history," Su said.
Su said that the government has dealt with the name-change issue in a mild, brave, honest and sincere manner and that it respects the opposing opinions expressed by some people on the matter.

Su stressed that the name changes will not undermine the rights and interests of the workers and clients of the affected companies but will enhance the companies' competitiveness and prominence, because they will no longer be confused with companies carrying similar names in China, such as China National Petroleum Corp. and China Petrochemical Corp.
Also undergoing a renaming on Feb. 9 was China Shipbuilding Corp., which decided to change its name to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-FSC COMMISSIONER INDICTED ON GRAFT CHARGES

TEXT.P: Lin Chung-cheng, a former member of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , was indicted Wednesday by Taipei prosecutors who asked that he be sentenced to 16 years in prison on suspicion of taking bribes from businessmen.

Prosecutors also sought a fine of NT$5 million (US$151,976) for Lin's role in a case in which he is suspected of abusing his power to prevent the FSC from referring several public companies to investigators for taking bids in return for profits.

Lin, an academic-turned-politician who was a lawmaker appointed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party before being recruited as a member of the country's supreme financial regulation body, has been detained incommunicado since last November by prosecutors on bribe-taking charges.
Lin's personal secretary, Su Chun-chi, who was also detained for his reported role as Lin's proxy in dealing with businessmen, was also indicted.

Chiu Mei-lan, a legal counselor of the China Development Financial Holding Corporation (CDFHC), which is one of the companies alleged to have bribed Lin, was indicted with prosecutors seeking a two-year sentence and a NT$1 million fine.
Eight others, including three CDFHC officials and five executives of four securities firms, were released without being indicted due to lack of evidence.
Seven other people, including a construction company owner and an architect, were handed deferred prosecutions.

Lin's detention was the latest in a series of blows to the two-year-old FSC, which has seen its former chief, Kong Jaw-sheng, and former head of its Finance Examination Bureau, Lee Chincheng, indicted separately on charges of corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up 90 points to close at 7,833, with 27,208 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March increased 100 points to finish at 7,850, with 15,331 contracts traded, while June futures gained 96 points to end at 7,830, with 12 contract transactions. September futures moved up 72 points to close at 7,655, with 20 contracts traded, while December futures increased 62 points to finish at 7,662, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 7,743 for February, 7,750 for March, 7,734 for June, 7,583 for September and 7,600 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

February TE futures increased 4.7 points to close at 330, with 4,477 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 4.95 points to finish at 329.8, with 4,083 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 3.7 points to end at 328, with eight contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

February TF futures moved up 2.2 points to close at 1,044.2, with 2,770 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures increased 4.4 points to close at 1,049.4, with 2,608 contracts traded. June TF futures increased four points to end at 1,049, with two contract transactions, while September TF futures increased 2.4 points to close at 1,040, with six contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU STRIVING TO BECOME WORLD'S LARGEST PEARL FARMING BASE

TEXT.P: National Penghu University (NPU) has made breakthroughs in pearl cultivation techniques, facilitating the goal of making Penghu County into the largest pearl farming base in the world, sources at the university said Wednesday.

NPU has been developing related techniques for three years, the sources said, adding that impressed by the initial results, Ichimura Co., based in Okinawa, Japan, has sought cooperation with the university, with the two sides signing a memorandum of understanding on cooperation last May.

Under the arrangement, NPU is to provide the latest cultivation techniques of black lip shell and penguin shell -- two of the common pearl shells, while Ichimura is to provide the business know-how. Combining the experience of the two sides, as well as the National Science Council's funding for research, they are aiming to boost Penghu's pearl business, according to the sources.
NPU professor Ueng Jinn-pyng said that after putting the research achievements into practice, the cost of pearl production has been significantly lowered, leading to increases in profits.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG QUEUE FORMS OUTSIDE RESIDENCE OF PRESIDENT'S PARENTS

TEXT.P: A long queue has been forming outside the residence of President Chen Shui- bian's parents in Kuantien township of Tainan County, southern Taiwan, in which people use chairs to mark their places in a line to receive red envelope be presented by Chen on Chinese New Year's Day.
The envelopes are believed by the recipients to be "lucky."
Every year of Chen's presidency the Chen family residence has been surrounded by crowds of "red envelope hunters" on Lunar New Year's Day, many of whom begin lining up days in advance.

The queue is headed this year by Chen Chao-shou from northern Taipei County, who started waiting Feb. 8 and has hardly left the queue since, according to security guards stationed at the Chen family residence.
Chen Chao-shou was also first in line last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO WIPE OUT CORAL-DEPLETING DRIFTNETS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chen Chin-teh urged Taiwan's fishing industry Wednesday to refrain from engaging in non-sustainable fishing.
Chen also called on government agencies to ban or strictly regulate driftnet fishing or bottom-dragging net fishing in Taiwan's fishing grounds.

He made the call after inviting officials from the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture, the Coast Guard Administration and fishermen's associations from eastern Yilan County on a field trip off the east coast.
During their field trip, Chen and the officials witnessed the rooting out of coral reefs and other living marine resources from the seabed by fishing boats using driftnets or bottom-dragging nets.
Claiming to be "horrified" by what they saw, the Fisheries Administration officials promised to step up efforts to demand that fishing boats to immediately abandon driftnetting.

Noting that banning driftnetting and bottom-dragging net fishing has for long been a world trend as these practices seriously deplete coral reefs and other marine resources, Chen called for the government to discourage and restrict the use of indiscriminate fishing methods in Taiwan's economic zones to ensure the conservation of living marine resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITY GROUP `SPREADS LOVE' IN INDIA
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, India, Feb. 14 (CNA) 02/14/07 17:26:39 (By Paul Kuo and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Chou Ta-kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation sent a five-member delegation on a visit to a national cancer research center in India Tuesday to express care for the center's hospitalized children.

The delegation, led by Foundation Founder Chou Chin-hua, brought books and gifts to the children at the Rajiv Gandhi Cancer Institute and Research Center, accompanied by Elliott Chang, a deputy chief at Taiwan's representative office in India.

Praising the center's doctors for accepting low wages to serve the children, Chou suggested to the center that it recommend model doctors and children to his foundation, which will invite them to Taiwan.
The next day, the delegation presented the 9th "Global Love for Life" award to Gobinda Pradhan, a gangster-turned-founder of a charity, to recognize his efforts to help prisoners in India.

The delegation also gave a book written by Chou Ta-kuan to Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, founder of the Art of Living Foundation. The foundation was established in 1981 and is dedicated to the promotion of purified life and good health.

The Chou Ta-kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation, founded in 1997, is named after the founder's son, who died of cancer at the age of 10. Each year, the foundation gives a "Global Love for Life" award to a person who demonstrates great passion for life and bravely faces challenges.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT CHAIRMAN'S PRESIDENTIAL BID CALLED 'POPULISTIC'

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh accused former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Wednesday of resorting to "populism" for announcing his bid to run for the next presidency immediately being charged with corruption.

The anti-corruption center under the Taiwan High Court Prosecutor's Office indicted Ma a day earlier on corruption charges after determining that he embezzled NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use during his two terms as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

While resigning from the KMT chairmanship immediately after the indictment, Ma claimed his innocence and announced his decision to run for the presidency in 2008 to prove his integrity "via voter support" in the election.

According to Hsieh, who is a possible presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Ma's move is unfavorable to the establishment of a fair judicial system, because the people do not review relevant documents, question witnesses or see any evidence but only base their judgment on their impressions.

On expected judicial investigations into suspected misuse of special allowance funds involving other government executives, which could implicate a number of other important politicians, Hsieh said he believes there are no problems with the way their special allowances were spent.
Hsieh claimed that he did not use fake receipts to claim reimbursement from the allowance and spent all the funds on office-related affairs.

Hsieh claimed that Ma is to be blamed for his own predicament, pointing out that he claimed he used the special allowance on office-related affairs in the beginning but later admitted that some of the funds were used for private purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Here are Red Brigates-mafia links.
The authorities, who are investigating into a Red Brigate-style terrorist group bursted by the police earlier this week, have discovered certain links between the brigates and domestic crime organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROADBAND WIRELESS ACCESS LICENCES TO BE ISSUED

TEXT.P: The government is to issue six regional licenses for broadband wireless access (BWA) services in the first part of a two-phase licensing plan, the Executive Yuan announced Tuesday.

The licenses, scheduled to be issued at the end of June, include three each for the northern and southern halves of the country, are valid for six years and can be renewed only once, the Executive Yuan said, adding that the government is expected to earn at least NT$1.26 billion (US$38.07 million) in license fees over the first six years.

According to an agenda drawn up by the Cabinet-level National Communications Commission (NCC) , the government will hold a public hearing on the BWA regulations draft in March, establish the regulations the same month, accept business applications in April and May, and then complete application reviews and bidding processes in June before giving out the licenses.

The northern BWA service region will include Taipei city and county, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu city and county, Miaoli County, Yilan County, Keelung City and Matsu islands, while the other parts of the country go to the southern service region, the NCC said.

Each regional licensee will be allocated a bandwidth of 30 MHz within the international standard spectrum range of 2.5 - 2.69 GHz, and regional operators will be permitted to merge and convert their regional licenses into a nationwide one, the NCC said.

Two of the six licenses will be first reserved for new players that are not running Type I Telecommunications Enterprise services and will apply the 802.16e standard, unless no such company wins a bid, NCC officials said. The Type I Telecommunications Enterprise is referred to businesses that provide telecommunications services with its own connection facilities.
Bidders that combine services and manufacturing industries will be better evaluated during the application review procedure, according to the NCC.

In the bidding process that follows, qualified bidders will compete with their offers of annual license fees, defined by a percentage of their total annual revenues. Minimums for the license fee are set at NT$20 million (US$ 604,318) for the first year, NT$30 million for the second year and NT$40 million per year from the third through the sixth year, the NCC said.

The Executive Yuan said in a news release that the issuance of three licenses each in two regions will not only accommodate the current needs of the business sector but will foster a healthy competitive environment, provide multiple choices to consumers and allow consumers to enjoy high-quality telecommunications services.
The news release added that in the second phase of the project, at least one additional nationwide license will be issued after June 2009, depending on the progress of phase one mergers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DECLINES TO COMMENT ON FORMER TAIPEI MAYOR'S INDICTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 14 (CNA) 02/14/07 18:09:20 (By Chen Yen-chun and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: China's Taiwan Affairs Office declined to comment Wednesday on former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's indictment on charges of embezzling from a mayoral special allowance fund betweem 1998 and 2006, saying only that its officials have noted the development.
Hours after the indictment Tuesday, Ma resigned from his post as chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and declared his intention to run for president in the 2008 election.

Li Weiyi, spokesman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office, was asked whether Chinese President Hu Jintao, who sent a congratulatory message to Ma when he was elected KMT chairman in 2005, contacted the KMT about Ma's indictment, and what the Chinese leadership would think if KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan were to be made acting chairman.
Li said that because none of the media speculation actually occurred, and because the KMT had not made a decision yet, the Beijing government had no comment.

Asked about speculation that Beijing might change its strategy toward Taiwan by no longer pinning its hopes on the KMT and beginning to develop a relationship with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Li said Beijing welcomes DPP members to visit China to increase mutual understanding as long as they acknowledge Beijing's one-China principle and the so-called 1992 Consensus.

The 1992 Consensus refers to an understanding the KMT claims was reached in Hong Kong between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that there is only one China, but with both sides free to make their own interpretations of what "one China" actually means.
Li urged the DPP to remove its party plank seeking Taiwan independence in order to open the gate to exchanges with China.
He said Beijing welcomes rank-and-file DPP members wishing to visit China because they are different from the "handful of diehards who champion Taiwan independence."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAIRMAN'S RESIGNATION TAKES EFFECT: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's resignation has become effective and will be sent to the party's Central Standing Committee (CSC) for reference during its Feb. 28 weekly meeting, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.

According to Wu, Ma remained firm on his promise to quit the KMT chairmanship despite the CSC's efforts to persuade him to stay in the post after Ma was indicted a day earlier on corruption charges over his alleged misuse of a special municipal allowance earmarked for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998 to 2006.
Ma tendered his resignation and officially announced his bid to run in the 2008 presidential race following his indictment Tuesday.

As Ma's resignation has taken effect, First Vice Chairman Wu Po-hsiung, in accordance with the party's regulations, will serve as KMT acting chairman in the coming three months until a new chairman is elected through a direct vote among party members.

In an effort to secure Ma's chance to take part in the next presidential election, the powerful CSC rescinded Tuesday evening a special clause implemented last July that bans indicted party members from participating in elections, on the grounds that it goes against the party platform that prohibits only convicted members from running for public office.

According to Juan Kang-meng, director of the KMT's Evaluation and Discipline Committee, the special clause has been removed and the party will only follow its platform to screen KMT members' candidacy in coming elections.

With the removal of the special clause, the KMT need not discuss the issue of Ma's indictment and therefore, the question of whether or not Ma should be suspended from participating in party activities does not exist, Juan said, adding that such rights of other KMT cadres who violated the special clause will be reinstated, including Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin and lawmaker Chang Chang-tsair.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune : Outside pressures broke North Korean deadlock.
Both beset by huge problems, George W. Bush and Kim Jong Il needed some kind of a breakthrough.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.091 to close at NT$32.990.
A total of US$1.06 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.081 and fluctuated between NT$32.975 and NT$33.098.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CLAIMS NO MISUSE IN HER SPECIAL ALLOWANCE FUND

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that she "has faith" in her use of special allowance fund amid reports that prosecutors will soon investigate alleged fund misuse involving many high-ranking officials, including Lu.
Lu claimed to have "no idea whatsoever" on how to handle the fund and said she simply follows the instructions of her staff.
"An executive will not dwell on trivialities," she claimed, adding that she "has confidence in the use of the public fund."

Lu's remarks came one day after prosecutors indicted former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on corruption charges, accusing him of embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$338,500) from his special allowance fund during his tenure as two-term Taipei mayor that ended December 2006. Ma has maintained his innocence.

According to Lu, when prosecutors indicted the first lady on corruption charges over the alleged misuse of the state affairs fund at the discretionary use of President Chen Shui-bian, the public reactions were in stark contrast with Ma's.
"Society has a serious double standard and this is the biggest crisis of the nation," she claimed.
According to Lu, Ma's case is largely similar to the president's 'state affairs fund" case.
If Ma is what Lu considered to be wronged by the prosecution, it is likely that the first lady and others involved in the state affairs fund case have also been wronged.
While the state affairs fund case caused an uproar from the opposition camp, Lu said, it seems that many on this occasion are taking a more lenient attitude toward Ma.
"We should calm down and reflect on whether there is an institutional defect in the system," she said, adding that if necessary, actions should be taken to amend any deficiencies in the system.
First lady Wu Shu-jen is accused of corruption in that she collected invoices from others to claim NT$14.8 million from the state affairs fund use between July 2002 and March 2006.

Prosecutors allege that Ma remitted half of his special allowance fund, or NT$17 million per month into his account, knowing that it should be used for public affairs but failing to return the unspent money to the national coffers. Although Ma claims to have donated over NT$68 million over the years, he did not convince the prosecutors that the donations came from the special allowance fund.

The nation's 6,500 high-ranking officials who are also entitled to special allowances, including Lu, the heads of the five branches of the government, city and county chiefs as well as school principles, are allowed to claim reimbursement from the fund in cash or check form or by direct bank account remittance.

Those who remit the funds into their bank accounts are the easiest to track down compared with those who deal in cash or checks. There have also been conflicting interpretations about whether the fund should be used for public affairs or simply given as a subsidy to the executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HONORARY HEAD AGREES TO HELP ARRANGE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDACY

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan agreed Wednesday to help coordinate and bolster cooperation between two key KMT members in the 2008 presidential election.

Speaking in a press release issued following a meeting with acting Chairman Wu Po-hsiung and five KMT vice chairmen who suggested that Lien help coordinate the presidential candidacy within the party, Lien promised to assist in the matter and called for joint efforts to serve that end.
"It may seem that the KMT is deeply mired in a crisis, but it also presents a turning point in the party's transformation into victory," Lien said.

Although Lien pledged to do his utmost to help forge cooperation between former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng in forming a ticket for the next presidential election, he said, however, that Ma's announcement of his presidential bid in the coming presidential race has "narrowed" the space for coordination.

Ma delivered on his promise to resign from the KMT chairmanship Tuesday after being indicted on corruption charges over his alleged mishandling of a special municipal allowance when serving as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

In a special emergency meeting that evening, the KMT's Central Standing Committee (CSC) returned Ma's resignation and rescinded a special clause that bans indicted party members from running in elections with the aim of bailing out Ma's participation in the 2008 presidential race as a KMT candidate.

Warning the KMT against flow-on effects of the clause's removal, Lien asked Wu to get Ma and Wang to sit down and talk as soon as possible, reiterating that "unity is essential if the KMT wants to win in December's legislative election and regain power in the 2008 presidential polls."
Meanwhile, Wang failed to agree to have a tete-a-tete with Ma in the coming days, despite Lien's hope for a meeting with the two men before the Feb. 18 Chinese New Year.
Instead, Wang urged the KMT to build a noble spirit to gain back widespread public support.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Britains children are unhappiest in the Western world
Britains children are the unhappiest in t he West, according to a Unicef study of 21 industrialised countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MOVES PRESIDENTIAL, LEGISLATIVE ELECTION PRIMARIES FORWARD

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will kick off its primaries for the year-end legislative elections and the March 2008 presidential election earlier than originally scheduled, officials said Wednesday.

The DPP Central Standing Committee passed a proposal at its regular weekly meeting that day that all aspirants for the presidential election must register between March 5 and March 9. A party member vote for both the presidential and legislative elections will be held May 6, which will account for 30 percent of the primary.
Public opinion polls for the presidential election will be held between May 7 and May 28, which will account for the remaining 70 percent. The party will announce its candidate May 30.
All hopefuls for the legislative elections should register with the party from March 12-16 and public opinion polls will be held May 11-June 17 before the candidates are announced June 20.

The DPP said earlier that the primary system should be institutionalized based on the three previous presidential elections, which would mean registration in April, a member vote in May and public opinion polls in June.

However, after President Chen Shui-bian intervened to sort out differences among the four heavyweights and aspirants for the presidency -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- a consensus was reached to bring the primary forward.
"The moving ahead of the primary has nothing to do with the announcement of former Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's bid for the presidential election," Yu said.

Ma resigned as the party head and announced his bid for the presidency after being indicted for allegedly embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$338,500) from a special allowance fund for his discretionary use during his tenure as two-term Taipei mayor that ended December 2006. Ma has maintained his innocence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFESSOR RECEIVES PAPAL BLESSING CERTIFICATE

TEXT.P: Huang Jung-huei, a professor at the Nan Kai Institute of Technology in central Nantou County received a "Certificate of Papal Blessing" from the pope at the Vatican Feb. 11, a spokesman of the college said Wednesday.

Huang, chairman of the college's multimedia art design department, was invited to paint artwork to celebrate the ascension of Pope Benedict XVI in 2005. Having only pictures of the pope from newspapers to work from, Huang spent two weeks depicting the pope's expressions in three Chinese ink paintings.
Cardinal Paul Shan in Taiwan issued the certificate on behalf of the pope to Huang in Kaohsiung, making Huang the first Chinese artist to receive the certificate, the spokesman said.

The pontiff was very glad to receive Huang's gift and said Huang made him look younger in the paintings. The pope plans to take one painting back to his home in Germany, while one will go into the Vatican Museum's collection, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP CALLS FOR DEBATE TO PRODUCE DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: A pro-Taiwan independence group called for debate among the aspirants of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for the 2008 presidential election in lieu of coordination to produce the party's candidate.

The Taiwan Society said that coordination among the four DPP aspirants -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun -- "might be convenient, but it shows no respect for the people."
"If a fair and reasonable set of game rules are followed, then those who fail to be nominated will accept the result gladly, " the group claimed.

Group members said that they are planning to co-sponsor with the media a public debate im March among the DPP presidential hopefuls in which they can present their platforms and engage in cross-debate.
Yu and Hsieh have expressed willingness to take part in such debate, while Lu and Su have yet to confirm their participation, society officials said.
Chin Heng-wei, a society member and TV commentator, said that what really makes the DPP win is the voters, claiming that the progress of democracy relies "on the system, not the people."
Chin claimed that the KMT currently only relies on one person, an oblique allusion to the most likely presidential bet for the party, former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
Chin said that "the potential of the DPP is better than that of the KMT, because the DPP can choose the best candidate through exchanges of views between the voters and the party."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CHINESE DIRECT FLIGHT BRINGS 297 HOME FOR FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: An airplane from the Shanghai-based China Eastern Airlines brought 297 Taiwanese passengers back home from Shanghai Wednesday to celebrate the Lunar New Year festival -- also called the Spring Festival -- which starts n New Year's Eve Feb. 17.
The passenger plane arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at noon, making it the first Chinese aircraft to land on the island this year.

In the absence of direct air links between Taiwan and China, China Eastern is one of six Chinese carriers contracted to provide charter flight service between the two sides during the Lunar New Year holiday season. Six Taiwanese carriers are also allowed to join the service.

The first chartered flight of the kind, operated by the Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines, left the previous day for Shanghai with more than 200 passengers on board -- mostly tourists and family members of Taiwan businessmen operating in China.
The special direct cross-strait charter service will last through the end of the festival season in early March.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENTS SEIZE 45 KG OF HEROIN FROM FISHING BOATS
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Feb. 14 (CNA) 02/14/07 20:31:43 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Law enforcement agents seized 45 kg of heroin bricks from two Taiwanese fishing boats Wednesday after intercepting the boats at sea two days ago.

Agents from the Bureau of Investigation's Kaohsiung office arrested Hsu Tung- sheng, owner of the two fishing boats -- Yu Fa 102 and Yu Fa No. 2 -- and three accomplices: Hu Jui-chung, skipper of Yu Fa 102; chief engineer officer Chen Shih-hsien; and crew member Chen Teh-liang.

Altogether the agents found 106 heroin bricks, with an estimated street value of NT$200 million (US$6.04 million), after the two boats were intercepted by anti- smuggling ships and escorted to Anping harbor in Tainan.

A spokesman for the Bureau of Investigation (BOI) said the bureau's Kaohsiung office received tip-offs from foreign sources last October that Hsu Tung-sheng would attempt to smuggle heroin into Taiwan from Phuket Island, Thailand.

A special task force was subsequently formed to monitor the activities of Hsu's boats. BOI agents also received aid from anti-drug authorities in Thailand and the United States Drug Enforcement Administration to keep Hsu under surveillance while he was in Thailand to contact his suppliers.

According to the spokesman, as Yu Fa 102 sailed into waters approximately 190 nautical miles southwest of Taiwan, Hsu Tung-sheng instructed its skipper, Hsu Hui-chung to phone Tungkang harbor's fishery radio station via satellite, and claim that the boat was low on fuel and needed its sister boat, Yu Fa No. 2, to bring a supply of fuel and meet it in the open sea.
Actually, the spokesman explained, their real intention was to have the Yu Fa No. 2 take possession of the heroin bricks in order to avoid police inspection.

Two anti-smuggling ships dispatched to intercept Yu Fa 102 and Yu Fa No. 2 met the two boats in waters southwest of Taiwan two days ago and escorted them to Anping harbor. At that point, agents boarded the boats and seized the heroin from where it was hidden among the fishing nets and gear.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Iraqis Announce New Crackdown Across Baghdad
The Iraqi government on Tuesday ordered tens of thousands of Baghdad residents to leave homes they are occupying illegally, in a surprising and highly challenging effort to reverse the tide of sectarian cleansing that has left the capital bloodied and Balkanized.
In a televised speech, Lt. Gen. Aboud Qanbar, who is leading the new crackdown, also announced the closing of Iraqs borders with Iran and Syria, an extension of the curfew in Baghdad by an hour, and the setup of new checkpoints run by the Defense and Interior Ministries, both of which General Qanbar said he now controlled.
Wall Street Journal:Shifting Down In Humbling Overhaul,Chrysler Faces Big Cuts
With a painful restructuring slated for today, Chrysler becomes the last of the Detroit Big Three to abandon hope of growing its way out of problems. Now it has a humbler goal: making money.
DaimlerChrysler AG is set to announce that it plans to cut some 10,000 jobs and close factories at its Chrysler Group unit in the U.S. The retrenchment by the company that not long ago claimed to have risen above the problems plaguing General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. highlights the challenges unionized U.S. auto makers face. It's also a setback for DaimlerChrysler chief Dieter Zetsche, who got his job in large part because of his apparent success at turning around Chrysler after a profit collapse in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS DIPLOMATS ARRIVE IN SAN FRANCISCO FOR FRIENDLY VISIT

TEXT.P: The 2006 cohort of Young Diplomats, representing the young people of Taiwan in people-to-people diplomacy, arrived in San Francisco Feb. 13 for a friendly visit as part of their scheduled tour of Canada and the United States, a government official said Wednesday.

Yeh Fei-bi, deputy spokeswoman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and Lin Wen-tung, from the Ministry of Education (MOE), are leading the delegation on its tour of Vancouver, Seattle, and San Francisco.

This is the fifth delegation of Young Diplomats to be co-sponsored by the MOFA and the MOE. During its two-day visit to San Francisco, the delegation will visit the city government, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, and Lowell High School to exchange views and increase their understanding of the city.

The delegation is composed of 12 students from three schools: Wu-ling Senior High School in Taoyuan, Taipei Municipal Nanhu School, and National Hsinchu Girls' Senior High School. These three schools were selected from 137 applicant institutions through various competitions, including group performances and impromptu English public speaking.

Yeh said that the Young Diplomats program aims to encourage students to pay attention to international affairs and improve their English communication skills, and that the delegation's travels abroad will help in Taiwan's people- to-people diplomatic efforts.
Previous visits by the delegation to Seattle has forged precious international friendships for Taiwan, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY MAGISTRATE ACQUITTED OF ELECTION BRIBERY

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was acquitted of election bribery by the Tainan District Prosecutor's Office Tuesday, county officials said Wednesday.
The prosecutor's office was tipped off that the DPP's Tainan County chapter sponsored a barbecue Oct. 9, 2005 to bribe voters ahead of the county magistrate election late that year.

After a thorough probe, prosecutors indicted Su and 20 other DPP candidates for county councilor and township chief elections as well as DPP Tainan chaper staff members Jan. 20, 2006 on vote-buying charges. Prosecutors even recommended that Su be given an eight-month sentence.
But the district court acquitted all of the accused on the ground that the barbecue was a DPP local chapter activity without any intention to bribe voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TULIP EXHIBITION OPENS IN TAICHUNG MUSEUM

TEXT.P: A tulip exhibition opened at the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung Wednesday to coincide with Valentine's Day.
The flower show puts on display more than 60 varieties of tulips, including the Darwin Hybrid group, the Triumph group and the Lily-flowered group, in a great variety of colors.

Many of these tulip varieties were brought in from the Netherlands and cultivated in Taiwan. The Netherlands exports more tulips than any other country, supplying some 7 billion bulbs worth roughly US$750 million a year.

Jack Damen, director of the Agricultural and Food Department in the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office in Taiwan, gave a lecture on the history of his country's tulip industry and the international tulip trade.

He said the tulip is a symbol of caring, love and life, and that to him personally, it is also a symbol of friendship because through these flowers he has made many foreign friends eager to know more about his country.
The tulip exhibition will continue until March 31 with related activities held at the exhibition site, including a flower painting contest and a lecture Feb. 28 on how to cultivate bulbous plants.
Information about the exhibition and related activities can be found at the museum's Web site: http://www.nmns.edu.tw/.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO REVOKE NCC DECISION FAVORING EX-KMT BROADCASTER

TEXT.P: Disaffected with a National Communications Commission (NCC) administrative decision seen as unduly favoring a formerly Kuomintang-owned (KMT) radio station, the Executive Yuan announced Wednesday that it will void the offending decision.
The Executive Yuan will also form a team to investigate the possibility of misconduct and negligence at the NCC, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said in a news conference.

The NCC's moves to make a deal with the Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) , to repeal a previous governmental decision and disregard the Cabinet's policy is a violation of due administrative procedure and ethics, and has done serious harm to the prestige of the government, Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching said.

When the BCC in 2004 applied to renew its broadcasting license with the Government Information Office (GIO), the GIO listed several conditions, including one concerning proportioning of political ads by party on the BCC during the presidential election period, and another that asked the KMT company not to dispose of its ill-gotten real estate before the delivery of a verdict in property litigation. The GIO also asked the BCC to return to government control a number of frequencies.

The BCC filed a lawsuit against the GIO and asked for compensation from the state after an administrative appeal with the Executive Yuan was rejected. In 2006, the newly-founded NCC, which took over the GIO's supervisory role regarding the country's broadcasting companies -- and thus the lawsuit case -- reached a settlement with the BCC, and in early December voided the GIO's previous stipulations.
Later that month, former UFO Radio Chairman and former New Party politician Jaw Shau-kong confirmed that he has bought the BCC.
NCC Vice Chairman Shih Shih-hau reiterated Wednesday that the commission's moves were justified, saying the conditions that the GIO imposed on the BCC were irrelevant.

Election ads are the business of the Central Election Commission, while the property litigation was a civil case; neither has anything to do with the renewal of a broadcasting license, Shih said, adding that the settlement has averted scenarios in which the government may have needed to pay compensation.
Lin Ferng-ching, however, said that the NCC should have gone to the Cabinet for permission when seeking to reach a settlement, rather than arbitrarily deciding to repeal previous stipulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HONORARY CHAIR TO HELP COORDINATE CHOICE OF 2008 PARTY CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) honorary Chairman Lien Chan will host a meeting Friday to help arrive at a consensus among all aspirants contending to be the party's candidate in the 2008 presidential election, party sources said Wednesday.

Early efforts to come to an agreement on the party's presidential ticket grew urgent after former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou announced his presidential bid and resigned as KMT chairman following his indictment on corruption charges Tuesday.

Lien said earlier in the day that Ma's hasty announcement of his presidential bid may "narrow" the maneuvering room available in attempting to coordinate with another party kingpin -- Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.

Ma, a former mayor of Taipei, has been seen as the front-runner in the 2008 race. His indictment over the alleged misappropriation of public funds during his mayoral term has dealt a serious blow to the KMT.
Party sources now say the best hope for the party to win the 2008 presidential election is for Ma to make peace with his bitter political rival.
Ma beat Wang in a contest for the party's chairmanship election in 2005 by painting his rival as corrupt, but Tuesday's charges have undermined Ma's once formidable "Mr. Clean" image.

Analysts said Wang resented the accusations, which may have stoked his interest in opposing Ma in the KMT's presidential selection process, or perhaps even have encouraged him to consider running as an independent in the presidential poll.
Through KMT acting Chairman Wu Po-hsiung's intensive contacts, Wang and Ma have accepted Lien's invitation to a meeting at Lien's office Friday morning, party sources said.
But the sources said it remains unclear how Lien would push for Wang and Ma to team up -- forming a Wang-Ma ticket or a Ma-Wang ticket -- or to come to terms on other options.

According to the sources, Wang has assumed a low profile since Ma's announcement of his presidential bid. Wang said earlier in the day that he feels no rush to announce his future plans. "I think I still have much time to review all variables before coming to a decision," he told reporters.
Sources close to Wang said joining the presidential race remains Wang's top priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGE MARKS NO VIOLATION OF COMMITMENTS TO U.S.: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday the campaign to rename state-owned companies to remove Chinese reference and add the word "Taiwan" to their titles to avoid confusions with similarly named Chinese counterparts has nothing to do with changes of the country's official title.

The corporate redesignation campaign is also by no means in violation of his "four noes" commitment to the United States, whcih includes no change to the country's official title during his presidency, Chen added.
Chen made the remarks during agathering with reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO REVOKE NCC DECISION FAVORING EX-KMT BROADCASTER

TEXT.P: Disaffected with a National Communications Commission (NCC) administrative decision seen as unduly favoring a formerly Kuomintang-owned (KMT) radio station, the Executive Yuan announced Wednesday that it will void the offending decision.
The Executive Yuan will also form a team to investigate the possibility of misconduct and negligence at the NCC, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said in a news conference.

The NCC's moves to make a deal with the Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) , to repeal a previous governmental decision and disregard the Cabinet's policy is a violation of due administrative procedure and ethics, and has done serious harm to the prestige of the government, Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching said.

When the BCC in 2004 applied to renew its broadcasting license with the Government Information Office (GIO), the GIO listed several conditions, including one concerning proportioning of political ads by party on the BCC during the presidential election period, and another that asked the KMT company not to dispose of its ill-gotten real estate before the delivery of a verdict in property litigation. The GIO also asked the BCC to return to government control a number of frequencies.

The BCC filed a lawsuit against the GIO and asked for compensation from the state after an administrative appeal with the Executive Yuan was rejected. In 2006, the newly-founded NCC, which took over the GIO's supervisory role regarding the country's broadcasting companies -- and thus the lawsuit case -- reached a settlement with the BCC, and in early December voided the GIO's previous stipulations.
Later that month, former UFO Radio Chairman and former New Party politician Jaw Shau-kong confirmed that he has bought the BCC.
NCC Vice Chairman Shih Shih-hau reiterated Wednesday that the commission's moves were justified, saying the conditions that the GIO imposed on the BCC were irrelevant.

Election ads are the business of the Central Election Commission, while the property litigation was a civil case; neither has anything to do with the renewal of a broadcasting license, Shih said, adding that the settlement has averted scenarios in which the government may have needed to pay compensation.
Lin Ferng-ching, however, said that the NCC should have gone to the Cabinet for permission when seeking to reach a settlement, rather than arbitrarily deciding to repeal previous stipulations.
