DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 15, or the 28th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1564: Galileo Galilei, the Italian astronomer and physicist who was the first to use a telescope to study the stars, is born.
1748: Jeremy Bentham, English philosopher, is born. He was a pioneer of utilitarianism, an ethical doctrine which holds that the best action is one that will result in the greatest happiness and least pain for the greatest number of people.
1898: The U.S. battleship Maine, which was sent to Cuba to protect American citizens during the Cuban rebellion against Spanish rule, explodes and sinks in Havana Harbor as 260 lose their lives.
1912: Yuan Shih-kai is elected provisional president by the provisional Senate.
1922: The Permanent Court of International Justice, established by the League of Nations, holds its first session in The Hague, capital of the Netherlands.
1928: After some 70 years of efforts, the Oxford English Dictionary is published.
1933: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt escapes an assassination attempt in Miami by Italian-born anarchist Giuseppe Zangara.
1936: China's first international long-distance telephone service between Shanghai and Tokyo begins operation.
1942: Thousands of British troops in Singapore surrender to Japanese forces in World War II.
1944: The Allies begin to bomb the German-held strategic position of Monte Cassino in Italy as some 1,000 British bombers pound Berlin, Germany. Meanwhile U.S. troops recapture the Solomon Islands in the Pacific in World War II.
1945: British forces reach the River Rhine in their advance toward Berlin during World War II.
1946: The world's first computer is born at a university in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania.
1952: Greece and Turkey formally join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1965: Canada adopts a new national flag with red and white colors as its base and a maple leaf at the center.
1965: Mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Chen Yi says in Beijing that peaceful coexistence with the United States is out of the question.
1966: South Korean President Park Chung Hee arrives in Taipei for a four-day state visit.
1970: A Dominican Airlines DC-9 crashes into the sea, killing all 102 aboard.
1973: Henry A. Kissinger, the United States' national security adviser under President Richard M. Nixon, visits the Chinese mainland.
1973: The Republic of China and Paraguay sign an agreement on technical cooperation at Asuncion.
1974: The Chinese Petroleum Corporation signs an oil exploration agreement with two Philippine corporations.
1974: Arthur Pothuije, director of the new U.S. Trade Center in Taipei, arrives with his wife.
1974: Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of state for finance and national economy, arrives in Taipei for talks on economic cooperation.
1975: Kuo Chie-hsiung of the Republic of China fires a record 6-under-par 66 for an eight-stroke victory in the Philippines Open Golf Championship.
1976: Clement C. Conger, curator of the U.S. White House and the diplomatic reception room of the U.S. State Department, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1989: The Soviet Union withdraws its remaining soldiers from Afghanistan, ending nine years of military intervention.
1994: Pyongyang agrees to open part of its nuclear program to international inspection.
1995: A fire at a restaurant in Taichung City claims 64 lives in one of Taiwan's worst fire disasters in recent years.
1999: Henry Kendall, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, dies at the age of 72. He is considered a pioneer of the environmental movement among scientists.
2000: The two new naval patrol boats, the Chinchiang and the Hsianchiang, are formally commissioned by the ROC Navy.
2001: The sixth Japanese-Taiwan academic symposium, sponsored by the Asia- Pacific Forum of Japan, is held in Tokyo, attended by about 50 scholars and experts from the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, sentiment is called out by the study of poetry; judgment is formed by the study of the arts; and education of the character is completed by the study of music."

DOC.HEADLINE: HOG TRACEABILITY SYSTEM TO BE IN PLACE BY JUNE: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: A hog traceability system will be introduced by the end of June as part of the government's efforts to prevent sick and dead hogs from being illegally processed into edible pork products, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Thursday.

Premier Su Tseng-chang gave the directive after a Council of Agriculture (COA) official delivered a report on stepping up supervision of pork production to ensure food sanitation at a weekly Cabinet meeting the day before, Cheng said.

According to Cheng, the premier also ordered the COA to flesh out measures for stricter control of sick and dead hogs, including encouraging hog farmers to join a national hog insurance program to secure compensation in the event of the death of their hogs.

With consumers getting increasingly critical of food quality and hygiene, Premier Su said relevant government agencies should initiate new measures and new systems to streamline management of farm produce production and marketing.
Su also said that a farm produce traceability system should be introduced and promoted throughout the country, according to Cheng.

Compared with other farm products, it should be easier to implement a traceability system for hogs, Su said, adding that technical details for implementing the system should be in place by the end of June.
Su said that under the new system, each package of pork products should have a label explaining where the hog was reared, as well as information about the farm and the breed.
According to COA tallies, Taiwan produces about 9 million hogs annually. To strengthen management, Su said the hog insurance system should be expanded to cover as many hogs as possible.

The COA has come up with a plan to set up a special fund, with money provided by hog farmers and relevant government agencies, to subsidize farmers in case their insured hogs die. The subsidy may reach about 70 percent of the market price of the dead hog.

According to a COA plan, the current hog insurance program will be expanded to cover up to 5.7 million hogs raised in 18 cities and counties around the island by the end of this year. In the future, COA officials said, all of the hogs raised in the country will be covered by the insurance program.

Meanwhile, the premier asked law enforcement authorities to speed up investigations into suspicious trade in sick and dead hogs and bring to justice all those involved. Unscrupulous dealers should be harshly punished and fined, while areas where relatively large quantities of suspicious pork products have been uncovered should be listed for intensified monitoring and crackdown, Su said.

The issue of sick and dead hogs being sold on the market has drawn the public's attention after substandard pork products were uncovered in certain southern counties earlier this month. Key government agencies have reached an agreement to list sick and dead hogs as waste subject to stringent regulation.

The Environmental Protection Administration is working on a set of rules to better govern the disposal of sick and dead hogs. For its part, the COA will coordinate with county and city governments to establish an orderly hog production and sale system. And the Department of Health will step up its crackdown on illegal pork processing plants, inspections on downstream pork vendors and probes into the sources of suspicious meat products used for human consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
VP LU HAS NO PLANS AT PRESENT TO JOIN DPP PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that she has no plans at present to take part in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) primary for the 2008 presidential election.

Lu dismissed as "groundless" a media report claiming that President Chen Shui- bian has tried to dissuade her and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun from running for the presidency in 2008 in an effort to "simplify" the presidential competition within the DPP.
"How could President Chen possibly have dissuaded me as I have never told him that I want to join the race?" Lu asked.

According to the report, Chen is trying to reduce the number of DPP contenders to just two, namely former Premier Frank Hsieh and incumbent Premier Su Tseng- chang, and has offered to arrange some other positions for Lu and Yu in exchange for them agreeing not to run.
Lu, Yu, Hsieh and Su are widely seen as "the four DPP heavyweights" who are likely to compete to represent the party in the next presidential election.
Asked about the same report Thursday, Yu denied any knowledge of the president's reported efforts to dissuade him and Lu from joining the race.

While expressing his support for efforts within the DPP to try to mediate among the presidential aspirants, Yu, however, said such efforts, if excessive, might create misunderstanding that the DPP is making some kind of under-the-counter deals with the aspirants.
Yu confirmed that President Chen has consulted with him about the possibility of his taking over the premiership, but he stressed that the offer has nothing to do with the presidential election.
Yu said he has no intention of leaving his present position, because as the DPP chairman, he can do a lot of things for the country, especially those related to the country's development and future.

Also commenting on the report, Wang Shu-huei, a deputy whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said that the DPP has a complete primary system to guide the nomination of candidates for public offices and that it is unlikely the president will try to dissuade anyone from running for the presidency when no one has publicly announced their decision to join the race.
According to a timetable for the presidential primary finalized by the DPP's Central Standing Committee Wednesday, registration for the primary will be open from March 5-9.

A vote by party members is scheduled for May 6, while opinion polls on the support ratings of the aspirants will be conducted from May 7-28. The outcome of the primary is slated to be announced May 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOTAL NUMBER OF CIVIL SERVANTS DOWN SLIGHTLY

TEXT.P: The number of civil servants in Taiwan totaled 335,274 as of the end of 2006, with their age averaging 42.88 years, the Ministry of Civil Service under the Examination Yuan said Thursday.
The figure marked a decrease of 1,987 from 337,261 at the end of 2005, mainly because of the continued streamlining of state-owned enterprises and health institutions, ministry officials said.
The officials made the remarks while delivering a report on the manpower structure of the nation's civil service at the Examination Yuan.

By level of government, there were 185,286 civil servants working for the central government, accounting for 55.26 percent of the total, and 149,988 civil servants working at local-level government agencies.
By gender, men significantly outnumbered women, with a total of 211,374 of the civil servants, or 63.05 percent, being male.
The average age of the civil servants was 42.88 years, up 0.29 years from the average of 42.59 years at the end of 2005.
The average age of civil servants working for the central government was 44.55 years, with their period of service averaging 16.72 years, up 0.25 years from 16.47 years at the end of 2005.
In terms of education background, civil servants with university degrees and above accounted for 76.45 percent of the total.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TRAFFIC POLICE TO BE BOOSTED DURING HOLIDAY PERIOD

TEXT.P: The number of traffic police will be doubled to maintain road safety and keep traffic flowing during the Chinese New Year holidays as the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) forecasts a 40-percent increase in the number of travelers using Taiwan's roadways during the holiday period, an official of the Naitonal Police Agency (NPA) said Thursday.
According to the NPA's transportation affairs department, a total of 10,241 traffic police officers and 2,959 volunteer traffic police will be dispatched on roadways around Taiwan between Feb. 17-25.

Meanwhile, police will step up measures and crack down on traffic violators at scenic spots, main connecting roadways and major bottleneck spots on highways around the island to keep traffic moving along during peak travel periods during the holidays.

The MOTC also announced that a special "traffic conditions hotline" will be set up, with traffic police around the island reporting several times a day on the latest traffic situation in their respective jurisdictions.

Meanwhile, the NPA urged anyone planning on taking a road trip during the holiday period to listen to the Police Radio Station to get the latest update on the traffic conditions along their planned route before setting off.

The NPA also asked members of the general public to use the special toll-free hotline, at 080000123, to report any heavy traffic congestion they encounter while traveling in order to assist police in their efforts to keep traffic flowing smoothly during the holiday period.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IMPORTS NO CONTAMINATED U.S. PEANUT BUTTER: DOH

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not imported peanut butter from two U. S. brands that have been linked to a recent salmonella outbreak in America, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday.

A salmonella outbreak that has slowly grown to nearly 300 cases in 37 U.S. states since last August has been linked to tainted jars of Peter Pan or Great Value peanut butter -- both brands produced by the same ConAgra Foods company.

Cheng Hui-wen, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Safety said that after detailed examination it was found that Taiwan has not imported those brands of peanut butter -- which has only been sold in the U.S. state of Georgia -- over the past year.
ConAgra Foods has reportedly begun to recall all Peter Pan and Great Value peanut butter produced after May 2006, according to Cheng.
Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH Center for Disease Control, said salmonella infection is most commonly caused by uncooked chicken, followed by infant formula.

It is probably the first salmonella outbreak associated with peanut butter in U.S. history since about 85 percent of the infected people said they ate peanut butter, according to a report from the U. S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. About 20 percent of the people infected have been hospitalized, although none have died.
U.S. health officials said how salmonella got into the peanut butter is still under investigation.
Shih said the CDC has launched an investigation, via the Taiwan PulseNet, into all imported food products and has found no suspicious cases of salmonella contamination.
Symptoms of salmonella can include diarrhea, fever, dehydration, abdominal pain and vomiting, according to Shih.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-KMT HEAD'S PRESIDENTIAL BID REFLECTS 'DOUBLE STANDARD': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang accused former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying- jeou of adopting a "double standard" in how he is dealing with his own corruption charges and those against first lady Wu Shu-jen.
Su was commenting on Ma's announcement, immediately after being charged with corruption Tuesday, of his bid to run for the presidency in 2008.

Su pointed out that Ma demanded that President Chen Shui-bian step down when Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for alleged misuse of the president's "state affairs fund, " a case in which Chen was named as a "joint perpetrator" but not charged because he currently enjoys presidential immunity from criminal prosecution.
However, contrary to what Ma has demanded of Chen, Ma is now making a bid for the presidency while facing similar charges, Su said.

The anti-corruption center of the Taiwan High Court Prosecutor's Office indicted Ma Tuesday on corruption charges after determining that he embezzled NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use during his two terms as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

While resigning from the KMT chairmanship immediately after the indictment, Ma claimed that he is innocent and announced his decision to run for the presidency in 2008 to prove his integrity "via voter support" in the election.

Ma claimed he had no intention of breaking the law because he considered the fund set aside for his discretionary use as "private money, " as it is regarded by every other recipient of similar funds in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MEDIATION BEFORE REGISTRATION CLOSED FOR DPP PRIMARY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has no plan to mediate among the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential aspirants before the registration period for the party's primary ends, a Presidential Office official said Thursday.

According to Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, it is impossible for the president to do anything before that date, because there is no way to know who will be vying for the party's nomination until then.
Cho said recent newspaper reports about President Chen trying to dissuade certain aspirants from joining the race are based merely on speculation.

A local daily reported Thursday that Chen has tried to dissuade Vice President Annette Lu and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun from running for the presidency in 2008 in an effort to "simplify" the presidential competition within the DPP.

It said Chen is trying to reduce the number of DPP contenders to just two, namely former Premier Frank Hsieh and incumbent Premier Su Tseng-chang, and has offered to arrange some other positions for Lu and Yu in exchange for them agreeing not to run.

Lu, Yu, Hsieh and Su are widely seen as "the four DPP heavyweights" who are likely to compete to represent the party in the next presidential election, but none of them has publicly announced their decision to join the race.
Both Lu and Yu have denied having discussed the issue with the president.
According to a timetable for the presidential primary finalized by the DPP's Central Standing Committee Wednesday, registration for the primary will be open from March 5-9.

A vote by party members is scheduled for May 6, while opinion polls on the support ratings of the contenders will be conducted from May 7-28. The outcome of the primary is slated to be announced May 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAVYWEIGHTS TO MEET OVER PRESIDENTIAL BID

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and four another party heavyweights are to meet Friday in an effort to build a consensus and encourage cooperation within the party prior to its presidential primaries, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said Thursday.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Wu Den-yih said that Lien is to call a meeting the next day with KMT Acting Chairman Wu Po-hsiung, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to coordinate presidential candidacy within the party.

Lien's Wednesday decision to mediate the issue came one day after Wu Po-hsiung, leading five KMT vice chairmen, paid a visit to Lien to express their hope that Lien, a respected figure in the party, could assist in coordinating the matter before he leaves Taiwan Saturday to spend the Chinese New Year holiday overseas.
Lien is expected to push Ma and Wang to form a single ticket, avoiding a KMT split in the coming presidential polls.

As to a media report that the two Wus have formed an alliance to help Ma outgun Wang in seeking the KMT's nomination for the 2008 presidential race, Wu Den-yih said that Wu Po-hsiung will lead the party in accordance with its regulations after Ma stepped down as KMT chairman Tuesday over an indictment againsh him on corruption charges earlier the same day.

Ma immediately announced his decision to quit the KMT chairmanship and officially made public his presidential bid following the indictment over his allegedly mishandling of a special municipal allowance allocated for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1996 to 2006.
Ma's announcement of his intention to take part in the next presidential election has placed Wang, who is also keenly interested in vying for the KMT's nomination, in an awkward position.

In a bid to secure Ma's right to participate in the party's presidential primaries, the KMT's powerful Central Standing Committee removed a special clause banning indicted members from running in elections during its weekly meeting Wednesday, provoking criticism that it is a tailor-made measure to bail out Ma.
KMT-affiliated Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, who met Lien earlier Thursday, said that Lien strongly believes that unity is the key to securing the party's victory in the 2008 presidential race.
Hau quoted Lien as saying that both Ma and Wang are valuable assets to the KMT but that the two men need to cooperate to win the election.
According to Hau, Lien contended that there absolutely is room for coordination to work out a solution between Ma and Wang given the precondition that party unity be maintained.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW TO SERVE AT HOSPITAL IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, orthopedic surgeon Chao Chien-ming, will serve at SinLau Hospital's Matou branch starting March 1, the hospital announced Thursday at a news conference in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.

SinLau Hospital superintendent Chuang Ming-hsiung said at the news conference that Chao hopes for a fresh start and that the board of directors of the hospital only agreed to hire him after he vowed to serve "with a spirit of voluntarism" by donating his entire salary to charity.

Chuang said that Chao first talked with hospital officials on January 18 but that he did not touch on the subject of serving at the hospital during that talk. Later, Rev. Kao Chun-ming, former president of the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan, served as a go-between, and the hospital learned of Chao's intention of serving patients in remote areas.
Rev. Kao said that when he first met with Chao, he was at his lowest point in life because of the insider trading scandal.

Kao said that as a Christian, he wanted to extend a helping hand to others. He added that he was also deeply moved by Chao's aspiration to help people in need in remote areas and therefore began actively working to help Chao achieve his goal.
Chuang said that Chao will donate his entire salary to charity, but the hospital has yet to determine how much to pay him and what organization or organizations the money should be given to.
The superintendent denied that the government has offered him the post of Department of Health minister in exchange for inviting Chao to work at the hospital.
Chuang said that he was once indeed interested in politics but that he has lost "the zest for it" in recent years.
The hospital has dealt directly with Chao concerning his request to work there, and no one at the Presidential Office or in the first family has been involved in the hiring, Chuang said.
Chao was not present at Thursday's news conference. Instead, a written statement in which he expressed his appreciation to the hospital for allowing him to work there was read at the news conference.
In the statement, Chao also asked that he be allowed to carry out his work of helping patients at the hospital without being hounded by members of the media.

Chao recently resigned from National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) , with the resignation taking effect Wednesday. He was suspended from duty by the hospital immediately after he was indicted in July 2006 on charges of insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stocks.
NTUH voted down Chao's request to return to his job last October on the grounds that he had "seriously violated medical ethics."

The Taipei District Court sentenced Chao to six years in prison and fined him NT$30 million (US$909,090) in December after determining that he had taken advantage of his influence to obtain important information regarding TDC share prices, based upon which he traded TDC shares for huge profits.
Chao has appealed his case to the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS 80% OF WORKING PEOPLE PUT MONEY BEFORE LOVE

TEXT.P: A survey conducted by 1111 Manpower Bank, an online job search firm, shows that over 80 percent of working men and women believe financial means are a prerequisite for marriage, a spokesman for the manpower bank said Thursday.

Wu Juei-ying, vice general manager and spokesman for 1111 Manpower Bank, said that the online survey, conducted Jan. 30- Feb. 13, on working class attitudes towards love and money, elicited 1,957 valid responses.

The results of the survey show that 80.71 percent of working women would not marry to those with poor financial resources, and 80.37 percent of working men admit that they would not make a commitment to a girlfriend under similar conditions.

Wu pointed out that three ideal indications of financial ability that women look for in men are a monthly income of NT$100,000 (US$ 3,043) --31.56 percent, home ownership--25.80 percent, and NT$1 million in available funds--13.86 percent.

Working men ranked highest the following three threshold conditions for entering into marriage: available cash of NT$1 million--33.11 percent, stable monthly income of NT$ 100,000--20.78 percent, and a car--16.89 percent.

Overall, the three top ranked considerations when considering stepping out of a love affair and into a marriage, for both unmarried men and women, are a stable relationship (78.83 percent), financial ability (71.17 percent), and stable employment (44.67 percent).
Wu said only less than 20 percent of working people believe in love without money.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

Despite criticism about tax breaks and land giveaways, the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors and the Los Angeles City Council gave final approvals Tuesday to a sprawling mini-city atop Bunker Hill that will alter L.A.'s skyline and set a course for future development in downtown. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWYER/COMMISSIONER FOUND DROWNED IN RIVER

TEXT.P: Lawyer Vincent Wang, who doubled as a commissioner of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, was found drowned in a river in Taipei City's southern suburb Thursday. He was 39 years old.
Wang's body was first found by an angler under the Wanshou Bridge in Mucha in Taipei City's southern suburb Thursday morning.
Police cordoned off the scene, where prosecutors and forensics experts arrived later to conduct an investigation into the cause of Wang's drowning.
Wang's newly-wed wife said Wang went out for a walk late Wednesday night saying that he was feeling really low.

Chien Shih-ying, chief secretary of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, quoted Wang's friends and relatives as saying that Wang had been in low spirits as he had been under great pressure at work and had undergone two surgeries in recent months.
Chien said the commission will do its best to help Wang's family in matters concerning their former colleague's funeral.

TEXT.P: Economic growth for 2007 will be 4.3 percent, the Directorate Generate of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) predicted Thursday.
DGBAS officials also said that economic growth for the fourth quarter of 2006 was 4.02 percent, and the growth for the whole year was 4.62 percent.
The consumer price index (CPI) in 2006 registered an annual increase of 0.6 percent. It is expected that the CPI increase for 2007 will be 1.43 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLENTY OF PORK SUPPLIES FOR FIRST HALF OF YEAR: COA

TEXT.P: The supply of pork in the first half of this year should be more than adequate, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

COA officials said that the results of the latest census, which was conducted last November, show that hog farmers could provide 4.78 million hogs in the first half the year, indicating that there will be an ample supply of pork.
The survey also showed that there were 12,671 hog farmers at the end of last November, down 2.3 percent from the same month in the previous year.
The number of hogs totaled 7.09 million, down 1.4 percent year-on-year. On average, each operation raised 560 hogs.

The COA said that the survey showed that six counties south of Changhua are the major areas to rear the hogs -- Pingtung County, Yunlin County, Changhua County, Tainan County, Kaohsiung County and Chiayi County. The number of hogs raised in the six counties account for 83.1 percent of national hog production.

The COA said that the census also included black hogs whose meat is preferred among local people. The census also showed that 90 percent of the hogs raised by 5,587 hog farmers, or 44.1 percent of all hog farmers, were black hogs.
The survey also showed the number of black hogs is now 1.06 million, accounting for 15 percent of the hogs around the island, and that operations raising black hogs tend to work on a smaller scale.

The census also queried hog farmers about their intentions to raise hogs in the first part of the year, with the result showing that 85 percent of them said that they would maintain their present level, 10 percent said that they are willing to cut the number, and three percent said they are willing to increase the number.

The COA said that with the rise in the price of feed on the international market the cost of raising hogs has also risen, suggesting that hog growers not to increase the number of hogs, and should adopt a limited growth strategy to maintain hog price and ensure profitability.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC OPINION REFLECTS RISING TAIWANESE IDENTITY: MAC REPORT

TEXT.P: Public opinion showed a rise in expressions of Taiwanese identity in the nation in 2006, according to a report released Thursday by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

After analyzing all public surveys carried out in 2006 in Taiwan on issues concerning cross-Taiwan Strait relations, MAC researchers come up with the following four conclusions: the Taiwan people support the idea of promoting cross-strait exchanges in the fields of trade and investment in a prudent manner; public opinion reflects a growing Taiwanese identity; the Taiwan people hope that Beijing will conduct negotiations and talks with the Taiwan government; and the Taiwan people strongly agree that government should take steps to expand Taiwan's role in the international community.
The report was compiled by the MAC from the results of 49 public surveys conducted by 15 different poll centers around the island.
On questions concerning Taiwan independence or unification with China, all of the surveys show that most respondents favor the idea of maintaining the status quo, the MAC said.

Most survey respondents oppose unification as described in Taiwan's now shelved Guidelines for National Unification, as well as China's "one country, two systems" policy, and believe that Taiwan's future should be decided by the people of Taiwan, the MAC said.

In terms of cross-strait trade and investment, the MAC said the survey results show that Taiwanese people do not believe the country has benefited from Taiwanese investment in China and think the government should impose stricter restrictions on investment in China.

While most survey respondents expressed support for the government' s "active management, effective opening" policy regarding cross-strait trade and investment, they also support the notion that the government should reinforce its management of such exchanges, with national interests the guiding principle, the MAC said.

On the subject of cross-strait negotiations, the MAC said most of the respondents believe Beijing's decision to make contact with Taiwan's private sector but keep "open lines of communication" with the government will affect the general interests of Taiwan.

The MAC said the surveys show that the public do not agree with Beijing's attempt to deny the existence of Taiwan's government and that opposition political parties cannot take the place of the government in dealing with problems derived from cross-strait exchanges.
Only through government-to-government channels can the national interests and rights of Taiwan be properly secured, the MAC claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO HOLD ICT INDUSTRY FORUM AT HANOVER CEBIT SHOW

TEXT.P: The semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will hold a forum on the development of the information and communications technology (ICT) industry at the upcoming 2007 CeBIT show in Hanover, Germany, TAITRA officials said Thursday.

The Taiwan ICT industry forum is slated for March 16, with representatives of the German Association for Information Technology, Telecommunications and New Media, O2 -- a leading European company in telecommunications operations, and major mobile phone manufacturers of Taiwan invited to attend for talks about the ICT industry's future development, according to TAITRA officials.

CeBIT, the world's largest trade fair showcasing digital IT and telecommunications solutions, will be held March 15-21 with the participation of more than 6,000 businesses from 71 countries. Over 570 of the participants will be from Taiwan, the officials said.

Displays at the fair's 24 exhibition halls will be divided into six major sections -- business processes, communications, digital equipment and systems, banking and finance, the public sector, and the future. The event is expected to draw around 450,000 visitors from around the world.
Over 6,200 exhibitors from around 70 countries and some 430,000 visitors attended the 2006 CeBIT show.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MUST PAY DAMAGES FOR UNSUPPORTED CLAIM: COURT

TEXT.P: Taipei District Court ruled Thursday that President Chen Shui-bian must pay opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong NT$3 million (US$91,183) in damages and apologize in newspapers for his allegation that Soong met secretly with China's State Council Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin in 2005.
The court said the president failed to carry out necessary verification before making his allegation.
"The president exercises overall control over the executive sector resources and his responsibility to verify information must be weighted," a court spokesman said.

PFP spokesman Lee Hung-Chun called the judgment "comforting" but said it came too late. "It took more than a year for the first judgment to come out," he said, adding that this meant the public did not get the chance to learn the truth during a time when the political situation was changing rapidly.
Chen's counsel said he will appeal to the High Court.
Chen claimed in an interview with a cable TV channel in May 2005 that Soong met Chen Yunlin in the United States in February that year.

Claiming that his remarks were based on "intelligence," Chen also said Soong promised during the meeting to oppose a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, in exchange for Beijing's approval for Soong to visit China.
Soong filed a defamation suit against Chen in June 2005, demanding a symbolic NT$1 in compensation and a published apology in four major local newspapers for three consecutive days.

After Chen repeated his claim in another TV interview in October that same year, Soong extended his compensation demand to NT$50 million and asked Chen to publish an apology in four internationally famous newspapers in the United States, the United Kingdom, France and Japan, as well as in three local ones.

According to the written judgment, Chen said that the intelligence about Soong's activity was submitted to him by Bureau of Investigation Director- General Yeh Cherng-maw. However, Yeh told the court that he had warned Chen that the intelligence, some of which he admitted was drawn from media speculation, was difficult to check.

The judgment said that as president, Chen must have understood the weakness of the information and could have ordered the national security system to conduct further verification, but decided not to bother.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARLYLE AGREES TO TERMINATE ASE BUYOUT EXCLUSIVE CLAUSE

TEXT.P: The U.S. Carlyle Group has agreed to terminate an exclusive clause that it signed late last year with Taiwan's Advanced Semiconductor Engineering, Inc. (ASE) concerning Carlyle's proposed buyout, ASE officials announced Thursday.

ASE announced that the exclusive clause -- signed by ASE Chairman Jason Chang and the Carlyle Group management Nov. 16 -- along with agreements on buyout costs and contract-breaching compensation, became null and void with immediate effect.

Noting that the termination complies with U.S. stock market regulations and norms, the officials said the company sought the termination of the exclusive clause aimed at protecting the interests of ASE investors from Taiwan and abroad.

The Carlyle Group, one of the world's largest private equity firms, offered in early January to purchase ASE, the world's largest chip packaging and testing company, for approximately US$5.5 billion, or NT$39 per share for ASE's entire stocks, and make it private.
ASE said it was not sure whether NT$39 per share is a reasonable price for the buyout and that there are probably other companies willing to acquire ASE at a higher price.
The Carlyle Group's ASE acquisition case, however, is still being reviewed by an assessment group headed by Cheng Tien-cheng, a member of the ASE board, the officials said.
So far, ASE is still uncertain as to whether the Carlyle Group will still be interested in continuing the acquisition bid, they added.

The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, a non-profit association that groups companies involved in business between Taiwan and the United States, said Feb. 1 in a news release that the potential deal highlights the ability of Taiwan companies to attract substantial foreign investments, greatly benefiting Taiwan's economy.

It also underscores the attractiveness of Taiwan's semiconductor market, which the council has predicted will become the world's largest market for chip equipment spending and for DRAM production in 2007, due largely to new partnerships and a number of new investments, the press statement said.
Responding to the U.S. council's comments, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official in charge of investment affairs said the buyout application is still in the opinion-soliciting stage.

According to the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, the Carlyle Group's intention to enter Taiwan's semiconductor market reflects the high caliber of Taiwan businesses and a desire to link the U.S. and Taiwan -- arguably the two most important semiconductor markets in the world.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Bush Declares Irans Arms Role in Iraq Is Certain
President Bush said Wednesday that he was certain that factions within the Iranian government had supplied Shiite militants in Iraq with deadly roadside bombs that had killed American troops. But he said he did not know whether Irans highest officials had directed the attacks.
Mr. Bushs remarks amounted to his most specific accusation to date that Iran was undermining security in Iraq. They appeared to be part of a concerted effort by the White House to present a clearer, more direct case that Iran was supplying the potent weapons X and to push back against criticism that the intelligence used in reaching the conclusions was not credible.
Wall Street Journal:How a Chastened KPMG Got By Tax-Shelter Crisis
Timothy Flynn, a top executive at KPMG LLP, was driving to a nephew's graduation in May 2005 when he got a phone call from the chairman: The firm faced imminent criminal indictment over tax shelters it used to sell.
Then a different sort of shock. One week later, the chairman, Eugene O'Kelly, learned he had a brain tumor that left him just months to live. Mr. Flynn, a down-to-earth accountant who once led KPMG's human-resources department, was suddenly thrust into its top job, where he faced an urgent task: to somehow persuade the government not to indict. He knew that criminal charges against the firm would probably kill it, as they did Arthur Andersen after the Enron scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCA TO PROMOTE TAIWAN LIFE AESTHETICS MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) will spend four years promoting the "Taiwan Life Aesthetics Movement" with a budget of NT$ 3.02 billion (US$ 91.9 million) from the central government, a spokesman for the CCA said Thursday.

To increase the Taiwanese people's awareness of aesthetics and the environment, the CCA solicited contributions from experts and scholars then drafted a plan for the "Taiwan Life Aesthetics Movement, " which has since been referred to the Executive Yuan for approval.

According to the spokesman, the plan has three main aspects: creating an artistic environment, increasing public awareness of aesthetics, and nurturing talents in the arts. The movement's goals include the reformation, promotion, demonstration, and evaluation of art.

The first aspect of the plan calls for an "artistic reformation of public space" and an "aesthetics reformation of cultural arenas". The second includes a "student museum" and general "life aesthetics promotion", while the third envisions the creation of an "artistic promotional bank" and provision of local "artistic creative resources."
The CCA hopes to cultivate the Taiwanese people's aesthetic sensibilities and create a robust environment in which the country's art will flourish, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUICIDE MORTALITY DROPS FOR FIRST TIME IN DECADE: DOH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's crude (unadjusted by age) death rate from suicide grew by 0.7 percent or 4,000 people last year, marking the first decline in a decade in this regard, the National Suicide Prevention Center (NSPC) under the Department of Health (DOH) reported Thursday.

Compared to the growth of 23 percent posted during the 2004-2005 period, the 0.7 percent growth figure posted in 2006 was massively relieved, said Hsu Ching- hsin, a department chief of the DOH Bureau of Medical Affairs.
The growth figure stood at 15 percent 10 years ago, according to tallies compiled by the DOH.
The country's crude death rate from suicide hit an all-time high of 18.8 per 100,000 people in 2005.
According to DOH tallies, suicide was the ninth most frequent cause of death in Taiwan in 2005, with crude mortality surpassing the previous record of 18.73 persons per 100,000 recorded in 1964.
Since the NSPC was inaugurated in January 2005, local hospitals and clinics have been required to report every attempted suicide case.

Crude mortality from suicide also declined in Keeling City, Taoyuan County, Changhua County and Kaohsiung City since the four cities and counties were selected for enforced suicide-prevention efforts, Hsu said.
Hsu said that some people, particularly depressives or people who live alone, can be suicidal on special days such as Valentine's Day, Christmas or New Year holidays.
Noting that some 40 percent of suicidal people send out messages before their suicide attempts, Hsu called for the public to help prevent suicides during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: `SPIRIT OF TAIWAN' 228 CONCERT TO BE HELD

TEXT.P: A concert titled "Spirit of Taiwan" will take place Feb. 28 at the Chungshan Soccer Stadium in Taipei City, a concert organizer said at a press conference Thursday.

Lin Hsu-tzuo, a member of local band Chthonic, which will perform at the concert, said the concert is being organized by people from the music, art, film and academic circles to "express non-government, civic voices about solutions to social problems in Taiwan" and to mark the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident, in which thousands of Taiwanese were murdered by troops of the then-ruling authoritarian Kuomintang headed by the late President Chiang Kai-shek.

The concert aims to convey the idea and call for people's recognition of "transitional justice" that it is believed can bring Taiwan on the road of reconciliation to its history of authoritarian rule giving way to democracy.

Wang Dan, a leader of China's 1989 pro-democracy movement that later led to the tragic Tiananmen massacre, said at the conference that he admires Taiwan's democratic society but still sees that its civic society is not well developed yet.

Lin said that in addition to groups from Taiwan, bands from other countries have been invited to perform, including the U.K.'s Muse, Plastic People of the Universe from the Czech Republic and Akiakane from Japan. There will also be speeches and a film on human rights and democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS GOVERNMENT TO OPERATE DURING NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that government agencies will continue to work during the Chinese New Year holiday and he ordered agency heads to determine and designate in advance the skeleton operations that will continue during the upcoming holiday period.

Su made the remarks during a Cabinet meeting prior to the Feb. 18 Lunar Chinese New Year festival, while giving away red envelopes containing auspicious sayings to Cabinet staff members and wishing them a happy New Year.

He noted that he floated the concept of "holiday services" at the first meeting of the Cabinet following its reorganization last year, adding that as the government cannot simply cease functioning, all level of agencies must come up with contingency plans and designate personnel to deal with unexpected situations during the holiday.

Banks were told to ensure that their ATMs were restocked during the nine-day holiday, and Su also instructed police authorities to coordinate with contractors to decrease construction barriers and enclosures located on main traffic routes around the country, adding that traffic control should be continued during the holiday.

As for the problems of criminals selling meat from deceased and sick hogs, Su said that his administration will adopt stricter penalties for offenders and step up a crackdown on those who those who ignore health regulations and continue selling questionable meat.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER QUESTIONS KMT CHARTER REVISION PLAN

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) kingpin reminded the party Thursday that the people's feelings should be taken into account when the party mulls a plan to revise its charter so that the party can nominate criminals convicted in their first and second trials and that only when convicted in a third trial will such criminals be banned from being nominated by the party to run for elected office.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who has a keen interest in seeking the main opposition party's nomination for the 2008 presidential election, made the comments after it was widely reported that the KMT is considering amending its charter to allow for nomination of indicted former Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to run for the 2008 presidency.

It has been reported that the KMT will advance its party congress to early June to carry out the revision through due process by lowering the threshold to ban only "those convicted in a third trial" from being nominated by the party to run for elected office.
Ma was indicted Tuesday on corruption charges over his alleged mishandling of a special allowance fund earmarked for his discretionary use during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006.

Saying that the KMT must not ignore the people's negative response to its sudden charter shift, Wang claimed that the party would have no future and is doomed to fail should it make people feel it is "embarking on the road of moral degeneration."

"How could people continue supporting the KMT if it is unable to touch their hearts? " Wang asked, urging the party to "maintain a high level of moral standards" and "maintain the public's strong confidence in it."

Asked whether he would consider forming a Wang-Ma or Ma-Wang ticket to represent the KMT in the next presidential election, Wang said it is "too early" to talk about the issue but called for sincere unity among party members.
Wang said he has yet to make a final decision on whether he will run in the 2008 presidential election and made it clear that the decision will not be made anytime soon.

Meanwhile, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih denied the report that the KMT is softening its stance regarding indicted members wishing to run for public office, but he acknowledged that many of the KMT's rank-and-file members and Central Standing Committee members support a charter modification to help party candidates avoid what they called "political interference from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party."
KMT lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng, however, backed the charter revisions, claiming that it would be a change to help protect KMT candidates in the year-end legislative elections.

Wu, one of Ma's proteges who once served as a core aide to Ma when the former KMT chairman served as mayor of Taipei from 1998 to 2006, claimed that the proposal "is by no means aimed at bailing out Ma. It is a measure to protect KMT members from politically charged prosecution by the DPP."
Wu made the claim at the Legislative Yuan at a time when the KMT has come under fire for customizing its rules to guarantee Ma's right to participate in the party's presidential primaries.

In view of a foreseeable fierce competition in December's legislative polls, it is necessary to implement the charter modification to secure the KMT's survival, Wu contended, pointing out that "the revision still needs to be discussed by more than 1,000 party delegates in the June national congress."
"The party needs to hear the voices of its members first before making a final decision on the issue after it has gained an understanding of public opinion," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HISTORIANS BLAME CHIANG KAI-SHEK FOR 228 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The late President Chiang Kai-shek was the person most responsible for the bloody 228 Incident, the head of Academica Historica, the country's top state history institution, said Thursday upon release of a shortened version of a famous report on the 1947 tragedy.

To herald the approach of the 60th anniversary of the still controversial incident, the Ketagalan Institute published a booklet of around 60 pages to publicize the gist of "The 228 Incident: A Record on Responsibility, " a 600-page research report published by the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation a year earlier.

"Chiang Kai-shek ordered sending more troops to kill Taiwanese people; he was of course the prime culprit behind the historical trauma, " Academia Historica chief Chang Yen-hsien said at the publication press conference for the booklet.

He also said then-Taiwan Governor Chen Yi, Taiwan Provincial Garrison Command Chief of Staff Ko Yuan-fen and Kaohsiung Garrison Commander Peng Meng-chi were also responsible, as all three advocated violent suppression and asked the central government in Nanking to send more troops to Taiwan.

A number of "half-mainlanders" collaborated with the then-ruling Kuomintang (KMT) regime and helped in the purge of Taiwan's elite, he added. "Half- mainlanders" refers to people with Taiwan origins during Japanese colonization but who later went to China and built ties with the KMT.

Chen Yi-shen, a co-author of the 2005 report and a researcher with Academica Sinica's Institute of Modern History, rebutted a claim by Chiang Kai-shek's grandson, KMT lawmaker John Chiang, that the former strongman had tried to prevent bloodshed.

Chiang claims that his grandfather had on March 13, 1947 issued an order prohibiting troops from killing in retaliation. However, Chen said, Chiang gave the order only because ombudsman Yang Liang-kung informed him of the bloody situation, and the order was not issued until four days after island-wide massacre began.

Chen said there should be no "Chiang Kai-shek Temple" -- a reference to Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall -- in Taiwan, and added that while commemorating the 228 Incident, Taiwan should pursue the ultimate goal of changing its official name and drafting a new constitution.
Ketagalan Institute Chairman Lee Hung-hsi said Chiang Kai-shek's slaughter of Taiwan's elite deprived Taiwanese people of their identity.
"It's regrettable that younger generations in Taiwan only know this year as the 70th anniversary of the Nanking massacre but have no knowledge about the anniversary of the 228 incident," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK HITS NEW ALL-TIME HIGH IN TURNOVER

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan reported another record high of NT$1.12 trillion (US$33.9 billion) in total revenue last year, up 14 percent from the same level in 2005, park administration officials said Thursday.

The rising demand for information electronic products -- such as PCs, cell phones, digital cameras, and digital TVs -- benefited the semiconductor industry in 2006, which also contributed to the growth in the park's total revenue, the officials noted.

Four of the six major industries in the park saw increases while the other two -- the computer peripherals industry and the communications industry -- posted a small decline, according to the officials.

The total revenue of the park's integrated circuit (IC) industry went up 17 percent, the officials explained, adding that the optoelectronics industry was up 18 percent, precision machinery industry up 36 percent, and the bioindustry up 2 percent.

By the end of last year, the total number of companies and manufacturers in the park had reached a record high of 395, with 121,762 employees, which was a 10 percent rise from the previous year, the officials pointed out.

The total value of import and export trade in the park last year rose 20 percent to hit NT$982.3 billion, the officials said. The total value of exports was up 22 percent to reach NT$592.9 billion, while that of imports increased 18 percent to record NT$389.4 billion, they explained in detail.
In 2007, the park's revenue is expected to go up 10 percent to total NT$1.25 trillion, the officials forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT REGISTERS 1ST BUDGET BALANCE SINCE 1999

TEXT.P: Thanks to higher-than-expected tax revenues, the central government managed to make its ends meet last year for the first time since 1999, the country's budget chief said Thursday.

According to preliminary tallies, Hsu Chang-yao, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), said the government's 2006 tax revenues exceeded its original target by NT$125 billion.
"The government resultingly managed to make its ends meet last year," Hsu said, adding that it marked the first time since 1999 that the government has managed to balance its annual budget.

Preliminary tallies show that individual income tax revenues amounted to NT$334.3 billion last year, business income tax revenues totaled NT$311.8 billion and securities transaction tax revenues topped NT$89.9 billion due to a 30 percent annual increase in accumulated securities trading volume over the past year.
To sum up, Hsu said, the government's tax revenues surpassed its original target by more than NT$120 billion last year compared to the 2005 level.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Feb. 16

Asked whether he would consider forming a Wang-Ma or Ma-Wang ticket to represent the KMT in the next presidential election, Wang said it is "too early" to talk about the issue but called for sincere unity among party members.
Wang said he has yet to make a final decision on whether he will run in the 2008 presidential election and made it clear that the decision will not be made anytime soon.

Meanwhile, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih denied the report that the KMT is softening its stance regarding indicted members wishing to run for public office, but he acknowledged that many of the KMT's rank-and-file members and Central Standing Committee members support a charter modification to help party candidates avoid what they called "political interference from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party."
KMT lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng, however, backed the charter revisions, claiming that it would be a change to help protect KMT candidates in the year-end legislative elections.

Wu, one of Ma's proteges who once served as a core aide to Ma when the former KMT chairman served as mayor of Taipei from 1998 to 2006, claimed that the proposal "is by no means aimed at bailing out Ma. It is a measure to protect KMT members from politically charged prosecution by the DPP."
Wu made the claim at the Legislative Yuan at a time when the KMT has come under fire for customizing its rules to guarantee Ma's right to participate in the party's presidential primaries.

In view of a foreseeable fierce competition in December's legislative polls, it is necessary to implement the charter modification to secure the KMT's survival, Wu contended, pointing out that "the revision still needs to be discussed by more than 1,000 party delegates in the June national congress."
"The party needs to hear the voices of its members first before making a final decision on the issue after it has gained an understanding of public opinion," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HISTORIANS BLAME CHIANG KAI-SHEK FOR 228 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The late President Chiang Kai-shek was the person most responsible for the bloody 228 Incident, the head of Academica Historica, the country's top state history institution, said Thursday upon release of a shortened version of a famous report on the 1947 tragedy.

To herald the approach of the 60th anniversary of the still controversial incident, the Ketagalan Institute published a booklet of around 60 pages to publicize the gist of "The 228 Incident: A Record on Responsibility, " a 600-page research report published by the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation a year earlier.

"Chiang Kai-shek ordered sending more troops to kill Taiwanese people; he was of course the prime culprit behind the historical trauma, " Academia Historica chief Chang Yen-hsien said at the publication press conference for the booklet.

He also said then-Taiwan Governor Chen Yi, Taiwan Provincial Garrison Command Chief of Staff Ko Yuan-fen and Kaohsiung Garrison Commander Peng Meng-chi were also responsible, as all three advocated violent suppression and asked the central government in Nanking to send more troops to Taiwan.

A number of "half-mainlanders" collaborated with the then-ruling Kuomintang (KMT) regime and helped in the purge of Taiwan's elite, he added. "Half- mainlanders" refers to people with Taiwan origins during Japanese colonization but who later went to China and built ties with the KMT.

Chen Yi-shen, a co-author of the 2005 report and a researcher with Academica Sinica's Institute of Modern History, rebutted a claim by Chiang Kai-shek's grandson, KMT lawmaker John Chiang, that the former strongman had tried to prevent bloodshed.

Chiang claims that his grandfather had on March 13, 1947 issued an order prohibiting troops from killing in retaliation. However, Chen said, Chiang gave the order only because ombudsman Yang Liang-kung informed him of the bloody situation, and the order was not issued until four days after island-wide massacre began.

Chen said there should be no "Chiang Kai-shek Temple" -- a reference to Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall -- in Taiwan, and added that while commemorating the 228 Incident, Taiwan should pursue the ultimate goal of changing its official name and drafting a new constitution.
Ketagalan Institute Chairman Lee Hung-hsi said Chiang Kai-shek's slaughter of Taiwan's elite deprived Taiwanese people of their identity.
"It's regrettable that younger generations in Taiwan only know this year as the 70th anniversary of the Nanking massacre but have no knowledge about the anniversary of the 228 incident," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK HITS NEW ALL-TIME HIGH IN TURNOVER

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan reported another record high of NT$1.12 trillion (US$33.9 billion) in total revenue last year, up 14 percent from the same level in 2005, park administration officials said Thursday.

The rising demand for information electronic products -- such as PCs, cell phones, digital cameras, and digital TVs -- benefited the semiconductor industry in 2006, which also contributed to the growth in the park's total revenue, the officials noted.

Four of the six major industries in the park saw increases while the other two -- the computer peripherals industry and the communications industry -- posted a small decline, according to the officials.

The total revenue of the park's integrated circuit (IC) industry went up 17 percent, the officials explained, adding that the optoelectronics industry was up 18 percent, precision machinery industry up 36 percent, and the bioindustry up 2 percent.

By the end of last year, the total number of companies and manufacturers in the park had reached a record high of 395, with 121,762 employees, which was a 10 percent rise from the previous year, the officials pointed out.

The total value of import and export trade in the park last year rose 20 percent to hit NT$982.3 billion, the officials said. The total value of exports was up 22 percent to reach NT$592.9 billion, while that of imports increased 18 percent to record NT$389.4 billion, they explained in detail.
In 2007, the park's revenue is expected to go up 10 percent to total NT$1.25 trillion, the officials forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT REGISTERS 1ST BUDGET BALANCE SINCE 1999

TEXT.P: Thanks to higher-than-expected tax revenues, the central government managed to make its ends meet last year for the first time since 1999, the country's budget chief said Thursday.

According to preliminary tallies, Hsu Chang-yao, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), said the government's 2006 tax revenues exceeded its original target by NT$125 billion.
"The government resultingly managed to make its ends meet last year," Hsu said, adding that it marked the first time since 1999 that the government has managed to balance its annual budget.

Preliminary tallies show that individual income tax revenues amounted to NT$334.3 billion last year, business income tax revenues totaled NT$311.8 billion and securities transaction tax revenues topped NT$89.9 billion due to a 30 percent annual increase in accumulated securities trading volume over the past year.
To sum up, Hsu said, the government's tax revenues surpassed its original target by more than NT$120 billion last year compared to the 2005 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 16, or the 29th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, Polish astronomer, is born. He advanced the theory that the earth and other planets revolve around the sun, discrediting the Ptolemaic model of the universe.
1659: A new way of paying money without using either coinage or a letter of credit is first used in England when Mr. Nicholas Vanacker signs a "cheque" to a creditor.
1884: Robert J. Flaherty, U.S. explorer and filmmaker, is born. His works, including "Nanook of the North," were the world's first major documentaries.
1906: British labor representatives meet in London to establish the Labour Party.
1918: Lithuania, which is located in Northern Europe, proclaims its independence from Russia.
1931: The Control Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1937: The synthetic material nylon, which was developed by the U.S. chemist Wallace Carothers, is patented.
1942: Kim Jong Il, North Korean leader, is born.
1944: Allied aircraft bomb a Japanese naval base at Truk in the Caroline Islands, destroying some 200 planes.
1945: The United States starts massive air raids on Tokyo as U.S. forces capture Bataan in the Philippines during World War II.
1959: Fidel Castro becomes the leader of Cuba at the age of 32.
1960: The USS Triton begins an underwater voyage around the world, becoming the first nuclear submarine to undertake such a journey.
1968: A China Air Transportation plane flying from Hong Kong to Taipei crashes in Linkuo, killing 21 and injuring 43.
1970: The Directorate General of Posts starts nighttime business operations.
1973: Robert E. Page, vice president of United Press International, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The Republic of China revalues the New Taiwan dollar upward by 5 percent against the U.S. dollar. The new exchange rate is NT$38 to US$1.
1976: A new radar control system is inaugurated at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.
1976: Yu Hao-chang, former ROC Army commander in chief, returns to Taipei after more than a year of medical treatment in the United States.
1983: The Dutch airline Martinair inaugurates flight services to Taiwan, marking the first air link between the Netherlands and the Republic of China.
1986: A China Airlines Boeing 737 plane crashes near Makung, in Taiwan's Penghu Islands, killing all 13 aboard.
1992: OPEC member countries agree to cut oil output by 1 million barrels a day.
1994: An earthquake claims 134 lives and injures at least 550 in southern Sumatra in Indonesia.
1994: The Helenic Republic (Greece) declares an embargo on the Macedonian Republic in a conflict over the use of the name Macedonia. The two countries later reached an agreement on the use of the formal name "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" for the latter's entry into the United Nations.
1998: A China Airlines Airbus A-300 plane returning from Bali crashes near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing all 116 aboard and six people on the ground.
2000: Two destroyers of the Republic of China, the Loyang and Suiyang, are decommissioned after more than two decades of active service.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang formally files a lawsuit against independent presidential candidate and former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, accusing him of embezzling party funds.
2004: Taiwan's Government Information Office and National Geographic Channel International announce a cooperative project on documentary production aimed at introducing Taiwan's natural beauty and cultural legacy to the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The common people should be educated in what they ought to do; not to ask why they should do it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
RATIO OF ADULT CHILDREN LIVING WITH PARENTS DECLINING

TEXT.P: The percentages of adult children living with their parents on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have both been in steady decline, but they remain higher than that in the United States, an economist said Friday.

Cyrus C. Y. Chu, an academic at Academia Sinica, said in a speech delivered at National Taiwan University that more than 60 percent of adult children lived together with their parents in China in the 1990s, compared with 50 percent in Taiwan and 40 percent in the United States.
According to his study, Chu said the average number of people in a family has also dropped on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, from slightly more than four two decades ago to about three at present.

In his view, Chu said, many of those who choose to live together with their parents are not necessarily doing so because of filial piety, but rather because they need their parents' help in caring for their young children, particularly those aged under 3.

"Studies show that adult children tend to become less willing to live with their parents when their income increases, " Chu said, adding that daughters-in-law tend not to be inclined to live with their parents-in-law when they earn more.
According to Chu, sons-in-law also tend to be less willing to live with their parents-in-law if they have a high income.

In Taiwan, Chu said, the parental preference for sons over daughters has been declining, with the percentage of those wanting boys falling from 68 percent to 46 percent in a series of his studies . A similar trend is also seen in China, Chu added without elaborating.

Chu further said the average age of women when they give birth for the first time is also steadily increasing on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, with the number of women giving birth to their first child after 30 years of age rising continuously.
In one of Chu's studies, 17 percent of all children born in China were born to mothers aged over 30, with the figure in Taiwan being 48 percent.

Chu's studies also found that American parents usually do not pass all of their assets or property on to their children before their death because, if they do so, their children may no longer visit them regularly. In America, he said, the richer the parents, the more frequent their children come back to see them.

In Taiwan, Chu said, the frequency of children visiting their parents tends to remain high or even become higher after their parents pass their assets to their children. The phenomenon is probably related to pressure from siblings and society, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRAVELERS TO CHINA WARNED OF RABIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan citizens who are planning to visit China during the Chinese New Year holidays were warned Friday about the risk of acquiring rabies -- an infectious disease that killed 182 people in China in January.

The Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health called for potential visitors to China to avoid contact with dogs or other animals in order to avoid getting rabies, a disease caused by a virus found in the saliva of infected animals and transmitted to humans by bites or possibly by contamination of an open cut.

According to a report released recently by the Chinese Ministry of Health, 217 people were bitten by dogs or other animals that were infected by the rabies virus across China in January. Of the total, 182, or over 80 percent, died.
Rabies was the top specific infectious disease that killed the greatest number of people for eight consecutive months in China, followed by tuberculosis, which killed 94 people in January.

CDC Deputy Director Shih Wen-yi said that China has been a rabies-endemic country and that there was a case several years ago where a Chinese citizen, who had been bitten by a stray dog before leaving for Taiwan for a short visit, died of rabies in Taiwan, which is not a rabies-endemic country.
Shih said that treatment of an infected person is critical and that rabies can cause a painful death if untreated.

Shih said that in addition to avoiding contact with dogs and other animals while visiting China, Taiwan visitors can also receive preexposure rabies vaccination before heading to China or receive rabies vaccination immediately if they are bitten by an animal.

Rabies is an acute, fatal encephalomyelitis caused by neurotropic viruses in the family Rhabdoviridae, genus Lyssavirus. The disease progresses from a nonspecific prodromal phase to paresis or paralysis; muscle spasms can be stimulated by the sight, sound, or perception of water (hydrophobia) ; delirium and convulsions can develop, followed by coma and death.

Most animals can be infected by the virus and can transmit the disease to humans. Infected bats, raccoons, foxes, skunks, dogs or cats provide the greatest risk to humans. Rabies may also spread through exposure to infected domestic farm animals, groundhogs, weasels and other wild carnivores. Squirrels, rodents and rabbits are seldom infected.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME-CHANGE DRIVE WILL NOT INCLUDE CHANGING NATIONAL TITLE: LAWMAKER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 15 (CNA) 02/16/07 13:45:15 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ongoing name rectification campaign will not include changing the country's official title or flag and thus will not violate President Chen Shui- bian's "four noes" commitments, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said here Thursday.
Hsiao Bi-khim, who is on a visit in Washington D.C., told Taiwan reporters that she made the assurance to the U.S. side during her meeting with U.S. officials and members of major think tanks.

According to Hsiao, the U.S. officials were surprised at Taiwan's move and expressed concern about whether the campaign will be further expanded to include changing Taiwan's national title and affect President Chen's commitments to the United States.

Hsiao said she has explained to the U.S. officials that Taiwan's efforts to change the names of state-owned enterprises containing references to China are aimed at avoiding confusion and that the DPP has no intention of pushing the campaign further.

Also, Hsiao said the United States is concerned about whether the candidates to be fielded by various political parties in Taiwan for the 2008 presidential election will take into account the position of the United States while putting forth their policies, especially whether the DPP's candidate will follow Chen's commitments to the United States.

In his 2000 and 2004 inauguration addresses, Chen pledged that if China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, not change the official name of the country, not include the "state-to-state" concept on cross-strait relations in the Constitution, and not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.

On the corruption charges against former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying- jeou, Hsiao said the U.S. side is paying much attention to Ma's ability to manage the crisis triggered by his indictment and how he is going to cope with other challenges.

Hsiao said that although the decline in Ma's popularity following his indictment has boosted the DPP's confidence concerning the next presidential election, the DPP still needs to work harder to win the people's support.

The anti-corruption center of the Taiwan High Court Prosecutor's Office indicted Ma Tuesday on corruption charges after determining that he had embezzled NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use during his two terms as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

While resigning from the KMT chairmanship immediately after the indictment, Ma claimed that he is innocent and announced his decision to run for the presidency in 2008 to prove his integrity "via voter support" in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF STUDENTS RECEIVING VISAS TO STUDY ABROAD HITS 10-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan students receiving visas to study abroad in 2006 totaled 37,171, marking a record high over the past decade, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Friday.
The 2006 figure also represented an increase of more than 3,000, or 9.1 percent, over that of the previous year, the ministry said.

The latest statistics show that Taiwan students still prefer English-speaking countries and that among the top three foreign countries in terms of number of visas issued to Taiwan students in 2006, the United States was first, issuing visas to 16,451 Taiwan students, followed by Britain, which issued 9,600 visas to Taiwan students, and Australia, which issued 2,862 visas.
Japan issued student visas to 2,108 Taiwan students in 2006, ranking it fourth. The figure marked an increase of 360 over the previous year.

The top eight countries in terms of the number of visas issued to Taiwan students -- namely the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Australia, New Zealand and Japan -- issued more visas to Taiwan students in 2006 than they did in the previous year, except for Canada.

Chang Chin-sheng, director of the ministry's Bureau of International Culture & Education Relations, attributed the increase in the number of Taiwan students studying abroad to the ministry's encouragement by providing students with scholarships and pushing domestic colleges and universities to send top students to study abroad.
In addition, the ministry kicked off a study abroad loan program in 2004. It further eased the conditions for applying for overseas study loans in 2006, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITIES TO HOLD HOLIDAY ACTIVITIES FOR FOREIGN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Several Taiwan universities have planned a series of Lunar New Year activities for foreign students to give them the opportunity to enjoy a traditional Taiwan holiday celebration experience first-hand, according to the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) Bureau of International Cultural & Educational Relations.
According to MOE tallies, there are currently more than 13,000 foreign students pursuing degrees or enrolled in Chinese-language learning programs at universities around Taiwan.

To give these foreign students a taste of local culture during the festive season, more than ten universities have arranged various holiday activities, including couplet writing, lantern design, and reunion dinner events, officials at the bureau said.

Among the universities arranging holiday activities for foreign students are National Chi Nan University in Puli, Nantou County, and National Taiwan Ocean University in Keelung City, which will each hold a special dinner party on the night before Chinese New Year's Eve. Meanwhile, Kai Nan University in Luchu, Taoyuan County has arranged for foreign students at the school to visit the homes of Taiwan students to enjoy a traditional reunion dinner on Lunar New Year's Eve with a real Taiwanese family.

Several universities have also planned activities for the Lantern Festival, which falls on the 15th day of the first month on the lunar calendar and marks the end of the series of Chinese New Year celebrations.
