DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER NEVER HAD PLANS TO RESIGN TO PREPARE FOR 2008 RACE: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang has not had any plans to resign from his post to prepare for a bid for the presidency in 2008, Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said in a statement Friday.

Cheng made the remarks in response to an Apple Daily report Friday that said Su had planned to resign prior to the Chinese New Year and to announce his presidential bid but then changed his mind after President Chen Shui-bian asked him to enter the race without quitting his post until after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) primary for the presidential election.
Cheng said that the daily's report was "based merely on speculation" and that the newspaper failed to verify its report before printing it.

Meanwhile, Ker Chien-ming, a DPP legislative caucus whip, confirmed that President Chen will mediate among the DPP's presidential aspirants concerning the timetable for the party's presidential primary.

As to whether Su should resign or not to join the DPP primary, Ker said that these are matters for the president and the premier to decide upon and that the DPP legislative caucus will fully respect whatever decision they make.

DPP Legislator Lin Chung-mo, however, noted that once a DPP official is chosen as the party's candidate for the presidential election, he or she should resign from their post immediately to focus on the race.

Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su and former premiers Frank Hsieh and Yu Shyi-kun are widely seen as "the four DPP heavyweights" who are likely to compete to represent the party in the election. However, none of them have publicly announced their decision to join the race.

Registration for the DPP primary will be open March 5-9, and a vote by party members is scheduled for May 6, while opinion polls on the support ratings of the contenders will be conducted May 7-28. The outcome of the primary is slated to be announced May 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER HSIEH TO REGISTER FOR DPP'S PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh announced Friday his decision to vie for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) nomination for the 2008 presidential election.

Hsieh said he will make use of the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday to contemplate national issues such as social welfare and taxation reform, after which he will register for the party's primary for the election.
According to Hsieh, the position means a great responsibility because the president has the obligation to stabilize politics.
Hsieh said that he has heard the people's voices calling for his participation in the race and that he will reciprocate their expectations seriously.
Hsieh made the remarks in response to reporters' questions regarding his intention to run for the presidency during a trip to Kaohsiung City.
Hsieh, who is a former mayor of the southern port city, was greeted by crowds of local residents urging him to run for president.
He is the first DPP politician to publicly announce his intention of entering the race for the party's nomination for the 2008 presidential election.
According to a timetable for the presidential primary finalized by the DPP's Central Standing Committee Wednesday, registration for the primary will be open from March 5-9.

A vote by party members is scheduled for May 6, while opinion polls on the support ratings of the contenders will be conducted from May 7-28. The outcome of the primary is slated to be announced May 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS ON CHINESE PROFESSIONALS' VISITS TO BE EASED

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has passed a proposal to amend regulations governing approval for professionals from China to engage in professional activities in Taiwan, relaxing some restrictions on visits by professionals in the fields of industry, technology, sport, media and religion.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun explained Thursday that the amendment is part of the Executive Yuan's drive to attract high-tech and sports talent from China to upgrade the standard of Taiwan's science and technology and to strengthen its training programs for national athletes to compete in international sporting events such as the Olympics.
The amendment will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for ratification before being sent to the Ministry of the Interior, which will publicize and implement the revision.

According to the MAC, the amendment allows Chinese professionals invited to assist in the training of athletes of Taiwan's national teams to stay on the island for up to one year at a time, instead of the current six months. If the professionals are invited to help train athletes for the Olympics, they can extend their stay in Taiwan up to six years.
Moreover, Chinese sports or high-tech professionals who have to stay in Taiwan for at least four months for work are permitted to bring their spouse and children aged under 18 with them.

Liu pointed out that before the revision, Chinese media professionals who wanted to conduct interviews, cover news or produce television programs in Taiwan had to apply for official permission at least two months in advance. Now, the condition has been lifted for emergency cases.

In addition, the amendment also allows a Chinese actor or actress to bring along five assistants while making a film in Taiwan, and religious professionals who come to the island to study at certified religious institutions can get a one- year resident permit.
Liu added that the Chinese professionals need not attach their return tickets on their visa applications if they apply for a stay of at least six months.
Besides the revision, the MAC has also worked out many measures to improve the government's management of the movements of Chinese professionals in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST KAOHSIUNG-SHANGHAI LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHT TAKES OFF

TEXT.P: An aircraft of the Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) took off around noon Friday from Kaohsiung International Airport for Shanghai, marking the first Lunar New Year charter flight between Taiwan's southern port city and China's largest city in 2007.
The Airbus A-300, carrying 284 passengers, departed from the Kaohsiung airport at 12: 15 p.m. for Shanghai's Pudong airport. It is scheduled to land at around 2:45 p.m. the same day.

The Airbus A-300 is expected to take 311 passengers -- mostly Taiwan businesspeople -- back to Kaohsiung for the New Year reunion, marking a passenger load factor of 90 percent. This year's Chinese New Year's Day falls on Feb. 18.
The 2007 special direct cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flight services, which kicked off Feb. 13, will last through the end
of the holidays in early March.

Six carriers from each side of the Taiwan Strait will provide passengers with 192 special charter flights between Taiwan and China during the Chinese New Year holidays, up by 48 flights from the previous year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR CHARGED WITH DEFAMATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu was indicted on defamation charges Friday for insulting remarks she made about ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun.

According to the indictment issued by the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office, Hung called Yu "the most loyal dog" of President Chen Shui-bian and accused Yu of being "worse than a dog" while commenting on Yu's move to sue the China Times during a TV talk show Sept. 25, 2006.
Cheng Tsun-chi, another guest on the show who made similar remarks about Yu, was indicted Jan. 30.
Responding to her indictment Friday, Hung said she respects the opinions of the prosecutors.
Hung accused the DPP of repeatedly resorting to lawsuits to "attack and criminalize" KMT politicians, which she said reflects the ruling party's pettiness.

DOC.HEADLINE: GARDEN OF HOPE LAUNCHES CAMPAIGN TO HELP SEXUALLY-ABUSED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Estimating that an average of 52 children in Taiwan are sexually abused every day, the Garden of Hope Foundation has decided to launch a "Flying Dandelion" campaign to raise funds to help the victims of such abuse and to work to eradicate the problem.

The foundation said that it hopes to raise NT$20 million (US$607,902.7) to be used toward setting up victim treatment services at its centers around Taiwan, educating the public about the problem of sexual abuse of children, and working to prevent such crimes.

Noting that there were more than 4,900 reported sex crimes around Taiwan in 2005, foundation officials said the actual number of cases could be seven to 10 times that figure. They added that three out of every five sex crime victims were children.

Based on the estimate that the actual number of cases was seven times the reported figure, that would mean that a child was sexually abused every 27 minutes on average in Taiwan last year, according to the officials.

Chi Hui-jung, chief executive officer of the foundation, said that if child victims of sexual abuse do not receive therapy early on, they could be scarred for life. "It's like a broken arm, which if not treated immediately, will not heal properly," he added.
"If a child victim of sexual abuse can receive therapy to deal with what they have experienced, they then have a much better chance of recovering and leading a healthy, normal life," he continued.

He further said that although the Garden of Hope Foundation has centers in the north, south, east and west of the island, only the foundation's center in Taipei has the resources to provide the treatment that child victims of sexual abuse need to recover.

"Therefore, we hope to raise enough funds through our 'Flying Dandelion' campaign to expand our treatment services to our centers in other parts of Taiwan where they are urgently needed, " he continued.

Currently, according to Chi, Taiwan's child sex crime prevention and treatment services lag far behind those of other developed countries. "In most developed countries, cases of sexual abuse of children are exposed within one year on average, while in Taiwan, the average is over three or four years," he said, adding that "the costs of helping these victims recover are extremely high."
Through its campaign, the foundation also aims to enter schools and local society to educate people on the problem of sexual abuse of children and how to prevent it, Chi said.
He also urged everyone to report any cases of suspected sexual abuse of children to authorities, noting that "one phone call can change a child's entire life."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO FIELD STRONG TICKET IN 2008 PRESIDENTIAL RACE: ACTING CHAIR

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will field only the strongest ticket with the greatest chance of winning the 2008 presidential election, acting KMT Chairman Wu Po-hsiung said Friday.

Wu made the announcement after a closed-door meeting with KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, former KMT Chairman Ma Ying- jeou aimed at helping arrive at a consensus among all aspirants contending for the party's candidacy in the 2008 race.
Lien, who called the meeting, said that the four exchanged views in a "very friendly" atmosphere, although all of them were serious about the subjects discussed.

After the meeting, Wu announced a six-point consensus that the four KMT bigwigs reached: that the KMT is resolute in defending the country and the people's interests; that esprit de corps tops all issues concerning the 2008 race; that a new KMT chairman will be elected soon after the Lunar New Year; that the KMT will be equally single-minded and relentless in efforts toward the year-end legislative election as it is toward the 2008 presidential election; that the KMT hierarchy will remain completely neutral; and that Wang and Ma will give deep thought during the Lunar New Year holiday concerning the 2008 presidential race and that mediation as well as coordination will begin soon after the holidays end.
An early agreement on the KMT's presidential ticket grew urgent after Ma announced his presidential bid and resigned as KMT chairman following his indictment on corruption charges Feb. 13.
Lien has said that Ma's hasty announcement of his presidential bid may "narrow" the maneuvering room available in attempting to mediate between Ma and Wang, who is another KMT kingpin.

DOC.HEADLINE: `HUMAN HAIR LIFTING ELEPHANT' ACTIVITY HELD DESPITE PROTEST

TEXT.P: An activity of using human hair to lift an "elephant" off the ground was held in an amusement park in Tainan County, southern Taiwan Friday, although rocks and timber took the place of a real elephant due to protests from animal rights activists.
The protest caused embarrassment at one point for the National Science and Technology Museum and Wan-Pi World, which sponsored the heavily advertised activity.

The museum spent NT$250,000 (US$7,570) to buy 1.6 million human hairs and asked a vocational school in Kaohsiung to braid into a rope capable of lifting an elephant and platform with a total weight of around eight tons.
But the activity caused concern among animal right groups, which sent officials to appeal against using an elephant.

Lin Tai-ching, an ecology activist, pointed out that if the activity is aimed merely at proving that human hair is strong enough to lift heavy objects -- which in any case is already well-known and hardly a scientific breakthrough -- there is no need to use a living elephant.

Elephants are sensitive animals and even caging them in zoos is already a violation of nature, let alone lifting one chained to a platform, Lin said while questioning who would be held responsible if anything goes wrong.
Wan-Pi World Chairman Hsu Chung-fa said the Asian elephant they had planned to use has been held captive in the zoo for more than 10 years and is mild- tempered.

Moreover, the park had done everything possible to ensure the animal's safety and the platform carrying the elephant would only be lifted 10 cm off the ground, which he said would also be an opportunity to get an exact weight the elephant.

But because of the vehement protests from conservationists, the organizers decided to use rocks and timber of equal weight to carry out the "experiment" and apply for listing in the Guinness Book of World Records.
Wang Chun-fa, director of the museum, claimed that the experiment was "very creative."

DOC.HEADLINE: PALACE MUSEUM TO SHORTEN OPENING HOURS ON NEW YEAR'S EVE

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum will close at 4 p.m. Saturday, Chinese New Year's eve, when most people go home to have a family reunion dinner, a museum spokesman said Friday.
The museum will remain open as usual during the Feb. 18-25 Chinese New Year holiday, the spokesman said, adding that museum food courts and gift shops will also stay open.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURNOVER OF HON HAI COULD BREAK NT$2 TRILLION THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Turnover of the Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. is expected to break NT$2 trillion (US$60.6 billion) in 2007, which would be one year ahead of schedule, Hon Hai Chairman Terry Guo said Friday.
Guo, believed to be the richest man in Taiwan, made the announcement at a year- end party for the company employees.
He said that this year, Hon Hai will continue its growth and noted that he predicted three years ago at a shareholders' meeting that Hon Hai's revenue would break NT$1 trillion in 2008.
He adjusted the goal last year to break NT$2 trillion in 2008, but said the goal can now be achieved this year.
Guo said he would follow his original plan to retire to a back-seat job and expressed hope that employees aged between 35 and 45 will prepare to take up some major posts.

On being elected as the enterprise that took best care of its employees last year, Guo also mentioned several points adopted to allow the employees to enjoy their workplace -- safety, health, stability and development.

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Tehran's Role in Iraq Unclear, U.S. Now Says.
U.S. officials from President Bush to a top general in Baghdad said Wednesday that there was no solid evidence that high-ranking officials in Iran had ordered deadly weapons to be sent to Iraq for use against American troops , backing away from claims made by military and intelligence officials in Baghdad this week. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Japan's GDP grows at annualized 4.8%
Japan's economy expanded at an annualized 4.8 percent in real terms during the October-December period of last year, beating economists' average forecast of 3.8 percent, a government preliminary report showed Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.085 to close at NT$32.993.
A total of US$897 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.908 and fluctuated between NT$32.821 and NT$33.000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL URGES U.S. TO BE CREATIVE IN DEALING WITH FTA ISSUE

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang suggested Friday that the U.S. government be more creative in dealing with the issue of Taiwan's proposed free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States.

Shih made the remarks in response to media inquiries about reports that Shih asked Washington to develop U.S.-Taiwan FTA ties based on the framework of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) , which the U.S. Congress passed in 1979 to govern U.S.-Taiwan interactions after the severance of diplomatic relations between the two countries.
The TRA authorizes quasi-diplomatic ties with the government in Taiwan by giving authority to the American Institute in Taiwan to serve as the de facto embassy.

Describing the act as a "very special legal arrangement, " Shih said that since Washington could create a set of special measures regarding U.S.-Taiwan exchanges in the absence of diplomatic ties, it is possible for it to come up with creative ideas and measures on the FTA issue.

Commenting on the existence of the U.S.-Taiwan Trade and Investment Framework Agreement, sealed in 1994 to resolve bilateral trade issues and enhance economic cooperation, Shih said the agreement cannot replace a FTA because the latter concerns rules of taxation, which have to be regulated by the law.
Taiwan still wants an FTA with the United States because it would be a mutually beneficial arrangement, the official claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAKE RED WINE RING CAUGHT SELLING 240,000 BOTTLES

TEXT.P: The Tainan District Prosecutor's Office recently cracked a criminal ring that produced and sold some 240,000 bottles of fake red wine over the past two years, the prosecution said Friday, adding that the wine was mostly sold to catering services.
Two suspects have been detained, the prosecutors said.

The prosecutors and investigators searched several sites related to a food company and a winery in Kaohsiung and Tainan counties and seized counterfeit sorghum liquor and the fake red wine. Continuing investigations over the next two days uncovered the ring's operations, the prosecutors said.

The winery used grape juice, red wine extract and flavoring to produce the fake wine, which it sold to another company for NT$70 to NT$80 per bottle. The second company sold it for NT$120 to NT$150 per bottle, according to the prosecutors, who added that most of the estimated 240,000 bottles had been sold to catering services and probably had already been consumed.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGULAR EXERCISE LOWERS SENIORS' RISK OF DEATH: STUDY

TEXT.P: The risk of death among senior citizens who exercise regularly is 35 percent lower than those who do not, according to the results of a study released Friday by the National Health Research Institute (NHRI).
The study was based on data collected via tracking the exercise habits and health conditions of 2,113 people aged 65 or above over a two-year period.

The study found that the more the seniors exercise, the better the effect of lowering their risk of death, with the risk dropping significantly if they exhaust more than 1,000 kcal of energy per week through exercise.
To exhaust 1,000 kcal of energy per week, a person needs to walk at least 40 minutes per day, researchers said.
The study shows that walking is the most popular exercise among senior citizens in Taiwan, along with tai chi, wai tan kung and folk dance.
However, the study found that of all senior citizens in Taiwan, only 60 percent of men and 54 percent of women exercise regularly.
Of those who exercise regularly, only 50 percent exercise enough to exhaust 1,000 kcal of energy per week, according to the study.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRAISES PHYSICALLY CHALLENGED DANCERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his admiration toward members of an unusual local dance troupe Friday, saying he was deeply touched by the beauty of their dance demonstration.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with the Bird and Water dance troupe made up of physically challenged dancers.
Troupe director Yen Tsuei-chen told the president she was driven to teach the physically challenged how to dance by her desire to help the impaired live with confidence and hope.
Chen said he has been impressed by their frequent performances in schools, prisons and charity activities, and praised the dancers for their courage and determination.

He described the dancers as beautiful butterflies who become brighter and more willing to help others through dance, like the metamorphosis of a pupa transforming into a butterfly, he said, adding he is happy to know that the troupe has decided to attend the ninth Asian dance competition to be held in Japan later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG A blue tarpaulin hung across the front of the ground-floor council maisonette in Clapham, South London, where 15-year-old Billy Cox was killed on Valentines Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND INVESTMENT DOWN IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Approved overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan in January totaled US$577 million, down 87.3 percent from the same month of last year, the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.

Commission officials attributed the decrease mainly to the high comparison base caused by Philips acquiring Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. shares at US$3.76 billion in January last year. If this factor is excluded, inbound investment in Taiwan in January for 2007 would show an increase of 141.54 percent from the same month of last year.
Meanwhile, the commission approved 28 outbound investment projects in January worth a total of US$193.8 billion, up 246 percent from the year-earlier level.
On investment in China, the commission approved 105 investment projects worth US$809.81 million, up 46.95 percent from the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YEAR GATHERING OF TAISHANG SLATED FOR FEB. 26

TEXT.P: A Chinese New Year gathering for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, known locally as taishang, will be held Feb. 26 in Taipei City, a spokesman for the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Friday.

According to the spokesman, the SEF, a quasi-official organization set up to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official cross-strait contacts, organizes the annual gathering to express its concern and attention to taishang, and to use it as a chance to exchange views among taishang, local businessmen and government representatives.

Nearly 400 people, including government officials, senior executives of taishang associations in China, representatives of local business groups and industry leaders, will participate in this year's meeting, which will be hosted by the SEF, the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Chinese National Federation of Industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCTU EXCHANGE STUDENTS TALK ABOUT EXPERIENCES ABROAD

TEXT.P: Exchange students from National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) who went to America and Belgium returned home before the Chinese New Year to talk about their experiences of studying abroad, a spokesman for the university said Friday.

The students are in NCTU's Electronics Engineering and Computer Science undergraduate honors program and went to the University of Illinois at Urbana- Champaign (UTUC) and Carnegie Mellon University(CMU) in America, and Katholieke Universiteit Leuven in Belgium.

NCTU's top university project chief executive, Chuan Shau-hsun, said sending students abroad and the policy of undecided majors are in response to the new trends of globalization and inter-disciplinary study.

Chang Yung-hsu, a student who went to UTUC, said she realized that Taiwan students might have narrower visions compared to students in America. Chang praised the undecided major policy she experienced abroad and in particular the practice of letting students choose majors after they have better understanding about themselves in their junior and senior years.

Lu Shi-jung, a student who went to CMU, said his experience of studying abroad allowed him to practice his English, try new things, and inspire him with new ideas. He encouraged college students to continue trying new things and new environments, instead of being trapped by fixed thoughts.
Lu also said that he sensed fierce competition when he was at CMU, adding that Taiwan students should be more courageous in exploring their potential and limits.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE TAKES MEASURES OVER STUDENTS' INTERNET SECURITY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) is "protecting students' Internet security" through promotion and education on information ethics and online self- protection, a spokesman for the MOE claimed Friday.

A survey conducted by the Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC) shows that Internet usage rate among Taiwan families was 72 percent, and that of individual users is 68 percent as of June 2006, with 95 percent of users aged from 12-25. The spokesman claimed that Internet use by young people will cause more social problems of Internet pornography or slander.

To prevent such social problems, the MOE initiated the Taiwan Academic Network improper information filtering system for nearly 3,500 schools four years ago to protect students from bad Web sites, and also provides students' parents with free downloading of IEblocker software -- an end-user filtering system.

Additionally, the MOE subsidized the Taiwan chapter of the global End Child Prostitution, Child Pornography and Trafficking in Children to build the www.smartkid.org.tw Web site to teach students about Internet etiquette and self-protection. The ministry also built the www.eteacher.edu.tw Web site offering teaching resources about Internet use.

Other measures in practice include the promotion of an Internet rating system and an excellent Web site recommendation, including information ethics in high school textbooks, providing related regulations and laws on the MOE's Web site and offering counseling to students affected by Internet use.

DOC.HEADLINE: HON HAI TO BUILD 5 INDUSTRIAL PARKS IN VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Guo announced Friday that in addition to the group's investment plans for China, Hon Hai is scheduled to build five industrial parks in Vietnam in the coming years.

Guo made the announcement at Hon Hai's year-end dinner party after outlining the group's US$ 119 million total investment in 11 subsidiary company projects in China, covering a wide geographical range including Liaoning, Shandung, Shanghai, Jiangsu, and Hubei provinces.

Guo said that Hon Hai's investment in Vietnam will be centered in the country's capital Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, with two industrial parks to be constructed this year to house production facilities for all of the group's product lines. Construction of the remaining three will get under way later.

DOC.HEADLINE: CASH IN CIRCULATION HITS NEW HIGH: CENTRAL BANK

TEXT.P: The amount of the country's currency issued has hit a record high NT$1,376.7 billion (US$41.75 billion) , the Central Bank said Friday.

The currency issued, meaning the cash in circulation, often peaks on the day before Lunar New Years' Eve, the Central Bank said, because companies are paying year-end bonus and people are buying more.
The figure has been growing every year since 2003, this year growing NT$57.7 billion, or 4.38%, over last year's amount, according to Central Bank records.
New Year holidays this year last as long as nine days and people need to keep more cash on hand, said Chang Hsing-wu, a Central Bank official who oversees the business of currency issuance.

Some analysts, however, said that the trend towards ever increasing amounts of currency issued is, in part, due to the ever closer cross-strait economic ties as many Taiwanese people bring Taiwan dollars when they travel to China, where the currency is also used in a number of cities.
The figure will go down after the New Year holidays, especially after the Lantern Festival, when people again start banking their money, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT `PROUD TO HAVE FEMALE VP'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has told a group of female German parliamentarians that Taiwan was proud to elect a female vice president in 2000.

Receiving the Bundestag representatives at the Presidential Office Thursday, Chen said that even though the United States -- a country that has been building its democracy for more than 200 years -- has yet to elect a woman as vice president, Taiwan not only has already elected its first female vice president but has also appointed two women as vice premier.
Chen said he attaches great importance to women's human rights during a meeting with the German delegation.

He added that German women take an active role in the political arena and that from Angela Merkel, who was elected as Germany's first female chancellor in 2005, he thinks German people particularly favor and admire female political figures.
Claiming that the competition environment is "always unfavorable to females, " Chen said that given better opportunities and room to perform, "women can do as well as men."

Chen said he cares about women's rights and noted that the Taipei city government recruited the most female chief executives among all government agencies during his tenure as Taipei mayor prior to assuming the presidency.
He thanked the delegation for the German parliament's support and concern for issues related to Taiwan and expressed hope for a peaceful resolution to cross- Taiwan Strait disputes through dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Pressing Allies, President Warns of Afghan Battle
President Bush warned on Thursday that he expected fierce fighting to flare in Afghanistan this spring, and he pressed NATO allies to provide a bigger and more aggressive force to guard against a resurgence by the Taliban and Al Qaeda that could threaten the fragile Afghan state.
With American and NATO commanders pressing for more troops and experts predicting that further gains by the Taliban could put the Afghan government of President Hamid Karzai in danger, Mr. Bush used his presidential platform to lay out what he said was substantial progress in Afghanistan since 2001, but also a continuing threat.
Wall Street Journal:Probes of Backdating Move to Faster Track
On Jan. 4, 2002, the chief financial officer of Broadcom Corp. tapped out an email about stock options to his chief executive and others."I very strongly recommend that these options be priced as of December 24," he wrote.
They were, and that was fortunate for recipients. Broadcom's share price rose 23% between the two dates. The pretense that the options had been granted on the earlier date made them extra valuable.
A probe into Broadcom is a sign of how long- running investigations of stock- options backdating are heating up, as prosecutors winnow the roster of some 140 companies with options problems to a tighter list.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC MINISTRY FORMS TASK FORCE TO ENSURE ENERGY SUPPLY

TEXT.P: State-run enterprises have formed special task forces to address possible emergency situations during the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday, which starts Feb. 17, officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.
Taiwan Power Company, CPC Corp., Taiwan, and the Taiwan Water Corp (TWC) have all taken steps to ensure a stable supply of electricity, oil, and water, during this period, the officials noted.
The power company reminded the public to turn off household electricity before leaving home for a long vacation during the holiday.
Should a power failure occur during the holiday, the public can call a hotline at 1911, and the company will send staff to fix the problem immediately, according to the officials.

In addition, the oil company said that 269 of its 651 gas stations run by private owners around Taiwan will continue to provide 24-hour service, while adding that stations in scenic areas will extend their business hours, the officials said.
Services will return to normal Feb. 23, according to the officials.
Moreover, the water company said that people can call a toll free hotline at 0800-000876 if water supplies are interrupted or leakage occurs, the officials continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE TRAVEL BETWEEN KINMEN, FUJIAN VIA MINI LINK

TEXT.P: Over 2,500 people traveled between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait via the "mini three links" routes linking Taiwan's Kinmen to China's Xiamen and Quanzhou in Fujian Province, with 60 percent of the travelers being Taiwanese businessmen operating in China or their family members, according to Kinmen officials in charge of port affairs.
Taiwanese travelers were on their way to return home for Chinese New Year celebrations which begin Feb. 18 this year.

Shipments between Kinmen and the two Chinese coastal cities have increased since Feb. 10 as part of special transportation services between Taiwan and China during the Lunar New Year festival, one of the most important traditional festivals in Chinese society.
Since then, there have been over 10,000 passengers traveling from Xiamen and Quanzhou to Kinmen, and some 730 people taking ferries from Kinmen to China, according to Kinmen port statistics.
According to Kinmen port authorities, the "mini three links" shipping service in Kinmen will be suspended on Saturday afternoon and all of Sunday. Saturday is Chinese New Year's Eve.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE HIT 4.62% FOR 2006: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2006 reached 4.62 percent, thanks to diminishing credit card problems, a rising stock market and good weather, the country's budget chief said Friday.
The figure surpassed the government's target of 4.5 percent, Hsu Chang-yao, director-general of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS), said.

Meanwhile, last year's unemployment rate was 3.91 percent, while the consumer price index (CPI) saw an annual increase rate of 0.6 percent, Hsu said, adding that both figures were lower than the government's targets of 4 percent and 2 percent, respectively.

Attributing the rise in the economic growth rate to good performance in the fourth quarter, Hsu said the effect of two "ghost months" -- the seventh month of the Chinese calendar when business activity is usually sluggish -- was over and that the negative impact of bad credit card debt was subsiding.
The two factors had helped boost the tourism and food and beverage sectors by 11 percent and 7.5 percent, respectively, Hsu went on.
Moreover, the stock market became more active, reporting a 20.4 increase in the total trading value compared with the 2005 level, Hsu said, adding that this had also increased private spending.

The economic growth rate in the final quarter of last year recorded 4.02 percent, higher than the 3.15 percent forecast by the government, while the per capita gross domestic product (GDP) reached US$15,640 in 2006, according to Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEBRUARY 17 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Feb. 17
07:30, Premier Su Tseng-chang will inspect Chinese New Year period immigration operations at Taoyuan International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway.
18:00, The Presidential Office will release video footage featuring President Chen Shui-bian's Lunar New Year's Eve speech.
24:05, Vice President Annette Lu will pray for the country's well-being at Paoan Temple in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER JOURNALISTS INDICTED FOR BLACKMAILING TERRY GUO

TEXT.P: Taipei prosecutors indicted Friday two former journalists for their alleged blackmailing of Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Guo, Taiwan's richest man.

The indictment says that Next Magazine reporter Tzang Chia-yi -- collaborating with her boyfriend Huang Shang-ping -- last August and September twice sent draft articles to Guo that defamed him, with the excuse that she was writing a biography of Guo and asking that he preview the script.

The worried Guo sought help from Yang Jen-kai, former editor-in-chief of the China Times Weekly who had also worked with Hon Hai. However, according to the indictment, Yang joined Tzang and Huang's plot to blackmail Guo and demanded 10% of the NT$32 million (US$970,432) the pair were extorting in exchange for not publishing the biography.
Police, informed by Guo, arrested Tzang and Huang Dec. 14 at a bank where Guo's employees were pretending to hand over the money to the pair, the prosecutors said.
Prosecutors dismissed claims by Tzang and Huang that Guo was to pay the NT$32 million as copyright fee for the book and indicted the two and Yang.
Next Magazine sacked Tzang immediately following her arrest.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY INSTALLS NEW NIGHTTIME COMBAT TRAINING FACILITY

TEXT.P: The Army Special Service Force training center in central Taichung County has installed a new nighttime combat training classroom in the hopes of upgrading the Special Service Force's nighttime combat capabilities, military sources said Friday.

The special training center in Taichung County's Kukuan township has long been known as a testing ground for the Army's special service personnel. The new training facility is aimed at honing the special service forces' nighttime combat skills, sources said.

Noting that intensive, rigorous nighttime combat training is expected to help special service officers and soldiers overcome fear and psychological pressures, an Army officer said the installation is consistent with worldwide security trends.

According to the officer, the Army has referred to simialr foreign facilities in designing the new nighttime training classroom in which military instructors can design various training and testing programs to improve team spirit and coordination.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007.02.17 TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Saturday, Feb. 17, or the 30th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1933: Newsweek magazine starts publication.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Washington for a visit.
1949: Chaim Weizmann is elected Israel's first president.
1952: Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) is formed in Taipei.
1959: The United States sucessfully launches its first meteorological satellite "Pioneer II."
1979: A large scale war breaks out on the border between mainland China and Vietnam.
1989: Leaders of Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, Lybia and Mauritania sign a treaty to form the North African Common Market.
1992: The Republic of China Ministry of National Defense publishes its first white paper on national defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007.02.18 TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Sunday, Feb. 18, or the first day of first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Mary Tudor, the English queen known as "Bloody Mary" because of her relentless persecution of Protestants, is born.

1546: Martin Luther, German theologian and the 16th century Protestant reformation leader who confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church, dies in Eisleben, Germany, at the age of 63.

1564: Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet, and the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance who created some of the greatest works of all time, including his marble sculpture "David," the paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and the plans for St. Peter's Cathedral, dies in Rome at the age of 89.

1678: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer celebrated for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of a Christian's journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City, publishes the first part of his masterpiece.
1685: La Salle, a French explorer, sets up the first European settlement in Texas.
1745: Alessandro Volta, Italian physicist who invented the electric battery, is born. The volt is named in his honor.
1855: Nicholas I, the czar of Russia who suppressed the December Movement and led his country into the Crimean War, dies at the age of 59.
1915: German submarines start a maritime blockade of Great Britain.
1930: Clyde William Tombaugh, a US astronomer, is the first to see Pluto, realizing it is the Sun's ninth and smallest planet, at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.

1932: Japan announces that the "Manchukuo" regime will be installed in northeastern China. The "land of the Manchu" (Manchuria) proved to be no more than another stepping-stone for the expansion of Japanese aggression.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek addresses a joint session of the US House and Senate.
1945: The battle for Iwo Jima starts in the Pacific.
1951: Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announces the formation of a new government in Vietnam.
1960: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay agree to establish the Latin American Free Trade Association.
1965: The West African nation of Gambia proclaims independence.
1967: Robert Julius Oppenheimer, the American physicist known as the father of the A-bomb, dies at the age of 65.
1972: The Supreme Court of California abolishes the death penalty.
1974: Jorge Cervantes-Pinzon, outgoing charge d'affaires from Colombia, leaves Taipei for home.
1976: C.C. Yang, ROC economic affairs vice minister, and S.M. Osman, secretary- general of the Afro-Asian Rural Reconstruction Organization, sign an agreement on technical cooperation.
1984: McDonald's, the Chicago-based fast-food chain, opens its first branch in Taiwan.
1986: The Asian Development Bank votes to admit mainland China.
1988: Boris Yeltsin is ousted from the ruling Communist Party Politburo in Moscow.
1991: The US assault ship Tripoli and the guided missile cruiser Princeton are damaged by mines in the Persian Gulf during the Gulf War.
1992: A delegation from the US President's Export Council arrives in Taipei to promote bilateral trade.
1994: Lin Wen-chiang, a mainland Chinese hijacker, commandeers a Southwest Airlines passenger plane from the mainland to Taiwan.
1998: Mya Than Tint, one of Burma's most renowned and admired writers, dies at the age of 69.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man may have abilities as admirable as our Lord of Chou (the Chinese equivalent of Moses or Solomon), but if he is proud and mean, you need not consider the other qualities of his mind."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007.02.19.TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Monday, Feb. 19, or the second day of the first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, the Polish astronomer who advanced the theory that the Earth rotates daily on its axis and, with the other planets in the solar system, revolves around the Sun, is born.
1800: Napoleon Bonaparte proclaims himself First Consul of the newly established French dictatorship.
1861: Tsar Alexander II signs a proclamation setting free 20 million serfs, almost a third of Russia's population.
1878: Thomas Edison, the U.S. inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.

1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th U.S. president, who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War and was an avid big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1915: A French-British fleet begins shelling Turkish fortifications along the strategic Dardenelles waterway in a bid to defeat Turkey and reopen the critical Black Sea supply route to Russia.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.

1945: U.S. forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN CALL FOR DIPLOMATIC RECOGNITION OF TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/17/07 15:49:44 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.C. Jou)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's official representative office and civil groups in the United States expressed gratitude Friday for a bipartisan U.S. House of Representatives proposal led by Rep. Tom Tancredo (R-Colo.) calling for the United States to resume normal diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Tancredo, along with Reps. Mark Souder (R-Ind.), Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) , Edolphus Towns (D-N.Y.) and Dan Burton (R-Ind.) , introduced earlier the same day the resolution urging the Bush administration to recognize Taiwan as a sovereign and independent state in demonstration of concrete support for the democracy.

The resolution calls on the U.S. president to abandon the fundamentally flawed "one China policy" in favor of a more realistic "one China, one Taiwan policy" and begin the process of resuming normal diplomatic relations with Taiwan. It also urges the United States to aggressively support Taiwan's bid for full participation in the United Nations and other international organizations that require statehood for membership.
Tancredo said that "the 'one China' policy is a fiction - a relic of time that has long since passed, " arguing that it is time for the United States to "stop living this lie."

Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) President C.T. Lee applauded the resolution, saying "the policy of dual recognition will be the most effective way for the United States to manifest its support for democratic countries around the world and to counter China's ambition of invading Taiwan."
FAPA is a Washington-based private non-profit organization aiming to promote Taiwan's international status.
The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States also expressed its appreciation to Tancredo and his colleagues for introducing the resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNTY GOV'T HIRES FERRY TO HELP PEOPLE RETURN HOME FOR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: A special ferry hired by the Kinmen County Government to help Kinmen people living on Taiwan proper return home for the Lunar New Year holidays arrived at the outlying island's Liaoluo Harbor Saturday morning after a nine-hour journey from Taichung Harbor.

A total of 355 people took advantage of the special ferry service set up by the county government for the first time as a solution to the problem of limited availability of air tickets during the holiday period due to high demand.
Passengers aboard the "Kinmen Express" received a warm welcome as well as red envelopes from Kinmen County Commissioner Lee Chu-feng upon their arrival at Liaoluo Harbor.

Most of the passengers interviewed expressed satisfaction with the ferry service. Some of them said they took the ferry because there were no plane tickets available, while others said they decided to return home by sea as the cost was much lower than flying.
As the county government bore most of the cost of providing the ferry service, passengers only needed to pay NT$500 (US$15) for an adult one-way ticket.

Lunar New Year traffic has been a nightmare for Kinmen people who live on Taiwan proper and wish to return home to reunite with family during the holidays, as there are only a limited number of flights and no regular passenger ferry service linking Taiwan to the outlying island.
The Kinmen Express will depart on its return trip to Taichung Harbor at 10:00 p.m. on Feb. 24, the county government said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGHER CONSUMER SPENDING REFLECTS PROGRESS IN QUALITY OF LIFE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The increased level of consumer spending in Taiwan, which totaled NT$7.07 trillion (US$214.89 billion) in 2006, reflects improvements in the quality of life of local people, the Cabinet's statistics agency reported Saturday.

According to the results of a recent survey by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , Taiwan's consumer spending -- meaning the purchase of goods and services by individual citizens -- increased 2.2 percent year-on-year in 2006.

An in-depth analysis of consumer spending in Taiwan over the past decade shows that the percentage of spending on basic necessities, such as food, water, shelter and clothing, has declined steadily, while spending on entertainment and education has been on an upward spiral, a trend that points to progress in the pursuit of higher quality of life following increases in the nation's per-capita income, DGBAS officials said.
In 2006, spending on food continued to represent the lion's share of overall consumer spending at 23.6 percent, but the figure marked a decline of 0.5 percentage points over that of a decade earlier.

Rent and water bills accounted for 14.6 percent of total consumer spending, down 2.8 percentage points from the level registered a decade ago, DGBAS officials said, adding that the percentage of spending on clothing also dropped 0.9 percentage points to a mere 3.7 percent of total spending.

In contrast, the ratio of spending on travel, entertainment, recreation, education and cultural services increased by 1.9 percentage points to reach 18.7 percent of total spending, the officials said.

As local people's average life expectancy has risen steadily over the past decade, medical and health care bills have also spiked, with the ratio surging 1.5 percentage points to reach 9.1 percent of total household spending in 2006.

The prevalence of mobile phone and Internet service has driven up the ratio of spending on transportation and communications to 11.9 percent, or 0.8 percentage points higher than the figure a decade ago, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TAICHUNG MAYOR'S WIFE MAKES FIRST PUBLIC APPEARANCE SINCE ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Shirley Shaw, wife of Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, on Saturday made her first public appearance since being seriously injured in a highway accident in late November.

Shaw was able to walk slowly with Hu leading her by the hand and greet the public upon exiting the China Medical University Hospital in Taichung, where she has been recuperating since the accident. She will return to the hospital on Tuesday after spending Lunar New Year's Eve at home.
Encouraged by her husband, Shaw faced the media cameras and thanked the public for all their support and wished everyone a Happy New Year in the hospital's lobby.

The traffic accident occurred on the evening of Nov. 18 when Hu and his wife were heading home to Taichung from a campaign rally in Kaohsiung along the north-bound section of the Formosa Freeway. Their car rolled over after it was hit by a vehicle that was trying to pass a truck. Shaw sustained serious injuries in the accident and was unconscious when she arrived at Chimei Hospital in Tainan. Hu also sustained minor injuries in the accident. The medical team treating Shaw said Saturday that it will take between six months and a year for Shao to fully regain her cognitive functions. They further said that she will be fitted with an artificial limb for her amputated left forearm.
Hu expressed appreciation to the Chi Mei Medical Center, China Medical University Hospital and the public "for praying for and giving blessings to us."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 20,000 USE KINMEN FERRY SERVICE AHEAD OF HOLIDAYS

TEXT.P: Nearly 20,000 passengers have traveled between Taiwan and China via the outlying island of Kinmen for the Chinese New Year holiday over the last eight days leading up to and including Saturday, according to officials from the Kinmen Harbor Authority.
The small Taiwan-held island saw 571 inbound travelers and 373 outbound travelers Saturday. Ferries will not operate Sunday on Chinese New Year's Day.

Most of the inbound passengers Saturday were Taiwan businessmen working in China. They made a transit stop in Kinmen before flying on to Taiwan. The outbound passengers were mainly China-born spouses of Taiwan nationals heading back to their hometowns or Taiwan businessmen assigned to work in China during the holidays.

Although the ferry service was operating smoothly Saturday, the island's only airport was closed for an hour in the morning because of heavy fog, and a flight from Taiwan carrying some 200 passengers wanting to head on to Xiamen by ferry arrived about an hour late. As a result, the departure time of Saturday's last ferry to Xiamen, originally scheduled for 11 a.m., was delayed for fifty minutes to wait for the passengers.

The Kinmen Harbor Authority, which operates the ferry services between the outlying island and Xiamen and Chuanzhou in Fujian Province in southern China, began adding extra ferry service eight days ago to handle the increased passenger traffic ahead of the holidays. As of the end of Saturday, a total of 19,138 people had used the ferry service during the eight-day period, marking an increase of 2,184 passengers over the figure for the same period last year, the officials said.

Ferry service will resume Monday, when many local residents are expected to travel to China for sightseeing during the weeklong Lunar New Year holiday and Taiwan businessmen will begin to return to their posts in China following the holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN EXTENDS NEW YEAR GREETINGS TO COMPATRIOTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian extended his Lunar New Year greetings to his fellow compatriots in a short videotape Saturday, wishing them a happy New Year's Day.

The one minute and 52 second long video tape is a montage consisting of footage of the country's two female tenis players who won the second place in the women's double at the 2006 Australian Open tenis championship, an engineer standing in front of the Hsueshan Tunnel on the freeway linking Yilan and Taipei, a train running on the island's high speed railway, and a farmer whose rise won the top prize in a islandwide competition.

By playing these images of the country's glorious moments, the president said the outgoing year is a fruitful one thanks to the hard work of all people, and the coming year is sure to be more brilliant as long as the people keep working hard.

1707: Aurangzeb, the sixth and perhaps last of the great Mogul emperors of India, dies at the age of 88. He seized the throne at Agra from his father, Shah Jahan, 49 years earlier, killing two of his brothers and jailing the third to secure his succession.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG MAYORAL BY-ELECTION TENTATIVELY SET FOR MAY 12

TEXT.P: Electoral authorities have decided tentatively to hold a by-election on May 12 for the post of Keelung mayor, which has been rendered vacant by the death of Hsu Tsai-li, an official said Tuesday.
Hsu, 60, who suffered from diabetes and cardiovascular disease, died of related complications Monday after serving barely more than one year of his second four- year term as Keelung mayor.

Teng Tien-yu, spokesman for the Central Election Commission, noted that according to the country's election laws, a by-election should be held within three months after an elective post becomes vacant if the original office holder has not yet served half of the term.

With a by-election due by May 19 in this case, the election committee of Taiwan Province is planning to schedule the by-election for May 12, as elections in the country are usually held on the second Saturday of a month, Teng said.
He said the committee will call a meeting after the Chinese New Year holiday to finalize the date for the election and other related details.

Political observers said the upcoming by-election will be a litmus test of the coalitions formed by the "pan-blue alliance" and "pan-green camp" for the year- end legislative elections and next year's presidential election.

Opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung remains the most likely candidate to stand for the "pan-blue alliance, " but the support of the party's ally -- the opposition Kuomintang -- will be crucial for victory if he is to run for the post, the observers said.

Meanwhile, although the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -led "pan-green camp" is widely seen as enjoying weaker voter support in the northern port city than the "pan-blue alliance, " DPP officials said the party will take the by-election very seriously.

Even if the DPP loses the by-election, the DPP will learn from the results whether the people are disappointed in the party and how it should adjust its strategies for the upcoming legislative and presidential elections, the officials said.
It remains to be seen as to whether DPP Legislator Wang Tuoh, who has expressed his intention to leave politics, will take part in the by-election.

Hsu, who ran under the banner of the KMT in the last Keelung mayoral election in December 2005, won with 76,162 votes, while Taiwan Solidarity Union's Chen Chien-ming, who represented the "pan-green camp," took 58,243 votes.
PFP's Liu garnered 47,932 votes, and the DPP's Wang got 2,771 votes despite his withdrawal from the election.

The KMT expelled Hsu from the party after he was found guilty of corruption by the Keelung District Court in September 2006 for trying to sell a plot of land he bought from a businessman to the city's bus service department for a windfall profit.
The KMT had since urged Hsu to resign from the mayoral post and launched a drive to recall him after the request was ignored.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MUSEUM LAUNCHES 'VIVA THE PIG' EXHIBIT

TEXT.P: The Taichung-based National Museum of Natural Science (NMNS) has launched a "Viva the Pig" exhibit in celebration of the Year of the Pig, as well as revealing many of the true facets of pigs, museum official said Tuesday.

NMNS Director Lin Tzong-shyan noted that there are some long-held prejudices against pigs, such as laziness and stupidity, however, pigs are smart, clean, and diligent, as their way of living shows visitors.

According to some previous studies, the average intelligence quotient of pigs trails after only humans, monkeys, whales and dolphins. Pigs also possess a good ability to learn and a significant long-term memory.

The exhibition covers several themes, including the 19 kinds of wild boar existing on earth, the history of the domestication of the pig, pig-related Chinese characters, and specimens of pigs and boars from around the world.
The exhibit started Feb. 16 and runs thru May 15, and is open 9 a.m. - 5 p.m. everyday.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOLUME OF CHINESE NEW YEAR SMS CALLS RISES OVER 20%

TEXT.P: The number of mobile messages sent via major telecommunications networks in Taiwan recorded a year-on-year increase of more than 20 percent for the three days leading up to and and including the first day of the lunar New Year as sending mobile New Year greetings has become increasingly popular.

A total of 19 million, 22.52 million and 24.98 million messages were sent via the Chunghwa Telecom mobile network two days before, the day before, and the first day of Chinese New Year, respectively, company officials said.

The average number of mobile messages sent during these three days rose 49.5 percent compared with the same period last year, and the income generated from the messaging service for these three days amounted to approximately NT$90 million, the officials said.
Taiwan Mobile Co. saw 31.18 million and 38.33 million mobile messages transmitted or received via its network on Chinese New Year's eve and Chinese New Year's day, respectively, officials said.
The figures represent a rise of 20 percent and 24 percent, respectively, over the same time last year, they said.

Meanwhile, officials at Far Eastone Telecommunications Co. said the volume of 2G messages sent via its network during the first hour of Chinese New Year jumped 30 percent over last year, while the volume of 3G imaging messages sent during the same period climbed 70 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO STEP UP ANTI-DRUG EFFORTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) will strengthen its supervision of narcotic hazard prevention and control centers nationwide this year to ensure that they operate efficiently, ministry officials said Tuesday.

In addition, the ministry will work with the Ministry of the Interior, Department of Health, Ministry of Education and Council of Labor Affairs to step up anti-drug publicity, improve the social relief and rehabilitation services available to drug addicts, and supervise the Taiwan After-Care Association's establishment of a half-way home to shelter drug-addicted ex-convicts and provide them with religious counseling, the officials said.

The government has designated the five years 2004 - 2008 as the "National Anti- Drug Combat Years" and has implemented a series of measures with the goal of eliminating the hazards posed by narcotic use.

Among these measures are the establishment of narcotic hazard prevention and control centers in various counties and cities -- begun July 2006 -- to promote drug awareness, provide drug rehabilitation services, prevent drug abuse and help former drug addicts avoid falling back into their old habit.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANGMINGSHAN BLOSSOM SEASON KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government announced Tuesday the start of this year's blossom season on Yangmingshan, a suburban mountain resort.

During the blossom season, which is set to run through March 25, the city government will provide special bus services to the Yangming Park on Yangmingshan, with stops in seven scenic spots along Yangteh Avenue, officials said.
In addition, people who visit the park 6 p.m - 9 p.m. during the blossom season can have dinner then take their coffee among the blossoming cherry trees, they said.

While presiding over the inauguration of the park's visitor service center Tuesday, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin invited the public to visit the park during the Chinese New Year holiday, saying the joyful atmosphere, cherry and peach blossoms will give them a good start to the year.
Hau also suggested that the public use the bus services provided by the city government to avoid traffic congestion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS FAMILIES OF 228 INCIDENT VICTIMS IN HUALIEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian traveled to the eastern city of Hualien Tuesday to meet with bereaved families of the 228 Incident victims.
Chen exchanged Lunar New Year greetings with the families at the office of the Concern for 228 Incident Victims Association and wished them a prosperous, auspicious new year.

Noting that he has come to gain a better understanding of the living conditions of the families of the 228 Incident victims, including the schooling and employment of their children, Chen said his administration has spared no efforts to pursue the facts concerning the events in the hopes that such a tragedy will never be repeated.
"The 228 Incident" refers to a series of events in 1947 that led to a brutal crackdown by the former Kuomintang (KMT) government against the local population, particularly the intelligentsia.

"It is hoped that the historical facts concerning the 228 Incident will come to light in full to serve as a part of our democratic education and help avoid any repetition of the tragedy, " Chen said, adding that the pursuit of transitional justice is an issue in all emerging democratic countries seeking to resolve the sad legacies of authoritarian rule.

During the talks, Lin Lien-ming, president of the Concern for 228 Incident Victims Association, expressed worries that a 228 Incident memorial monument in Peipin Park in Hualien City may be toppled because of a highway expansion project to link the nearby Hualien Harbor Bureau to other parts of the city.

In response, Chen promised to ask relevant government authorities to include the building of an even more magnificent monument in commemoration of the tragic incident as part of the road expansion project.

The bloody 228 Incident took place during a turbulent period of Taiwan's history. In 1945, the mainland China-based KMT government reclaimed Taiwan, which had been a Japanese colony. But the KMT's rule was brutal and corrupt, leading to a massive protest Feb. 28, 1947, by the native Taiwanese. More troops were sent from the mainland to crush the demonstrations and in the following months, soldiers arrested and killed thousands of people whom they claimed were communists or saboteurs trying to overthrow the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REMAINS TIGHT-LIPPED ON PRESIDENTIAL BID

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang remained tight-lipped Tuesday about when he will formally throw his hat in the ring and declare his candidacy for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination (DPP's) for the 2008 presidential election.

Su was asked by a group of reporters concerning his intention to run for the presidency during a tour of a tropical agricultural park in Changchih township in southernmost Pingtung County where he once served as magistrate.

The premier was accompanied by Council of Agriculture Minister Su Jia-chyuan and Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung on the tour as part of his community outreach program during the Chinese New Year holiday.
In the company of his octogenarian mother and his wife, Su toured various sectors of the park which is divided into 18 areas for planting different tropical floral and fruit species.

Along the way, Su was often surrounded by crowds of local residents asking to have their photos taken together with him and cheering him to "go for the presidency." Some passionate supporters even addressed him as "President Su." The premier was all smiles while greeting his fans, but he refrained from giving any response to press queries concerning when he will announce his bid for the presidency.
Su instead knelt on the ground and spent 10 minutes carving the words "praying for a better future for Taiwan, wishing everyone a happy new year" on a big pumpkin.
Concluding his tour of the pumpkin section of the agricultural park, Su dispensed "red envelopes" containing a NT$10 coin to holidaymakers in the park and wished them a prosperous new year.
Su is one of the four DPP bigwigs viewed as possible presidential contenders. The other three are Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh.
So far, only Hsieh has formally declared his candidacy for the DPP primary preceding the 2008 presidential election.
Hsieh threw his hat in the ring last Friday, a day before the long Chinese New Year holiday that lasts until Feb. 25.

Hsieh, a former mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, announced his candidacy while meeting with his grass roots supporters in Kaohsiung. He told them that he will take advantage of the Chinese New Year holiday to ponder issues of public welfare and taxation reform and will then register for the DPP's presidential primary.
Registration for the DPP primary will be open from March 5 through March 9, according to a timetable for the presidential primary finalized by the DPP's Central Standing Committee last Wednesday.

Party members will vote on both presidential and legislative hopefuls May 6, after which public opinion polls will be held. The votes of party members are weighted to comprise 30 percent of a would-be candidate's score, while the public opinion poll counts for 70 percent. The presidential aspirant who receives the highest approval rating will be named as the party's presidential candidate May 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG CITY COUNCIL SPEAKER THROWS HAT IN RING FOR BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Keelung City Council Speaker Chang Tung-jung threw his hat in the ring and declared his candidacy Tuesday for the northern port city's mayoral by-election, which has become necessary following the death of embattled Mayor Hsu Tsai-li the previous day.
Chang, a member of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said he feels "bound in honor" to "succeed Hsu and complete Hsu's uncompleted city development projects."
Hsu, who was sentenced to seven years in prison on a graft charge, died of complications from chronic heart disease Monday at the age of 60.
The Ministry of the Interior has named Hsu Ching-kun, chief secretary of the Keelung City Government, to serve as the city's acting mayor.

According to the country's public functionaries election law, a by-election should be held within three months after an elective post becomes vacant if the original office holder has not yet served half of the term.

With a by-election due by May 19 in Hsu's case, the election committee of Taiwan Province is planning to schedule the by-election for May 12, as elections in the country are usually held on the second Saturday of a month.
Chang was the first from both ruling and opposition camps to explicitly express intention to run in the mayoral by-election.

Hsu, who ran under the banner of the KMT in the last Keelung mayoral election in December 2005, won with 76,162 votes, while Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU's) Chen Chien-ming, who represented the "pan-green camp," took 58,243 votes.

Another candidate, Liu Wen-hsiung, a legislator from the opposition People First Party, which has formed a"pan-blue alliance" with the KMT, garnered 47,932 votes, and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Wang Tuoh got 2,771 votes despite his withdrawal from the election to support the TSU's Chen.

The KMT expelled Hsu from the party after he was found guilty of corruption by the Keelung District Court in September 2006 for trying to sell a plot of land he bought from a businessman to the city's bus service department for a windfall profit. The deal was called off after prosecutors began probes into the case.
The KMT had since urged Hsu to resign from the mayoral post and launched a drive to recall him after the request was ignored.
Chang said he fully understands Hsu's grievances and is determined to win the mayoral by-election to fulfill Hsu's uncompleted missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NOT TO BE ABSENT FROM KEELUNG MAYORAL BY-ELECTION: PARTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will definitely nominate a qualified aspirant to run for the Keelung mayorship following the death of the northern port city's embattled Mayor Hsu Tsai-li, the party's top leader said Tuesday.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun made the remarks while visiting the famous Lungshan Temple in Taipei to pray for national well-being as part of his community outreach activities during the Chinese New Year holiday.
Yu said he will meet with the leading figures of the DPP's Keelung chapter and opinion leaders familiar with Keelung politics in the next few days to exchange views on the party's candidacy issue.

As to whether DPP Legislator Wang Tuoh, a veteran politician in the Keelung constituency, will likely represent the DPP in the upcoming Keelung mayoral by- election, Yu said he would not rule out any possible candidate.

Wang garnered 2,771 votes in the last mayoral election in December 2005, albeit he announced his withdrawal from the race a few weeks before the election and threw his support behind Chen Chien-ming, the candidate of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a DPP ally in the legislature, who eventually captured 58,243 votes.

Hsu, who ran under the banner of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the last mayoral election, won with 76,162 votes. He was expelled by the KMT last September after being found guilty of corruption for trying to sell a plot of land he bought from a buisnessman to Keelung's city bus service department for a windfall profit. The deal of called off after prosecutors began probes into the case.

Hsu died from complications from chronic heart disease Monday a the age of 60. According to the current public functionary election law, a by-election must be held within three months because Hsu had not yet serve out half of his term. A by-election is tentatively set on May 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 21, or the fourth day of the first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1673: Jean Baptiste Poquelin Moliere, the French playwright whose sophisticated comedies include "Tartuffe" and "The Misanthrope," is buried in secret in a Paris cemetery.
1795: Holland surrenders Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) to Britain.
1858: Edwin Holmes of Boston installs the first electric burglar alarm.
1866: August von Wasserman, the German bacteriologist who invented a test to detect syphilis, is born.
1911: The United States and Japan sign a treaty limiting the flow of Japanese workers into the United States.
1916: Massed German artillery begin a furious bombardment of a crucial 13-kilometer sector of the French line at Verdun in the middle of the Western Front.
1917: Modern China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes "The Fundamental Knowledge in Democracy," a book dealing with the procedures of parliamentary rule.
1944: General Hideki Tojo, prime minister of Japan, replaces Field Marshall Hajime Sugiyama as chief of the Imperial Army general staff.
1957: Israel defies a U.N. resolution and holds on to the Gaza Strip.
1963: Moscow warns Washington that an American attack on Cuba would mean world war.
1969: King Hassan of Morocco is granted a patent by the U.S. Patents Office for his device to monitor the function of the human heart.
1970: A cargo plane belonging to Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes on top of Fushoushan in suburban Taipei, killing its two pilots.
1972: U.S. President Richard Nixon visits mainland China.
1973: Forty-six manufacturers attend the second European Industrial Machinery Exhibition in Taipei.
1973: Lt. Gen. Robert R. Williams, acting commander of the U.S. Army, Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Swaziland Vice Prime Minister Z.A. Khumalo arrives in Taipei for a week- long tour.
1974: The Buenos Aires University Club rugby team, champions of South America, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: The Taiwan Shipbuilding Corporation begins construction of a fifth 100,000-ton tanker for the Chinese Petroleum Corporation.
1986: Mainland Chinese air force pilot Chen Baozhong defects to South Korea in a MiG-19 fighter.
1986: Shigechiyo Izumi, the world's oldest man, dies in Japan at the age of 120.
1989: Czech writer Vaclav Havel is imprisoned for initiating a demonstration. Havel later became president of Czechoslovakia.
1990: Hun Sen, premier of Cambodia, holds peace talks with his rival, Prince Ranaridh Sihanouk, in Bangkok.
1990: Salvadorean President Alfredo Cristiani visits the Republic of China.
1992: Mainland China welcomes foreigners back to its stock market in Shanghai for the first time since 1949.
1998: The U.S. government advises its citizens to leave Iraq, in anticipation of new airstrikes.
2000: ROC Defense Minister Tang Fei arrives in Singapore to attend a five-day Asian Aerospace Show.
2000: Liberian President Charles Ghankay Taylor arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Appearance of high spirits without integrity, of dullness without humility, of simplicity without honesty -- of such men I really do not know what to say."
