DOC.HEADLINE: DULAN POLICE STATION IN TAITUNG NOW SAFE CAMPING AREA

TEXT.P: The Dulan Police Station in Taitung County's Tungho township along the east coast -- always a scenic spot -- has become a very secure camping area for tourists thanks to the 24-hour police presence, a spokesman for the station said Wednesday.

Luo Kuang-chung, director of Chengkung Police Precinct of the Taitung County Police Bureau said the idea behind making the police station into a scenic rest area is to bridge the gap between the police and people and share the natural beauty of the scenery surrounding the station with tourists.

The station's free camping spaces can hold about 10 tents at one time, and no reservations are needed. Tourists may camp there so long as there is space remaining, provided that they notify the police. Luo said over 200 people have camped at the station since March 2006.

With subsidies from the East Coast National Scenic Area Administration provided for its renovation, Dulan Police Station is now a convenient and beautiful stopping-off point with a fountain, ecology pond, showers and washing facilities, all free for those camping at the site.

Campers may also visit nearby pre-historical relics, Dulan Artist Village, Dulan sugar factory, and Moonlight Inn--once a shooting location in an old movie. In addition to the Dulan Police Station, the Tuli Police Station in Taitung County also offers free camp sites for the public, Luo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLASS ART EXHIBITION IN HSINCHU CELEBRATES ARRIVAL OF YEAR OF THE PIG
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/07 16:07:12 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Hsinchu -- the "garden city" of northern Taiwan -- is holding a glass art exhibition at the Hsinchu Municipal Glass Museum to celebrate the arrival of the Year of the Pig.

Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-Tzer said Wednesday that the city government welcomes visitors to view a collection of 58 works showing pigs in various colors with different facial expressions created by by 43 glass artists.
He pointed out that the pig, as one of 12 animals in the Chinese zodiac, is a symbol of harmony, prosperity and peace.

Lin Sung, director of Hsinchu City's Cultural Affairs Bureau, said the city government arranged the exhibition not only to add a festive element to the Lunar New Year, but to wish everyone a happy, prosperous year.
The two-month-long exhibition will last until April 8.
Side by side with that event, the same museum is putting on another exhibition by 22 members of the Hsinchu Wind City Glass Artist Association, which presents 64 of their glass works.

Meanwhile, ceramic artist Yeh Tso-yeh is displaying his pottery works featuring the motif of the pig at an annual art exhibition in a showroom of Hsinchu's Bureau of Cultural Affairs. The four-week-long exhibition will end Feb. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ULTRA MARATHONER CROSSES SAHARA DESERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ultra-endurance marathoner Kevin Lin, along with an American and a Canadian, completed their run across the Sahara Desert Tuesday (Taipei time) , making the trio the first three modern runners to cross the Sahara's grueling 7,300 kilometers.

Lin, 30, and his fellow ultra-athletes -- Charlie Engle, 44 and Ray Zahab, 38 -- reached the Suez Canal at Egypt's Red Sea Tuesday night after running 111 consecutive days to cross the Sahara -- the world's largest desert. The trio traversed six countries, beginning with Senegal, but also including Mauritania, Mali, Niger and Libya, by the time their trek ended in Egypt.

The trio endured strong winds, which can abruptly raise sand in every direction, making it difficult to see and breathe, and extreme temperatures, which might peak as high as 38 degrees Celsius during the day but dip below freezing at night, on the trek, which was originally scheduled to finish in 80 days.
They began last November but had to run an extra 200 kilometers under the surveillance of the Libyan authorities, who at one point refused to grant them entry visas.

Lin, who has traveled the world competing in adventure races, said during a mobile phone call to his mentor Tuesday night that running through turbulent conditions is nothing new to him, but the past 111 days had tested his physical and mental limitations.
He had to change his running shoes from size seven to 8.5 due to swelling, but this had not forced him to rest for one single day, Lin said.
Lin, the first Asian to run a seven-day-six-night Sahara marathon in 2002, is scheduled to return to Taiwan Saturday.

A film crew followed trio, chronicling their desert journey for a documentary by actor Matt Damon's production company, LivePlanet. Damon plans to narrate the documentary, which will be a film titled "Running the Sahara."

At several points in their trek, Lin said, they stopped near sparsely populated wells to talk with villagers and nomads about the difficulties they face finding water -- prompting them to plan a fund-raiser for the nonprofit group H2O Africa, which was established to raise awareness about the need for clean water throughout the African continent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PASSES BUSY DAY VISITING NURSING HOME, COAST GUARD BASE

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang had a busy day Wednesday, visiting a nursing home and a coast guard base in Taipei county.

Su visited the Shuanglian Nursing Home located in Sanchih, Taipei County and spent some happy hours with the elders living there. When Su was asked by the seniors when he will announce his presidential bid, Su ducked the question, saying only that he has not ceased for a single day to push for the well-being of the people of the country.

Su -- considered a strong contender to become a 2008 presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and, according to DPP legislator Wu Ping-jui who accompanied Su during the visit, likely to announce his presidential bid after the Lunar New Year holidays -- noted that the country should emulate Kevin Lin, who had just finished the daunting, unprecedented cross-Sahara marathon, saying that with perseverance and determination, everybody will succeed as long as they try hard enough.

Su lauded Lin as having fully demonstrated the "spirit of Taiwan" by achieving the "impossible dream" of crossing the 7,400-km Sahara Desert by foot in 111 days, carrying the Republic of China national flag on his back.
The premier said he phoned Lin upon hearing the good news the night before and told Lin that he is a source of pride for all of Taiwan.

Later in the day, Su visited a coast guard base in Tamshui, Taipei County and boarded a cutter to gain better understanding of the coast guard's daily duties, particularly operations to crack down on smugglers and the interception of illegal immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG'S HOUSING MARKET CONTINUES GROWING

TEXT.P: The new housing market in the central Taiwan city of Taichung recorded growth of more than 7 percent last year and is expected to grow even more rapidly in 2007, market experts said Wednesday.

Wang Chung-cheng, chairman of the Taichung Real Estate Development Association, quoted statistics showing that new housing projects launched in Taichung during 2006 amounted to NT$117.15 billion (US$3.54 billion) in total value, an increase of NT$9.5 billion, or 7.7 percent, from 2005.

According to Wang, the city's Hsitun District was the most sought-after neighborhood for house buyers because of its close proximity to the city's amenities, including the new civic center, the Taichung Opera House and the Central Taiwan Science Park.
Statistics show that new housing projects launched in Hsitun District in 2006 totaled NT$31.25 billion, accounting for 35 percent of the new housing market in Taichung.

Wang attributed Taichung's booming new housing market to increased employment opportunities brought by the Central Taiwan Science Park and a number of newly opened hypermarkets, as well as the launch of the first high speed railway traversing Taiwan's west corridor.
He predicted that 2007 would see even more rapid growth in Taichung's new housing market, with the total value of new projects launched in the year reaching NT$150 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO STEP UP ANTI-CORRUPTION CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has completed the installation of a nationwide anti-graft website for ordinary citizens to join the fight against political corruption by reporting suspicious corrupt cases to relevant law enforcement authorities, an MOJ official said Wednesday.
In the new year, the official said the MOJ will mobilize all government ethics units to investigate suspicious governmental operations in accordance with the ministry's anti-corruption plan.
The plan, approved by the Executive Yuan in November 2006, attacks the problem of corruption from two directions, "eliminating corruption" and "preventing corruption," the official said.

The MOJ set up the website to harness all available energy and knowledge in its efforts to wipe out political corruption. The website went live Jan. 15, 2007, showcasing government's performance in the anti-corruption campaign and keeping the public informed of its progress.

In order to encourage people to report cases of corruption, the MOJ is scheduled to raise the minimum monetary reward from NT$ 200,000 (US$ 6,062) to NT$ 300,000, and the maximum reward from NT$ 6 million to NT$ 10 million, provided that the Executive Yuan approves of relevant changes to the Anti-Corruption Informant Rewards and Protection Regulations.

The official said the MOJ will also craft strategies and decide upon key points to thoroughly investigate major irregularities at governmental institutions, especially those pertaining to suspicious governmental operations that score poorly on the integrity index following surveys.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN PUSHES FOR PASSAGE OF TAIWAN ARMS BILL

TEXT.P: Visiting U. S. Congressman Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) said Wednesday that as a close friend of Taiwan, he will continue to offer Taiwan his resolute support in Congress, but also hopes that Taiwan's legislature would pass the long-stalled arms bill to demonstrate the island's determination to defend itself.

Chabot, co-chairman of the U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus, made the statement during a visit to Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Mainland Affairs, who is Taiwan's top China policy planner.

A bill on an arms procurement package from the United States -- which includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries -- has been blocked by the opposition-controlled legislature over 70 times since it was first submitted in mid-2004.

The budget for the arms procurement package from the United States was slashed from NT$610.8 billion to NT$480 billion in 2005 to placate opposition lawmakers. It was further reduced to NT$340 billion to cover only the purchase of the submarines and sub-hunting aircraft.

During the visit, Wu said, he expressed appreciation on behalf of the government to Chabot for the congressman's long-standing, staunch support for Taiwan's cause and also called for continued U.S. support of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization and other major international organizations.

In response to Chabot's inquiries about Taiwan's reaction to China's Taiwan policies, Wu said that Beijing has been adept at employing two-pronged strategy -- showing so-called "goodwill" to the people of Taiwan on one hand while marginalizing Taiwan on the world stage and building up its military forces targeting Taiwan on the other.

Beijing has relentlessly strangled Taiwan's attempts to gain maneuvering room in the international community, most recently barring Taiwan from joining the World Health Organization and many other NGOs, organizations supposedly least influenced by politics and completely concerning people's well-being, Wu said.

Nevertheless, Wu said, despite China's relentless efforts to choke off Taiwan, militarily and diplomatically, the Mainland Affairs Council has done its utmost to improve bilateral relations with China in order to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Council efforts to help alleviate tensions across the strait included persistent calls for cross-strait negotiations and stepped-up exchanges; the opening of direct cross-strait cargo and passenger charter flight services; as well as Taiwan's cross-the-board opening up to Chinese citizens for leisure trips, Wu told Chabot.

Wu said to Chabot that it is keenly hoped that all Chinese citizens will be allowed to travel to Taiwan for tourism and to experience Taiwan society and its democracy for themselves so that people from the two sides will better understand each other, indirectly enhancing peace and stability across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOWER FESTIVAL AT YANGMINGSHAN NATIONAL PARK IN FULL SWING

TEXT.P: The annual flower season at Yangmingshan National Park is now in full swing, attracting nearly 100,000 visitors daily during the Lunar New Year holiday and causing serious traffic jams on roads leading from the city of Taipei to its "back garden".
The flower festival formally began Feb. 20 and will last 34 days until March 25. It is one of Taipei's five major flower shows throughout the year.
More than 2,000 cherry trees in the park are in full bloom. Other flowers presently blooming are camellia, peach and Hydrangea chinensis.
In addition to opening during normal day-time hours, the park will provide sufficient lighting to allow visitors to view cherry blossoms between 6 p.m. and 9 p.m. daily.
Officials at the Taipei city government's Parks and Street Lights Office urged people planning a trip to the park to use public transport and avoid having their trips spoiled by traffic congestion.
Related activities, including performances by street artists, will be held during the festival to entertain the visitors, said officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWSUIT AGAINST REBAR FOUNDER TO BE FILED SHORTLY: LAWYER
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/07 20:57:29 (By Lu-sheng Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Lawyer Chiu Chang, who obtained her doctorate of law (J.D.) in the United States, said Wednesday that she will represent some Taiwan creditors to file a lawsuit against fugitive tycoon Wang You-theng in Los Angeles shortly.

Chiu, who was formerly a legislator-at-large of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said she is sending a copy of a plaint to Wang, who is currently detained at an immigration center in San Pedro, California, and will file the plaint to a court of law in the California High Court Thursday.

Chiu said a news conference will be held in Los Angeles within days to brief the media how and what she will do as a litigator representating part of the Taiwan creditors after Wang and his wife reportedly having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the Rebar Asia Pacific Group before fleeing to China late last year and then to the United States early this year.

On Chiu's action, Bern Steves, an expert in international litigation services, said Wang's case involves a jurisdictional issue at the initial stage and it is too early to speculate whether the lawsuit against the Wangs will get to a U.S. court.

Steves warned that Wang's attorneys could ask the California High Court not to accept and hear the suit on the premise that none of the "crimes" that the Wangs were accused of had occurred in the United States.

Wang has been detained at a San Pedro immigration holding center for illegal entry into the United States since Feb. 2, when he tried to return to Los Angeles with both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports canceled, following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore.
Following a hearing on the Wang case held in mid-February, a next hearing is scheduled for March 6 or 7, although U.S. justice officials would not confirm the information.
The tycoon is wanted by Taiwanese authorities for his suspected involvement in a series of crimes, including forgery, fraud, insider trading, and embezzlement of corporate funds from his group.
The U.S. government has been asked by Taiwan law enforcement authorities to help extradite the Wangs as the two countries maintain a judicial cooperation pact.
Fifty-one people related to the Rebar scandal have been probed as suspects, 13 of whom have been detained. The number of people related to the case barred from leaving Taiwan has increased to 91.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES TAIWAN PEOPLE'S RIGHT TO FREE CHOICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Wednesday that only the people of Taiwan have the right to determine their country's future and the form of relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"In tandem with the spirit of popular sovereignty and the principle of democracy, nobody else can arbitrarily conclude that ultimate unification is the only available choice for the development of cross-strait relations," Chen said.

He made the remarks while receiving visiting U.S. Congressman Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) at the Presidential Office. Also present at the occasion was Stephen Young, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

During a Lunar New Year's Day gathering in his southern hometown in 2006, Chen unexpectedly announced his intention to cease the functioning of the National Unification Council (NUC) and the application of the National Unification Guidelines, both of which were created in the early 1990s when the pro- unification Kuomintang was in power. His announcement immediately drew strong reaction from the United States and China as they were skeptical whether Taiwan would move toward formal independence following the abolishment of the two symbols of Taiwan's commitment to eventual cross-strait unification.
To the best of his knowledge, Chen said, Young was concerned whether he would announce sensitive policy initiatives of a similar gravity during the current Lunar New Year festive season.

Chen said he had assured Young of "no surprise" this time around. "I have honored my promise. I just savored sweet dumplings and other festive snacks as well as exchanged New Year greetings with townsfolk during my homecoming visit three days ago. You can now take it easy and need not be in a stew any more," Chen told Young.

During the NUC dispute, Chen said Chabot didn't hesitate to throw support behind his decision. Calling Chabot "Taiwan's best friend and one of his dearest siblings, " Chen said he is grateful for his resolute support for Taiwan's cause. "Your generosity has helped us withstand hardships and challenges."

Claiming that he remains open and doesn't harbor any preset stance on the future development of cross-strati relations, Chen said what he insists is that only the 23 million Taiwan people have a final say on Taiwan's future.

"And this is why the NUC should cease to function and its guideline should cease to apply," Chen stressed, adding that his administration managed to do away with the NUC and its guidelines within one month following his revelation of his plan.

Touching on Taiwan-U.S. relations, Chen said he appreciates Chabot's ardent efforts to push for the signing of a bilateral free trade agreement between the two countries. It is hoped that both sides can continue working together to realize this goal, he added.
Chen further expressed his heartfelt gratitude for Chabot's call for the U.S. government to agree to senior Taiwanese officials' visits to major U.S. cities, including Washington, D.C.

"We also wholeheartedly admire and appreciate your courage to push the U.S. government to review its so-called 'one China' policy on the ground that the policy is outdated and unfit for today's situation as Taiwan has fully democratized," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI CALLS FOR IPR CAPITALIZATION TO BOOST BIOTECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan should promote capitalization and securitization of intellectual property rights (IPR) to rev up the development of the knowledge-based biotechnology industry, a researcher with the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) said Wednesday.

Lee Lien-tze, a research fellow at ITRI's Biomedical Engineering Research Laboratory, said the R&D-oriented biotechnology industry tends to require heavy capital investment over a long period of time to fruition.

Citing the pharmaceuticals industry, Lee said the overall time needed to develop and market a new drug could reach 10 years and the cost may hit US$1 billion. "Investment in this kind of industry is highly risky," he added.
Unlike the manufacturing-oriented electronic and information technology (IT) industries, Lee went on, the biotechnology industry is R&D-oriented and its manufacturing cost is comparatively low.

Against this backdrop, Lee said, the OEM formula commonly used in the IT industry cannot apply to the biotechnology industry. Any biotechnology company intending to adopt an OEM business strategy would face the predicament of "minimal profits and limited development potential," he added.

According to ACER Group founder Stan Shih's "Smiling Curve" theory, Lee said R&D is the most profitable sector of the pharmaceutical market and the most promising field for Taiwanese investors to explore.
The annual turnover of the global biomedical market reaches an estimated US$800 billion, of which sales of new pharmaceuticals account for about US$150 billion, Lee said.

To tap this lucrative market, Lee said Taiwan should step up IPR capitalization or securitization of patenting to offer easier access to needed R&D funds and accelerate the growth of local biotechnology industry.

Securitization is a financing technique that allows the corporation to separate credit origination and funding activities and can thereby convert illiquid assets into liquid assets to facilitate business operations and expansion.

In Stan Shih's "Smiling Curve" theory, the entire business or production process comprises three sectors -- R&D, manufacturing and marketing/services. According to Shih, the starting point or R&D and access to end users or marketing/service are the most profitable, while the manufacturing section is least lucrative.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 22, or the fifth day of the first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: Amerigo Vespucci, Italian navigator and "discoverer" of the South American coast, dies at the age of 58. America was named in his honor.
1732: George Washington, the first U.S. president, is born.
1784: The Empress of China, the first trading ship sent to China from the United States, sets sail from New York.
1788: Arthur Schopenhauer, German philosopher who saw the ideal state of man as one of contemplative freedom achieved through art, is born.
1810: Frederick Chopin, Polish-born French composer and pianist of the romantic era, is born. His music was noted chiefly for its expressiveness.
1857: Robert Baden-Powell, British hero of the siege of Mafeking in the Boer War and founder of the Boy Scouts, is born.
1819: Spain cedes the state of Florida to the United States.
1879: U.S. storekeeper Frank W. Woolworth, thinking centralized purchasing will help keep prices down and profits up, opens the new F.W. Woolworth Co. Five- and-Ten Cent Store in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
1924: Calvin Coolidge becomes the first U.S. president to broadcast from the White House.
1932: Edward Kennedy, U.S. senator and younger brother of John F. Kennedy, is born.
1934: Nicaraguan guerrilla leader General Augusto Sandino is executed by his rival, General Anastasio Somoza, commander of the National Guard.
1940: The 14th Dalai Lama is enthroned in Lhasa, Tibet.
1946: Dr. Selman Abrahams announces he has discovered streptomycin, an antibiotic which can be used to treat tuberculosis and bacterial infections.
1948: More than 20,000 students demonstrate against the Yalta Secret Agreement and call for the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from China.
1967: Indonesian President Sukarno announces the end of his rule and transfers political power to Gen. Suharto.
1967: U.S. forces and South Vietnamese troops launch Operation Junction City, attacking communist forces in Tayninh Province north of Saigon.
1973: Gordon T. Wallis, chairman of the Irving Trust Company of New York, arrives to open a Taipei branch.
1974: Minister of Finance K.T. Li, Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun and Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of finance and national economy, issue a joint communique on financial and economic cooperation.
1979: The Caribbean island of St. Lucia announces independence from Britain.
1990: The last statue of Joseph Stalin topples in Ulan Bator, capital of Mongolia.
1991: U.S. President George Bush gives Saddam Hussein 24 hours to quit Kuwait or face an all-out ground war against allied forces.
1993: The Taiwanese film "The Wedding Banquet" wins a Golden Bear Award for Best Picture at the 43rd Berlin International Film Festival.
1996: Russia and the International Monetary Fund reach a deal on a loan of more than US$10 billion.
1996: The French government announces the abolition of conscription and the adoption of a voluntary system for military service.
2000: Chien Wen-hui successfully receives a piece of his wife's liver in an operation performed at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung, marking the first wife-to-husband live-donor liver transplant ever conducted in Taiwan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian is accused of taking bribes from a Malaysian business tycoon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, study always as if you have not yet reached your goal and as though apprehensive of losing it."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES TAIWAN PEOPLE'S RIGHT TO FREE CHOICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Wednesday that only the people of Taiwan have the right to determine their country's future and the form of relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"In tandem with the spirit of popular sovereignty and the principle of democracy, nobody else can arbitrarily conclude that ultimate unification is the only available choice for the development of cross-strait relations," Chen said.

He made the remarks while receiving visiting U.S. Congressman Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) at the Presidential Office. Also present at the occasion was Stephen Young, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

During a Lunar New Year's Day gathering in his southern hometown in 2006, Chen unexpectedly announced his intention to cease the functioning of the National Unification Council (NUC) and the application of the National Unification Guidelines, both of which were created in the early 1990s when the pro- unification Kuomintang was in power. His announcement immediately drew strong reaction from the United States and China as they were skeptical whether Taiwan would move toward formal independence following the abolishment of the two symbols of Taiwan's commitment to eventual cross-strait unification.
To the best of his knowledge, Chen said, Young was concerned whether he would announce sensitive policy initiatives of a similar gravity during the current Lunar New Year festive season.

Chen said he had assured Young of "no surprise" this time around. "I have honored my promise. I just savored sweet dumplings and other festive snacks as well as exchanged New Year greetings with townsfolk during my homecoming visit three days ago. You can now feel relieved and need not be in a stew any more," Chen told Young.

During the NUC dispute, Chen said Chabot didn't hesitate to throw support behind his decision. Calling Chabot "Taiwan's best friend and my dearest brother, " Chen said he is grateful for Chabot's resolute support for Taiwan's cause. "Your generosity has helped us withstand hardships and challenges."

Claiming that he remains open and doesn't harbor any preset stance on the future development of cross-strati relations, Chen said what he insists is that only the 23 million Taiwan people have a final say on Taiwan's future.

"And this is why the NUC should cease to function and its guideline should cease to apply," Chen stressed, adding that his administration managed to do away with the NUC and its guidelines within one month following his revelation of his plan.

Touching on Taiwan-U.S. relations, Chen said he appreciates Chabot's ardent efforts to push for the signing of a bilateral free trade agreement between the two countries. It is hoped that both sides can continue working together to realize this goal, he added.
Chen further expressed his heartfelt gratitude for Chabot's call for the U.S. government to agree to senior Taiwanese officials' visits to major U.S. cities, including Washington, D.C.

"We also wholeheartedly admire and appreciate your courage to push the U.S. government to review its so-called 'one China' policy on the ground that the policy is outdated and unfit for today's situation as Taiwan has fully democratized," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOLAR POWER COMPANIES TO TAP MARKET IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will collaborate with local solar power technology companies to hold a forum on the photovaltaics (PV) industry in Osaka, Japan April 16-19 with the aim of helping Taiwanese enterprises explore foreign markets, a TAITRA official said Thursday.

Riding high on last year's success, the TAITRA, in conjunction with nine major Taiwanese PV companies, is planning to head for Japan to organize the forum titled "2007 Taiwan Photovoltaics Day", which will include a presentation and several one-to-one trade consultation meetings, the official added.

The marketing delegation, to be headed by Wang Han-lung, executive director of the Koyork Co., and Shih Hao-chun, deputy general manager of the Sino Silicon Technology Inc., will pay visits to Sharp and Kyocera Corps. in an attempt to forge strategic alliances between enterprises from the two countries, according to the official.

The participating companies will include Sino Silicon Technology Inc., Powercom Co., Mosel Vitelic Inc., NewcoreTek Co., Ablerex Electronics Co., Koyork Co., LightStar Technologies, Chai Tun Silk-Screen Printing Co., and High Light Tech. International Corp.

Japan is the largest supplier of PV products in the world, accounting for 41.9 percent of global output, the official said, adding that at present it is also the second largest market for PV products, next only to Germany, and the market is expected to increase annually by 12.3 percent from 2005 to 2025.
The official said that the TAITRA hopes the event will help Taiwan's PV enterprises keep abreast of the latest trends of Japanese PV industry and secure more commercial opportunities in that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTSTANDING ENERGY-SAVING COMPANIES TO BE AWARDED

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Energy will sponsor an energy conservation contest to promote efficient use of energy, a bureau official said Thursday.
According to the bureau's plan, 15 energy-efficient enterprises or institutions will be selected for public recognition in July.
Prospective applicants are welcome to register for the contest now through March 31, the official said.

Businesses or groups from both the public and private sector are invited to take part in the contest by submitting applications or through recommendations from related agencies, associations, governments, the Industrial Technology Research Institute or Taiwan Green Productivity Foundation, according to the official.

The selection will cover two categories -- manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries -- and will take into account industry-specific characteristics, the amount of energy consumption and carbon dioxide emissions.

A panel of judges consisting of energy saving experts and scholars is scheduled to choose the 15 enterprises best achieving sound performance in energy conservation after primary, secondary and final evaluation stages, the official noted, adding that the winners will each be awarded NT$ 300,000 (US$9,230) at a citation ceremony slated for July.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENEWABLE ENERGY TO COMPRISE 10% OF TOTAL CAPACITY BY 2010: MOEA

TEXT.P: The government has set a goal of increasing the output of renewable energies to contribute 10 percent of the nation's total electricity output by 2010, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

MOEA officials said Thursday that the 10% goal would require some 5.13 megawatts of electricity capacity, most of which would come from wind power -- with an estimate output of 2.15 megawatts by 2010.
Energy from hydropower, biofuels, and solar power would fill the remaining supply gap, they said.

According to MOEA, taking into account the fluctuations inherent in wind power, by 2010 that output might result in the generation of 5.74 billion kilowatt- hours per year, translating into a market value of NT$11.48 billion.
Moreover, the annual energy output from wind power would be the equivalent to that generated by 1.43 million kiloliters of oil.
Wind power facilities could also help eliminate the emission of some 3.45 million tons of carbon dioxide, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL TRADE VALUE TOPS US$12.58 BILLION: COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's 2006 agricultural trade was valued at US$12.58 billion, a decrease of 2.75 percent from the year-earlier level, according to a statistical report released by the Council of Agriculture (COA) Thursday.
The COA report was based on its analysis of 2006 agricultural import and export data provided by the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, a COA spokesman said.

The report shows that the island's 2006 agricultural imports totaled US$9.28 billion, showing a slight year-on-year decrease of 0.77 percent; the island's agricultural exports reached US$3.3 billion, making a significant decrease of 7.91 percent. As a result the overall agricultural trade deficit increased US$211 million to reach the total of US$5.98 billion.

The spokesman said the island's main agricultural imports are corn, tobacco, soybean, cotton, frozen beef, milk powder, and broad leaf material. Main agricultural exports include frozen tuna, feathers, frozen bonita, eel, wool, pigskin, frozen mouthbreeder and frozen squid.

The value of Taiwan's frozen tuna exports decreased by US$300 million because the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) largely cut Taiwan's 2006 quota for bigeye tuna in November 2005, and Taiwan's take of yellowfin tuna in the Indian Ocean slumped. But as the ICCAT has reinstated Taiwan's 2007 quota for bigeye tuna, its exports value is expected to rise in the year to come.

The main source of agricultural imports to Taiwan in 2006 were the United States, Australia, Japan, Malaysia, and China; the main destinations for exports were Japan, Hong Kong, China, and the United States, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIOFUEL SUPPLIES TO BE AVAILABLE IN 2 CITIES BY JUNE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is expected to reach the second stage of its biofuel development scheme by June 2007, supplying B1 biodiesel to two cities, government officials said Thursday.

The two cities, which are yet to be selected, will have biodiesel supplied to all gas stations within the city limits, with the more expensive biodiesel sold at the same price of normal diesel, thanks to MOEA subsides.
Biodiesel is classified according to the amount of ethanol mixed into the diesel. For example, diesel containing 1 percent ethanol is B1 biodiesel, while B2 biodiesel has a 2 percent ethanol content.
Biofuel development scheme aims to lead biofuels into local people's everyday live, they said.
The first stage was implemented last January by mandating that all 428 buses in Kaohsiung City begin using B1 biodiesel, MOEA officials said.
The MOEA will obligate all filling stations in Taiwan to offer B1 biodiesel by 2008 in the third stage, while in the fourth stage, the biodiesel supplies will be upgraded to B2 biodiesel by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 BIOTECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY OUTPUT VALUED OVER NT$177 BILLION: IDB

TEXT.P: Local biotechnology industry's 2006 turnover reached an estimated NT$177.2 billion (US$5.37 billion) , marking an 11 percent year-on-year rise, an Industrial Development Bureau spokesman said Thursday.

Of the amount, NT$65 billion came from the pharmaceutical sector, NT$43.2 billion belonged to emerging sectors of the biotechnology industry, and NT$69 billion came from the medical device industry which grew rapidly with help from Taiwan's information-technology industry, the spokesman said.

The preliminary statistics also show that over the past five years the yearly growth rate of the island's biotechnology industry reaches an average of 12 percent. Annual investment in the industry has remained above NT$20 billion since 2001, and increased to 25.3 billion in 2005. The 2006 amount was estimated to be NT$21.013 billion.

The spokesman pointed out that biotechnology was a part of the "two trillion, twin star" plan. The government set up dozens of incubation centers to nurture biotechnology companies, and plans to establish several technology parks to bring the benefits of the clustering effect to this industry.

The government's three policies to improve the island's competence in this industrial sector include introducing foreign pharmaceutical factories to Taiwan, availing the industry of advantages derived from the electronic and chemical industries to produce more and better products, and expanding the international market for Taiwan's medicines.

The spokesman said that in order to help make Taiwan a powerhouse in the industry, the government established a number of goals, including realizing investment of approximately NT$150 billion by 2008, achieving a 25 percent yearly revenue growth rate, establishing more than 500 biotech companies within 10 years, and having 18 successful companies in this industry by 2010, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER DENIES CHINA VISIT REPORT

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday a newspaper report about his plan to visit China in March is not factual.
Wang, who is widely seen as a potential candidate in the 2008 presidential election, made the denial during a community outreach visit to offshore Penghu County.
"I have long worked on a China travel plan, but the timing has not yet been ripe to make such a visit, " Wang said, adding that he is still waiting for an opportune time to realize such a plan.

Wang was responding to a China Times report that Wang would visit China in March in his capacity as the head of Taiwan's top legislative body. According to the Chinese-language newspaper, Wang would meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao during his Beijing visit.
Wang, a former vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said the report "deviates from truth."

The report came a week after a Taiwan prosecutor filed corruption charges against former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, prompting Ma to quit his post as KMT chairman. Ma has formally announced his bid for the 2008 presidency.
Asked whether he would declare his candidacy for the KMT primary for the 2008 presidential election after the current Lunar New Year holiday, Wang said he is still pondering the issue.
"I think I need to solicit opinions and views from various social quarters and grassroots groups before I come to a decision on whether to throw my hat in the ring," Wang said.

The legislative speaker said his visit to Penghu is part of his grass roots outreach activities during the Lunar New Year holiday. At noon, he had a lunch meeting with volunteer firefighters in the Penghu area in his capacity as the head of the national volunteer firefighting corps.

In the company of Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa and other local political figures, Wang visited the county's popular temples to pray for national well-being. Later in the day, he visited the county government and county council on foot, receiving a warm welcome from crowds of local residents along the way.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHANOL GASOLINE TO BE USED BY GOVERNMENT VEHICLES IN TAIPEI CITY

TEXT.P: Government vehicles in Taipei City will switch to using E3 ethanol gasoline within this year on a trial basis, officials at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.
They said the ethanol gasoline will be supplied to these vehicles at specific state-owned CPC Corp., Taiwan gas stations.

By 2009, the ethanol gasoline will be available in several other major cities in Taiwan, and filling stations all around the island will make available both normal and ethanol gasoline by 2011, according to the MOEA.

E3 ethanol gasoline is composed of 97 percent gasoline and 3 percent ethanol. Countries of the European Union have been using E85 ethanol gasoline, while E93 has been introduced on the market in Brazil.

Although ethanol mixed fuels can help reduce dependency on fossil fuels and diminish emissions of greenhouse gases, MOEA officials noted that ethanol can erode fuel tanks and limit driving performance -- factors which can only be offset by future improvements.

Citing a previous survey, MOEA officials said that 1.17 million cars, or 80 percent of all cars made after 2001, are adaptive to ethanol gasoline. However, cars made before 2001 must be tested to determine whether they can use ethanol- blended fuels.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S NAME RECTIFICATION CAMPAIGN NOT U.S. CONCERN: CONGRESSMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/22/07 21:51:59 (By Lin Chiehyu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Congressman Tom Tancredo has sent a letter to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice criticizing what he called the State Department's overreaction to Taiwan's "name rectification" efforts.

In his Feb. 20 letter to Rice, Rep. Tancredo writes: "First, it is rather difficult to understand how a decision about what the name of a local business might be in Taiwan is any of the State Department's concern. Second, for the State Department to equate the renaming of a gas station with a change Taiwan's international status is, to say the least, rather puzzling."

Tancredo was referring to Taiwan's recent decision to rename three of its state- owned enterprises to get rid of Chinese reference in their titles and add the word "Taiwan" to make them more identifiable with their country of origin and avoid confusion with similarly named Chinese counterparts.

Referring to China's passage of the anti-secession law in 2005, Rep. Tancredo writes: "Clearly, this act represented a change in the "status quo" - yet the strongest and most direct rebuke to China that State Department spokesman Richard Boucher could muster was "[W]e think it's important for both sides to focus on dialogue." The best then-White House spokesman Scott McClellan could do at the time was to characterize the law as "unhelpful."

The congressman concludes: "We often hear that the State Department is concerned about unilateral actions by either China or Taiwan that might change the 'status quo.' In practice, however, the department seems more than willing to criticize Taiwan's leaders (often for quite trivial things) , yet very reluctant to rebuke the leadership in Beijing."

Tancredo is a member of the U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus, a Taiwan-friendly subgroup in the House of Representatives. He has promoted many bills in U.S. Congress in support of Taiwan's cause in the past few years.

Meanwhile, C.T. Lee, president of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, a Washington-based non-profit organization dedicated to promote international support for Taiwan's cause, echoed Tancredo's view, saying the State Department reaction to Taiwan's "name rectification" campaign is an irony.

Lee said in a written statement that reads: "State Department guidelines over the past decade clearly state that U.S. officials can and may not refer to Taiwan as the "Republic of China" - only "Taiwan" - since the United States and Taiwan do not maintain diplomatic relations. (E.g. Taiwan Relations Act, American Institute in Taiwan, Taiwan desk a the State Department etc...) Now Taiwan no longer uses "China" but starts using "Taiwan, " and the State Department criticizes Taiwan for that! It is the ultimate irony!"

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW WTO DEPUTY REPRESENTATIVE TO ASSUME POST
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/22/07 22:15:17 (By P.C. Tang and Y.L.Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's outgoing deputy representative to the European Union and Belgium will soon leave for Geneva to assume his new post as deputy representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Wei Ko-ming, a seasoned trade negotiator who once served as deputy head of the Board of Foreign Trade, will depart Brussels Friday, ending his more than four years of stint as Taiwan's second highest-ranking official stationed in the E.U. and Belgium.
Wei is no stranger to WTO affairs as he was deeply involved in negotiations for Taiwan's WTO accession during his tenure as deputy director of the Board of Foreign Trade.
Wei will fill the post left vacant by John C. Deng who has been serving as Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States since late last June.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPEFUL VOWS TO USE NEW THINKING TO TACKLE CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday he will use new thinking to address the deadlocked relations across the Taiwan Strait if he manages to win the 2008 presidential election.
Yu, who served as premier between 2002 and 2005, made the remarks after announcing his decision to run in the DPP primary for the 2008 presidential election earlier in the day.
Noting that a country's head of state must be resolute and visionary, Yu said he believes he is the best person to move Taiwan forward.
While upholding Taiwan's core values, Yu said he will adopt new thinking and innovative strategy to break the lingering cross-strait limbo for the sake of national security and stability.
Yu is the second DPP bigwig to throw his hat in the ring after another former premier, Frank Hsieh, declared his candidacy for the DPP presidential primary last Friday.
To ensure electoral fairness, Yu said he will apply for a leave of absence from the DPP chairmanship after he formally registers for the party primary.

As to his running mate, Yu said he has yet to ponder the issue. Asked whether he is likely to serve as other DPP aspirant's running mate, Yu said since he has declared his intention to join the presidential race, he will not give a thought to such a possibility for the moment.
Yu announced his bid during a visit to the Taoist Tingan Temple in Tungshan township in northeastern Yilan County where he served as magistrate for two terms from 1989-1997.
"I choose to make the important announcement in Yilan because friends in my homeland have always been my best support throughout my political career," Yu said.
Registration for the DPP presidential primary will be open from March 5-9, according to a timetable passed by the party's Central Standing Committee last Wednesday.

Party members will vote on both presidential and legislative hopefuls May 6, after which public opinion polls will be held. The votes of party members are weighted to comprise 30 percent of a would-be candidate's score, while the public opinion poll counts for 70 percent. The presidential aspirant who receives the highest approval rating will be named as the party's presidential candidate May 30.
It remains to be seen whether or when another two DPP heavyweights -- Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Su Tseng-chang -- will announce their presidential bid.
In the opposition camp, only former Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has thrown his hat in the ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY MUST NOT UNDERMINE NATIONAL DIGNITY

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential aspirants said Thursday they would not oppose the inclusion of Taiwan into the relay of the 2008 Beijing Olympic Torch so long as Taiwan's national sovereignty and dignity will not be undermined or compromised.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh, both of who have thrown their hat in the ring for the DPP primary for the 2008 presidential election, made the remarks after a local newspaper reported the same day that the Beijing Olympic Torch is very likely relayed through Taiwan.

Noting that the Olympic Torch has traditionally been relayed through major countries around the world before it reaches the host country shortly before the opening day of the Olympic Games, Yu said if Taiwan is not regarded as a local government in the event, he will welcome the inclusion of the Taiwan leg in the Beijing Olympic Torch relay. Otherwise, Yu said he couldn't support the arrival of the torch.
Hsieh echoed Yu's views, saying that he would throw his support behind the arrival of the Beijing Olympic Torch provided that Taiwan's national status and dignity remain intact in the relay.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 23, or the sixth day of the first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1743: Meyer Rothschild, a German banker who founded a bank at
Frankfurt am Main, is born. His sons, most notably Salomon and Nathan Meyer, established branches of the bank throughout Europe.
1792: Sir Joshua Reynold, British painter and first president of
the Royal Academy, dies at the age of 69. He is considered one of the most important figures in the history of English painting.
1836: The siege of the Alamo begins in San Antonio, Texas. The siege ended March 6 with all the Texans killed by Mexican troops.
1848: John Quincy Adams, the sixth president of the United
States, who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine, dies at the age of 81.
1863: British explorers John Speke and J.A. Grant announce that they have "discovered" Lake Victoria to be the source of the Nile.
1898: Emile Zola, the French writer and critic who was a leading
proponent of naturalism in fiction, is imprisoned for the publication of his letter "J'accuse, " which accused the French government of anti-Semistism and of wrongly imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
1905: Paul P. Harris, a lawyer in Chicago, establishes Rotary International. There are now about 24,500 Rotary clubs in 167 countries, with about 1.1 million members.
1906: Johann Hoch is imprisoned in Chicago for murdering six of
his 13 wives.
1924: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United
States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at the age of 68. His administration was marked by World War I and the introduction of prohibition.
1933: Japanese forces occupy Chinese territory north of the Great
Wall of China.
1942: Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States sign
the Master Mutual Aid Agreement.
1942: A Japanese submarine shells an oil refinery near Santa
Barbara, California.
1944: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Chechen republic and forces 1
million Chechens into exile, accusing them of collaboration with Nazi Germany.
1945: U.S. Marines plant the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi of Iwo Jima, a strategic island 750 miles from Tokyo, after 74 days of bombardment and four days of a bitter ground battle.
1955: The first meeting of the Southeast Asian Treaty
Organization (SEATO) is held in Bangkok, Thailand.
1957: Republic of China Major-General Chiang Wei-kuo weds Helene B. Chiu in Tokyo, Japan.
1958: Taiwan's first Cobalt 60 medical instrument for treating
cancer arrives in Keelung from the United States.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Cameroon.
1969: Chang Chun-li, chairman of the China Democratic Socialist
Party, dies in San Francisco at the age of 83.
1970: British Guinea ends its association with Britain and sets
up the Republic of Guyana.
1976: The Association of East Asian Relations and Japan's
Interchange Association open a two-day economic and trade conference.
1990: Prince Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 11 years in
exile.
1991: The National Unification Council holds its fifth meeting
and passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which are now the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. Its long-term goal is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1991: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhaven is arrested
after the armed forces seize power in a bloodless coup.
1995: U.S. President Bill Clinton voices support for a united Canada in a speech to Canada's parliament.
1997: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to Article 4
of the February 28 Incident Disposition and Compensation Act, stipulating that February 28, named "Peace Memorial Day," be deemed a national holiday.
2000: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang
adopts a proposal that Adolfo Sun should succeed Kuo Kang to become the ROC's ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How toweringly high and surpassingly great in moral grandeur was the way by which the ancient Emperors Shun and Yu came to the government of the Empire, and yet they themselves were unconscious of it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
NEW KAOHSIUNG DEPUTY MAYOR VOWS TO WORK TO BOOST ECONOMY

TEXT.P: New Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san expressed Friday that boosting the economy of the southern port city, attracting investment, and luring more tourists are his three most "urgent tasks" in his new position which he assumed two months ago.

Chiu, who holds a master's degree in law from National Taiwan University, had served as a prosecutor, a lawyer, a legislator and vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council before he was appointed by Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu to serve as her deputy.

As a professional in the field of law, as well as finance and economics, Chiu has been commissioned to work to boost the economy of the country's second largest city, which also has the island's largest port.
"At the very least, I'm expected to prevent Kaohsiung's economy from becoming a target of criticism," Chiu told reporters.

Chiu said he thinks one of the urgent tasks is to attract investment in local enterprises in Kaohsiung, adding that local industries should be upgraded and developed with local characteristics as part of efforts to maintain their competitiveness.
He further said that he wants to develop the port city into a "city of hope," where investors like to stay on.

Noting that tourism is also important to Kaohsiung's economy, Chiu said he hopes that the city can become the last stop on the itinerary of visitors touring attractions in central, eastern and southern Taiwan, such as Alishan in Chiayi County, Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County, and the Taroko National Park in Hualien County.
"Last night in Kaohsiung" will be the slogan for the city to develop tourism, Chiu said, adding that he hopes that tourists will also indulge in the pleasant experience of shopping in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO PAY HEED TO GROWING CHINESE CURRENCY STASH IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The government should pay heed to the possible adverse impact on the efficacy of its monetary policy of the growing Chinese currency stash in Taiwan, an economist said Friday.
Hung Tsai-lung, a research fellow with the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said local people may have amassed a total of more than 100 billion Chinese yuan over the past several years.

The accumulation of Chinese currency in Taiwan can be attributed to a combination of factors, including China's chronic trade deficit with Taiwan and the inclination of Taiwan businesspeople operating in China to bring home Chinese yuan, Hung said.

In March 2004, Taiwan's central bank began to allow each local citizen to bring in up to 6,000 yuan per homecoming visit, and the amount was raised to 20,000 yuan in October 2005. According to an estimate by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, local people have made a total of more than 12 million visits to China over the past three years.

"If each China-bound visitor brings home 6,000 yuan per visit, then that would mean about 72 billion yuan has been brought into the country over the past three years, " Hung said, adding that the total domestic yuan stash probably exceeds 100 billion if the Chinese currency brought in before 2004, including earnings from illegal trade deals between fishing boats from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, is taken into account.

As Taiwan may soon fully open its doors to Chinese tourists, Hung said, the domestic Chinese yuan stash may increase further. Noting that Chinese yuan still cannot be converted into local currency freely, Hung said the government should not ignore the possible negative effects of the yuan hoarding in Taiwan.

"Money laundering and banknote counterfeiting that could arise from the influx of yuan onto the black market may only be trivial matters compared with a possible resulting strain on the domestic currency circulation due to financial authorities' inability to get real-time monetary market information," Hung said.

Worse still, Hung said, the current ban on Chinese yuan conversion would hobble Taiwanese businesspeople's funding operations and consequently discourage them from remitting their earnings back to Taiwan from China.

Hung suggested that the government step up efforts to sign a cross-strait agreement on the establishment of a cash settlement mechanism. If such a mechanism cannot be formulated in the near future, he said, Taiwan should unilaterally open free Chinese yuan conversion through selected banking institutions.
"By so doing, we'll be able to properly resolve the issues arising from rapid accumulation of the Chinese currency in Taiwan, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN STUDENTS TO STUDY AT ACADEMIA SINICA

TEXT.P: Two students from Guru Gobind Singh Indraprastha University in Delhi, India are slated to head to Taiwan this June for a study program, the university's school of Basic & Applied Sciences director Avinash C. Sharma said Thursday.

The two students pursuing master's degrees in physical engineering will study at the Taipei-based Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institution, under a program aimed at promoting various academic exchanges between the Indian university and the Taiwan institution, Sharma said.
Two teachers from the university are also slated to visit Academia Sinica this July, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BACKLOG OF CASES BUILDS AS CONTROL YUAN SEATS REMAIN UNFILLED

TEXT.P: More than 24,000 cases have piled up at the office of the Control Yuan, which has not been operating since Feb. 1, 2005 because of the opposition-controlled legislature's refusal to endorse President Chen Shui-bian's nominees for seats in the country's supreme watchdog body.

According to Control Yuan administrative staff, 40,000-plus cases were filed with the watchdog body between February 2005 and January 2007, including petitions from ordinary citizens, public functionaries' assets disclosure reports, and cases involving conflict of interests and political contributions.

Some of these cases have been addressed in accordance with a package of expedient measures approved by former Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, but more than 24,000 cases remain in backlog because they can only be investigated and tackled by Control Yuan members.

Over the past two years, a Control Yuan administrator said, a spate of high- profile scandals and irregularities have caused widespread concern about official corruption and deterioration of business ethics.

Those cases include sales of pork products from sick and dead hogs, illegal money lending and leaks of confidential personnel data in the military, controversies surrounding the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit construction project, "stock vulture" insider trading, prosecutorial coverup of drug trafficking, and ethical problems involving judicial personnel.

With no Control Yuan members available to probe whether any government official should be held responsible for dereliction of duty or violation of law in those cases, the Control Yuan administrator said, people's trust in the government has been affected.

Moreover, the official said, 67 cases involving censure or punishment of individual government employees are pending approval of Control Yuan members. "Any delay in finalizing probes into those cases is unfair to all those involved," he added.

The absence of Control Yuan members has had an even more serious result, namely inaction on suspected infractions in assets disclosure reports by public office holders as well as cases involving conflict of interests and irregularities in political donations, the official said, adding that the inaction is like offering "a legal break" to those who violate various "sunshine laws" designed to promote clean politics.
The official also lamented the large backlog of petitions filed by individual citizens over alleged infringements on human rights or personal property rights.

Noting that the International Ombudsman Institute (IOI) is one of the few international organizations that Taiwan has been admitted to under its official title -- the Republic of China, the official said Taiwan has missed three IOI meetings over the past two years because of the absence of Control Yuan members. According to the official, China has repeatedly tried, although in vain, to have Taiwan expelled from the organization.

Claiming that the Control Yuan has been incapacitated by the Legislative Yuan's refusal to exercise its power of consent to the president's nominations to the watchdog body, the official said the memberless Control Yuan poses an "unprecedented strange phenomenon in the country's constitutional history."

It is keenly hoped that all the Control Yuan seats can be filled as early as possible to resume the watchdog body's normal operations in addressing individual citizens' petitions and grievances, protecting their legitimate rights and interests, as well as correcting wrongdoings of government agencies and individual officials, and supervising operations of law enforcement officers.

President Chen has agreed to redraw a list of nominees for the Control Yuan seats and asked various political parties to recommend qualified candidates. But the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, which holds a slim majority in the legislature, has so far given a lukewarm response to Chen's call.
With no signs of reconciliation between the ruling and opposition camps in sight, it remains unclear when the Control Yuan will resume normal operations, the analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL URGES WASHINGTON TO LEARN ABOUT 228 INCIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/23/07 18:15:30 (By Chiehyu Lin & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A former U.S. official urged Washington Thursday to acquaint itself well with the history of the 228 Incident of 1947 in Taiwan, saying he believes that doing so will be helpful for the U.S. government in forming its Taiwan policy.

Randy Schriver, former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs responsible for China, Taiwan, Mongolia and Hong Kong, made the call at a workshop on the 228 Incident. The workshop was co-organized by the Brookings Institution, a prestigious think tank in the U.S. capital, and the Washington-headquartered Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA).

Schriver and Peng Ming-min, a renowned Taiwanese scholar on international law and one of the leaders of Taiwan's independence movement, were invited to attend the workshop hosted by Richard C. Bush, director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution and former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan.

Schriver said that the 228 Incident has profoundly affected Taiwan's political and cultural development, suggesting that policymakers in Washington study the history of the incident which led to the deaths of around 30,000 people.

The 228 Incident was sparked by a skirmish on Feb. 28, 1947, in which Monopoly Bureau officials who tried to confiscate smuggled cigarettes in Taipei caused injury to a woman vendor and the death of an innocent bystander, prompting mass demonstrations and clashes all over Taiwan between locals and mainland Chinese. Nationalist government troops moved into Taiwan March 8 and began a brutal crackdown.

Schriver said he believes the fact that the U.S. government has never really understood how important the historic event is to Taiwan has affected the judgment of its policymakers on the Taiwan issue.
Making efforts to learn about the tragic event will help the United States in evaluating the political situation in Taiwan and mapping out its Taiwan policy, he said.

The U.S. will be able to better understand the historic meaning behind the current "name rectification" movement promoted by Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Schriver said, adding that he supports the move to declassify the documents concerning the 228 Incident, which have been kept confidential for more than half a century. He added the family members of victims of the 228 Incident have the right of access to information concerning the death of their loved ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISTS SURE TO BE DRAWN TO TAICHUNG CITY: TOURISM OPERATOR

TEXT.P: With scores of attractive specialities, facilities and a fun nightlife in Taichung City, Chinese tourists are sure to be attracted to the central Taiwan city and give the local economy a boost, a tourism operator said Friday.

The tourism operator made the remarks in response to the recent claim by Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, that the planned full opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists is an established policy of the government.

Although Taichung City is short of natural scenic spots, the city's special delicacies, colorful nightlife, department stores, shopping malls, pubs, gourmet restaurants, and many five-star restaurants, as well as the National Museum of Natural Science and the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts are sure to please Chinese tourists who stopover in the city en route to two must-see natural scenic spots, namely Mount Ali in southern Chiayi County and Sun Moon Lake in central Nantou County, the tourism operator said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPATS IN U.S. TO 'MARCH FOR TAIWAN'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/23/07 20:09:15 (By Chiehyu Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Representatives from over 30 Taiwanese groups based on the east coast of the United States will kick off a five-day "March for Taiwan" activity Saturday to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident, organizers said Thursday.

Participants in the activity will jog or walk on the 150-mile journey from the starting point at the Independence Hall in Philadelphia to Independence Avenue in Washington, D.C., according to the organizers.

On the sidelines, a series of memorial activities, including speeches and concerts, will be held in Washington, D.C. to commemorate the 228 Incident of 1947, in which thousands of Taiwanese elite were massacred by Kuomintang (KMT) government troops in the initial stages of the KMT's authoritarian rule in Taiwan.
David Lee, Taiwan's top liaison official stationed in the United States, is scheduled to give a speech Feb. 24 in the U.S. capital in commemoration of the victims of the 228 Incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PAYS RESPECTS TO LATE DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that it is a positive thing that many within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are keen on bidding to represent the party in the next presidential election.

The president made the remarks after visiting the tomb of Huang Hsin-chieh in Taipei County's Pali township to pay his respects to the late chairman of the DPP, whom he said was his life-long mentor who led him along the path into politics. Accompanying Chen on the visit was Vice President Annette Lu.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun announced his bid Thursday to run in the party's primary for the 2008 presidential election, becoming the second DPP heavyweight to do so. Former Premier Frank Hsieh was the first to throw his hat in the ring, announcing last Friday that he would run in the party's primary next month.
The two other DPP heavyweights -- Vice President Lu and Premier Su Tseng-chang -- have yet to make an announcement on whether they will also run.
After visiting Huang's tomb Friday, Chen spoke of his own experience to represent the party in the 2000 presidential election.

"It's all about fate, " the president said, noting that before 2000, he had only thought about running for re-election as Taipei mayor in 1998. Ma Ying-jeou defeated Chen in the mayoral election that year and went on to serve as mayor for two terms before stepping down in December 2006.
"If you're destined to get the post, then you'll be able to overcome the major difficulties ahead, even if your chances may look slim," Chen said.
He said he is gratified to see so many capable people within the party keen to represent the party in the presidential election, adding that "as long as there is competition, there is progress."
The president also said that he hopes for a "gentlemen's battle" among the party's hopefuls in the primary.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT EXPECTED TO ELECT NEW CHAIRMAN NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) is expected to elect a new chairman in the middle of April to lead the party, KMT Acting Chairman Wu Po-hsiung said Friday.

Wu expressed the hope that a new chairman can be elected by that time and said that party unity is his top concern at this juncture when the KMT is gearing up to choose its candidates for December's legislative elections and to hold a primary to select its candidate for the 2008 presidential election.

Asked by reporters whether he will vie for the post of KMT chairman, to be elected in a direct vote by the party's members, Wu said that he is not considering the matter right now, pointing out that his top priority now is reinforcing party unity.

Wu, a KMT first vice chairman, has been serving as the acting chairman in accordance with the party's regulations following Ma Ying-jeou's resignation from the post Feb. 13 after Ma was indicted on corruption charges earlier the same day for his alleged misuse of a special municipal allowance fund during his two terms as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

Ma also announced his presidential bid that same day, making him a possible rival of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng within the party, who is also expected to announce soon his bid to seek to represent the KMT in the next presidential election.
Wang made it clear later Saturday in southern Kaohsiung county that he has no plans to run for the post of KMT chairman and praised Wu as a good candidate for the party's chairmanship.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:U.S. Used Base in Ethiopia to Hunt Al Qaeda in Africa
The American military quietly waged a campaign from Ethiopia last month to capture or kill top leaders of Al Qaeda in the Horn of Africa, including the use of an airstrip in eastern Ethiopia to mount airstrikes against Islamic militants in neighboring Somalia, according to American officials.
The close and largely clandestine relationship with Ethiopia also included significant sharing of intelligence on the Islamic militants positions and information from American spy satellites with the Ethiopian military. Members of a secret American Special Operations unit, Task Force 88, were deployed in Ethiopia and Kenya, and ventured into Somalia, the officials said.
Wall Street Journal:For Snowboarders, A Colorado SchoolIs Just the Ticket
Like several of his classmates, Zeppelin Zeerip, a lanky, soft-spoken 14-year- old, sports a stocking cap, sagging jeans and a broken bone. He fractured his collarbone when he fell in practice, and before that he broke his arm.
Sitting a few desks away in history class are teenagers with arms in slings. In the cafeteria, crutches lean against round tables. At times, as many as a fourth of the 67 students at Crested Butte Academy are nursing sprains and breaks. Here, in this picturesque mountain town of about 1,500, a cast or knee brace is often a sign of daring, not failure.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO MARK MAY 15 AS 'NATIONAL FAMILY DAY' FROM 2008

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will begin in 2008 an annual national campaign, marking May 15 as "National Family Day" in a drive to promote parenthood education, MOE officials said Friday.

With the planned "National Family Day" campaign, the MOE hopes to assist people in efforts to organize a "healthy and happy" family, the officials said, indicating that during this year, the MOE will first work to promote 10 major related programs with the cooperation of family education centers in cities and counties around the country.

The programs cover education for the parents of newborns, and those of pre- school children, elementary schoolchildren or teenagers, as well as educational assistance to certain families, including single-parent families, families with members who are physically or mentally challenged, and families of new immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VISITS NURSING HOME FOR RETIRED SERVICEMEN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang took time during the Chinese New Year holidays to pay a visit to a nursing home for veterans in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan Friday.
During his visit, the premier played snooker with some of the veterans and wished them prosperity in the Year of Pig.

Su, widely considered a strong contender within the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to represent the party in the 2008 presidential election, was tightlipped when asked about when he is going to announce his bid to enter the race.
Instead, he said that his primary concern is to do his job well in order to "live up to the expectations of the public."

Meanwhile, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, who announced Thursday that he will take part in the party's primary for the next presidential election, said that he will do everything he can to win the party's nomination.

"I have not considered the question of who would be my partner on the ticket for the presidential election if I were to win the primary, nor have I considered whether I would join another winner of the primary on a ticket," Yu said.
He made the remarks while paying a visit to a temple in Tainan, southern Taiwan, where he distributed red envelops containing cash to wellwishers.
Yu said that Taiwan is moving along the path of freedom and democracy but that it has yet to become a "normal country."

He touted himself as the one who can best lead Taiwan out of its difficulties to move forward and also the one who insists most on "Taiwan-centric consciousness" and who is closest to the "grassroots" public.
During a visit to the Taiwan Society, a local pro-independence group, later the same day, Yu also spoke of his campaign platform of "making Taiwan into a normal country within a decade."
Yu said that he personally thinks becoming a "normal country" involves rectification of the nation's official designation and the crafting of a "timely, relevant and viable" constitution.

Other elements involved in making Taiwan into a normal country will include gaining membership in the United Nations, establishing a sufficient self-defense capability, and building a sound economy to compete with other nations around the world.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Feb. 24
