DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 24, or the seventh day of the first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Charles V, the Holy Roman emperor and King of Spain as Charles I, who summoned the Diet of Worms and the Council of Trent, is born.
1815: Robert Fulton, the American engineer who developed the first useful submarine and torpedo and invented the steamboat, dies at the age of 50.
1868: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, becomes the first president to have impeachment proceedings brought against him by the House of Representatives. He was acquitted by one vote.
1885: Chester Nimitz, American admiral of the Pacific Fleet during World War II, is born. He halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers.
1891: The Ching court pays an indemnity to Russia for the return of Ili Valley in northwest China.
1909: The world's first color movie is shown in England.
1920: The Nazi Party, or the National Socialist German Workers Party, announces its program to set up the Third Reich.
1920: American-born Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in Britain's House of Commons.
1933: The League of Nations votes 40 to one to pass a resolution refusing to recognize "Manchukuo," a puppet regime installed by the Japanese in China. Japan walks out of the international organization after the vote.
1945: U.S. forces liberate Manila from Japanese occupation.
1945: Ahmed Maher Pasha, premier of Egypt, is shot dead in parliament just after declaring war on the Axis powers.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1948: The Labor Union of Taiwan Province is established.
1950: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting in Taipei.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular rather than in the classical style, dies in Taipei at the age of 72.
1966: Ghana's President Kwame Nkrumah is overthrown in an army coup while he is visiting communist China. He was forced into exile in the Republic of Guinea.
1968: U.S. and South Vietnamese troops recapture the old Vietnamese imperial city of Hue after a fierce battle.
1969: A passenger plane of Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes in Kuijen village, Tainan County, killing all 36 people on board.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Malta.
1974: Pakistan officially recognizes Bangladesh as an independent nation.
1976: A nine-member economic mission of Japan's Sankei Shimbun newspaper led by Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the newspaper, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: U.S. President Jimmy Carter cuts off U.S. aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia because of human rights violations.
1978: Construction of the first-phase of the Taiwan Railway Administration's railway electrification project is completed and opened to traffic.
1989: Funeral rites for Japanese Emperor Hirohito, who had reigned since 1926, are held in Tokyo. His son, Akihito, becomes the new emperor.
1990: Malcolm Forbes, American tycoon, escort of Elizabeth Taylor and owner of "Forbes Magazine," dies.
1997: A fire at a Hindu pilgrim encampment in eastern India claims more than 200 lives and injures over 500 people.
2000: Chung Jung-chi, a minister without portfolio and a key member of the Kuomintang's election machine, announces his resignation from public office and also from the party in a "consciousness-raising" move.
2004: A Taiwan-developed hybrid car powered by an internal combustion engine and an electric motor is unveiled.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not now see a man who can love moral worth in man as he loves beauty in woman."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S NEW DEPUTY REP TO WTO ASSUMES OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Switzerland, Feb. 23 (CNA) 02/24/07 14:18:24 (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new deputy representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) assumed office Friday.
Almost immediately after taking up his new post, Wei Ko-ming began work on matters concerning the Doha Development Round of WTO negotiations, which aims to lower trade barriers around the world.

Wei, a seasoned trade negotiator who once served as deputy head of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) , is no stranger to WTO affairs as he was deeply involved in negotiations for Taiwan's WTO accession during his tenure as BOFT deputy director.

Before coming to Geneva, Wei served as Taiwan's deputy representative to the European Union and Belgium. During his more than four years serving in the post, Wei made contributions to efforts to promote Taiwan's trade and economic relations with the European Union and Belgium.
Wei was appointed last September to fill the post left vacant by John C. Deng, who has been serving as Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States since late last June.

DOC.HEADLINE: FTZ TRADE REACHES US$455 MILLION FOR 2006

TEXT.P: Total trade at Taiwan's five free trade zones (FTZs) reached NT$15 billion (US$455 million) for 2006, an encouraging figure that has led the government to take more active steps to try to attract more foreign investment in the FTZs, the vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development said Saturday.

Yeh Ming-feng revealed that relevant officials, including those at the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, have been working together to come up with new incentives to attract businesses to invest in the FTZs.

The planned incentives will target businesses in the international logistics, manufacturing and technical services sectors, Yeh said, noting that his council believes the new incentives will bring in a "considerable" amount of investment which is expected to create numerous job and trade opportunities.

As part of efforts to attract more foreign investment, Yeh further said, the officials also plan to organize at least 13 presentations overseas this year to introduce the investment environment in Taiwan's FTZs.

According to the council's statistics, as of the end of January, there were a total of 93 businesses based in the FTZs, which are situated at the Taipei and Keelung ports in northern Taiwan, the Taichung port in central Taiwan, and the Kaohsiung port in the south, as well as at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
As of the end of 2006, total investment in the FTZs had surpassed NT$9.9 billion, according to statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF TAIWAN STUDENTS LIKE PHYS ED CLASS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A majority of students in Taiwan like physical education class, according to the results of an online survey released Saturday.

The survey was conducted by National Taiwan Normal University between October and November last year on 3,933 elementary school, junior high school, senior high school, vocational high school, college and university students around Taiwan.

The results show that 71.8 percent of elementary school students, 61.8 percent of junior high school students, 58.5 percent of senior high school and vocational high school students, and 50.6 percent of college and university students like physical education class.
Most students have physical education class twice a week for 50 minutes each class, according to the survey.

A total of 32.7 percent of elementary school students, 26.6 percent of junior high school students, 25.6 percent of senior high school and vocational high school students, and 40.4 percent of college and university students believe that two physical education classes per week is sufficient to get an adequate amount of exercise.

However, 34.8 percent of elementary school students, 36 percent of junior high school students, 38.3 percent of senior high school and vocational high school students, and 21.4 percent of college and university students feel that twice a week is not enough, according to the survey.

By gender, 26.2 percent of male students and 35.9 percent of female students believe that two physical education classes per week is sufficient, while 41.9 percent of male students and 25.5 percent of female students believe that twice a week is not enough.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOANS FOR YOUNG BUSINESS STARTERS TO CONTINUE THIS YEAR: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government will continue to cooperate with several domestic banking institutions to provide a total of NT$1.42 billion (US$43.16 million) in business start up loans for young entrepreneurs this year, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Saturday.

Half of the amount will be appropriated from the Sino-American Fund for Economic and Social Development, while the other half will be jointly provided by the Bank of Taiwan, Taiwan Business Bank and Taiwan Cooperative Bank, the officials said.
With the loans, the government aims to help 1,500 young entrepreneurs start their own business and create 5,900 job opportunities this year, they said.
Under a similar program in 2006, 2,078 young entrepreneurs were granted a total of NT$1.72 billion in business start up loans, according to the CEPD.

Among last year's loan recipients, 92.1 percent started up businesses in the service sector, while 7.8 percent set up businesses in the industrial sector, and 0.1 percent set up businesses in the agricultural sector, the CEPD tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The ruling center-left coalition assured that Premier Romano Prodi has a majority support in the parliament. President Giorgio Napolitano is to decide how to deal with Prodi's resignation Saturday after concluding two days of consultations with political leaders a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS GAIN ADMISSION TO FRENCH PREPARATORY SCHOOL

TEXT.P: Six Taiwan senior high school students have recently gained admission to Classes Proparatoires aux Grandes Ecoles, a French preparatory school for the prestigious Les Grandes Ecoles, Ministry of Education (MOE) officials said Saturday.

The students are Lin Chieh-an and Lin Yang-yao from National Taichung First Senior High School, Lin Pin-ting from Chiayi Hsing-Hwa Senior High School, Chen Wei-min from Tainan First Senior High School, Chen Yi-kui from Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School and Hsieh Cheng-ying from Changhua Senior High School, the officials said.
The French Ministry of Education held an examination in Taiwan in late 2006 to select outstanding senior high school students wishing to attend the preparatory school, according to the officials.
They are slated to depart for France in August to attend a French-language study program first, they added.
Their two-year tuition will be funded by the French government, while the MOE will provide them with round-trip plane tickets.
If they gain admission to Les Grandes Ecoles after they finish the preparatory school courses, 90 percent of their tuition will be financed by the French government, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP ALLIANCE MULLING TASK FORCE TO COUNTER DPP TACTICS

TEXT.P: In response to a name change campaign and a new constitution drive rekindled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , the People First Party (PFP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) are considering setting up a task force to tackle the DPP's electioneering offensive, a core PFP aide said Saturday.

According to the aide, the KMT-PFP alliance, established in January, will study ways to fight the DPP's ideological tactics aimed at reinforcing "deep green" voter support in the December legislative elections and the March 2008 presidential polls.

As the KMT-PFP alliance vowed in its founding declaration to play a key stabilizing force in case of contingencies across the Taiwan Strait, the two parties will not sit idly by should the DPP try to rehash ideological issues to fuel confrontation in society and shift public attention away from its corruption scandals, the aide said.

The KMT-PFP alliance's planned task force is expected to focus on observing the cross-strait situation and political developments at home so as to prevent the DPP from scoring political points, the aide said.

In a related development, PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun said a day earlier that the PFP insists that no matter whether former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou or Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng represents the opposition "pan-blue alliance" in the next presidential election, whoever is picked must also be endorsed and jointly fielded by the KMT-PFP alliance.
The KMT, the PFP and the New Party are partners in the loose "pan-blue alliance" against the pro-independence DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Although PFP Chairman James Soong is currently in the United States, Lee said that Soong has been carefully watching political developments in Taiwan but is in no hurry to pledge his support for either Ma or Wang.
Soong will cautiously gauge which of the two he will support despite the fact that Ma seems to enjoy a comfortable lead over Wang, Lee said.

Lee quoted PFP lawmakers as expressing worry that Ma's public approval ratings might continue to drop after he was indicted on corruption charges earlier this month over his alleged mishandling of a special municipal fund allocated for his discretionary use during his eight-year term as mayor of Taipei from 1998 to 2006.

Under the terms of an accord clinched by the KMT and the PFP upon forming their alliance, the two parties must closely cooperate in the coming legislative and presidential elections, which is the reason behind the PFP's insistence that any "pan-blue" candidate hoping to run in the 2008 presidential race must also be approved by the new KMT-PFP alliance.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO BEGIN MEDIATING DPP HOPEFULS AFTER PRIMARY REGISTRATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian might begin mediating presidential hopefuls in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) after the registration deadline for its primary ends March 9, a ranking government official said Saturday.

According to the Executive Yuan official, Chen will mediate to help the DPP field the most "winnable" candidate to run in the March 2008 presidential election during the period from March 9 until late April.
DPP aspirants can register to run in the party's presidential primary from March 5 to March 9, and the party is slated to make public its official presidential candidate May 30.

Should Chen's mediation fail to produce a presidential candidate, the party will then have to resort to its primary mechanism -- a composite of public opinion polls and a direct vote among party members -- to screen a hopeful to run in the presidential race, the official said.

Meanwhile, Premier Su Tseng-chang was expected to announce his participation in the DPP's presidential primary Sunday, following in the footsteps of former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, who made public their intentions to seek the party's nomination Feb. 16 and Feb. 22, respectively.
Vice President Annette Lu is the only one of the DPP's four top heavyweights who had yet to announce her presidential ambition and she continued to refuse to discuss the issue Saturday.

Hsieh, also a former Kaohsiung mayor, called for a "democratic demeanor" in the DPP's mediation process, because "the DPP is a democratic and institutional political party" and because "it is vital to restore public confidence in the party."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MILITARY DEPLOYMENTS FACTOR IN CROSS-STRAIT INSTABILITY: U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/24/07 18:32:11 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government needs to take into account all factors affecting stability across the Taiwan Strait in dealing with cross-strait issues, which include China's military deployments against Taiwan and the lack of high-level political contact between the two sides, a U.S. official said Friday.

Therefore, the United States has encouraged Beijing to make contact with the Taiwan government, said Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs with responsibility for China, Taiwan and Mongolia.

Christensen made the remarks during a Hong Kong TV interview when asked to comment on Beijing's criticism that the United States has failed to take any substantial steps to try to stop the trend toward independence in Taiwan, with the exception of making some strongly worded statements.
Christensen reiterated that the United States does not support Taiwan independence and is opposed to any unilateral action by either Taiwan or China to change the status quo.
While people have often focused their attention on action taken by Taiwan, the United States needs to also take into consideration other factors that cause cross-strait instability, Christensen said.
He said the United States aims to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and hopes Taiwan and China will find a peaceful, mutually acceptable resolution to their differences.

On Taiwan's recent move to change the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China, Christensen noted that the United States has taken a clear and consistent stand on this issue, namely that Washington expects President Chen Shui-bian to honor the commitments he has made publicly, including those made in his 2000 inaugural address.
He said the United States takes Chen's pledges seriously and that the statement released recently by the State Department has addressed the issue in a very appropriate manner.

In the statement issued Feb. 9, the State Department said the United States does not support administrative steps by Taiwan that would appear to change Taiwan's status unilaterally or move toward independence, including changes in terminology for entities administered by the Taiwan authorities.

The State Department also called on Chen to fulfill his "four noes" commitments, namely not to declare independence, not to change Taiwan's national title, not to push for inclusion of sovereignty themes in the Constitution, and not to promote a referendum to change the status quo regarding independence or unification.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO FOLLOW `GREEN DIET'

TEXT.P: In light of a significant increase in the amount of leftovers during the one- week Chinese New Year holiday, the Environment Protection Administration (EPA) urged the public in a news release Saturday to adopt an environmentally friendly "green diet."

Leftovers account for around a quarter of the garbage generated by the average household per day on average, according to the EPA. Based on this calculation, the whole country produces 4,500 tons of leftovers every normal day.
During the Chinese New Year festival -- one of the most important traditional festivals in Chinese society -- extra leftovers are generated, the EPA news release said.
The EPA called for the public to follow its "green diet, " in which followers "cook only the dishes they can finish" and "order only the dishes they can finish when dining out."
They should also "classify" any leftovers, the EPA said.

Taipei County, Taipei City, Taichung City, Changhua County, Yilan County and Taitung County are the best at recycling leftovers, according to the press release, which added that the EPA has invited 16 experts in the field of waste management to visit all 25 cities and counties in the country to examine and review their efforts to recycle kitchen waste and old furniture.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO-ONE COMES FORWARD FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP: PARTY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: No-one within the Kuomintang (KMT) has shown any willingness to run for the party chairman post in a by-election tentatively slated for mid-April or early May, not even acting Chairman Wu Po-hsiung, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said Saturday.
Wu Den-yih made the comments while answering questions from reporters amid speculation that Wu Po-hsiung is almost certain to take part in a planned by- election for the party's top post.
"No-one has come forward and displayed interest in running, and all media reports on the issue are sheer speculation, " Wu Den-yih said.

The KMT is slated to finalize a timetable for the by-election in the next weekly meeting of its decision-making Central Standing Committee Feb. 28, Wu Den-yih said, adding that it might be held in the middle of April or early May.
Meanwhile, KMT lawmakers were mixed in their reaction to media speculation that Honorary Chairman Lien Chan might assume the chairmanship or that Wu Po-hsiung might take part in the by-election.

Wu Po-hsiung, the KMT's first vice chairman, took over the post from former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou earlier this month after Ma was indicted on corruption charges over alleged misuse of a special municipal allowance when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998 to 2006.

Ma offered to resign as KMT chairman following his indictment and immediately announced his bid to participate in the 2008 presidential race, making him a possible opponent of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is also interested in representing the KMT in the presidential race. The KMT is Taiwan's largest opposition party.
KMT Lawmaker Wu Chih-yang, Wu Po-hsiung's son, categorically denied the media rumors that his father is gearing up to run for the party's chair.
Wu Chih-yang said that "the top priority for my father now is building party unity and pushing Ma and Wang to discuss their presidential rivalry."

According to lawmaker Hsu Shu-po, "it would be best" if Lien were to be handed the KMT chairmanship without having to take part in the by-election, and he called for KMT members' support for this idea.
Wu Po-hsiung has yet to make public any intention to run for the KMT chairmanship, and Ma's aides had better not to speculate over the issue, Hsu said.
Lawmaker Wu Yu-shen, a protege of Ma, argued that Lien should have to run in the by-election in accordance with the party's mechanism if he is interested in assuming the KMT chairmanship.
"Whoever wants to become KMT chairman must follow the party's system and get elected through the by-election in line with the party's reform efforts," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUP TO `SEEK TRUTH' THROUGH 228 MEMORIAL EVENT

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Society will hold a memorial event on the eve of the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident with the theme of "restoring the truth of the tragedy, " an official said Saturday.
The Feb. 27 event will take place at Taipei's Machangting Memorial Park -- the site where many victims of the 228 Incident were executed, said Yang Wen-chia, secretary-general of the group.

Noting that both the government and private sectors have held various memorial events to mark the incident annually for many years, Yang claimed that the Taiwan Society will discard the "sentimental tone" in which such events have been held in the past and will take a tough stand this year to seek justice on behalf of the victims' families.

Yang claimed that a documentary film on the 228 Incident produced by the Taipei city government during the term of former Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was an attempt by the former ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to distort the truth.
"This is like rubbing salt into the wounds of the victims' families, which has brought them inexpressible sadness and resentment," Yang said.
Yang said that during the memorial event, his group will try to represent the bloody atmosphere of 60 years ago through dance and audio-video effects.
In addition, President Chen Shui-bian will erect a monument condemning the perpetrators at the scene and lead the participants in performing a ritual symbolizing a crusade for justice, Yang said.
He claimed that the event is "not aimed at stirring up ethnic conflict but upholding justice."

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has accused the late President Chiang Kai-shek of being the key perpetrator of the 228 Incident of 1947, in which thousands of people were massacred by KMT troops suppressing a rebellion against the KMT's iron-fisted rule of Taiwan.

To mark the 60th anniversary of the incident, the DPP has put forth a series of proposals regarding the pursuit of transitional justice, including measures to "eliminate the remnants of authoritarian rule" associated with Chiang, such as removing military guards posted at Chiang's mausoleum, renaming the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall the "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall" and renaming all roads named after Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN UNDECIDED ON PRESIDENTIAL RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, who has announced his bid to compete for the party's nomination for the 2008 presidential election, said Saturday that he has not decided on his choice of running mate.

Yu said he will register for the party's primary for the election and that he hopes to obtain the support of party members to help him win the race, adding that he will make public his choice for running mate at an appropriate time after the primary.
Yu made the remarks during a trip to the southern city of Kaohsiung.
Registration for the DPP's primary is set to be open from March 5-9, with its outcome slated to be announced May 30.
In addition to Yu, former Premier Frank Hsieh has also decided to participate in the primary.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG One dead in Cumbria train crash An 80-year-old woman has been killed and several people seriously injured when an express train derailed in the Lake District and fell down an embankment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOLK SINGER, WRITER, PRODUCER DIES

TEXT.P: Folk singer, writer and producer Ma Chao-chun died at the age of 48 early Saturday after collapsing the previous night.

Doctors at the Cardinal Tien Hospital's Yungho branch in Taipei County said Ma showed no signs of life when he arrived at the hospital. Doctors gave up attempts to resuscitate him after working on him for more than an hour.
He left behind a wife and three children, the youngest of whom is just a month old.
Ma had a history of high blood pressure and experienced difficulty breathing recently and doctors speculated that the talented musician, who was overweight, might have died from heart disease.
Ma made his mark early in life. At the tender age of 19, he became a recording star and a cash cow for recording companies.
He reached his zenith in his 20s, when such famous singers like Teresa Teng, Tracy Huang, Liu Wen-cheng and Fong Fei-fei were keen on cooperating with him and singing his songs.
But the sudden death of his father plunged the talented musician into depression and he began drinking heavily and using marijuana.
He suffered a further blow when the devastating 9-21 earthquake in 1999 destroyed his music studio, leaving him heavily in debt.

After his house in Taichung was auctioned off by the court, he brought his wife and daughters back to Taipei. In dire financial straits, he was left at one point with only NT$500 for the whole family, and had to make the difficult choice of whether to buy lunchboxes for the grownups or baby formula for the toddler daughter. The situation inspired him to write "Formula or Bento," which appears on his new album.
Just when Ma, a devoted Christian in the latter stage of his life, was almost penniless, he began receiving royalties from recording companies.
Ma served as a goodwill ambassador for a "save the jobless family" drive launched by an online human resources bank and convenience store chain earlier this month.
He vowed to help 100,000 people to find employment and expressed a "love affairs with work" in the Year of the Pig.
Ma's wife has decided to hold a memorial service for him, although the time and location had yet to be decided.
Recording companies also said that they will hold a memorial concert for him.
hito Radio, where Ma worked as a DJ, will broadcast a special program in his honor.

New York Times:Canadian Court Limits Detention in Terror Cases

The detention measure, the security certificate system, has been described by government lawyers as an important tool for combating international terrorism and maintaining Canadas domestic security. Six men are now under threat of deportation without an open hearing under the certificates.
Wall Street Journal:States Set Big Spending Plans As Washington Preaches Austerity
Washington may currently be focused on fiscal austerity. But a major spending spree is shaping up in the states, as local legislators abandon a half-decade of fiscal conservatism to pursue bigger budgets.
From New York to Montana to California, states are proposing budget increases that outpace inflation and far exceed the 1% rise in domestic outlays -- outside of defense and homeland security -- that President Bush recently proposed in his fiscal 2008 federal budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ANNOUNCES PRESIDENTIAL BID

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang announced his bid to represent the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the 2008 presidential election Sunday.

Su made the announcement at Fort San Domingo in Tamsui, Taipei County. Choosing the historic site originally built by the Spanish in 1628 and seen by the Taiwanese as a sign of the country's previous foreign rulers, Su said Taiwan's democracy must not step back and that "the owner of Fort San Domingo must not change again."
Su said the people of Taiwan need a leader with "a blueprint for governing the country as well as resolution, willpower and executive ability that can make Taiwan keep advancing."

He said Taiwan needs to break constraints on its international activities, form a united national identity, create new opportunities for economic development, deal with new social problems, promote quality of life, build a mature democratic culture, re-establish the people's trust and seriously address the challenges facing the next generation.

Su claimed that his personal history from a DPP founding member to the party's chairman, from Pingtung county commissioner to legislator, Taipei county commissioner, Presidential Office secretary-general and premier proves him "trustworthy, capable and honest."

Registration for the DPP's presidential primary is set to take place March 5-9. Former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun have declared their bids to compete in the primary, which according to the party leadership might not be held if negotiations convened by President Chen Shui-bian successfully determine the party's candidates for president and vice president.

Su's declaration left Vice President Annette Lu the only one of the four top DPP heavyweights expected to compete for the party's nomination that had not announced her bid, while none of the others had nominated their running mate.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., TAIWAN TIES GROWING STEADILY: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/25/07 14:21:12 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Ties between Taiwan and the United States have been growing steadily despite Washington's criticism of Taiwan, Republic of China Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Saturday.

Lee said that although President George W. Bush criticized the Taiwan leadership in 2003 and then-U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell described Taiwan as a "landmine" in Washington-Beijing relations in 2004, U.S.-Taiwan relations have been growing steadily as U.S. criticism on Taiwan has eased off over the past couple of years.

Lee made the remarks during a speech titled "Current Situation of Taiwan-U.S. Ties, " at an event held in Washington, D.C. to commemorate the Feb. 28 Incident, which has left deep scars on Taiwan's contemporary political history.
He said the Taiwan people must strive to retain a system of freedom and democracy -- values that are identical to those pursued by the U.S.

The system of freedom and democracy -- which allows the Taiwan people to criticize the president and the government -- has above all granted the people of Taiwan the right to choose their future freely, according to Lee.
To defend this right, nevertheless, Taiwan must have the ability to defend itself, he went on.

Compared with China's continuous military build-up, with its military budget growing by double digits annually, Lee said, Taiwan's overall defense budget for 2007 has not even been passed, while a bill governing procurement of weapon systems from the United States has been long-stalled in the legislature.
Lee said he hopes the 2007 overall defense budget and the U.S. weapon procurement bill will be passed by the Legislative Yuan in March as a boost to Taiwan's system of freedom and democracy.
He also called on the Taiwan public of all political persuasions to consolidate for the cause of the nation and to retain their freedom and democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP REMAINS MUM ON PRESIDENTIAL BID

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu remained tightlipped Sunday when asked whether and when she will announce her presidential bid.

Lu was the only one of the four highest-ranking Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweights considered the strongest contenders for the DPP's 2008 presidential ticket not to have announced her presidential bid.
Premier Su Tseng-chang announced his bid earlier in the day following announcements by the other two DPP bigwigs -- former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun.
Lu was asked about her intention of running in the 2008 presidential race during a visit to a Buddhist temple in Keelung, where she offered incense to pray for the country's peace and prosperity.
The "cause" is not due yet, Lu said, adding that she would not talk about politics or elections during the Lunar New Year holiday.
Lu offered her blessings to Su and expressed hope that he will succeed in whatever he pursues.

DOC.HEADLINE: 228 INCIDENT COMMEMORATION EVENT HELD IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/25/07 15:13:11 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwanese groups based in Washington urged the people of Taiwan Saturday to unite to seek transitional justice and a fair society during an event to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident.

The commemoration was organized by the Taiwanese Presbyterian Church of Washington in conjunction with the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the U.S. and other Taiwanese groups in the greater Washington, D.C. area.

A series of activities was included in the commemoration, including a choir performance, a call to worship, keynote speeches and music performances, as well as a minute's silence for the victims of the 228 Incident.

David Tawei Lee, Taiwan's top representative in the U.S., said everyone who loves Taiwan should have better knowledge of the history of the 228 Incident of 1947, saying that people should learn from history to avoid any repetition of the tragedy.

The 228 Incident refers to a series of events in 1947 in which thousands of people, particularly the intelligentsia, were killed by troops of the then- ruling Kuomintang which brutally suppressed a rebellion against the late President Chiang Kai-shek's iron-fisted rule over Taiwan.

Professor Sung Chuan-sheng, who was invited to deliver a speech titled "Taiwanese Self-Help Movement," called on the Taiwanese people to move forward toward democracy and freedom and forsake the historical sorrow.
He claimed that the key problem in Taiwan is not an ethnic problem but a problem of national identity and said the people of Taiwan need to unite to fight for justice in society.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPATS IN U.K. GATHER TO CELEBRATE LUNAR NEW YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/25/07 15:14:29 (By Jennifer Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese expatriates residing in Britain held a gathering in London Saturday to celebrate the Lunar New Year.

The celebration brought together around 100 Taiwanese expatriates, with Taiwan Representative to the United Kingdom Edgar Lin handing out lucky red envelopes and wishing everybody health and happiness, the organizers said.
A series of performances were staged, including a lion dance, a show by the Taipei Folk Dance Theatre and a wide variety of traditional folk performing arts.

This year's event was organized by several groups, including the European Federation of Taiwanese Women's Associations, the Taiwanese Women's Association in the U.K. and the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in England.
A dinner party attended by 157 Taiwanese was hosted later that evening by the London Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMBERS OF TOP INVESTIGATION TASK FORCE TO BE CHOSEN IN MARCH

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming said Sunday that members of a soon-to-be-established special investigation task force are expected to be finalized in early March, paving the way for the group to formally become operational in April.

Chen, who was nominated by President Chen Shui-bian for the top prosecutorial post and confirmed in January by votes from 126 legislators, said he has probed the intentions of several dozen prosecutors who were seeking to be candidates for the special investigation task force.

The operations of the special investigation task force to be established under the State Public Prosecutor-General's Office will be mainly based on the operations of the Anti-Corruption Center under the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office and Chen touted it as a "high-efficiency team" of 40 experts, including eight to 10 prosecutors, a number of prosecutorial affairs officers and a few dozen clerks.

Although the new task force will have the authority to deal with crimes committed by top government officials or their relatives, it will also include top prosecutors with knowledge and experience of dealing with financial and economic crimes, as well as computer and high-technology crimes, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: UP TO CENTRAL BANK WHETHER BEIJING COINS CAN BE SOLD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A decision on whether Beijing-issued Olympic commemorative coins can be sold in Taiwan is for the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) to make, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said Sunday.

Liu said the MAC will respect the decision of the CBC -- the authoritative agency in terms of Taiwan circulation of commemorative coins from foreign lands -- on the matter of whether the coins, issued by Beijing late last year to commemorate the 2008 Olympics, can be sold in Taiwan.
Liu made the remarks in response to front-page ads placed in major daily newspapers in Taiwan Sunday by a coin dealer identified as Oceancoins to promote the coins.

He said that if the CBC decides that the coins can be imported, the ads and the sales drive will be permitted, adding that there are laws and regulations in the country governing the sales of foreign coins in Taiwan and activities regarding the Beijing Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO COLLABORATE WITH KMT IN NEW LEGISLATIVE SESSION: PFP WHIP

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will work closely with its ally, the Kuomintang (KMT), in pushing through major legislation in the new Legislative Yuan session, a PFP legislator in charge of the party's policy said Sunday.

Daniel Hwang, executive director of the PFP Policy Committee, told reporters that a proposed amendment to the Organic Law of the Central Election Commission (CEC) that failed to pass in the last legislative session will continue to be a priority on the legislative agenda when the legislature begins to screen draft bills in early March.

Hwang said the PFP and the KMT will try to have the legislature complete the third reading of the amendment in the new legislative session because the legislation is needed to ensure a fair and just presidential election in 2008.

He added that although the DPP opposed the amendment in the last legislative session, the proposed legislation will get passed easily in the new session as long as Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is determined to enforce the legislative agenda.

The amendment proposed by the KMT would have the CEC's members selected according to the ratio of seats held by each political party in the legislature, instead of being nominated by the premier and appointed by the president as is the case at present.
The KMT has complained that 15 of the 17 members currently serving on the CEC are from the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

On the final day before the last legislative session ended Jan. 19, DPP legislators resorted to physical violence to block the draft amendment from passing on the grounds that the budget bill was more important and should have been reviewed first.
However, opposition legislators refused to make concessions to the DPP lawmakers and insisted on pushing for a vote on the third reading of the amendment.

To prevent the speaker from re-entering the legislative floor after a recess to continue the legislative process, radical DPP lawmakers even locked the main entrance to the legislature with a motorcycle padlock.
The legislative session ended without passing any bills and left the central government without a fiscal budget after the start of the fiscal year for the first time in the nation's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF DESCRIBE ETHNIC PROBLEM AS 'SERIOUS': POLL

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of Taiwanese citizens do not think the identification of the late President Chiang Kai-shek as the prime culprit behind the 228 Incident will harm harmony between ethnic groups, according to the results of a survey released Sunday.

Three days prior to the 60th anniversary of the 1947 tragedy, the Taiwan Thinktank held a news conference to announce the results of its recent poll on public perceptions of the incident and ethnic relations.

The 228 incident refers to an uprising against the corrupt Kuomintang (KMT) regime, and the government's brutal crackdown on Taiwanese people, who had just come under the China-based KMT rule following the end of half a century of Japanese colonization. Thousands of Taiwanese, including many of the nation's intelligentsia, were murdered, leaving a scar on the nation's collective memory that exists to this day.

On the question of whether they agreed that the identification of Chiang as the prime culprit behind the incident could damage relations between the country's ethnic groups, 60.9 percent of the respondents said it would not while 27.9 percent said it would.
"Ethnic groups" in Taiwan generally refer to Hoklo (or Hokkien) , Hakka, Waishengren and indigenous people.

A 600-page research report titled "The 228 Incident: A Record on Responsibility" published by the semi-official 228 Incident Memorial Foundation last year named the former strongman as the person most responsible, raising controversy.

The poll results also said 46.7 percent of the respondents agreed that efforts to clarify truth of the incident so far have been insufficient; 43.8 said that commemorating the incident would harm ethnic harmony, while 47.7 said it would not.
Asked whether the ethnic problem is serious, 47.3 percent said yes while 38.7 said no, the think tank officials added.

Hsu Yung-ming, a political scientist at Academia Sinica, said at the conference that the percentage of people perceiving serious ethnic problems has risen significantly over the past two decades. "The reason is the worsening of political conflicts, and political leaders should properly address this problem," he said.

Chen Chun-kai, a professor of history at the Catholic Fu Jen University, said standing institutions should be set up to investigate the 228 Incident as well as the "White Terror," the KMT's violent purge of so-called "leftists" in the 1950s.
"Only the restoration of truth and clarification of responsibility can really improve ethnic harmony," Chen said.
The telephone poll was conducted Feb. 13-14 and received 936 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: 50 HOTEL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS UNDER WAY TO GREET CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: More than 50 hotel construction projects have been launched throughout Taiwan or are being contemplated by various financial groups in anticipation of a government decision to allow more Chinese tourists to visit the country.

Officials at the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Communication and Transportation said Sunday that most of the construction projects are scheduled for completion within three years, with some hoteliers indicating that they will build a new hotel at a different location in Taiwan each year.
The officials acknowledged that the construction boom has triggered worry among some existing hoteliers that three years from now, Taiwan will be dogged by an oversupply of hotel rooms.

They noted that many conglomerates, including the Uni-President Group, the Shin Kong Group, the Pou Chen Group, the Leofoo Group and the Ambassador Hotel chain, are planning to launch new hotel construction projects.

Taiwan reached an agreement with China last year to launch regular direct cross- Taiwan Strait charter passenger flights for holidays and case-by-case charter passenger and cargo flights, paving the way for the establishment of regular transport links.

The two sides are expected to hold talks on allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, as the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council has indicated that the planned full opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists is an established policy of the government.
China has also urged Taiwan to respond to its proposal to begin consultations on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC TIGHTENS CHECKS ON INBOUND SUSPECTED DISEASE CARRIERS

TEXT.P: The government has stepped up checks at airports and seaports as Taiwan holidaymakers return home from abroad at the end of the Lunar New Year holiday, in a bid to keep contagious diseases at bay, a health official said Sunday.

The Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health has assigned extra manpower at the country's borders to watch for the entry of Taiwan citizens who have made leisure trips to Southeast Asia, China, Hong Kong and Macau and might be carrying contagious diseases.
CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said traditionally, the days after the Lunar New Year holiday sees the annual apex of the risk of disease brought in by inbound passengers.

Shih said the CDC has tried hard to bar the entry of diseases such as avian flu, arboviruses, intestinal and respiratory diseases in general and dengue fever, influenza and bacillary dysentery in particular.

Most recently, Shih said, two Taiwan citizens who had traveled to Thailand for a few days had become infected with bacillary dysentery, while 107 out of 109 reported dengue fever cases in Taiwan last year were picked up on trips to Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, Indonesia and Singapore.
Shih called for returning travelers to fill in forms at the airport or seaport about their symptoms if they develop fever, coughing, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes or jaundice.
People who develop such symptoms in the month after their return from abroad should also report their conditions and disease history to the health authorities, Shih noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS RENDER MILLIONS OF DOLLARS-WORTH OF SERVICES

TEXT.P: A total of 364 teams made up of college student volunteers went to help students in 364 elementary and junior high schools in remote areas around the country during the just-concluded winter vacation, officials from the National Youth Commission under the Executive Yuan said Sunday.
The officials said the teams organized by the commission helped students in remote areas to improve their reading skills and learning ability during the winter vacation.

Ever since its inception in 2004, the officials said, the program, which was set up by the youth commission and the Ministry of Education, has attracted more than 44,000 college students who have provided 880,000 hours of service to 170,000 students in 2,300 elementary and junior high schools.
In dollar value terms, these services would be worth NT$57 million (US$1.72 million) according to the minimum wage of NT$65 per hour set by the Council of Labor Affairs, the officials went on.

Claiming that volunteer services help people foster an unselfish and altruistic character and facilitate the development of a civic society, the officials quoted National Youth Commission Minister Cheng Li-chiun as saying that the commission will expand its program into a "Ten Thousand Youths, Ten Thousand Volunteers" campaign this year by enlisting the help of other government ministries and the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE-YEAR-BOY DEMONSTRATES CALLIGRAPHY SKILLS

TEXT.P: A three-year-old boy took part in a Chinese New Year calligraphy activity Sunday in Taipei, gaining applause from the audience when he completed and added a personal stamp to his work.

The boy, surnamed Lo, was accompanied by his family at the calligraphy event. He wrote two Chinese couplets and his mother said that as Lo's grandmother is a member of a Chinse calligraphy association, he began to practice calligraphy at the age of two and had learned a number of Chinese characters.
She added that the little boy's main recreational activities had been limited to practicing calligraphy and memorizing Tang Dynasty poems instead being allowed to play with toys or games.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OLYMPICS COMMEMORATIVE COINS APPROVED FOR SALE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Beijing Olympics commemorative coins issued by People's Bank of China have been approved for sale in Taiwan, a trade official said Sunday.

Huang Chih-peng, chief of the Foreign Trade Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said his office had given a green light for sale of the coins in Taiwan without bothering to consult the opinion of the Mainland Affairs Council, after deciding that there was no political motives behind the sales.
Huang made the remarks after a coin salesman took out ads in local newspapers touting the coins that day.

As commemorative coins are not actual currency, permits for their sale fall under the authority of the Ministry of Economic Affairs rather than the country's central bank, a financial official pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN RESCUED AFTER BEING TRAPPED ON CLIFF FOR NINE DAYS

TEXT.P: A man was rescued unscathed Sunday after being trapped for nine days on a rock ledge in a mountainous area of Hungye village in Taitung County.
The 49-year-old Chung Fu-chin was hungry but otherwise all right, according to his rescuers from the Taitung fire department.

Chung, who worked as a ranger for local fruit farmers and hunters, said he fell down a precipice Feb. 16 while inspecting shelters belonging to his employers and landed unharmed on a rocky ledge about 30 meters above a ravine from which he was unable to climb either down or up.
Trapped without food or water, Chung said he survived by eating leaves and drinking water dripping down the precipice.

He was boosted by the sound of intense firecrackers from the nearby Hungye village Feb. 17 which was Chinese New Year's Eve, but his hopes of getting through the ordeal faded as the sound of firecrackers became fewer and further between with the passing of New Year's Day.
Chung said he saw a man walking into the ravine Sunday morning and began to blow his whistle loudly to draw his attention.
The man, a photographer trying to capture the natural beauty of the ravine, was surprised to see Chung on the ledge and quickly alerted police in Hungye village.
It took rescuers three hours to drop a rope to Chung from the top of the precipice and help him abseil down into the ravine to safety.
The rescuers said afterward that Chung had almost eaten all the leaves he could reach from his rocky perch.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 26, or the ninth day of the first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: An earthquake rocks Portugal, killing more than 20,000 people.
1791: The Bank of England issues the first-ever pound note.
1802: Victor Marie Hugo, the French writer who wrote such novels as "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" and "Les Miserables" and went into exile after Napoleon III seized power in 1851, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
1901: Chi Hsui and Hsu Cheng-yu, leaders of the "Righteous Harmony Fist" uprising, or the Boxer Rebellion, are publicly beheaded by a court executioner in Peking (Beijing), ending two years of unrest over the presence of foreigners in China.
1906: Angered by an incident in which a French missionary stabbed and injured the magistrate of Nanchang County in Kiangsi Province, Nanchang citizens kill a total of nine English and French missionaries in the county.
1935: Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, a Scottish electronics engineer and inventor, demonstrates for the first time, at Daventry in England, the radar he helped develop.
1936: An army revolt to establish a more nationalistic government fails, but three leading members of the civilian government are killed during the uprising, and Japan's military leaders gain a firm control of the government.
1936: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler opens the first factory for the production of the Volkswagen, literally the "People's Car," in Saxony.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes denies knowledge of a Big Three Agreement authorizing the USSR to remove machinery from Manchuria.
1951: The 22nd Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed, limiting presidents to two four-year terms in office.
1952: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that Britain has developed an atomic bomb and will test it in the Australian desert.
1964: The ROC Air Force receives a number of F-104G jet fighters from the United States under a military aid program.
1970: The Executive Yuan decides to go ahead with construction on the North- South Freeway.
1974: Members of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers arrive for their 1974 conference in Taipei.
1975: The Republic of China and South Africa sign a trade agreement in Taipei.
1976: Spain gives up control of the Spanish Sahara, and the region comes to be called the Western Sahara, which is divided into two parts under the separate control of Morocco and Mauritania, respectively.
1979: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan is formally opened.
1980: The Ministry of Finance approves the opening of Taipei branches by five European banks: Grindlays Bank (Great Britain), the European Asia Bank (West Germany), the Societe Generale (France), the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas (France), and Hollandsche Bank-Unie, N.V. (the Netherlands).
1981: A French super-high-speed train connecting Paris with several cities in France travels at a top speed of 380 kph, a new world record.
1982: An ancient tomb dating back to the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-8 A.D.) is unearthed in Mawangtui, in suburban Changsha City, Hunan Province.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui and El Salvadoran President Alfredo Felix Cristiani Burkard sign a joint communique for closer bilateral cooperation.
1990: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's new president, announces in Moscow that all Soviet troops will leave his country by July, ending 21 years of armed occupation.
1991: Saddam Hussein orders Iraqi troops to retreat from Kuwait and declares a great victory.
1993: Two mainland Chinese basketball teams arrive in Taiwan to play exhibition matches against local teams, marking the first time in four decades that athletes from Taiwan and the mainland will compete in Taiwan.
1995: Communist China and the United States sign an agreement mandating Chinese respect for copyrights, trademarks and patents.
1995: Barings, the London finance house, collapses after suffering losses run up in Singapore by trader Nick Leeson.
2000: ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho holds a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the completion of 49 newly-built brick houses in a village in northern Thailand for Nationalist veterans.
2003: The world's oldest Asian elephant living in captivity Lin Wang dies at the Taipei City Zoo at age 86.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Youth should be respected. How do we know that their future will not be as good as we are now? Only when a man is forty or fifty without having done anything to distinguish himself, does he then cease to command respect."

The head of US Commission on Graduates of Foreign Nursing Schools has advised the head of the Professional Regulation Commission it would be a waste of time to appeal CGFNSs decision on the retake of the June 2006 nursing board exam.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT CHAIRMAN VOWS TO SPARE NO EFFORTS TO WIN PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who was indicted on corruption charges earlier this month, vowed Monday to spare no efforts in trying to win the 2008 presidential race.
Ma said he will go all out for the 2008 race while regarding the country's future as his own responsibility and "not taking personal honor or humiliation into consideration."
Ma made the vow during a KMT gathering of party heavyweights and delegates to mark the beginning of the new year on the lunar calendar.
He called for all members of the general public to strive concertedly to help the country rebound from its lowest ebb in seven years.
"The time has come for the opposition to shake off the shackles of defeat and stand up to turn around the political situation, " he added.

Ma, who resigned from the KMT chairmanship Feb. 13 upon being charged with allegedly lining his pockets during his time as Taipei mayor with NT$11 million (US$332,684) from a special allowance fund set aside for the mayor's discretionary use, declined to answer a reporter's question on whether he would continue with his presidential bid if he were to be found guilty.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Major overhaul of ElderShield scheme.
A Major overhaul of ElderShield, Singapore' s disability insurance scheme, is under way to provide higher payouts and greater options, including more insurers to choose from.
The Lianhe Zaobao: 4 Medisave withdrawals limits liberalised further from May.
The Health Minister Khaw Boon Wan announced yesterday that the four limits of Medisave withdrawals and the ElderShield will be liberalised further from May.
