The Washington Post: Baghdad Plan Has Elusive Targets U.S. Patrols Still Unable to Tell Friend From Foe
The engineer stood aside as Iraqi and American soldiers rifled through his daughter's wardrobe and peered under her bed. He did not mind when they confiscated the second clip for his AK-47, because he knew it could be easily replaced. He demurred when asked about insurgent activity in the neighborhood, afraid to be stamped an informant and driven from his home of 14 years. Face to face with the Baghdad security plan, it seemed to him a bit absurd.

DOC.HEADLINE: 228 FOUNDATION TO 'EXIST FOREVER': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang announced Monday that the non-profit 228 Incident Memorial Foundation, which was inaugurated in 1995 and which is slated to become history in 2010, will "exist forever."

Su said he will see to it that the foundation -- established by the Executive Yuan in April 1995 based on the Compensation and Rehabilitation Act which was signed into law by then President Lee Teng-hui for the 228 Incident of 1947 to deal with compensation and rehabilitation matters for the victims of the incident -- will not become history in 2010 and instead will remain in operation.
Su said that since 2000 when the Democratic Progressive Party came to power, the government has presented certificates to families of the 228 Incident victims to clear the victims' names.

Over the past six years, Su said, the foundation has not only provided compensation to the families of the victims of the incident, it has also consoled them by holding memorial activities, investigating the truth, and paying personal visits to them.

The foundation has compiled a mammoth archive of 16 volumes about the 228 Incident -- which happened due to the mismanagement of the then Taiwan provincial government and cost thousands of people their lives -- so as to provide researchers with accurate accounts for their studies on that period in history, Su added.

The incident severely impeded social harmony and created ethnic cleavage. After the lifting of martial law in 1987, the government, realizing the impact the incident had had upon our society, decided to ameliorate this historic tragedy and to promote integration of all ethnic groups. In 1990, the Executive Yuan set up a task force, inviting scholars and experts to study the incident. The "Report of the February-28 Incident" was then published in 1992. In 1995. the Feb. 28 Memorial Monument was established in the Feb. 28 Peace Park in Taipei City, which has served as a symbol and a cornerstone for a more harmonious society.

Meanwhile, Su said a "228 Peace Fund" will be established soon by the government in the hopes that NT$1.5 billion will be allocated over five years to help finance the sustainable operations of the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 90.75 points to close at 7,900.2.
The bourse opened at 7,939.4 and fluctuated between 7,950.2 and 7,899.55 during trading. A total of 4.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$125.71 billion (US$3.81 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 4.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 2.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 2.1 percent, textile stocks at 2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.4 percent.
Banking and financial shares were the only major stock category that lost ground, dropping 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 848 to 342, with 169 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANNOT TAKE POWER WITHOUT MAJORITY IN LEGISLATURE: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng claimed Monday that it is only possible for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to take power if "pan-blue alliance" candidates in the year-end Legislative Yuan elections win overwhelmingly.

Wang made the remarks while visiting a temple in Banciao City, Taipei County, accompanied by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and several legislators of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party.

Wang claimed to be unconcerned about the problem of how the KMT selects its candidate for the 2008 presidential election, and said he was thinking more about how to assist KMT candidates running for seats in the Legislative Yuan.
The first thing to do is campaign for the "pan-blue" candidates to win legislative seats, said the KMT heavyweight who is widely seen as a potential candidate in the 2008 presidential election.

In reply to media inquiries about Chou's proposal for the KMT to decide its candidates running for the presidency and vice presidency based on the results of party polls, Wang said that a common consensus reached by KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, former Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and himself has paved the way for the integration of the "pan blue alliance" while all three agree that the most important thing is a "pan-blue" legislative victory.
He refused to answer the question of when he will announce his bid for the presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S, DPP'S TRUST INDICES UP

TEXT.P: Trust indices for both President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rose in the latest public opinion poll conducted in February, the Global Views Monthly reported Monday.

In its Taiwan public mood index (TPMI) survey for February, the magazine found that Chen's trust index had risen to 33.7, up 0.7 points from January, while the DPP's "ruling side trust index" had advanced to 34.6, up one point from January.

The monthly attributed the rising trust indices mainly to the president's and the DPP's recent steps aimed at winning back the hearts and souls of pro- independence diehards ahead of the DPP presidential primary, including the removal of references to the late President Chiang Kai-shek from Taiwan and the changing of the names of several state-owned enterprises to add "Taiwan" to their titles.

The trust index for Premier Su Tseng-chang, however, dropped 1.5 points to 52.7 in February, the survey found. Despite the fall, Su remained the most popular figure among the DPP heavyweights and the only DPP official to enjoy a trust index exceeding 50, pollsters of the monthly said.

By comparison, the survey found, the trust index for former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou remained at 54.2, the same as that posted in January. The February survey was conducted before Ma resigned as KMT chairman Feb. 13, the day he was indicted on corruption charges.
The trust index for the main opposition KMT dropped -- down 2.5 points to 46.5 in February, according to the survey results.

The Taiwan public mood index stood at 39.5 in February, the same as that posted in January. That index was composed of a political confidence index, which stood at 43.1, and an economic confidence index, which stood at 35.8, according to the monthly.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S COMMENTS ON 2008 TICKET AIMED AT BOOSTING DPP COHESION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was aiming to strengthen the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) cohesion when he expressed hope that the presidential aspirants who finish first and second in the party primary can form a ticket for the 2008 presidential election, sources at the Presidential Office said Monday.
The primary will consist of two parts, with a DPP member vote accounting for 30 percent of individual candidate's total score and public opinion polls accounting for 70 percent.

The sources were responding to reports by the Liberty Times, a major local newspaper, that the president said a day earlier that he hopes coordination he initiated among the presidential hopefuls will move in line with the opinion poll results, with the two aspirants who place first and second forming a ticket for the presidential election.

Chen reportedly said he will start to listen to views from the presidential hopefuls and the party after registration for the primary starts March 5 to bring about a coordination mechanism that can be accepted by all. He was also reported to have noted that some had suggested that opinion polls should decide the rankings and that the member vote should be scrapped to avoid division.

Former Premier Frank Hsieh, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and Premier Su Tseng-chang have each announced their intentions to join the race to represent the DPP in the election. Vice President Annette Lu is the only DPP heavyweight yet to announce her intentions.
But the president will also respect whatever decision the two hopefuls who finish first and second in the primary make on forming a ticket, the sources said.

Chen said the party has to unify in the March 2008 presidential election and that the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections in December 2006 clearly demonstrated that all the factions in the DPP must unite in order to be victorious, according to the reports by the Liberty Times.

The DPP retained its hold on the Kaohsiung mayorship by a slim margin, despite the fact that a series of scandals surrounding the president's close aides and family members in 2006 seriously dented the party's approval ratings. Although the DPP lost the Taipei mayoral election, it was able to expand its support base in Taiwan's capital, traditionally a stronghold of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
"The DPP's most formidable rival is not the KMT nor former KMT Chairman Ma Ying- jeou, but rather a lack of solidarity within the DPP itself," the report quoted the president as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES `RATIONAL' ELECTIONS IN 2007

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged candidates in the various elections to be held in 2007 Monday to run "rationally and responsibly."
Chen made the appeal at a Lunar New Year gathering at the Presidential Office in which Chen and Vice President Annette Lu extended New Year greetings to their staff.
Noting that 2007 will be an "election year," Chen said he hopes all electoral battles will be gentleman's battles.

More importantly, Chen said it is hoped that all participants will refrain from adopting election campaign ploys designed to hinder approval of the central government's general budget -- which includes funds for arms purchases -- and other proposed bills related with people's livelihoods.

Chen also said the calligraphy characters "Taiwan" printed on the red envelopes he handed out symbolize his great affection for the country and that the government's policy on changing the names of state-owned companies is only a small step toward making Taiwan a "normal" country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING TOP CHOICE FOR SENIOR HIGH MALES IN 2006

TEXT.P: The first college and university choice for male senior high school students in 2006 was electrical engineering, while for girls it was business administration, Ministry of Education officials said Monday.

The officials made the remarks while releasing statistics about the top 50 college and university departments as ranked by graduating high school students in 2006 in order to help this year's high school graduates to make their college selections.

For males in 2006, the second choice was mechanical engineering, followed by information management, computer science and information engineering, while for females, the second choice was information management, followed by finance, account and nursing, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, losing NT$0.019 to close at NT$32.974.
A total of US$909 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.993 and fluctuated between NT$32.870 and NT$33.028.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up 66 points to close at 7,899, with 14,654 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March increased 83 points to finish at 7,933, with 20,596 contracts traded, while June futures gained 82 points to end at 7,912, with 26 contract transactions. September futures moved up 91 points to close at 7,746, with 33 contracts traded, while December futures increased 90 points to finish at 7,752, with six contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,833 for February, 7,850 for March, 7,830 for June, 7,655 for September and 7,662 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

February TE futures increased 4.15 points to close at 334.15, with 2,122 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 4.1 points to finish at 333.9, with 3,057 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down four points to end at 324, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

February TF futures moved down four points to close at 1,040.2, with 1,936 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures decreased 4.2 points to close at 1,045.2, with 2,956 contracts traded. June TF futures decreased 0.8 points to end at 1,049.4, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUGAR CO. ORCHIDS WIN PRIZES IN TOKYO

TEXT.P: Two moth orchid hybrids, named Glory of Taiwan Sugar and Red Pearl, both cultivated by Taiwan Sugar Co., won prizes in the 2007 International Tokyo Orchid Show, a spokesman for the company said Monday.

The spokesman said the Glory of Taiwan Sugar -- a yellow moth orchid that won the first prize in the "other colors" category of the contest -- was supposed to have fewer and smaller flowers, but the company's horticulture techniques made it bloom abundantly this season, bringing it a lot of attention at the show.
The Red Pearl -- a small red orchid which won the bronze prize -- started being exported to Japan in 2006 and has popular, despite a market that traditionally favors white moth orchids.

The company's orchids have won prizes for the second time in International Tokyo Orchid Show, which is a big event in the orchid industry, not only proving the company's techniques in growing orchids but also helping to expand Japan's market for Taiwan orchids, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE INDUSTRY PRODUCTION VALUE SHRINKS IN 2006

TEXT.P: The production value of the textile industry in Taiwan reached NT$457.2 billion (US$13.8 billion) in 2006, representing a decline of 2.6 percent from the previous year, according to statistics released Monday by the Industrial Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) of the Taiwan Textile Research Institute (TTRI).
In terms of foreign trade, textile sector exports amounted to US$11.76 billion in 2006, while imports reached US$2.7 billion, for a trade surplus of US$9.06 billion, the tallies show.

The artificial fiber manufacturing sector generated a production value of NT$151 billion in 2006, registering a year-on-year decrease of 1.7 percent, while the production value of the sector producing yarns and fabrics reached NT$262.7 billion, also with an annual drop of 1.7 percent.

The clothing industry generated a production value of NT$43.5 billion last year, with an annual drop of 10.5 percent. The decline, however, was smaller than the level of 17.7 percent recorded in 2005, the ITIS statistics show.

TTRI analysts said Taiwan's general textile industry is suffering an impact triggered by accelerating changes in the international industrial environment. Enterprises have to be able to act fast in response to the changes, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO DEAL WITH SCRAPPING CHIANG MEMORIAL HALL STEP BY STEP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the government will deal with the issue of scrapping a mausoleum and a memorial hall for the late President Chiang Kai-shek step by step.

The president made the remarks when he attended an international seminar to mark the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident, an uprising against the corrupt Kuomintang administration under Chiang that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was followed by a bloody crackdown, resulting in tens of thousands of civilian deaths. The seminar was sponsored by the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation.

Chen noted that Chiang's mausoleum in Tzuhu, Taoyuan County, is a feudal legacy completely out of tune with a democratic era. Chiang's embalmed body was temporarily placed there when he died in 1975 and is now awaiting reburial in a military cemetery in suburban Taipei.

Chen also said that the existence of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, located in downtown Taipei, is also highly controversial, given the fact that it was built when the line between the KMT and the nation was thin.
When dealing with historic legacies, the government is bound to encounter steep resistance and opposition, Chen said.

"But I'm convinced that justice will be upheld and that the people will make the right choice so as to let the country emerge from the shadow of the past and move toward becoming a normal, complete, beautiful, progressive and great country," he said.
Chen said that "228" symbolizes the suffering of the Taiwan people for over half a century and stands for a total denial of freedom and democracy by an alien, authoritarian regime.

"It was an authoritarian regime's ruthless suppression of basic human rights and was by no means a rebellion caused by misgovernment or conflict between the people and the police as claimed by some," according to Chen.

"If it were that simple, there would not have been martial law that lasted for more than three decades, " he said, referring to the declaration of martial law in the year following the incident that was not lifted until 1987.
To define the 228 Incident as misgovernment or conflicts between the police and the people is an attempt to "paper over" the past authoritarian brutality, Chen said.
He said the past administration saw only the sufferers and victims and never touched on the ones who imposed the suffering or the perpetrators of the brutal suppression.
"Such a passive approach might avoid social conflict for the time being, but will never uphold justice and true forgiveness and reconciliation will never be achieved," he said.
Chen noted that the 99-piece "Tahsi files" relating to the 228 Incident were exchanges between Chiang and Taiwan Garrison Commander Chen Yi and other ranking party, government and military officials.

The exchanges were enough to prove that Chiang was deeply involved in the killings and that "it was an open fact that it was Chiang's decision to send troops to crack down on the uprising," Chen said.

Peng Meng-chi, then the commander of the Kaohsiung Fortress, killed around 2,500 people, which won him notoriety as the "Kaohsiung butcher. " Despite this, Chiang promoted Peng to Taiwan garrison commander, demonstrating his support and endorsement.
"Chiang was undoubtedly the main culprit behind the 228 Incident judging from the related historical documents and government files," Chen said.

However, Chiang continues to enjoy special status like a feudal king and those who imposed suffering during the 228 Incident and the ensuing martial law rule have escaped persecution, which Chen said is "intolerable to the victims and family members of the incident."

The president described his name rectification drive of recent years, including changing the name of the road in front of the Presidential Office to Ketagalan Boulevard, the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to Taiwan Taoyaun International Airport as well as the dismantling of more than 200 Chiang Kai- shek statutes in military barracks -- as the "first step toward addressing history seriously."

DOC.HEADLINE: CASUAL GAMES CREATE MORE ONLINE GAMERS

TEXT.P: Promotion of casual games by the online video game industry has expanded the market by bringing in many who would otherwise be outsiders and changed the composition of the virtual world, according to a recent study.

The Market Intelligence Center (MIC) under the quasi-official Institute for Information Industry (III) conducted research into online video game markets and found that light players, who spend less than an hour per day playing games, make up 36 percent of online gamers and for the first time outnumbered medium and heavy players, the MIC officials said Monday.

Heavy players, who play games for more than four hours a day, constitute 27.5 percent of the market while medium players make up 35.9 percent, the study said, adding that compared to last year's survey, light players have showed an increase in percentage while both of the other two categories showed a relative decline.

Heavier players tend to prefer multiplayer games, strategy games, role-playing games and games with more complex design that require more skill and practice, while light players favor simpler ones, MIC researchers said.

With the game industry now making greater efforts to develop and promote casual games that are simple and suitable for short breaks, many people that were too busy to play games are being drawn into the circle of online video game players, the study said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi to promote welfare reforms.
Italian Premier Romano Prodi is to promote social welfare reforms in his speech to be delivered at the parliament prior to a confidence vote on his administration. The social welfare reforms form a part of a 12-point-programme accord signed by the ruling coalition parties to have him stay on the premiership.

DOC.HEADLINE: `IGNOMINIOUS' MARKINGS OF VICTIMS OF 228 INCIDENT TO BE REMOVED: MOI

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Monday that the ministry has asked for the ignominious descriptions of "mobster" or "thug" to be deleted from the household registration records of the victims of the 228 Incident.

Lee made the remarks in response to complaints by families of the victims of the 228 Incident, an uprising against the corrupt Kuomintang administration that began Feb. 28, 1947 -- barely two years after the end of half a century of Japanese colonial rule -- and a subsequent bloody crackdown that resulted in the death of thousands of civilians.

Lee said in a press release that according to the regulations governing how to deal with the 228 Incident and compensation for the victims, their families can ask for their damaged names to be cleared.

According to household registration operations, the tags of "mobster" or "thug" in household information do not pertain to household registration and household registration offices around the nation should delete all such references.

Lee also asked public and private institutions to fly the national flag at half- mast Wednesday to mark the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident, which has been designated as the nation's Peace Memorial Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES WIDER APPLICATION OF DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will seek during negotiations with China wider applications for cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services to allow foreign nationals to also benefit, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.

Wu made the remarks following a wish expressed by President Chen Shui-bian during a Lunar New Year party with China-based Taiwan businessmen that if negotiations with China over charter flights and the issue of Chinese citizens coming to Taiwan for tourism are successful, foreign nationals traveling to Taiwan from China, Chinese tourists and China-based Taiwanese businessmen should all be allowed to board direct cross-strait charter flights.

Noting that direct cross-strait charter flights are only available to Taiwanese businessmen, their dependents and other Taiwan citizens, including tourists and students, during the Lunar New Year holidays, Tomb Sweeping Festival, Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-Autumn Festival, Wu said the MAC will continue to push for wider availability of the charter flight services to other categories of passengers.
The MAC will also seek to allow cargo to be transported across the strait via direct charter flights, Wu added.

He refused to speculate on when the negotiations will be completed, saying only that the MAC has been "active and enthusiastic" on the matter and expressing hope that the Chinese authorities will act in a similar manner.

Meanwhile, Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei said opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists is a set policy of the government and an expanded cross-strait charter flight program would also be welcomed by both the government and the private sector.

Tsai said he had no idea when Chinese tourists will be allowed to Taiwan or when direct cross-strait charter flight services will be expanded to weekends, but added that March would be the most appropriate time for the programs to kick off.

President George W. Bush willl send a tough message to President Pervez Musharraf warning him that U.S. aid could be cut unless he becomes more aggressive in hunting Al Qaeda leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Bush to Warn Pakistan to Act on Terror
President Bush has decided to send an unusually tough message to one of his most important allies, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, warning him that the newly Democratic Congress could cut aid to his country unless his forces become far more aggressive in hunting down operatives with Al Qaeda, senior administration officials say.
The decision came after the White House concluded that General Musharraf is failing to live up to commitments he made to Mr. Bush during a visit here in September.
Wall Street Journal:Policy Makers At Fed Rethink Inflation's Roots
For decades, a simple rule has governed how the Federal Reserve views the nation's economy: When unemployment falls too low, inflation goes up, and vice versa.
But Fed officials have rethought that notion. They believe it takes a far bigger change in unemployment to affect inflation today than it did 25 years ago. Now, when inflation fluctuates, they are far more likely to blame temporary factors, such as changes in oil prices or rents, than a change in the jobless rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER URGES ESTABLISHMENT OF 'WHITE TERROR' TRUTH COMMISSION

TEXT.P: One incumbent and one former legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called Monday for the establishment of a "white terror" truth investigative commission.
DPP Legislator Shen Fa-huei and former Legislator Duan Yi-kang made the appeal during a press conference as the 6oth anniversary of the 228 Incident draws near.

The incident refers to an uprising against the corrupt Kuomintang administration under the late President Chiang Kai-shek that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was followed by a bloody crackdown that resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of civilians.

The ensuing "White Terror" -- involving the suppression of political dissents and of public discussion of the massacre -- was conducted under martial law declared following the incident; the martial period only ended in 1987.

During the White Terror, around 140,000 Taiwanese were imprisoned or executed for their real or perceived opposition to the Kuomintang government led by Chiang Kai-shek, according to a report by the Executive Yuan. Some prosecuted Taiwanese were labeled by the Kuomintang as "bandit spies", meaning spies for Chinese communists, and punished as such. The "White Terror" left many native Taiwanese with a deep-seated bitterness towards the Kuomintang, Chiang Kai-shek, and sometimes mainlanders.

Shen and Duan said that according to statistics published by a foundation dealing with compensation for the "bandit spy" cases during the martial law years, some 8,488 applications have been filed with the foundation as of Feb. 9.
The number of those who were compensated for totaled 6,341, among whom 58 percent of are of Taiwanese origin and 43 percent are mainlanders.
Judging from the figures, Shen said the gap of Taiwanese and mainlander victims is not significant.
Those responsible for the imposition of suffering were a few led by the late Chiang, although blame was shifted to the mainlanders as a whole.

The duo spoke positively of Wu Nai-teh, a researcher of Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, who is promoting a private version of a "Truth & Reconciliation Commission, " but urged the government to take the lead in forming a "white terror" commission to investigate the truth so as to uphold the "transitional justice" advocated by the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES 50 POLICE MOTORCYCLES TO PHILIPPINES
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/07 21:14:40 (By Emerson T. Lim/ Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to the Philippines donated 50 police motorcycles on behalf of the Republic of China government to the Philippines' Bureau of Fire Protection (BFP) under the Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG) Monday.

Wu Hsin-hsing, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Manila symbolically transferred keys to the motorcycles to the Philippines' DILG Secretary Ronald Puno in the ceremony held at the BFP's headquarter. Puno reciprocated by presenting a "certificate of thanks" to Wu.

The donation is the second extension of fire fighting aid since the Philippines' DILG ex-secretary Angelo Reyes made a verbal request of help from Taiwan in 2004. Taiwan's government made the first donation of two ambulances, fire fighting equipment, and 140 police motorcycles in 2005.
Puno admitted that the BFP is short of money to purchase or maintain equipment, adding that these 50 motorcycles will be distributed to remote townships for fire patrol duties.

Wu said Taiwan's government hopes to help the Philippines in building safer cities. In addition to the donations to the Philippines government, Taiwan also donated more than 100 fire fighting engines to volunteer fire fighters groups in Taiwanese communities in the Philippines over the past decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3G USERS HIT 3.43 MILLION IN 2006

TEXT.P: The number of people using third generation mobile communications (3G) rapidly increased in 2006, up 157.5 percent over 2005 levels to 3.43 million, a spokesman for the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan said Monday.

The spokesman said that the total number of mobile phone users also increased, by 4.9 percent, to 23.25 million. At the same time there were some 101.6 mobile phone numbers for every 100 people in 2006, but even that high number fell short of the historic peak of 110 numbers per 100 users.

The number of users of digital, low-power wireless communications increased 40.2 percent to reach 1.37 million. While users of second generation mobile communications has slumped 7.1 percent to 18.46 million.

Total calling time in 2006 reached 29.9 billion minutes, increasing 3.8 percent from 2005 level. Of that total, the calling time devoted to 3G use increased 146.1 percent, while of 2G decreased 7.9 percent.

The spokesman pointed out that communication fees and prices of communication equipment have continued to fall due to companies' competitive marketing. The 2006 Consumer Price Index of Communication Fees slumped by 3.1 percent, and that of communication equipment decreased 9.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-AFRICA LEADERSHIP MEETING MAY BE HELD IN TAIWAN: MINISTER

TEXT.P: A planned leadership meeting between the Republic of China and its African allies may be held in Taiwan, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Monday but noted that the plan won't be settled before discussions between the two sides.
Huang made the remarks in response to media inquiries on recent news reports saying that President Chen Shui-bian may visit Africa in March for the planned summit.
"So far, the president has no overseas travel plans for March and the planned ROC-Africa summit may be held in Taiwan," Huang said.

Leaders of five African allies -- Burkina Faso, the Republic of Malawi, the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe, the Kingdom of Swaziland, and the Republic of The Gambia -- have all said they would be delighted to come to Taiwan for the meeting, Huang said, adding Taiwan has the proper soft- and hardware facilities to host such an international event, and that his ministry is currently working to come up with a plan for the Taiwan to host the summit.

Asked about a news report that said Saint Lucia -- a Caribbean island-state -- might sever its diplomatic ties with China after the Chinese New Year festival, Huang declined to make a comment, saying only that the ROC will spare no efforts to make new allies in its drive to expand its foreign relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow TimesG'Green' Fears Dog Sochi's 2014 Bid
Persistent environmental concerns and the many facilities waiting to be built -- including skating rinks, bobsled tracks, chairlifts and hotels -- could sink Sochi's bid to host the 2014 Winter Games, despite extensive government support. [By Chang Hung kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST 'TAIWAN' STAMPS TO BE ISSUED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: State-owned Taiwan Post Co., formerly known as Chunghwa Post Co. prior to a recent name change, is slated to publish its first stamps carrying the word "Taiwan " Wednesday -- the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday.
Su made the remarks during a Cabinet meeting after hearing a briefing by Taiwan Post Co. officials on their preparations to launch its first "Taiwan" stamps featuring the 228 Incident Memorial Hall.

Su hailed the Taiwan Post Co.'s efficiency in issuing the stamp and called for public understanding of the government's sincerity when it comes to both facing up to history and expressing its love for the nation.

According to Su, the publication of the stamps carrying "Taiwan" forms a part of the government's effort to acknowledge the suffering of families of the 228 Incident victims and to underscore Taiwan's sovereignty as an independent nation.
Thousands of Taiwan's elite were massacred by Kuomintang government troops in the 1947 incident -- two years before the KMT regime relocated to Taiwan from China.

Taiwan Post Co. was one of the three state-run companies that decided to change their corporate names recently as part of the Democratic Progressive Party administration's name rectification campaign to signify Taiwan's distinct national identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICE SHOULD BE AVAILABLE TO FOREIGNERS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that foreign nationals and Chinese tourists should be given access to direct charter flight services across the Taiwan Strait if Taipei and Beijing finally come to terms on relevant issues.
Chen made the remarks while attending a Lunar New Year gathering at Taipei Grand Hotel of Taiwanese businesspeople operating in Cina, known locally as "taishang."

After years of efforts, Chen said, progress has been made on cross-strait negotiations over the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists as well as the launch of regular cross-strait charter flight services.

"It is hoped that bilateral talks can come to fruition in the near future so that ordinary Chiense people can visit Taiwan to experience diversity, openness and hospitability in local society, " Chen said.

According to Chen, the two sides have reached consensus on technical details regarding the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, including the "group-in, group-out" formula, the daily number of Chinese tourists to be allowed to enter Taiwan, regulations governing travel agencies, delivery of travel documents, travel quality assurance, treatment of overstaying visitors and a mechanism for handling emergencies.
Chen said relevant government agencies will continue negotiations with China on unsettled issues to pave the way for entry of Chinese tourists.

As to the launch of direct charter flights, Chen said significant progress has been made in this regard over the past two years. "I'm convinced that convenient direct cross-strait passenger and cargo flight services will become available on a regular basis in the not too distant future," Chen said.

In addition, Chen said the government has completed an overall review of the "mini three links" services between the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen and Matsu and port cities of Xiamen and Mawei in China's Fujian province. The government will adopt some flexible adjustments to expand availability of relevant services.

The government will also allow for conversion of Chinese currency in small amount on an experimental basis, Chen said, adding that all these measures are aimed at promoting development of cross-strait relations in a constructive direction. "They are our response to the growing force of 'taishang,'" the president added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO DEAL WITH FALLING BIRTH RATE

TEXT.P: The government should take measures early on to deal with likely impacts of the dropping birth rate, according to a report released by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), a local think thank.
The TIER report also called on the public to accept cohabitation and children born out of wedlock, which it claimed could help solve the issue.

According to the statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), the average fertility of women in Taiwan in 2005 was 1.1 babies per woman, the report noted.

The figure was lower than the world average total fertility rate -- 2.7 babies per woman -- and the 1.6 babies average of advanced countries, the report said, adding that the figure was only higher than the current 1.0 babies per woman in Hong Kong.

Following this trend, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) estimated that in 2017, the population of people aged 65-year-old and above will surpass that of people aged 14-year-old and under.
A reduction in the number of children could cut teaching jobs at primary and middle schools, and might decrease the demand for medical services for women and children, the TIER added in the report.

In addition, the falling birth rate could cut the labor force, which will be detrimental to Taiwan's economic growth, the report said, adding that raising labor productivity is thus becoming an important task.
However, it is impossible to lift the labor productivity to a level capable of solving all the negative influences resulted from the declining birth rate, according to the report.

For instance, by 2035, the Germany government will need to raise labor productivity by 15 percent in order to cope with the shrinking, economically active population, the report said. Yet, it will be possible to increase it by only six percent at most, the institute noted.

Citing Japan as a further example, the report said that the measures proposed by the Taiwan government, such as providing subsidies, or maternity leave, might not generate satisfactory results, as they failed in Japan in the early 1990s.
However, the report noted that western or northern European countries are successful in dealing with the slumping birth rate by adopting different family values.
In these countries, women enjoy a high status, and children are independent at early ages, the report said, adding that cohabitation and illegitimate children are more socially accepted.
According to the report, unless people in Taiwan change their family values it will be difficult to boost the fertility of women.

However, the think tank admitted that changing family values is not likely to happen in the foreseeable future. As a result, the government should help those who are willing to have a baby strike a balance between work and family, the report urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER IN NO HURRY TO ANNOUNCE CANDIDACY: AIDES

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a stalwart of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , is in no hurry to announce his presidential candidacy, his aides said over the weekend.

Although Wang is widely seen as a potential contender for the 2008 presidency, his aides said that he has no plans to formally announce his bid at present but might do so around the Lantern Festival -- which falls on March 4 this year.
At that time, Wang will put forward a comprehensive discourse and vision on his philosophy of how to rule the country, his aides said.

December's legislative elections are Wang's top concern for the time being as they are critical to the KMT's chances of victory in the 2008 presidential race and will have ramifications for the party's sustainable development and continued cooperation with the People First Party to maintain a majority in the Legislative Yuan, they said.
In addition, they went on, the KMT's chairman election and the variables surrounding former Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, are also issues of concern to Wang.

Ma stepped down from the party's top post and announced his desire to take part in the next presidential polls after being indicted in the middle of this month on corruption charges over alleged misuse of a special municipal allowance earmarked for his discretionary use during his term as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

These thorny issues must be carefully handled by the new KMT chairman, the aides quoted Wang as saying. Wang contends that it is better to elect a new chairman within the next month, they pointed out.

But Wang remains unchanged regarding his plan to visit China as part of his efforts to make peace cross the Taiwan Strait, despite the fact that the planned trip may be postponed to April from originally scheduled March, the aides said.

Wang also favors the idea of inviting Honorary Chairman Lien Chan to assume the KMT's chairmanship the sooner the better, they said, adding that Wang is not seeking to compete against acting KMT Chairman Wu Po-hsiung for the chairmanship.

Citing the results of several recent polls, Wang's aides said that more than 60 percent of respondents said no indicted candidates should be allowed to pursue the presidency, ahead of 37 percent who are in favor of a recent KMT rule change to give Ma the right to take part in the 2008 presidential election.
Meanwhile, Lien is expected to help mediate between Ma and Wang in seeking the KMT's nomination to represent the party in the next presidential race, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN AIRPORT REPORTS RECORD HIGH PASSENGER NUMBERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, reported a record high number of nearly 90,000 passengers Sunday -- the last day of the Lunar New Year holiday, airport customs officials said Monday.

The figure surpassed the number of travelers reported on the eve of Chinese New Year, which fell on Feb. 17 this year, the officials noted, adding that more than 83,000 visitors entered and left Taiwan on that day.
The new record was twice the average number of passengers each day at the airport, the officials pointed out.
The officials attributed the high rise in the number of passengers to the fact that many Taiwanese people returned home Sunday from trips abroad, while many overseas Chinese visitors left.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 27, or the 10th day of the first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
285: Constantine I, Emperor of Rome known as "Constantine the Great," is born. He adopted the Christian faith and suspended the persecution of Christians.
1782: The British Parliament votes to abandon the American War of Independence.
1844: The Dominican Republic gains its independence from Haiti.
1861: Rudolf Steiner, the Austrian philosopher, educationalist, and founder of anthroposophy, is born.
1879: Constantin Fahlberg, a chemist at Johns Hopkins University, announces the discovery of saccharine, a synthetic sweetener.
1910: Dr. Sun Yat-sen sets up a U.S. headquarters in San Francisco after organizing the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo in 1905 to sponsor an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a proclamation at a "harangue-the-troops" ceremony in Guilin, Guangxi Province, before a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1932: British physicist Sir James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a subatomic particle which is used by scientists to render various elements radioactive.
1933: Japanese troops invade Jehol Province in northeastern China.
1933: Chancellor Adolf Hitler calls for a "God-given signal" that the communists should be crushed, as a mysterious fire guts Berlin's Reichstag, or Parliament.
1942: Japanese forces sink three Allied destroyers and a cruiser in the first phase of the Battle of the Java Sea.
1948: The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seizes power in Prague with communists given all the top jobs in the new Cabinet.
1952: The United Nations convenes its first session in its new permanent headquarters in New York.
1962: Two mutinous Republic of Vietnam Air Force planes bomb the presidential office in Saigon. President Ngo Dinh Diem escapes unscathed.
1973: Governor Yu Kuo-hwa of the Central Bank of China leaves for Saigon to sign a US$5 million loan contract with the Vietnamese government.
1973: Ronald H.C. Ho assumes office as president of the Bank of Taiwan.
1974: Osamu Itagaki, chairman of the Sino-Japan Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for talks on ROC-Japan civil aviation relations.
1975: The ROC and Saudi Arabia sign an air agreement in which Saudi Airlines will offer flight services from Jeddah or Riyadh to Taipei or Kaohsiung and China Airlines will offer flight services from Taipei or Kaohsiung to Jeddah or Riyadh via Hong Kong.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Dennis Theike, commander of Pacific Areas of the U.S. Veterans of Foreign Wars.
1980: Taiwan Power Co. signs a syndicated loan of US$100 million with ten foreign banks to finance development projects.
1981: Beijing strongly protests against the Dutch government's decision to sell two submarines to the ROC, with both sides recalling their respective envoys.
1993: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan succeeds Hau Pei-tsun as premier of the ROC following his confirmation by the Legislative Yuan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian promises to create 100,000 jobs to benefit 100,000 families and one million people if he is elected president on March 18.
2001: Kuomintang Chairman Lian Chan meets with People First Party Chairman James Soong, with the two agreeing to bolster future cooperation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you speak to a man in the strict words of the law, he will probably agree with you; but the important point is that he should so profit by what you say to him as to change his conduct. If you speak to a man in parables, he will probably be pleased with your story; but the important point is that he should apply the moral to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
FORMER IMMIGRATION CLERK, 145 OTHERS INDICTED ON HUMAN TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: A former clerk with the Bureau of Immigration, which was superseded by the National Immigration Agency at the beginning of this year, was indicted Tuesday on charges of colluding with "snakeheads" in smuggling Chinese prostitutes into Taiwan in exchange for cash rewards.

The Taipei Prosecutor's Office charged Lee Juo-ling with corruption and violations of the statute governing civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait on suspicion that she had offered tips to a human trafficking ring to facilitate the entry of Chinese women to work as prostitutes.

Meanwhile, 145 other suspects, including tour operators, the human trafficking ring mastermind, Chinese women and their local bogus marriage partners, were also indicted on charges of fraud and of violating the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

According to the indictment, Lee, a former member of a liaison task force with the Legislative Yuan, was very familiar with the processing procedures for Chinese women's entry permit applications due to her long years of service at the immigration office.

Lee is suspected of having told the human trafficking ring led by Chung Ju-chih to have Chinese women fake pregnancy to get early entry interviews. Moreover, she is accused of having on many occasions asked her immigration colleagues to speed up processing of their entry applications under the false claim that certain lawmakers had requested it.

Under the scheme, the indictment said, 82 Chinese women had managed to enter Taiwan via marriages of convenience, among whom 34 had received direct assistance from Lee. The Chinese women tended to pose as brides of Taiwanese men before turning to prostitution, the indictment said.

For each case, Lee allegedly received between NT$30,000 (US$910) and NT$80,000, and she is believed to have raked in NT$2.04 million in bribes, while the human trafficking ring made about at NT$6.8 million in total.

Lee was fired by the immigration office late last October after she was taken into custody pending investigation. Chung and two other accomplices were also held incommunicado to prevent them from coordinating false stories.

One of Chung's accomplices, Lin Chieh-shan, a tour operator, is accused of having on many occasions asked an independent lawmaker to lobby for the speedy processing by the immigration office of Chinese women's entry applications.

Prosecutors said no individual lawmaker or legislative aide has so far been found to be involved in the case, but they added that separate investigations have begun to determine whether any lawmaker or legislative aide was involved in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ASPIRANTS URGED TO GIVE PRESIDENT ROOM TO MEDIATE

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged all aspirants contending to represent the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the 2008 presidential election to give President Chen Shui-bian room to mediate among them.

Chen is reportedly supposed to begin mediating among DPP presidential hopefuls after the registration deadline for the party's primary for the presidential election ends March 9 to help produce the strongest ticket for the election. The party is scheduled to make public its official presidential candidate May 30.
While urging the DPP presidential aspirants to allow Chen some room for mediation, Su said the hopefuls should also respect the president's opinions and efforts in this regard.

Su said he believes that the president will engage in comprehensive thinking before moving to mediate and will help work out who is the most acceptable candidate with the greatest chance of winning the presidential race.

Su and former premiers Frank Hsieh and Yu Shyi-kun have all announced their bids to represent the ruling DPP in the next election. Local newspapers have speculated that Chen may push for Su and Hsieh to be on the DPP's presidential ticket.

On questions regarding whether a debate among the aspirants or a public opinion poll should be conducted to help the DPP arrive at a consensus regarding the party's ticket in the next election, Su said he remains open to all of these options.

Vice President Annette Lu, another DPP heavyweight, has yet to announce whether she will make a bid to represent the party in the presidential election and has remained tightlipped regarding the issue of Chen's possible mediation or a DPP presidential primary.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER RECUPERATING WELL AFTER KIDNEY REMOVAL SURGERY

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin has been recuperating well since undergoing surgery last week to have a cancerous kidney removed, a National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) source said Tuesday.
Ho is expected to be released from hospital March 2, said Yu Hung-cheng, director of NTUH's Department of Urology.

According to Yu, Ho's doctors found a tiny malignant tumor on his left kidney during a routine health check-up before the Lunar New Year holiday. At the doctors' advice, Ho underwent surgery during the holiday to have the kidney removed.
Yu said Ho will be asked to return to the hospital for post-surgery follow-up examinations.
Ho has also been advised to adhere to a healthy, balanced diet, featuring less intake of salt, fat and high protein, after he returns home for rehabilitation, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK REGISTERS TURNOVER OF US$13.68 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Southern Taiwan Science Park registered business turnover of NT$451.6 billion (US$13.68 billion) for 2006, up 28 percent over the year-earlier figure, the park's director-general, Chen Chun-wei, said Tuesday.

Chen said that the original target for 2006 was NT$500 billion but that the park failed to attain the goal due to market and price factors, although it still recorded robust growth of around NT$100 billion over the previous year's level.
Looking ahead, Chen said that the park has set the goal of NT$520 billion in business turnover and of 52,000 employees for 2007. The park employed 47,371 workers in 2006.
He said that if the market continues to grow steadily, the park's turnover will be even higher in the coming years.
He expressed the hope that the park's annual business turnover will reach NT$1 trillion by 2011, led by the booming optoelectronics, semiconductor, precision machinery and biotechnology sectors.

He said the park had approved 198 manufacturers to invest in the park as of the end of 2006, among which 93 have started mass production. The optoelectronics and integrated circuit sectors are the two dominant sectors in the park, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU RESIDENTS TO BE ALLOWED TO TRAVEL TO CHINA VIA 'MINI LINKS'

TEXT.P: Residents of the offshore county of Penghu are expected to be allowed before the end of March to travel to China via the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Wu said that pushing for the implementation of expanded transport links between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the cities of Xiamen, Quanzhou and Fuzhou in the Chinese province of Fujian -- better known as the "mini links" -- is a set policy of the government and that the MAC has spared no efforts to carry it out.

Wu said residents of Penghu Island -- which is located near the mid-point of the Taiwan Strait -- will be able by the end of March at the latest to travel to China via Kinmen or Matsu after they have applied for the relevant travel documents.
Wu added that relevant regulations are still being crafted and need to be passed by the legislature for formal implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 1.76 points to close at 7,901.96.
The bourse opened at 7,908.79 and fluctuated between 7,939.5 and 7,881.92 during trading. A total of 3.97 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$116.44 billion (US$3.53 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, construction issues at 1.1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, textile stocks at 0.8 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent.
The other two major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares increasing 0.5 percent and cement stocks increasing 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 664 to 514, with 171 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGITAL STUDENT IDS TO BE IN USE FROM MARCH: TAIPEI CITY GOV'T

TEXT.P: Digital student identification cards are being made available to some 374,000 high school, junior high and elementary school students around Taipei City and will be ready for use beginning March 1, the Taipei City Department of Education reported Tuesday.

The digital student IDs -- modified from the Easy Cards that are sold by the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. -- can be used by the students as electronic tickets for Taipei metro systems and city buses, library cards, and as ordinary student IDs. They will carry their owners' names, student numbers and photos, said Han Chang-tze, director of the Education Department's computer office.
Nearly all of Taipei City's high schools, junior high schools and elementary schools have been requested to install electronic card-reading machines to facilitate use of the digital student IDs.
Beginning April 1, Han said, the school will notify the student's parents or legal guardians by text message free of charge should the student not report to school during the day.
However, parents or legal guardians should pay a charge if they want to be notified on regular basis when their children arrive and leave school, according to Han.
There are still 25,000 students from 25 schools that are yet to have their traditional student cards upgraded to digital student IDs, Han added.
