La Repubblica: Trade unions opposes to pension reforms.
Italian trade unions expressed their opposition to a pension reform programme initiated by Premier Romano Prodi. The pension reforms, which form a part of the 12-point accord signed by the ruling coalition parties, are to raise the pension age to 58 beginning from 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER OFFICIAL TO GIVE PRIZE HONORING FREEDOM OF SPEECH
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/07 17:49:48 (By Lillian Lin and Y.C. Jou)

TEXT.P: A former government information officer has established a prize worth US$30,000 annually for individuals whose actions promote freedom of speech.
74-year-old Chang Chao-ying said he and his family set up the "Freedom of Speech Prize" in order to improve Taiwanese people's understanding of this democratic value.

Chang, now living in New York, said the prize money, and an equivalent amount for administration expenditures, have been donated by his American son-in-law Brian Scanlan, a computer software businessman.

The Washington-based, Taiwanese group Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) is cooperating in selecting the prize winner and organizing the awards ceremony, which will be held in Taipei Mar. 4. at FAPA's 25th anniversary event. Scanlan will present to award the prize as Chang, who is receiving chemotherapy for cancer, will not be able to attend.

Chang was an information officer for Taiwan's government in New York between 1967 and 1980, in Tokyo from 1980-1985, and again from 1994-1998. Among his legendary achievements was his acquiring of intelligence shortly before the Carter Administration of the United State announced that it would cut diplomatic relations with Taiwan in December 1978.

Brought up in a millionaire family in Taipei at the turn of Japanese colonization and Kuomintang rule, Chang benefited from broad international experiences that his contemporaries rarely enjoyed, which were featured in his 2006 prize-winning and best-selling dictated autobiography "90-banchi, Miyamae- cho".

Chang said his concerns for Taiwan go beyond party lines. "Taiwanese people have the right to decide their own future, " he said, "while people may be different in their preference for unification or independence, everybody's freedom of speech should be respected."

DOC.HEADLINE: 12-YEAR EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM TO BE IMPLEMENTED IN 2009: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang announced Tuesday that the government has decided to prolong the compulsory educational system from nine years to 12 beginning in 2009.

Su made the announcement while delivering an administrative report at the Legislative Yuan. In the report, Su touted his administration's achievements in the fields of education, social security, transportation, health care, social welfare, and economy.
Explaining the decision, Su said the government regards prolonging the compulsory education as a "must" measure in its drive to strengthen national competitiveness.

He mentioned that it was 1968 when Taiwan adopted the nine-year compulsory educational system. In that year, there were less than 10 countries which had adopted a compulsory educational system of such length.
However, today more than 46 countries have adopted a fundamental educational system of at least 10-years, the premier said.

In preparation for the implementation of the new system, Su said the government will first carry out two projects this year, including offering tuition fee subsidies to private high school and vocational school students who are economically disadvantaged, and subsidizing the operations of high schools with high-quality educational environments.
In 2008, the government will undertake an overall effort to promote a national program to provide learning assistance to elementary and junior high school students, Su noted.

The decision to prolong the compulsory educational system, however, triggered criticism from independent Legislator Lin Ping-kun, who claimed that the government has never shown any signs of wishing to promote a 12-year educational system before it come out with the "sudden" announcement.

Lin criticized the government's apparent lack of regard for working out proper resolutions of problems, such as disputes over school district divisions that are expected to arise following the implementation of the prolonged compulsory educational system, before deciding to implement the new system.
Lin denounced the plan as an election gambit intended to woo voters in the 2008 presidential election.

In response to the criticism, Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng explained the government had taken 10 months to come out with a complete set of programs for the plan to prolong the compulsory educational system. His ministry will convene public hearing on the programs as soon as possible, and will invite all of the relevant individuals, including school administrators, teachers and parents of students to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADJUSTING TREATMENT ACCORDED CHIANG NOT PROVOCATIVE: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the government should consider adjusting the special treatment accorded to the late President Chiang Kai-shek but that the change is by no means aimed at fanning an ethnic row.
Chen made the remarks at the Presidential Office during a meeting with a group of victims' families from the 228 Incident, recently returned from the United States.

Stressing that "now is the time for the government to face up to the truth and hold the culprits accountable 60 years after the tragedy, " Chen said that it is a very serious issue and cannot be dodged.
Thousands of Taiwanese elite were massacred by the KMT government troops during the 228 Incident, in which local people rose against an authoritarian KMT rule in Taiwan.

Although the government has taken some measures to help compensate for damage to the Taiwanese people, including the creation of a 228 Memorial Fund and the publication of a series of reports on the 1947 incident, Chen said that the government should consider adjusting the special treatment accorded Chiang now that solid evidence points to him as the main culprit behind the tragedy.

The government's plan to remove the guards posted at Chiang's mausoleum in Tahsi township in northern Taoyuan county and a planned name change for the Chiang Kai-shek memorial Hall in downtown Taipei were not made with any intention of stoking ethnic disputes, rather, it is a step forward toward clarifying the truth of the incident and doing justice to the suffering of the victims and their families, Chen said.
The president said Monday that the Chiang's mausoleum and the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall should be phased out to purge Taiwan of Chiang's lingering shadow.

Premier Su Tseng-chang said the same day that he supports the president's proposal on renaming the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park so as to observe Taiwan's democratization.
The Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall could serve as a good exhibition venue for the government to mark the country's democratization process, Su said.
Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun asked the Executive Yuan withdraw guards and relevant personnel stationed at Chiang's mausoleum as soon as possible.

Yu also asked former KMT Chairman Ma Yin-jeou, the person most likely to represent the opposition "pan-blue alliance" in the 2008 presidential election, to stop whitewashing the history of the Chiang regime and stop paying respect to Chiang on his death day at his tomb.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC COMPLETES NAME CHANGE ON SHIPYARD GOLIATH CRANE

TEXT.P: The China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) completed repainting its new name, "Taiwan International Shipbuilding Corp.", in Chinese on the huge Goliath crane at the CSBC Kaohsiung shipyard, a CSBC official said Tuesday.

The working crew spent the whole day painting the CSBC's new Chinese name on the Goliath bridge crane, which is a hallmark of the CSBC. The repainting task was not easy as the Goliath crane is 177 meters wide and 87 meters high, and each Chinese character on it covers nine square meters, which is the equivalent of approximately three stories in height.

The official said that the CSBC's name-change plan has been approved by its board directors, and is awaiting final approval by CSBC general investors March 1. That motion is expected to pass smoothly as the Ministry of Economic Affairs holds most of the stocks of the CSBC.
Premier Su will host an unveiling ceremony marking the CSBC's new name March 3 after the plan's final approval, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY UNEMPLOYMENT RATE HITS SIX YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: The unemployment rate stood at 3.79 percent in January, the lowest level recorded for that month in six years, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
There were 403,000 people without jobs in the first month of the year in Taiwan, a decline of 2,000 people from the previous month, the tallies showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TENTATIVELY SETS APRIL 7 FOR PARTY CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has tentatively set April 7 for a by- election to select the party's chairman, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said Tuesday.
Wu said this was in response to a recent call by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who wanted a new party head to be installed as early as possible.

Wang, a former KMT vice chairman, said recently that he has no plans to run for the post of KMT chairman and praised Wu Poh-hsiung, the party's first vice chairman who is serving as acting chairman, as a good candidate for the party's chairmanship.
But Wu Den-yih also said that the date still has to be confirmed by a meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee Wednesday.
He said that if the date passes, the party will proclaim the process for the by- election March 1, after which there be a little time for hopefuls to solicit sufficient endorsements before April 7.

The by-election has been made necessary by Ma Ying-jeou's resignation as party chairman Feb. 13 immediately after he was indicted on corruption charges for his alleged misuse of a special allowance fund put under his discretionary use during his two-term mayoralty between 1998 and 2006. Ma also announced simultaneously his bid for the 2008 presidential election.

Wu noted that a party chairman by-election will cost about NT$20 million (US$606,000), and that some party members have suggested that the by-election be held in tandem with a primary vote to select the party's presidential candidate May 26.

But most party members later concurred that the major task of a party chairman is to coordinate the party's slate of candidates for the year-end legislative election as well as the March 2008 presidential election, so that the date should be set at some point prior to the presidential primary.
Reports said that no one has come forward to express interest in running for the party's head.
Wu Poh-hsiung, though favored by all sides, said recently that he is not considering the matter right now, pointing out that his top priority now is reinforcing party unity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WATER CORP. TO CHANGE ITS CHINESE DESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The board of directors of state-run Taiwan Water Corporation (TWC) decided Tuesday that the company's Chinese name, literally Taiwan Provincial Water Corp., will be changed to Taiwan Water Corp., matching its English designation, said TWC Vice President Chen Fu-tien.

Chen revealed the decision after a board meeting at the company's headquarters in Taichung city, central Taiwan, noting the resolution will be delivered to the Executive Yuan for ratification before beginning name-changing procedures.
Chen said the new name is expected to allow the company to adopt a more appropriate image as a state-operated business.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday, although the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March moved down eight points to close at 7,925, with 32,570 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for April increased seven points to finish at 7,925, with 178 contracts traded, while June futures lost one point to end at 7,920, with seven contract transactions. September futures moved up six points to close at 7,752, with 39 contracts traded, and December futures increased 24 points to finish at 7,780, with one contract transaction.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 7,933 for March, 7,918 for April, 7,921 for June, 7,746 for September and 7,756 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

March TE futures increased 0.75 points to close at 334.65, with 5,661 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 0.2 point to finish at 334, with 28 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up one point to end at 334, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

March TF futures moved down 6.6 points to close at 1,038.6, with 3,368 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures decreased 2.6 points to close at 1,041, with six contracts traded. June TF futures decreased 2.8 points to end at 1,041, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPT. NOT TO REGULATE COPPER LEVELS IN OYSTERS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday that it is not considering regulation of copper levels in oysters in view of the fact that most other countries have not imposed similar limits.

The DOH was responding to a call by the Consumers' Foundation, which urged the government to regulate copper levels in the wake of its random check of 20 samples of oysters in market and finding three samples contained copper levels in excess of 200 ppm.
Cheng Hui-wen, director general of DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, said that the bureau will not contemplate setting up a maximum level for the time being.

Cheng said that copper, which is easily worked out of the body, is generally not considered a health hazard. In addition, copper is one of the metal elements of which all animals require trace amounts.
Cheng said that Taiwan, as well as most other countries in the world, has not regulated every kind of heavy metal, and has only set maximum limits on highly toxic metals such as mercury and lead.

Lin Chieh-liang, director of Clinical Toxic Department of Chang Kung Memorial Hospital, also said that oysters tend to accumulate heavy metals easily, but it is easy for the human body to eliminate copper.
Unless one eats several kilograms of oysters a day, these levels of copper will not affect one's organs, including the liver where many toxins accumulate, Lin added.
But DOH health officials nonetheless reminded consumers to be careful not to choose oysters whose color is green, as this indicates high levels of copper.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.024 to close at NT$32.950.
A total of US$1.14 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.974 and fluctuated between NT$32.922 and NT$32.980.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS PROPOSE LAW REVISION AIMED AT INDICTED CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: A group of ruling party lawmakers proposed Tuesday a law revision which would ban citizens under indictment from pursuing presidential election, a move inexplicitly aimed at former main Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who is widely viewed as a strong contender in the 2008 presidential election.

Democratic Progressive Party lawmakers Cheng Kuo-chung, Chiu Chuang-chin and Chen Ching-teh unveiled the idea and called for widespread legislative support for their proposed amendment in a Legislative Yuan news conference.

According to Chen, it is unbelievable that Ma will pursue the presidency after he was indicted in mid-February by Taipei prosecutors on corruption charges over alleged misuse of a special municipal fund earmarked for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

The Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law currently forbids those who have been given a death sentence, a term of life-long imprisonment, or a jail term of more than 10 years from registering to run in a presidential race.
If Ma still wanted to pursue the presidency, Chen argued, the country may have to choose a president again if Ma were given a sentence of over 10 years after he was elected.

The proposed amendment would ban indicted aspirants, even if not yet convicted in their first trial, from registering to run in presidential polls, Chen said, urging lawmakers from different parties to back the initiative and have the proposal be included on the agenda for the procedural committee.
If the revision were made law, it would be a milestone in the government's efforts to promote clean politics, Chen said.
Now, with presidential hopefuls subject to the strictest public scrutiny, it is necessary to push through the proposed amendment to the law and bolster public confidence, Cheng said.
Echoing Cheng's view, Chiu said that such a revision would reflect the people's high expectations for political integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMODITY PRICE GROWTH SLOWS AS ECONOMY GROWS IN 2006

TEXT.P: Taiwan created an economic growth rate of 4.62 percent in 2006, while the growth of commodity prices was controlled at a moderate scale of 0.6 percent, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The tallies also show that average monthly earnings amounted to NT$44,107 (US$1,335) in 2006, representing a growth of 1.13 percent from the previous year.

Because the salary growth was not offset by the growth of commodity prices, real earnings recorded a year-on-year growth of 0.64 percent last year, a new high for the past five years, DGBAS officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DAMAGE TO TAIWAN SOVEREIGNTY IN CROSS-STRAIT NEGOTIATION: MAC

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan would welcome more Chinese tourists to Taiwan and is looking forward to direct charter flights between Taiwan and China, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has never compromised national sovereignty in bilateral negotiations, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

Wu made the statement to reporters after opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Tseng Tsahn-deng, in an interpellation session earlier that same day, accused the MAC of yielding to China in its efforts to reach agreement on the two matters.
Tseng claimed that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is leaning toward China, even though it "might seem on the surface to be promoting Taiwan independence to gain voter support."
According to Tseng, recent poll results showed that more than 74 percent of the people surveyed believe that Taiwan is an independent sovereignty.

Brushing aside Tseng's allegation that the DPP has failed to safeguard Taiwan's independent sovereignty in cross-strait talks, Wu said that the MAC has never given way to China in bilateral talks regarding the authority of the governments on the two sides of the strait. In contrast, it has always tried to do its utmost to safeguard Taiwan's sovereignty and standing, he added.
According to Wu, indirect passenger flights between Taiwan and China are currently offered on three routes, via Hong Kong, Okinawa or South Korea's Jeju.

Even if domestic carriers fly between Taiwan and China with a transit stop in Hong Kong, they are still designated as "international" routes, Wu explained, rebutting local media claims that they are classified as "domestic" flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE, 228 FOUNDATION TO HOST EXHIBITION FEB. 28

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) and the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation will host an exhibition to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident from Feb. 28 at the newly established National 228 Memorial Museum, an MOE official said Tuesday.

The official said the museum, located at the intersection of Nanhai Road and Chuanchou Street in Taipei City, will open Feb. 28, which marks the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident of 1947. President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the museum's unveiling and opening ceremony.

Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng and the foundation's Board Chairman Chen Chin- huang introduced the exhibition's themes, topics and content at a press conference and the official said the exhibition, planned by the National Museum of History, will include topics such as facing the truth of 228, forgiving, rethinking, breaking and being reborn."
The exhibition is designed to present historical materials, photos and audio recordings relating to the incident, and also to introduce the future vision of the museum, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIANG KAI-SHEK'S DESCENDANTS URGED TO DECIDE ON HIS REMAINS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will work out a plan to handle the remains of the late President Chiang Kai-shek if his descendants refuse to have them interred in a tomb prepared for him by the Ministry of National Defense (MND), Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsang said Tuesday.

The MND will ask Chiang's descendants to decide where they want to inter the remains of Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching-kuo -- who served as president three years after his father died in 1975.

Their remains have been stored separately in temporary mausoleums in Tahsi, Taoyuan County, since their deaths in 1975 and 1988, respectively, and their mausoleums are under the charge of the MND, which assigns a squadron of military honor guards to protect the Chiang Kai-shek mausoleum.

Cheng said Chiang's descendants agreed in 2004 to lay them to rest permanently in a military cemetery in Taipei, but told the authorities in 2005 when the construction of their graveyards was completed that there were different opinions in the family about whether the interring should proceed.

Cheng said that if the remains of the two Chiangs are transferred to the military cemetery, the guards posted at Chiang Kai-shek's mausoleum will be withdrawn and if the family refuses to allow the bodies to be removed, the Executive Yuan will ask the MND to come up with anew plan about the management of the mausoleum.
He made the statement after Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, urged the Executive Yuan Tuesday to remove the military guards.

Citing a statement by President Chen Shui-bian earlier that day that Chiang is responsible for the brutal crushing of a Taiwanese revolt in 1947, Yu argued that there is no reason for the country to pay any respects to the late dictator by allowing an honor guard to protect his mausoleum.
He urged the MND to give up management of the two Chiang mausoleums and turn them over to the Chiang family.

New York Times:Iraqis Reach an Accord on Oil Revenues
The Iraqi cabinet approved a draft of a law on Monday that would set guidelines for nationwide distribution of oil revenues and foreign investment in the immense oil industry. The endorsement reflected a major agreement among the countrys ethnic and sectarian political blocs on one of Iraqs most divisive issues.
The draft law approved by the cabinet allows the central government to distribute oil revenues to the provinces or regions based on population, which could lessen the economic concerns of the rebellious Sunni Arabs, who fear being cut out of Iraqs vast potential oil wealth by the dominant Shiites and Kurds. Most of Iraqs crude oil reserves lie in the Shiite south and Kurdish north.
Wall Street Journal:Famous Name Does Wonders for Career Of Ms. de Villepin
In the modeling world, there are tales of rags to riches -- and then there's the one about Marie de Villepin.
The 20-year-old daughter of French Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin is the new face of French fashion house Givenchy's latest fragrance, "Ange ou Demon" ("Angel or Demon"). And she walked down the runway for Italian brand Krizia at last week's Milan fashion shows.
But the distinctly patrician name that makes her a fashion phenomenon is also her father's Achilles' heel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 28, or the 11th day of the first month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: John Wesley, the British religious leader who founded Methodism in 1738, signs the "deed of declaration" formalizing the establishment of the Wesleyan faith.
1825: Russia and Britain sign a treaty settling the border between Canada and Alaska, then a Russian possession.
1854: U.S. opponents of slavery, meeting at Ripon, Wisconsin, agree to form a new political party. The Republican Party was born later in 1854.
1900: The British Labour Representation Committee, which later would become the Labour Party, is founded with Ramsay MacDonald as its secretary.
1909: Linus Pauling, the American chemist and physicist who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1934 and the Noble Peace Prize in 1962, is born.
1921: Russian sailors of the Baltic Fleet and workers at Kronstadt naval base rise up against the communist government.
1922: Britain declares Egypt's independence, while it retains control of the Suez Canal.
1942: Japanese troops land in Java, Indonesia after the Japanese sink two more Allied ships on the second day of the Battle of Java Sea.
1946: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh and French Ambassador to China Jacques Meyrier sign the "Sino-French Treaty Regarding the Revocation of French Extraterritorial Jurisdiction and Related Privileges in China" in Chungking.
1947: Rioting breaks out in Taipei, following an incident in which an old woman was brutally beaten by police for violating the tobacco monopoly by selling untaxed cigarettes.
1951: The Republic of China Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Dr. Chien Shih-liang as president of National Taiwan University.
1956: Indonesia and India sign a mutual aid treaty.
1967: American editor and publisher Henry Robinson Luce dies at the age of 69. He co-founded Time in 1923 and later founded Fortune in 1930 and Sports Illustrated in 1954.
1973: Forty-four additional members of the ROC Legislative Yuan are sworn in.
1976: Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines announces full and complete amnesty to communist rebels who lay down their weapons.
1992: The ROC and the Philippines sign an official investment guarantee agreement to protect Taiwan businesspeople investing in the Philippines.
1992: The United Nations Security Council approves a peacekeeping force for Cambodia.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui gives an apology to the families of the victims of the Feb. 28 Incident in 1947 during a ceremony at Taipei's New Park, where a monument commemorating the tragedy was built with government sponsorship.
1996: Russia becomes the 39th member of the Council of Europe.
1996: Britain's Princess Diana agrees to divorce her estranged husband Prince Charles.
1997: An earthquake hits western Pakistan, claiming more than 35 lives, while another earthquake in Iran destroys over 20 villages and kills nearly 1,000 people.
2000: The Philippine government urges Taipei to return to the negotiating table to resolve the fresh aviation dispute between the two sides and proposes that the talks be reopened in Manila between March 1-2.
2000: Chen Li-an, former president of the Control Yuan, formally makes known his intention to support Vice President Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang.
2001: Taipei and Shanghai authorities agree to further bolster sisterhood exchanges between the two mucipalities, beginning with a student exchange program.
2004: More than 1 million people held hands together to form a human chain that stretched the length of Taiwan from Hoping Island in the northern tip to Pingtung County near the island's southern tip to demonstrate their love for Taiwan and their desire for peace.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When I find a man agrees with me in what I say without being able to profit by it by changing his conduct, or one who is pleased with my parable without being able to apply the moral to himself -- I can do nothing for such a man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TORCH RELAY MARKING 228 INCIDENT ANNIVERSARY KICKS OFF AT ELUANPI

TEXT.P: A round-the-island torch relay kicked off early Wednesday morning at the Eluanpi lighthouse on the southernmost point of Taiwan to mark the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident.
The flame was lit by Legislator Pan Meng-an of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Wang Hsien-chi, convener of the 908 Taiwan Republic Campaign which organized the torch relay.
The torch will be relayed between runners at 6,000 locations around the island.

At a ceremony marking the beginning of the relay, Pan noted that through the activity, they hope to convey the spirit of democracy, which he said had brought Taiwan out of the shadow of colonial rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA POSES THREAT TO UNITED STATES: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/28/07 14:40:28 (By Lin Chiehyu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: China poses a threat to the United States, and the threat will grow over time due to Beijing's rapid military buildup, a U.S. intelligence officer said Tuesday.

Lt. Gen. Michael Maples, director of U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency, told a U.S. Senate hearing that Beijing began its military modernization in 1999 and that its rapid military buildup will not cease even if the Taiwan problem is resolved because of China's aspirations for great power status.

Maples said the Chinese are developing more capable long-range ballistic missiles with terminally guided maneuverable warheads able to hit U.S. aircraft carriers at sea and targets in the continental United States.

Chinese military modernization has been coupled with its notable success in improving relations with Japan and its active engagement with multilateral organizations, including ASEAN, Maples continued.

However, Maples said he sees a diminished possibility of China engaging in conflict with Taiwan and a low risk of China undergoing a severe financial crisis over the next five years despite its banks' huge amount of bad loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERIES ADMINISTRATION PREPARING TO RELOCATE HEADQUARTERS TO SOUTH

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture is preparing to relocate its headquarters from Taipei to southern Taiwan in line with the government's policy of bolstering fishery development in the country.
Fisheries Administration Director Hsieh Dah-wen said the relocation move will be made upon instructions from the Executive Yuan.
According to Hsieh, the Fisheries Administration already maintains a regional office in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
Premier Su Tseng-chang said while delivering an administrative report at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday that the Fisheries Administration will be moved to southern Taiwan, presumably Kaohsiung.

President Chen Shui-bian also said recently that the country should consider relocating several Cabinet-level agencies, including the Council of Agriculture and the Council of Labor, to the south before talking about relocating the capital city there.
Agriculture and fishery form the backbone of southern Taiwan economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIALS, LAWMAKERS MEET WITH BRITISH COUNTERPARTS IN LONDON
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/28/07 15:54:38 (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A visiting delegation of Taiwan legislators and government officials have met with their British counterparts and exchanged views over the past two days on issues regarding global climate change and renewable energy.

Legislators Lee Chun-yi, Luo Shih-hsiung, Wang Tu-fa, Chen Ming-chen, representing the Legislative Yuan's discipline, economic, and energy and science-technology committees, respectively, as well as Yeh Hui-ching, chairman of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, have paid visits to the United Kingdom's Foreign and Commonwealth Office and the Department of Trade and Industry, marking the first Taiwan official delegation to visit U.K. government offices in 35 years since London switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

At a news conference held at the Taipei Representative Office in the United Kingdom Tuesday, Lee said his delegation has engaged in intensive discussions on climate change and renewable energy issues with the British officials and has suggested to the officials that Taiwan and the United Kingdom can cement bilateral ties via cooperation in voluntary carbon offset transactions.
The delegation has also paid visits to relevant committees under the British House of Commons, Lee said.
Lee further said that Taiwan will take part in a global wind power conference to be hosted by the United Kingdom in September at the earliest.
Taiwan hopes to invite British officials and experts to the country next year for discussions on systems, mechanisms and technologies concerning sustainable renewable energies, Lee added.

During their visit, Lee said, the members of the delegation have asked for the United Kingdom's help to facilitate Taiwan's joining the Kyoto Protocol. Taiwan has continued to be excluded from the Kyoto Protocol -- aimed at reducing carbon dioxide emissions -- as the protocol is an agreement formed under an organization of the United Nations, and statehood is therefore a requirement for participation.

The legislators have also stressed to the British officials that Taiwan's success in reducing carbon dioxide emissions should never be listed under the efforts of China and should instead be recognized as Taiwan's achievement, Lee added.
In response, the British officials have expressed that they "understand" the Taiwan lawmakers' position, but they have not made any promises on the issue, Lee noted.

Lee further said that a draft bill governing renewable energy development has already been screened by the legislature's Economic and Energy Committee, and it is expected to be passed into law before the end of June this year.

Meanwhile, an energy taxation draft bill has already been signed by 134 legislators from across the political spectrum, and its passage into law is only a matter of time, said Legislator Chen Ming-chen, who initiated the bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OPENS 228 MEMORIAL MUSEUM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over the opening of the National 228 Memorial Museum Wednesday and said in his opening address that the museum symbolizes the government's determination to heed the lessons of history and safeguard democracy.
"I hope the museum will eventually become a first-class platform for human rights exchanges in the world," Chen said.

Chen said the turbulent history of the bloody revolt should not be forgotten, distorted or smeared. Now that the National 228 Memorial Museum has been established, the government will accelerate efforts to restore historical truth and facts, he added.

He expressed hope that the museum will not only become a top human rights museum -- which will help champion the causes of peace, freedom, democracy and human rights -- but that it will also contribute to turning the tragic term of the "228 Incident" into a pronoun that stands for hope, forgiveness, reconciliation and consolidation.

Vice President Annette Lu, who also delivered an address at the opening ceremony, pointed out that it has been 60 years since the incident and that relevant developments in finding out the truth and facts surrounding the incident have continued, underlining the government's resolve to give justice to all of the victims of the brutality, and to their families.

Also addressing the ceremony, Premier Su Tseng-chang said the government will continue to strive to collect information and historical archives on the 228 Incident from home and abroad to better facilitate related studies.
Meanwhile, Su said, the Executive Yuan has decided to allocate a budget of NT$1.5 billion over a period of five years to allow the National 228 Memorial Museum to remain in operation.
After the ceremony, the officials joined families of the 228 victims to observe a minute of silence to pay homage to the dead.

A "Division and Rebirth" exhibition commemorating the 60th anniversary of the incident is being staged at the museum, which is remodeled from the building in which the former U.S. News and Culture Center was located.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FLIGHT PASSENGERS MUST CHECK IN 3 HOURS PRIOR: CAA

TEXT.P: From March 1, passengers departing on international flights are advised to check in three hours prior to their departure times to cope with new security measures, the Civil Aeronautic Administration (CAA) said Wednesday.

CAA officials said that from March 1, passengers will be forbidden from carrying containers of more than 100ml of liquid, gel or spray on international flights and that liquids of less than 100ml must be sealed in a see-through plastic bag and checked by security officials before boarding.

The plastic bags -- sized 24 cm x 17 cm -- will be provided by the aviation police and no more than one plastic bag will be allowed per passenger, CAA officials said, adding that the bags are similar to those already being used at international airports in the United States, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Macau.

Denying criticism by some airline companies that the "three hours earlier" requirement is irrational and trouble-causing, CAA officials said the requirement is in line with U.S. air transport security measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLAR CELL PRODUCTION VALUE TO TOP NT$25 BILLION BY 2010: ITRI

TEXT.P: The total production value of Taiwan's solar cell industry is estimated to top NT$20 billion-NT$25 billion (US$ 605 million-US$757 million) by 2010, a four- fold expansion compared with the present value, academic sources said Wednesday.

Officials at the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) said that thanks to a complete upstream-to-downstream production capacity, the solar cell industry has a good opportunity to engage in fast expansion along with the surging global demand for clean, renewable energy.
The current production value of solar cells in Taiwan is about NT$5.6 billion, representing 6 percent of the global market.

Officials said that with the help of government funding -- including NT$16.5 billion in investment over the next five years, a favorable purchase price for solar energy at NT$10 per kilowatt- hour, and a 50 percent subsidy for solar energy equipment, Taiwan's total production capacity will top 280 megawatts by 2010, with an estimated market value of NT$20 billion-NT$25 billion.
Taiwan's global market share will have expanded to 15 percent-20 percent by that time, they predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: KMT SHOULD APOLOGIZE FOR MARTIAL LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should apologize to the nation for its 38 years of martial law rule.

Speaking at a memorial ceremony for the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident at Taipei's 228 Memorial Park, Chen said the incident was not a simple historical event but inseparable from the ensuing nearly four decades of martial law.
All the Taiwanese people suppressed under the authoritarian regime were 228 Incident victims,he said.

On May 20, 1949, then-Taiwan Provincial Garrison Commander Chen Cheng declared martial law on Taiwan at a time when the KMT had lost a bloody civil war to the communists in China. The martial law era lasted until July 15, 1987, when the late President Chiang Ching-kuo ended it.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLARS DISCUSS 228 INCIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/07 17:17:53 (By Chiehyu Lin & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two U.S. scholars said on the eve of the 228 Incident of 1947 that historical evolution has transformed Taiwan into a completely democratic country.

James Mann, a scholar at Johns Hopkins University, and John J. Tkacik Jr., a senior research fellow in Asian studies at the Washington D.C.-headquartered Heritage Foundation, were invited by Taiwan media Tuesday to comment on the tragic incident.
Mann, who has served as the Los Angeles Times Beijing bureau chief, said democracy has developed in completely different directions on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
There has been a flourishing democratic movement in Taiwan since the 228 Incident, which saw the brutal crushing of local people by the then-Kuomintang government, Mann said.

In contrast, he said democratic development in China remains a "mirage" even though the country has managed to achieve a boom in economic development since Beijing's brutal military suppression of democracy advocates during protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

Tkacik said it is understandable that Taiwan's present Democratic Progressive Party government has been working to eliminate all facilities and symbols that mark the image of late President Chiang Kai-shek as a great man, while accusing him of being responsible for the 228 Incident that caused the deaths of thousands of Taiwanese.

He said the movement to eradicate Chiang's memory is a declaration that Taiwan is totally different from the Taiwan of the Chiang regime and described the 228 Incident as a terrible moment in history.
When reviewing history, the government should answer calls for a complete revelation of the truth behind the tragedy, the scholar suggested.

The 228 Incident refers to an uprising against the Chiang-led Kuomintang administration that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was followed by a bloody crackdown that resulted in the death of tens of thousands of civilians.
A so-called "White Terror" ensued, which involved the suppression of political dissent and of public discussion of the massacre.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi: Electoral reform now.
Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi said that reforming the electoral law will be a priority of his administration if he wins the confidence vote at the parliament Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune : Asian markets fall more on concerns over US economy.
Stock markets in China, where a historic 9 percent plunge Tuesday opened a global sell-off, bounced back early Wednesday afternoon. But markets elsewhere in Asia plummeted Wednesday in tandem with markets in New York and Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD ADMIT MISTAKE OVER 228 INCIDENT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should eat humble pie, admit its mistake over the 228 Incident and hand over all relevant archives to the government, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday.
Addressing a plaque-unveiling ceremony for the National 228 Incident Memorial Hall, Su said the families of the victims yearn to learn the historical facts about the tragic event.

Claiming that only a complete revelation of the truth behind the tragedy can comfort the souls of the victims, Su said the KMT should turn over to the government all documents relating to the incident kept at its party history hall.

The 228 Incident refers to uprising against the corrupt KMT administration under the late President Chiang Kai-shek that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was followed by a bloody crackdown resulting in the deaths of tens of thousands of civilians.
The ensuing "White Terror" -- involving the suppression of political dissent and of public discussion of the massacre -- was conducted under martial law declared following the incident.

The 228 Incident remains a sensitive subject for millions of Taiwanese -- particularly the older generation -- and a key source of acrimony between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT-led opposition.

Although former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who is widely seen as the KMT's best bet for victory in the 2008 presidential election, has apologized for the 228 Incident on behalf of his party, Su said he did not feel the party's sincere repentance.

"The KMT is saying one thing while doing another. For one thing, the KMT still refuses to hand over its 228 Incident archives to the government, " Su said, adding that many important documents, including those detailing how the then-KMT Taiwan chapter contacted the KMT government in Nanjing and asked it to send troops to Taiwan to crush the uprising.

Moreover, Su went on, the KMT and its "pan-blue" ally, the People First Party, have continued to block the passage of a bill calling for people who committed atrocities during the 228 Incident to stand trial.
The bill is aimed at amending the Statute for Handling of and Compensation for the 228 Incident, enacted in April 1995. The statute details a series of steps to help the victims and their families.

Dissatisfied with the statute because it focuses mainly on compensation issues, the DPP proposed an amendment that is aimed at determining legal responsibility for the incident and replacing the word "compensation" with "indemnification" as well as enacting a special law entitling 228 Incident victims to seek indemnification from the people who injured them and demand that those people face justice.

DPP lawmakers suggested Tuesday that the amendment bill be put on the legislative agenda for discussion at Friday's plenary session, but the proposal was voted down by the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance, " which controls a slim majority in the legislature.

Su said that if the KMT truly repents its past mistakes as Ma has claimed, it should return its billions of dollars-worth of ill-gotten party assets amassed during its five decades of authoritarian rule of Taiwan to use as compensation to the families of the victims.

President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu and many other govenrment officials and representatives of the families of the 228 Incident victims also attended the ceremony, which also marked the inauguration of an exhibition commemorating the 60th anniversary of the tragic incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FIRM WINS ORDER TO PROVIDE TAIWAN WITH ADVANCED RADIO SYSTEMS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/28/07 18:50:56 (By Lin Chiehyu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Carlsbad, California-based firm has won an order to produce advanced radio systems for the Taiwan government, according to the latest edition of Defense News weekly issued here Tuesday.

ViaSat Inc, which produces satellite and other wireless communication products, won the order from the U.S. Navy's Space and Naval Warfare Systems to provide 70 multifunctional information distribution system (MIDS) terminals for Taiwan's military, according to the magazine.
MIDS is a tactical radio system that provides an electronic overview of the battlefield.
The order is part of Taiwan's Po Sheng C4ISR upgrade program aimed at improving its early warning and air defense radar networks, according to the magazine.

Although the order carries a price of only US$12 million, the weekly quoted ViaSat Vice President Paul Baca as saying that his company sees the contract an excellent entry point for future business in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTLOOK FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT EXECUTIVE JETS PROMISING: CAA

TEXT.P: Thanks to a brisk Chinese economy and anticipated direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, growth in Taiwan's executive air travel market is in sight, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) officials forecast Wednesday.

The officials predicted promising prospects for Taiwan's executive air travel market in view of the fast expansion in Hong Kong and Macau business travel to and from China. The CAA has proposed exploring the market, they added.
The CAA conducted an opinion survey of top 500 local enterprises last year to explore the commercial aviation market potential. A total of 88 valid replies were collected.

Citing the results of the survey, the officials said that two of them expressed full willingness to use special executive jets for their business travel as long as the government gives a green light, while 49 companies said that they would "conditionally" consider the possibility.

Costs were the main consideration when 43 of the 49 companies willing to use special executive jets weighed the issue, the officials said. Twenty six enterprises said that they would think about the issue only when direct cross- strait air travel has been put in place, while 25 said that they would do so when regular commercial flights are not effective enough to cope with demand.

As most Taiwan corporations are small- or medium-sized businesses, only four of the local companies surveyed said that they would consider purchasing a private airplane, according to the poll results.

For international routes, Taipei Songshan Airport was most-often cited by respondents as the best hub for executive jets, followed by Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taoyuan County and Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan. Songshan Airport led its counterparts in Kaohsiung, Taoyuan, Taichung and Tainan in terms of domestic air travel demand.

The CAA hopes to permit Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport to serve special executive jets and private planes plying international routes in its planned first-phase opening.

In the second phase, Songshan Airport and other airports in Hualien, Taichung, Kinmen and Makung that operate international charters will be authorized to serve special executive and private planes on international routes, as well as all other civilian airports, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REBUTS CHINA'S INTERPRETATION OF 228 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) rebutted Wednesday China's interpretation of the 228 Incident, describing it as mere distortion serving only to further disaffect the Taiwanese people from the Beijing communists.

"Having experienced more than 20 years of deepening democracy, the Taiwanese people have gradually established their identification with the nation, their history, culture and values. China and international society should respect that identification, " the MAC said in a news release.

The news release was in response to a statement from a spokesman for China's State Council Taiwan Affairs Office who said earlier in the day that Beijing's stance is that the "228 Uprising was a patriotic movement pursuing democracy and autonomy against the Kuomintang regime's autocratic rule and a part of the Chinese people's struggle for liberation."

The MAC release said the tragedy that took place 60 years ago was a brutal persecution conducted by the government against innocent civilians and members of Taiwan's elite that has left a scar deep on the nation's memory. However, it said, through commemoration of the past, the Taiwanese people have become more able to understand the truth.

It said that while Taiwanese people are broadminded enough to forgive, realization of and reflection on the past are the most important procedures to ensure that such a tragedy never happens again and that Taiwan's democracy keeps advancing and consolidating.

"Eighteen years ago in Beijing there was another massacre conducted by the military against innocent students, and Chinese people will have the same feeling as the 23 million Taiwanese people now have when they probe into the truth in the future, " the news release continued.

"Like the Taiwanese government, the Chinese government has to face the same international human rights criteria, " it said, adding that "fundamental human rights in China will only be manifested when the Chinese government admits its past guilt."

The MAC said China's passage of its so-called Anti-secession Law in 2005, its attempts to unilaterally impose its politics on Taiwan and change the cross- strait status quo using non-peaceful means, and its denial of the fact that two sides of the strait are under different governments are the biggest barriers preventing better development in cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEMANDS TRUTH FROM KMT ON 228 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang demanded Wednesday that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) publish the truth behind the 228 Incident and compensate the families of the victims of the tragedy with money from sale of its assets.

Su issued the demand at a central government-sponsored ceremony at the 228 Memorial Park in downtown Taipei to mark the 60th anniversary of the incident, in which thousands of Taiwan's elite were massacred by KMT government troops controlled by the late President Chiang Kai-shek.

President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun were also present at the ceremony.

Insisting that nothing but the truth will allow reconciliation, Su demanded that former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, the most likely contender of the "pan-blue alliance" in the 2008 presidential election, apologize in public again for the massacre and make the KMT unveil historic facts behind the incident.

Su denied that public demand for digging out the 228 Incident truth is a politically motivated move, describing it instead as a way of serving justice and helping younger generations learn from history. He added that the KMT should compensate the families of the victims with money earned from the sale of its ill-gotten party assets, instead of having the government pay the reparations.
Meanwhile, Ma paid his respects to the 228 Incident victims at a memorial monument at the 228 Memorial Park in Hsinying City in southern Tainan County -- the home of President Chen Shui-bian.

Claiming that he is willing to bear the burden of the KMT's past, Ma said that the historic tragedy can be forgiven but never forgotten and that present-day Taiwan youth must keep this in mind and do their best to prevent any recurrence.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOT SALES OF FIRST POSTAGE STAMP BEARING WORD 'TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: Sales of the first postage stamp bearing the word "Taiwan" were brisk Wednesday at post offices in Taipei City, including a temporary one at the new National 228 Memorial Museum.

Fifty-one post offices were open around Taiwan on 228 Memorial Day -- a national holiday -- to manage sales of the first "Taiwan" postage stamp featuring the National 228 Memorial Museum and carrying the mark of Taiwan Post Co., a state- owned company previously known as Chunghwa Post Co.

The change of name to Taiwan Post from Chunghwa Post is part of the government's drive to change the names of state-run businesses to get rid of Chinese references in their titles and add the word "Taiwan" to make them more identifiable with their country of origin and avoid confusion with similarly named Chinese organizations.

The historic stamp issuance was also made in accordance with the opening of the National 228 Memorial Museum, located in the former United States Information Service Building on Nanhai Road in Taipei.

Stamp collectors waited in long queues in front of the North Gate and Nanhai post offices in Taipei for the post offices to open. It was estimated that over 1,000 people lined up at the North Gate post office to purchase the first "Taiwan" stamp.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Medical backlash over health foods
Two of the most popular products in Britains vast health food industry come under attack today, as scientists cast doubts on the benefits of vitamin supplements and low-fat dairy products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TORCH RELAY ORGANIZER PUBLICIZES DRAFT 'TAIWANESE CONSTITUTION'

TEXT.P: The organizer of a round-the-island torch relay publicized Wednesday a draft "Taiwan Constitution" in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan as part of efforts to promote formal Taiwan independence.

The Taipei-based 908 Taiwan Republic Campaign held a rally at the Kaohsiung railway station to receive the torch, which was lit earlier at the Eluanpi lighthouse on Taiwan's southernmost tip to mark the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident.
At the gathering, campaign convener Wang Hsien-chi explained that the movement was formed to prepare for the establishment of an independent Taiwanese republic.

The organization plans to gather supporters in front of the Presidential Office Sept. 8 when it will formally publicize its proposed constitution, national flag and national anthem for the republic, Wang said, claiming that by then Taiwanese people will be able to announce to the world that Taiwan is independent.
The 228 torch, being relayed between runners at 6,000 locations around the island, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei, northern Taiwan, March 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLIGHTS TO PINTUNG MUST CONTINUE: CAA

TEXT.P: Air carriers must continue providing flights to southern Pingtung county despite the fact that these are money-losing operations, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) officials said Wednesday.

The officials' remarks came amid widespread rumors that Mandarin Airlines is planning to stop plying its Taipei-Taichung route and that carriers offering flights to Pintung county and Hengchun Peninsula in southern Taiwan may also follow the suit.

"Air travel is indispensable for passengers from Pingtung and the many tourists hoping to visit the county's scenic Hengchun area, " a CAA official said, adding "it is necessary that flight services to the southern area be maintained."

To encourage aviation companies to continue their flight services to Pingtung County and Hengchun Peninsula, where the Kending National Park is located, the CAA is working on diversified incentives to help carriers overcome current operating difficulties, the official said.
"Carriers flying to the Pingtung and Hengchun airports have been operating in red," the CAA official admitted.
Trans Asia Airways, the sole carrier operating on the Taipei-Pingtung county route, recorded an average 53.7 percent passenger load for 2006, the official cited CAA statistics as saying.

Mandarin Airlines, Trans Asia Airways and UNI Airways, which provide flights from Taipei to Hengchun, registered an average passenger load that reached only 48 percent of capacity for the whole of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Wall St. Tumble Adds to Worries About Economies
Stock markets around the world plummeted yesterday in a wave of selling set off by a plunge in China that was reinforced by worries of weakening economies. The falling prices continued in early Asian trading today, but by midday the Chinese market seemed to be stabilizing.
While China was the first market to tumble, it was not clear what set off the selling. But once it began, it spread first to other Asian countries, then to Europe and the United States.
Wall Street Journal: Markets' Slide Spotlights Risks
Yesterday's plunge in stock prices around the world, including the steepest percentage decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average in nearly four years, signals that investors may finally be re- evaluating their insatiable appetite for risky investments.
The catalyst was Tuesday's nearly 9% fall in stock prices in Shanghai, one of the hottest and most volatile markets in the world. That helped send U.S. stocks on a roller coaster that ended with the DJIA down 416.02 points, or 3.3%, to 12216.24.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE SAILS BOAT FROM U.S. TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese yachtsman has sailed a boat he purchased in the United States to eastern Taiwan in a four-month, 7,400-km voyage, a coast guard official said Wednesday.
Kao Chi-liang, the owner of the boat and a former journalist, asked for permission three days ago to moor at a port in the eastern county of Taitung due to bad weather, the official noted.
Kao told the official that he had planned to have the boat shipped to Taiwan. However, it was very troublesome and the cost was high, so he decided to sail it back himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANTERN FESTIVAL CELEBRATIONS KICK OFF

TEXT.P: Cities and counties around Taiwan will kick off various activities this week to mark the Lantern Festival, which falls on March 4 this year, a Tourism Bureau official announced Wednesday.
The Taipei city government took the lead Tuesday by lighting up a "lantern tunnel" on Renai Road. Starting from March 3, colorful lanterns will be on display at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
In addition, the city government will give away 60,000 small lanterns to the public at the hall from March 2-4.
Meanwhile, the Taipei county government kicked off celebrations Wednesday by launching the 2007 Pingsi Heavenly Lantern Festival, during which sky lanterns will be released.
The official 2007 Taiwan Lantern Festival, organized by the Tourism Bureau and the Chiayi county government, will take place in the southern county March 3, a bureau official said.

The event, which will feature performances by Japanese and Taiwanese music and dance groups, is expected to attract over 6 million visitors, the official said, adding that a total of 45,000 small lanterns will be distributed from March 3-5 at the event.

The Koahsiung city government will kick off the Kaohsiung Lantern Festival March 3, the official said, adding that the annual event will also help promote the 2009 World Games, which the southern port city will host.
In Taitung, eastern Taiwan, the county government will hold the Blasting Handan parade, during which locals use firecrackers to bombard a man who plays the part of Handan, the god of wealth.

In southern Taiwan, the Tainan county government will hold the Yanshuei Beehive Firecracker Festival, during which the county government will set off a 13-km- long string of firecrackers in an attempt to break a Guinness world record.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE, CHINESE ARTISTS STAGE ART EXHIBITION IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Two young artists from Taiwan and China, respectively, are staging an exhibition of their creations in the central city of Taichung, featuring 50 oil paintings and 70 pottery works, a city government official said Wednesday.
The exhibition will run until March 8, Huang Guo-rong, director-general of the Taichung city government's Cultural Affairs Bureau said at a press conference.
The show marks the first time that Lin Chin-chun, an award-winning painter from China born in 1978, has exhibited in Taiwan, Huang noted.
Chen Ya-ping, a Taiwanese artist born in 1972 who has been working in ceramics since the age of 16, said her works are "a combination of shapes and colors with a classic and luxury touch."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VOWS TO INVESTIGATE MARTIAL LAW ERA ABUSES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the commemoration for the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident marked a beginning of a new era in which emphasis will be placed on investigating the legal responsibility of every perpetrator of abuses in the country's authoritative past.

Addressing the central government's 228 Incident remembrance ceremony held at the 228 Memorial Park, Chen said he never described the incident as an ethnic conflict because many mainlanders were also victimized.
Chen said the incident was not a simple historical event but that it was inseparable from the ensuing four decades of martial law.

All the Taiwanese people suppressed under the authoritarian regime were 228 Incident victims, he said,in this respect most of Taiwanese people are together on the side of the victims and their families, willing to strive for justice.

He said the government will investigate every perpetrator's legal responsibilities so as to clarify the historical truth and achieve justice, adding that such investigations will not be applied to the 228 Incident alone, but also all crimes against human rights committed during the martial law era.

Citing former President Lee Teng-hui's apology while Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman for the 228 Incident, Chen said the KMT should also apologize for its 38 years of martial law rule if the party is sincere in its reflections on history and its belief in the universal value of democracy and human rights.
The KMT should also return to the country, and the people, all the property it stole through the mechanisms of the party-state regime, Chen said.
It is unacceptable that some politician on the one hand apologizes for the 228 Incident, while on the other speeding up the sale and disposal of ill-gotten party assets,he said.

He said the government opposes the actions of the ruling bloc during the authoritative era. The historical fact that members of the bloc were mostly of Waishengrens, people who fled to Taiwan from China during and after the China Civil War and their decedents, does not mean the government is singling out that specific ethnic group.
It is sheer distortion to describe the pursuit for democracy and freedom as the suppression of a particular ethnic group, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG CITY GOVERNMENT COMMEMORATES INFAMOUS 228 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Keelung city government held a memorial service in front of a monument in the northern port city at 2: 28 p.m. Wednesday in commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the infamous 228 Incident.

Acting Mayor Hsu Ching-kun led department heads of the Keelung city government and families of the tragic event in observing a moment of silence in remembrance of all those killed in the incident at the beginning of the memorial service.

The incident refers to uprising against the corrupt Kuomintang administration under the late President Chiang Kai-shek that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was followed by a bloody crackdown resulting in the deaths of tens of thousands of civilians.

Noting that the incident resulted from the previous government's wrongdoing, Hsu said the city government has held a memorial service on Feb. 28 annually in the hopes of heeling the past wounds and remind everybody to work together to avoid recurrence of similar tragedies.

Acknowledging that it's not easy for the families of the 228 Incident victims to forget the trauma of losing their loved ones to political persecution, Hsu said the city government is willing to do every possible effort to help alleviate the historical wounds.

In line with the central government's directive, Hsu said, the Keelung city government will have the national flag fly at half-mast at all municipal institutions from this year. It is hoped that everyone in the country can commemorate the incident with magnanimity and vision to boost social harmony.
Similar memorial services were held in all amjor cities and counties around the country.

In Taipei, Mayor Hau Lung-bin attended a ceremony held at the 228 Memorial Park in the city's downtown district, in which Hau said the incident has not only caused distress and affliction to the victims and their families but has also sowed seeds of discord and animosity between native Taiwanese and Chinese immigrants.

Noting that the lesson of the tragic incident lies in reminding those in power to deal with people humbly rather than oppressively, Hau said the tribulation caused by abuse of political power can be irreparable.
Hau said he is determined to do whatever he can during his tenure to heel historical wounds and mend ethnic division and resentment.
The Kaohsiung city government in southern Taiwan sponsored a special concert in commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident, with Mayor Chen Chu presiding.

In her opening remarks, Chen said the 228 Incident has come to crystallize the beginning of a string of tragedies and abuses that began almost immediately after the KMT troops arrived in Taiwan at the end of World War II.

"These abuses, including the security census and the White Terror that followed the 228 Incident, must never be forgotten if the nation is to avoid repetition of similar tragedies, " Chen said, adding that an indispensable part of the process is the release of all information from official investigations to let the facts be known.
"True forgiveness is only possible with justice and understanding, and understanding must be built on facts and the courage to face up to them and the consequences of their release, " Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS SING TO REMEMBER 228

TEXT.P: Thousands sang in chorus Wednesday afternoon at the heart of Taipei to remember the 228 Incident of 1947, with President Chen Shui-bian, former President Lee Teng-hui and several otherPan-Greencamp political heavyweights present at the rally.

The event was held by the Hand-in-Hand to Safeguard Taiwan Alliance and 228 Incident Memorial Foundation on the Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, and opened with an orchestra's performance of the1947 Overture, a work of composer Hsiao Tyzen.
Addressing the audience, Lee Teng-hui said Taiwan should draw up a new Constitution, change the country's official name and become a normal country.
Lee said he was a witness and "mental victim" of the 228 Incident, which erupted at the time he was a Taiwan University senior in agricultural economics.
Sixty years on, I still cannot forget the Taiwanese people's passion to follow their ideals, and the horrible sight of the Kuomintang slaughtering Taiwanese people,he said.

He recited his achievements in curing the wounds caused by the tragedy during his presidential terms, including setting up a cabinet level research team to publish an investigative report, meeting with victims' families, and extending an apology in the name of the state to people who suffered.
President Chen arrived at the event after Lee left and did not deliver a speech. He sang the songTaiwantogether with the crowd.

Ng Chiau-tong, convener of the Hand-in-Hand to Safeguard Taiwan Alliance, said the 1947 incident happened because Taiwanese people at that time mistook China as the fatherland, andwe should never again make the same mistake.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL CONCERT TO MARK 60TH ANNIVERSARY OF INFAMOUS 228 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: A special concert was held at the Chungshan Soccer Stadium in Taipei Wednesday to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the infamous 228 Incident.
Music bands from Taiwan, China, Britain, the United States and the Czech Republic performed in the concert as part of a "With Justice We Cure the Nation" campaign.

The special concert attracted more than 10,000 audiences, including many influential political figures from both ruling and opposition camps, including Premier Su Tseng-chang, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, former President Lee Teng-hui, former Premier Frank Hsieh, former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.

Organizers said the concert was designed to enlist support for the "With Justice We Cure the Nation" campaign aimed at pursuing transitional justice to get rid of negative legacies from the previous period of authoritarian rule. The concert climaxed at the signing of the declaration on the "Justice" campaign by political bigwigs.

Except Ma, all other aspirants for the 2008 presidential election signed the declaration to signify their support for all feasible approaches to heel historical wounds from previous political persecution and human rights abuses, including the 228 Incident.

President Chen Shui-bian signed the declaration before the beginning of the concert. A video featuring his signing of the declaration at the his office was shown at the concert. In the video, Chen said he takes pleasure in signing the declaration and seeing progress in the transitional justice campaign. He also called for an end to ethnic animosity and confrontation.

Transitional justice refers to a range of approaches that societies undertake to reckon with legacies of widespread or systematic human rights abuse as they move from a period of violent conflict or oppression towards peace, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for individual and collective rights.

In making such a transition, societies must confront the painful legacy, or burden, of the past in order to achieve a holistic sense of justice for all citizens, to establish or renew civic trust, to reconcile people and communities, and to prevent future abuses. A variety of approaches to transitional justice are available that can help wounded societies start anew.
These approaches are both judicial and nonjudicial, and they seek to encompass broadly the various dimensions of justice that can heal wounds and contribute to social reconstruction.

Transitional justice incorporates a realistic view of the challenges faced by societies emerging from conflict or repression, and an appreciation of their unique cultural and historical contexts, without allowing these realities to serve as excuses for inaction. All stakeholders in the transition process must be consulted and participate in the design and implementation of transitional justice policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 1 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, March 1
09:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend the changeover ceremony for chairman of the Chungcheng Cultural Center that comprises the National Concert Hall and the National Theater.
09:35, President Chen Shui-bian will make a grassroots outreach tour of farmland in central Taichung County's Wutai township to get a first-hand look into spring plantation in rural areas.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference.
12:30, The National Science Council will hold a news conference on progress in upgrading yield rate of semiconductor production.
16:00, Legislative caucuses of ruling and opposition parties will hold a consultative session to seek consensus on certain controversial bills.
16:30, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference.
